Anglo-Cherokee War: Cherokee warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Echoee near present-day Otto, North Carolina.
British forces defeat French forces in the last naval battle in New France.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Liegnitz: Frederick the Great's victory over the Austrians under Ernst Gideon von Laudon.
French and Indian War: French surrender Montreal to the British, completing the latter's conquest of New France.
Seven Years' War: Russian and Austrian troops briefly occupy Berlin.
In a treaty with the Dutch colonial authorities, the Ndyuka people of Suriname – descended from escaped slaves – gain territorial autonomy.
King George III succeeds to the British throne on the death of his grandfather George II.
The secondly-built Castellania in Valletta is officially inaugurated with the blessing of the interior Chapel of Sorrows.
The rebuilt debtors' prison, at the Castellania in Valletta, receives the first prisoners.
The Third Battle of Panipat, the largest battle of the 18th century, is fought in India between the Afghan Durrani Empire under Ahmad Shah Durrani, and the Maratha Empire under Sadashivrao Bhau.
source_pages: Third_Battle_of_Panipat; January_14; India; Afghanistan; Durrani_Empire; Ahmad_Shah_Durrani; Maratha_Empire; Sadashivrao_Bhau

event_text: The 1761 Lisbon earthquake strikes off the Iberian Peninsula with an estimated magnitude of 8.5, six years after another quake destroyed the city.
Exhibition of 1761, the inaugural exhibition of the Society of Artists of Great Britain opens at Spring Gardens in London.
Marriage of King George III of the United Kingdom to Duchess Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz.
George III and Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz are crowned King and Queen, respectively, of the Kingdom of Great Britain.
Seven Years' War: After a four-month siege, the Russians under Pyotr Rumyantsev take the Prussian fortress of Kołobrzeg.
Great Britain declares war on Spain, which meant the entry of Spain into the Seven Years' War.

French Huguenot Jean Calas, who had been wrongly convicted of killing his son, dies after being tortured by authorities; the event inspired Voltaire to begin a campaign for religious tolerance and legal reform.
Russia and Prussia sign the Treaty of St. Petersburg.
Sweden and Prussia sign the Treaty of Hamburg.
Trevi Fountain is officially completed and inaugurated in Rome.
Seven Years' War: British forces begin the Siege of Havana and temporarily capture the city.
Battle of Wilhelmsthal: The British-Hanoverian army of Ferdinand of Brunswick defeats French forces in Westphalia.
Catherine the Great becomes Empress of Russia following the coup against her husband, Peter III.
Former emperor Peter III of Russia is murdered.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Signal Hill.
Seven Years' War: The British capture Manila from Spain and occupy it.
French and Indian War: The Treaty of Paris ends the war and France cedes Quebec to Great Britain.
Berbice slave uprising in Guyana: The first major slave revolt in South America.
Pontiac's War begins with Pontiac's attempt to seize Fort Detroit from the British.
First issue of Norske Intelligenz-Seddeler, the first regular Norwegian newspaper (1763–1920).
Pontiac's Rebellion: At what is now Mackinaw City, Michigan, Chippewas capture Fort Michilimackinac by diverting the garrison's attention with a game of lacrosse, then chasing a ball into the fort.
source_pages: Pontiac's_War; Mackinaw_City,_Michigan; Ojibwe; Fort_Michilimackinac; Lacrosse; June_2

event_text: The Mozart family grand tour of Europe begins, lifting the profile of son Wolfgang Amadeus.
Odawa Chief Pontiac's forces defeat British troops at the Battle of Bloody Run during Pontiac's War.
Pontiac's War: Battle of Bushy Run: British forces led by Henry Bouquet defeat Chief Pontiac's Indians at Bushy Run.
Catherine II of Russia endorses Ivan Betskoy's plans for a Foundling Home in Moscow.
Seneca warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Devil's Hole during Pontiac's War.
King George III issues the Royal Proclamation of 1763, closing Indigenous lands in North America north and west of the Alleghenies to white settlements.
Dedication of the Touro Synagogue, in Newport, Rhode Island, the first synagogue in what will become the United States.
John Wilkes is expelled from the British House of Commons for seditious libel.
Bolle Willum Luxdorph records in his diary that a mail bomb, possibly the world's first, has severely injured the Danish Colonel Poulsen, residing at Børglum Abbey.
The city of St. Louis is established in Spanish Louisiana (now in Missouri, USA).
One of the strongest tornadoes in history strikes Woldegk, Germany, killing one person while leveling numerous mansions with winds estimated greater than 300 miles per hour (480 km/h).
Election of Stanisław August Poniatowski as the last ruler of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
A British naval expedition arrives at and names Port Egmont in the Falkland Islands, founding a settlement there eight days later. (Arrival was 15 January 1765 O.S.)

After a campaign by the writer Voltaire, judges in Paris posthumously exonerate Jean Calas of murdering his son. Calas had been tortured and executed in 1762 on the charge, though his son may have actually died by suicide.
The British Parliament passes the Stamp Act that introduces a tax to be levied directly on its American colonies.
Great Britain passes the Quartering Act, which requires the Thirteen Colonies to house British troops.
HMS Victory is launched at Chatham Dockyard, Kent. She is not commissioned until 1778.
Treaty of Allahabad is signed. The Treaty marks the political and constitutional involvement and the beginning of Company rule in India.
The British Parliament enacts the Stamp Act on the Thirteen Colonies in order to help pay for British military operations in North America.
Antonio de Ulloa, the first Spanish governor of Louisiana, arrives in New Orleans.
American Revolution: The British Parliament repeals the Stamp Act.
A large earthquake causes heavy damage and loss of life in Istanbul and the Marmara region.

François-Jean de la Barre, a young French nobleman, is tortured and beheaded before his body is burnt on a pyre along with a copy of Voltaire's Dictionnaire philosophique nailed to his torso for the crime of not saluting a Roman Catholic religious procession in Abbeville, France.
source_pages: François-Jean_de_la_Barre; Pyre; Voltaire; Dictionnaire_philosophique; Catholic_Church; Abbeville

event_text: The Nottingham Cheese Riot breaks out at the Goose Fair in Nottingham, UK, in response to the excessive cost of cheese.
The last colonial governor of New Jersey, William Franklin, signs the charter of Queen's College (later renamed Rutgers University).
Swedish parliament approves the Swedish Freedom of the Press Act and implements it as a ground law, thus being first in the world with freedom of speech.
In London, auctioneer James Christie holds his first sale.
Mapuches in Chile launch a series of surprise attacks against the Spanish starting the Mapuche uprising of 1766.
End of Burmese–Siamese War (1765–1767).
Samuel Wallis, a British sea captain, sights Tahiti and is considered the first European to reach the island.
Pitcairn Island is discovered by Midshipman Robert Pitcairn on an expeditionary voyage commanded by Philip Carteret.
Norway's oldest newspaper still in print, Adresseavisen, is founded and the first edition is published.
Jesuits all over Chile are arrested as the Spanish Empire suppresses the Society of Jesus.
Rioting occurs in London after John Wilkes is imprisoned for writing an article for The North Briton severely criticizing King George III.
James Otis Jr. offends the King and Parliament in a speech to the Massachusetts General Court.
Captain James Cook sets sail from England on board HMS Endeavour.
Unification of Nepal

The Treaty of Fort Stanwix is signed, the purpose of which is to adjust the boundary line between Indian lands and white settlements set forth in the Royal Proclamation of 1763 in the Thirteen Colonies.
The former slave ship Fredensborg sinks off Tromøya in Norway.
The first edition of the Encyclopædia Britannica is published.
King Taksin's coronation achieved through conquest as a king of Thailand and established Thonburi as a capital.
Mozart departed Italy after the last of his three tours there.
An expedition led by Gaspar de Portolá leaves its base in San Diego and sets out to find the Port of Monterey (now Monterey, California).
Father Junípero Serra founds California's first mission, Mission San Diego de Alcalá. Over the following decades, it evolves into the city of San Diego, California.
Dartmouth College is founded by the Reverend Eleazar Wheelock, with a royal charter from King George III, on land donated by Royal governor John Wentworth.
source_pages: Dartmouth_College; Eleazar_Wheelock; Royal_charter; George_III; Governor-general; Sir_John_Wentworth,_1st_Baronet; December_13

event_text: Sino-Burmese War: The war ends with the Qing dynasty withdrawing from Burma forever.

British customs officer Ebenezer Richardson fires blindly into a crowd during a protest in North End, Boston, fatally wounding 11-year-old Christopher Seider; the first American fatality of the American Revolution.

Boston Massacre: Five Americans, including Crispus Attucks, are fatally shot by British troops in an event that would contribute to the outbreak of the American Revolutionary War (also known as the American War of Independence) five years later.
Daskalogiannis leads the people of Sfakia in the first Greek uprising against the Ottoman rule
Captain James Cook, still holding the rank of lieutenant, sights the eastern coast of what is now Australia.
Marie Antoinette marries Louis XVI in a proxy wedding.
The Georgian king, Erekle II, abandoned by his Russian ally Count Totleben, wins a victory over Ottoman forces at Aspindza.
source_pages: Georgia_(country); Heraclius_II_of_Georgia; Russian_Empire; Gottlob_Heinrich_Curt_von_Tottleben; Ottoman_Empire; Battle_of_Aspindza

event_text: James Cook arrives in Australia at Botany Bay, which he names.
The 14-year-old Marie Antoinette marries 15-year-old Louis-Auguste, who later becomes king of France.
British explorer Captain James Cook runs aground on the Great Barrier Reef.
Lexell's Comet is seen closer to the Earth than any other comet in recorded history, approaching to a distance of 0.0146 astronomical units (2,180,000 km; 1,360,000 mi).
The Battle of Chesma between the Russian Empire and the Ottoman Empire begins.
The Battle of Larga between the Russian Empire and the Ottoman Empire takes place.
James Cook formally claims eastern Australia for Great Britain, naming it New South Wales.
James Cook names and lands on Possession Island, and claims the east coast of Australia for Britain as New South Wales.
James Bruce discovers what he believes to be the source of the Nile.
29th Regiment of Foot privates Hugh Montgomery and Matthew Kilroy are found guilty for the manslaughter of Crispus Attucks and Samuel Gray respectively in the Boston Massacre.
source_pages: 29th_(Worcestershire)_Regiment_of_Foot; Private_(rank); Hugh_Montgomery_(British_Army_soldier); Matthew_Kilroy_(British_Army_soldier); Crispus_Attucks; Boston_Massacre; December_5

event_text: Gustav III becomes the King of Sweden.
The Battle of Alamance, a pre-American Revolutionary War battle between local militia and a group of rebels called The "Regulators", occurs in present-day Alamance County, North Carolina.
Foundation of the Mission San Antonio de Padua in modern California by the Franciscan friar Junípero Serra.
Bloody Falls massacre: Chipewyan chief Matonabbee, traveling as the guide to Samuel Hearne on his Arctic overland journey, massacres a group of unsuspecting Inuit.
Premiere in Milan of the opera Ascanio in Alba, composed by Mozart at age 15.
The first traveler's cheques, which could be used in 90 European cities, are issued by the London Credit Exchange Company.
Alexander Fordyce flees to France to avoid debt repayment, triggering the credit crisis of 1772 in the British Empire and the Dutch Republic.
source_pages: Alexander_Fordyce; Kingdom_of_France; British_credit_crisis_of_1772–1773; British_Empire; Dutch_Republic; June_8

event_text: The British schooner Gaspee is burned in Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island.
French explorer Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne and 25 of his men are killed by Māori in New Zealand.

First Partition of Poland: The representatives of Austria, Prussia, and Russia sign three bilateral conventions condemning the "anarchy" of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and imputing to the three powers "ancient and legitimate rights" to the territories of the Commonwealth. The conventions allow each of the three great powers to annex a part of the Commonwealth, which they proceed to do over the course of the following two months.
source_pages: First_Partition_of_Poland; Habsburg_monarchy; Prussia; Russian_Empire; Polish–Lithuanian_Commonwealth; August_5

event_text: Gustav III of Sweden stages a coup d'état, in which he assumes power and enacts a new constitution that divides power between the Riksdag and the King.
King Gustav III completes his coup d'état by adopting a new Constitution, ending half a century of parliamentary rule in Sweden and installing himself as an enlightened despot.
The Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa is founded in San Luis Obispo, California.

The hymn that becomes known as "Amazing Grace", previously titled "1 Chronicles 17:16–17, Faith's Review and Expectation", is first used to accompany a sermon led by John Newton in the town of Olney, Buckinghamshire, England.
Captain James Cook leads the first expedition to sail south of the Antarctic Circle.

The Parliament of Great Britain passes the Tea Act, designed to save the British East India Company by reducing taxes on its tea and granting it the right to sell tea directly to North America. The legislation leads to the Boston Tea Party.
source_pages: Parliament_of_Great_Britain; Tea_Act; East_India_Company; Tea; Boston_Tea_Party; May_10

event_text: Wolraad Woltemade rescues 14 sailors at the Cape of Good Hope from the sinking ship De Jonge Thomas by riding his horse into the sea seven times. Both he and his horse, Vonk, are drowned on his eighth attempt.
Cúcuta, Colombia, is founded by Juana Rangel de Cuéllar.
America's first insane asylum opens.
The first recorded ministry of education, the Commission of National Education, is formed in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
American Revolution: Boston Tea Party: Members of the Sons of Liberty disguised as Mohawk Indians dump hundreds of crates of tea into Boston harbor as a protest against the Tea Act.
source_pages: American_Revolution; Boston_Tea_Party; Sons_of_Liberty; Mohawk_people; Boston; Tea_Act

event_text: Moscow State Academy of Choreography was founded under the reign of Catherine II. It is the second ballet school in Russia after Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet.
Abdul Hamid I becomes Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and Caliph of Islam.
American Revolution: The Kingdom of Great Britain orders the port of Boston, Massachusetts closed pursuant to the Boston Port Act.
Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette become King and Queen of France.

Intolerable Acts: The Quartering Act of 1774 is enacted, allowing a governor in colonial America to house British soldiers in uninhabited houses, outhouses, barns, or other buildings if suitable quarters are not provided.
Rhode Island becomes the first of Britain's North American colonies to ban the importation of slaves.
The British pass the Quebec Act, setting out rules of governance for the colony of Quebec in British North America.
Orangetown Resolutions are adopted in the Province of New York, one of many protests against the British Parliament's Coercive Acts.
Russo-Turkish War (1768–74): Russia and the Ottoman Empire sign the Treaty of Küçük Kaynarca ending the war.
British scientist Joseph Priestley discovers oxygen gas, corroborating the prior discovery of this element by German-Swedish chemist Carl Wilhelm Scheele.
Massachusetts Bay colonists rise up in the bloodless Powder Alarm.
New Caledonia is first sighted by Europeans, during the second voyage of Captain James Cook.
First Continental Congress assembles in Philadelphia.
American Revolution: The First Continental Congress denounces the British Parliament's Intolerable Acts and demands British concessions.
American Revolution: The Continental Association, a nonconsumption and nonimportation agreement against the British Isles and the British West Indies, is adopted by the First Continental Congress.
source_pages: American_Revolution; Continental_Association; Nonconsumption_agreements; British_Isles; British_West_Indies; First_Continental_Congress; October_20

event_text: The flag of Taunton, Massachusetts is the first to include the word "Liberty".
American Revolution: The First Continental Congress adjourns in Philadelphia.
American Revolutionary War: The British Parliament declares Massachusetts in rebellion.
The British East India Company factory on Balambangan Island is destroyed by Moro pirates.

An anonymous writer, thought by some to be Thomas Paine, publishes "African Slavery in America", the first article in the American colonies calling for the emancipation of slaves and the abolition of slavery.
American Revolutionary War: Patrick Henry delivers his speech – "Give me liberty or give me death!" – at St. John's Episcopal Church, Richmond, Virginia.
The Society for the Relief of Free Negroes Unlawfully Held in Bondage, the first abolition society in North America, is organized in Philadelphia by Benjamin Franklin and Benjamin Rush.
source_pages: Pennsylvania_Abolition_Society; Abolitionism_in_the_United_States; Philadelphia; Benjamin_Franklin; Benjamin_Rush; April_14

event_text: American Revolution: The British Army advances up the Charles River in Massachusetts to destroy supplies of American militias, while Paul Revere and other riders rapidly warn the countryside.
source_pages: American_Revolution; British_Army_during_the_American_Revolutionary_War; Charles_River; Province_of_Massachusetts_Bay; Militia; Paul_Revere; Paul_Revere's_midnight_ride; April_18

event_text: American Revolutionary War: The war begins during the Battles of Lexington and Concord with a victory of American minutemen and other militia over British forces, later referred to as the "shot heard round the world".
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Battles_of_Lexington_and_Concord; Minutemen; Militia; Kingdom_of_Great_Britain; Shot_heard_round_the_world; April_19

event_text: American Revolutionary War: Following the Battles of Lexington and Concord, the Siege of Boston begins with American militias blocking land access to the British-held city.
American Revolutionary War: A small Colonial militia led by Ethan Allen and Colonel Benedict Arnold captures Fort Ticonderoga.
American Revolutionary War: The Second Continental Congress takes place in Philadelphia.
The Mecklenburg Declaration of Independence is allegedly signed in Charlotte, North Carolina.
American Revolution: The Mecklenburg Resolves are adopted in the Province of North Carolina.
The Coronation of Louis XVI in Reims, the last coronation before the French Revolution.
The American Revolutionary War's first naval engagement, the Battle of Machias, results in the capture of a small British naval vessel.

American War of Independence: British general Thomas Gage declares martial law in Massachusetts. The British offer a pardon to all colonists who lay down their arms. There would be only two exceptions to the amnesty: Samuel Adams and John Hancock, if captured, were to be hanged.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; British_Army; Thomas_Gage; Martial_law; Province_of_Massachusetts_Bay; Samuel_Adams; John_Hancock

event_text: American Revolutionary War: the Continental Army is established by the Continental Congress, marking the birth of the United States Armed Forces.
American Revolutionary War: Colonists inflict heavy casualties on British forces while losing the Battle of Bunker Hill.
American Revolutionary War: George Washington takes command of the Continental Army at Cambridge, Massachusetts.
The Second Continental Congress adopts the Olive Branch Petition.
The Olive Branch Petition is signed by the Continental Congress of the Thirteen Colonies of North America.
The office that would later become the United States Post Office Department is established by the Second Continental Congress. Benjamin Franklin of Pennsylvania takes office as Postmaster General.
Founding of the U.S. Army Medical Department:  The Second Continental Congress passes legislation establishing "an hospital for an army consisting of 20,000 men."
Founding of the U.S. Army Judge Advocate General's Corps: General George Washington appoints William Tudor as Judge Advocate of the Continental Army.
The Spanish establish the Presidio San Augustin del Tucson in the town that became Tucson, Arizona.

American Revolutionary War: King George III delivers his Proclamation of Rebellion to the Court of St James's stating that the American colonies have proceeded to a state of open and avowed rebellion.
The unsuccessful Rising of the Priests in Malta.
Benedict Arnold's expedition to Quebec leaves Cambridge, Massachusetts.
American Revolutionary War: The invasion of Quebec by the Continental Army begins with the Siege of Fort St. Jean.
American Revolution: Ethan Allen surrenders to British forces after attempting to capture Montreal during the Battle of Longue-Pointe.
American Revolution: Benedict Arnold's expedition to Quebec sets off.
The Continental Congress establishes the Continental Navy (predecessor of the United States Navy).
African-American poet Phillis Wheatley is freed from slavery.
American Revolutionary War: The Burning of Falmouth (now Portland, Maine).
King George III expands on his Proclamation of Rebellion in the Thirteen Colonies in his speech from the throne at the opening of Parliament.

John Murray (also known as Lord Dunmore), the Royal Governor of the Colony of Virginia, starts the first mass emancipation of slaves in North America by issuing Lord Dunmore's Offer of Emancipation, which offers freedom to slaves who abandoned their colonial masters to fight with Murray and the British.
The United States Marine Corps is founded at Tun Tavern in Philadelphia by Samuel Nicholas.
American Revolutionary War: Patriot revolutionary forces under Gen. Richard Montgomery occupy Montreal.
The city of Kuopio, Finland (belonging to Sweden at this time) is founded by King Gustav III of Sweden.
American Revolution: USS Alfred becomes the first vessel to fly the Continental Union Flag (precursor to the "Stars and Stripes"); the flag is hoisted by John Paul Jones.
source_pages: American_Revolution; USS_Alfred; Continental_Union_Flag; Flag_of_the_United_States; John_Paul_Jones; December_3

event_text: At Fort Ticonderoga, Henry Knox begins his historic transport of artillery to Cambridge, Massachusetts.
American Revolutionary War: British troops and Loyalists, misinformed about Patriot militia strength, lose the Battle of Great Bridge, ending British rule in Virginia.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Loyalist_(American_Revolution); Patriot_(American_Revolution); Battle_of_Great_Bridge; Virginia; December_9

event_text: American Revolutionary War: Battle of Quebec: British forces under General Guy Carleton repulse an attack by Continental Army General Richard Montgomery in a snowstorm.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Battle_of_Quebec_(1775); Guy_Carleton,_1st_Baron_Dorchester; Continental_Army; Richard_Montgomery; December_31

event_text: American Revolutionary War: Burning of Norfolk – Norfolk, Virginia, is burned to the ground by combined Royal Navy and Continental Army action.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Burning_of_Norfolk; Norfolk,_Virginia; Royal_Navy; Continental_Army; January_1

event_text: General George Washington hoists the first United States flag, the Continental Union Flag, at Prospect Hill.
Empress Maria Theresa of Austria amends the Constitutio Criminalis Theresiana to include the abolition of torture throughout the Habsburg-ruled countries of Austria and Bohemia.
American Revolution: Thomas Paine publishes his pamphlet Common Sense.
American Revolutionary War: Henry Knox's "noble train of artillery" arrives in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Moore's Creek Bridge in North Carolina breaks up a Loyalist militia.
American Revolutionary War: Patriot militia units attempt to prevent capture of supply ships in and around the Savannah River by a small fleet of the Royal Navy in the Battle of the Rice Boats.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Patriot_(American_Revolution); Savannah_River; Royal_Navy; Battle_of_the_Rice_Boats; March_2

event_text: American Revolutionary War: The first amphibious landing of the United States Marine Corps begins the Battle of Nassau.
American Revolutionary War: The Continental Army fortifies Dorchester Heights with cannon, leading the British troops to abandon the Siege of Boston.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Continental_Army; Fortification_of_Dorchester_Heights; Dorchester_Heights; Cannon; Kingdom_of_Great_Britain; Siege_of_Boston

event_text: Scottish philosopher Adam Smith publishes The Wealth of Nations, ushering in the classical period of political economy.
American Revolution: The British Army evacuates Boston, ending the Siege of Boston, after George Washington and Henry Knox place artillery in positions overlooking the city.
source_pages: American_Revolution; British_Army; Evacuation_Day_(Massachusetts); Boston; Siege_of_Boston; George_Washington; Henry_Knox; Fortification_of_Dorchester_Heights

event_text: American Revolutionary War – American Patriots conduct a Raid on Tybee Island, primarily seeking to capture runaway slaves who sought refuge with British forces stationed there.
Juan Bautista de Anza finds the site for the Presidio of San Francisco.
American Revolutionary War: Ships of the Continental Navy fail in their attempt to capture a Royal Navy dispatch boat.
American Revolution: With the Halifax Resolves, the North Carolina Provincial Congress authorizes its Congressional delegation to vote for independence from Britain.
Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to renounce allegiance to King George III.
American Revolutionary War: A Continental Army garrison surrenders in the Battle of The Cedars.
Richard Henry Lee presents the "Lee Resolution" to the Continental Congress. The motion is seconded by John Adams and will lead to the United States Declaration of Independence.
American Revolutionary War: Continental Army attackers are driven back at the Battle of Trois-Rivières.
The Continental Congress appoints Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Benjamin Franklin, Roger Sherman, and Robert R. Livingston to the Committee of Five to draft a declaration of independence.
source_pages: Continental_Congress; Thomas_Jefferson; John_Adams; Benjamin_Franklin; Roger_Sherman; Robert_R._Livingston; Committee_of_Five; United_States_Declaration_of_Independence

event_text: The Virginia Declaration of Rights is adopted.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Sullivan's Island ends with the American victory, leading to the commemoration of Carolina Day.
American Revolutionary War: Thomas Hickey, Continental Army private and bodyguard to General George Washington, is hanged for mutiny and sedition.

American Revolution: The Continental Congress adopts the Lee Resolution severing ties with the Kingdom of Great Britain, although the wording of the formal Declaration of Independence is not adopted until July 4.
American Revolution: The United States Declaration of Independence is adopted by the Second Continental Congress.
Church bells (possibly including the Liberty Bell) are rung after John Nixon delivers the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence of the United States.

George Washington orders the Declaration of Independence to be read out to members of the Continental Army in Manhattan, while thousands of British troops on Staten Island prepare for the Battle of Long Island.
source_pages: George_Washington; United_States_Declaration_of_Independence; Continental_Army; Manhattan; Staten_Island; Battle_of_Long_Island; July_9

event_text: Captain James Cook begins his third voyage.
The signing of the United States Declaration of Independence took place.

American Revolutionary War: Members of the 1st Maryland Regiment repeatedly charged a numerically superior British force during the Battle of Long Island, allowing General Washington and the rest of the American troops to escape.
William Livingston, the first Governor of New Jersey, begins serving his first term.

According to American colonial reports, Ezra Lee makes the world's first submarine attack in the Turtle, attempting to attach a time bomb to the hull of HMS Eagle in New York Harbor (no British records of this attack exist).
source_pages: Ezra_Lee; Submarine; Turtle_(submersible); Time_bomb; HMS_Eagle_(1774); New_York_Harbor

event_text: The Continental Congress officially names its union of states the United States.
American Revolutionary War: Nathan Hale volunteers to spy for the Continental Army.
British–American peace conference on Staten Island fails to stop nascent American Revolutionary War.
American Revolutionary War: British forces land at Kip's Bay during the New York Campaign.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Harlem Heights is fought.
The Presidio of San Francisco is founded in New Spain.
Part of New York City is burned shortly after being occupied by British forces.
Nathan Hale is hanged for spying during the American Revolution.
American Revolution: A fleet of American boats on Lake Champlain is defeated by the Royal Navy, but delays the British advance until 1777.
American Revolutionary War: British troops attack and capture Chatterton Hill from the Continental Army.
American Revolutionary War: British and Hessian units capture Fort Washington from the Patriots.
American Revolutionary War: British forces land at the Palisades and then attack Fort Lee. The Continental Army starts to retreat across New Jersey.
During the American Revolutionary War, the Battle of Fort Cumberland, Nova Scotia, comes to an end with the arrival of British reinforcements.
Phi Beta Kappa, the oldest academic honor society in the U.S., holds its first meeting at the College of William & Mary.
Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette, arranges to enter the American military as a major general.
Thomas Paine publishes one of a series of pamphlets in The Pennsylvania Journal entitled "The American Crisis".
American Revolutionary War: General George Washington and the Continental Army cross the Delaware River at night to attack Hessian forces serving Great Britain at Trenton, New Jersey, the next day.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; George_Washington; Continental_Army; George_Washington's_crossing_of_the_Delaware_River; Battle_of_Trenton; Hessian_(soldier); Kingdom_of_Great_Britain; Trenton,_New_Jersey; December_25

event_text: American Revolutionary War: In the Battle of Trenton, the Continental Army under General George Washington executes a successful surprise attack and defeats a garrison of Hessian forces serving Great Britain.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Battle_of_Trenton; Continental_Army; George_Washington; Hessian_(soldier); Kingdom_of_Great_Britain; December_26

event_text: American Revolutionary War: American forces under the command of General George Washington repulse a British attack led by General Charles Cornwallis at the Battle of the Assunpink Creek near Trenton, New Jersey.
American Revolutionary War: American forces under General George Washington defeat British forces at the Battle of Princeton, helping boost patriot morale.
American Revolutionary War: New Connecticut (present-day Vermont) declares its independence.
American Revolutionary War: American forces are ambushed and defeated in the Battle of Bound Brook, New Jersey.
Sybil Ludington, aged 16, allegedly rode 40 miles (64 km) to alert American colonial forces to the approach of British regular forces
Continental Army officer Lachlan McIntosh fatally wounds Button Gwinnett, a signer of the United States Declaration of Independence, in a duel in Savannah, Georgia.
source_pages: Continental_Army; Lachlan_McIntosh; Button_Gwinnett; United_States_Declaration_of_Independence; Gwinnett–McIntosh_duel; Savannah,_Georgia; May_16

event_text: American Revolutionary War: Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette lands near Charleston, South Carolina, in order to help the Continental Congress to train its army.
The Second Continental Congress passes the Flag Act of 1777 adopting the Stars and Stripes as the Flag of the United States.
American Revolutionary War: Siege of Fort Ticonderoga: After a bombardment by British artillery under General John Burgoyne, American forces retreat from Fort Ticonderoga, New York.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Siege_of_Fort_Ticonderoga_(1777); Artillery; John_Burgoyne; United_States; Fort_Ticonderoga

event_text: American forces retreating from Fort Ticonderoga are defeated in the Battle of Hubbardton.

The U.S. Second Continental Congress passes a resolution that the services of Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette "be accepted, and that, in consideration of his zeal, illustrious family and connexions, he have the rank and commission of major-general of the United States."
American Revolutionary War: The bloody Battle of Oriskany prevents American relief of the Siege of Fort Stanwix.
American Revolutionary War: The Americans led by General John Stark rout British and Brunswick troops under Friedrich Baum at the Battle of Bennington in Walloomsac, New York.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; John_Stark; Duchy_of_Brunswick; Friedrich_Baum; Battle_of_Bennington; Walloomsac,_New_York

event_text: British forces abandon the Siege of Fort Stanwix after hearing rumors of Continental Army reinforcements.
American Revolutionary War: During the Battle of Cooch's Bridge, the Flag of the United States is flown in battle for the first time.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Brandywine: The British celebrate a major victory in Chester County, Pennsylvania.
American Revolutionary War: British forces win a tactically expensive victory over the Continental Army in the First Battle of Saratoga.
American Revolution: British troops occupy Philadelphia.
American Revolution: Lancaster, Pennsylvania becomes the capital of the United States for one day after Congress evacuates Philadelphia.
American Revolutionary War: Troops under George Washington are repelled by British troops under William Howe.
American Revolutionary War: British forces capture Forts Clinton and Montgomery on the Hudson River.

American Revolutionary War: The Americans defeat British forces under general John Burgoyne in the Second Battle of Saratoga, also known as the Battle of Bemis Heights, compelling Burgoyne's eventual surrender.
American Revolutionary War: British General John Burgoyne surrenders his army at Saratoga, New York.
American Revolutionary War: American defenders of Fort Mercer on the Delaware River repulse repeated Hessian attacks in the Battle of Red Bank.
American Revolutionary War: After 16 months of debate the Continental Congress approves the Articles of Confederation.
Articles of Confederation (United States) are submitted to the states for ratification.
San Jose, California, is founded as Pueblo de San José de Guadalupe by José Joaquín Moraga. It is the first civilian settlement, or pueblo, in Alta California.
Virginia becomes the first state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.
American Revolution: France formally recognizes the United States.
The United States celebrates its first Thanksgiving, marking the recent victory by the American rebels over British General John Burgoyne at Saratoga in October.
American Revolutionary War: George Washington's Continental Army goes into winter quarters at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania.
Kiritimati, also called Christmas Island, is discovered by James Cook.
James Cook is the first known European to discover the Hawaiian Islands, which he names the "Sandwich Islands".
American Revolutionary War: In Paris the Treaty of Alliance and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce are signed by the United States and France signaling official recognition of the new republic.
New York became the third state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.
Rhode Island becomes the fourth US state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.

The United States flag is formally recognized by a foreign naval vessel for the first time, when French Admiral Toussaint-Guillaume Picquet de la Motte renders a nine gun salute to USS Ranger, commanded by John Paul Jones.
source_pages: Flag_of_the_United_States; Naval_ship; Admiral; Toussaint-Guillaume_Picquet_de_la_Motte; USS_Ranger_(1777); John_Paul_Jones

event_text: American Revolutionary War: Baron von Steuben arrives at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, to help train the Continental Army.
Heinrich XI, count of the Principality of Reuss-Greiz, is elevated to Prince by Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor.
American Revolutionary War: The British Army abandons Philadelphia.
American Revolutionary War: The American Continentals engage the British in the Battle of Monmouth Courthouse resulting in standstill and British withdrawal under cover of darkness.
American Revolutionary War: The Iroquois, allied with Britain, massacre 360 Patriot soldiers during the Battle of Wyoming.
American Revolutionary War: US forces under George Clark capture Kaskaskia during the Illinois campaign.
American Revolution: Louis XVI of France declares war on the Kingdom of Great Britain.
The Emigration of Christians from the Crimea in 1778 begins.
American Revolution: First Battle of Ushant: British and French fleets fight to a standoff.
Constitution of the province of Cantabria ratified at the Assembly Hall in Bárcena la Puente, Reocín, Spain.
The theatre La Scala in Milan is inaugurated with the première of Antonio Salieri's Europa riconosciuta.
American Revolutionary War: British forces begin besieging the French outpost at Pondichéry.
The first recorded ascent of Triglav, the highest mountain in Slovenia.
American Revolutionary War: British and American forces battle indecisively at the Battle of Rhode Island.
American Revolutionary War: France invades Dominica in the British West Indies, before Britain is even aware of France's involvement in the war.
The Treaty of Fort Pitt is signed. It is the first formal treaty between the United States and a Native American tribe.
The Continental Congress passes the first United States federal budget.
Cherry Valley massacre: Loyalists and Seneca Indian forces attack a fort and village in eastern New York during the American Revolutionary War, killing more than forty civilians and soldiers.
In the Hawaiian Islands, Captain James Cook becomes the first European to visit Maui.
American Revolutionary War: British and French fleets clash in the Battle of St. Lucia.

American Revolutionary War: British forces under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Archibald Campbell defeat American forces under Major General Robert Howe and capture the port city of Savannah, Georgia.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Lieutenant_colonel_(United_Kingdom); Archibald_Campbell_(British_Army_officer,_born_1739); Major_general_(United_States); Robert_Howe_(Continental_Army_officer); Capture_of_Savannah; Savannah,_Georgia; December_29

event_text: American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Kettle Creek is fought in Georgia.
James Cook is killed by Native Hawaiians near Kealakekua on the Island of Hawaii.
American Revolutionary War: The Continental Army is routed at the Battle of Brier Creek near Savannah, Georgia.

War of the Bavarian Succession: Russian and French mediators at the Congress of Teschen negotiate an end to the war. In the agreement Austria receives the part of its territory that was taken from it (the Innviertel).
The court-martial for malfeasance of Benedict Arnold, a general in the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War, begins.
source_pages: Court-martial; Misfeasance; Benedict_Arnold; General_officer; Continental_Army; American_Revolutionary_War; June_1

event_text: American Revolutionary War: Spain declares war on the Kingdom of Great Britain, and the Great Siege of Gibraltar begins.
American Revolutionary War: The Great Siege of Gibraltar begins.
Battle of Grenada: The French defeat British naval forces in the Caribbean during the American Revolutionary War.
American Revolutionary War: Light infantry of the Continental Army seize a fortified British Army position in a midnight bayonet attack at the Battle of Stony Point.
American Revolutionary War: The Royal Navy defeats the Penobscot Expedition with the most significant loss of United States naval forces prior to the attack on Pearl Harbor.
American Revolutionary War: American forces battle and defeat the British and Iroquois forces at the Battle of Newtown.
American Revolutionary War: The Franco-American Siege of Savannah begins.
American Revolution: John Paul Jones, naval commander of the United States, on board the USS Bonhomme Richard, wins the Battle of Flamborough Head.
American Revolution: Samuel Huntington is elected President of the Continental Congress, succeeding John Jay.
The city of Tampere, Finland (belonging to Sweden at this time) is founded by King Gustav III of Sweden.
American Revolutionary War: A combined Franco-American assault on British defenses during the Siege of Savannah is repulsed with heavy casualties.
American Revolutionary War: The Franco-American Siege of Savannah is lifted.
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Cape St. Vincent.
American Revolutionary War: Spanish forces capture Fort Charlotte in Mobile, Alabama, the last British frontier post capable of threatening New Orleans.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Spanish_Empire; Battle_of_Fort_Charlotte; Mobile,_Alabama; New_Orleans; March_14

event_text: Franz Friedrich Wilhelm von Fürstenberg founds the University of Münster.
American Revolutionary War: In the largest defeat of the Continental Army, Charleston, South Carolina is taken by British forces.

The Cumberland Compact is signed by leaders of the settlers in the Cumberland River area of what would become the U.S. state of Tennessee, providing for democratic government and a formal system of justice.
New England's Dark Day, an unusual darkening of the day sky, was observed over the New England states and parts of Canada.
American Revolutionary War: At the Waxhaws Massacre, the British continue attacking after the Continentals lay down their arms, killing 113 and critically wounding all but 53 that remained.
The anti-Catholic Gordon Riots in London leave an estimated 300 to 700 people dead.
American Revolution: Battle of Springfield fought in and around Springfield, New Jersey (including Short Hills, formerly of Springfield, now of Millburn Township).
American Revolutionary War: Battle of Camden: The British defeat the Americans near Camden, South Carolina.
James Cook's ship HMS Resolution returns to England (Cook having been killed on Hawaii during the voyage).
American Revolutionary War: Sugarloaf massacre: A small detachment of militia from Northampton County, Pennsylvania, are attacked by Native Americans and Loyalists near Little Nescopeck Creek.
American Revolutionary War: Benedict Arnold gives the British the plans to West Point.
American Revolutionary War: John André, a British Army officer, is hanged as a spy by the Continental Army.

American Revolutionary War: American militia defeat royalist irregulars led by British major Patrick Ferguson at the Battle of Kings Mountain in South Carolina, often regarded as the turning point in the war's Southern theater.
The Great Hurricane of 1780 kills 20,000–30,000 in the Caribbean.
American Revolutionary War: The British-led Royalton raid is the last Native American raid on New England.
The Great Hurricane of 1780 finishes after its sixth day, killing between 20,000 and 24,000 residents of the Lesser Antilles.
The Rebellion of Túpac Amaru II against Spanish rule in the Viceroyalty of Peru begins.
French-American forces under Colonel LaBalme are defeated by Miami Chief Little Turtle.

American Revolutionary War: In the Battle of Fishdam Ford a force of British and Loyalist troops fail in a surprise attack against the South Carolina Patriot militia under Brigadier General Thomas Sumter.
Founding Father Alexander Hamilton marries Elizabeth Schuyler Hamilton at the Schuyler Mansion in Albany, New York.
source_pages: Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States; Alexander_Hamilton; Elizabeth_Schuyler_Hamilton; Schuyler_Mansion; Albany,_New_York; December_14

event_text: American Revolutionary War: One thousand five hundred soldiers of the 6th Pennsylvania Regiment under General Anthony Wayne's command rebel against the Continental Army's winter camp in Morristown, New Jersey in the Pennsylvania Line Mutiny of 1781.
American Revolutionary War: Richmond, Virginia, is burned by British naval forces led by former American general Benedict Arnold.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Richmond,_Virginia; Raid_on_Richmond; Kingdom_of_Great_Britain; His_Majesty's_Naval_Service; Benedict_Arnold; January_5

event_text: In the Battle of Jersey, the British defeat the last attempt by France to invade Jersey in the Channel Islands.

American Revolutionary War: Battle of Cowpens: Continental troops under Brigadier General Daniel Morgan defeat British forces under Lieutenant Colonel Banastre Tarleton at the battle in South Carolina.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Battle_of_Cowpens; Daniel_Morgan; Banastre_Tarleton; South_Carolina; January_17

event_text: American Revolutionary War: British forces seize the Dutch-owned Caribbean island Sint Eustatius.
Fourth Anglo-Dutch War: Captain Thomas Shirley opens his expedition against Dutch colonial outposts on the Gold Coast of Africa (present-day Ghana).
The Articles of Confederation goes into effect in the United States.
William Herschel discovers Uranus.
American Revolutionary War: British and French ships clash in the Battle of Fort Royal off the coast of Martinique.
Jack Jouett begins his midnight ride to warn Thomas Jefferson and the Virginia legislature of an impending British raid.
Fourth Anglo-Dutch War, a fleet of six East India Company ships sets sail from Fort Marlborough to raid the Dutch VOC factories on the West coast of Sumatra including the major port of Padang.
source_pages: Fourth_Anglo-Dutch_War; East_India_Company; Fort_Marlborough; Dutch_East_India_Company; Sumatra; Padang; August_4

event_text: The Battle of Dogger Bank takes place.
American Revolutionary War: A small force of Pennsylvania militia is ambushed and overwhelmed by an American Indian group, which forces George Rogers Clark to abandon his attempt to attack Detroit.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Pennsylvania; Militia_(United_States); Lochry's_Defeat; George_Rogers_Clark; Detroit

event_text: Los Angeles is founded as El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora La Reina de los Ángeles (The Village of Our Lady, the Queen of the Angels) by 44 Spanish settlers.
Battle of the Chesapeake in the American Revolutionary War: The British Navy is repelled by the French Navy, contributing to the British surrender at Yorktown.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Groton Heights takes place, resulting in a British victory.
American Revolutionary War: The Battle of Eutaw Springs in South Carolina, the war's last significant battle in the Southern theater, ends in a narrow British tactical victory.
American Revolution: French and American forces backed by a French fleet begin the siege of Yorktown.
The Battle of Raft Swamp marks the last battle fought in North Carolina during the American Revolutionary War with a Patriot victory. It occurred four days before the British surrender at Yorktown.
American Revolutionary War: British General Charles, Earl Cornwallis surrenders at the Siege of Yorktown.
American Revolutionary War: The siege of Yorktown comes to an end.
The Patent of Toleration, providing limited freedom of worship, is approved in Austria.
The crew of the British slave ship Zong murders 54 Africans by dumping them into the sea to claim insurance, beginning the Zong massacre.
The first American commercial bank, the Bank of North America, opens.
Superintendent of Finance Robert Morris addresses the U.S. Congress to recommend establishment of a national mint and decimal coinage.
American Revolutionary War: The House of Commons of Great Britain votes against further war in America.

Gnadenhutten massacre: Ninety-six Native Americans in Gnadenhutten, Ohio, who had converted to Christianity, are killed by Pennsylvania militiamen in retaliation for raids carried out by other Indian tribes.
source_pages: Gnadenhutten_massacre; Native_Americans_in_the_United_States; Gnadenhutten,_Ohio; Christianity; Pennsylvania; March_8

event_text: The Second Rockingham ministry assumes office in Great Britain and begins negotiations to end the American War of Independence.
King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke (Rama I) of Siam (modern day Thailand) establishes the Chakri dynasty.
American Revolution: A Royal Navy fleet led by Admiral George Rodney defeats a French fleet led by the Comte de Grasse at the Battle of the Saintes off Dominica in the Caribbean Sea.
source_pages: Royal_Navy; George_Rodney,_1st_Baron_Rodney; François_Joseph_Paul_de_Grasse; Battle_of_the_Saintes; Dominica; Caribbean_Sea; April_12

event_text: John Adams secures Dutch recognition of the United States as an independent government. The house which he had purchased in The Hague becomes the first American embassy.
The city of Rattanakosin, now known internationally as Bangkok, is founded on the eastern bank of the Chao Phraya River by King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke.
Construction begins on the Grand Palace, the royal residence of the King of Siam in Bangkok, at the command of King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke.
King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke (Rama I) of Siam (modern day Thailand) is crowned.
The U.S. Congress adopts the Great Seal of the United States.
Raid on Lunenburg: American privateers attack the British settlement of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia.
George Washington orders the creation of the Badge of Military Merit to honor soldiers wounded in battle. It is later renamed to the more poetic Purple Heart.

American Revolutionary War: Battle of Blue Licks: The last major engagement of the war, almost ten months after the surrender of the British commander Charles Cornwallis following the Siege of Yorktown.
British forces under Edward Despard complete the reconquest of the Black River settlements on the Mosquito Coast from the Spanish.
American Revolutionary War: Franco-Spanish troops launch the unsuccessful "grand assault" during the Great Siege of Gibraltar.
American Revolutionary War: Review of the French troops under General Rochambeau by General George Washington at Verplanck's Point, New York.
American Revolutionary War: Treaty of Paris: In Paris, representatives from the United States and Great Britain sign preliminary peace articles (later formalized as the 1783 Treaty of Paris).
The Montgolfier brothers first test fly an unmanned hot air balloon in France; it floats nearly 2.5 km (1.6 mi).
British East India Company: Muharram Rebellion: Hada and Mada Miah lead the first anti-British uprising in the subcontinent against Robert Lindsay and his contingents in Sylhet Shahi Eidgah.
source_pages: East_India_Company; Muharram_Rebellion; Indian_subcontinent; Robert_Lindsay_(colonial_official); Sylhet_Shahi_Eidgah; December_16

event_text: The Kingdom of Great Britain signs preliminary articles of peace with the Kingdom of France, setting the stage for the official end of hostilities in the American Revolutionary War later that year.
Spain–United States relations are first established.
In Calabria, a sequence of strong earthquakes begins.
American Revolutionary War: French and Spanish forces lift the Great Siege of Gibraltar.
In an emotional speech in Newburgh, New York, George Washington asks his officers not to support the Newburgh Conspiracy. The plea is successful, and the threatened coup d'état never takes place.
American Revolutionary War: Colbert's Raid: A Spanish garrison under Captain Jacobo du Breuil defeat British irregulars at Arkansas Post.
source_pages: American_Revolutionary_War; Colbert_raid; Spanish_Empire; Garrison; Kingdom_of_Great_Britain; Irregular_military; Arkansas_Post; April_17

event_text: Three-Fifths Compromise: The first instance of black slaves in the United States of America being counted as three-fifths of persons (for the purpose of taxation), in a resolution of the Congress of the Confederation. This was later adopted in the 1787 Constitution.
First United Empire Loyalists reach Parrtown (later called Saint John, New Brunswick), Canada, after leaving the United States.
A Great Jubilee Day held at North Stratford, Connecticut, celebrates the end of fighting in the American Revolutionary War.
The Montgolfier brothers publicly demonstrate their montgolfière (hot air balloon).
Laki, a volcano in Iceland, begins an eight-month eruption which kills over 9,000 people and starts a seven-year famine.
A poisonous cloud caused by the eruption of the Laki volcano in Iceland reaches Le Havre in France.
American Revolutionary War: The war's last action, the Siege of Cuddalore, is ended by a preliminary peace agreement.
Mount Asama erupts in Japan, killing about 1,400 people (Tenmei eruption). The eruption causes a famine, which results in an additional 20,000 deaths.
A huge fireball meteor is seen across Great Britain as it passes over the east coast.
American Revolutionary War: The war ends with the signing of the Treaty of Paris by the United States and the Kingdom of Great Britain.
The Montgolfier brothers' hot air balloon makes the first human ascent, piloted by Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier.
The American Continental Army is disbanded.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's Symphony No. 36 is performed for the first time in Linz, Austria.
In Paris, Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier and François Laurent d'Arlandes make the first untethered hot air balloon flight.
American Revolutionary War: The last British troops leave New York City three months after the signing of the Treaty of Paris.
A 5.3 magnitude earthquake strikes New Jersey.
At Fraunces Tavern in New York City, U.S. General George Washington bids farewell to his officers.
William Pitt the Younger becomes the youngest Prime Minister of the United Kingdom at 24.
George Washington resigns as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army at the Maryland State House in Annapolis, Maryland.
American Revolutionary War: Ratification Day, United States: Congress ratifies the Treaty of Paris with Great Britain.
The signing of the Treaty of Mangalore brings the Second Anglo-Mysore War to an end.
The Emerald Buddha is moved with great ceremony to its current location in Wat Phra Kaew, Thailand.

The Treaty of Paris, ratified by the United States Congress on January 14, 1784, is ratified by King George III of the Kingdom of Great Britain, ending the American Revolutionary War. Copies of the ratified documents are exchanged on May 12, 1784.
source_pages: Treaty_of_Paris_(1783); United_States_Congress; George_III; Kingdom_of_Great_Britain; American_Revolutionary_War; April_9

event_text: Élisabeth Thible becomes the first woman to fly in an untethered hot air balloon. Her flight covers four kilometres (2.5 mi) in 45 minutes, and reached an estimated 1,500 metres (4,900 ft) in altitude.
The first British mail coach service ran from Bristol to London.
Russian colonization of North America: Awa'uq Massacre: The Russian fur trader Grigory Shelikhov storms a Kodiak Island Alutiit refuge rock on Sitkalidak Island, killing 500+ Alutiit.
source_pages: Russian_colonization_of_North_America; Awa'uq_Massacre; Grigory_Shelikhov; Kodiak_Island; Alutiiq; Sitkalidak_Island; August_14

event_text: Classical composer Luigi Boccherini receives a pay rise of 12,000 reals from his employer, the Infante Luis, Count of Chinchón.
Western North Carolina (now eastern Tennessee) declares itself an independent state under the name of Franklin; it is not accepted into the United States, and only lasts for four years.
Frenchman Jean-Pierre Blanchard and American John Jeffries travel from Dover, England, to Calais, France, in a gas balloon.
source_pages: Jean-Pierre_Blanchard; John_Jeffries; Dover; Calais; Balloon; January_7

event_text: Invading Siamese forces attempt to exploit the political chaos in Vietnam, but are ambushed and annihilated at the Mekong river by the Tây Sơn in the Battle of Rạch Gầm-Xoài Mút.
The University of Georgia is founded, the first state-chartered public university in the United States.
The Boston King's Chapel adopts James Freeman's revised prayer book, without the Nicene Creed, establishing it as the first Unitarian congregation in the United States.
The first Treaty of Hopewell is signed, by which the United States acknowledges Cherokee lands in what is now East Tennessee.
Virginia enacts the Statute for Religious Freedom authored by Thomas Jefferson.
A landslide dam on the Dadu River created by an earthquake ten days earlier collapses, killing 100,000 in the Sichuan province of China.
Gavriil Pribylov discovers St. George Island of the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea.
Alexander Macdonell and over five hundred Roman Catholic highlanders leave Scotland to settle in Glengarry County, Ontario.
The first federal Indian Reservation is created by the United States.
Mont Blanc on the French-Italian border is climbed for the first time by Jacques Balmat and Dr. Michel-Gabriel Paccard.
Captain Francis Light establishes the British colony of Penang in Malaysia.
Shays' Rebellion, an armed uprising of Massachusetts farmers, begins in response to high debt and tax burdens.
The beginning of the Annapolis Convention.
The mine of Huancavelica in the Peruvian Andes collapses killing more than hundred people. The event was a major setback for quicksilver production in the Spanish Empire.
The oldest musical organization in the United States is founded as the Stoughton Musical Society.
The Grand Duchy of Tuscany, under Pietro Leopoldo I, becomes the first modern state to abolish the death penalty (later commemorated as Cities for Life Day).
Mission Santa Barbara is dedicated (on the feast day of Saint Barbara).

The nationally known image of the Black Nazarene in the Philippines was transferred from what is now Rizal Park to its present shrine in the minor basilica of Quiapo Church. This is annually commemorated through its Traslación (solemn transfer) in the streets of Manila and is attended by millions of devotees.
source_pages: Black_Nazarene; Philippines; Rizal_Park; Basilicas_in_the_Catholic_Church; Quiapo_Church; Manila; January_9

event_text: William Herschel discovers Titania and Oberon, two moons of Uranus.
source_pages: William_Herschel; Timeline_of_discovery_of_Solar_System_planets_and_their_moons; Titania_(moon); Oberon_(moon); Moons_of_Uranus; Uranus; January_11

event_text: Shays' Rebellion: The rebellion's largest confrontation, outside the Springfield Armory, results in the killing of four rebels and the wounding of twenty.
Militia led by General Benjamin Lincoln crush the remnants of Shays' Rebellion in Petersham, Massachusetts.
After a delay of 11 days, the United States Constitutional Convention formally convenes in Philadelphia after a quorum of seven states is secured.
Oliver Ellsworth moves at the Federal Convention to call the government the 'United States'.

The Congress of the Confederation enacts the Northwest Ordinance establishing governing rules for the Northwest Territory. It also establishes procedures for the admission of new states and limits the expansion of slavery.
Sixty proof sheets of the Constitution of the United States are delivered to the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
The United States Constitution is signed at Independence Hall in Philadelphia, bringing the Constitutional Convention to an end.
The Congress of the Confederation votes to send the newly written United States Constitution to the state legislatures for approval.
Russians under Alexander Suvorov defeat the Turks at Kinburn.
Delaware becomes the first state to ratify the United States Constitution.
Pennsylvania becomes the second state to ratify the US Constitution.
New Jersey becomes the third state to ratify the U.S. Constitution.
The first edition of The Times of London, previously The Daily Universal Register, is published.
Georgia becomes the fourth state to ratify the United States Constitution.
Connecticut becomes the fifth state to ratify the United States Constitution.
The first elements of the First Fleet carrying 736 convicts from Great Britain to Australia arrive at Botany Bay.
The second group of ships of the First Fleet arrive at Botany Bay.
The third and main part of First Fleet arrives at Botany Bay, beginning the British colonization of Australia. Arthur Phillip decides that Port Jackson is a more suitable location for a colony.
The British First Fleet, led by Arthur Phillip, sails into Port Jackson (Sydney Harbour) to establish Sydney, the first permanent European settlement on Australia. Commemorated as Australia Day.
source_pages: First_Fleet; Arthur_Phillip; Port_Jackson; Sydney; Australia_Day; January_26

event_text: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state to ratify the United States Constitution.
The First Fleet arrives at Norfolk Island in order to found a convict settlement.
A fire in New Orleans leaves most of the town in ruins.
Settlers establish Marietta, Ohio, the first permanent settlement created by U.S. citizens in the recently organized Northwest Territory.
Maryland becomes the seventh state to ratify the United States Constitution.
King Louis XVI of France attempts to impose the reforms of Étienne Charles de Loménie de Brienne by abolishing the parlements.
South Carolina became the eighth state to ratify the United States Constitution.
French Revolution: Day of the Tiles: Civilians in Grenoble toss roof tiles and various objects down upon royal troops.
Russian explorer Gerasim Izmailov reaches Alaska.
New Hampshire becomes the ninth state to ratify the Constitution of the United States.
Virginia becomes the tenth state to ratify the United States Constitution.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart completes his Symphony No. 40 in G minor (K550).
New York ratifies the United States Constitution and becomes the 11th state of the United States.
The Anjala conspiracy is signed.
The Congress of the Confederation sets the date for the first presidential election in the United States, and New York City becomes the country's temporary capital.
Nguyễn Huệ proclaims himself Emperor Quang Trung, in effect abolishing on his own the Lê dynasty.
The first American novel, The Power of Sympathy or the Triumph of Nature Founded in Truth by William Hill Brown, is printed in Boston.

Georgetown College, the first Catholic university in the United States, is founded in Georgetown, Maryland (now a part of Washington, D.C.) when Bishop John Carroll, Rev. Robert Molyneux, and Rev. John Ashton purchase land for the proposed academy for the education of youth.
source_pages: Georgetown_University; Catholic_higher_education; Georgetown_(Washington,_D.C.); John_Carroll_(archbishop_of_Baltimore); Robert_Molyneux; January_23

event_text: Tây Sơn forces emerge victorious against Qing armies and liberate the capital Thăng Long.
George Washington is unanimously elected as the first President of the United States by the U.S. Electoral College.
In New York City, the first Congress of the United States meets, putting the United States Constitution into effect.
In New York City, the United States House of Representatives achieves its first quorum and elects Frederick Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania as its first Speaker.
George Washington arrives at Grays Ferry, Philadelphia, while en route to Manhattan for his inauguration.
John Adams sworn in as first US Vice President (nine days before George Washington).
George Washington's reception at Trenton is hosted by the Ladies of Trenton as he journeys to New York City for his first inauguration.
Mutiny on the Bounty: Lieutenant William Bligh and 18 sailors are set adrift, and the rebel crew returns to Tahiti briefly before setting sail for Pitcairn Island.
On the balcony of Federal Hall on Wall Street in New York City, George Washington takes the oath of office to become the first President of the United States.
In France, the Estates-General convenes for the first time since 1614.
James Madison introduces twelve proposed amendments to the United States Constitution in Congress.
Mutiny on the Bounty: HMS Bounty mutiny survivors including Captain William Bligh and 18 others reach Timor after a nearly 7,400 km (4,600 mi) journey in an open boat.
In France, the Third Estate declares itself the National Assembly.
Deputies of the French Third Estate take the Tennis Court Oath.
In Versailles, the National Assembly reconstitutes itself as the National Constituent Assembly and begins preparations for a French constitution.
Alexander Mackenzie reaches the Mackenzie River delta.
Jacques Necker is dismissed as France's Finance Minister sparking the Storming of the Bastille.
In response to the dismissal of the French finance minister Jacques Necker, the radical journalist Camille Desmoulins gives a speech which results in the storming of the Bastille two days later.
Storming of the Bastille in Paris. This event escalates the widespread discontent into the French Revolution. Bastille Day is still celebrated annually in France.
French Revolution: Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette, is named by acclamation Colonel General of the new National Guard of Paris.
The first U.S. federal government agency, the Department of Foreign Affairs, is established (it will be later renamed Department of State).
France: abolition of feudalism by the National Constituent Assembly.
The United States Department of War is established.
The first naval battle of the Svensksund began in the Gulf of Finland.
The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen is approved by the National Constituent Assembly of France.
William Herschel discovers a new moon of Saturn: Enceladus.
The United States Department of the Treasury is founded.
Alexander Hamilton is appointed the first United States Secretary of the Treasury.
The United States "Department of Foreign Affairs", established by law in July, is renamed the Department of State and given a variety of domestic duties.
The office of United States Postmaster General is established.
Battle of Rymnik: Alexander Suvorov's Russian and allied army defeats superior Ottoman Empire forces.
The United States Congress passes the Judiciary Act, creating the office of the Attorney General and federal judiciary system and ordering the composition of the Supreme Court.

The United States Congress passes twelve constitutional amendments: the ten known as the Bill of Rights, the (unratified) Congressional Apportionment Amendment, and the Congressional Compensation Amendment.
George Washington appoints Thomas Jefferson the first United States Secretary of State.
The United States Department of War first establishes a regular army with a strength of several hundred men.
The United States Bill of Rights is sent to the various States for ratification.
George Washington proclaims Thursday November 26, 1789 a Thanksgiving Day.
French Revolution: The Women's March on Versailles effectively terminates royal authority.
French Revolution: King Louis XVI is forced to change his residence from Versailles to the Tuileries Palace.
John Jay is sworn in as the first Chief Justice of the United States.
New Jersey becomes the first U.S. state to ratify the Bill of Rights.
North Carolina ratifies the United States Constitution and is admitted as the 12th U.S. state.
A national Thanksgiving Day is observed in the United States as proclaimed by President George Washington at the request of Congress.
George Washington delivers the first State of the Union address in New York City.
France is divided into 83 départements, cutting across the former provinces in an attempt to dislodge regional loyalties based on ownership of land by the nobility.
Russo-Turkish war (1787–1792): Greek privateer Lambros Katsonis loses three of his ships in the Battle of Andros.
Rhode Island becomes the last of North America's original Thirteen Colonies to ratify the Constitution and become one of the United States.
Manuel Quimper explores the Strait of Juan de Fuca.
The United States enacts its first copyright statute, the Copyright Act of 1790.
The Swedish Navy captures one third of the Russian Baltic fleet.
The Civil Constitution of the Clergy is passed in France by the National Constituent Assembly.
Inaugural Fête de la Fédération is held to celebrate the unity of the French people and the national reconciliation.
The District of Columbia is established as the capital of the United States after signature of the Residence Act.
The first U.S. patent is issued, to inventor Samuel Hopkins for a potash process.
The first United States Census is conducted.
A newly passed tariff act creates the Revenue Cutter Service (the forerunner of the United States Coast Guard).
The Treaty of Wereloe ended the 1788–1790 Russo-Swedish War.
Four Great Anhui Troupes introduce Anhui opera to Beijing in honor of the Qianlong Emperor's eightieth birthday.
A severe earthquake in northern Algeria causes severe damage and a tsunami in the Mediterranean Sea and kills three thousand.
Northwest Indian War: Native American forces defeat the United States, ending the Harmar Campaign.
Edmund Burke publishes Reflections on the Revolution in France, in which he predicts that the French Revolution will end in a disaster.
The U.S. Congress moves from New York City to Philadelphia.
The Aztec calendar stone is discovered at  El Zócalo, Mexico City.
The Turkish fortress of Izmail is stormed and captured by Alexander Suvorov and his Russian armies.
Louis XVI of France gives his public assent to Civil Constitution of the Clergy during the French Revolution.
Efimeris, the oldest Greek newspaper of which issues have survived till today, is published for the first time.
Northwest Indian War: The Big Bottom massacre is committed by Lenape and Wyandot warriors in the Ohio Country, North America.
source_pages: Northwest_Indian_War; Big_Bottom_massacre; Lenape; Wyandot_people; Ohio_Country; January_2

event_text: The Siege of Dunlap's Station begins near Cincinnati during the Northwest Indian War.
The British Parliament passes the Constitutional Act of 1791 and splits the old Province of Quebec into Upper Canada and Lower Canada.
Congress passes a law admitting the state of Vermont to the Union, effective 4 March, after that state had existed for 14 years as a de facto independent largely unrecognized state.
Claude Chappe demonstrates the first semaphore line near Paris.
Vermont is admitted to the United States as the fourteenth state.
The Constitution of May 3 (the first modern constitution in Europe) is proclaimed by the Sejm of Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
French Revolution: Maximilien Robespierre proposes the Self-denying Ordinance.
King Louis XVI, disguised as a valet, and the French royal family attempt to flee Paris during the French Revolution.
King Louis XVI of France and his immediate family begin the Flight to Varennes during the French Revolution.
At Padua, the Emperor Leopold II calls on the monarchs of Europe to join him in demanding the king of France Louis XVI's freedom.
Beginning of Priestley Riots (to 17 July) in Birmingham targeting Joseph Priestley as a supporter of the French Revolution.

Members of the French National Guard under the command of General Lafayette open fire on a crowd of radical Jacobins at the Champ de Mars, Paris, during the French Revolution, killing scores of people.
source_pages: National_Guard_(France); Gilbert_du_Motier,_Marquis_de_Lafayette; Champ_de_Mars_massacre; Jacobin_(politics); Champ_de_Mars; French_Revolution

event_text: The Treaty of Sistova is signed, ending the Ottoman–Habsburg wars.
American troops destroy the Miami town of Kenapacomaqua near the site of present-day Logansport, Indiana in the Northwest Indian War.
Slaves from plantations in Saint-Domingue hold a Vodou ceremony led by houngan Dutty Boukman at Bois Caïman, marking the start of the Haitian Revolution.
source_pages: Saint-Domingue; Haitian_Vodou; Oungan; Dutty_Boukman; Bois_Caïman; Haitian_Revolution; August_14

event_text: A Vodou ceremony, led by Dutty Boukman, turns into a violent slave rebellion, beginning the Haitian Revolution.
The Haitian slave revolution begins in Saint-Domingue, Haiti.
John Fitch is granted a United States patent for the steamboat.

French Revolution: Frederick William II of Prussia and Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor, issue the Declaration of Pillnitz, declaring the joint support of the Holy Roman Empire and Prussia for the French monarchy, agitating the French revolutionaries and contributing to the outbreak of the War of the First Coalition.
source_pages: French_Revolution; Frederick_William_II_of_Prussia; Leopold_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor; Declaration_of_Pillnitz; Holy_Roman_Empire; Prussia; Kingdom_of_France; War_of_the_First_Coalition; August_27

event_text: HMS Pandora sinks after having run aground on the outer Great Barrier Reef the previous day.
Olympe de Gouges writes the Declaration of the Rights of Woman and of the Female Citizen.
Washington, D.C., the capital of the United States, is named after President George Washington.
King Louis XVI of France accepts the new constitution.
The Papal States lose Avignon to Revolutionary France.
The National Assembly of France votes to award full citizenship to Jews.
The first performance of Mozart's opera The Magic Flute takes place two months before his death.
France's National Constituent Assembly is dissolved, to be replaced the next day by the National Legislative Assembly.
First session of the French Legislative Assembly.
The revolutionary group the United Irishmen is formed in Belfast, Ireland leading to the Irish Rebellion of 1798.
Treaty of Drottningholm, between Sweden and Russia
The University of Vermont, the oldest university in Vermont, and fifth-oldest in New England, is chartered.
Northwest Indian War: The Western Confederacy of American Indians wins a major victory over the United States in the Battle of the Wabash.
The Dublin Society of United Irishmen is founded.
The first edition of The Observer, the world's first Sunday newspaper, is published.
The United States Bill of Rights becomes law when ratified by the Virginia General Assembly.
Treaty of Jassy between Russian and Ottoman Empire is signed, ending the Russo-Turkish War of 1787–92.
Federalist Thomas Pinckney appointed first U.S. minister to Britain.
The London Corresponding Society is founded.
The Postal Service Act, establishing the United States Post Office Department, is signed by United States President George Washington.
King Gustav III of Sweden is shot; he dies on March 29.
Battle of Croix-des-Bouquets: Black slave insurgents gain a victory in the first major battle of the Haitian Revolution.
King Gustav III of Sweden dies after being shot in the back at a midnight masquerade ball at Stockholm's Royal Opera 13 days earlier.
The Coinage Act is passed by Congress, establishing the United States Mint.
United States President George Washington exercises his authority to veto a bill, the first time this power is used in the United States.
France declares war against the "King of Hungary and Bohemia", the beginning of the French Revolutionary Wars.
Tiradentes, a revolutionary leading a movement for Brazil's independence, is hanged, drawn and quartered.
Highwayman Nicolas J. Pelletier becomes the first person executed by guillotine.
"La Marseillaise" (the French national anthem) is composed by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle.
France invades the Austrian Netherlands (present day Belgium and Luxembourg), beginning the French Revolutionary Wars.
The New York Stock Exchange is formed under the Buttonwood Agreement.
A lava dome collapses on Mount Unzen, near the city of Shimbara on the Japanese island of Kyūshū, creating a deadly tsunami that killed nearly 15,000 people.
source_pages: Lava_dome; Mount_Unzen; Shimabara,_Nagasaki; Japan; Kyushu; 1792_Unzen_landslide_and_tsunami; May_21

event_text: Kentucky is admitted as the 15th state of the United States.
Captain George Vancouver claims Puget Sound for the Kingdom of Great Britain.
The Brunswick Manifesto is issued to the population of Paris promising vengeance if the French royal family is harmed.
French Revolution: Storming of the Tuileries Palace: Louis XVI is arrested and taken into custody as his Swiss Guards are massacred by the Parisian mob.
King Louis XVI of France is formally arrested by the National Tribunal, and declared an enemy of the people.
Maximilien de Robespierre presents the petition of the Commune of Paris to the Legislative Assembly, which demanded the formation of a revolutionary tribunal.

During what became known as the September Massacres of the French Revolution, rampaging mobs slaughter three Roman Catholic bishops, more than two hundred priests, and prisoners believed to be royalist sympathizers.
The Hope Diamond is stolen along with other French crown jewels when six men break into the house where they are stored.
French troops stop an allied invasion of France at the Battle of Valmy.
French Revolution: The National Convention abolishes the monarchy.
Primidi Vendémiaire of year one of the French Republican Calendar as the French First Republic comes into being.
A militia departs from the Spanish stronghold of Valdivia to quell a Huilliche uprising in southern Chile.
The first celebration of Columbus Day is held in New York City.
In Washington, D.C., the cornerstone of the United States Executive Mansion (known as the White House since 1818) is laid.
Mount Hood (Oregon) is named after Samuel Hood, 1st Viscount Hood by Lt. William E. Broughton who sighted the mountain near the mouth of the Willamette River.
Battle of Jemappes in the French Revolutionary Wars.
French Revolution: King Louis XVI of France is put on trial for treason by the National Convention.
Jean-Pierre Blanchard becomes the first person to fly in a balloon in the United States.
Nicolas Jean Hugon de Bassville, representative of Revolutionary France, is lynched by a mob in Rome.
After being found guilty of treason by the French National Convention, Louis XVI of France is executed by guillotine.
Second Partition of Poland.
French Revolutionary Wars: France declares war on the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.
The first modern republic in Germany, the Republic of Mainz, is declared by Andreas Joseph Hofmann.
Flanders Campaign of the French Revolution, Battle of Neerwinden.
During the French Revolution, the Committee of Public Safety becomes the executive organ of the republic.
The French troops led by Léger-Félicité Sonthonax defeat the slaves settlers in the Siege of Port-au-Prince.
French revolutionary Jean-Paul Marat is acquitted by the Revolutionary Tribunal of charges brought by the Girondin in Paris.
Battle of Famars during the Flanders Campaign of the War of the First Coalition.
