French Revolution: François Hanriot, leader of the Parisian National Guard, arrests 22 Girondists selected by Jean-Paul Marat, setting the stage for the Reign of Terror.
source_pages: French_Revolution; François_Hanriot; Girondins; Jean-Paul_Marat; Reign_of_Terror; June_2

event_text: The Jardin des Plantes museum opens in Paris. A year later, it becomes the first public zoo.
French Revolution: Following the arrests of Girondin leaders, the Jacobins gain control of the Committee of Public Safety installing the revolutionary dictatorship.
Haitian Revolution: The Battle of Cap-Français ends with French Republican troops and black slave insurgents capturing the city.
The first Republican constitution in France is adopted.
The Act Against Slavery in Upper Canada bans the importation of slaves and will free those who are born into slavery after the passage of the Act at 25 years of age.
Alexander Mackenzie reaches the Pacific Ocean becoming the first recorded human to complete a transcontinental crossing of North America.
Kingdom of Prussia re-conquers Mainz from France.
The Rhône and Loire départments are created when the former département of Rhône-et-Loire is split into two.
French Revolution: A levée en masse is decreed by the National Convention.

French Revolutionary Wars: The city of Toulon revolts against the French Republic and admits the British and Spanish fleets to seize its port, leading to the Siege of Toulon by French Revolutionary forces.
source_pages: French_Revolutionary_Wars; Toulon; French_First_Republic; Toulon_arsenal; Siege_of_Toulon_(1793); French_Revolutionary_Army

event_text: French Revolution: The French National Convention initiates the Reign of Terror.
French Revolutionary Wars: Battle of Hondschoote.
War of the Pyrenees: France defeats a Spanish force at the Battle of Peyrestortes.
The first cornerstone of the United States Capitol is laid by George Washington.
The cornerstone of Old East, the oldest state university building in the United States, is laid at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
French Revolutionary Wars: Austro-Prussian victory over Republican France at the First Battle of Wissembourg.
Queen Marie Antoinette of France is tried and convicted of treason.
French Revolution: Queen Marie Antoinette is executed.
War of the First Coalition: French victory at the Battle of Wattignies forces Austria to raise the siege of Maubeuge.
French playwright, journalist and feminist Olympe de Gouges is guillotined.
A Goddess of Reason is proclaimed by the French Convention at the suggestion of Pierre Gaspard Chaumette.
French Revolution: Ninety dissident Roman Catholic priests are executed by drowning at Nantes.
Surrender of the frigate La Lutine by French Royalists to Lord Samuel Hood; renamed HMS Lutine, she later becomes a famous treasure wreck.
War of the First Coalition: The Siege of Toulon ends when Napoleon's French artillery forces the British to abandon the city, securing southern France from invasion.
The Battle of Savenay: A decisive defeat of the royalist counter-revolutionaries in War in the Vendée during the French Revolution.
Northwest Indian War: General "Mad Anthony" Wayne and a 300 man detachment identify the site of St. Clair's 1791 defeat by the large number of unburied human remains at modern Fort Recovery, Ohio.
source_pages: Northwest_Indian_War; Anthony_Wayne; Legion_of_the_United_States; St._Clair's_defeat; Fort_Recovery,_Ohio; December_25

event_text: Second Battle of Wissembourg: France defeats Austria.
The French legislature abolishes slavery throughout all territories of the French First Republic. It would be reestablished in the French West Indies in 1802.
First session of United States Senate opens to the public.
The first Christiansborg Palace in Copenhagen burns down.
The 11th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is passed by the U.S. Congress.
Eli Whitney is granted a patent for the cotton gin.
The Slave Trade Act of 1794 bans the export of slaves from the United States, and prohibits American citizens from outfitting a ship for the purpose of importing slaves.
In Kraków, Tadeusz Kościuszko announces a general uprising against Imperial Russia and the Kingdom of Prussia, and assumes the powers of the Commander in Chief of all of the Polish forces.
source_pages: Kraków; Tadeusz_Kościuszko; Kościuszko's_proclamation; Kościuszko_Uprising; Commander-in-chief; Polish_Armed_Forces; March_24

event_text: The United States Government establishes a permanent navy and authorizes the building of six frigates.
Battle of Beaumont during the Flanders Campaign of the War of the First Coalition.
Sardinians, headed by Giovanni Maria Angioy, start a revolution against the Savoy domination, expelling Viceroy Balbiano and his officials from Cagliari, the capital and largest city of the island.
French Revolution: Robespierre introduces the Cult of the Supreme Being in the National Convention as the new state religion of the French First Republic.
source_pages: French_Revolution; Maximilien_Robespierre; Cult_of_the_Supreme_Being; National_Convention; State_religion; French_First_Republic

event_text: Branded a traitor during the Reign of Terror, French chemist Antoine Lavoisier, who was also a tax collector with the Ferme générale, is tried, convicted and guillotined in one day in Paris.
Battle of Tourcoing during the Flanders Campaign of the War of the First Coalition.
The battle of the Glorious First of June is fought, the first naval engagement between Britain and France during the French Revolutionary Wars.
Haitian Revolution: Battle of Port-Républicain: British troops capture the capital of Saint-Domingue.
Maximilien Robespierre inaugurates the French Revolution's new state religion, the Cult of the Supreme Being, with large organized festivals all across France.
Foundation of Anglo-Corsican Kingdom.
Empress Catherine II of Russia grants Jews permission to settle in Kyiv.
French Revolutionary Wars: Battle of Fleurus marks the first successful military use of aircraft and turns the tide of the War of the First Coalition.
Northwest Indian War: Native American forces under Blue Jacket attack Fort Recovery.
The Battle of Trippstadt between French forces and those of Prussia and Austria begins.
The 16 Carmelite Martyrs of Compiègne are executed ten days prior to the end of the French Revolution's Reign of Terror.
French Revolution: Maximilien Robespierre is arrested after encouraging the execution of more than 17,000 "enemies of the Revolution".
French Revolution: Maximilien Robespierre and Louis Antoine de Saint-Just are executed by guillotine in Paris, France.
U.S. President George Washington invokes the Militia Acts of 1792 to suppress the Whiskey Rebellion in western Pennsylvania.
Joseph Whidbey leads an expedition to search for the Northwest Passage near Juneau, Alaska.

Northwest Indian War: United States troops force a confederacy of Shawnee, Mingo, Delaware, Wyandot, Miami, Ottawa, Chippewa, and Potawatomi warriors into a disorganized retreat at the Battle of Fallen Timbers.
source_pages: Northwest_Indian_War; Shawnee; Mingo; Lenape; Wyandot_people; Miami_people; Odawa; Ojibwe; Potawatomi; Battle_of_Fallen_Timbers

event_text: French Revolutionary Wars: Arthur Wellesley (later Duke of Wellington) sees his first combat at the Battle of Boxtel during the Flanders Campaign.
Flanders Campaign: France completes its conquest of the Austrian Netherlands at the Battle of Sprimont.
The United States and the Kingdom of Great Britain sign Jay's Treaty, which attempts to resolve some of the lingering problems left over from the American Revolutionary War.
The Batavian Republic is proclaimed in the Netherlands, replacing the Dutch Republic.
After crossing the frozen Zuiderzee, the French cavalry captured 14 Dutch ships and 850 guns, in a rare occurrence of surrender of naval vessels to land forces.
The 11th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified.
The Battle of Kharda is fought between the Maratha Confederacy and the Nizam of Hyderabad, resulting in Maratha victory.
Partitions of Poland: The Duchy of Courland and Semigallia, a northern fief of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, ceases to exist and becomes part of Imperial Russia.
source_pages: Partitions_of_Poland; Duchy_of_Courland_and_Semigallia; Fief; Polish–Lithuanian_Commonwealth; Russian_Empire; March_28

event_text: Peace of Basel between France and Prussia is made.
The French First Republic adopts the kilogram and gram as its primary unit of mass.
French Revolution: The Revolutionary Tribunal is suppressed.

French Revolutionary Wars: In what became known as Cornwallis's Retreat, a British Royal Navy squadron led by Vice Admiral William Cornwallis strongly resists a much larger French Navy force and withdraws largely intact, setting up the French Navy defeat at the Battle of Groix six days later.
source_pages: French_Revolutionary_Wars; Cornwallis's_Retreat; Royal_Navy; William_Cornwallis; French_Navy; Battle_of_Groix

event_text: The burghers of Swellendam expel the Dutch East India Company magistrate and declare a republic.
Financier James Swan pays off the $2,024,899 US national debt that had been accrued during the American Revolution.
Treaty of Greenville is signed, ending the Northwest Indian War in the Ohio Country.
War of the First Coalition: The British capture Trincomalee (present-day Sri Lanka) from the Dutch in order to keep it out of French hands.
Britain seizes the Dutch Cape Colony in southern Africa to prevent its use by the Batavian Republic.
More than a year after the Battle of Sprimont, the Austrian Netherlands (present-day Belgium) are officially annexed by Revolutionary France.
source_pages: Battle_of_Sprimont; Austrian_Netherlands; Belgium; History_of_Belgium; French_Revolution; French_First_Republic

event_text: Napoleon first rises to prominence by suppressing counter-revolutionary rioters threatening the National Convention.
Poland is completely consumed by Russia, Prussia and Austria.
The United States and Spain sign the Treaty of Madrid, which establishes the boundaries between Spanish colonies and the U.S.
The French Directory, a five-man revolutionary government, is created.
Partitions of Poland: Stanisław August Poniatowski, the last king of independent Poland, is forced to abdicate and is exiled to Russia.
Construction of Yonge Street, formerly recognized as the longest street in the world, begins in York, Upper Canada (present-day Toronto).
The capital of Upper Canada is moved from Newark to York.
Colombo in Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) falls to the British, completing their invasion of Ceylon.
The Dutch East India Company is nationalized by the Batavian Republic.
Napoléon Bonaparte marries his first wife, Joséphine de Beauharnais.
Georges Cuvier delivers the first paleontological lecture.

War of the First Coalition: Napoleon Bonaparte wins his first victory as an army commander at the Battle of Montenotte, splitting the Austrian and Piedmontese armies away from each other, and marking the beginning of the Piedmontese surrender in the war.

War of the First Coalition: In the climax of the Montenotte Campaign, Napoleon Bonaparte decisively defeats the army of Piedmont at the Battle of Mondovi, leading to Piedmont's surrender a week later and decisively turning the Italian campaign in France's favor.
The Armistice of Cherasco is signed by Napoleon Bonaparte and Vittorio Amedeo III, King of Sardinia, expanding French territory along the Mediterranean coast.
War of the First Coalition: Napoleon wins a victory against Austrian forces at Lodi bridge over the Adda River in Italy. The Austrians lose some 2,000 men.
source_pages: War_of_the_First_Coalition; Napoleon; Battle_of_Lodi; Habsburg_monarchy; Lodi,_Lombardy; Adda_(river); May_10

event_text: Edward Jenner administers the first smallpox inoculation.

War of the First Coalition: In the Battle of Borghetto, Napoleon Bonaparte manages to cross the Mincio River against the Austrian army. This crossing forces the Austrians to abandon Lombardy and retreat to the Tyrol, leaving the fortress of Mantua as the sole remaining Austrian stronghold in Northern Italy.
Tennessee is admitted as the 16th state of the United States.
The United States takes possession of Detroit from Great Britain under terms of the Jay Treaty.
Surveyors of the Connecticut Land Company name an area in Ohio "Cleveland" after Gen. Moses Cleaveland, the superintendent of the surveying party.
French Revolutionary Wars: Napoleon leads the French Army of Italy to victory in the Battle of Lonato.
The Battle of Castiglione in Napoleon's first Italian campaigns of the French Revolutionary Wars results in a French victory.
French Revolutionary Wars: Battle of Bassano: French forces defeat Austrian troops at Bassano del Grappa.
Grenelle camp affair, a failed uprising by supporters of Gracchus Babeuf against the French Directory
George Washington's Farewell Address is printed across America as an open letter to the public.
French Revolutionary Wars: Battle of the Bridge of Arcole: French forces defeat the Austrians in Italy.
French Revolutionary Wars: Two British frigates under Commodore Horatio Nelson and two Spanish frigates under Commodore Don Jacobo Stuart engage in battle off the coast of Murcia.
The incorporation of Baltimore as a city.

French Revolutionary Wars: A naval battle between a French ship of the line and two British frigates off the coast of Brittany ends with the French vessel running aground, resulting in over 900 deaths.

The Battle of Rivoli is fought with a decisive French victory by Napoleon Bonaparte, marking the beginning of the end of the War of the First Coalition and the start of French hegemony over Italy for two decades.
The Riobamba earthquake strikes Ecuador, causing up to 40,000 casualties.

French Revolutionary Wars: Battle of Cape St. Vincent: John Jervis, (later 1st Earl of St Vincent) and Horatio Nelson (later 1st Viscount Nelson) lead the British Royal Navy to victory over a Spanish fleet in action near Gibraltar.
source_pages: French_Revolutionary_Wars; Battle_of_Cape_St._Vincent_(1797); John_Jervis,_1st_Earl_of_St_Vincent; Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson; Royal_Navy; Gibraltar

event_text: French Revolutionary Wars: Sir Ralph Abercromby and a fleet of 18 British warships invade Trinidad.
A force of 1,400 French soldiers invaded Britain at Fishguard in support of the Society of United Irishmen. They were defeated by 500 British reservists.
The last Invasion of Britain begins near Fishguard, Wales.
The Bank of England issues the first one-pound and two-pound banknotes.
John Adams is inaugurated as the 2nd President of the United States of America, becoming the first President to begin his presidency on March 4.
Sir Ralph Abercromby attacks San Juan, Puerto Rico, in what would be one of the largest invasions of the Spanish territories in the Americas.
Citizens of Verona begin an unsuccessful eight-day rebellion against the French occupying forces.
War of the First Coalition: Napoleon Bonaparte conquers Venice.
French troops disembark in Corfu, beginning the French rule in the Ionian Islands.

Battle of Santa Cruz de Tenerife: Battle between Spanish and British naval forces during the French Revolutionary Wars. During the Battle, Rear-Admiral Nelson is wounded in the arm and the arm had to be partially amputated.
Horatio Nelson loses more than 300 men and his right arm during the failed conquest attempt of Tenerife (Spain).
Coup of 18 Fructidor in France.
The Royal Navy decisively defeats the Batavian Navy at Camperdown during the French Revolutionary Wars.
Treaty of Campo Formio is signed between France and Austria
In Boston Harbor, the 44-gun United States Navy frigate USS Constitution is launched.
André-Jacques Garnerin makes the first recorded parachute jump, from 1,000 metres (3,300 ft) above Paris.
The Prussian heir apparent, Frederick William, becomes King of Prussia as Frederick William III.
Constantine Hangerli arrives in Bucharest, Wallachia, as its new Prince, invested by the Ottoman Empire.
source_pages: Constantine_Hangerli; Bucharest; Wallachia; List_of_princes_of_Wallachia; Ottoman_Empire; January_4

event_text: The Roman Republic is proclaimed after Louis-Alexandre Berthier, a general of Napoleon, had invaded the city of Rome five days earlier.
Louis-Alexandre Berthier removes Pope Pius VI from power.
The Mississippi Territory is organized from disputed territory claimed by both the United States and the Spanish Empire. It is expanded in 1804 and again in 1812.
French Revolutionary Wars: A French force attempting to dislodge a small British garrison on the Îles Saint-Marcouf is  repulsed with heavy losses.
The Irish Rebellion of 1798 led by the United Irishmen against British rule begins.
United Irishmen Rebellion: Battle of Carlow begins; executions of suspected rebels at Carnew and at Dunlavin Green take place.
The Pitt–Tierney duel takes place on Putney Heath outside London. A bloodless duel between the Prime Minister of Great Britain William Pitt the Younger and his political opponent George Tierney.
source_pages: Pitt–Tierney_duel; Wimbledon_Common; London; Duel; Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom; William_Pitt_the_Younger; George_Tierney; May_27

event_text: The Battle of Oulart Hill takes place in Wexford, Ireland; Irish rebel leaders defeat and kill a detachment of militia.
United Irishmen Rebellion: Between 300 and 500 United Irishmen are executed as rebels by the British Army in County Kildare, Ireland.
Battle of New Ross: The attempt to spread the United Irish Rebellion into Munster is defeated.
Irish Rebellion of 1798: Battles of Arklow and Saintfield.
Irish Rebellion of 1798: Battle of Ballynahinch.
Irish Rebellion of 1798: The British Army defeats Irish rebels at the Battle of Vinegar Hill.
As a result of the XYZ Affair, the US Congress rescinds the Treaty of Alliance with France sparking the "Quasi-War".
The United States Marine Corps is re-established; they had been disbanded after the American Revolutionary War.
The Sedition Act of 1798 becomes law in the United States making it a federal crime to write, publish, or utter false or malicious statements about the United States government.
French campaign in Egypt and Syria: Napoleon's forces defeat an Ottoman-Mamluk army near Cairo in the Battle of the Pyramids.
source_pages: French_invasion_of_Egypt_and_Syria; Napoleon; Ottoman_Empire; Mamluk; Cairo; Battle_of_the_Pyramids

event_text: French Revolutionary Wars: Battle of the Nile (Battle of Aboukir Bay): Battle begins when a British fleet engages the French Revolutionary Navy fleet in an unusual night action.
French Revolutionary Wars: The Battle of the Nile concludes in a British victory.
The Vietnamese Catholics report a Marian apparition in Quảng Trị, an event which is called Our Lady of La Vang.
French troops land at Kilcummin, County Mayo, Ireland to aid the rebellion.

Wolfe Tone's United Irish and French forces clash with the British Army in the Battle of Castlebar, part of the Irish Rebellion of 1798, resulting in the creation of the French puppet Republic of Connacht.
source_pages: Wolfe_Tone; Society_of_United_Irishmen; French_Revolutionary_Army; British_Army; Battle_of_Castlebar; Irish_Rebellion_of_1798; Sister_republic; Irish_Republic_(1798)

event_text: Irish Rebellion: Irish rebels, with French assistance, establish the short-lived Republic of Connacht.
The week long battle of St. George's Caye begins between Spain and Britain off the coast of Belize.
Conscription is made mandatory in France by the Jourdan law.
At the Battle of St. George's Caye, British Honduras defeats Spain.
Flemish and Luxembourgish peasants launch the rebellion against French rule known as the Peasants' War.
The forces of Ali Pasha of Janina defeat the French and capture the town of Preveza in the Battle of Nicopolis.
The Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu begins.
Trade between the United States and modern-day Uruguay begins when John Leamy's frigate John arrives in Montevideo.
British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the Napoleonic Wars.
source_pages: Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom; William_Pitt_the_Younger; Income_tax; Shilling; Pound_sterling; Napoleonic_Wars; January_9

event_text: Maltese patriot Dun Mikiel Xerri, along with a number of other patriots, is executed.
The Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu ends with the surrender of the French garrison.
Napoleon Bonaparte captures Jaffa in Palestine and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.
source_pages: Napoleon; Siege_of_Jaffa; Jaffa; Palestine_(region); Albania; March_7

event_text: French Revolutionary Wars: The Battle of Mount Tabor: Napoleon drives Ottoman Turks across the River Jordan near Acre.
source_pages: French_Revolutionary_Wars; Battle_of_Mount_Tabor_(1799); Napoleon; Ottoman_Turks; Jordan_River; Acre,_Israel

event_text: Fourth Anglo-Mysore War: The Battle of Seringapatam: The siege of Seringapatam ends when the city is invaded and Tipu Sultan killed by the besieging British army, under the command of General George Harris.
source_pages: Fourth_Anglo-Mysore_War; Siege_of_Seringapatam_(1799); Srirangapatna; Tipu_Sultan; George_Harris,_1st_Baron_Harris; May_4

event_text: The end of the Siege of Acre (1799): Napoleon Bonaparte abandons his siege of the Ottoman city of Acre after two months. This was the turning point of Bonaparte's Egyptian campaign and one of the first major defeats he suffered in his military career.
War of the Second Coalition: Austrian forces defeat the French at Winterthur, Switzerland.
Action of 18 June 1799: A frigate squadron under Rear-admiral Jean-Baptiste Perrée is captured by the British fleet under Lord Keith.
Ranjit Singh conquers Lahore and becomes Maharaja of the Punjab (Sikh Empire).
The Rosetta Stone is found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard during Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign.
source_pages: Rosetta_Stone; Egypt; Rosetta; Captain_(armed_forces); Pierre-François_Bouchard; Napoleon; French_invasion_of_Egypt_and_Syria; July_15

event_text: Tekle Giyorgis I begins his first of six reigns as Emperor of Ethiopia.
Napoleon Bonaparte defeats a numerically superior Ottoman army under Mustafa Pasha at the Battle of Abukir.
Napoleon Bonaparte leaves Egypt for France en route to seizing power.
The entire Dutch fleet is captured by British forces under the command of Sir Ralph Abercromby and Admiral Sir Charles Mitchell during the War of the Second Coalition.
French Revolutionary Wars: French-Dutch victory against the Russians and British in the Battle of Bergen.
War of the 2nd Coalition: French troops defeat Austro-Russian forces, leading to the collapse of Suvorov's campaign.
HMS Lutine sinks with the loss of 240 men and a cargo worth £1,200,000.
Jeanne Geneviève Labrosse becomes the first woman to jump from a balloon with a parachute.
Napoleon Bonaparte leads the Coup of 18 Brumaire ending the Directory government, and becoming First Consul of the successor Consulate Government.
War of the Second Coalition: Battle of Wiesloch: Austrian Lieutenant Field Marshal Anton Sztáray defeats the French at Wiesloch.
source_pages: War_of_the_Second_Coalition; Battle_of_Wiesloch_(1799); Austrian_Empire; Anton_Sztáray; First_French_Empire; Wiesloch; December_3

event_text: France adopts the metre as its official unit of length.
Henry Lee III's eulogy to George Washington in congress declares him as "first in war, first in peace and first in the hearts of his countrymen".
With the church leadership driven out of Rome during an armed conflict, Pius VII is crowned Pope in Venice with a temporary papal tiara made of papier-mâché.
source_pages: Papal_States; Rome; Pope_Pius_VII; Papal_coronation; Venice; List_of_papal_tiaras_in_existence

event_text: Ludwig van Beethoven leads the premiere of his First Symphony in Vienna.

The Treaty of Constantinople establishes the Septinsular Republic, the first autonomous Greek state since the Fall of the Byzantine Empire. (Under the Old Style calendar then still in use in the Ottoman Empire, the treaty was signed on 21 March.)
The Septinsular Republic is established.
The United States Library of Congress is established when President John Adams signs legislation to appropriate $5,000 to purchase "such books as may be necessary for the use of Congress".
The 6th United States Congress recesses, and the process of moving the Federal government of the United States from Philadelphia to Washington, D.C., begins the following day.
David Thompson reaches the mouth of the Saskatchewan River in Manitoba.
The French Army of First Consul Napoleon Bonaparte defeats the Austrians at the Battle of Marengo in Northern Italy and re-conquers Italy.
War of the Second Coalition Battle of Höchstädt results in a French victory over Austria.
The Acts of Union 1800 are passed which merge the Kingdom of Great Britain and the Kingdom of Ireland into the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
Gabriel Prosser postpones a planned slave rebellion in Richmond, Virginia, but is arrested before he can make it happen.
The French garrison in Valletta surrenders to British troops who had been called at the invitation of the Maltese. The islands of Malta and Gozo become the Malta Protectorate.
The Maltese National Congress Battalions are disbanded by British Civil Commissioner Alexander Ball.
Via the Third Treaty of San Ildefonso, Spain cedes Louisiana to France, which would sell the land to the United States thirty months later.
French corsair Robert Surcouf, commander of the 18-gun ship La Confiance, captures the British 38-gun Kent.
War of the Second Coalition: Britain takes control of the Dutch colony of Curaçao.
John Adams becomes the first President of the United States to live in the Executive Mansion (later renamed the White House).
The United States Congress holds its first session in Washington, D.C.

War of the Second Coalition: Battle of Hohenlinden: French General Jean Victor Marie Moreau decisively defeats the Archduke John of Austria near Munich. Coupled with First Consul Napoleon Bonaparte's earlier victory at Marengo, this will force the Austrians to sign an armistice and end the war.
source_pages: Battle_of_Hohenlinden; Jean_Victor_Marie_Moreau; Archduke_John_of_Austria; Munich; French_Consulate; Napoleon; Battle_of_Marengo; Treaty_of_Lunéville; December_3

event_text: United States presidential election: The Electoral College casts votes for president and vice president that result in a tie between Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr.
The Plot of the rue Saint-Nicaise fails to kill Napoleon Bonaparte.
The legislative union of Kingdom of Great Britain and Kingdom of Ireland is completed, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland is proclaimed.
Ceres, the largest and first known object in the Asteroid belt, is discovered by Giuseppe Piazzi.
John Marshall is sworn in as Chief Justice of the United States.

United States presidential election: A tie in the Electoral College between Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr is resolved when Jefferson is elected President of the United States and Burr Vice President by the United States House of Representatives.
source_pages: 1800_United_States_presidential_election; United_States_Electoral_College; Thomas_Jefferson; Aaron_Burr; President_of_the_United_States; Vice_President_of_the_United_States; United_States_House_of_Representatives

event_text: Pursuant to the District of Columbia Organic Act of 1801, Washington, D.C. is placed under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Congress.
War of the Second Coalition: At the Battle of Abukir, a British force under Sir Ralph Abercromby lands in Egypt with the aim of ending the French campaign in Egypt and Syria.
The Battle of Alexandria is fought between British and French forces near the ruins of Nicopolis near Alexandria in Egypt.
Tsar Paul I of Russia is struck with a sword, then strangled, and finally trampled to death inside his bedroom at St. Michael's Castle.
Treaty of Florence is signed, ending the war between the French Republic and the Kingdom of Naples.

French Revolutionary Wars: In the Battle of Copenhagen a British Royal Navy squadron defeats a hastily assembled, smaller, mostly-volunteer Dano-Norwegian Navy at high cost, forcing Denmark out of the Second League of Armed Neutrality.
source_pages: French_Revolutionary_Wars; Battle_of_Copenhagen_(1801); Royal_Navy; Royal_Danish_Navy; Denmark; Second_League_of_Armed_Neutrality; April_2

event_text: Captain Thomas Cochrane in the 14-gun HMS Speedy captures the 32-gun Spanish frigate El Gamo.
First Barbary War: The Barbary pirates of Tripoli declare war on the United States of America.
First Battle of Algeciras: Outnumbered French Navy ships defeat the Royal Navy in the fortified Spanish port of Algeciras.
French astronomer Jean-Louis Pons makes his first comet discovery. In the next 27 years he discovers another 36 comets, more than any other person in history.
British ships inflict heavy damage on Spanish and French ships in the Second Battle of Algeciras.
First Barbary War: The American schooner USS Enterprise captures the Tripolitan polacca Tripoli in a single-ship action off the coast of modern-day Libya.
source_pages: First_Barbary_War; Schooner; USS_Enterprise_(1799); Action_of_1_August_1801; Tripoli,_Libya; Polacca; List_of_single-ship_actions; Libya

event_text: Alexander I of Russia confirms the privileges of Baltic provinces.
The Army Corps of Engineers is established to found and operate the United States Military Academy at West Point.
The Treaty of Amiens is signed as a "Definitive Treaty of Peace" between France and the United Kingdom.
Heinrich Wilhelm Matthäus Olbers discovers 2 Pallas, the second asteroid ever to be discovered.
Twelve thousand Wahhabis sack Karbala, killing over three thousand inhabitants.
Napoleon Bonaparte signs a general amnesty to allow all but about one thousand of the most notorious émigrés of the French Revolution to return to France.

Washington, D.C. is incorporated as a city after Congress abolishes the Board of Commissioners, the District's founding government. The "City of Washington" is given a mayor-council form of government.
Napoleon Bonaparte founds the Legion of Honour.
By the Law of 20 May 1802, Napoleon Bonaparte reinstates slavery in the French colonies, revoking its abolition in the French Revolution.
In Guadeloupe, 400 rebellious slaves, led by Louis Delgrès, blow themselves up rather than submit to Napoleon's troops.
King Charles Emmanuel IV of Sardinia abdicates his throne in favor of his brother, Victor Emmanuel.
The United States Military Academy opens at West Point, New York.
Emperor Gia Long conquers Hanoi and unified Viet Nam, which had experienced centuries of feudal warfare.
France annexes the Kingdom of Piedmont.
The Garinagu arrive at British Honduras (present-day Belize).
In Marbury v. Madison, the Supreme Court of the United States establishes the principle of judicial review.
Thousands of meteor fragments fall from the skies of L'Aigle, France; the event convinces European scientists that meteors exist.
Louisiana Purchase: The United States purchases the Louisiana Territory from France for $15 million, more than doubling the size of the young nation.
Napoleonic Wars: The United Kingdom revokes the Treaty of Amiens and declares war on France.
Haitian Revolution: The Royal Navy led by Rear-Admiral John Thomas Duckworth commence the blockade of Saint-Domingue against French forces.
The Louisiana Purchase is announced to the US people.
The Convention of Artlenburg is signed, leading to the French occupation of the Electorate of Hanover (which had been ruled by the British king).
The Surrey Iron Railway, arguably the world's first public railway, opens in south London, United Kingdom.
British scientist John Dalton begins using symbols to represent the atoms of different elements.
The Battle of Delhi, during the Second Anglo-Maratha War, between British troops under General Lake, and Marathas of Scindia's army under General Louis Bourquin ends in a British victory.
source_pages: Battle_of_Delhi_(1803); Second_Anglo-Maratha_War; Gerard_Lake,_1st_Viscount_Lake; Marathi_people; House_of_Scindia; September_11

event_text: Second Anglo-Maratha War: The Battle of Assaye is fought between the British East India Company and the Maratha Empire in India.
The United States Senate ratifies the Louisiana Purchase.
The Battle of Vertières, the last major battle of the Haitian Revolution, is fought, leading to the establishment of the Republic of Haiti, the first black republic in the Western Hemisphere.
The Balmis Expedition starts in Spain with the aim of vaccinating millions against smallpox in Spanish America and Philippines.
In New Orleans, Spanish representatives officially transfer the Louisiana Territory to the French First Republic.
Five French warships attempting to escape the Royal Naval blockade of Saint-Domingue are all seized by British warships, signifying the end of the Haitian Revolution.
The Louisiana Purchase is completed at a ceremony in New Orleans.
French rule ends in Haiti. Haiti becomes the first black-majority republic and second independent country in North America after the United States.
Karađorđe leads the First Serbian Uprising against the Ottoman Empire.
First Barbary War: Stephen Decatur leads a raid to burn the pirate-held frigate USS Philadelphia.
The first self-propelling steam locomotive makes its outing at the Pen-y-Darren Ironworks in Wales.
Castle Hill Rebellion: Irish convicts rebel against British colonial authority in the Colony of New South Wales.
Code Napoléon is adopted as French civil law.
Forces sent by Yusuf Karamanli of Tripoli to retake Derna from the Americans attack the city.
William Clark and 42 men depart from Camp Dubois to join Meriwether Lewis at St Charles, Missouri, marking the beginning of the Lewis and Clark Expedition's historic journey up the Missouri River.
source_pages: William_Clark; Camp_Dubois; Meriwether_Lewis; St._Charles,_Missouri; Lewis_and_Clark_Expedition; Missouri_River; May_14

event_text: Napoleon Bonaparte is proclaimed Emperor of the French by the French Senate.
The Lewis and Clark Expedition officially begins as the Corps of Discovery departs from St. Charles, Missouri.
New Hampshire approves the Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution, ratifying the document.
A duel occurs in which the Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr mortally wounds former Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton.
Francis II assumes the title of first Emperor of Austria.
3 Juno, one of the largest asteroids in the Main Belt, is discovered by the German astronomer Karl Ludwig Harding.
The Teton Sioux (a subdivision of the Lakota) demand one of the boats from the Lewis and Clark Expedition as a toll for allowing the expedition to move further upriver.
Hobart, capital of Tasmania, is founded.
At Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor of the French.
The United States House of Representatives adopts articles of impeachment against Supreme Court Justice Samuel Chase.
The Michigan Territory is created.
Justice Samuel Chase is acquitted at the end of his impeachment trial before the U.S. Senate.
The Italian Republic, with Napoleon as president, becomes the Kingdom of Italy, with Napoleon as King of Italy.
Lewis and Clark Expedition: The Corps of Discovery breaks camp among the Mandan tribe and resumes its journey West along the Missouri River.
German composer Ludwig van Beethoven premieres his Third Symphony, at the Theater an der Wien in Vienna.
First Barbary War: United States Marines captured Derne under the command of First Lieutenant Presley O'Bannon.
source_pages: First_Barbary_War; United_States_Marine_Corps; Battle_of_Derna_(1805); Derna,_Libya; First_lieutenant; Presley_O'Bannon

event_text: First Barbary War: United States Marines and Berbers attack the Tripolitan city of Derna (The "shores of Tripoli" in the Marines' Hymn).
source_pages: First_Barbary_War; United_States_Marine_Corps; Berbers; Tripoli,_Libya; Derna,_Libya; Marines'_Hymn

event_text: Muhammad Ali becomes Wāli of Egypt.
Napoléon Bonaparte assumes the title of King of Italy and is crowned with the Iron Crown of Lombardy in Milan Cathedral, the gothic cathedral in Milan.
source_pages: Napoleon; King_of_Italy; Iron_Crown; Milan_Cathedral; Gothic_architecture; Milan

event_text: French and Spanish forces begin the assault against British forces occupying Diamond Rock, Martinique.
Napoleonic Wars: A Franco-Spanish fleet recaptures from the British the island of Diamond Rock, which guards the entrance to the bay leading to Fort-de-France, Martinique.
source_pages: Napoleonic_Wars; First_French_Empire; Enlightenment_in_Spain; Battle_of_Diamond_Rock; Diamond_Rock; Fort-de-France; June_2

event_text: First Barbary War: Yusuf Karamanli signs a treaty ending the hostilities between Tripolitania and the United States.
A fire consumes large portions of Detroit in the Michigan Territory.
Lewis and Clark Expedition: Scouting ahead of the expedition, Meriwether Lewis and four companions sight the Great Falls of the Missouri River.
Under An act to divide the Indiana Territory into two separate governments, adopted by the U.S. Congress on January 11, 1805, the Michigan Territory is organized.

Napoleonic Wars: War of the Third Coalition: Battle of Cape Finisterre: An inconclusive naval action is fought between a combined French and Spanish fleet under Admiral Pierre-Charles Villeneuve of France and a British fleet under Admiral Robert Calder.
War of the Third Coalition: A French corps defeats an Austrian attempt to escape encirclement at Ulm.
War of the Third Coalition: Napoleon surrounds the Austrian army at Ulm.
War of the Third Coalition: Austrian General Mack surrenders his army to Napoleon at the Battle of Ulm.
Napoleonic Wars: A British fleet led by Lord Nelson defeats a combined French and Spanish fleet under Admiral Villeneuve in the Battle of Trafalgar.
Napoleon Bonaparte invades Austria during the War of the Third Coalition.
Napoleonic Wars: Battle of Dürenstein: Eight thousand French troops attempt to slow the retreat of a vastly superior Russian and Austrian force.
Napoleonic Wars: Battle of Schöngrabern: Russian forces under Pyotr Bagration delay the pursuit by French troops under Joachim Murat.
Beethoven's only opera, Fidelio, premieres in Vienna.
Official opening of Thomas Telford's Pontcysyllte Aqueduct.
War of the Third Coalition: Battle of Austerlitz: French troops under Napoleon decisively defeat a joint Russo-Austrian force.
source_pages: War_of_the_Third_Coalition; Battle_of_Austerlitz; Napoleon; Russian_Empire; Austrian_Empire; December_2

event_text: Austria and France sign the Treaty of Pressburg.
The French Republican Calendar is abolished.
The Dutch Cape Colony in southern Africa becomes the British Cape Colony as a result of the Battle of Blaauwberg.
Admiral Horatio Lord Nelson receives a state funeral and is interred in St Paul's Cathedral.
Jan Willem Janssens surrenders the Dutch Cape Colony to the British.
The original Lower Trenton Bridge (also called the Trenton Makes the World Takes Bridge), which spans the Delaware River between Morrisville, Pennsylvania and Trenton, New Jersey, is opened.
Battle of San Domingo: British naval victory against the French in the Caribbean.
After traveling through the Louisiana Purchase and reaching the Pacific Ocean, explorers Lewis and Clark and their Corps of Discovery begin their arduous journey home.
Construction is authorized of the Great National Pike, better known as the Cumberland Road, becoming the first United States federal highway.
Action of 21 April 1806: A French frigate escapes British forces off the coast of South Africa.
Future U.S. President Andrew Jackson kills Charles Dickinson in a duel.
British forces take Buenos Aires during the first of the British invasions of the River Plate.
The Vellore Mutiny is the first instance of a mutiny by Indian sepoys against the British East India Company.
At the insistence of Napoleon, Bavaria, Baden, Württemberg and thirteen minor principalities leave the Holy Roman Empire and form the Confederation of the Rhine.
Pike Expedition: United States Army Lieutenant Zebulon Pike begins an expedition from Fort Bellefontaine near St. Louis, Missouri,  to explore the west.
source_pages: Pike_Expedition; United_States_Army; Lieutenant; Zebulon_Pike; Fort_Belle_Fontaine; St._Louis

event_text: A gunpowder magazine explosion in Birgu, Malta, kills around 200 people.
Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor, declares the moribund empire to be dissolved, although he retains power in the Austrian Empire.
Santiago de Liniers, 1st Count of Buenos Aires re-takes the city of Buenos Aires, Argentina after the first British invasion.
Battle of Mišar during the Serbian Revolution begins. The battle ends two days later with a Serbian victory over the Ottomans.
A massive landslide destroys the town of Goldau, Switzerland, killing 457.
Prussia begins the War of the Fourth Coalition against France.
War of the Fourth Coalition: Napoleon decisively defeats Prussia at the Battle of Jena–Auerstedt.
Former leader of the Haitian Revolution, Emperor Jacques I, is assassinated after an oppressive rule.
The French Army under Napoleon enters Berlin following the Prussian defeat at the Battle of Jena–Auerstedt.
War of the Fourth Coalition: Convinced that he is facing a much larger force, Prussian General von Romberg, commanding 5,300 men, surrenders the city of Stettin to 800 French soldiers.
Pike Expedition: Lieutenant Zebulon Pike spots a mountain peak while near the Colorado foothills of the Rocky Mountains. It is later named Pikes Peak in his honor.
Battles of Pultusk and Golymin: Russian forces hold French forces under Napoleon.
A British military force, under Brigadier-General Sir Samuel Auchmuty captures the Spanish Empire city of Montevideo, now the capital of Uruguay.
Napoleonic Wars: Napoleon finds Bennigsen's Russian forces taking a stand at Eylau. After bitter fighting, the French take the town, but the Russians resume the battle the next day.
Napoleon defeats the coalition forces of Russian General Bennigsen and Prussian General L'Estocq at the Battle of Eylau.
source_pages: Napoleon; War_of_the_Fourth_Coalition; Russian_Empire; Levin_August_von_Bennigsen; Prussia; Anton_Wilhelm_von_L'Estocq; Battle_of_Eylau; February_8

event_text: Former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr is arrested for treason in Wakefield, Alabama, and confined to Fort Stoddert.
The U.S. Congress passes the Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves, disallowing the importation of new slaves into the country.
The Swansea and Mumbles Railway, then known as the Oystermouth Railway, becomes the first passenger-carrying railway in the world.
The Froberg mutiny on Malta ends when the remaining mutineers blow up the magazine of Fort Ricasoli.
The Slave Trade Act 1807 takes effect, abolishing the slave trade within the British Empire.
A grand jury indicts former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr on a charge of treason.
Mustafa IV became Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and Caliph of Islam.
Emperor Napoleon's French Grande Armée defeats the Russian Army at the Battle of Friedland in Poland (modern Russian  Kaliningrad Oblast) ending the War of the Fourth Coalition.
source_pages: Napoleon; Grande_Armée; Russian_Empire; Battle_of_Friedland; Kaliningrad_Oblast; War_of_the_Fourth_Coalition

event_text: In the Chesapeake–Leopard affair, the British warship HMS Leopard attacks and boards the American frigate USS Chesapeake.
Second British invasion of the Río de la Plata; John Whitelocke lands at Ensenada on an attempt to recapture Buenos Aires and is defeated by the locals.
Russo-Turkish War: Admiral Dmitry Senyavin destroys the Ottoman fleet in the Battle of Athos.
In Buenos Aires the local militias repel the British soldiers within the Second English Invasion.
The first Treaty of Tilsit between France and Russia is signed, ending hostilities between the two countries in the War of the Fourth Coalition.
The second Treaty of Tilsit is signed between France and Prussia, ending the War of the Fourth Coalition.
Nicéphore Niépce is awarded a patent by Napoleon for the Pyréolophore, the world's first internal combustion engine, after it successfully powered a boat upstream on the river Saône in France.
Robert Fulton's North River Steamboat leaves New York City for Albany, New York, on the Hudson River, inaugurating the first commercial steamboat service in the world.
British troops under Sir Arthur Wellesley defeat a Danish militia outside Copenhagen in the Battle of Køge.
Napoleonic Wars: The British Royal Navy bombards Copenhagen with fire bombs and phosphorus rockets to prevent Denmark from surrendering its fleet to Napoleon.
Beethoven's Mass in C major, Op. 86, is premiered, commissioned by Nikolaus I, Prince Esterházy, and displeasing him.
John VI of Portugal flees Lisbon from advancing Napoleonic forces during the Peninsular War, transferring the Portuguese court to Brazil.
Napoleonic Wars: France issues the Milan Decree, which confirms the Continental System.
The Embargo Act, forbidding trade with all foreign countries, is passed by the U.S. Congress at the urging of President Thomas Jefferson.
The United States bans the importation of slaves.

John Rennie's scheme to defend St Mary's Church, Reculver, founded in 669, from coastal erosion is abandoned in favour of demolition, despite the church being an exemplar of Anglo-Saxon architecture and sculpture.
source_pages: John_Rennie_the_Elder; St_Mary's_Church,_Reculver; Coastal_erosion; Anglo-Saxon_architecture; Anglo-Saxon_art; January_12

event_text: The organizational meeting leading to the creation of the Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is held in Edinburgh.
The Portuguese royal family arrives in Brazil after fleeing the French army's invasion of Portugal two months earlier.
The Rum Rebellion is the only successful (albeit short-lived) armed takeover of the government in New South Wales.
Jesse Fell burns anthracite on an open grate as an experiment in heating homes with coal.

Without a previous declaration of war, Russian troops cross the border to Sweden at Abborfors in eastern Finland, thus beginning the Finnish War, in which Sweden will lose the eastern half of the country (i.e. Finland) to Russia.
Charles IV, king of Spain, abdicates after riots and a popular revolt at the winter palace Aranjuez. His son, Ferdinand VII, takes the throne.
John Jacob Astor incorporates the American Fur Company, that would eventually make him America's first millionaire.
Dano-Swedish War of 1808–1809: The Battle of Trangen took place at Trangen in Flisa, Hedemarkens Amt, between Swedish and Norwegian troops.
Outbreak of the Peninsular War: The people of Madrid rise up in rebellion against French occupation. Francisco de Goya later memorializes this event in his painting The Second of May 1808.
Finnish War: Sweden loses the fortress of Sveaborg to Russia.
Peninsular War: The Madrid rebels who rose up on May 2 are executed near Príncipe Pío hill.
Finnish War: Swedish-Finnish troops, led by Captain Karl Wilhelm Malmi, conquer the city of Kuopio from Russians after the Battle of Kuopio.
The Finnish War: the Battle of Lapua is fought.
Mahmud II became Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and Caliph of Islam.
Finnish War: Swedish forces led by General von Döbeln defeat Russian forces led by General Šepelev in the Battle of Kauhajoki.
The Finnish War: The Battle of Alavus is fought.

Battle of Vimeiro: British and Portuguese forces led by General Arthur Wellesley defeat French force under Major-General Jean-Andoche Junot near the village of Vimeiro, Portugal, the first Anglo-Portuguese victory of the Peninsular War.
source_pages: Battle_of_Vimeiro; United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland; Portuguese_people; Arthur_Wellesley,_1st_Duke_of_Wellington; French_Armed_Forces; Jean-Andoche_Junot; Vimeiro; Peninsular_War

event_text: The Treaty of Paris is signed ending the French military occupation of Prussia.
Finnish War: In the Battle of Jutas, Swedish forces under Lieutenant General Georg Carl von Döbeln beat the Russians, making von Döbeln a Swedish war hero.
Finnish War: Russians defeat the Swedes at the Battle of Oravais.
The Republic of Ragusa is annexed by France.
Finnish War: The Convention of Olkijoki in Raahe ends hostilities in Finland.
French and Poles defeat the Spanish at Battle of Tudela.
Napoleonic Wars: Under the orders by commander Tomás de Morla, the city of Madrid surrenders to French Emperor Napoleon I after a 4 day long siege.
Peninsular War: The Siege of Zaragoza begins.
Ludwig van Beethoven conducts and performs in concert at the Theater an der Wien, Vienna, with the premiere of his Fifth Symphony, Sixth Symphony, Fourth Piano Concerto and Choral Fantasy.
source_pages: Ludwig_van_Beethoven; Beethoven_concert_of_22_December_1808; Symphony_No._5_(Beethoven); Symphony_No._6_(Beethoven); Piano_Concerto_No._4_(Beethoven); Choral_Fantasy_(Beethoven); December_22

event_text: Combined British, Portuguese and colonial Brazilian forces begin the Invasion of Cayenne during the Napoleonic Wars.
Peninsular War: The British defeat the French at the Battle of La Coruña.
The Territory of Illinois is created by the 10th United States Congress.
London's Drury Lane Theatre burns to the ground, leaving its owner, Irish writer and politician Richard Brinsley Sheridan, destitute.
Britain invades and captures the French colony of Martinique.
Action of 27 February 1809: Captain Bernard Dubourdieu captures HMS Proserpine.
Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden is deposed in the Coup of 1809.
Peninsular War: A combined Franco-Polish force defeats the Spanish in the Battle of Ciudad Real.
Peninsular War: France defeats Spain in the Battle of Medellín.
King Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden abdicates after a coup d'état.
At the Diet of Porvoo, Finland's four Estates pledge allegiance to Alexander I of Russia, commencing the secession of the Grand Duchy of Finland from Sweden.
source_pages: Diet_of_Porvoo; Riksdag_of_the_Estates; Alexander_I_of_Russia; Grand_Duchy_of_Finland; Lands_of_Sweden; March_29

event_text: Napoleonic Wars: The War of the Fifth Coalition begins when forces of the Austrian Empire invade Bavaria.
Battle of the Basque Roads: Admiral Lord Gambier fails to support Captain Lord Cochrane, leading to an incomplete British victory over the French fleet.

An Austrian corps is defeated by the forces of the Duchy of Warsaw in the Battle of Raszyn, part of the struggles of the Fifth Coalition. On the same day the Austrian main army is defeated by a First French Empire Corps led by Louis-Nicolas Davout at the Battle of Teugen-Hausen in Bavaria, part of a four-day campaign that ended in a French victory.
source_pages: Duchy_of_Warsaw; Battle_of_Raszyn_(1809); War_of_the_Fifth_Coalition; First_French_Empire; Louis-Nicolas_Davout; Battle_of_Teugen-Hausen

event_text: Two Austrian army corps in Bavaria are defeated by a First French Empire army led by Napoleon at the Battle of Abensberg on the second day of a four-day campaign that ended in a French victory.

Two Austrian army corps are driven from Landshut by a First French Empire army led by Napoleon as two French corps to the north hold off the main Austrian army on the first day of the Battle of Eckmühl.
The second day of the Battle of Eckmühl: The Austrian army is defeated by the First French Empire army led by Napoleon and driven over the Danube in Regensburg.
source_pages: Battle_of_Eckmühl; Austrian_Empire; First_French_Empire; Napoleon; Danube; Regensburg

event_text: Mary Kies becomes the first woman awarded a U.S. patent, for a technique of weaving straw with silk and thread.
source_pages: Mary_Dixon_Kies; Patent; Weaving; Straw; Silk; Yarn

event_text: Emperor Napoleon I orders the annexation of the Papal States to the French Empire.
The first day of the Battle of Aspern-Essling between the Austrian army led by Archduke Charles and the French army led by Napoleon I of France sees the French attack across the Danube held.

On the second and last day of the Battle of Aspern-Essling (near Vienna, Austria), Napoleon I is defeated in a major battle for the first time in his career, and repelled by an enemy army for the first time in a decade.
Chuquisaca Revolution: Patriot revolt in Chuquisaca (modern-day Sucre) against the Spanish Empire, sparking the Latin American wars of independence.
The Battle of Wagram between the French and Austrian Empires begins.
The second day of the Battle of Wagram; France defeats the Austrian army in the largest battle to date of the Napoleonic Wars.

The city of La Paz, in what is today Bolivia, declares its independence from the Spanish Crown during the La Paz revolution and forms the Junta Tuitiva, the first independent government in Spanish America, led by Pedro Domingo Murillo.
Peninsular War: Battle of Talavera: Sir Arthur Wellesley's British, Portuguese and Spanish army defeats a French force led by Joseph Bonaparte.
The Senate of Finland is established in the Grand Duchy of Finland after the official adoption of the Statute of the Government Council by Tsar Alexander I of Russia.
Peace between Sweden and Russia in the Finnish War; the territory that will become Finland is ceded to Russia by the Treaty of Fredrikshamn.
The Royal Opera House in London opens.
British Secretary of War Lord Castlereagh and Foreign Secretary George Canning meet in a duel on Putney Heath, with Castlereagh wounding Canning in the thigh.
source_pages: Secretary_of_State_for_War_and_the_Colonies; Robert_Stewart,_Viscount_Castlereagh; Foreign_Secretary_(United_Kingdom); George_Canning; Castlereagh–Canning_duel; Wimbledon_Common; September_21

event_text: The Treaty of Schönbrunn is signed, ending the War of the Fifth Coalition, the final successful war in Napoleon Bonaparte's military career.
Golden Jubilee of George III is celebrated in Britain as he begins the fiftieth year of his reign.
In a naval action during the Napoleonic Wars, French frigates defeat British East Indiamen in the Bay of Bengal.
source_pages: Action_of_18_November_1809; Napoleonic_Wars; Frigate; East_Indiaman; Bay_of_Bengal; November_18

event_text: The Berners Street hoax is perpetrated by Theodore Hook in the City of Westminster, London.
Dr. Ephraim McDowell performs the first ovariotomy, removing a 22-pound tumor.
Major-General Lachlan Macquarie officially becomes Governor of New South Wales.
Napoleonic Wars: Britain seizes Guadeloupe.
Peninsular War: Siege of Cádiz begins.
Venezuela achieves home rule: Vicente Emparán, Governor of the Captaincy General is removed by the people of Caracas and a junta is installed.
source_pages: Venezuela; Vicente_Emparán; Governor; General_Captaincy; Caracas; Supreme_Junta

event_text: May Revolution: Citizens of Buenos Aires expel Viceroy Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros during the "May Week", starting the Argentine War of Independence.
The newspaper Gazeta de Buenos Ayres is first published in Argentina.
John Jacob Astor forms the Pacific Fur Company.
Napoleon annexes the Kingdom of Holland as part of the First French Empire.
Citizens of Bogotá, New Granada declare independence from Spain.
Napoleon annexes Westphalia as part of the First French Empire.
Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte, Marshal of France, is elected Crown Prince of Sweden by the Swedish Riksdag of the Estates.
The former viceroy Santiago de Liniers of the Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata is executed after the defeat of his counter-revolution.
Napoleonic Wars: The French Navy defeats the British Royal Navy, preventing them from taking the harbour of Grand Port on Île de France.
Napoleonic Wars: The French Navy accepts the surrender of a British Royal Navy fleet at the Battle of Grand Port.
The Tonquin sets sail from New York Harbor with 33 employees of John Jacob Astor's newly created Pacific Fur Company on board.
With the Grito de Dolores, Father Miguel Hidalgo begins Mexico's fight for independence from Spain.
First Government Junta in Chile. Though supposed to rule only during the Peninsular War in Spain, it is in fact the first step towards independence from Spain, and is commemorated as such.
A new Act of Succession is adopted by the Riksdag of the Estates, and Jean Baptiste Bernadotte becomes heir to the Swedish throne.
A large fire destroys a third of all the buildings in the town of Raahe in the Grand Duchy of Finland.
The citizens of Munich hold the first Oktoberfest in celebration of the marriage of Crown Prince Louis of Bavaria and Princess Therese of Saxe-Hildburghausen.
United States annexes the former Spanish colony of West Florida.
Sweden declares war on its ally the United Kingdom to begin the Anglo-Swedish War, although no fighting ever takes place.
Charles Deslondes leads an unsuccessful slave revolt in the North American settlements of St. Charles and St. James, Louisiana.
Mexican War of Independence: In the Battle of Calderón Bridge, a heavily outnumbered Spanish force of 6,000 troops defeats nearly 100,000 Mexican revolutionaries.
Leaders of the Mamluk dynasty are killed by Egyptian ruler Muhammad Ali.
Argentine War of Independence: A royalist fleet defeats a small flotilla of revolutionary ships in the Battle of San Nicolás on the River Plate.
source_pages: Argentine_War_of_Independence; Spanish_Empire; Flotilla; May_Revolution; Battle_of_San_Nicolás; Río_de_la_Plata

event_text: Peninsular War: A French force under the command of Marshal Victor is routed while trying to prevent an Anglo-Spanish-Portuguese army from lifting the Siege of Cádiz in the Battle of Barrosa.
Paraguayan forces defeat Manuel Belgrano at the Battle of Tacuarí.
Peninsular War: A day after a successful rearguard action, French Marshal Michel Ney once again successfully delays the pursuing Anglo-Portuguese force at the Battle of Redinha.
source_pages: Peninsular_War; Rearguard; Marshal_of_France; Michel_Ney; Portugal; Battle_of_Redinha; March_12

event_text: A French and Italian fleet is defeated by a British squadron off the island of Vis in the Adriatic during the Napoleonic Wars.
Percy Bysshe Shelley is expelled from the University of Oxford for publishing the pamphlet The Necessity of Atheism.
Paraguay: Pedro Juan Caballero, Fulgencio Yegros and José Gaspar Rodríguez de Francia start actions to depose the Spanish governor.

Peninsular War: The allies Spain, Portugal and United Kingdom fight an inconclusive battle against the French at the Albuera. It is, in proportion to the numbers involved, the bloodiest battle of the war.
Battle of Las Piedras: The first great military triumph of the revolution of the Río de la Plata in Uruguay led by José Artigas.

Survivors of an attack the previous day by Tla-o-qui-aht on board the Pacific Fur Company's ship Tonquin, intentionally detonate a powder magazine on the ship, destroying it and killing about 100 attackers.
The Carlton House Fête is held in London to celebrate the establishment of the Regency era.
The Venezuelan Declaration of Independence is adopted by a congress of the provinces.
Explorer David Thompson posts a sign near what is now Sacajawea State Park in Washington state, claiming the Columbia District for the United Kingdom.
Father Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla, leader of the Mexican insurgency, is executed by the Spanish in Chihuahua City, Mexico.
First ascent of Jungfrau, third highest summit in the Bernese Alps by brothers Johann Rudolf and Hieronymus Meyer.
The Juliana begins operation as the first steam-powered ferry in New York harbor.
The silver deposits of Agua Amarga are discovered in Chile becoming in the following years instrumental for the Patriots to finance the Chilean War of Independence.
Salvadoran priest José Matías Delgado rings the bells of La Merced church in San Salvador, calling for insurrection and launching the 1811 Independence Movement.
Tecumseh's War: The Battle of Tippecanoe is fought near present-day Battle Ground, Indiana, United States.
José Miguel Carrera, Chilean founding father, is sworn in as President of the executive Junta of the government of Chile.
Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 in E-flat major, Op. 73, premieres at the Gewandhaus in Leipzig.
The first two in a series of four severe earthquakes occur in the vicinity of New Madrid, Missouri.
A theater fire in Richmond, Virginia kills 72 people, including the Governor of Virginia George William Smith and the president of the First National Bank of Virginia Abraham B. Venable.
source_pages: Richmond_Theatre_fire; Richmond,_Virginia; Governor_of_Virginia; George_William_Smith_(politician); Abraham_B._Venable; December_26

event_text: The first steamboat on the Ohio River or the Mississippi River arrives in New Orleans, 82 days after departing from Pittsburgh.
source_pages: New_Orleans_(steamboat); Ohio_River; Mississippi_River; New_Orleans; Pittsburgh; January_10

event_text: The strongest in a series of earthquakes strikes New Madrid, Missouri.
Massachusetts governor Elbridge Gerry is accused of "gerrymandering" for the first time.
Treaty of Paris between Napoleon and Frederick William III of Prussia against Russia is signed.
Argentine War of Independence: Manuel Belgrano raises the Flag of Argentina in the city of Rosario for the first time.
Poet Lord Byron gives his first address as a member of the House of Lords, in defense of Luddite violence against Industrialism in his home county of Nottinghamshire.
The Cortes of Cádiz promulgates the Spanish Constitution of 1812.
An earthquake devastates Caracas, Venezuela.
A political cartoon in the Boston-Gazette coins the term "gerrymander" to describe oddly shaped electoral districts designed to help incumbents win reelection.
British forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington assault the fortress of Badajoz. This would be the turning point in the Peninsular War against Napoleon-led France.
Czar Alexander I, the Russian Emperor and the Grand Duke of Finland, officially announces the transfer of the status of the Finnish capital from Turku to Helsinki.
source_pages: Alexander_I_of_Russia; Emperor_of_Russia; Grand_Duke_of_Finland; Turku; Helsinki; April_8

event_text: The Territory of Orleans becomes the 18th U.S. state under the name Louisiana.
The Siege of Cuautla during the Mexican War of Independence ends with both sides claiming victory.
Prime Minister Spencer Perceval is assassinated by John Bellingham in the lobby of the British House of Commons.
Imperial Russia signs the Treaty of Bucharest, ending the Russo-Turkish War. The Ottoman Empire cedes Bessarabia to Russia.
source_pages: Russian_Empire; Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1812); Russo-Turkish_War_(1806–1812); Ottoman_Empire; Bessarabia; May_16

event_text: John Bellingham is found guilty and sentenced to death by hanging for the assassination of British Prime Minister Spencer Perceval.
War of 1812: U.S. President James Madison asks the Congress to declare war on the United Kingdom.
Following Louisiana's admittance as a U.S. state, the Louisiana Territory is renamed the Missouri Territory.
The United States declaration of war upon the United Kingdom is signed by President James Madison, beginning the War of 1812.
France declares war on Russia, starting Napoleon's invasion.
War of 1812: Great Britain revokes the restrictions on American commerce, thus eliminating one of the chief reasons for going to war.
Napoleonic Wars: Napoleon's Grande Armée crosses the Neman river beginning the invasion of Russia.
The American Army of the Northwest briefly occupies the Upper Canadian settlement at what is now at Windsor, Ontario.
The Treaties of Orebro end both the Anglo-Russian and Anglo-Swedish Wars.
Napoleonic Wars: Peninsular War: Battle of Salamanca: British forces led by Arthur Wellesley (later the Duke of Wellington) defeat French troops near Salamanca, Spain.
Peninsular War: French troops engage British-Portuguese forces in the Battle of Majadahonda.
War of 1812: American General William Hull surrenders Fort Detroit without a fight to the British Army.
War of 1812: American frigate USS Constitution defeats the British frigate HMS Guerriere off the coast of Nova Scotia, Canada earning the nickname "Old Ironsides".
Peninsular War: A coalition of Spanish, British, and Portuguese forces succeed in lifting the two-and-a-half-year-long Siege of Cádiz.
Twenty-four settlers are killed in the Pigeon Roost Massacre in Indiana.
War of 1812: The Siege of Fort Harrison begins when the fort is set on fire.
War of 1812: The Siege of Fort Wayne begins when Chief Winamac's forces attack two soldiers returning from the fort's outhouses.
French invasion of Russia: The Battle of Borodino, the bloodiest battle of the Napoleonic Wars, is fought near Moscow and results in a French victory.
War of 1812: A supply wagon sent to relieve Fort Harrison is ambushed in the Attack at the Narrows.
Napoleonic Wars: The French Grande Armée enters Moscow. The Fire of Moscow begins as soon as Russian troops leave the city.
The Grande Armée under Napoleon reaches the Kremlin in Moscow during the failed French invasion of Russia.
War of 1812: A second supply train sent to relieve Fort Harrison is ambushed in the Attack at the Narrows.
The 1812 Fire of Moscow dies down after destroying more than three-quarters of the city. Napoleon returns from the Petrovsky Palace to the Moscow Kremlin, spared from the fire.
War of 1812: In a naval engagement on Lake Erie, American forces capture two British ships: HMS Detroit and HMS Caledonia.
War of 1812: Sir Isaac Brock's British and native forces repel an invasion of Canada by General Rensselaer's United States forces.
The French invasion of Russia fails when Napoleon begins his retreat from Moscow.
General Claude François de Malet begins a conspiracy to overthrow Napoleon, claiming that the Emperor died in the Russian campaign.
Napoleonic Wars: The Battle of Maloyaroslavets takes place near Moscow.
War of 1812: The American frigate, USS United States, commanded by Stephen Decatur, captures the British frigate HMS Macedonian.
Napoleon's armies are defeated at the Battle of Vyazma.
Napoleonic Wars: At the Battle of Smoliani, French Marshals Victor and Oudinot are defeated by the Russians under General Peter Wittgenstein.
source_pages: Napoleonic_Wars; Battle_of_Smoliani; Claude-Victor_Perrin; Nicolas_Oudinot; Peter_Wittgenstein; November_14

event_text: Napoleonic Wars: The Battle of Krasnoi ends in French defeat, but Marshal of France Michel Ney's leadership leads to him becoming known as "the bravest of the brave".
The Battle of Berezina begins during Napoleon's retreat from Russia.
The French invasion of Russia comes to an end as the remnants of the Grande Armée are expelled from Russia.
War of 1812: U.S. forces attack a Lenape village in the Battle of the Mississinewa.
USS Constitution, under the command of Captain William Bainbridge, captures HMS Java off the coast of Brazil after a three-hour battle.
Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is first published in the United Kingdom.
José de San Martín defeats a Spanish royalist army at the Battle of San Lorenzo, part of the Argentine War of Independence.
In the action of 7 February 1813 near the Îles de Los, the frigates Aréthuse and Amelia batter each other, but neither can gain the upper hand.
Manuel Belgrano defeats the royalist army of Pío de Tristán during the Battle of Salta.
Sinking of HMS Peacock by USS Hornet on the Demerara River, Guyana.
Cyril VI of Constantinople is elected Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople.
War of 1812: American troops capture York, the capital of Upper Canada, in the Battle of York.
William Lawson, Gregory Blaxland and William Wentworth discover a route across the Blue Mountains, opening up inland Australia to settlement.
Napoleon Bonaparte leads his French troops into the Battle of Bautzen in Saxony, Germany, against the combined armies of Russia and Prussia. The battle ends the next day with a French victory.
South American independence leader Simón Bolívar enters Mérida, leading the invasion of Venezuela, and is proclaimed El Libertador ("The Liberator").
War of 1812: In Canada, American forces capture Fort George.
In Australia, William Lawson, Gregory Blaxland and William Wentworth reach Mount Blaxland, effectively marking the end of a route across the Blue Mountains.
Capture of USS Chesapeake.

War of 1812: In the Battle of Stoney Creek, considered a critical turning point in the war, a British force of 700 under John Vincent defeats an American force twice its size under William Winder and John Chandler.
source_pages: War_of_1812; Battle_of_Stoney_Creek; John_Vincent_(British_Army_officer); William_H._Winder; John_Chandler; June_6

event_text: Capture of USRC Surveyor.
Peninsular War: Wellington defeats Joseph Bonaparte at the Battle of Vitoria.

War of 1812: After learning of American plans for a surprise attack on Beaver Dams in Ontario, Laura Secord sets out on a thirty kilometres (19 mi) journey on foot to warn Lieutenant James FitzGibbon.
Battle of Beaver Dams: A British and Indian combined force defeats the United States Army.
War of 1812: Three weeks of British raids on Fort Schlosser, Black Rock and Plattsburgh, New York commence.
Sir Thomas Maitland is appointed as the first Governor of Malta, transforming the island from a British protectorate to a de facto colony.
In Colombia, Juan del Corral declares the independence of Antioquia.
Gervasio Antonio de Posadas joins Argentina's Second Triumvirate.
At the Battle of Großbeeren, the Prussians under Von Bülow repulse the French army.
War of the Sixth Coalition: An impromptu battle takes place when French and Prussian-Russian forces accidentally run into each other near Liegnitz, Prussia (now Legnica, Poland).
French Emperor Napoleon I defeats a larger force of Austrians, Russians, and Prussians at the Battle of Dresden.
First Battle of Kulm: French forces are defeated by an Austrian-Prussian-Russian alliance.
Creek War: Fort Mims massacre: Creek "Red Sticks" kill over 500 settlers (including over 250 armed militia) in Fort Mims, north of Mobile, Alabama.
Peninsular War: Spanish troops repel a French attack in the Battle of San Marcial.
At the final stage of the Peninsular War, British-Portuguese troops capture the town of Donostia (now San Sebastián), resulting in a rampage and eventual destruction of the town.
The United States defeats a British Fleet at the Battle of Lake Erie during the War of 1812.
War of 1812: British troops arrive in Mount Vernon and prepare to march to and invade Washington, D.C.
Followers of the Eight Trigram Sect loyal to Lin Qing attack the Forbidden City in a failed attempt to oust the Jiaqing Emperor of the Qing dynasty.
source_pages: Baguadao; Forbidden_City; Eight_Trigrams_uprising_of_1813; Jiaqing_Emperor; Qing_dynasty; September_15

event_text: War of 1812: The Army of the Northwest defeats a British and Native Canadian force threatening Detroit.
The Treaty of Ried is signed between Bavaria and Austria.
The Sixth Coalition attacks Napoleon in the four-day Battle of Leipzig.
War of the Sixth Coalition: Napoleon is forced to retreat from Germany after the Battle of Leipzig.

Treaty of Gulistan: The Russo-Persian War of 1804-1813 comes to a close with the signing of the Treaty of Gulistan, under which terms Qajar Iran agrees to cede the bulk of its Caucasian territories, which comprise much of modern Dagestan, Georgia, Armenia, and Azerbaijan, to the Russian Empire.
source_pages: Treaty_of_Gulistan; Russo-Persian_War_(1804–1813); Qajar_Iran; Dagestan; Georgia_(country); Armenia; Azerbaijan; Russian_Empire; October_24

event_text: War of 1812: A combined force of British regulars, Canadian militia and Mohawks defeat the United States Army in the Battle of the Chateauguay.
source_pages: War_of_1812; British_Regulars; Canadian_Militia; Mohawk_people; United_States_Army; Battle_of_the_Chateauguay

event_text: War of 1812: Battle of Crysler's Farm: British and Canadian forces defeat a larger American force, causing the Americans to abandon their Saint Lawrence campaign.
War of 1812: British soldiers burn Buffalo, New York.
Treaty of Kiel: Frederick VI of Denmark cedes the Kingdom of Norway to Charles XIII of Sweden in return for Pomerania.
source_pages: Treaty_of_Kiel; Frederick_VI_of_Denmark; Norway; Charles_XIII; Pomerania; January_14

event_text: War of the Sixth Coalition: France engages Russia and Prussia in the Battle of Brienne.
Gervasio Antonio de Posadas becomes Supreme Director of the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata (present-day Argentina).
Mayon in the Philippines erupts, killing around 1,200 people, which was the most devastating eruption of the volcano.
Napoleonic Wars: The Battle of Champaubert ends in French victory over the Russians and the Prussians.
War of the Sixth Coalition: The Battle of Mormant.
Napoleonic Wars: The Battle of Montereau.
War of 1812: Americans defeat British forces at the Battle of Longwoods between London, Ontario and Thamesville, near present-day Wardsville, Ontario.
Emperor Napoleon I of France wins the Battle of Craonne.
Emperor Napoleon I is defeated at the Battle of Laon in France.
Napoleonic Wars: Austrian forces repel French troops in the Battle of Arcis-sur-Aube.
War of 1812: In central Alabama, U.S. forces under General Andrew Jackson defeat the Creek at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend.
War of 1812: In the Battle of Valparaíso, two American naval vessels are captured by two Royal Navy vessels.
The Sixth Coalition occupies Paris after Napoleon's Grande Armée capitulates.
Napoleon abdicates (conditionally) for the first time and names his son Napoleon II as Emperor of the French, followed by unconditional abdication two days later.
Nominal beginning of the Bourbon Restoration; anniversary date that Napoleon abdicates and is exiled to Elba.
The Treaty of Fontainebleau ends the War of the Sixth Coalition against Napoleon Bonaparte, and forces him to abdicate unconditionally for the first time.
Emperor Napoleon arrives at Portoferraio on the island of Elba to begin his exile.
King Ferdinand VII abolishes the Spanish Constitution of 1812, returning Spain to absolutism.
Occupation of Monaco changes from French to Austrian.
The Constitution of Norway is signed and Crown Prince Christian Frederick of Denmark is elected King of Norway by the Norwegian Constituent Assembly.
The First Treaty of Paris is signed, returning the French frontiers to their 1792 extent, and restoring the House of Bourbon to power.
War of 1812: Battle of Chippawa: American Major General Jacob Brown defeats British General Phineas Riall at Chippawa, Ontario.
The Carabinieri, the national gendarmerie of Italy, is established.
War of 1812: An American attack on Canada is repulsed.
The Swedish–Norwegian War begins.
American Indian Wars: The Creek sign the Treaty of Fort Jackson, giving up huge parts of Alabama and Georgia.
The Convention of London, a treaty between the United Kingdom and the United Netherlands, is signed in London, England.
A cease fire agreement, called the Convention of Moss, ended the Swedish–Norwegian War.
British troops capture Washington, D.C. and set the Presidential Mansion, Capitol, Navy Yard and many other public buildings ablaze.
War of 1812: On the second day of the Burning of Washington, British troops torch the Library of Congress, United States Treasury, Department of War, and other public buildings.
Chilean War of Independence: Infighting between the rebel forces of José Miguel Carrera and Bernardo O'Higgins erupts in the Battle of Las Tres Acequias.
War of 1812: The climax of the Battle of Plattsburgh, a major United States victory in the war.
Battle of North Point: an American detachment halts the British land advance to Baltimore in the War of 1812.

In a turning point in the War of 1812, the British fail to capture Baltimore. During the battle, Francis Scott Key composes his poem "Defence of Fort McHenry", which is later set to music and becomes the United States' national anthem.
Battle of Baltimore: The poem Defence of Fort McHenry is written by Francis Scott Key. The poem is later used as the lyrics of The Star-Spangled Banner.
The Congress of Vienna opens with the intention of redrawing Europe's political map after the defeat of Napoleon in the previous spring.
War of 1812: The United States Revenue Marine attempts to defend the cutter Eagle from the Royal Navy.
Eight people die in the London Beer Flood.
Congress of Vienna opens to re-draw the European political map after the defeat of France in the Napoleonic Wars.
The Times of London becomes the first newspaper to be produced on a steam-powered printing press, built by the German team of Koenig & Bauer.
War of 1812: The Royal Navy seizes control of Lake Borgne, Louisiana.
source_pages: War_of_1812; Royal_Navy; Battle_of_Lake_Borgne; Lake_Borgne; Louisiana; December_14

event_text: Representatives of the United Kingdom and the United States sign the Treaty of Ghent, ending the War of 1812.
Rev. Samuel Marsden holds the first Christian service on land in New Zealand at Rangihoua Bay.

War of 1812: The destruction of the schooner USS Carolina brings to an end Commodore Daniel Patterson's makeshift fleet, which fought a series of delaying actions that contributed to Andrew Jackson's victory at the Battle of New Orleans.
source_pages: War_of_1812; USS_Carolina_(1812); Daniel_Patterson_(naval_officer); Andrew_Jackson; Battle_of_New_Orleans; December_27

event_text: Austria, the United Kingdom, and France form a secret defensive alliance against Prussia and Russia.
War of 1812: Battle of New Orleans: Andrew Jackson leads American forces in victory over the British.
War of 1812: British troops capture Fort Peter in St. Marys, Georgia, the only battle of the war to take place in the state.
War of 1812: American frigate USS President, commanded by Commodore Stephen Decatur, is captured by a squadron of four British frigates.
source_pages: War_of_1812; USS_President_(1800); Commodore_(rank); Stephen_Decatur; Capture_of_USS_President; January_15

event_text: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
Napoleon returns to France from his banishment on Elba.
Signing of the Kandyan Convention treaty by British invaders and the leaders of the Kingdom of Kandy.
Francis Ronalds describes the first battery-operated clock in the Philosophical Magazine.
Participants at the Congress of Vienna declare Napoleon an outlaw following his escape from Elba
Prince Willem proclaims himself King of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands, the first constitutional monarch in the Netherlands.
After escaping from Elba, Napoleon enters Paris with a regular army of 140,000 and a volunteer force of around 200,000, beginning his "Hundred Days" rule.
Joachim Murat issues the Rimini Proclamation, among the earliest calls for Italian unification.
The Mount Tambora volcano begins a three-month-long eruption, lasting until July 15. The eruption ultimately kills 71,000 people and affects Earth's climate for the next two years.
The Second Serbian Uprising: A second phase of the national revolution of the Serbs against the Ottoman Empire, erupts shortly after the annexation of the country to the Ottoman Empire.
Neapolitan War: Joachim Murat, King of Naples, is defeated by the Austrians at the Battle of Tolentino, the decisive engagement of the war.
The East Indiaman Arniston is wrecked during a storm at Waenhuiskrans, near Cape Agulhas, in present-day South Africa, with the loss of 372 lives.
Napoleon promulgates a revised Constitution after it passes a plebiscite.
