End of the Congress of Vienna: The new European political situation is set.
Battle of Ligny and Battle of Quatre Bras, two days before the Battle of Waterloo.

Napoleonic Wars: The Battle of Waterloo results in the defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte by the Duke of Wellington and Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher forcing him to abdicate the throne of France for the second and last time.
source_pages: Napoleonic_Wars; Battle_of_Waterloo; Napoleon; Arthur_Wellesley,_1st_Duke_of_Wellington; Gebhard_Leberecht_von_Blücher; First_French_Empire

event_text: Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord becomes the first Prime Minister of France.
Napoleonic Wars: Napoleon Bonaparte surrenders aboard HMS Bellerophon.
The modern Constitution of the Netherlands is signed.
Napoleon begins his exile on Saint Helena in the South Atlantic Ocean.

The Second Treaty of Paris is signed, returning the French frontiers to their 1790 extent, imposing large indemnities, and prolonging the occupation by troops of Great Britain, Austria, Prussia, and Russia for several more years.
Adoption of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Poland.
The U.S. Senate creates a select committee on finance and a uniform national currency, predecessor of the United States Senate Committee on Finance.
The novel Emma by Jane Austen is first published.
The Handel and Haydn Society, oldest continually performing arts organization in the United States, gives its first performance.
Humphry Davy tests his safety lamp for miners at Hebburn Colliery.
Rossini's opera The Barber of Seville premieres at the Teatro Argentina in Rome.
The Federal government of the United States approves the creation of the Second Bank of the United States.
Bussa, a slave in British-ruled Barbados, leads a slave rebellion, for which he is remembered as the country's first national hero.
A mob in Littleport, Cambridgeshire, England, riots over high unemployment and rising grain costs, and the riots spread to Ely the next day.
Battle of Seven Oaks between North West Company and Hudson's Bay Company, near Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada.
The French frigate Méduse strikes the Bank of Arguin and 151 people on board have to be evacuated on an improvised raft, a case immortalised by Géricault's painting The Raft of the Medusa.
Argentina declares independence from Spain.

Seminole Wars: The Battle of Negro Fort ends when a hot shot cannonball fired by US Navy Gunboat No. 154 explodes the fort's Powder Magazine, killing approximately 275. It is considered the deadliest single cannon shot in US history.
The British Admiralty dismisses Francis Ronalds's new invention of the first working electric telegraph as "wholly unnecessary", preferring to continue using the semaphore.
The United Kingdom formally annexes the Tristan da Cunha archipelago, administering the islands from the Cape Colony in South Africa.
The Treaty of St. Louis is signed in St. Louis, Missouri.
Louis XVIII has to dissolve the Chambre introuvable ("Unobtainable Chamber").
HMS Whiting runs aground on the Doom Bar.
Warsaw University is established.
Indiana becomes the 19th U.S. state.
The Treaty of St. Louis between the United States and the united Ottawa, Ojibwa, and Potawatomi Indian tribes is proclaimed.
An army of 5,423 soldiers, led by General José de San Martín, crosses the Andes from Argentina to liberate Chile and then Peru.
Crossing of the Andes: Many soldiers of Juan Gregorio de las Heras are captured during the action of Picheuta.
An army led by Grand Marshal Las Heras crosses the Andes to join San Martín in the liberation of Chile from Spain.
source_pages: Army_of_the_Andes; Grand_marshal; Juan_Gregorio_de_las_Heras; Crossing_of_the_Andes; José_de_San_Martín; Chilean_War_of_Independence; Spanish_Empire; February_8

event_text: An Argentine/Chilean patriotic army, after crossing the Andes, defeats Spanish troops at the Battle of Chacabuco.

Thomas Hopkins Gallaudet and Laurent Clerc found the American School for the Deaf (then called the Connecticut Asylum for the Education and Instruction of Deaf and Dumb Persons), the first American school for deaf students, in Hartford, Connecticut.
Opening of the first private mental health hospital in the United States, the Asylum for the Relief of Persons Deprived of the Use of Their Reason (now Friends Hospital, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania).
The first Great Lakes steamer, the Frontenac, is launched.
The earliest form of bicycle, the dandy horse, is driven by Karl von Drais.
In Rome, New York, construction on the Erie Canal begins.
Unsuccessful in his attempt to conquer the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi for the Russian-American Company, Georg Anton Schäffer is forced to admit defeat and leave Kauaʻi.
Italian explorer and archaeologist Giovanni Belzoni, uncovered the Tomb of Seti I in the Valley of the Kings.
Simón Bolívar sentences Manuel Piar to death for challenging the racial-caste in Venezuela.
Simón Bolívar becomes President of the Third Republic of Venezuela.
The Bank of Montreal, Canada's oldest chartered bank, opens in Montreal.
Mississippi becomes the 20th U.S. state.
Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley (anonymously) publishes the pioneering work of science fiction, Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus, in London.
The British Institution of Civil Engineers is founded by a group of six engineers; Thomas Telford would later become its first president.

A paper by David Brewster is read to the Royal Society, belatedly announcing his discovery of what we now call the biaxial class of doubly-refracting crystals. On the same day, Augustin-Jean Fresnel signs a "supplement" (submitted four days later) on reflection of polarized light.
source_pages: David_Brewster; Royal_Society; Birefringence; January_15; Augustin-Jean_Fresnel; Polarization_(waves)

event_text: Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte ascends to the thrones of Sweden and Norway.
Bernardo O'Higgins formally approves the Chilean Declaration of Independence near Concepción, Chile.

Physicist Augustin Fresnel reads a memoir on optical rotation to the French Academy of Sciences, reporting that when polarized light is "depolarized" by a Fresnel rhomb, its properties are preserved in any subsequent passage through an optically-rotating crystal or liquid.
The United States Congress, affirming the Second Continental Congress, adopts the flag of the United States with 13 red and white stripes and one star for each state (20 at that time).
In the Battle of Maipú, Chile's independence movement, led by Bernardo O'Higgins and José de San Martín, win a decisive victory over Spain, leaving 2,000 Spaniards and 1,000 Chilean patriots dead.
The United States Senate ratifies the Rush–Bagot Treaty, limiting naval armaments on the Great Lakes and Lake Champlain.
French physicist Augustin Fresnel signs his preliminary "Note on the Theory of Diffraction" (deposited on the following day). The document ends with what we now call the Fresnel integrals.
US Flag Act of 1818 goes into effect creating a 13 stripe flag with a star for each state. New stars would be added on July 4 after a new state had been admitted.

French physicist Augustin Fresnel submits his prizewinning "Memoir on the Diffraction of Light", precisely accounting for the limited extent to which light spreads into shadows, and thereby demolishing the oldest objection to the wave theory of light.
Carl III of Sweden–Norway is crowned king of Norway, in Trondheim.
The Convention of 1818 is signed between the United States and the United Kingdom, which settles the Canada–United States border on the 49th parallel for most of its length.
Illinois becomes the 21st U.S. state.
Cyril VI of Constantinople resigns from his position as Ecumenical Patriarch under pressure from the Ottoman Empire.
The first performance of "Silent Night" takes place in the Nikolauskirche in Oberndorf, Austria.
University of Virginia chartered by Commonwealth of Virginia, with Thomas Jefferson one of its founders.
Stamford Raffles lands on the island of Singapore.
The Treaty of Singapore was signed by Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles, Hussein Shah of Johor, and Temenggong Abdul Rahman, and it is now recognised as the founding of modern Singapore.
Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles leaves Singapore after just taking it over, leaving it in the hands of William Farquhar.
The United States House of Representatives passes the Missouri Compromise for the first time.
British explorer William Smith discovers the South Shetland Islands.
By the Adams–Onís Treaty, Spain sells Florida to the United States for five million U.S. dollars.
SS Savannah leaves port at Savannah, Georgia, United States, on a voyage to become the first steamship to cross the Atlantic Ocean.
The Argentine Constitution of 1819 is promulgated.

A major earthquake strikes the Kutch district of western India, killing over 1,543 people and raising a 6-metre-high (20 ft), 6-kilometre-wide (3.7 mi), ridge, extending for at least 80 kilometres (50 mi), that was known as the Allah Bund ("Dam of God").
The U.S. vessel SS Savannah arrives at Liverpool, United Kingdom. It is the first steam-propelled vessel to cross the Atlantic, although most of the journey is made under sail.
Johann Georg Tralles discovers the Great Comet of 1819, (C/1819 N1). It is the first comet analyzed using polarimetry, by François Arago.
The Bank for Savings in the City of New-York, the first savings bank in the United States, opens.
Norwich University is founded in Vermont as the first private military school in the United States.
Simón Bolívar triumphs over Spain in the Battle of Boyacá.
Peterloo Massacre: Seventeen people die and over 600 are injured in cavalry charges at a public meeting at St. Peter's Field, Manchester, England.
1819 Balloon riot occurred at Vauxhall Garden in Philadelphia, PA and resulted in the destruction of the amusement park.
Alabama becomes the 22nd U.S. state.
Simón Bolívar declares the independence of Gran Colombia in Angostura (now Ciudad Bolívar in Venezuela).
The Great Savannah Fire of 1820 destroys over 400 buildings in Savannah, Georgia.
A Russian expedition led by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen and Mikhail Petrovich Lazarev discovers the Antarctic continent, approaching the Antarctic coast.
Edward Bransfield sights the Trinity Peninsula and claims the discovery of Antarctica.
The Chilean Navy under the command of Lord Cochrane completes the two-day long Capture of Valdivia with just 300 men and two ships.
The first 86 African American immigrants sponsored by the American Colonization Society depart New York to start a settlement in present-day Liberia.
Cato Street Conspiracy: A plot to murder all the British cabinet ministers is exposed and the conspirators arrested.

The Missouri Compromise is signed into law by President James Monroe. The compromise allows Missouri to enter the Union as a slave state, brings Maine into the Union as a free state, and makes the rest of the northern part of the Louisiana Purchase territory slavery-free.
source_pages: Missouri_Compromise; James_Monroe; Missouri; Admission_to_the_Union; Slave_states_and_free_states; Maine; Louisiana_Purchase

event_text: Maine is admitted as the twenty-third U.S. state.
The Venus de Milo is discovered on the Aegean island of Milos.
Alexander Ypsilantis is declared leader of Filiki Eteria, a secret organization to overthrow Ottoman rule over Greece.[citation needed]
Execution of the Cato Street Conspirators, who plotted to kill the British Cabinet and Prime Minister Lord Liverpool.
source_pages: Cato_Street_Conspiracy; United_Kingdom; Cabinet_of_the_United_Kingdom; Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom; Robert_Jenkinson,_2nd_Earl_of_Liverpool; May_1

event_text: Constitutionalist insurrection at Oporto, Portugal.
Constitutionalist revolution in Lisbon, Portugal.
Guayaquil declares independence from Spain.
Captain Nathaniel Palmer becomes the first American to see Antarctica. (The Palmer Peninsula is later named after him.)

An 80-ton sperm whale attacks and sinks the Essex (a whaling ship from Nantucket, Massachusetts) 3,200 kilometres (2,000 mi) from the western coast of South America. (Herman Melville's 1851 novel Moby-Dick was in part inspired by this incident.)
source_pages: Sperm_whale; Essex_(whaleship); Whaling; Nantucket; Herman_Melville; Moby-Dick

event_text: Final stage of the Mexican War of Independence from Spain with Plan of Iguala.
Greek War of Independence: Greek revolutionaries seize Kalavryta.
Greek War of Independence: Battle and fall of city of Kalamata.
Greek War of Independence: Traditional date of the start of the Greek War of Independence. The war had actually begun on 23 February 1821 (Julian calendar).
Patriarch Gregory V of Constantinople is hanged by the Ottoman government from the main gate of the Patriarchate and his body is thrown into the Bosphorus.
Greek War of Independence: the island of Psara joins the Greek struggle for independence.
Benderli Ali Pasha arrives in Constantinople as the new Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire; he remains in power for only nine days before being sent into exile.
Emperor Napoleon dies in exile on the island of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic Ocean.
The first edition of The Manchester Guardian, now The Guardian, is published.
Greek War of Independence: The Greeks defeat the Turks at the Battle of Gravia Inn.
The first major battle of the Greek War of Independence against the Turks is fought in Valtetsi.
Establishment of the Peloponnesian Senate by the Greek rebels.
Badi VII, king of Sennar, surrenders his throne and realm to Isma'il Pasha, general of the Ottoman Empire, ending the existence of that Sudanese kingdom.
Badi VII, king of Sennar, surrenders his throne and realm to Ismail Pasha, general of the Ottoman Empire, bringing the 300 year old Sudanese kingdom to an end.
Decisive defeat of the Filiki Eteria by the Ottomans at Drăgășani (in Wallachia).
Battle of Carabobo: Decisive battle in the war of independence of Venezuela from Spain.
Four hundred and seventy prominent Cypriots including Archbishop Kyprianos are executed in response to Cypriot aid to the Greek War of Independence.
The Kingdom of Spain cedes the territory of Florida to the United States.
Coronation of George IV of the United Kingdom.
While the Mora Rebellion continues, Greeks capture Monemvasia Castle. Turkish troops and citizens are transferred to Asia Minor's coasts.
José de San Martín declares the independence of Peru from Spain.
The Saturday Evening Post is published for the first time as a weekly newspaper.
Jarvis Island is discovered by the crew of the ship, Eliza Frances.
The Treaty of Córdoba is signed in Córdoba, now in Veracruz, Mexico, concluding the Mexican War of Independence from Spain.
The Captaincy General of Guatemala declares independence from Spain.
Tripolitsa, Greece, is captured by Greek rebels during the Greek War of Independence.
The Army of the Three Guarantees triumphantly enters Mexico City, led by Agustín de Iturbide. The following day Mexico is declared independent.
The Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire is drafted. It will be made public on 13 October.
The Peruvian Navy is established during the War of Independence.
The Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire is publicly proclaimed.
Cry of Independence by Rufina Alfaro at La Villa de Los Santos, Panama setting into motion a revolt which led to Panama's independence from Spain and to it immediately becoming part of Colombia.
Panama Independence Day: Panama separates from Spain and joins Gran Colombia.
José Núñez de Cáceres wins the independence of the Dominican Republic from Spain and names the new territory the Republic of Spanish Haiti.
The Greek Constitution of 1822 is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.
The government of Central America votes for total annexation to the First Mexican Empire.
The Portuguese prince Pedro I of Brazil decides to stay in Brazil against the orders of the Portuguese King João VI, beginning the Brazilian independence process.
The design of the Greek flag is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.
Greek War of Independence: Demetrios Ypsilantis is elected president of the legislative assembly.
Haiti attacks the newly established Dominican Republic on the other side of the island of Hispaniola.
The first Swaminarayan temple in the world, Shri Swaminarayan Mandir, Ahmedabad, is inaugurated.
The Florida Territory is created in the United States.
Greek War of Independence: The Turks capture the Greek town of Souli.
Battle of Pichincha: Antonio José de Sucre secures the independence of the Presidency of Quito.
At least 113 people die in the Grue Church fire, the biggest fire disaster in Norway's history.
Alexis St Martin is accidentally shot in the stomach, leading to William Beaumont's studies on digestion.
Charles Babbage proposes a difference engine in a paper to the Royal Astronomical Society.
Konstantinos Kanaris blows up the Ottoman navy's flagship at Chios, killing the Kapudan Pasha Nasuhzade Ali Pasha.
source_pages: Konstantinos_Kanaris; Ottoman_Navy; Chios; Kapudan_Pasha; Nasuhzade_Ali_Pasha; June_18

event_text: Thirty-five slaves, including Denmark Vesey, are hanged in South Carolina after being accused of organizing a slave rebellion.
Chippewas turn over a huge tract of land in Ontario to the United Kingdom.
José de San Martín arrives in Guayaquil, Ecuador, to meet with Simón Bolívar.
First day of the three-day Battle of Dervenakia, between the Ottoman Empire force led by Mahmud Dramali Pasha and the Greek Revolutionary force led by Theodoros Kolokotronis.
Dom Pedro I declares Brazil independent from Portugal on the shores of the Ipiranga Brook in São Paulo.

French physicist Augustin-Jean Fresnel, in a "note" read to the Academy of Sciences, reports a direct refraction experiment verifying David Brewster's hypothesis that photoelasticity (as it is now known) is stress-induced birefringence.
source_pages: Augustin-Jean_Fresnel; French_Academy_of_Sciences; David_Brewster; Photoelasticity; Birefringence; September_16

event_text: Jean-François Champollion officially informs the Académie des Inscriptions et Belles Lettres in France that he has deciphered the Rosetta Stone.
Pedro I of Brazil is proclaimed the emperor.
Greek War of Independence: The First Siege of Missolonghi begins.
Emperor Agustín de Iturbide attempts to dissolve the Congress of the Mexican Empire.
American Old West: Missouri trader William Becknell arrives in Santa Fe, New Mexico, over a route that became known as the Santa Fe Trail.
Pedro I is crowned Emperor of Brazil.

French physicist Augustin-Jean Fresnel, in a memoir read to the Academy of Sciences, coins the terms linear polarization, circular polarization, and elliptical polarization, and reports a direct refraction experiment verifying his theory that optical rotation is a form of birefringence.
source_pages: Augustin-Jean_Fresnel; French_Academy_of_Sciences; Linear_polarization; Circular_polarization; Elliptical_polarization; Optical_rotation; Birefringence; December_9

event_text: Carnival tragedy of 1823: About 110 boys are killed during a human crush at the Convent of the Minori Osservanti in Valletta, Malta.
source_pages: Carnival_tragedy_of_1823; Crowd_collapses_and_crushes; Franciscan_Church_of_St_Mary_of_Jesus; Valletta; Crown_Colony_of_Malta; February_11

event_text: Sailor Benjamin Morrell erroneously reported the existence of the island of New South Greenland near Antarctica.
The five Central American nations of Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica declare independence from the First Mexican Empire after being annexed the year prior.
Bahia Independence Day: The end of Portuguese rule in Brazil, with the final defeat of the Portuguese crown loyalists in the province of Bahia.
A fire destroys the ancient Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls in Rome, Italy.
American fur trapper Hugh Glass is mauled by a grizzly bear while on an expedition in South Dakota.
Joseph Smith claims to have found the golden plates after being directed by God through the Angel Moroni to the place where they were buried.
Monroe Doctrine: In a State of the Union message, U.S. President James Monroe proclaims American neutrality in future European conflicts, and warns European powers not to interfere in the Americas.
The Ashantis defeat British forces in the Gold Coast during the First Anglo-Ashanti War.
William Buckland formally announces the name Megalosaurus, the first scientifically validly named non-avian dinosaur species.
First Anglo-Burmese War: The British officially declare war on Burma.

The Anglo-Dutch Treaty is signed in London, dividing the Malay archipelago. As a result, the Malay Peninsula is dominated by the British, while Sumatra and Java and surrounding areas are dominated by the Dutch.
American explorer Benjamin Morrell departed Antarctica after a voyage later plagued by claims of fraud.

The Mechanics' Institution is established in Manchester, England at the Bridgewater Arms hotel, as part of a national movement for the education of working men. The institute is the precursor to three Universities in the city: the University of Manchester, UMIST and the Metropolitan University of Manchester (MMU).
World premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven's Ninth Symphony in Vienna, Austria. The performance is conducted by Michael Umlauf under the composer's supervision.
The National Gallery in London opens to the public.
A meeting at Old Slaughter's coffee house in London leads to the formation of what is now the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA).
Greek War of Independence: Egyptian forces capture Psara in the Aegean Sea.
Costa Rica annexes Guanacaste from Nicaragua.
Greek War of Independence: Konstantinos Kanaris leads a Greek fleet to victory against Ottoman and Egyptian naval forces in the Battle of Samos.
Peruvian War of Independence: Patriot forces led by Simón Bolívar defeat the Spanish Royalist army in the Battle of Junín.
The Marquis de Lafayette, the last surviving French general of the American Revolutionary War, arrives in New York and begins a tour of 24 states.
Mexico adopts a new constitution and becomes a federal republic.
Portland cement is patented.

United States presidential election: Since no candidate received a majority of the total electoral college votes in the election, the United States House of Representatives is given the task of deciding the winner in accordance with the Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
Patriot forces led by General Antonio José de Sucre defeat a Royalist army in the Battle of Ayacucho, putting an end to the Peruvian War of Independence.
The U.S. Congress approves Indian Territory (in what is present-day Oklahoma), clearing the way for forced relocation of the Eastern Indians on the "Trail of Tears".
The Ohio Legislature authorizes the construction of the Ohio and Erie Canal and the Miami and Erie Canal.

After no candidate receives a majority of electoral votes in the US presidential election of 1824, the United States House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams as sixth President of the United States in a contingent election.
The Creek cede the last of their lands in Georgia to the United States government by the Treaty of Indian Springs, and migrate west.
Roberto Cofresí, one of the last successful Caribbean pirates, is defeated in combat and captured by authorities.
The Coronation of Charles X of France takes place in Reims Cathedral, the last ever coronation of a French monarch.
General Lafayette, a French officer in the American Revolutionary War, speaks at what would become Lafayette Square in Buffalo, New York, during his visit to the United States.
The first cornerstone is laid for Fort Hamilton in New York City.
The Bolivian Declaration of Independence is proclaimed.
The Thirty-Three Orientals declare the independence of Uruguay from Brazil.

Portuguese and Brazilian diplomats sign the Treaty of Rio de Janeiro, which has Portugal recognise Brazilian independence, formally ending the Brazilian war of independence. The treaty will be ratified by the King of Portugal three months later.
source_pages: Kingdom_of_Portugal; Empire_of_Brazil; Treaty_of_Rio_de_Janeiro_(1825); Brazilian_War_of_Independence; List_of_Portuguese_monarchs; August_29

event_text: The world's first public railway to use steam locomotives, the Stockton and Darlington Railway, is ceremonially opened with the engine Locomotion pulling wagons with coal and passengers from Shildon to Darlington to Stockton.
source_pages: Stockton_and_Darlington_Railway; Locomotion_No._1; Shildon; Darlington; Stockton-on-Tees; September_27

event_text: Restauration arrives in New York Harbor from Norway, the first organized immigration from Norway to the United States.
The Erie Canal opens, allowing direct passage from the Hudson River to Lake Erie.
Advocates of liberalism in Russia rise up against Czar Nicholas I in the Decembrist revolt, but are later suppressed.
The Treaty of St. Louis between the United States and the Shawnee Nation is proclaimed.
The Menai Suspension Bridge, considered the world's first modern suspension bridge, connecting the Isle of Anglesey to the north West coast of Wales, is opened.
University College London is founded as University of London.
The signing of the Treaty of Yandabo marks the end of the First Anglo-Burmese War.
Shrigley abduction: 15-year old Ellen Turner is abducted by Edward Gibbon Wakefield, a future figure in the establishment of colonies in South Australia and New Zealand.
Pope Leo XII publishes the apostolic constitution Quo Graviora in which he renewed the prohibition on Catholics joining freemasonry.
The 10,500 inhabitants of the Greek town of Missolonghi begin leaving the town after a year's siege by Turkish forces. Very few of them survive.
The galaxy Centaurus A or NGC 5128 is discovered by James Dunlop.
HMS Beagle departs on its first voyage.
Maniots defeat Egyptians under Ibrahim Pasha in the Battle of Vergas.
Major Gordon Laing becomes the first European to enter Timbuktu.

Captain William Morgan, an ex-freemason is arrested in Batavia, New York for debt after declaring that he would publish The Mysteries of Free Masonry, a book against Freemasonry. This sets into motion the events that led to his mysterious disappearance.
The Granite Railway begins operations as the first chartered railway in the U.S.
The Greek frigate Hellas arrives in Nafplion to become the first flagship of the Hellenic Navy.
Benjamin W. Edwards rides into Mexican-controlled Nacogdoches, Texas, and declares himself ruler of the Republic of Fredonia.
American settlers in Nacogdoches, Mexican Texas, declare their independence, starting the Fredonian Rebellion.
The Eggnog Riot at the United States Military Academy begins that night, wrapping up the following morning.
The Eggnog Riot at the United States Military Academy concludes after beginning the previous evening.
Slavery is abolished in the State of New York.
Dutch King William I and Pope Leo XII sign concord.
José de La Mar becomes President of Peru.
The Great Fire of Turku almost completely destroys Finland's former capital city.
Russo-Persian War: The Russian army under Ivan Paskevich storms Yerevan, ending a millennium of Muslim domination of Armenia.

Greek War of Independence: In the Battle of Navarino, a combined Turkish and Egyptian fleet is defeated by British, French and Russian naval forces in the last significant battle fought with wooden sailing ships.
The Democratic Party of the United States is organized.
Initial issue of the Cherokee Phoenix is the first periodical to use the Cherokee syllabary invented by Sequoyah.
René Caillié becomes the second non-Muslim to enter Timbuktu, following Major Gordon Laing. He would also be the first to return alive.
U.S. President John Quincy Adams signs the Tariff of 1828 into law, sparking outrage in the South and leading to the Nullification crisis.
Brazil and Argentina recognize the sovereignty of Uruguay in the Treaty of Montevideo.
Morea expedition: The city of Patras, Greece, is liberated by the French expeditionary force.
Greek War of Independence: The French Morea expedition to recapture Morea (now the Peloponnese) ends when the last Ottoman forces depart the peninsula.
Greek War of Independence: The London Protocol entails the creation of an autonomous Greek state under Ottoman suzerainty, encompassing the Morea and the Cyclades.
Argentine general Juan Lavalle makes a coup against governor Manuel Dorrego, beginning the Decembrist revolution.
Vice President of the United States John C. Calhoun sparks the Nullification Crisis when he anonymously publishes the South Carolina Exposition and Protest, protesting the Tariff of 1828.
source_pages: Vice_President_of_the_United_States; John_C._Calhoun; Nullification_crisis; South_Carolina_Exposition_and_Protest; Tariff_of_Abominations; December_19

event_text: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust: The First Part of the Tragedy receives its premiere performance.
The Wellington–Winchilsea duel takes place in London involving the Prime Minister the Duke of Wellington.
In the London Protocol, the three protecting powers (United Kingdom, France and Russia) establish the borders of Greece.
The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829, allowing Catholics to serve in Parliament.
The Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829 gives Roman Catholics in the United Kingdom the right to vote and to sit in Parliament.
Charles Fremantle arrives in HMS Challenger off the coast of modern-day Western Australia prior to declaring the Swan River Colony for the British Empire.
After anchoring nearby, Captain Charles Fremantle of HMS Challenger, declares the Swan River Colony in Australia.
Accordion patent granted to Cyrill Demian in Vienna, Austrian Empire.
HMS Pickle captures the armed slave ship Voladora off the coast of Cuba.
The first Boat Race between the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge takes place on the Thames in London.
In the United States, William Austin Burt patents the typographer, a precursor to the typewriter.
The Treaty of Lewistown is signed by the Shawnee and Seneca peoples, exchanging land in Ohio for land west of the Mississippi River.
source_pages: Treaty_of_Lewistown; Shawnee; Seneca_people; Ohio; Mississippi_River; August_3

event_text: An expedition led by Isidro Barradas at Tampico, sent by the Spanish crown to retake Mexico, surrenders at the Battle of Tampico, marking the effective end of Spain's resistance to Mexico's campaign for independence.
The Ottoman Empire signs the Treaty of Adrianople with Russia, thus ending the Russo-Turkish War.
The Metropolitan Police of London, later also known as the Met, is founded.
The South African College is founded in Cape Town, later separating into the University of Cape Town and the South African College Schools.
Stephenson's Rocket wins the Rainhill Trials.
In the face of fierce local opposition, British Governor-General Lord William Bentinck issues a regulation declaring that anyone who abets sati in Bengal is guilty of culpable homicide.
The London Protocol of 1830 establishes the full independence and sovereignty of Greece from the Ottoman Empire as the final result of the Greek War of Independence.
The Royal Netherlands East Indies Army is created.
The Book of Mormon is published in Palmyra, New York.
Church of Christ, the original church of the Latter Day Saint movement, is organized by Joseph Smith and others at either Fayette or Manchester, New York.
source_pages: Church_of_Christ_(Latter_Day_Saints); Latter_Day_Saint_movement; April_6_(LDS_Church); Joseph_Smith; Fayette,_New_York; Manchester,_New_York

event_text: The Canterbury and Whitstable Railway is opened; it is the first steam-hauled passenger railway to issue season tickets and include a tunnel.
Ecuador gains its independence from Gran Colombia.
U.S. President Andrew Jackson signs the Indian Removal Act which denies Native Americans their land rights and forcibly relocates them.
Beginning of the Invasion of Algiers: Thirty-four thousand French soldiers land 27 kilometers west of Algiers, at Sidi Ferruch.
Beginning of the French colonization of Algeria: Thirty-four thousand French soldiers begin their invasion of Algiers, landing 27 kilometers west at Sidi Fredj.
William IV becomes king of Britain and Hanover following the death without surviving legitimate issue of his older brother George IV.

The General Assembly's Institution, now the Scottish Church College, one of the pioneering institutions that ushered the Bengali Renaissance, is founded by Alexander Duff and Raja Ram Mohan Roy, in Calcutta, India.
Charles X of France abdicates the throne in favor of his grandson Henri.
Louis Philippe becomes the king of the French following abdication of Charles X.
The Belgian Revolution begins.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's new Tom Thumb steam locomotive races a horse-drawn car, presaging steam's role in U.S. railroads.
Anti-Masonic Party convention; one of the first American political party conventions.
The Liverpool to Manchester railway line opens; British MP William Huskisson becomes the first widely reported railway passenger fatality when he is struck and killed by the locomotive Rocket.
A revolutionary committee of notables forms the Provisional Government of Belgium.
The Belgian Revolution takes legal form when the provisional government secedes from the Netherlands.
Saint Catherine Labouré experiences a Marian apparition.
An armed rebellion against Russia's rule in Poland begins.
Ras Marye of Yejju marches into Tigray and defeats and kills Dejazmach Sabagadis in the Battle of Debre Abbay.

The Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek, the first removal treaty in accordance with the Indian Removal Act, is proclaimed. The Choctaws in Mississippi cede land east of the river in exchange for payment and land in the West.
The French Foreign Legion is created by Louis Philippe, the King of France, from the foreign regiments of the Kingdom of France.
First documented bank heist in U.S. history, when burglars stole $245,000 (1831 values) from the City Bank (now Citibank) on Wall Street. Most of the money was recovered.
Pedro II becomes Emperor of Empire of Brazil.
Soldiers marching on the Broughton Suspension Bridge in Manchester, England, cause it to collapse.
The University of Alabama is founded in Tuscaloosa, Alabama.
James Clark Ross becomes the first European at the North Magnetic Pole.
Samuel Francis Smith writes "My Country, 'Tis of Thee" for the Boston, Massachusetts July 4 festivities.
Regulamentul Organic, a quasi-constitutional organic law is adopted in Wallachia, one of the two Danubian Principalities that were to become the basis of Romania.
source_pages: Regulamentul_Organic; Organic_law; Wallachia; Danubian_Principalities; Romania; July_13

event_text: Seneca and Shawnee people agree to relinquish their land in western Ohio for 60,000 acres west of the Mississippi River.
Inauguration of Leopold I of Belgium, first king of the Belgians.
Four hundred Shawnee people agree to relinquish their lands in Ohio in exchange for land west of the Mississippi River in the Treaty of Wapakoneta.
French intervention forces William I of the Netherlands to abandon his attempt to suppress the Belgian Revolution.
Nat Turner leads black slaves and free blacks in a rebellion in Southampton County, Virginia, which will claim the lives of 55 to 65 whites and about twice that number of blacks.
Nat Turner's rebellion of enslaved Virginians is suppressed.
Michael Faraday discovers electromagnetic induction.

The Order of St. Gregory the Great is established by Pope Gregory XVI of the Vatican State to recognize high support for the Vatican or for the Pope, by a man or a woman, and not necessarily a Roman Catholic.
William IV and Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen are crowned King and Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
November uprising: The Battle of Warsaw effectively ends the Polish insurrection.
Ioannis Kapodistrias, the first head of state of independent Greece, is assassinated.
Nat Turner is arrested for leading the bloodiest slave rebellion in United States history.
In Jerusalem, Virginia, Nat Turner is hanged after inciting a violent slave uprising.
Ecuador and Venezuela are separated from Gran Colombia.
Former U.S. President John Quincy Adams takes his seat in the House of Representatives.
The Great Jamaican Slave Revolt begins; up to 20% of Jamaica's slaves mobilize in an ultimately unsuccessful fight for freedom.
Charles Darwin embarks on his journey aboard HMS Beagle, during which he will begin to formulate his theory of evolution.
Gramercy Park is deeded to New York City.
Ecuador annexes the Galápagos Islands.
In Hiram, Ohio, a group of men beat and tar and feather Mormon leader Joseph Smith.
Black Hawk War: Around 300 United States 6th Infantry troops leave St. Louis, Missouri to fight the Sauk Native Americans.
Greece's independence is recognized by the Treaty of London.
Juan Godoy discovers the rich silver outcrops of Chañarcillo sparking the Chilean silver rush.
The First Kingdom of Greece is declared in the London Conference.
The June Rebellion breaks out in Paris in an attempt to overthrow the monarchy of Louis Philippe.
The June Rebellion in Paris is put down by the National Guard.
The Great Reform Act of England and Wales receives royal assent.
Asian cholera reaches Quebec, brought by Irish immigrants, and kills about 6,000 people in Lower Canada.
John Neal delivers the first public lecture in the US to advocate the rights of women.
Durham University established by Act of Parliament; the first recognized university to be founded in England since Cambridge over 600 years earlier.
U.S. President Andrew Jackson vetoes a bill that would re-charter the Second Bank of the United States.
The British Medical Association is founded as the Provincial Medical and Surgical Association by Sir Charles Hastings at a meeting in the Board Room of the Worcester Infirmary.
Black Hawk, leader of the Sauk tribe of Native Americans, surrenders to U.S. authorities, ending the Black Hawk War.
Texian political delegates convene at San Felipe de Austin to petition for changes in the governance of Mexican Texas.
South Carolina passes the Ordinance of Nullification, declaring that the Tariffs of 1828 and 1832 were null and void in the state, beginning the Nullification Crisis.
HMS Clio under the command of Captain Onslow arrives at Port Egmont under orders to take possession of the Falkland Islands.
Egyptian–Ottoman War: Egyptian forces decisively defeat Ottoman troops at the Battle of Konya.
John C. Calhoun becomes the first Vice President of the United States to resign. He resigned after being elected Senator from South Carolina.
Captain James Onslow, in the Clio, reasserts British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands.
United States President Andrew Jackson writes to Vice President elect Martin Van Buren expressing his opposition to South Carolina's defiance of federal authority in the Nullification Crisis.
Otto becomes the first modern King of Greece.
The Convention of 1833, a political gathering of settlers in Mexican Texas to help draft a series of petitions to the Mexican government, begins in San Felipe de Austin.
A revolt broke out in southern Vietnam against Emperor Minh Mang, who had desecrated the deceased mandarin Le Van Duyet.
The Chilean Constitution of 1833 is promulgated.
Lê Văn Khôi along with 27 soldiers stage a mutiny taking over the Phiên An citadel, developing into the Lê Văn Khôi revolt against Emperor Minh Mạng.
Admiral Charles Napier vanquishes the navy of the Portuguese usurper Dom Miguel at the third Battle of Cape St. Vincent.
source_pages: Admiral; Charles_Napier_(Royal_Navy_officer); Kingdom_of_Portugal; Usurper; Miguel_I_of_Portugal; Battle_of_Cape_St._Vincent_(1833)

event_text: Noongar Australian aboriginal warrior Yagan, wanted for the murder of white colonists in Western Australia, is killed.
The Slavery Abolition Act passes in the British House of Commons, initiating the gradual abolition of slavery in most parts of the British Empire.
The great 1833 Kathmandu–Bihar earthquake causes major damage in Nepal, northern India and Tibet, a total of 500 people perish.
The Slavery Abolition Act 1833 receives royal assent, making the purchase or ownership of slaves illegal in the British Empire with exceptions.
Great Meteor Storm of 1833.
A massive undersea earthquake, estimated magnitude between 8.7 and 9.2, rocks Sumatra, producing a massive tsunami all along the Indonesian coast.
The national anthem of the Russian Empire, "God Save the Tsar!", is first performed.
Most of Germany forms the Zollverein customs union, the first such union between sovereign states.
Six farm labourers from Tolpuddle, Dorset, England are sentenced to be transported to Australia for forming a trade union.
The Battle of Asseiceira is fought; it was the final and decisive engagement of the Liberal Wars in Portugal.

Minister of Justice Joaquim António de Aguiar issues a law seizing "all convents, monasteries, colleges, hospices and any other houses" from the Catholic religious orders in Portugal, earning him the nickname of "The Friar-Killer".
The looting of Safed commences.
In New York City, four nights of rioting against abolitionists began.
The Spanish Inquisition is officially disbanded after nearly 356 years.

Slavery is abolished in the British Empire as the Slavery Abolition Act 1833 comes into force, although it remains legal in the possessions of the East India Company until the passage of the Indian Slavery Act, 1843.
Construction begins on the Wilberforce Monument in Kingston Upon Hull.
Opening of the Dublin and Kingstown Railway, the first public railway on the island of Ireland.
Much of the ancient structure of the Palace of Westminster in London burns to the ground.
The Pinjarra massacre occurs in the Swan River Colony. An estimated 30 Noongar people are killed by British colonists.
Founding of the Free University of Brussels by Pierre-Théodore Verhaegen.
Slavery is abolished in the Cape Colony in accordance with the Slavery Abolition Act 1833.
The Zollverein (German Customs Union) begins the first regular census in Germany.
HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin on board, drops anchor off the Chonos Archipelago.
US President Andrew Jackson announces a celebratory dinner after having reduced the United States national debt to zero for the only time.
Slaves in Salvador da Bahia, Brazil, stage a revolt, which is instrumental in ending slavery there 50 years later.

In the first assassination attempt against a President of the United States, Richard Lawrence attempts to shoot president Andrew Jackson, but fails and is subdued by a crowd, including several congressmen as well as Jackson himself.
Slavery is abolished in Mauritius.
The original Quorum of the Twelve Apostles, in the Latter Day Saint movement, is formed in Kirtland, Ohio.
Serbia's Sretenje Constitution briefly comes into effect.
The 1835 Concepción earthquake destroys Concepción, Chile.
Elias Lönnrot signed and dated the first version of the Kalevala, the so-called foreword to the Old Kalevala.
The first railway in continental Europe opens between Brussels and Mechelen.
James Gordon Bennett, Sr. publishes the first issue of the New York Herald.
James Bowman Lindsay demonstrates a constant electric light at a public meeting in Dundee, Scotland.
P. T. Barnum begins his career as a showman and circus entrepreneur by exhibiting Joice Heth, an octogenerian African slave whom he claims was George Washington's nursemaid.
The first Great Moon Hoax article is published in The New York Sun, announcing the discovery of life and civilization on the Moon.
Australia: Melbourne, Victoria is founded.
HMS Beagle, with Charles Darwin aboard, reaches the Galápagos Islands. The ship lands at Chatham or San Cristobal, the easternmost of the archipelago.
The decade-long Ragamuffin War starts when rebels capture Porto Alegre in Brazil.
Texas Revolution: Mexican troops attempt to disarm the people of Gonzales, but encounter stiff resistance from a hastily assembled militia.
The United Tribes of New Zealand are established with the signature of the Declaration of Independence.
Construction is completed on the Wilberforce Monument in Kingston Upon Hull.
The Texas Provincial Government authorizes the creation of a horse-mounted police force called the Texas Rangers (which is now the Texas Ranger Division of the Texas Department of Public Safety).
James Pratt and John Smith are hanged in London; they are the last two to be executed for sodomy in England.
Texas Revolution: The Texian Army captures San Antonio following the Siege of Béxar.
The second Great Fire of New York destroys 53,000 square metres (13 acres) of New York City's Financial District.
Osceola leads his Seminole warriors in Florida into the Second Seminole War against the United States Army.
The Treaty of New Echota is signed, ceding all the lands of the Cherokee east of the Mississippi River to the United States.
King William IV signs Letters Patent establishing the province of South Australia.
Texas Revolution: The Siege of the Alamo (prelude to the Battle of the Alamo) begins in San Antonio, Texas.
Samuel Colt is granted a United States patent for his revolver firearm.
A convention of delegates from 57 Texas communities convenes in Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas, to deliberate independence from Mexico.
Texas Revolution: The Declaration of independence of the Republic of Texas from Mexico is adopted.
Samuel Colt established his first factory to produce recently patented production-model revolver, the .34-caliber "Paterson".

Texas Revolution: Battle of the Alamo: After a thirteen-day siege by an army of 3,000 Mexican troops, the 187 Texas volunteers, including frontiersman Davy Crockett and colonel Jim Bowie, defending the Alamo are killed and the fort is captured.
source_pages: Texas_Revolution; Battle_of_the_Alamo; Siege; Davy_Crockett; James_Bowie; Alamo_Mission

event_text: Texas Revolution: On the orders of General Antonio López de Santa Anna, the Mexican Army massacres 342 Texian Army POWs at Goliad, Texas.
source_pages: Texas_Revolution; Antonio_López_de_Santa_Anna; Mexican_Army; Goliad_massacre; Texian_Army; Goliad,_Texas

event_text: U.S. Congress passes an act creating the Wisconsin Territory.
Texas Revolution: The Battle of San Jacinto: Republic of Texas forces under Sam Houston defeat troops under Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna.

Texas Revolution: A day after the Battle of San Jacinto, forces under Texas General Sam Houston identify Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna among the captives of the battle when some of his fellow soldiers mistakenly give away his identity.
source_pages: Texas_Revolution; Battle_of_San_Jacinto; Republic_of_Texas; Sam_Houston; Antonio_López_de_Santa_Anna; April_22

event_text: Formation of Ancient Order of Hibernians.
The Treaties of Velasco are signed in Velasco, Texas.
Francis Baily observes "Baily's beads" during an annular eclipse.
The formation of the London Working Men's Association gives rise to the Chartist Movement.
The Fly-fisher's Entomology is published by Alfred Ronalds. The book transformed the sport and went to many editions.
Inauguration of the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, France.
British parliament accepts registration of births, marriages and deaths.
The city of Houston is founded by Augustus Chapman Allen and John Kirby Allen.
Narcissa Whitman, one of the first English-speaking white women to settle west of the Rocky Mountains, arrives at Walla Walla, Washington.
Sam Houston is elected as the first president of the Republic of Texas.
The Riograndense Republic is proclaimed by rebels after defeating Empire of Brazil's troops in the Battle of Seival, during the Ragamuffin War.
Great Trek: Afrikaner voortrekkers repulse a Matabele attack, but lose their livestock.
Sam Houston is inaugurated as the first President of the Republic of Texas.
The Toledo War unofficially ends as the "Frostbitten Convention" votes to accept Congress' terms for admitting Michigan as a U.S. state.
The U.S. Patent Office building in Washington, D.C., nearly burns to the ground, destroying all 9,957 patents issued by the federal government to that date, as well as 7,000 related patent models.
The worst ever avalanche in England occurs at Lewes, Sussex, killing eight people.
South Australia and Adelaide are founded.
Spain recognizes the independence of Mexico with the signing of the Santa María–Calatrava Treaty.
Michigan is admitted as the 26th U.S. state.
Richard Johnson becomes the first and only Vice President of the United States chosen by the Senate.
The city of Chicago is incorporated.
The great fire in Surat city of India caused more than 500 deaths and destruction of more than 9,000 houses.
The University of Athens is founded in Athens, Greece.
Panic of 1837: New York City banks suspend the payment of specie, triggering a national banking crisis and an economic depression whose severity was not surpassed until the Great Depression.
Houston is incorporated by the Republic of Texas.
The Broad Street Riot occurs in Boston, fueled by ethnic tensions between Yankees and Irish.
King William IV dies, and is succeeded by his niece, Victoria.
A system of civil registration of births, marriages and deaths is established in England and Wales.
Grand Junction Railway, the world's first long-distance railway, opens between Birmingham and Liverpool.
The first commercial use of an electrical telegraph is successfully demonstrated in London by William Cooke and Charles Wheatstone.
Tiffany & Co. (first named Tiffany & Young) is founded by Charles Lewis Tiffany and Teddy Young in New York City. The store is called a "stationery and fancy goods emporium".
Approximately 300 Muscogee die in the steamboat Monmouth disaster on the Trail of Tears in the United States.
In Alton, Illinois, abolitionist printer Elijah P. Lovejoy is shot dead by a mob while attempting to protect his printing shop from being destroyed a third time.
Mary Lyon founds Mount Holyoke Female Seminary, which later becomes Mount Holyoke College.
An earthquake in Valdivia, south-central Chile, causes a tsunami that leads to significant destruction along Japan's coast.
Canadian journalist and politician William Lyon Mackenzie calls for a rebellion against the United Kingdom in his essay "To the People of Upper Canada", published in his newspaper The Constitution.
The Battle of Montgomery's Tavern, the only battle of the Upper Canada Rebellion, takes place in Toronto, where the rebels are quickly defeated.
A fire in the Winter Palace of Saint Petersburg kills 30 guards.
Second Seminole War: American general Zachary Taylor leads 1,100 troops against the Seminoles at the Battle of Lake Okeechobee.
Alfred Vail and colleagues demonstrate a telegraph system using dots and dashes (this is the forerunner of Morse code).
Weenen massacre: Hundreds of Voortrekkers along the Blaukraans River, Natal are killed by Zulus.
The French Army captures Veracruz in the Pastry War.
Nicaragua declares independence from the Central American Federation.
Myall Creek massacre: Twenty-eight Aboriginal Australians are murdered.
Coronation of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom.
The Iowa Territory is organized.

Ralph Waldo Emerson delivers the Divinity School Address at Harvard Divinity School, discounting Biblical miracles and declaring Jesus a great man, but not God. The Protestant community reacts with outrage.
source_pages: Ralph_Waldo_Emerson; Divinity_School_Address; Harvard_Divinity_School; Miracles_of_Jesus; Jesus; Protestantism_in_the_United_States

event_text: The Wilkes Expedition, which would explore the Puget Sound and Antarctica, weighs anchor at Hampton Roads.
Saint Andrew's Scots School, the oldest school of British origin in South America, is established.
Future abolitionist Frederick Douglass escapes from slavery.
The Anti-Corn Law League is established by Richard Cobden.
The Killough massacre in east Texas sees eighteen Texian settlers either killed or kidnapped.
Missouri governor Lilburn Boggs issues the Extermination Order, which orders all Mormons to leave the state or be killed.
The Times of India, the world's largest circulated English language daily broadsheet newspaper is founded as The Bombay Times and Journal of Commerce.

Great Trek: Battle of Blood River: Voortrekkers led by Andries Pretorius and Sarel Cilliers defeat Zulu impis, led by Dambuza (Nzobo) and Ndlela kaSompisi in what is today KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.
source_pages: Great_Trek; Battle_of_Blood_River; Andries_Pretorius; Sarel_Cilliers; Zulu_people; Impi; Ndlela_kaSompisi; KwaZulu-Natal; December_16

event_text: The Night of the Big Wind, the most damaging storm in 300 years, sweeps across Ireland, damaging or destroying more than 20% of the houses in Dublin.
The French Academy of Sciences announces the Daguerreotype photography process.
The British East India Company captures Aden.
In the Battle of Yungay, Chile defeats an alliance between Peru and Bolivia.
A massive earthquake destroys the former capital Inwa of the Konbaung dynasty, present-day Myanmar.
The first Henley Royal Regatta is held.
The Treaty of London establishes Belgium as a kingdom and guarantees its neutrality.
In Humen, China, Lin Zexu destroys 1.2 million kilograms of opium confiscated from British merchants, providing Britain with a casus belli to open hostilities, resulting in the First Opium War.
Henley Royal Regatta: the village of Henley-on-Thames, on the River Thames in Oxfordshire, stages its first regatta.

In the Kingdom of Hawaii, Kamehameha III issues the edict of toleration which gives Roman Catholics the freedom to worship in the Hawaiian Islands. The Hawaii Catholic Church and the Cathedral of Our Lady of Peace are established as a result.
source_pages: Hawaiian_Kingdom; Kamehameha_III; Edict_of_toleration; Catholic_Church; Hawaiian_Islands; Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Honolulu; Cathedral_Basilica_of_Our_Lady_of_Peace

event_text: Cherokee leaders Major Ridge, John Ridge, and Elias Boudinot are assassinated for signing the Treaty of New Echota, which had resulted in the Trail of Tears.
source_pages: Cherokee; Major_Ridge; John_Ridge; Elias_Boudinot_(Cherokee); Treaty_of_New_Echota; Cherokee_removal

event_text: Twenty miles off the coast of Cuba, 53 kidnapped Africans led by Joseph Cinqué mutiny and take over the slave ship Amistad.
The first state normal school in the United States, the forerunner to today's Framingham State University, opens in Lexington, Massachusetts with three students.
The French government announces that Louis Daguerre's photographic process is a gift "free to the world".
The United Kingdom captures Hong Kong as a base as it prepares for the First Opium War with Qing China.
Battle of Kowloon: British vessels open fire on Chinese war junks enforcing a food sales embargo on the British community in China in the first armed conflict of the First Opium War.
The United Kingdom declares war on the Qing dynasty of China.
John Herschel takes the first glass plate photograph.
Newport Rising: The last large-scale armed rebellion against authority in mainland Britain.
The Virginia Military Institute is founded in Lexington, Virginia.
A cyclone slams into south-eastern India.  An estimated 300,000 deaths resulted from the disaster.
In Boston, Massachusetts, the American Statistical Association is founded.
The steamship Lexington burns and sinks four miles off the coast of Long Island with the loss of 139 lives.
Signing of the Treaty of Waitangi, establishing New Zealand as a British colony.
Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom marries Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.
Gaetano Donizetti's opera La fille du régiment receives its first performance in Paris, France.
The Penny Black, the first official adhesive postage stamp, is issued in the United Kingdom.
The Penny Black postage stamp becomes valid for use in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
The Great Natchez Tornado strikes Natchez, Mississippi killing 317 people. It is the second deadliest tornado in United States history.
The penal transportation of British convicts to the New South Wales colony is abolished.
Samuel Morse receives the patent for the telegraph.
A Ms  7.4 earthquake strikes present-day Turkey and Armenia; combined with the effects of an eruption on Mount Ararat, kills 10,000 people.
The Province of Canada is created by the Act of Union.
Willem II becomes King of the Netherlands.
The Maronite leader Bashir Shihab II surrenders to the Ottoman Empire and later is sent to Malta in exile.
Hong Kong Island is occupied by the British during the First Opium War.
Gordon Bremer takes formal possession of Hong Kong Island at what is now Possession Point, establishing British Hong Kong.
The U.S. Supreme Court rules in the United States v. The Amistad case that captive Africans who had seized control of the ship carrying them had been taken into slavery illegally.
The National Bank of Greece is founded in Athens.

William Henry Harrison dies of pneumonia, becoming the first President of the United States to die in office, and setting the record for the briefest administration. Vice President John Tyler succeeds Harrison as President.
U.S. President John Tyler is sworn in, two days after having become president upon William Henry Harrison's death.
The Paris Opera Ballet premieres Giselle in the Salle Le Peletier.
Thomas Lempriere and James Clark Ross carve a marker on the Isle of the Dead in Van Diemen's Land to measure tidal variations, one of the earliest surviving benchmarks for sea level rise.
source_pages: Thomas_Lempriere; James_Clark_Ross; Isle_of_the_Dead_(Tasmania); Van_Diemen's_Land; Sea_level_rise; July_1

event_text: Thomas Cook organises the first package excursion, from Leicester to Loughborough.
Coronation of Emperor Pedro II of Brazil.

U.S. President John Tyler vetoes a bill which called for the re-establishment of the Second Bank of the United States. Enraged Whig Party members riot outside the White House in the most violent demonstration on White House grounds in U.S. history.
The Sultanate of Brunei cedes Sarawak to James Brooke.
Queen's University is founded in the Province of Canada.
James Braid first sees a demonstration of animal magnetism by Charles Lafontaine, which leads to his study of the subject he eventually calls hypnotism.

Dr. William Brydon, an assistant surgeon in the British East India Company Army during the First Anglo-Afghan War, becomes famous for being the sole survivor of an army of 4,500 men and 12,000 camp followers when he reaches the safety of a garrison in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.
Battle of Debre Tabor: Ras Ali Alula, Regent of the Emperor of Ethiopia defeats warlord Wube Haile Maryam of Semien.
John Greenough is granted the first U.S. patent for the sewing machine.
Giuseppe Verdi's third opera, Nabucco, receives its première performance in Milan; its success establishes Verdi as one of Italy's foremost opera composers.
The first documented discovery of gold in California occurs at Rancho San Francisco, six years before the California Gold Rush.
The Female Relief Society of Nauvoo is formally organized with Emma Smith as president.
First concert of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Otto Nicolai.
Ether anesthesia is used for the first time, in an operation by the American surgeon Dr. Crawford Long.
A train derails and catches fire in Paris, killing between 52 and 200 people.
The first edition of the The Illustrated London News, the world's first illustrated weekly news magazine, was published.
The first major wagon train heading for the Pacific Northwest sets out on the Oregon Trail from Elm Grove, Missouri, with 100 pioneers.
John Francis attempts to murder Queen Victoria as she drives down Constitution Hill in London with Prince Albert.
The Lombard Street riot erupts in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States.
The Webster–Ashburton Treaty is signed, establishing the United States–Canada border east of the Rocky Mountains.
American Indian Wars: Second Seminole War ends, with the Seminoles forced from Florida.
Treaty of Nanking signing ends the First Opium War.
A slave revolt in the Cherokee Nation commences.
First concert of the New York Philharmonic, founded by Ureli Corelli Hill.
The first minstrel show in the United States, The Virginia Minstrels, opens (Bowery Amphitheatre in New York City).
Giuseppe Verdi's opera I Lombardi alla prima crociata receives its first performance in Milan, Italy.
Lord George Paulet occupies the Kingdom of Hawaii in the name of Great Britain in the Paulet affair.
The Disruption in Edinburgh of the Free Church of Scotland from the Church of Scotland.
The Wairau Affray, the first serious clash of arms between Māori and British settlers in the New Zealand Wars, takes place.
Treaty of Nanking comes into effect, Hong Kong Island is ceded to the British "in perpetuity".
Brunel's steamship the SS Great Britain is launched, becoming the first ocean-going craft with an iron hull and screw propeller, becoming the largest vessel afloat in the world.

The Cathedral of Our Lady of Peace in Honolulu, Hawaii is dedicated. Now the cathedral of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Honolulu, it is the oldest Roman Catholic cathedral in continuous use in the United States.
Tivoli Gardens, one of the oldest still intact amusement parks in the world, opens in Copenhagen, Denmark.
King Otto of Greece is forced to grant a constitution following an uprising in Athens.
The Greek Army rebels (OS date: September 3) against the autocratic rule of king Otto of Greece, demanding the granting of a constitution.
The crew of schooner Ancud, led by John Williams Wilson, takes possession of the Strait of Magellan on behalf of the Chilean government.
In New York City, B'nai B'rith, the oldest Jewish service organization in the world, is founded.
Irish nationalist Daniel O'Connell is arrested by the British on charges of criminal conspiracy.
William Rowan Hamilton invents quaternions, a three-dimensional system of complex numbers.
Ka Lā Hui (Hawaiian Independence Day): The Kingdom of Hawaii is officially recognized by the United Kingdom and France as an independent nation.
The discovery of octonions by John T. Graves, who denoted them with a boldface O, was announced to his mathematician friend William Hamilton, discoverer of quaternions, in a letter on this date.
The first issue of the Swedish-languaged Saima newspaper founded by J. V. Snellman is published in Kuopio, Finland.
The Dominican Republic gains independence from Haiti.

A gun explodes on board the steam warship USS Princeton during a pleasure cruise down the Potomac River, killing six, including Secretary of State Abel Upshur. President John Tyler, who was also on board, was not injured from the blast.
King Oscar I ascends to the thrones of Sweden and Norway.
The Althing, the parliament of Iceland, was reopened after 45 years of closure.
The Baháʼí calendar begins. This is the first day of the first year of the Baháʼí calendar. It is annually celebrated by members of the Baháʼí Faith as the Baháʼí New Year or Náw-Rúz.
One of the most important battles of the Dominican War of Independence from Haiti takes place near the city of Santiago de los Caballeros.
Hong Kong Police Force, the world's second modern police force and Asia's first, is established.
Báb: A merchant of Shiraz announces that he is a Prophet and founds a religious movement. He is considered to be a forerunner of the Baháʼí Faith.

Samuel Morse sends the message "What hath God wrought" (a biblical quotation, Numbers 23:23) from a committee room in the United States Capitol to his assistant, Alfred Vail, in Baltimore, Maryland, to inaugurate a commercial telegraph line between Baltimore and Washington D.C.
source_pages: Samuel_Morse; Bible; Book_of_Numbers; United_States_Capitol; Alfred_Vail; Baltimore; Maryland; Telegraphy; May_24

event_text: The last pair of great auks is killed.
The Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) is founded in London.
Joseph Smith, founder of the Latter Day Saint movement, and his brother Hyrum Smith, are killed by a mob at the Carthage, Illinois jail.
The Quorum of the Twelve Apostles, headed by Brigham Young, is reaffirmed as the leading body of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church).

Governor-general of the Philippines Narciso Claveria, signs a decree to reform the country's calendar by skipping Tuesday, December 31, as a solution to anomalies that had existed since Ferdinand Magellan's arrival in 1521.
Oscar I of Sweden–Norway is crowned king of Sweden.

The Millerites (followers of Baptist preacher William Miller) anticipate the end of the world in conjunction with the Second Advent of Christ. The following day becomes known as the Great Disappointment.
The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers commences business at its cooperative in Rochdale, England, starting the Cooperative movement.

The Philippines skipped this date in order to align the country with the rest of Asia, as the trading interest switched to China, Dutch East Indies and neighboring territories after Mexico gained independence from Spain on 27 September 1821. In the islands, Monday, 30 December 1844 was immediately followed by Wednesday, 1 January 1845.

The Philippines moves its national calendar to align with other Asian countries' calendars by skipping Tuesday, December 31, 1844. The change has been ordered by Governor–General Narciso Claveria to reform the country's calendar so that it aligns with the rest of Asia. Its territory has been one day behind the rest of Asia for 323 years since the arrival of Ferdinand Magellan in the Philippines on March 16, 1521.
"The Raven" is published in The Evening Mirror in New York, the first publication with the name of the author, Edgar Allan Poe.
United States President John Tyler signs a bill authorizing the United States to annex the Republic of Texas.
Florida is admitted as the 27th U.S. state.

Flagstaff War: Unhappy with translational differences regarding the Treaty of Waitangi, chiefs Hōne Heke, Kawiti and Māori tribe members chop down the British flagpole for a fourth time and drive settlers out of Kororāreka, New Zealand.
source_pages: Flagstaff_War; Treaty_of_Waitangi; Hōne_Heke; Te_Ruki_Kawiti; Māori_people; Russell,_New_Zealand; March_11

event_text: Felix Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto receives its première performance in Leipzig with Ferdinand David as soloist.
New Zealand Legislative Council pass the first Militia Act constituting the New Zealand Army.
Captain Sir John Franklin and his ill-fated Arctic expedition depart from Greenhithe, England.
The Fatel Razack coming from India, lands in the Gulf of Paria in Trinidad and Tobago carrying the first Indians to the country.
Henry David Thoreau moves into a small cabin on Walden Pond in Concord, Massachusetts. Thoreau's account of his two years there, Walden, will become a touchstone of the environmental movement.

Great New York City Fire of 1845: The last great fire to affect Manhattan begins early in the morning and is subdued that afternoon. The fire kills four firefighters and 26 civilians and destroys 345 buildings.
The first issue of Scientific American magazine is published.
Possible start of the Great Famine of Ireland.
In Annapolis, Maryland, the Naval School (later the United States Naval Academy) opens with 50 students.
Anglo-French blockade of the Río de la Plata: Battle of Vuelta de Obligado.
Manifest Destiny: In a State of the Union message, U.S. President James K. Polk proposes that the United States should aggressively expand into the West.
Ether anesthetic is used for childbirth for the first time by Dr. Crawford Long in Jefferson, Georgia.

Having coined the phrase "manifest destiny" the previous July, journalist John L. O'Sullivan argued in his newspaper New York Morning News that the United States had the right to claim the entire Oregon Country.
The United States annexes the Republic of Texas and admits it as the 28th state.
Slavery in Tunisia is abolished.
The Battle of Aliwal, India, is won by British troops commanded by Sir Harry Smith.
After the Milwaukee Bridge War, the United States towns of Juneautown and Kilbourntown unify to create the City of Milwaukee.
The first Mormon pioneers make their exodus from Nauvoo, Illinois, westward towards Salt Lake Valley.
First Anglo-Sikh War: Battle of Sobraon: British defeat Sikhs in the final battle of the war.

In Austin, Texas, the newly formed Texas state government is officially installed. The Republic of Texas government officially transfers power to the State of Texas government following the annexation of Texas by the United States.
Polish insurgents lead an uprising in Kraków to incite a fight for national independence.
Thornton Affair: Open conflict begins over the disputed border of Texas, triggering the Mexican–American War.
The few remaining Mormons left in Nauvoo, Illinois, formally dedicate the Nauvoo Temple.
The Cambridge Chronicle, America's oldest surviving weekly newspaper, is published for the first time in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
Mexican–American War: American forces led by Zachary Taylor defeat a Mexican force north of the Rio Grande in the first major battle of the war.
The Donner Party of pioneers departs Independence, Missouri for California, on what will become a year-long journey of hardship and cannibalism.
source_pages: Donner_Party; Settler; Independence,_Missouri; California; Human_cannibalism; May_12

event_text: Mexican–American War: The United States declares war on the Federal Republic of Mexico following a dispute over the American annexation of the Republic of Texas and a Mexican military incursion.
source_pages: Mexican–American_War; United_States; United_States_declaration_of_war_on_Mexico; Second_Federal_Republic_of_Mexico; Texas_annexation; Republic_of_Texas; Thornton_Affair; May_13

event_text: The Associated Press is formed in New York City as a non-profit news cooperative.
Mexican–American War: President Mariano Paredes of Mexico unofficially declares war on the United States.
Bear Flag Revolt begins: Anglo settlers in Sonoma, California, start a rebellion against Mexico and proclaim the California Republic.
The Oregon Treaty extends the border between the United States and British North America, established by the Treaty of 1818, westward to the Pacific Ocean.
The Papal conclave of 1846 elects Pope Pius IX, beginning the longest reign in the history of the papacy.

The first officially recorded, organized baseball game is played under Alexander Cartwright's rules on Hoboken, New Jersey's Elysian Fields with the New York Base Ball Club defeating the Knickerbockers 23–1. Cartwright umpired.
US troops occupy Monterey and Yerba Buena, thus beginning the US conquest of California.
The Second Federal Republic of Mexico is established.
Elias Howe is granted a patent for the sewing machine.
Jang Bahadur and his brothers massacre about 40 members of the Nepalese palace court.
Two French shepherd children, Mélanie Calvat and Maximin Giraud, experience a Marian apparition on a mountaintop near La Salette, France, now known as Our Lady of La Salette.
Astronomers Urbain Le Verrier, John Couch Adams and Johann Gottfried Galle collaborate on the discovery of Neptune.
Mexican–American War: General Zachary Taylor captures Monterrey.
Triton, the largest moon of the planet Neptune, is discovered by English astronomer William Lassell.
William T. G. Morton administers ether anesthesia during a surgical operation.
British acquired Labuan from the Sultanate of Brunei for Great Britain.
Iowa is admitted as the 29th U.S. state.
The world's first "Mercy" Hospital is founded in Pittsburgh, United States, by a group of Sisters of Mercy from Ireland; the name will go on to grace over 30 major hospitals throughout the world.
Samuel Colt obtains his first contract for the sale of revolver pistols to the United States government.
The Treaty of Cahuenga ends the Mexican–American War in California.
Westward expansion of the United States: John C. Frémont is appointed Governor of the new California Territory.
Yerba Buena, California is renamed San Francisco, California.
The first group of rescuers reaches the Donner Party.
Mexican–American War: The Battle of Buena Vista: Five thousand American troops defeat 15,000 Mexican troops.
Mexican–American War: Battle of Buena Vista: In Mexico, American troops under future president General Zachary Taylor defeat Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna.
Mexican–American War: The first large-scale amphibious assault in U.S. history is launched in the Siege of Veracruz.
Mexican–American War: United States forces led by General Winfield Scott take Veracruz after a siege.
Shooting of a Māori by an English sailor results in the opening of the Wanganui Campaign of the New Zealand Wars.
American victory at the battle of Cerro Gordo opens the way for invasion of Mexico.
After 17 months of travel, Brigham Young leads 148 Mormon pioneers into Salt Lake Valley, resulting in the establishment of Salt Lake City.
Richard March Hoe,  American inventor, patented the rotary-type printing press.
Liberia declares its independence from the United States. France and the United Kingdom are the first to recognize the new nation.
Mexican–American War: the Battle of Chapultepec begins.

Mexican–American War: Six teenage military cadets known as Niños Héroes die defending Chapultepec Castle in the Battle of Chapultepec. American troops under General Winfield Scott capture Mexico City in the Mexican–American War.
source_pages: Mexican–American_War; Cadet; Niños_Héroes; Chapultepec_Castle; Battle_of_Chapultepec; Winfield_Scott

event_text: Slavery is abolished in the Swedish colony of Saint Barthélemy.
The novel Jane Eyre is published in London.
Sir James Young Simpson, a Scottish physician, discovers the anaesthetic properties of chloroform.
The passenger ship Stephen Whitney is wrecked in thick fog off the southern coast of Ireland, killing 92 of the 110 on board. The disaster results in the construction of the Fastnet Rock lighthouse.
The second Canadian railway line, the Montreal and Lachine Railroad, is opened.
The Sonderbund is defeated by the joint forces of other Swiss cantons under General Guillaume-Henri Dufour.
Missionaries Dr. Marcus Whitman, his wife Narcissa, and 15 others are killed by Cayuse and Umatilla Indians, causing the Cayuse War.
Jefferson Davis is elected to the U.S. Senate.
Joseph Jenkins Roberts is sworn in as the first president of Liberia.
The Palermo rising takes place in Sicily against the Bourbon Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
California Gold Rush: James W. Marshall finds gold at Sutter's Mill near Sacramento.
John C. Frémont is court-martialed for mutiny and disobeying orders.
Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels publish The Communist Manifesto.
The French Revolution of 1848, which would lead to the establishment of the French Second Republic, begins.
King Louis-Philippe of France abdicates the throne.
Carlo Alberto di Savoia signs the Statuto Albertino that will later represent the first constitution of the Regno d'Italia.
The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is ratified by the United States Senate, ending the Mexican–American War.
Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine and Robert Baldwin become the first Prime Ministers of the Province of Canada to be democratically elected under a system of responsible government.
The German revolutions of 1848–1849 begin in Vienna.
A revolution breaks out in Hungary, and the Habsburg rulers are compelled to meet the demands of the reform party.
The premiere of Fry's Leonora in Philadelphia is the first known performance of a grand opera by an American composer.
Revolutions of 1848: A rebellion arose in Milan which in five days of street fighting drove Marshal Radetzky and his Austrian soldiers from the city.
German revolutions of 1848–49: King Ludwig I of Bavaria abdicates.
The ship John Wickliffe arrives at Port Chalmers carrying the first Scottish settlers for Dunedin, New Zealand. Otago province is founded.
The boar-crested Anglo-Saxon Benty Grange helmet is discovered in a barrow on the Benty Grange farm in Derbyshire.
Opening of the first German National Assembly (Nationalversammlung) in Frankfurt, Germany.

Mexican–American War: Mexico ratifies the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo thus ending the war and ceding California, Nevada, Utah and parts of four other modern-day U.S. states to the United States for US$15 million.
Slavery is abolished in Martinique.
The Slavic Congress opens in Prague.
In the Wallachian Revolution, Ion Heliade Rădulescu and Christian Tell issue the Proclamation of Islaz and create a new republican government.
A photograph of the June Days uprising becomes the first known instance of photojournalism.
End of the June Days Uprising in Paris.
Governor-General Peter von Scholten emancipates all remaining slaves in the Danish West Indies.
Waterloo railway station in London opens.
Women's rights: A two-day Women's Rights Convention opens in Seneca Falls, New York.
The first Women's Rights Convention in Seneca Falls, New York, a two-day event, concludes.
The University of Wisconsin–Madison is established by Nelson Dewey, first Governor of Wisconsin.
Great Famine of Ireland: Tipperary Revolt: In County Tipperary, Ireland, then in the United Kingdom, an unsuccessful nationalist revolt against British rule is put down by police.
Oregon Territory is organized by act of Congress.
Camila O'Gorman and Ladislao Gutierrez are executed on the orders of Argentine dictator Juan Manuel de Rosas.
California Gold Rush: The New York Herald breaks the news to the East Coast of the United States of the gold rush in California (although the rush started in January).
A new constitution marks the establishment of Switzerland as a federal state.

Vermont railroad worker Phineas Gage survives an iron rod 1+1⁄4 inches (3.2 cm) in diameter being driven through his brain; the reported effects on his behavior and personality stimulate discussion of the nature of the brain and its functions.
The Battle of Pákozd is a stalemate between Hungarian and Croatian forces and is the first battle of the Hungarian Revolution.
In Boston, Massachusetts, the first medical school for women, Boston Female Medical School (which later merged with the Boston University School of Medicine), opens.
A greatly revised Dutch constitution, which transfers much authority from the king to his parliament and ministers, is proclaimed.
Franz Joseph I becomes Emperor of Austria.
California Gold Rush: In a message to the United States Congress, U.S. President James K. Polk confirms that large amounts of gold had been discovered in California.

French presidential election: Having won the popular vote in a landslide, Louis Napoleon Bonaparte is inaugurated in the chamber of the National Assembly as the first (and only) president of the French Second Republic.
Establishment of the Colony of Vancouver Island.
Second Anglo-Sikh War: Battle of Chillianwala: British forces retreat from the Sikhs.
Second Anglo-Sikh War: The Siege of Multan ends after nine months when the last Sikh defenders of Multan, Punjab, surrender.
Elizabeth Blackwell is awarded her M.D. by the Geneva Medical College of Geneva, New York, becoming the United States' first female doctor.
The new Roman Republic is declared.

The delegation headed by Metropolitan bishop Andrei Șaguna hands out to the Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria the General Petition of Romanian leaders in Transylvania, Banat and Bukovina, which demands that the Romanian nation be recognized.
source_pages: Andrei_Șaguna; Franz_Joseph_I_of_Austria; Transylvania; Banat; Bukovina; Romanians
