event_text: In New York City, James Knox Polk becomes the first serving President of the United States to have his photograph taken.
The Territory of Minnesota is created.

Zachary Taylor, 12th President of the United States of America and Millard Fillmore, 12th Vice President, did not take their respective oaths of office (they did so the following day), leading to the erroneous theory that outgoing President pro tempore of the United States Senate David Rice Atchison had assumed the role of acting president for one day.
source_pages: Zachary_Taylor; President_of_the_United_States; Millard_Fillmore; Inauguration_of_Zachary_Taylor; President_pro_tempore_of_the_United_States_Senate; David_Rice_Atchison; Acting_President_of_the_United_States

event_text: The Austrians defeat the Piedmontese at the Battle of Novara.
The United Kingdom annexes the Punjab.
Lajos Kossuth presents the Hungarian Declaration of Independence in a closed session of the National Assembly.
Hungary declares itself independent of Austria with Lajos Kossuth as its leader.
The Governor General of Canada, Lord Elgin, signs the Rebellion Losses Bill, outraging Montreal's English population and triggering the Montreal Riots.
The May Uprising in Dresden begins: The last of the German revolutions of 1848–49.

Astor Place Riot: A riot breaks out at the Astor Opera House in Manhattan, New York City over a dispute between actors Edwin Forrest and William Charles Macready, killing at least 22 and injuring over 120.
source_pages: Astor_Place_Riot; Astor_Opera_House; Manhattan; Edwin_Forrest; William_Macready; May_10

event_text: The Sicilian revolution of 1848 is finally extinguished.
Future U.S. President Abraham Lincoln is issued a patent for an invention to lift boats, making him the only U.S. president to ever hold a patent.
Territorial Governor Alexander Ramsey declared the Territory of Minnesota officially established.
Denmark becomes a constitutional monarchy by the signing of a new constitution.
France invades the Roman Republic and restores the Papal States.
The Charleston Workhouse Slave Rebellion began in Charleston, South Carolina, United States.
The first air raid in history occurs; Austria launches pilotless balloons against the city of Venice
Antonio María Claret y Clará founds the Congregation of the Missionary Sons of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, popularly known as the Claretians in Vic, in the province of Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain.
Joven Daniel wrecks at the coast of Araucanía, Chile, leading to allegations that local Mapuche tribes murdered survivors and kidnapped Elisa Bravo.

Passaleão incident: João Maria Ferreira do Amaral, the governor of Portuguese Macau, is assassinated by a group of Chinese locals, triggering a military confrontation between China and Portugal at the Battle of Passaleão three days after.
source_pages: Passaleão_incident; João_Maria_Ferreira_do_Amaral; Governor_of_Macau; Portuguese_Macau; Qing_dynasty; History_of_Portugal_(1834–1910); August_22

event_text: President Faustin Soulouque of the First Republic of Haiti has the Senate and Chamber of Deputies proclaim him the Emperor of Haiti, abolishing the Republic and inaugurating the Second Empire of Haiti.
Revolutions of 1848 in the Austrian Empire: After a month-long siege, Venice, which had declared itself independent as the Republic of San Marco, surrenders to Austria.
American abolitionist Harriet Tubman escapes from slavery.
The execution of the 13 Martyrs of Arad after the Hungarian war of independence.
The city of Manizales, Colombia, is founded by 'The Expedition of the 20'.
Boilers of the steamboat Louisiana explode as she pulls back from the dock in New Orleans, killing more than 150 people.
A Russian court sentences writer Fyodor Dostoyevsky to death for anti-government activities linked to a radical intellectual group; his sentence is later commuted to hard labor.
Henry Clay introduces the Compromise of 1850 to the U.S. Congress.
The Britannia Bridge across the Menai Strait between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales is opened.
Senator Daniel Webster gives his "Seventh of March" speech endorsing the Compromise of 1850 in order to prevent a possible civil war.
The Arana–Southern Treaty is ratified, ending "the existing differences" between Great Britain and Argentina.
The American League of Colored Laborers, the first African American labor union in the United States, is established in New York City.
Princess Louise of the Netherlands marries Crown Prince Karl of Sweden–Norway.
Autocephaly officially granted by the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople to the Church of Greece.
U.S. President Zachary Taylor dies after eating raw fruit and iced milk; he is succeeded in office by Vice President Millard Fillmore.
Persian prophet Báb is executed in Tabriz, Persia.
U.S. President Millard Fillmore is sworn in, a day after becoming president upon Zachary Taylor's death.
Vega became the first star (other than the Sun) to be photographed.
Richard Wagner's Lohengrin premieres at the Staatskapelle Weimar.
The Compromise of 1850 transfers a third of Texas's claimed territory to federal control in return for the U.S. federal government assuming $10 million of Texas's pre-annexation debt.
California is admitted as the thirty-first U.S. state.
The U.S. Congress passes the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850.
The papal bull Universalis Ecclesiae restores the Roman Catholic hierarchy in England and Wales.
Riots start, which lead to a massacre in Aleppo.
The first National Women's Rights Convention begins in Worcester, Massachusetts.
Danish troops defeat a Schleswig-Holstein force in the town of Lottorf, Schleswig-Holstein.
The treaty, Punctation of Olmütz, is signed in Olomouc. Prussia capitulates to Austria, which will take over the leadership of the German Confederation.
source_pages: Punctation_of_Olmütz; Olomouc; Prussia; Austrian_Empire; German_Confederation; November_29

event_text: The Charlotte Jane and the Randolph bring the first of the Canterbury Pilgrims to Lyttelton, New Zealand.
Taiping Rebellion: Hong Xiuquan proclaims the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom, starting the Jintian Uprising.
Northwestern University becomes the first chartered university in Illinois.
The largest Australian bushfires in a populous region in recorded history take place in the state of Victoria.
The first performance of Rigoletto by Giuseppe Verdi takes place in Venice.
Rama IV is crowned King of Thailand after the death of his half-brother, Rama III.
Queen Victoria opens The Great Exhibition at The Crystal Palace in London.
The first Australian gold rush is proclaimed, although the discovery had been made three months earlier.
Slavery in Colombia is abolished.
Sojourner Truth delivers her famous Ain't I a Woman? speech at the Woman's Rights Convention in Akron, Ohio.
Harriet Beecher Stowe's anti-slavery serial, Uncle Tom's Cabin, or Life Among the Lowly, starts a ten-month run in the National Era abolitionist newspaper.
Annibale de Gasparis discovers asteroid 15 Eunomia.
Isaac Singer is granted a patent for his sewing machine.
The first America's Cup is won by the yacht America.

Christiana Resistance: Escaped slaves led by William Parker fight off and kill a slave owner who, with a federal marshal and an armed party, sought to seize three of his former slaves in Christiana, Pennsylvania, thereby creating a cause célèbre between slavery proponents and abolitionists.
First publication of The New-York Daily Times, which later becomes The New York Times.
Herman Melville's Moby-Dick is first published as The Whale by Richard Bentley of London.
William Lassell discovers the moons Umbriel and Ariel orbiting Uranus.
Kentucky marshals abduct abolitionist minister Calvin Fairbank from Jeffersonville, Indiana, and take him to Kentucky to stand trial for helping a slave escape.
The Denny Party lands at Alki Point, before moving to the other side of Elliott Bay to what would become Seattle.
Moby-Dick, a novel by Herman Melville, is published in the USA.
Mutineers take control of the Chilean penal colony of Punta Arenas in the Strait of Magellan.
French President Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte overthrows the Second Republic.
Conservative Santiago-based government troops defeat rebels at the Battle of Loncomilla, signaling the end of the 1851 Chilean Revolution.
The first YMCA in North America is established in Montreal.
India's first freight train is operated in Roorkee, to transport material for the construction of the Ganges Canal.
The Library of Congress in Washington, D.C., burns.
The United Kingdom signs the Sand River Convention with the South African Republic.
The New Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg, Russia, one of the largest and oldest museums in the world, opens to the public.
Great Ormond St Hospital for Sick Children, the first hospital in England to provide in-patient beds specifically for children, is founded in London.
The Helsinki Cathedral (known as St. Nicholas' Church at time) is officially inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland.
Harriet Beecher Stowe's Uncle Tom's Cabin is published.
Jenny Lind leaves New York after her two-year American tour.
Congress establishes the United States' 2nd mint in San Francisco.
Frederick Douglass delivers his "What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?" speech in Rochester, New York.
Harvard University wins the first Boat Race between Yale University and Harvard. The race is also known as the first ever American intercollegiate athletic event.
Steamboat Atlantic sank on Lake Erie after a collision, with the loss of at least 150 lives.
Tlingit Indians destroy Fort Selkirk, Yukon Territory.
Outbreak of Revolution of September 11 resulting in the State of Buenos Aires declaring independence as a Republic.
Annibale de Gasparis discovers the asteroid Massalia from the north dome of the Astronomical Observatory of Capodimonte.
The first powered, passenger-carrying airship, the Giffard dirigible, travels 17 miles (27 km) from Paris to Trappes.
The University of Sydney, Australia's oldest university, is inaugurated in Sydney.
Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour, becomes the prime minister of Piedmont-Sardinia, which soon expands to become Italy.
An earthquake as high as magnitude 8.8 rocks the Banda Sea, triggering a tsunami and killing at least 60 in the Dutch East Indies.
Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte becomes Emperor of the French as Napoleon III.
After having been kidnapped and sold into slavery in the American South, Solomon Northup regains his freedom; his memoir Twelve Years a Slave later becomes a national bestseller.
Giuseppe Verdi's opera Il trovatore receives its premiere performance in Rome.
The Great Indian Peninsula Railway opens the first passenger rail in India, from Bori Bunder to Thane.
The Russian Army crosses the Prut river into the Danubian Principalities (Moldavia and Wallachia), providing the spark that will set off the Crimean War.
The Perry Expedition arrives in Edo Bay with a treaty requesting trade.
Opening of the first major US world's fair, the Exhibition of the Industry of All Nations in New York City.
Joaquin Murrieta,  the famous Californio bandit known as the "Robin Hood of El Dorado", is killed.
Admiral Despointes formally takes possession of New Caledonia in the name of France.
The Crimean War begins when the Ottoman Empire declares war on the Russian Empire.
Crimean War: Battle of Sinop: The Imperial Russian Navy under Pavel Nakhimov destroys the Ottoman fleet under Osman Pasha at Sinop, a sea port in northern Turkey.
source_pages: Crimean_War; Battle_of_Sinop; Imperial_Russian_Navy; Pavel_Nakhimov; Military_of_the_Ottoman_Empire; Sinop,_Turkey; Turkey; November_30

event_text: Gadsden Purchase: The United States buys land from Mexico to facilitate railroad building in the Southwest.
A dinner party is held inside a life-size model of an iguanodon created by Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins and Sir Richard Owen in south London, England.
The McDonald Islands are discovered by Captain William McDonald aboard the Samarang.
The RMS Tayleur sinks off Lambay Island on her maiden voyage from Liverpool to Australia with great loss of life.
A law is approved to found the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology. Lectures started October 16, 1855.
The United Kingdom recognizes the independence of the Orange Free State.
The official independence of the Orange Free State, South Africa is declared.
A Penny Red with perforations becomes the first perforated postage stamp to be officially issued for distribution.
The Republican Party of the United States is organized in Ripon, Wisconsin, US.
President José Gregorio Monagas abolishes slavery in Venezuela.
Crimean War: France and Britain declare war on Russia.
Commodore Matthew Perry signs the Convention of Kanagawa with the Tokugawa Shogunate, opening the ports of Shimoda and Hakodate to American trade.
source_pages: Commodore_(United_States); Matthew_C._Perry; Convention_of_Kanagawa; Tokugawa_shogunate; Shimoda,_Shizuoka; Hakodate

event_text: The Kansas–Nebraska Act becomes law establishing the U.S. territories of Kansas and Nebraska.
Åland War: The British navy destroys merchant ships and about 16,000 tar barrels of the wholesale stocks area in Oulu, Grand Duchy of Finland.
source_pages: Åland_War; Royal_Navy; Merchant_ship; Tar; Oulu; Grand_Duchy_of_Finland; June_1

event_text: The United States Naval Academy graduates its first class of students.
The Republican Party of the United States held its first convention in Jackson, Michigan.
In the Battle of Guaymas, Mexico, General José María Yáñez stops the French invasion led by Count Gaston de Raousset-Boulbon.
USS Constellation (1854), the last all-sail warship built by the United States Navy and now a museum ship in Baltimore Harbor, is commissioned.
The Hinomaru is established as the official flag to be flown from Japanese ships.
American Transcendentalist philosopher Henry David Thoreau publishes his memoir Walden.
The First Sioux War begins when United States Army soldiers kill Lakota chief Conquering Bear and in return are massacred.
Crimean War: British and French troops defeat Russians at the Battle of Alma.

The paddle steamer SS Arctic, owned by the Collins Line of New York, sinks off the coast of Newfoundland, following a collision with a smaller vessel, the SS Vesta. Only 88 of over 300 people on board survive. About a dozen of the occupants of the Vesta are killed when their lifeboat is hit by the Arctic.
In England the Great fire of Newcastle and Gateshead leads to 53 deaths and hundreds injured.
Florence Nightingale and a staff of 38 nurses are sent to the Crimean War.
The Battle of Balaclava takes place during the Crimean War. It is soon memorialized in verse as The Charge of the Light Brigade.
Battle of the Eureka Stockade: More than 20 gold miners at Ballarat, Victoria, are killed by state troopers in an uprising over mining licences.
In his Apostolic constitution Ineffabilis Deus, Pope Pius IX proclaims the dogmatic definition of Immaculate Conception, which holds that the Blessed Virgin Mary was conceived free of Original Sin.
source_pages: Apostolic_constitution; Ineffabilis_Deus; Pope_Pius_IX; Papal_infallibility; Immaculate_Conception; Mary,_mother_of_Jesus; Original_sin

event_text: The Legislative Assembly of the Province of Canada abolishes the seigneurial system.
Point No Point Treaty is signed in Washington Territory.
A locomotive on the Panama Canal Railway runs from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean for the first time.
Kassa Hailu is crowned Tewodros II, Emperor of Ethiopia.
Texas is linked by telegraph to the rest of the United States, with the completion of a connection between New Orleans and Marshall, Texas.
Alexander II becomes Tsar of Russia.
Origins of the American Civil War: "Border Ruffians" from Missouri invade Kansas and force election of a pro-slavery legislature.
American adventurer William Walker departs from San Francisco with about 60 men to conquer Nicaragua.
The American adventurer William Walker conquers Nicaragua.
Major Henry C. Wayne departs New York aboard the USS Supply to procure camels to establish the U.S. Camel Corps.
Twentieth opera of Giuseppe Verdi, Les vêpres siciliennes ("The Sicilian Vespers"), is premiered in Paris.
Sigma Chi fraternity is founded in North America.
Signing of the Quinault Treaty: The Quinault and the Quileute cede their land to the United States.
The first edition of Walt Whitman's book of poems, Leaves of Grass, is published in Brooklyn.
The first ascent of Monte Rosa, the second highest summit in the Alps.
Åland War: The Battle of Suomenlinna begins.
American Indian Wars: In Nebraska, 700 soldiers under United States General William S. Harney avenge the Grattan massacre by attacking a Sioux village and killing 100 men, women and children.
Crimean War: The French assault the tower of Malakoff, leading to the capture of Sevastopol.
Crimean War: The Siege of Sevastopol comes to an end when Russian forces abandon the city.
The Philippine port of Iloilo is opened to world trade by the Spanish administration.

A powerful earthquake occurs in Edo, Japan, causing considerable damage in the Kantō region from the shaking and subsequent fires. It had a death toll of 7,000–10,000 people and destroyed around 14,000 buildings.
David Livingstone becomes the first European to see the Victoria Falls in what is now Zambia-Zimbabwe.
In Birmingham, England, Albert, Prince Consort lays the foundation stone of the Birmingham and Midland Institute.
First Battle of Seattle: Marines from the USS Decatur drive off American Indian attackers after all-day battle with settlers.
Queen Victoria issues a Warrant under the Royal sign-manual that establishes the Victoria Cross to recognise acts of valour by British military personnel during the Crimean War.
source_pages: Queen_Victoria; Warrant_(law); Royal_sign-manual; Victoria_Cross; British_Empire; Crimean_War; January_29

event_text: The Kingdom of Awadh is annexed by the British East India Company and Wajid Ali Shah, the king of Awadh, is deposed.
The United States Republican Party opens its first national convention in Pittsburgh.
The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the Crimean War.
Second Battle of Rivas: Juan Santamaría burns down the hostel where William Walker's filibusters are holed up.
Australian labour movement: Stonemasons and building workers on building sites around Melbourne march from the University of Melbourne to Parliament House to achieve an eight-hour day.
Lawrence, Kansas is captured and burned by pro-slavery forces.

Congressman Preston Brooks of South Carolina severely beats Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts with a cane in the hall of the United States Senate for a speech Sumner had made regarding  Southerners and slavery.
source_pages: United_States_House_of_Representatives; Preston_Brooks; South_Carolina; Caning_of_Charles_Sumner; United_States_Senate; Charles_Sumner; Massachusetts; Southern_United_States; Slavery_in_the_United_States

event_text: John Brown and his men kill five slavery supporters at Pottawatomie Creek, Kansas.
A group of 194 Pitcairn Islanders, descendants of the mutineers of HMS Bounty, arrives at Norfolk Island, commencing the Third Settlement of the Island.
Five hundred Mormons leave Iowa City, Iowa for the Mormon Trail.
Christchurch, New Zealand, is chartered as a city.
The Last Island hurricane strikes Louisiana, resulting in over 200 deaths.
The Tianjing incident takes place in Nanjing, China.
The Saimaa Canal is inaugurated.
The Second Opium War between several western powers and China begins with the Arrow Incident.
An M 7.7–8.3 earthquake off the Greek island of Crete cause major damage as far as Egypt and Malta.

Second Opium War: Dissatisfied with imperial commissioner Ye Mingchen's reparations for the alleged slighting of a British-owned vessel and at Consul Harry Parkes's urging, British Rear-Admiral Michael Seymour launches an assault on the Barrier Forts outside Canton in the first military engagement of the Second Opium War.
American Old West: On the Sonoita River in present-day southern Arizona, the United States Army establishes Fort Buchanan in order to help control new land acquired in the Gadsden Purchase.
The Coup of 1856 leads to Luxembourg's unilateral adoption of a new, reactionary constitution.
The Iranian city of Bushehr surrenders to occupying British forces.
The 7.9 Mw  Fort Tejon earthquake shakes Central and Southern California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent).
The University of Calcutta is formally founded as the first fully fledged university in South Asia.
Second Opium War: France and the United Kingdom declare war on China.
The Supreme Court of the United States rules 7–2 in the Dred Scott v. Sandford case that the Constitution does not confer citizenship on black people.
Elisha Otis's first elevator is installed at 488 Broadway New York City.

Sepoy Mangal Pandey of the 34th Regiment, Bengal Native Infantry mutinies against the East India Company's rule in India and inspires the protracted Indian Rebellion of 1857, also known as the Sepoy Mutiny.
source_pages: Sepoy; Mangal_Pandey; Regiment; Bengal_Native_Infantry; East_India_Company; Company_rule_in_India; Indian_Rebellion_of_1857; March_29

event_text: "The Spirits Book" by Allan Kardec is published, marking the birth of Spiritualism in France.
The East India Company disbands the 34th Regiment of Bengal Native Infantry whose sepoy Mangal Pandey had earlier revolted against the British in the lead up to the War of Indian Independence.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: In India, the first war of Independence begins. Sepoys mutiny against their commanding officers at Meerut.
Indian Rebellion of 1857: Indian rebels seize Delhi from the British.
Mindon Min was crowned as King of Burma in Mandalay, Burma.
Charles Baudelaire's Les Fleurs du mal is published.
The Revolution of the Ganhadores begins in Salvador, Bahia, Brazil.
The first investiture of the Victoria Cross in Hyde Park, London.
Louis Faidherbe, French governor of Senegal, arrives to relieve French forces at Kayes, effectively ending El Hajj Umar Tall's war against the French.
Indian Rebellion: Sixty-eight men hold out for eight days against a force of 2,500 to 3,000 mutinying sepoys and 8,000 irregular forces.
The Panic of 1857 begins, setting off one of the most severe economic crises in United States history.
Mountain Meadows massacre: Mormon settlers slaughter most members of a peaceful emigrant wagon train.
The Mountain Meadows massacre: Mormon settlers and Paiutes massacre 120 pioneers at Mountain Meadows, Utah.

The SS Central America sinks about 160 miles east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, drowning a total of 426 passengers and crew, including Captain William Lewis Herndon. The ship was carrying 13–15 tons of gold from the California gold rush.
The Indian Rebellion of 1857 ends with the recapture of Delhi by troops loyal to the East India Company.
The Russian warship Lefort capsizes and sinks during a storm in the Gulf of Finland, killing all 826 aboard.
Sheffield F.C., the world's oldest association football club still in operation, is founded in England.
Second relief of Lucknow: Twenty-four Victoria Crosses are awarded, the most in a single day.
Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa, then a small logging town, as the capital of the Province of Canada.
British forces finally defeat Rajab Ali Khan of Chittagong
Napoleon III of France escapes an assassination attempt made by Felice Orsini and his accomplices in Paris.
The Wedding March by Felix Mendelssohn is played at the marriage of Queen Victoria's daughter, Victoria, and Friedrich of Prussia, and becomes a popular wedding processional.
source_pages: Wedding_March_(Mendelssohn); Felix_Mendelssohn; Queen_Victoria; Victoria,_Princess_Royal; Frederick_III,_German_Emperor; Wedding_music

event_text: The first Hallé concert is given in Manchester, England, marking the official founding of The Hallé orchestra as a full-time, professional orchestra.
Bernadette Soubirous's first vision of the Blessed Virgin Mary occurs in Lourdes, France.

After the original Big Ben, a 14.5 tonnes (32,000 lb) bell for the Palace of Westminster, had cracked during testing, it is recast into the current 13.76 tonnes (30,300 lb) bell by Whitechapel Bell Foundry.
The 1858 Christiania fire severely destroys several city blocks near Stortorvet in Christiania, Norway, and about 1,000 people lose their homes.
The Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is dissolved.
The Bawani Imli massacre, where 52 Indian freedom fighters were hanged to death on a tamarind tree by British colonial forces.
Abraham Lincoln delivers his House Divided speech in Springfield, Illinois.
Charles Darwin receives a paper from Alfred Russel Wallace that includes nearly identical conclusions about evolution as Darwin's own, prompting Darwin to publish his theory.
Joint reading of Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace's papers on evolution to the Linnean Society of London.
The last apparition of the Blessed Virgin Mary to Bernadette Soubirous in Lourdes, France.
United States and Japan sign the Harris Treaty.
The Government of India Act 1858 replaces Company rule in India with that of the British Raj.
Cyrus West Field and others complete the first transatlantic telegraph cable after several unsuccessful attempts. It will operate for less than a month.
The first Australian rules football match is played between Melbourne Grammar and Scotch College.
The Eiger in the Bernese Alps is ascended for the first time by Charles Barrington accompanied by Christian Almer and Peter Bohren.

U.S. President James Buchanan inaugurates the new transatlantic telegraph cable by exchanging greetings with Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom. However, a weak signal forces a shutdown of the service in a few weeks.
Charles Darwin first publishes his theory of evolution through natural selection in The Journal of the Proceedings of the Linnean Society of London, alongside Alfred Russel Wallace's same theory.
The first of the Lincoln–Douglas debates is held in Ottawa, Illinois.
George Mary Searle discovers the asteroid 55 Pandora.
Approximately 20 people die in Bradford, England, UK, after being poisoned from ingesting sweets that had been accidentally adulterated with arsenic trioxide.
source_pages: Bradford; England; 1858_Bradford_sweets_poisoning; Candy; Adulterant; Arsenic_trioxide; October_30

event_text: Modified Julian Day zero.
The city of Denver, Colorado is founded.
The United Principalities of Moldavia and Wallachia (later named Romania) is formed as a personal union under the rule of Domnitor Alexandru Ioan Cuza.
The Codex Sinaiticus is discovered in Egypt.

Alexandru Ioan Cuza, Prince of Moldavia, is also elected as prince of Wallachia, joining the two principalities as a personal union called the United Principalities, an autonomous region within the Ottoman Empire, which ushered in the birth of the modern Romanian state.
source_pages: Alexandru_Ioan_Cuza; Moldavia; Wallachia; Personal_union; United_Principalities_of_Moldavia_and_Wallachia; Ottoman_Empire; Romania; February_5

event_text: Oregon is admitted as the 33rd U.S. state.
Cochinchina Campaign: The French Navy captures the Citadel of Saigon, a fortress manned by 1,000 Nguyễn dynasty soldiers, en route to conquering Saigon and other regions of southern Viet Nam.
United States representative Daniel Sickles, after learning of an affair between his wife and Attorney General Philip Barton Key II, murders him in Washington, D.C.
The two-day Great Slave Auction, once thought to be the largest such auction in United States history, begins.
The two-day Great Slave Auction, the largest such auction in United States history, concludes.
British and French engineers break ground for the Suez Canal.
The sailing clipper ship Pomona wrecked on the coast of Ireland with the loss of 424 of the 448 passengers and crew aboard.
The Cornwall Railway opens across the Royal Albert Bridge linking Devon and Cornwall in England.
Members of the Melbourne Football Club codified the first rules of Australian rules football.
The clock tower at the Houses of Parliament, which houses Big Ben, starts keeping time.
Italian Independence wars: In the Battle of Magenta, the French army, under Louis-Napoleon, defeat the Austrian army.
Queensland is established as a separate colony from New South Wales. The date is still celebrated as Queensland Day.
Ambiguity in the Oregon Treaty leads to the "Northwestern Boundary Dispute" between American and British/Canadian settlers.
First ascent of Aletschhorn, second summit of the Bernese Alps.
Battle of Solferino (Battle of the Three Sovereigns): Sardinia and France defeat Austria in Solferino, northern Italy.
The first conformation dog show is held in Newcastle upon Tyne, England.
French acrobat Charles Blondin crosses Niagara Falls on a tightrope.
The United States discovers and claims Midway Atoll.
King Charles XV & IV accedes to the throne of Sweden–Norway.
First ascent of Grand Combin, one of the highest summits in the Alps.
The American Dental Association is founded in Niagara Falls, New York.
The Grand Duchy of Tuscany formally deposes the exiled House of Lorraine.
Petroleum is discovered in Titusville, Pennsylvania, leading to the world's first commercially successful oil well.
The Carrington event is the strongest geomagnetic storm on record to strike the Earth. Electrical telegraph service is widely disrupted.
The Carrington Event is the strongest geomagnetic storm on record.
Joshua A. Norton declares himself "Norton I, Emperor of the United States."
Origins of the American Civil War: Abolitionist John Brown and his supporters launch a raid on Harpers Ferry, Virginia (now West Virginia).
source_pages: Origins_of_the_American_Civil_War; Abolitionism_in_the_United_States; John_Brown_(abolitionist); John_Brown's_raid_on_Harpers_Ferry; Harpers_Ferry,_West_Virginia; October_16

event_text: Spain declares war on Morocco.
The Royal Charter Storm kills at least eight hundred people in the British Isles.
British naturalist Charles Darwin's On the Origin of Species is published.
Origins of the American Civil War: Militant abolitionist leader John Brown is hanged for his October raid on Harpers Ferry, Virginia (now West Virginia).
source_pages: Origins_of_the_American_Civil_War; Abolitionism_in_the_United_States; John_Brown_(abolitionist); John_Brown's_raid_on_Harpers_Ferry; Harpers_Ferry,_West_Virginia; December_2

event_text: Nigeria's first newspaper, missionary Henry Townsend's Iwe Irohin, was published.
The first Polish postage stamp is issued, replacing the Russian stamps previously in use.
Abraham Lincoln makes a speech at Cooper Union in the city of New York that plays an important role in his election to the Presidency.
Parma, Tuscany, Modena and Romagna vote in referendums to join the Kingdom of Sardinia.
source_pages: Parma; Tuscany; Modena; Romagna; Referendum; Kingdom_of_Sardinia_(1720–1861)

event_text: The First Taranaki War begins in Taranaki, New Zealand, a major phase of the New Zealand Wars.
Sakuradamon Incident: Japanese Chief Minister (Tairō) Ii Naosuke is assassinated by rōnin samurai outside the Sakurada Gate of Edo Castle.
source_pages: Sakuradamon_Incident_(1860); Tairō; Ii_Naosuke; Rōnin; Samurai; Sakurada_Gate; Edo_Castle; March_24

event_text: First Taranaki War: The Battle of Waireka begins.
The first successful United States Pony Express run from St. Joseph, Missouri, to Sacramento, California, begins.
The declaration on the introduction of the Finnish markka as an official currency is read in different parts of the Grand Duchy of Finland.
The Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, later renamed Community of Christ, is organized by Joseph Smith III and others at Amboy, Illinois.
On his phonautograph machine, Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville makes the first known recording of an audible human voice.
United States presidential election: Abraham Lincoln wins the Republican Party presidential nomination over William H. Seward, who later becomes the United States Secretary of State.
Giuseppe Garibaldi begins the Siege of Palermo, part of the wars of Italian unification.
The United States Congress establishes the Government Printing Office.
The 1860 Oxford evolution debate at the Oxford University Museum of Natural History takes place.
Charles XV of Sweden–Norway is crowned king of Norway in Trondheim.
Unification of Italy: Giuseppe Garibaldi enters Naples.
The steamship PS Lady Elgin sinks on Lake Michigan, with the loss of around 300 lives.

Second Opium War: Battle of Zhangjiawan: Now heading towards Beijing after having recently occupied Tianjin, the allied Anglo-French force engages and defeats a larger Qing Chinese army at Zhangjiawan.
source_pages: Second_Opium_War; Battle_of_Zhangjiawan; Beijing; Tianjin; United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland; Second_French_Empire; Qing_dynasty; September_18

event_text: The future King Edward VII of the United Kingdom begins the first visit to North America by a Prince of Wales.
Second Opium War: An Anglo-French force defeats Chinese troops at the Battle of Palikao.
First The Open Championship (referred to in North America as the British Open).
The Second Opium War finally ends at the Convention of Peking with the ratification of the Treaty of Tientsin, an unequal treaty.
Convention of Peking: The Second Opium War formally comes to a close, with Qing China ceding Kowloon in perpetuity to the victorious British Empire.
source_pages: Convention_of_Peking; Second_Opium_War; Qing_dynasty; Kowloon; British_Empire; October_24

event_text: Unification of Italy: The Expedition of the Thousand ends when Giuseppe Garibaldi presents his conquests to King Victor Emmanuel of Sardinia.
Abraham Lincoln is elected the 16th president of the United States with only 40% of the popular vote, defeating John C. Breckinridge, John Bell, and Stephen A. Douglas in a four-way race.
source_pages: Abraham_Lincoln; 1860_United_States_presidential_election; President_of_the_United_States; John_C._Breckinridge; John_Bell_(Tennessee_politician); Stephen_A._Douglas; November_6

event_text: South Carolina becomes the first state to attempt to secede from the United States with the South Carolina Declaration of Secession.
First Rules derby is held between Sheffield F.C. and Hallam F.C., the oldest football fixture in the world.
The launch of HMS Warrior, with her combination of screw propeller, iron hull and iron armour, renders all previous warships obsolete.
Liberal forces supporting Benito Juárez enter Mexico City.
American Civil War: Delaware votes not to secede from the United States.
American Civil War: "Star of the West" incident occurs near Charleston, South Carolina.
Mississippi becomes the second state to secede from the Union before the outbreak of the American Civil War.
American Civil War: Florida becomes the third state to secede from the Union.
American Civil War: Alabama secedes from the United States.
American Civil War: Georgia joins South Carolina, Florida, Mississippi, and Alabama in declaring secession from the United States.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Georgia_(U.S._state); South_Carolina; Florida; Mississippi; Alabama; Secession

event_text: American Civil War: The state of Louisiana secedes from the Union.
Kansas is admitted as the 34th U.S. state.
American Civil War: Texas secedes from the United States and joins the Confederacy a week later.
American Civil War: In Montgomery, Alabama, delegates from six breakaway U.S. states meet and initiate the process that would form the Confederate States of America on February 8.
American Civil War: Jefferson Davis is elected the Provisional President of the Confederate States of America by the Provisional Confederate Congress at Montgomery, Alabama
Jefferson Davis is notified by telegraph that he has been chosen as provisional President of the Confederate States of America.
American Civil War: The United States House of Representatives unanimously passes a resolution guaranteeing noninterference with slavery in any state.
Italian unification: The Siege of Gaeta ends with the capitulation of the defending fortress, effectively bringing an end of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
In Montgomery, Alabama, Jefferson Davis is inaugurated as the provisional President of the Confederate States of America.
With Italian unification almost complete, Victor Emmanuel II of Piedmont, Savoy and Sardinia assumes the title of King of Italy.
source_pages: Unification_of_Italy; Victor_Emmanuel_II; Piedmont; Savoy; Sardinia; King_of_Italy

event_text: Mariehamn, the capital city of Åland, is founded.
President-elect Abraham Lincoln arrives secretly in Washington, D.C., after the thwarting of an alleged assassination plot in Baltimore, Maryland.
Alexander II of Russia signs the Emancipation Manifesto, freeing serfs.
The first national flag of the Confederate States of America (the "Stars and Bars") is adopted.
El Hadj Umar Tall seizes the city of Ségou, destroying the Bamana Empire of Mali.
American Civil War: The Constitution of the Confederate States of America is adopted.
The Kingdom of Italy is proclaimed.
An earthquake destroys Mendoza, Argentina.
Alexander H. Stephens gives the Cornerstone Speech.
Discovery of the chemical elements: Sir William Crookes announces his discovery of thallium.
American Civil War: Battle of Fort Sumter. The war begins with Confederate forces firing on Fort Sumter, in the harbor of Charleston, South Carolina.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Fort_Sumter; Confederate_States_of_America; Fort_Sumter; Charleston,_South_Carolina; April_12

event_text: American Civil War: Union forces surrender Fort Sumter to Confederate forces.
President Abraham Lincoln calls for 75,000 militiamen to quell the insurrection that soon became the American Civil War.
The state of Virginia's secession convention votes to secede from the United States; Virginia later becomes the eighth state to join the Confederate States of America.
American Civil War: Baltimore riot of 1861: A pro-Secession mob in Baltimore attacks United States Army troops marching through the city.
American Civil War: Robert E. Lee resigns his commission in the United States Army in order to command the forces of the state of Virginia.
Thaddeus S. C. Lowe, attempting to display the value of balloons, makes record journey, flying 900 miles from Cincinnati to South Carolina.
American President Abraham Lincoln suspends the writ of habeas corpus.
Maryland in the American Civil War: Maryland's House of Delegates votes not to secede from the Union.
American Civil War: Arkansas secedes from the Union.
American Civil War: Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom issues a "proclamation of neutrality" which recognizes the Confederacy as having belligerent rights.
The Great Comet of 1861 is discovered by John Tebbutt of Windsor, New South Wales, Australia.
Pakistan's (then a part of British India) first railway line  opens, from Karachi to Kotri.
American Civil War: The state of Kentucky proclaims its neutrality, which will last until September 3 when Confederate forces enter the state.
American Civil War: The State of North Carolina secedes from the Union.
American Civil War: Union troops occupy Alexandria, Virginia, with Colonel Elmer E. Ellsworth becoming the first Union officer to be killed during the war.
The Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce is founded, in Hong Kong.
American Civil War: The Battle of Fairfax Court House is fought.
American Civil War: Battle of Philippi (also called the Philippi Races): Union forces rout Confederate troops in Barbour County, Virginia, now West Virginia.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Philippi_(1861); Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; Barbour_County,_West_Virginia; West_Virginia

event_text: American Civil War: Tennessee secedes from the Union.
American Civil War: Battle of Big Bethel: Confederate troops under John B. Magruder defeat a much larger Union force led by General Ebenezer W. Pierce in Virginia.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Big_Bethel; Confederate_States_of_America; John_B._Magruder; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ebenezer_W._Peirce; Virginia

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Vienna, Virginia.

American Civil War: At the order of President Abraham Lincoln, Union troops begin a 25-mile march into Virginia for what will become the First Battle of Bull Run, the first major land battle of the war.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Abraham_Lincoln; Bull_Run_campaign; Virginia; First_Battle_of_Bull_Run; July_16

event_text: American Civil War: First Battle of Bull Run: At Manassas Junction, Virginia, the first major battle of the war begins and ends in a victory for the Confederate army.

American Civil War: The United States Congress passes the Crittenden–Johnson Resolution, stating that the war is being fought to preserve the Union and not to end slavery, in the wake of the defeat at the First Battle of Bull Run.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; United_States_Congress; Crittenden–Johnson_Resolution; Union_(American_Civil_War); Slavery_in_the_United_States; First_Battle_of_Bull_Run

event_text: American Civil War: George B. McClellan assumes command of the Army of the Potomac following a disastrous Union defeat at the First Battle of Bull Run.

American Civil War: In order to help pay for the war effort, the United States government levies the first income tax as part of the Revenue Act of 1861 (3% of all incomes over US$800; rescinded in 1872).
The United States Army abolishes flogging.
Britain imposes the Lagos Treaty of Cession to suppress slavery in what is now Nigeria.

American Civil War: Battle of Wilson's Creek: A mixed force of Confederate, Missouri State Guard, and Arkansas State troops defeat outnumbered attacking Union forces in the southwestern part of the state.
First ascent of Weisshorn, fifth highest summit in the Alps.
American Civil War: Union forces attack Cape Hatteras, North Carolina in the Battle of Hatteras Inlet Batteries which lasts for two days.
American Civil War: The Battle of Hatteras Inlet Batteries gives Federal forces control of Pamlico Sound.
American Civil War: Confederate General Leonidas Polk invades neutral Kentucky, prompting the state legislature to ask for Union assistance.
American Civil War: Forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant bloodlessly capture Paducah, Kentucky, giving the Union control of the Tennessee River's mouth.
Argentine Civil Wars: The State of Buenos Aires defeats the Argentine Confederation at the Battle of Pavón.
Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management is published, going on to sell 60,000 copies in its first year and remaining in print until the present day.
American Civil War: Union troops repel a Confederate attempt to capture Fort Pickens in the Battle of Santa Rosa Island.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; Fort_Pickens; Battle_of_Santa_Rosa_Island; October_9

event_text: Aboriginal Australians kill nineteen Europeans in the Cullin-la-ringo massacre.
American Civil War: Union forces under Colonel Edward Baker are defeated by Confederate troops in the second major battle of the war.
The first transcontinental telegraph line across the United States is completed.
The Toronto Stock Exchange is created.
American Civil War: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln appoints George B. McClellan as the commander of the Union Army, replacing General Winfield Scott.
American Civil War: Battle of Belmont: In Belmont, Missouri, Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant overrun a Confederate camp but are forced to retreat when Confederate reinforcements arrive.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Belmont; Belmont,_Missouri; United_States; General_officer; Ulysses_S._Grant; Confederate_States_of_America

event_text: The first Melbourne Cup horse race is held in Melbourne, Australia.
American Civil War: The "Trent Affair": The USS San Jacinto stops the British mail ship Trent and arrests two Confederate envoys, sparking a diplomatic crisis between the UK and US.
American Civil War: A secession ordinance is filed by Kentucky's Confederate government.
American Civil War: Confederate President Jefferson Davis appoints Judah Benjamin Secretary of War.
American Civil War: The Confederate States of America accept a rival state government's pronouncement that declares Missouri to be the 12th state of the Confederacy.
American Civil War: The 109 electors of the several states of the Confederate States of America unanimously elect Jefferson Davis as President and Alexander H. Stephens as Vice President.
American Civil War: The Joint Committee on the Conduct of the War is established by Congress.
American Civil War: The Confederate States of America accept a rival state government's pronouncement that declares Kentucky to be the 13th state of the Confederacy.
Forces led by Nguyễn Trung Trực, an anti-colonial guerrilla leader in southern Vietnam, sink the French lorcha L'Esperance.
Medal of Honor: Public Resolution 82, containing a provision for a Navy Medal of Valor, is signed into law by President Abraham Lincoln.

American Civil War: The Trent Affair: Confederate diplomatic envoys James Murray Mason and John Slidell are freed by the United States government, thus easing tensions between the U.S. and the United Kingdom.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Trent_Affair; Confederate_States_of_America; James_M._Mason; John_Slidell; December_26

event_text: Hartley Colliery disaster: Two hundred and four men and boys killed in a mining disaster, prompting a change in UK law which henceforth required all collieries to have at least two independent means of escape.
American Civil War: Battle of Mill Springs: The Confederacy suffers its first significant defeat in the conflict.
American Civil War: The first American ironclad warship, the USS Monitor is launched.
Alvan Graham Clark discovers the white dwarf star Sirius B, a companion of Sirius, through an 18.5-inch (47 cm) telescope now located at Northwestern University.
Moldavia and Wallachia formally unite to create the Romanian United Principalities.
American Civil War: Forces under the command of Ulysses S. Grant and Andrew H. Foote give the Union its first victory of the war, capturing Fort Henry, Tennessee in the Battle of Fort Henry.
American Civil War: A Union naval flotilla destroys the bulk of the Confederate Mosquito Fleet in the Battle of Elizabeth City on the Pasquotank River in North Carolina.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Mosquito_Fleet; Battle_of_Elizabeth_City; Pasquotank_River; North_Carolina

event_text: American Civil War: Confederates commanded by Brig. Gen. John B. Floyd attack General Ulysses S. Grant's Union forces besieging Fort Donelson in Tennessee. Unable to break the fort's encirclement, the Confederates surrender the following day.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; John_B._Floyd; Ulysses_S._Grant; Battle_of_Fort_Donelson; Tennessee; February_15

event_text: American Civil War: General Ulysses S. Grant captures Fort Donelson, Tennessee.
American Civil War: Battle of Valverde is fought near Fort Craig in New Mexico Territory.

American Civil War: Jefferson Davis is officially inaugurated for a six-year term as the President of the Confederate States of America in Richmond, Virginia. He was previously inaugurated as a provisional president on February 18, 1861.

American Civil War: USS Monitor and CSS Virginia (rebuilt from the engines and lower hull of the USS Merrimack) fight to a draw in the Battle of Hampton Roads, the first battle between two ironclad warships.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; USS_Monitor; CSS_Virginia; USS_Merrimack_(1855); Battle_of_Hampton_Roads; Ironclad_warship; March_9

event_text: The Act Prohibiting the Return of Slaves is passed by the United States Congress, effectively annulling the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 and setting the stage for the Emancipation Proclamation.
The first railway line of Finland between cities of Helsinki and Hämeenlinna, called Päärata, is officially opened.
source_pages: Rail_transport_in_Finland; Finland; Helsinki; Hämeenlinna; Finnish_Main_Line; March_17

event_text: American Civil War: The First Battle of Kernstown, Virginia, marks the start of Stonewall Jackson's Valley Campaign. Although a Confederate defeat, the engagement distracts Federal efforts to capture Richmond.
American Civil War: In the Battle of Glorieta Pass, Union forces stop the Confederate invasion of the New Mexico Territory. The battle began on March 26.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Glorieta_Pass; Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; New_Mexico_Territory; March_26; March_28

event_text: American Civil War: The Battle of Yorktown begins.
American Civil War: The Battle of Shiloh begins: In Tennessee, forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant meet Confederate troops led by General Albert Sidney Johnston.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Shiloh; Tennessee; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ulysses_S._Grant; Confederate_States_of_America; Albert_Sidney_Johnston

event_text: American Civil War: The Union's Army of the Tennessee and the Army of the Ohio defeat the Confederate Army of Mississippi near Shiloh, Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Army_of_the_Tennessee; Army_of_the_Ohio; Battle_of_Shiloh; Army_of_Mississippi; Shiloh,_Hardin_County,_Tennessee

event_text: American Civil War: The Andrews Raid (the Great Locomotive Chase) occurs, starting from Big Shanty, Georgia (now Kennesaw).
American Civil War: Battle at Lee's Mills in Virginia.
American Civil War: The District of Columbia Compensated Emancipation Act, a bill ending slavery in the District of Columbia, becomes law.
Louis Pasteur and Claude Bernard complete the experiment disproving the theory of spontaneous generation.
American Civil War: Forces under U.S. Admiral David Farragut demand the surrender of the Confederate city of New Orleans, Louisiana.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Admiral; David_Farragut; Capture_of_New_Orleans; Confederate_States_of_America; New_Orleans

event_text: American Civil War: The Capture of New Orleans by Union forces under David Farragut.
American Civil War: The Siege of Corinth begins as Union forces under General Henry Halleck moves to engage Confederate forces led by General P. G. T. Beauregard.
source_pages: Siege_of_Corinth; Union_(American_Civil_War); Henry_Halleck; Confederate_States_of_America; P._G._T._Beauregard; April_29

event_text: Cinco de Mayo: Troops led by Ignacio Zaragoza halt a French invasion in the Battle of Puebla in Mexico.
American Civil War: Union Army troops occupy Baton Rouge, Louisiana.

Southern slave Robert Smalls steals the steamboat Planter, spirits it through Confederate lines and hands it to the United States Navy, who quickly commission it as the gunboat USS Planter and appoint Smalls as captain, thus making him the first black man to command a United States ship.
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs the Homestead Act into law, opening eighty-four million acres (340,000 km2) of public land to settlers.

American Civil War: The Siege of Corinth ends in a Union victory, with General Henry Halleck capturing the critical rail junction of Corinth, Mississippi from retreating Confederate forces under General P. G. T. Beauregard.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Siege_of_Corinth; Union_(American_Civil_War); Henry_Halleck; Corinth,_Mississippi; Confederate_States_of_America; P._G._T._Beauregard; May_30

event_text: American Civil War: Peninsula Campaign: Confederate forces under Joseph E. Johnston and G.W. Smith engage Union forces under George B. McClellan outside the Confederate capital of Richmond, Virginia.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Peninsula_campaign; Joseph_E._Johnston; Gustavus_Woodson_Smith; Battle_of_Seven_Pines; George_B._McClellan; Richmond,_Virginia

event_text: American Civil War: Peninsula Campaign: The Battle of Seven Pines (or the Battle of Fair Oaks) ends inconclusively, with both sides claiming victory.
American Civil War: Confederate troops evacuate Fort Pillow on the Mississippi River, leaving the way clear for Union troops to take Memphis, Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Confederate_States_of_America; Fort_Pillow_State_Historic_Park; Mississippi_River; Union_(American_Civil_War); Memphis,_Tennessee

event_text: As the Treaty of Saigon is signed, ceding parts of southern Vietnam to France, the guerrilla leader Trương Định decides to defy Emperor Tự Đức of Vietnam and fight on against the Europeans.
American Civil War: The First Battle of Memphis, a naval engagement fought on the Mississippi River, results in the capture of Memphis, Tennessee by Union forces from the Confederates.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; First_Battle_of_Memphis; Mississippi_River; Memphis,_Tennessee; Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; June_6

event_text: The United States and the United Kingdom agree in the Lyons–Seward Treaty to suppress the African slave trade.

American Civil War: A Confederate victory by forces under General Stonewall Jackson at the Battle of Cross Keys, along with the Battle of Port Republic the next day, prevents Union forces from reinforcing General George B. McClellan in his Peninsula campaign.
source_pages: Confederate_States_of_America; Stonewall_Jackson; Battle_of_Cross_Keys; Battle_of_Port_Republic; Union_(American_Civil_War); George_B._McClellan; Peninsula_campaign

event_text: American Civil War: Stonewall Jackson concludes his successful Shenandoah Valley Campaign with a victory in the Battle of Port Republic.
President Abraham Lincoln signs the Territorial Slavery Act of 1862, which prohibits slavery in all current and future United States territories.
Barbu Catargiu, the Prime Minister of Romania, is assassinated.
The Russian State Library is founded as the Library of the Moscow Public Museum.
Princess Alice of the United Kingdom, second daughter of Queen Victoria, marries Prince Louis of Hesse, the future Louis IV, Grand Duke of Hesse.
American Civil War: The Battle of Malvern Hill takes place. It is the last of the Seven Days Battles, part of George B. McClellan's Peninsula Campaign.
Lewis Carroll tells Alice Liddell a story that would grow into Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and its sequels.
The Medal of Honor is authorized by the United States Congress.

American Civil War: The CSS Arkansas, the most effective ironclad on the Mississippi River, battles with Union Navy ships commanded by Admiral David Farragut, severely damaging three ships and sustaining heavy damage herself.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; CSS_Arkansas; Ironclad_warship; Mississippi_River; Union_navy; David_Farragut

event_text: American Civil War: David Farragut is promoted to rear admiral, becoming the first officer in United States Navy to hold an admiral rank.
First ascent of Dent Blanche, one of the highest summits in the Alps.
American Civil War: Henry Halleck becomes general-in-chief of the Union Army.
American Civil War: Confederate spy Belle Boyd is arrested by Union troops and detained at the Old Capitol Prison in Washington, D.C.
American Civil War: Battle of Baton Rouge: Along the Mississippi River near Baton Rouge, Louisiana, Confederate troops attempt to take the city, but are driven back by fire from Union gunboats.
American Civil War: The Confederate ironclad CSS Arkansas is scuttled on the Mississippi River after suffering catastrophic engine failure near Baton Rouge, Louisiana.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Confederate_States_of_America; Ironclad_warship; CSS_Arkansas; Mississippi_River; Baton_Rouge,_Louisiana

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Cedar Mountain: At Cedar Mountain, Virginia, Confederate General Stonewall Jackson narrowly defeats Union forces under General John Pope.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Cedar_Mountain; Culpeper_County,_Virginia; Confederate_States_of_America; Stonewall_Jackson; Union_army; John_Pope_(general)

event_text: American Indian Wars: The Dakota War of 1862 begins in Minnesota as Dakota warriors attack white settlements along the Minnesota River.
American Civil War: Major General J. E. B. Stuart is assigned command of all the cavalry of the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia.
Dakota War: During an uprising in Minnesota, Lakota warriors decide not to attack heavily defended Fort Ridgely and instead turn to the settlement of New Ulm, killing white settlers along the way.
The Stadtpark, the first public park in Vienna, opens to the public.
American Civil War: The Second Battle of Bull Run, also known as the Battle of Second Manassas, begins in Virginia.  The battle ends on August 30 with another Union defeat.
American Civil War: Battle of Richmond: Confederates under Edmund Kirby Smith rout Union forces under General William "Bull" Nelson.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Richmond; Confederate_States_of_America; Edmund_Kirby_Smith; Union_army; William_"Bull"_Nelson

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Chantilly: Confederate Army troops defeat a group of retreating Union Army troops in Chantilly, Virginia.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Chantilly; Confederate_States_of_America; United_States_Army; Chantilly,_Virginia; September_1

event_text: American Civil War: United States President Abraham Lincoln reluctantly restores Union General George B. McClellan to full command after General John Pope's disastrous defeat at the Second Battle of Bull Run.
American Civil War Maryland Campaign: General Robert E. Lee takes the Army of Northern Virginia, and the war, into the North.
American Civil War: The Army of Northern Virginia crosses the Potomac River at White's Ford in the Maryland Campaign.
Millennium of Russia monument is unveiled in Novgorod.
American Civil War: Union soldiers find a copy of Robert E. Lee's battle plans in a field outside Frederick, Maryland. It is the prelude to the Battle of Antietam.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Robert_E._Lee; Special_Order_191; Frederick,_Maryland; Battle_of_Antietam

event_text: American Civil War: The Battle of South Mountain, part of the Maryland Campaign, is fought.
American Civil War: Confederate forces capture Harpers Ferry, Virginia.

American Civil War: George B. McClellan's Army of the Potomac halts the first invasion of the North by Robert E. Lee and his Army of Northern Virginia in the single-day Battle of Antietam, the bloodiest day in American military history.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; George_B._McClellan; Army_of_the_Potomac; Maryland_campaign; Northern_United_States; Robert_E._Lee; Army_of_Northern_Virginia; Battle_of_Antietam; September_17

event_text: American Civil War: The Allegheny Arsenal explosion in Lawrenceville, Pennsylvania results in the single largest civilian disaster during the war.
The Confederate States celebrate for the first and only time a Thanksgiving Day.
American Civil War: Union troops under William Rosecrans defeat a Confederate force commanded by Sterling Price.
Taiping Rebellion: The Ever Victorious Army defeats Taiping forces at the Battle of Cixi.
A preliminary version of the Emancipation Proclamation is released by Abraham Lincoln.
American Civil War: The two-day Second Battle of Corinth begins as Confederate forces under General Earl Van Dorn attack Union defenses led by General William Rosecrans around Corinth, Mississippi.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Second_Battle_of_Corinth; Confederate_States_of_America; Earl_Van_Dorn; Union_(American_Civil_War); William_Rosecrans; Corinth,_Mississippi; October_3

event_text: American Civil War: The two-day Second Battle of Corinth ends in a Union victory, with General William Rosecrans protecting the critical rail junction of Corinth, Mississippi from Confederate forces under General Earl Van Dorn.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Second_Battle_of_Corinth; Union_(American_Civil_War); William_Rosecrans; Corinth,_Mississippi; Confederate_States_of_America; Earl_Van_Dorn; October_4

event_text: American Civil War: The Confederate invasion of Kentucky is halted at the Battle of Perryville.
American Civil War: Confederate troops conduct a raid on Chambersburg, Pennsylvania.
American Civil War: Abraham Lincoln removes George B. McClellan as commander of the Army of the Potomac.
American Indian Wars: In Minnesota, 303 Dakota warriors are found guilty of rape and murder of whites and are sentenced to death. Thirty-eight are ultimately hanged and the others reprieved.
American Civil War: Union General Ambrose Burnside assumes command of the Army of the Potomac, after George B. McClellan is removed.
American Civil War: In the Battle of Cane Hill, Union troops under General James G. Blunt defeat General John Marmaduke's Confederates.
Notts County F.C. is founded in Nottingham, England, making it the oldest professional Association football club in the world.
American Civil War: In his second State of the Union Address, President Abraham Lincoln reaffirms the necessity of ending slavery as ordered ten weeks earlier in the Emancipation Proclamation.
American Civil War: USS Cairo sinks on the Yazoo River.
American Civil War: At the Battle of Fredericksburg, Confederate General Robert E. Lee repulses attacks by Union Major General Ambrose Burnside on Marye's Heights, inflicting heavy casualties.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Fredericksburg; Confederate_States_of_America; Robert_E._Lee; Union_army; Ambrose_Burnside; December_13

event_text: American Civil War: The Battle of Fredericksburg ends in a Union defeat as General Ambrose Burnside withdraws the Army of the Potomac across the Rappahannock River.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Fredericksburg; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ambrose_Burnside; Army_of_the_Potomac; Rappahannock_River; December_15

event_text: American Civil War: General Ulysses S. Grant issues General Order No. 11, expelling Jews from parts of Tennessee, Mississippi, and Kentucky.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Ulysses_S._Grant; General_Order_No._11_(1862); Jews; Tennessee; Mississippi; Kentucky

event_text: American Civil War: The Battle of Chickasaw Bayou begins as Union General William T. Sherman starts landing his troops in an attempt to advance on Vicksburg, Mississippi.
Dakota War of 1862: The largest mass-hanging in U.S. history takes place in Mankato, Minnesota, where 38 Native American prisoners are hanged.

American Civil War: The Battle of Chickasaw Bayou ends in a Union defeat as forces under General William T. Sherman are repulsed with heavy losses by Confederate troops under General John C. Pemberton.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Chickasaw_Bayou; Union_(American_Civil_War); William_Tecumseh_Sherman; Confederate_States_of_America; John_C._Pemberton; December_29

event_text: American Civil War: The three-day Battle of Stones River begins near Murfreesboro, Tennessee between the Confederate Army of Tennessee under General Braxton Bragg and the Union Army of the Cumberland under General William S. Rosecrans.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Stones_River; Murfreesboro,_Tennessee; Confederate_States_of_America; Army_of_Tennessee; Braxton_Bragg; Union_(American_Civil_War); Army_of_the_Cumberland; William_Rosecrans; December_31

event_text: American Civil War: Abraham Lincoln signs an enabling act that would admit West Virginia to the Union, thus dividing Virginia in two.
American Civil War: The Emancipation Proclamation takes effect in Confederate territory.

American Civil War: The three-day Battle of Stones River ends in a Union victory when the Confederate Army of Tennessee under General Braxton Bragg are repulsed for the final time by the Army of the Cumberland under General William S. Rosecrans.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Stones_River; Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; Army_of_Tennessee; Braxton_Bragg; Army_of_the_Cumberland; William_Rosecrans; January_2

event_text: The New Apostolic Church, a Christian and chiliastic church, is established in Hamburg, Germany.
American Civil War: Second Battle of Springfield.
The Metropolitan Railway, the world's oldest underground railway, opens between Paddington and Farringdon, marking the beginning of the London Underground.

American Civil War: The three-day Battle of Arkansas Post concludes as General John McClernand and Admiral David Dixon Porter capture Fort Hindman and secure control over the Arkansas River for the Union.
source_pages: Battle_of_Arkansas_Post; John_A._McClernand; David_Dixon_Porter; Arkansas_River; Union_(American_Civil_War); January_11

event_text: American Civil War: CSS Alabama encounters and sinks the USS Hatteras off Galveston Lighthouse in Texas.
The January Uprising breaks out in Poland, Lithuania and Belarus. The aim of the national movement is to regain Polish–Lithuanian–Ruthenian Commonwealth from occupation by Russia.
American Civil War: General Ambrose Burnside is relieved of command of the Army of the Potomac after the disastrous Fredericksburg campaign. He is replaced by Joseph Hooker.
American Civil War: Governor of Massachusetts John Albion Andrew receives permission from the Secretary of War to raise a militia organization for men of African descent.

The Bear River Massacre: A detachment of California Volunteers led by Colonel Patrick Edward Connor engage the Shoshone at Bear River, Washington Territory, killing hundreds of men, women and children.
source_pages: Bear_River_Massacre; List_of_Union_units_from_California_in_the_American_Civil_War; Patrick_Edward_Connor; Shoshone; Bear_River_(Washington); Washington_Territory; January_29

event_text: HMS Orpheus sinks off the coast of Auckland, New Zealand, killing 189.
A group of citizens of Geneva found an International Committee for Relief to the Wounded, which later became known as the International Committee of the Red Cross.
Arizona is organized as a United States territory.
Danish prince Wilhelm Georg is chosen as King George of Greece.
American Civil War: The largest in a series of Southern bread riots occurs in Richmond, Virginia.
American Civil War: During the Vicksburg Campaign, gunboats commanded by acting Rear Admiral David Dixon Porter run downriver past Confederate artillery batteries at Vicksburg.
American Civil War: Grierson's Raid begins: Troops under Union Army Colonel Benjamin Grierson attack central Mississippi.
A 65-man French Foreign Legion infantry patrol fights a force of nearly 2,000 Mexican soldiers to nearly the last man in Hacienda Camarón, Mexico.
American Civil War: The Battle of Chancellorsville between Robert E. Lee's Confederate Army of Northern Virginia and the Union Army of the Potomac under Joseph Hooker begins.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Chancellorsville; Robert_E._Lee; Confederate_States_of_America; Army_of_Northern_Virginia; Union_(American_Civil_War); Army_of_the_Potomac; Joseph_Hooker; May_1

event_text: American Civil War: During the Vicksburg campaign, Union forces under Ulysses S. Grant win the Battle of Port Gibson and establish a firm presence on the east side of the Mississippi River.
American Civil War: Stonewall Jackson is wounded by friendly fire while returning to camp after reconnoitering during the Battle of Chancellorsville. He succumbs to pneumonia eight days later.
American Civil War: The Battle of Chancellorsville ends with a major defeat of the Union's Army of the Potomac under Joseph Hooker by the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia under Robert E. Lee.
source_pages: Battle_of_Chancellorsville; Army_of_the_Potomac; Joseph_Hooker; Confederate_States_of_America; Army_of_Northern_Virginia; Robert_E._Lee; May_6

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Raymond: Two divisions of James B. McPherson's XVII Corps turn the left wing of Confederate General John C. Pemberton's defensive line on Fourteen Mile Creek, opening up the interior of Mississippi to the Union Army during the Vicksburg Campaign.
source_pages: Battle_of_Raymond; James_B._McPherson; XVII_Corps_(Union_army); Confederate_States_of_America; John_C._Pemberton; Fourteen_Mile_Creek; Mississippi; Union_(American_Civil_War); Vicksburg_campaign

event_text: American Civil War: During the Vicksburg campaign, Union forces drive Confederates under Joseph E. Johnston out of Jackson, Mississippi in the Battle of Jackson.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Vicksburg_campaign; Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; Joseph_E._Johnston; Jackson,_Mississippi; Battle_of_Jackson; May_14

event_text: American Civil War: During the Vicksburg campaign, the decisive Union victory by Ulysses S. Grant at the Battle of Champion Hill drives the Confederate army under John C. Pemberton back towards Vicksburg, Mississippi.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Vicksburg_campaign; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ulysses_S._Grant; Battle_of_Champion_Hill; Confederate_States_Army; John_C._Pemberton; Vicksburg,_Mississippi; May_16

event_text: Rosalía de Castro publishes Cantares Gallegos, the first book in the Galician language.
American Civil War: During the Vicksburg campaign, Union forces under John A. McClernand defeat a Confederate rearguard and capture around 1,700 men at the Battle of Big Black River Bridge.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Vicksburg_campaign; Union_(American_Civil_War); John_A._McClernand; Confederate_States_of_America; Battle_of_Big_Black_River_Bridge; May_17

event_text: American Civil War: Union forces under Ulysses S. Grant begin the Siege of Vicksburg during the Vicksburg campaign in order to take full control of the Mississippi River.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ulysses_S._Grant; Siege_of_Vicksburg; Vicksburg_campaign; Mississippi_River; May_18

event_text: American Civil War: The Union Army succeeds in closing off the last escape route from Port Hudson, Louisiana, in preparation for the coming siege.
American Civil War: Union forces begin the Siege of Port Hudson which lasts 48 days, the longest siege in U.S. military history.
The General German Workers' Association, a precursor of the modern Social Democratic Party of Germany, is founded in Leipzig, Kingdom of Saxony.
American Civil War: The first Union infantry assault of the Siege of Port Hudson occurs.
American Civil War: Robert E. Lee and his Army of Northern Virginia begin marching to invade the North for a second time, starting the Gettysburg campaign.
American Civil War: The Battle of Brandy Station in Virginia, the largest cavalry battle on American soil, ends Confederate cavalry dominance in the eastern theater.
During the French intervention in Mexico, Mexico City is captured by French troops.
American Civil War: Second Battle of Winchester: A Union garrison is defeated by the Army of Northern Virginia in the Shenandoah Valley town of Winchester, Virginia.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Second_Battle_of_Winchester; United_States; Army_of_Northern_Virginia; Shenandoah_Valley; Winchester,_Virginia

event_text: Second Assault on the Confederate works at the Siege of Port Hudson during the American Civil War.
American Civil War: Battle of Aldie in the Gettysburg Campaign.
American Civil War: West Virginia is admitted as the 35th U.S. state.
Slavery was abolished in the Dutch colony of Surinam, a date now celebrated as Ketikoti in independent Suriname.
American Civil War: The Battle of Gettysburg begins.
American Civil War: The final day of the Battle of Gettysburg culminates with Pickett's Charge.

American Civil War: Siege of Vicksburg: The Confederate army in Vicksburg, Mississippi surrenders to Union forces under Ulysses S. Grant after 47 days of siege, contributing to the Union capture of the Mississippi River.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Siege_of_Vicksburg; Confederate_States_of_America; Vicksburg,_Mississippi; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ulysses_S._Grant; Mississippi_River; July_4

event_text: American Civil War: Union forces repulse a Confederate army at the Battle of Helena in Arkansas. The battle thwarts a Rebel attempt to relieve pressure on the besieged city of Vicksburg, and paves the way for the Union capture of Little Rock.

American Civil War: Retreat from Gettysburg: The Confederate Army of Northern Virginia under Robert E. Lee withdraws from the battlefield after losing the Battle of Gettysburg, signaling an end to his last invasion of the North.
source_pages: Retreat_from_Gettysburg; Army_of_Northern_Virginia; Robert_E._Lee; Battle_of_Gettysburg; Gettysburg_campaign; Northern_United_States; July_4

event_text: The United States begins its first military draft; exemptions cost $300.
American Civil War: The Siege of Port Hudson ends in a Union victory and, along with the fall of Vicksburg five days earlier, gives the Union complete control of the Mississippi River.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Siege_of_Port_Hudson; Union_(American_Civil_War); Siege_of_Vicksburg; Mississippi_River; July_9

event_text: American Civil War: The New York City draft riots begin three days of rioting which will later be regarded as the worst in United States history.

American Civil War: Second Battle of Fort Wagner: One of the first formal African American military units, the 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry, supported by several white regiments, attempts an unsuccessful assault on Confederate-held Battery Wagner.

American Civil War: Morgan's Raid: At Buffington Island in Ohio, Confederate General John Hunt Morgan's raid into the north is mostly thwarted when a large group of his men are captured while trying to escape across the Ohio River.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Morgan's_Raid; Buffington_Island; Ohio; Confederate_States_of_America; John_Hunt_Morgan; Battle_of_Buffington_Island; Ohio_River

event_text: American Civil War: Morgan's Raid ends; At Salineville, Ohio, Confederate cavalry leader John Hunt Morgan and 360 of his volunteers are captured by Union forces.
American Indian Wars: Representatives of the United States and tribal leaders including Chief Pocatello (of the Shoshone)  sign the Treaty of Box Elder.
Valuev Circular banned the publication of religious, educational and training books in Ukrainian in the Russian Empire.
At the suggestion of Senator J. V. Snellman and the order of Emperor Alexander II, full rights are promised to the Finnish language by a language regulation in the Grand Duchy of Finland.
Matica slovenská, Slovakia's public-law cultural and scientific institution focusing on topics around the Slovak nation, is established in Martin.
American Civil War: Following his defeat in the Battle of Gettysburg, General Robert E. Lee sends a letter of resignation to Confederate President Jefferson Davis (which is refused upon receipt).

Tennessee Military Governor Andrew Johnson frees his personal slaves in Greeneville, Tennessee despite them being exempt from the Emancipation Proclamation, now commemorated as Emancipation Day in the state.
source_pages: Tennessee; Andrew_Johnson; Andrew_Johnson_and_slavery; Greeneville,_Tennessee; Emancipation_Proclamation; Emancipation_Day; August_8

event_text: The Anglo-Satsuma War begins between the Satsuma Domain of Japan and the United Kingdom (Traditional Japanese date: July 2, 1863).
The Dominican Restoration War begins when Gregorio Luperón raises the Dominican flag in Santo Domingo after Spain had recolonized the country.
American Civil War: In Charleston, South Carolina, Union batteries and ships bombard Confederate-held Fort Sumter.
Lawrence, Kansas is destroyed by pro-Confederate guerrillas known as Quantrill's Raiders.
The Swedish-language liberal newspaper Helsingfors Dagblad proposed the current blue-and-white cross flag as the flag of Finland.
American Civil War: Confederate forces evacuate Battery Wagner and Morris Island in South Carolina.
American Civil War: Union troops under Quincy A. Gillmore capture Fort Wagner in Morris Island after a seven-week siege.
American Civil War: In the Second Battle of Sabine Pass, a small Confederate force thwarts a Union invasion of Texas.
American Civil War: The Union Army enters Chattanooga, Tennessee.
Robert College, in Istanbul, the first American educational institution outside the United States, is founded by Christopher Robert, an American philanthropist.
American Civil War: The Battle of Chickamauga begins between Confederate and Union forces. It involves the second highest amount of casualties for any American Civil War battle apart from Gettysburg.

American Civil War: The first day of the Battle of Chickamauga, in northwestern Georgia, the bloodiest two-day battle of the conflict, and the only significant Confederate victory in the war's Western Theater.
American Civil War: The Battle of Chickamauga, in northwestern Georgia, ends in a Confederate victory.
Georges Bizet's opera Les pêcheurs de perles, premiered in Paris.
The last Thursday in November is declared as Thanksgiving Day by U.S. President Abraham Lincoln.
American Civil War: Confederate troops under the command of A. P. Hill fail to drive the Union Army completely out of Virginia.
The Football Association is founded.
American Civil War: Union forces led by General William F. Smith defeat Confederate forces in the Battle of Brown's Ferry, opening up a supply line to the besieged city of Chattanooga, Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); William_Farrar_Smith; Confederate_States_of_America; Battle_of_Brown's_Ferry; Military_supply-chain_management; Chattanooga_campaign; Chattanooga,_Tennessee; October_27

event_text: Eighteen countries meet in Geneva and agree to form the International Red Cross.

American Civil War: Battle of Wauhatchie: Forces under Union General Ulysses S. Grant repel a Confederate attack led by General James Longstreet in one of the few night battles of the war, protecting the Union's recently opened supply line into Chattanooga, Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Wauhatchie; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ulysses_S._Grant; Confederate_States_of_America; James_Longstreet; Military_supply-chain_management; Chattanooga,_Tennessee; October_29

event_text: Danish Prince Vilhelm arrives in Athens to assume his throne as George I, King of the Hellenes.
The New Zealand Wars resume as British forces in New Zealand led by General Duncan Cameron begin their Invasion of the Waikato.
American Civil War: In the Battle of Campbell's Station, Confederate troops unsuccessfully attack Union forces which allows General Ambrose Burnside to secure Knoxville, Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Campbell's_Station; Confederate_States_of_America; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ambrose_Burnside; Knoxville,_Tennessee

event_text: American Civil War: Siege of Knoxville begins: During the Knoxville campaign, Confederate forces under General James Longstreet besiege the city of Knoxville, Tennessee and its Union defenders led by General Ambrose Burnside.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Siege_of_Knoxville; Knoxville_campaign; Confederate_States_of_America; James_Longstreet; Knoxville,_Tennessee; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ambrose_Burnside; November_17

event_text: King Christian IX of Denmark signs the November constitution that declares Schleswig to be part of Denmark. This is seen by the German Confederation as a violation of the London Protocol and leads to the German–Danish war of 1864.
source_pages: Christian_IX; History_of_Schleswig-Holstein; Duchy_of_Schleswig; German_Confederation; London_Protocol_(1852); Second_Schleswig_War
