event_text: American Civil War: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln delivers the Gettysburg Address at the dedication ceremony for the military cemetery at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.
American Civil War: Battle of Chattanooga begins: Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant reinforce troops at Chattanooga, Tennessee, and counter-attack Confederate troops.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Chattanooga_campaign; United_States; Ulysses_S._Grant; Chattanooga,_Tennessee; Confederate_States_of_America; November_23

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Lookout Mountain: Near Chattanooga, Tennessee, Union forces under General Ulysses S. Grant capture Lookout Mountain and begin to break the Confederate siege of the city led by General Braxton Bragg.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Chattanooga_campaign; Chattanooga,_Tennessee; United_States; Ulysses_S._Grant; Lookout_Mountain; Confederate_States_of_America; Braxton_Bragg

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Missionary Ridge: Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant break the Siege of Chattanooga by routing Confederate troops under General Braxton Bragg at Missionary Ridge in Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Missionary_Ridge; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ulysses_S._Grant; Chattanooga_campaign; Confederate_States_of_America; Braxton_Bragg; Missionary_Ridge; Tennessee

event_text: United States President Abraham Lincoln proclaims November 26 as a national Thanksgiving Day, to be celebrated annually on the final Thursday of November.  Following the Franksgiving controversy from 1939 to 1941, it has been observed on the fourth Thursday in 1942 and subsequent years.
American Civil War: Confederate cavalry leader John Hunt Morgan and several of his men escape the Ohio Penitentiary and return safely to the South.
American Civil War: Battle of Mine Run: Union forces under General George Meade take up positions against troops led by Confederate General Robert E. Lee.

American Civil War: Union forces under General Ambrose Burnside successfully defend Knoxville, Tennessee from an attack by Confederate forces under General James Longstreet in the Battle of Fort Sanders during the Siege of Knoxville.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Ambrose_Burnside; Knoxville,_Tennessee; Confederate_States_of_America; James_Longstreet; Battle_of_Fort_Sanders; Siege_of_Knoxville; November_29

event_text: American Civil War: Confederate General James Longstreet lifts his unsuccessful siege of Knoxville, Tennessee after failing to capture the city.

Between two and three thousand churchgoers die during the Church of the Company Fire. Deemed as probably the largest single building fire by number of victims in modern history, it began at the start of a Mass held at the Church of the Society of Jesus in Santiago, Chile, during the celebration of the recently proclaimed Feast of the Immaculate Conception.
source_pages: Iglesia_de_la_Compañía_Fire; December_8; Mass_(liturgy); Jesuits; Santiago; Chile; Feast_of_the_Immaculate_Conception

event_text: American Civil War: The Confederate victory under General James Longstreet at the Battle of Bean's Station in East Tennessee ends the Knoxville Campaign, but achieves very little as Longstreet returns to Virginia next spring.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Confederate_States_of_America; James_Longstreet; Battle_of_Bean's_Station; East_Tennessee; Knoxville_campaign; Virginia; December_14

event_text: American Civil War: Confederate President Jefferson Davis appoints General Joseph E. Johnston to replace General Braxton Bragg as commander of the Army of Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Confederate_States_of_America; Jefferson_Davis; Joseph_E._Johnston; Braxton_Bragg; Army_of_Tennessee

event_text: Second Schleswig War: Prussian forces crossed the border into Schleswig, starting the war.
American Civil War: The H. L. Hunley becomes the first submarine to engage and sink a warship, the USS Housatonic.
American Civil War: Battle of Olustee: The largest battle fought in Florida during the war.
American Civil War: The first Northern prisoners arrive at the Confederate prison at Andersonville, Georgia.
The Great Sheffield Flood kills 238 people in Sheffield, England.
Rossini's Petite messe solennelle is first performed, by twelve singers, two pianists and a harmonium player in a mansion in Paris.
Archduke Maximilian of Habsburg is proclaimed emperor of Mexico during the French intervention in Mexico.
American Civil War: The Battle of Fort Pillow: Confederate forces kill most of the African American soldiers that surrendered at Fort Pillow, Tennessee.
American Civil War: The Battle of Plymouth begins: Confederate forces attack Plymouth, North Carolina.
Battle of Dybbøl: A Prussian-Austrian army defeats Denmark and gains control of Schleswig. Denmark surrenders the province in the following peace settlement.
The U.S. Congress passes the Coinage Act of 1864 that permitted the inscription In God We Trust be placed on all coins minted as United States currency.

American Civil War: In the Battle of Marks' Mills, a force of 8,000 Confederate soldiers attacks 1,800 Union soldiers and a large number of wagon teamsters, killing or wounding 1,500 Union combatants.
Theta Xi fraternity is founded at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the only fraternity to be founded during the American Civil War.
American Civil War: Confederate forces led by General E. Kirby Smith attack federal troops retreating across the Saline at Jenkins' Ferry, Arkansas.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Confederate_States_of_America; Edmund_Kirby_Smith; Battle_of_Jenkins'_Ferry; Federal_government_of_the_United_States; Saline_River_(Ouachita_River_tributary); Jenkins'_Ferry_Battleground_State_Park; April_30

event_text: American Civil War: The Battle of the Wilderness begins in Spotsylvania County.
American Civil War: The Army of the Potomac, under General Ulysses S. Grant, breaks off from the Battle of the Wilderness and moves southwards.
The world's oldest surviving clipper ship, the City of Adelaide is launched by William Pile, Hay and Co. in Sunderland, England, for transporting passengers and goods between Britain and Australia.
Second Schleswig War: The Danish navy defeats the Austrian and Prussian fleets in the Battle of Heligoland.

American Civil War: The Battle of Spotsylvania Court House: Union troops assault a Confederate salient known as the "Mule Shoe", with some of the fiercest fighting of the war, much of it hand-to-hand combat, occurring at "the Bloody Angle" on the northwest.
American Civil War: Battle of New Market, Virginia: Students from the Virginia Military Institute fight alongside the Confederate army to force Union General Franz Sigel out of the Shenandoah Valley.
source_pages: Battle_of_New_Market; Virginia; Virginia_Military_Institute; Confederate_States_of_America; Union_(American_Civil_War); Franz_Sigel; Shenandoah_Valley

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Ware Bottom Church: In the Virginia Bermuda Hundred campaign, 10,000 troops fight in this Confederate victory.
Russia declares an end to the Russo-Circassian War and many Circassians are forced into exile. The day is designated the Circassian Day of Mourning.
American Civil War: The Battle of Spotsylvania Court House ends.
The Ionian Islands reunite with Greece.
American Civil War: After ten weeks, the Union Army's Red River Campaign ends in failure.
Montana is organized as a United States territory.
Emperor Maximilian I of Mexico arrives in Mexico for the first time.
American Civil War: Overland Campaign: Battle of Cold Harbor: The Army of Northern Virginia engages the Army of the Potomac.
American Civil War: Union forces under Ulysses S. Grant sustain heavy casualties attacking Confederate troops under Robert E. Lee at the Battle of Cold Harbor in Hanover County, Virginia.
American Civil War: Battle of Piedmont: Union forces under General David Hunter defeat a Confederate army at Piedmont, Virginia, taking nearly 1,000 prisoners.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Piedmont; Union_(American_Civil_War); General_officer; David_Hunter; Confederate_States_of_America; Piedmont,_Augusta_County,_Virginia

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Brice's Crossroads: Confederate troops under Nathan Bedford Forrest defeat a much larger Union force led by General Samuel D. Sturgis in Mississippi.

American Civil War, Overland Campaign: Battle of Cold Harbor: Ulysses S. Grant gives the Confederate forces under Robert E. Lee a victory when he pulls his Union troops from their position at Cold Harbor, Virginia and moves south.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Overland_Campaign; Battle_of_Cold_Harbor; Ulysses_S._Grant; Robert_E._Lee; Cold_Harbor,_Virginia

event_text: American Civil War: The Second Battle of Petersburg begins.
American Civil War: The Battle of Jerusalem Plank Road begins.
American Civil War: Confederate forces defeat Union forces during the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain during the Atlanta Campaign.

At least 99 people, mostly German and Polish immigrants, are killed in Canada's worst railway disaster after a train fails to stop for an open drawbridge and plunges into the Rivière Richelieu near St-Hilaire, Quebec.
source_pages: Germans; Polish_people; Immigration; Beloeil_train_disaster; Drawbridge; Richelieu_River; Mont-Saint-Hilaire; Quebec; June_29

event_text: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln grants Yosemite Valley to California for "public use, resort and recreation".
Dimitri Atanasescu founds the first Romanian school in the Balkans for the Aromanians in Trnovo, in the Ottoman Empire (now in North Macedonia).
Ikedaya Incident: The Choshu Han shishis planned Shinsengumi sabotage on Kyoto, Japan at Ikedaya.
American Civil War: Battle of Fort Stevens; Confederate forces attempt to invade Washington, D.C.
Taiping Rebellion: Third Battle of Nanking: The Qing dynasty finally defeats the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom.
American Civil War: Battle of Peachtree Creek: Near Atlanta, Georgia, Confederate forces led by General John Bell Hood unsuccessfully attack Union troops under General William T. Sherman.
source_pages: Battle_of_Peachtree_Creek; Atlanta; Confederate_States_of_America; John_Bell_Hood; Union_(American_Civil_War); Union_army; William_Tecumseh_Sherman

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Atlanta: Outside Atlanta, Confederate General John Bell Hood leads an unsuccessful attack on Union troops under General William T. Sherman on Bald Hill.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Atlanta; Atlanta; Confederate_States_of_America; John_Bell_Hood; Union_(American_Civil_War); William_Tecumseh_Sherman

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Kernstown: Confederate General Jubal Early defeats Union troops led by General George Crook in an effort to keep them out of the Shenandoah Valley.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Second_Battle_of_Kernstown; Confederate_States_of_America; General_officers_in_the_Confederate_States_Army; Jubal_Early; Union_(American_Civil_War); George_Crook; Shenandoah_Valley

event_text: American Civil War: Battle of Ezra Church: Confederate troops make a third unsuccessful attempt to drive Union forces from Atlanta, Georgia.
American Civil War: Battle of the Crater: Union forces attempt to break Confederate lines at Petersburg, Virginia by exploding a large bomb under their trenches.

American Civil War: The Battle of Mobile Bay begins at Mobile Bay near Mobile, Alabama, Admiral David Farragut leads a Union flotilla through Confederate defenses and seals one of the last major Southern ports.
After Uruguay's governing Blanco Party refuses Brazil's demands, José Antônio Saraiva announces that the Brazilian military will begin reprisals, beginning the Uruguayan War.
American Civil War: Battle of Gainesville: Confederate forces defeat Union troops near Gainesville, Florida.
American Civil War: Battle of Globe Tavern: Union forces try to cut a vital Confederate supply-line into Petersburg, Virginia, by attacking the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Globe_Tavern; Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; Petersburg,_Virginia; Wilmington_and_Weldon_Railroad

event_text: Bakumatsu: Kinmon incident: The Chōshū Domain attempts to expel the Satsuma and Aizu Domains from Japan's imperial court.
source_pages: Bakumatsu; Kinmon_incident; Chōshū_Domain; Satsuma_Domain; Aizu_Domain; August_20

event_text: Twelve nations sign the First Geneva Convention, establishing the rules of protection of the victims of armed conflicts.
American Civil War: The Union Navy captures Fort Morgan, Alabama, thus breaking Confederate dominance of all ports on the Gulf of Mexico except Galveston, Texas.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_navy; Siege_of_Fort_Morgan; Confederate_States_of_America; Gulf_of_Mexico; Galveston,_Texas

event_text: During the American Civil War, Union forces led by General William T. Sherman launch an assault on Atlanta.
American Civil War: The Confederate Army General John Bell Hood orders the evacuation of Atlanta, ending a four-month siege by General William Tecumseh Sherman.
American Civil War: Union forces enter Atlanta, a day after the Confederate defenders flee the city, ending the Atlanta Campaign.
American Civil War: Atlanta is evacuated on orders of Union General William Tecumseh Sherman.
American Civil War: John Bell Hood begins the Franklin–Nashville Campaign in an unsuccessful attempt to draw William Tecumseh Sherman back out of Georgia.
American Civil War: Union troops under Philip Sheridan defeat a Confederate force commanded by Jubal Early. With over 50,000 troops engaged, it was the largest battle fought in the Shenandoah Valley.
The Battle of Chaffin's Farm is fought in the American Civil War.
The Treaty of Lisbon defines the boundaries between Spain and Portugal and abolishes the Couto Misto microstate.
American Civil War: Confederates defeat a Union attack on Saltville, Virginia. A massacre of wounded Union prisoners ensues.
American Civil War: A US Navy ship captures a Confederate raider in a Brazilian seaport.
American Civil War: Union cavalrymen defeat Confederate forces at Toms Brook, Virginia during Sheridan's Shenandoah Valley campaign.
American Civil War: The Union garrison of Glasgow, Missouri surrenders to Confederate forces.
American Civil War: The Battle of Cedar Creek ends the last Confederate threat to Washington, DC.
American Civil War: Confederate agents based in Canada rob three banks in Saint Albans, Vermont.
American Civil War: The Battle of Westport is the last significant engagement west of the Mississippi River, ending in a Union victory.
American Civil War: A Union attack on the Confederate capital of Richmond is repulsed.
Second War of Schleswig: The Treaty of Vienna is signed, by which Denmark relinquishes one province each to Prussia and Austria.
Nevada is admitted as the 36th U.S. state.
American Civil War: Confederate troops bombard a Union supply base and destroy millions of dollars in materiel at the Battle of Johnsonville.
American Civil War: The three-day Battle of Bull's Gap ends in a Union rout as Confederates under Major General John C. Breckinridge pursue them to Strawberry Plains, Tennessee.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Battle_of_Bull's_Gap; Union_(American_Civil_War); Confederate_States_of_America; John_C._Breckinridge; Strawberry_Plains,_Tennessee

event_text: American Civil War: Union General William Tecumseh Sherman begins his March to the Sea.

American Civil War: A group of Confederate operatives calling themselves the Confederate Army of Manhattan starts fires in more than 20 locations in an unsuccessful attempt to burn down New York City.
Colorado War: Colorado volunteers led by Colonel John Chivington massacre at least 150 Cheyenne and Arapaho noncombatants at Sand Creek inside Colorado Territory.
source_pages: Colorado_War; Colorado; John_Chivington; Sand_Creek_massacre; Cheyenne; Arapaho; Colorado_Territory; November_29

event_text: American Civil War: The Confederate Army of Tennessee misses an opportunity to crush the Union Army of the Ohio in the Battle of Spring Hill during the Franklin–Nashville campaign.

American Civil War: The Confederate Army of Tennessee led by General John Bell Hood suffers heavy losses in an attack on the Union Army of the Ohio under General John Schofield in the Battle of Franklin.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Confederate_States_of_America; Army_of_Tennessee; John_Bell_Hood; Union_(American_Civil_War); Army_of_the_Ohio; John_Schofield; Battle_of_Franklin; November_30

event_text: American Civil War: Sherman's March to the Sea: Union cavalry forces defeat Confederate cavalry in the Battle of Waynesboro, Georgia, opening the way for General William T. Sherman's army to approach the coast.
Pope Pius IX promulgates the encyclical Quanta cura and its appendix, the Syllabus of Errors, outlining the authority of the Catholic Church and condemning various liberal ideas.
American Civil War: Sherman's March to the Sea: Major General William Tecumseh Sherman's Union Army troops reach the outer Confederate defenses of Savannah, Georgia.

American Civil War: The Battle of Nashville begins at Nashville, Tennessee, and ends the following day with the destruction of the Confederate Army of Tennessee under General John Bell Hood as a fighting force by the Union Army of the Cumberland under General George H. Thomas.
source_pages: Battle_of_Nashville; Nashville,_Tennessee; Confederate_States_of_America; Army_of_Tennessee; John_Bell_Hood; Army_of_the_Cumberland; George_Henry_Thomas; December_15

event_text: American Civil War: The Battle of Nashville ends as the Union Army of the Cumberland under General George H. Thomas routs and destroys the Confederate Army of Tennessee under General John Bell Hood, ending its effectiveness as a combat unit.
source_pages: Battle_of_Nashville; Union_(American_Civil_War); Army_of_the_Cumberland; George_Henry_Thomas; John_Bell_Hood; December_16

event_text: American Civil War: Savannah, Georgia, falls to the Union's Army of the Tennessee, and General Sherman tells President Abraham Lincoln: "I beg to present you as a Christmas gift the city of Savannah".
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Savannah,_Georgia; Union_(American_Civil_War); Army_of_the_Tennessee; William_Tecumseh_Sherman; Abraham_Lincoln; December_22

event_text: Uruguayan War: The Siege of Paysandú ends as the Brazilians and Coloradans capture Paysandú, Uruguay.
source_pages: Uruguayan_War; Siege_of_Paysandú; Empire_of_Brazil; Colorado_Party_(Uruguay); Paysandú; January_2

event_text: American Civil War: Fort Fisher in North Carolina falls to the Union, thus cutting off the last major seaport of the Confederacy.
American Civil War: The United States Congress passes the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, abolishing slavery, and submits it to the states for ratification.
American Civil War: Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief of all Confederate armies.
President Abraham Lincoln signs the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
The municipal administration of Finland is established.

Delaware refuses to ratify the Thirteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, delaying the criminalization of slavery until the amendment's national adoption on December 6, 1865. The amendment is ultimately ratified by Delaware on February 12, 1901, the 92nd anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's birth.
American Civil War: Columbia, South Carolina, is burned as Confederate forces flee from advancing Union forces.
End of the Uruguayan War, with a peace agreement between President Tomás Villalba and rebel leader Venancio Flores, setting the scene for the destructive War of the Triple Alliance.
East Cape War: The Völkner Incident in New Zealand.
The third and final national flag of the Confederate States of America is adopted by the Confederate Congress.
U.S. politician Andrew Johnson made his drunk vice-presidential inaugural address in Washington, D.C.
American Civil War: The Congress of the Confederate States adjourns for the last time.
American Civil War: The Battle of Bentonville begins. By the end of the battle two days later, Confederate forces had retreated from Four Oaks, North Carolina.
American Civil War: In Virginia during the Siege of Petersburg, Confederate forces temporarily capture Fort Stedman from the Union before being repulsed.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Virginia; Siege_of_Petersburg; Confederate_States_of_America; Battle_of_Fort_Stedman; Union_(American_Civil_War)

event_text: American Civil War: Union troops led by Philip Sheridan decisively defeat Confederate troops led by George Pickett, cutting the Army of Northern Virginia's last supply line during the Siege of Petersburg.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Philip_Sheridan; Battle_of_Five_Forks; George_Pickett; Army_of_Northern_Virginia; Siege_of_Petersburg; April_1

event_text: American Civil War: Defeat at the Third Battle of Petersburg forces the Army of Northern Virginia and the Confederate government to abandon Richmond, Virginia.
American Civil War: Union forces capture Richmond, Virginia, the capital of the Confederate States of America.
American Civil War: A day after Union forces capture Richmond, Virginia, U.S. President Abraham Lincoln visits the Confederate capital.
source_pages: American_Civil_War; Union_(American_Civil_War); Richmond,_Virginia; Abraham_Lincoln; Confederate_States_of_America; April_4

event_text: American Civil War: The Battle of Sailor's Creek: Confederate General Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia fights and loses its last major battle while in retreat from Richmond, Virginia, during the Appomattox Campaign.
American Civil War: Robert E. Lee surrenders the Army of Northern Virginia (26,765 troops) to Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Court House, Virginia, effectively ending the war.
American Civil War: A day after his surrender to Union forces, Confederate General Robert E. Lee addresses his troops for the last time.
American Civil War: Mobile, Alabama, falls to the Union Army.
American Civil War: Raleigh, North Carolina is occupied by Union forces.
U.S. President Abraham Lincoln is shot in Ford's Theatre by John Wilkes Booth; Lincoln dies the following day.
William H. Seward, the U.S. Secretary of State, and his family are attacked at home by Lewis Powell.
President Abraham Lincoln dies after being shot the previous evening by actor John Wilkes Booth. Three hours later, Vice President Andrew Johnson is sworn in as president.
Astronomer Angelo Secchi demonstrates the Secchi disk, which measures water clarity, aboard Pope Pius IX's yacht, the L'Immaculata Concezion.
Union cavalry troopers corner and shoot dead John Wilkes Booth, assassin of President Abraham Lincoln, in Virginia.
The Empire of Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay sign the Treaty of the Triple Alliance.
American Civil War: The Confederate government was declared dissolved at Washington, Georgia.
American Civil War: Nathan Bedford Forrest surrenders his forces at Gainesville, Alabama.
American Civil War: President Andrew Johnson issues a proclamation ending belligerent rights of the rebels and enjoining foreign nations to intern or expel Confederate ships.
American Civil War: In Kentucky, Union soldiers ambush and mortally wound Confederate raider William Quantrill, who lingers until his death on June 6.
American Civil War: The Battle of Palmito Ranch: The first day of the last major land action to take place during the Civil War, resulting in a Confederate victory.
The International Telegraph Union (later the International Telecommunication Union) is established in Paris.
In Mobile, Alabama, around 300 people are killed when an ordnance depot explodes.

Conclusion of the American Civil War: The Confederate General Edmund Kirby Smith, commander of the Trans-Mississippi division, is the last full general of the Confederate Army to surrender, at Galveston, Texas.
source_pages: Conclusion_of_the_American_Civil_War; Confederate_States_of_America; Edmund_Kirby_Smith; Trans-Mississippi; Confederate_States_Army; Galveston,_Texas

event_text: The Naval Battle of the Riachuelo is fought on the rivulet Riachuelo (Argentina), between the Paraguayan Navy on one side and the Brazilian Navy on the other. The Brazilian victory was crucial for the later success of the Triple Alliance (Brazil, Uruguay, and Argentina) in the Paraguayan War.
source_pages: Battle_of_Riachuelo; Argentina; Paraguayan_Navy; Brazilian_Navy; Treaty_of_the_Triple_Alliance; Brazil; Uruguay; Paraguayan_War

event_text: Over two years after the Emancipation Proclamation, slaves in Galveston, Texas, United States, are officially informed of their freedom. The anniversary was officially celebrated in Texas and other states as Juneteenth. On June 17, 2021, Juneteenth officially became a federal holiday in the United States.
American Civil War: At Fort Towson in the Oklahoma Territory, Confederate Brigadier General Stand Watie surrenders the last significant Confederate army.
The Army of the Potomac is disbanded.
The United States Secret Service begins operation.
Four conspirators in the assassination of Abraham Lincoln are hanged.
The first ascent of the Matterhorn is completed by Edward Whymper and his party, four of whom die on the descent.
In the market square of Springfield, Missouri, Wild Bill Hickok shoots and kills Davis Tutt in what is regarded as the first western showdown.
Welsh settlers arrive at Chubut in Argentina.
The steamboat Brother Jonathan sinks off the coast of Crescent City, California, killing 225 passengers, the deadliest shipwreck on the Pacific Coast of the U.S. at the time.
The first narrow-gauge mainline railway in the world opens at Grandchester, Queensland, Australia.
Joseph Lister, British surgeon and scientist,  performs the first antiseptic surgery.
Hundreds of black men and women march in Jamaica, starting the Morant Bay rebellion.
Major Henry Wirz, the superintendent of a prison camp in Andersonville, Georgia, is hanged, becoming one of only three American Civil War soldiers executed for war crimes.
source_pages: Henry_Wirz; Andersonville,_Georgia; Hanging; American_Civil_War; Capital_punishment; War_crime

event_text: Treaty of Sinchula is signed whereby Bhutan cedes the areas east of the Teesta River to the British East India Company.
Battle of Papudo: A Spanish navy schooner is defeated by a Chilean corvette north of Valparaíso, Chile.
Shaw University, the first historically black university in the southern United States, is founded in Raleigh, North Carolina.
Alabama ratifies the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, followed by North Carolina, then Georgia; U.S. slaves were legally free within two weeks.
North Carolina ratifies 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, followed two days later by Georgia, and U.S. slaves were legally free within two weeks.
Chincha Islands War: Peru allies with Chile against Spain.
Georgia ratifies the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
First performance of the Unfinished Symphony by Franz Schubert.
US Secretary of State William Seward proclaims the adoption of the Thirteenth Amendment, prohibiting slavery throughout the United States.
Former Confederate officers Frank McCord, Richard Reed, John Lester, John Kennedy, J. Calvin Jones, and James Crowe form the Ku Klux Klan.
The Royal Aeronautical Society is formed in London.
Wesley College is established in Melbourne, Australia.
Spencer Compton Cavendish, Marquess of Hartington becomes British Secretary of State for War.
President of the United States of America Andrew Johnson vetoes the Civil Rights Act of 1866. His veto is overridden by Congress and the bill passes into law on April 9.
Alexander II of Russia narrowly escapes an assassination attempt by Dmitry Karakozov in the city of Saint Petersburg.
The Grand Army of the Republic, an American patriotic organization composed of Union veterans of the American Civil War, is founded. It lasts until 1956.
Austro-Prussian War: Italy and Prussia sign a secret alliance against the Austrian Empire.
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) is founded in New York City by Henry Bergh.
The Memphis Race Riots begin. Over three days, 46 blacks and two whites were killed. Reports of the atrocities influenced passage of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
Peruvian defenders fight off the Spanish fleet at the Battle of Callao.
Memorial Day first celebrated in United States at Waterloo, New York.
The United States Congress establishes the nickel.
Oliver Winchester founded the Winchester Repeating Arms.
Bedrich Smetana's comic opera The Bartered Bride premiered in Prague.
The Fenians defeat Canadian forces at Ridgeway and Fort Erie, but the raids end soon after.
One thousand eight hundred Fenian raiders are repelled back to the United States after looting and plundering the Saint-Armand and Frelighsburg areas of Canada East.
Battle of Custoza: An Austrian army defeats the Italian army during the Austro-Prussian War.
Austro-Prussian War is decided at the Battle of Königgrätz, enabling Prussia to exclude Austria from German affairs.
Austro-Prussian War: Battle of Lissa: The Austrian Navy, led by Admiral Wilhelm von Tegetthoff, defeats the Italian Navy near the island of Vis in the Adriatic Sea.
source_pages: Austro-Prussian_War; Battle_of_Lissa_(1866); Austro-Hungarian_Navy; Wilhelm_von_Tegetthoff; Regia_Marina; Vis_(island); Adriatic_Sea

event_text: Reconstruction: Tennessee becomes the first U.S. state to be readmitted to Congress following the American Civil War.
The United States Congress passes legislation authorizing the rank of General of the Army. Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant becomes the first to be promoted to this rank.
The first permanent transatlantic telegraph cable is successfully completed, stretching from Valentia Island, Ireland, to Heart's Content, Newfoundland.
At the age of 18, Vinnie Ream becomes the first and youngest female artist to receive a commission from the United States government for a statue (of Abraham Lincoln).
Armed Confederate veterans in New Orleans riot against a meeting of Radical Republicans, killing 48 people and injuring another 100.
The Grand Duchy of Baden announces its withdrawal from the German Confederation and signs a treaty of peace and alliance with Prussia.
President Andrew Johnson formally declares the American Civil War over.
The Austro-Prussian War ends with the Treaty of Prague.
The Battle of Curupayty is Paraguay's only significant victory in the Paraguayan War.

In accordance with the Treaty of Vienna, Austria cedes Veneto and Mantua to France, which immediately awards them to Italy in exchange for the earlier Italian acquiescence to the French annexation of Savoy and Nice.
A plebiscite ratifies the annexation of Veneto and Mantua to Italy, which had occurred three days before on October 19.
Oaks explosion: The worst mining disaster in England kills 361 miners and rescuers.
The Kingstree jail fire kills 22 freedmen in Reconstruction-era South Carolina.
The United States Congress passes the bill to allow African American men the right to vote in Washington, D.C.
Forty people die when ice covering the boating lake at Regent's Park, London, collapses.
Work begins on the covering of the Senne, burying Brussels's primary river and creating the modern central boulevards.
Nebraska is admitted as the 37th U.S. state.
The U.S. Congress passes the first Reconstruction Act.
Queen Victoria gives Royal Assent to the British North America Act which establishes Canada on July 1.
Alaska is purchased from Russia for $7.2 million, about two cents/acre ($4.19/km2), by United States Secretary of State William H. Seward.
Singapore becomes a British crown colony.
The Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867 ("the Compromise") is born through Act 12, which establishes the Austro-Hungarian Empire.
Coronation of Franz Joseph as King of Hungary following the Austro-Hungarian compromise (Ausgleich).
Maximilian I of the Second Mexican Empire is executed by a firing squad in Querétaro, Querétaro.

The British North America Act takes effect as the Province of Canada, New Brunswick, and Nova Scotia join into confederation to create the modern nation of Canada. John A. Macdonald is sworn in as the first Prime Minister of Canada. This date is commemorated annually in Canada as Canada Day, a national holiday.
source_pages: Constitution_Act,_1867; Province_of_Canada; New_Brunswick; Nova_Scotia; Canadian_Confederation; John_A._Macdonald; Prime_Minister_of_Canada; Canada_Day

event_text: Harvard School of Dental Medicine is established in Boston, Massachusetts. It is the first dental school in the U.S. that is affiliated with a university.
The United States takes possession of the (at this point unoccupied) Midway Atoll.
Mutsuhito, Emperor Meiji of Japan, marries Masako Ichijō, thereafter known as Empress Shōken.
Toronto becomes the capital of Ontario, having also been the capital of Ontario's predecessors since 1796.
United States takes possession of Alaska after purchasing it from Russia for $7.2 million. Celebrated annually in the state as Alaska Day.
The Medicine Lodge Treaty is signed by southern Great Plains Indian leaders. The treaty requires Native American Plains tribes to relocate to a reservation in the western Indian Territory.
Giuseppe Garibaldi and his followers are defeated in the Battle of Mentana and fail to end the Pope's Temporal power in Rome (it would be achieved three years later).
The Tokugawa shogunate hands back power to the Emperor of Japan, starting the Meiji Restoration.
An earthquake strikes the Virgin Islands, triggering the largest tsunami witnessed in the Caribbean and killing dozens.
The Manchester Martyrs are hanged in Manchester, England, for killing a police officer while freeing two Irish Republican Brotherhood members from custody.
At Tremont Temple in Boston, British author Charles Dickens gives his first public reading in the United States.
Former Minnesota farmer Oliver Hudson Kelley founds the Order of the Patrons of Husbandry (better known today as the Grange).
A Fenian bomb explodes in Clerkenwell, London, killing 12 people and injuring 50.
A magnitude 7.0 earthquakes strikes off the coast of Taiwan, triggering a tsunami and killing at least 580 people.
Meiji Restoration in Japan: The Tokugawa shogunate is abolished; agents of Satsuma and Chōshū seize power.

Boshin War: The Battle of Toba–Fushimi begins, between forces of the Tokugawa shogunate and pro-Imperial factions; it will end in defeat for the shogunate, and is a pivotal point in the Meiji Restoration.
source_pages: Boshin_War; Battle_of_Toba–Fushimi; Tokugawa_shogunate; Emperor_of_Japan; Meiji_Restoration; January_27

event_text: Andrew Johnson becomes the first President of the United States to be impeached by the United States House of Representatives. He is later acquitted in the Senate.
source_pages: Andrew_Johnson; President_of_the_United_States; Impeachment_of_Andrew_Johnson; United_States_House_of_Representatives; United_States_Senate; February_24

event_text: Mefistofele, an opera by Arrigo Boito, receives its premiere performance at La Scala.
Sakai incident: Japanese samurai kill 11 French sailors in the port of Sakai, Osaka.
The University of California is founded in Oakland, California when the Organic Act is signed into law.
Thomas D'Arcy McGee, one of the Canadian Fathers of Confederation, is assassinated by a Fenian activist.
At Arogee in Abyssinia, British and Indian forces defeat an army of Emperor Tewodros II. While 700 Ethiopians are killed and many more injured, only two British/Indian troops die.
Former shōgun Tokugawa Yoshinobu surrenders Edo Castle to Imperial forces, marking the end of the Tokugawa shogunate.
Boshin War: The Battle of Utsunomiya Castle ends as former Tokugawa shogunate forces withdraw northward.
The United States Senate fails to convict President Andrew Johnson by one vote.
Impeachment of Andrew Johnson: President Andrew Johnson is acquitted by one vote in the United States Senate.

Decoration Day (the predecessor of the modern "Memorial Day") is observed in the United States for the first time after a proclamation by John A. Logan, head of the Grand Army of the Republic (a veterans group).
The Treaty of Bosque Redondo is signed, allowing the Navajo to return to their lands in Arizona and New Mexico.
Mihailo Obrenović III, Prince of Serbia is assassinated.
Christopher Latham Sholes received a patent for an invention he called the "Type-Writer".
The 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, guaranteeing African Americans full citizenship and all persons in the United States due process of law.
The Wyoming Territory is established.
The 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution is certified, establishing African American citizenship and guaranteeing due process of law.

The 8.5–9.0 Mw  Arica earthquake struck southern Peru with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), causing 25,000+ deaths and a destructive basin wide tsunami that affected Hawaii and New Zealand.
French astronomer Pierre Janssen discovers helium.
La Gloriosa begins in Spain.
The Grito de Lares occurs in Puerto Rico against Spanish rule.
The Imperial Russian steam frigate Alexander Nevsky is shipwrecked off Jutland while carrying Grand Duke Alexei Alexandrovich of Russia.
The Battle of Alcolea causes Queen Isabella II of Spain to flee to France.
Cornell University holds opening day ceremonies; initial student enrollment is 412, the highest at any American university to that date.
The Ten Years' War begins against Spanish rule in Cuba.
Meiji Restoration: Having taken the shogunate's seat of power at Edo and declared it his new capital as Tokyo, Mutsuhito proclaims the start of the new Meiji era.
source_pages: Meiji_Restoration; Tokugawa_shogunate; Edo; Tokyo; Emperor_Meiji; Meiji_era; October_23

event_text: The Uspenski Cathedral, designed by Aleksey Gornostayev, is inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland.
Time zone: New Zealand officially adopts a standard time to be observed nationally.
John Willis Menard (R-LA) was the first African American elected to the United States Congress.  Because of an electoral challenge, he was never seated.
Camagüey, Cuba, revolts against Spain during the Ten Years' War.
American Indian Wars: Battle of Washita River: United States Army Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer leads an attack on Cheyenne living on reservation land.
source_pages: American_Indian_Wars; Battle_of_the_Washita_River; United_States_Army; Lieutenant_colonel; George_Armstrong_Custer; Cheyenne

event_text: The first traffic lights are installed, outside the Palace of Westminster in London. Resembling railway signals, they use semaphore arms and are illuminated at night by red and green gas lamps.
Paraguayan War: Brazilian troops defeat the Paraguayan Army at the Battle of Avay.
The Greek Presidential Guard is established as the royal escort by King George I.
Pardons for ex-Confederates: United States President Andrew Johnson grants an unconditional pardon to all Confederate veterans.
Boshin War: Tokugawa rebels establish the Ezo Republic in Hokkaidō.
The largest alluvial gold nugget in history, called the "Welcome Stranger", is found in Moliagul, Victoria, Australia.
Dmitri Mendeleev presents the first periodic table to the Russian Chemical Society.
The last of Tītokowaru's forces surrendered to the New Zealand government, ending his uprising.
Morelos is admitted as the 27th state of Mexico.
Chinese and Irish laborers for the Central Pacific Railroad working on the First transcontinental railroad lay ten miles of track in one day, a feat which has never been matched.

The four-day Naval Battle of Hakodate begins. The newly formed Imperial Japanese Navy defeats the remnants of the Tokugawa shogunate navy in the Sea of Japan off the city of Hakodate, leading to the surrender of the Ezo Republic on May 17.
source_pages: Naval_Battle_of_Hakodate; Imperial_Japanese_Navy; Tokugawa_shogunate; Sea_of_Japan; Hakodate; Republic_of_Ezo; May_4

event_text: The First transcontinental railroad, linking the eastern and western United States, is completed at Promontory Summit, Utah Territory with the golden spike.
Boston University is chartered by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
The Japanese daimyōs begin returning their land holdings to the emperor as part of the Meiji Restoration reforms. (Traditional Japanese Date: June 17, 1869).
Japan's Edo society class system is abolished as part of the Meiji Restoration reforms.
Battle of Acosta Ñu: A Paraguayan battalion largely made up of children is massacred by the Brazilian Army during the Paraguayan War.
The Mount Washington Cog Railway opens, making it the world's first mountain-climbing rack railway.
Black Friday (1869): Gold prices plummet after United States President Ulysses Grant orders the Treasury to sell large quantities of gold after Jay Gould and James Fisk plot to control the market.
The Saxby Gale devastates the Bay of Fundy region in Canada.
The Eastman tunnel, in Minnesota, United States, collapses during construction, causing a landslide that nearly destroys St. Anthony Falls.
The Cardiff Giant, one of the most famous American hoaxes, is "discovered".
Girton College, Cambridge is founded, becoming England's first residential college for women.
In New Brunswick, New Jersey, Rutgers College defeats Princeton University (then known as the College of New Jersey), 6–4, in the first official intercollegiate American football game.

The Victorian Aboriginal Protection Act is enacted in Australia, giving the government control of indigenous people's wages, their terms of employment, where they could live, and of their children, effectively leading to the Stolen Generations.
In Egypt, the Suez Canal, linking the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea, is inaugurated.
In Dumbarton, Scotland, the clipper Cutty Sark is launched.
The short-lived Republic of Ezo is proclaimed in the Ezo area of Japan. It is the first attempt to establish a democracy in Japan.
Construction work begins on the Brooklyn Bridge in New York, United States.
The inauguration of the Musikverein in Vienna, Austria.
John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil.
Thomas Nast publishes a political cartoon  symbolizing the Democratic Party with a donkey ("A Live Jackass Kicking a Dead Lion") for Harper's Weekly.
source_pages: Thomas_Nast; Political_cartoon; Democratic_Party_(United_States); Donkey; Harper's_Weekly; January_15

event_text: In Montana, U.S. cavalrymen kill 173 Native Americans, mostly women and children, in what becomes known as the Marias Massacre.
Reconstruction Era: Virginia is readmitted to the Union.
The Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, guaranteeing voting rights to male citizens regardless of race.
US president Ulysses S. Grant signs a joint resolution of Congress establishing the U.S. Weather Bureau.
Stevens Institute of Technology is founded in New Jersey, US, and offers the first Bachelor of Engineering degree in mechanical engineering.
Reconstruction Era: Post-U.S. Civil War military control of Mississippi ends and it is readmitted to the Union.
Hiram Rhodes Revels, a Republican from Mississippi, is sworn into the United States Senate, becoming the first African American ever to sit in Congress.
source_pages: Hiram_R._Revels; Republican_Party_(United_States); Mississippi; United_States_Senate; African_Americans; United_States_Congress; February_25

event_text: The Beach Pneumatic Transit in New York City, intended as a demonstration for a subway line, opens.
The current flag of Japan is first adopted as the national flag for Japanese merchant ships.
Marshal F. S. López dies during the Battle of Cerro Corá thus marking the end of the Paraguayan War.

A Chilean prospecting party led by José Díaz Gana discovers the silver ores of Caracoles in the Bolivian portion of Atacama Desert,  leading to the last of the Chilean silver rushes  and a diplomatic dispute over its taxation between Chile and Bolivia.
Texas is readmitted to the United States Congress following Reconstruction.
The New York City Metropolitan Museum of Art is founded.
The Manitoba Act is given the Royal Assent, paving the way for Manitoba to become a province of Canada on July 15.
The first game of rugby in New Zealand is played in Nelson between Nelson College and the Nelson Rugby Football Club.
The United States Department of Justice is created by the U.S. Congress.
The US Congress establishes the first federal holidays (New Year Day, July 4th, Thanksgiving, and Christmas).
The United States Department of Justice formally comes into existence.
Reconstruction Era of the United States: Georgia becomes the last of the former Confederate states to be readmitted to the Union.

Canadian Confederation: Rupert's Land and the North-Western Territory are transferred to Canada from the Hudson's Bay Company, and the province of Manitoba and the Northwest Territories are established from these vast territories.
source_pages: Canadian_Confederation; Rupert's_Land; North-Western_Territory; Hudson's_Bay_Company; Manitoba; Northwest_Territories

event_text: The First Vatican Council decrees the dogma of papal infallibility.
Franco-Prussian War: France declares war on Prussia.
Tower Subway, the world's first underground tube railway, opens in London, England, United Kingdom.
Franco-Prussian War: The Battle of Spicheren is fought, resulting in a German victory.
Franco-Prussian War: The Battle of Wörth results in a decisive German victory.
The Republic of Ploiești, a failed Radical-Liberal rising against Domnitor Carol of Romania.
Franco-Prussian War: The Battle of Mars-la-Tour is fought, resulting in a Prussian victory.
Franco-Prussian War: Battle of Gravelotte is fought.
The Wolseley expedition reaches Manitoba to end the Red River Rebellion.
Franco-Prussian War: The Battle of Sedan is fought, resulting in a decisive Prussian victory.
Franco-Prussian War: Battle of Sedan: Prussian forces take Napoleon III of France and 100,000 of his soldiers prisoner.
Franco-Prussian War: The Siege of Metz begins, resulting in a decisive Prussian victory on October 23.
Emperor Napoleon III of France is deposed and the Third Republic is declared.
Louisa Ann Swain of Laramie, Wyoming becomes the first woman in the United States to cast a vote legally after 1807.
Franco-Prussian War: The siege of Paris begins. The city held out for over four months before surrendering.
The Bersaglieri corps enter Rome through the Porta Pia, and complete the unification of Italy.
By plebiscite, the citizens of the Papal States accept annexation by the Kingdom of Italy.
Franco-Prussian War: Léon Gambetta escapes the siege of Paris in a hot-air balloon.
Franco-Prussian War: Marshal Bazaine surrenders to Prussian forces at the conclusion of the Siege of Metz along with 140,000 French soldiers.
In the United States, the Weather Bureau (later renamed the National Weather Service) makes its first official meteorological forecast.
The Battle of Coulmiers ends in a Pyrrhic victory for the French army during the Franco-German War of 1870.
Joseph H. Rainey of South Carolina becomes the second black U.S. congressman.
Wagner's Siegfried Idyll is first performed.
In the Battle of Bapaume, an engagement in the Franco-Prussian War, General Louis Faidherbe's forces bring about a Prussian retreat.

Wilhelm I of Germany is proclaimed Kaiser Wilhelm in the Hall of Mirrors of the Palace of Versailles (France) towards the end of the Franco-Prussian War. Wilhelm already had the title of German Emperor since the constitution of 1 January 1871, but he had hesitated to accept the title.
source_pages: Wilhelm_I; Hall_of_Mirrors; Palace_of_Versailles; Franco-Prussian_War; German_Emperor; Constitution_of_the_German_Confederation_(1871); January_18

event_text: Franco-Prussian War: In the Siege of Paris, Prussia wins the Battle of St. Quentin. Meanwhile, the French attempt to break the siege in the Battle of Buzenval will end unsuccessfully the following day.
Franco-Prussian War: The Siege of Paris ends in French defeat and an armistice.
The victorious Prussian Army parades through Paris, France, after the end of the Siege of Paris during the Franco-Prussian War.
Declaration of the Paris Commune; President of the French Republic, Adolphe Thiers, orders the evacuation of Paris.
Otto von Bismarck is appointed as the first Chancellor of the German Empire.
Journalist Henry Morton Stanley begins his trek to find the missionary and explorer David Livingstone.
In North Carolina, William Woods Holden becomes the first governor of a U.S. state to be removed from office by impeachment.
The elections of Commune council of the Paris Commune are held.
The first international rugby football match, when Scotland defeats England in Edinburgh at Raeburn Place.
Royal Albert Hall is opened by Queen Victoria.
The Camp Grant massacre takes place in Arizona Territory.
The National Association, the first professional baseball league, opens its first season in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
French troops invade the Paris Commune and engage its residents in street fighting. By the close of "Bloody Week", some 20,000 communards have been killed and 38,000 arrested.
Opening of the first rack railway in Europe, the Rigi Bahnen on Mount Rigi.
The Paris Commune falls after two months.
Sinmiyangyo: Captain McLane Tilton leads 109 US Marines in a naval attack on Han River forts on Kanghwa Island, Korea.
The Universities Tests Act 1871 allows students to enter the universities of Oxford, Cambridge and Durham without religious tests (except for those intending to study theology).
Victor Emmanuel II of Italy enters Rome after having conquered it from the Papal States during the Capture of Rome.
British Columbia joins the Canadian Confederation.
The Connecticut Valley Railroad opens between Old Saybrook, Connecticut and Hartford, Connecticut in the United States.
The Staten Island Ferry Westfield's boiler explodes, killing over 85 people.
An explosion of guncotton occurs in Stowmarket, England, killing 28.
Emperor Meiji orders the abolition of the han system and the establishment of prefectures as local centers of administration. (Traditional Japanese date: July 14, 1871).
Bishop John Coleridge Patteson, first bishop of Melanesia, is martyred on Nukapu, now in the Solomon Islands.
The Brazilian Parliament passes a law that frees all children thereafter born to slaves, and all government-owned slaves.
Slash-and-burn land management, months of drought, and the passage of a strong cold front cause the Peshtigo Fire, the Great Chicago Fire and the Great Michigan Fires to break out.
source_pages: Slash-and-burn_agriculture; Cold_front; Peshtigo_fire; Great_Chicago_Fire; Great_Michigan_Fire; October_8

event_text: The British in India enact the Criminal Tribes Act, naming many local communities "Criminal Tribes".
An estimated 17 to 22 Chinese immigrants are lynched in Los Angeles, California.
Liberian President Edward James Roye is deposed in a coup d'état.
Henry Morton Stanley locates missing explorer and missionary, David Livingstone in Ujiji, near Lake Tanganyika, famously greeting him with the words, "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?"
The National Rifle Association of America receives its charter from New York State.
Sixteen-year-old telegraphist Ella Stewart keys and sends the first telegraphed message from Arizona Territory at the Deseret Telegraph Company office in Pipe Spring.
source_pages: Telegraphist; Ella_Stewart_Udall; Arizona_Territory; Deseret_Telegraph_Company; Pipe_Spring_National_Monument; December_15

event_text: The opera Aida premieres in Cairo, Egypt.
Thespis, the first Gilbert and Sullivan collaboration, debuts.
Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum, the first imperial coronation in that city in over 200 years.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art opens in New York City.
The Prohibition Party holds its first national convention in Columbus, Ohio, nominating James Black as its presidential nominee.
Yellowstone National Park is established as the world's first national park.
George Westinghouse patents the air brake.
Construction of the Seven Sisters Colliery, South Wales, begins; it is located on one of the richest coal sources in Britain.
The Wanderers F.C. win the first FA Cup, the oldest football competition in the world, beating Royal Engineers A.F.C. 1–0 at The Oval in Kennington, London.
source_pages: Wanderers_F.C.; FA_Cup; Association_football; Royal_Engineers_A.F.C.; The_Oval; Kennington

event_text: The first Arbor Day is celebrated in Nebraska.
Victoria Woodhull becomes the first woman nominated for President of the United States.
Reconstruction Era: President Ulysses S. Grant signs the Amnesty Act into law, restoring full civil and political rights to all but about 500 Confederate sympathizers.
Trade unions are legalized in Canada.
The Ballot Act 1872 in the United Kingdom introduced the requirement that parliamentary and local government elections be held by secret ballot.
Women's suffrage in the United States: In defiance of the law, suffragist Susan B. Anthony votes for the first time, and is later fined $100.
The Great Boston Fire of 1872.
Susan B. Anthony and 14 other women are arrested for voting illegally in the United States presidential election of 1872.
The Modoc War begins with the Battle of Lost River.
The first-ever international football match takes place at Hamilton Crescent, Glasgow, between Scotland and England.
The American brigantine Mary Celeste is discovered drifting in the Atlantic. Her crew is never found.
In Louisiana, P. B. S. Pinchback becomes the first African American governor of a U.S. state following the impeachment of Henry C. Warmoth.
Challenger expedition: HMS Challenger, commanded by Captain George Nares, sails from Portsmouth, England.
A group of Modoc warriors defeats the United States Army in the First Battle of the Stronghold, part of the Modoc War.
King Amadeo I of Spain abdicates, triggering the proclamation of the First Spanish Republic.
Bulgarian revolutionary leader Vasil Levski is executed by hanging in Sofia by the Ottoman authorities.
Censorship in the United States: The U.S. Congress enacts the Comstock Law, making it illegal to send any "obscene literature and articles of immoral use" through the mail.
The first Azerbaijani play, The Adventures of the Vizier of the Khan of Lenkaran, prepared by Akhundov, is performed by Hassan-bey Zardabi and dramatist and Najaf-bey Vezirov.
The Spanish National Assembly abolishes slavery in Puerto Rico.
The White Star steamer SS Atlantic sinks off Nova Scotia, killing 547 in one of the worst marine disasters of the 19th century.
The Colfax massacre: More than 60 to 150 black men are murdered in Colfax, Louisiana, while surrendering to a mob of former Confederate soldiers and members of the Ku Klux Klan.
Der Krach: The Vienna stock exchange crash begins the Panic of 1873 and heralds the Long Depression.
Levi Strauss and Jacob Davis receive a U.S. patent for blue jeans with copper rivets.
source_pages: Levi_Strauss; Jacob_W._Davis; Patent; Jeans; Copper; May_20

event_text: The Canadian Parliament establishes the North-West Mounted Police, the forerunner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
Patrick Francis Healy becomes the first black president of a predominantly white university in the United States.
Sultan Barghash bin Said of Zanzibar closes the great slave market under the terms of a treaty with Great Britain.
Susan B. Anthony is fined $100 for attempting to vote in the 1872 presidential election.
Prince Edward Island joins into Canadian Confederation.
At Adair, Iowa, Jesse James and the James–Younger Gang pull off the first successful train robbery in the American Old West.
The Clay Street Hill Railroad begins operating the first cable car in San Francisco's famous cable car system.

American Indian Wars: While protecting a railroad survey party in Montana, the United States 7th Cavalry, under Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer clashes for the first time with the Cheyenne and Lakota people near the Tongue River; only one man on each side is killed.
source_pages: American_Indian_Wars; Montana; 7th_Cavalry_Regiment; Lieutenant_colonel_(United_States); George_Armstrong_Custer; Cheyenne; Lakota_people; Tongue_River_(Montana)

event_text: The Albert Bridge in Chelsea, London opens.
Austrian explorers Julius von Payer and Karl Weyprecht discover the archipelago of Franz Josef Land in the Arctic Sea.
Cetshwayo ascends to the throne as king of the Zulu nation following the death of his father Mpande.
Franco-Prussian War: The last Imperial German Army troops leave France upon completion of payment of indemnity.
The U.S. bank Jay Cooke & Company declares bankruptcy, contributing to the Panic of 1873.
Chief Kintpuash and companions are hanged for their part in the Modoc War of northern California.
A meeting at the U.S. Naval Academy establishes the U.S. Naval Institute.
Garnier Expedition: French forces under Lieutenant Francis Garnier captured Hanoi from the Vietnamese.
source_pages: Garnier_Expedition; French_Third_Republic; Francis_Garnier; Battle_of_Hanoi_(1873); Hanoi; Nguyễn_dynasty; November_20

event_text: The French steamer SS Ville du Havre sinks in 12 minutes after colliding with the Scottish iron clipper Loch Earn in the Atlantic, with a loss of 226 lives.
The Treaty of Pangkor is signed between the British and Sultan Abdullah of Perak, paving the way for further British colonization of Malaya.
Modest Mussorgsky's opera Boris Godunov premieres in Mariinsky Theatre in St.Petersburg.
The Oakland Daily Tribune publishes its first edition.
France and Vietnam sign the Second Treaty of Saigon, further recognizing the full sovereignty of France over Cochinchina.
The Hawaiian Kingdom signs a treaty with the United States granting exclusive trade rights.
A flood on the Mill River in Massachusetts destroys much of four villages and kills 139 people.
Verdi's Requiem was first performed at San Marco in Milan on the first anniversary of Manzoni's death.
The first group of Dorsland trekkers under the leadership of Gert Alberts leaves Pretoria.

Greek politician Charilaos Trikoupis publishes a manifesto in the Athens daily Kairoi entitled "Who's to Blame?" leveling complaints against King George. Trikoupis is elected Prime Minister of Greece the next year.
The Sholes and Glidden typewriter, the first commercially successful typewriter, goes on sale.
The Mounties begin their March West.
The Chicago Fire of 1874 burns down 47 acres of the city, destroying 812 buildings, killing 20, and resulting in the fire insurance industry demanding municipal reforms from Chicago's city council.
Aires de Ornelas e Vasconcelos is appointed the Archbishop of the Portuguese colonial enclave of Goa, India.
Patrick Francis Healy became the first African-American inaugurated as president of a predominantly white university, Georgetown University.
Japan launches its postal savings system, modeled after a similar system in the United Kingdom.
The Universal Postal Union is created by the Treaty of Bern.
A cartoon by Thomas Nast in Harper's Weekly, is considered the first important use of an elephant as a symbol for the United States Republican Party.
The United States Greenback Party is established as a political party consisting primarily of farmers affected by the Panic of 1873.
The military coup of Gen. Martinez Campos in Sagunto ends the failed First Spanish Republic and the monarchy is restored as Prince Alfonso is proclaimed King of Spain.
source_pages: Arsenio_Martínez_Campos; Sagunto; First_Spanish_Republic; Restoration_(Spain); Alfonso_XII; Spain; December_29

event_text: The Palais Garnier, one of the most famous opera houses in the world, is inaugurated in Paris.
The SS Gothenburg hits the Great Barrier Reef and sinks off the Australian east coast, killing approximately 100, including a number of high-profile civil servants and dignitaries.
Guangxu Emperor of Qing dynasty China begins his reign, under Empress Dowager Cixi's regency.
The first ever organized indoor game of ice hockey is played in Montreal, Quebec, Canada as recorded in the Montreal Gazette.
Bizet's opera Carmen is first performed at the Opéra-Comique in Paris.
Archbishop of New York John McCloskey is named the first cardinal in the United States.
India: Arya Samaj is founded in Mumbai by Swami Dayananda Saraswati to propagate his goal of social reform.
Aristides wins the first Kentucky Derby with the jockey Oliver Lewis (2:37.75).
Signing of the Metre Convention by 17 nations leading to the establishment of the International System of Units.
The Herzegovinian rebellion against the Ottoman Empire begins.
The Herzegovina Uprising against Ottoman rule begins, which would last until 1878 and have far-reaching implications throughout the Balkans.
The Treaty of Saint Petersburg between Japan and Russia is ratified, providing for the exchange of Sakhalin for the Kuril Islands.
Captain Matthew Webb becomes the first person to swim across the English Channel, traveling from Dover, England, to Calais, France, in 21 hours and 45 minutes.
The first official game of polo is played in Argentina after being introduced by British ranchers.
The 1864 play Heath Cobblers by Aleksis Kivi is premiered for the first time in Oulu, Finland.
The merchant sailing ship Ellen Southard is wrecked in a storm at Liverpool.
Brigham Young University is founded in Provo, Utah.
Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky’s Piano Concerto No. 1 in B♭ minor, Op. 23 premieres in Boston, Massachusetts, with Benjamin Johnson Lang as conductor and Hans von Bülow as soloist.
source_pages: Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky; Piano_Concerto_No._1_(Tchaikovsky); Boston; Massachusetts; Benjamin_Johnson_Lang; Hans_von_Bülow; October_25

event_text: Notorious New York City politician Boss Tweed escapes from prison; he is later recaptured in Spain.
The Plan of Tuxtepec is announced.
The first newspaper in Afrikaans, Die Afrikaanse Patriot, is published in Paarl.
Alexander Graham Bell applies for a patent for the telephone, as does Elisha Gray.
The stage première of Peer Gynt, a play by Henrik Ibsen with incidental music by Edvard Grieg, takes place in Christiania (Oslo), Norway.

Japan and Korea sign the Treaty of Kangwha, which grants Japanese citizens extraterritoriality rights in Korea, opens three Korean ports to Japanese trade, and ends Korea's status as a tributary state of Qing dynasty China.
source_pages: Empire_of_Japan; Korean_Empire; Japan–Korea_Treaty_of_1876; Extraterritoriality; Tributary_state; Qing_dynasty; February_26

event_text: Alexander Graham Bell is granted a patent for an invention he calls the "telephone".
The first successful test of a telephone is made by Alexander Graham Bell.
The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks is organized.
Catalpa rescue: The rescue of six Fenian prisoners from Fremantle Prison in Western Australia.
The April Uprising begins. Its suppression shocks European opinion, and Bulgarian independence becomes a condition for ending the Russo-Turkish War.
The first National League baseball game is played at the Jefferson Street Grounds in Philadelphia.
The April Uprising breaks out in Ottoman Bulgaria.
The Centennial Exposition is opened in Philadelphia.
Ottoman sultan Abdülaziz is deposed and succeeded by his nephew Murad V.

The secret decree of Ems Ukaz, issued by Russian Tsar Alexander II in the German city of Bad Ems, was aimed at stopping the printing and distribution of Ukrainian-language publications in the Russian Empire.
source_pages: Ems_Ukaz; Alexander_II_of_Russia; Bad_Ems; Ukrainian_language; Russian_Empire; May_30

event_text: An express train called the Transcontinental Express arrives in San Francisco via the first transcontinental railroad, 83 hours and 39 minutes after leaving New York City.
American Indian Wars: Battle of the Rosebud: One thousand five hundred Sioux and Cheyenne led by Crazy Horse beat back General George Crook's forces at Rosebud Creek in Montana Territory.
source_pages: American_Indian_Wars; Battle_of_the_Rosebud; Sioux; Cheyenne; Crazy_Horse; General_officer; George_Crook; Montana_Territory; June_17

event_text: American Indian Wars: Battle of the Little Bighorn: 300 men of the U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment under Lieutenant Colonel George Armstrong Custer are wiped out by 5,000 Lakota, Cheyenne and Arapaho, led by Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse.
source_pages: American_Indian_Wars; Battle_of_the_Little_Bighorn; 7th_Cavalry_Regiment; Lieutenant_colonel; George_Armstrong_Custer; Lakota_people; Cheyenne; Arapaho; Sitting_Bull; Crazy_Horse

event_text: The Hamburg massacre prior to the 1876 United States presidential election results in the deaths of six African-Americans of the Republican Party, along with one white assailant.
Colorado is admitted as the 38th U.S. state.
Thomas Edison receives a patent for his mimeograph.
Richard Wagner's Siegfried, the penultimate opera in his Ring cycle, is premiered at the Bayreuth Festspielhaus.
Richard Wagner's Götterdämmerung, the last opera in his Ringcycle, premieres at the Bayreuth Festspielhaus.
Ottoman Sultan Murad V is deposed and succeeded by his brother, Abdul Hamid II.
In Northfield, Minnesota, Jesse James and the James–Younger Gang attempt to rob the town's bank but are driven off by armed citizens.
The Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas opens as the first public college in Texas.

Shinpūren rebellion: Upset at the Westernisation of Meiji Japan and the abolition of the Tokugawa feudal hierarchy, the Keishintō, a group of extremist Shinto former samurai, launch a surprise attack against the Meiji government in Kumamoto Prefecture.
source_pages: Shinpūren_rebellion; Meiji_era; Edo_society; Shinto; Shizoku; Kumamoto_Prefecture; October_24

event_text: Corrupt Tammany Hall leader William Magear Tweed (better known as Boss Tweed) is delivered to authorities in New York City after being captured in Spain.

American Indian Wars: In retaliation for the American defeat at the Battle of the Little Bighorn, United States Army troops sack the sleeping village of Cheyenne Chief Dull Knife at the headwaters of the Powder River.
source_pages: American_Indian_Wars; Battle_of_the_Little_Bighorn; United_States_Army; Dull_Knife_Fight; Cheyenne; Morning_Star_(chief); Powder_River_(Wyoming_and_Montana); November_25

event_text: First day of the Constantinople Conference which resulted in agreement for political reforms in the Balkans.
The Ashtabula River railroad disaster occurs, leaving 64 injured and 92 dead at Ashtabula, Ohio.
Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom is proclaimed Empress of India.
Crazy Horse and his warriors fight their last battle against the United States Cavalry at Wolf Mountain, Montana Territory.
The last day of the Constantinople Conference results in agreement for political reforms in the Balkans.
Tchaikovsky's ballet Swan Lake receives its premiere at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow.
Just two days before inauguration, the U.S. Congress declares Rutherford B. Hayes the winner of the 1876 U.S. presidential election even though Samuel J. Tilden had won the popular vote.
First ever official cricket test match is played: Australia vs England at the MCG Stadium, in Melbourne, Australia.
The United Kingdom annexes the Transvaal.
Russo-Turkish War: The Russian Empire declares war on the Ottoman Empire.
American Indian Wars: Sitting Bull leads his band of Lakota into Canada to avoid harassment by the United States Army under Colonel Nelson Miles.
source_pages: American_Indian_Wars; Sitting_Bull; Lakota_people; United_States_Army; Colonel_(United_States); Nelson_A._Miles

event_text: Chief Crazy Horse of the Oglala Lakota surrenders to United States troops in Nebraska.
At Gilmore's Gardens in New York City, the first Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show opens.
Mihail Kogălniceanu reads, in the Chamber of Deputies, the Declaration of Independence of Romania. The date will become recognised as the Independence Day of Romania.

The 16 May 1877 crisis occurs in France, ending with the dissolution of the National Assembly 22 June and affirming the interpretation of the Constitution of 1875 as a parliamentary rather than presidential system. The elections held in October 1877 led to the defeat of the royalists as a formal political movement in France.
source_pages: 16_May_1877_crisis; French_Third_Republic; French_Parliament; French_constitutional_laws_of_1875; Parliament; Presidential_system; Monarchism_in_France; May_16

event_text: American Indian Wars: Battle of White Bird Canyon: The Nez Perce defeat the U.S. Cavalry at White Bird Canyon in the Idaho Territory.
Alexander Graham Bell installs the world's first commercial telephone service in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada.
The inaugural Wimbledon Championships begins.
The then-villa of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico, formally receives its city charter from the Royal Crown of Spain.

After rioting by Baltimore and Ohio Railroad workers and the deaths of nine rail workers at the hands of the Maryland militia, workers in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, stage a sympathy strike that is met with an assault by the state militia.
American Indian Wars: Battle of the Big Hole: A small band of Nez Percé Indians clash with the United States Army.
American astronomer Asaph Hall discovers Phobos, one of Mars's moons.
source_pages: Astronomer; Asaph_Hall; Phobos_(moon); Mars; Moons_of_Mars; August_18

event_text: American Indian Wars: Oglala Sioux chief Crazy Horse is bayoneted by a United States soldier after resisting confinement in a guardhouse at Fort Robinson in Nebraska.
source_pages: American_Indian_Wars; Oglala; Tribal_chief; Crazy_Horse; Bayonet; Fort_Robinson; Nebraska

event_text: The Battle of Shiroyama is a decisive victory of the Imperial Japanese Army over the Satsuma Rebellion.
The Nez Perce War in the northwestern United States comes to an end.
The Blantyre mining disaster in Scotland kills 207 miners.
Thomas Edison announces his invention of the phonograph, a machine that can record and play sound.
Anna Sewell's animal welfare novel Black Beauty is published.
Thomas Edison demonstrates his phonograph for the first time.

Russo-Turkish War: The Russian Army captures Plevna after a 5-month siege. The garrison of 25,000 surviving Turks surrenders. The Russian victory is decisive for the outcome of the war and the Liberation of Bulgaria.
Russo-Turkish War (1877–78): Sofia is liberated from Ottoman rule.
Umberto I becomes King of Italy.
Russo-Turkish War (1877–78): Battle of Philippopolis: Captain Aleksandr Burago with a squadron of Russian Imperial army dragoons liberates Plovdiv from Ottoman rule.
source_pages: Russo-Turkish_War_(1877–1878); Battle_of_Plovdiv_(1878); Aleksandr_Burago; Squadron_(army); Russian_Empire; Dragoon; Liberation_of_Bulgaria; Ottoman_Bulgaria

event_text: Yale Daily News becomes the first independent daily college newspaper in the United States.
John Tunstall is murdered by outlaw Jesse Evans, sparking the Lincoln County War in Lincoln County, New Mexico.
Thomas Edison patents the phonograph.
The first telephone directory is issued in New Haven, Connecticut.
The Russo-Turkish War ends with Bulgaria regaining its independence from the Ottoman Empire according to the Treaty of San Stefano.
Pope Leo XIII reestablishes the Catholic Church in Scotland, recreating sees and naming bishops for the first time since 1603.
The British frigate HMS Eurydice sinks, killing more than 300.
The Senate of the Grand Duchy of Finland issues a declaration establishing a city of Kotka on the southern part islands from the old Kymi parish.

The last witchcraft trial held in the United States begins in Salem, Massachusetts, after Lucretia Brown, an adherent of Christian Science, accused Daniel Spofford of attempting to harm her through his mental powers.
Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera H.M.S. Pinafore opens at the Opera Comique in London.
Cyprus Convention: The Ottoman Empire cedes Cyprus to the United Kingdom but retains nominal title.

League of Prizren is established, to oppose the decisions of the Congress of Berlin and the Treaty of San Stefano, as a consequence of which the Albanian lands in the Balkans were being partitioned and given to the neighbor states of Serbia, Montenegro, Bulgaria, and Greece.
source_pages: League_of_Prizren; Congress_of_Berlin; Treaty_of_San_Stefano; Balkans; Serbia; Montenegro; Bulgaria

event_text: Canada joins the Universal Postal Union.
Treaty of Berlin: The European powers redraw the map of the Balkans. Serbia, Montenegro and Romania become completely independent of the Ottoman Empire.
The American Bar Association is founded in Saratoga Springs, New York.
Emma Nutt becomes the world's first female telephone operator when she is recruited by Alexander Graham Bell to the Boston Telephone Dispatch Company.
Over 640 die when the crowded pleasure boat Princess Alice collides with the Bywell Castle in the River Thames.
The Edison Electric Light Company begins operation.

First assassination attempt against Umberto I of Italy by anarchist Giovanni Passannante, who was armed with a dagger. The King survived with a slight wound in an arm. Prime Minister Benedetto Cairoli blocked the aggressor, receiving an injury in a leg.
President Rutherford B. Hayes gets the first telephone installed in the White House.
The Al-Thani family become the rulers of the state of Qatar.
Karl Benz, working in Mannheim, Germany, files for a patent on his first reliable two-stroke gas engine. He was granted the patent in 1879.
The Anglo-Zulu War begins.
The Battle of Isandlwana during the Anglo-Zulu War results in a Zulu victory.
The Battle of Rorke's Drift, also during the Anglo-Zulu War and just some 15 km (9.3 mi) away from Isandlwana, results in a British victory.
Anglo-Zulu War: The Battle of Rorke's Drift ends.
The Bulgarian National Bank is founded.
Sandford Fleming first proposes the adoption of Universal Standard Time at a meeting of the Royal Canadian Institute.
England's cricket team, led by Lord Harris, is attacked in a riot during a match in Sydney.
The War of the Pacific breaks out when the Chilean Army occupies the Bolivian port city of Antofagasta.
Women's rights: US President Rutherford B. Hayes signs a bill allowing female attorneys to argue cases before the Supreme Court of the United States.
In Utica, New York, Frank Woolworth opens the first of many of five-and-dime Woolworth stores.
Shō Tai formally abdicates his position of King of Ryūkyū, under orders from Tokyo, ending the Ryukyu Kingdom.
War of the Pacific: The Battle of Topáter, the first battle of the war is fought between Chile and the joint forces of Bolivia and Peru.
Anglo-Zulu War: Battle of Kambula: British forces defeat 20,000 Zulus.
Bolivia declares war on Chile, and Chile declares war on Peru, starting the War of the Pacific.
Fire burns down the second main building and dome of the University of Notre Dame, which prompts the construction of the third, and current, Main Building with its golden dome.
The first group of 463 Indian indentured laborers arrives in Fiji aboard the Leonidas.
War of the Pacific: Two Chilean ships blocking the harbor of Iquique (then belonging to Peru) battle two Peruvian vessels in the Battle of Iquique.
Russia and the United Kingdom sign the Treaty of Gandamak establishing an Afghan state.
Gilmore's Garden in New York City is renamed Madison Square Garden by William Henry Vanderbilt and is opened to the public at 26th Street and Madison Avenue.
Napoléon Eugène, the last dynastic Bonaparte, is killed in the Anglo-Zulu War.
Charles Taze Russell publishes the first edition of the religious magazine The Watchtower.
Anglo-Zulu War: The Zululand capital of Ulundi is captured by British troops and burned to the ground, ending the war and forcing King Cetshwayo to flee.
Sailing ship USS Jeannette departs San Francisco carrying an ill-fated expedition to the North Pole.

The locals of Knock, County Mayo, Ireland report their having seen an apparition of the Virgin Mary. The apparition is later named "Our Lady of Knock" and the spot transformed into a Catholic pilgrimage site.
Anglo-Zulu War: Cetshwayo, last king of the Zulus, is captured by the British.

Siege of the British Residency in Kabul: British envoy Sir Louis Cavagnari and 72 men of the Guides are massacred by Afghan troops while defending the British Residency in Kabul. Their heroism and loyalty became famous and revered throughout the British Empire.
The Blackpool Illuminations are switched on for the first time.
The Macedo-Romanian Cultural Society is founded.
Germany and Austria-Hungary sign the "Twofold Covenant" and create the Dual Alliance.
War of the Pacific: The Chilean Navy defeats the Peruvian Navy in the Battle of Angamos.
Thomas Edison applies for a patent for his design for an incandescent light bulb.
Using a filament of carbonized thread, Thomas Edison tests the first practical electric incandescent light bulb (lasting 131⁄2 hours before burning out).

War of the Pacific: Battle of Tarapacá: The confrontation between the Chilean Army and the Peruvian Army takes place in Tarapacá, the Peruvian victory is consummated with the death of the 2 generals and the capture the Chilean general in said place of battle, headed by the Peruvian victory of General Juan Buendía y Noregia.
source_pages: War_of_the_Pacific; Battle_of_Tarapacá; Chilean_Army; Peruvian_Army; Tarapacá; General_officer; Chile; Juan_Buendía; November_27

event_text: World premiere of Henrik Ibsen's A Doll's House at the Royal Theatre in Copenhagen, Denmark.
Tay Bridge disaster: The central part of the Tay Rail Bridge in Dundee, Scotland, United Kingdom collapses as a train passes over it, killing 75.
Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time, in Menlo Park, New Jersey.
Thomas Edison receives a patent for his incandescent lamp.
Thomas Edison observes Thermionic emission.
Seven people are killed in the Mussel Slough Tragedy, a gun battle in California.
War of the Pacific: The Battle of Arica, the assault and capture of Morro de Arica (Arica Cape), ends the Campaña del Desierto (Desert Campaign).
First performance of O Canada at the Congrès national des Canadiens-Français. The song would later become the national anthem of Canada.
Australian bushranger Ned Kelly is captured at Glenrowan.
France annexes Tahiti, renaming the independent Kingdom of Tahiti as "Etablissements de français de l'Océanie".
Second Anglo-Afghan War: Battle of Maiwand: Afghan forces led by Mohammad Ayub Khan defeat the British Army in battle near Maiwand, Afghanistan.
Construction of Cologne Cathedral, the most famous landmark in Cologne, Germany, is completed.
The army of Mohammad Ayub Khan is routed by the British at the Battle of Kandahar, ending the Second Anglo-Afghan War.
The Basuto Gun War breaks out after the Basuto launch a rebellion against the Cape Colony.
The Cornell Daily Sun prints its first issue in Ithaca, New York.
A major earthquake strikes Zagreb and destroys many buildings, including Zagreb Cathedral.
Australian bushranger Ned Kelly is hanged at Melbourne Gaol.
Outbreak of the First Boer War between the Boer South African Republic and the British Empire.
Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell form the Oriental Telephone Company.
The Canadian Pacific Railway is incorporated by Act of Parliament at Ottawa (44th Vic., c.1).
Cleopatra's Needle, a 3,500-year-old Ancient Egyptian obelisk is erected in Central Park, New York.
China and Russia sign the Sino-Russian Ili Treaty.
First Boer War: The Battle of Majuba Hill takes place.
