Spelman College is founded in Atlanta, Georgia as the Atlanta Baptist Female Seminary, an institute of higher education for African-American women.
The Four Dead in Five Seconds Gunfight occurs in El Paso, Texas.
In Dodge City, Kansas, Bat Masterson fights his last gun battle.
Billy the Kid escapes from the Lincoln County jail in Mesilla, New Mexico.
Carol I is crowned the King of the Romanian Kingdom.
In North Africa, Tunisia becomes a French protectorate.
The American Red Cross is established by Clara Barton in Dansville, New York.
The USS Jeannette is crushed in an Arctic Ocean ice pack.
The Austro–Serbian Alliance of 1881 is secretly signed.
In Sudan, Muhammad Ahmad declares himself to be the Mahdi, the messianic redeemer of Islam.
The world's first international telephone call is made between St. Stephen, New Brunswick, Canada, and Calais, Maine, United States.
General Order 70, the culmination of the Cardwell and Childers reforms of the British Army, comes into effect.
Charles J. Guiteau shoots and fatally wounds U.S. President James A. Garfield (who will die of complications from his wounds on September 19).
In Alabama, the Tuskegee Institute opens.
American outlaw Billy the Kid is shot and killed by Sheriff Pat Garrett in the Maxwell House at Fort Sumner, New Mexico.
The Boundary Treaty of 1881 between Chile and Argentina is signed in Buenos Aires.
The Georgia hurricane makes landfall near Savannah, Georgia, resulting in an estimated 700 deaths.
In the Swiss state of Glarus, a rockslide buries parts of the village of Elm, destroying 83 buildings and killing 115 people.
U.S. President Chester A. Arthur is sworn in upon the death of James A. Garfield the previous day.
First known conversation in modern Hebrew by Eliezer Ben-Yehuda and friends.
Wyatt Earp and Doc Holliday participate in the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral in Tombstone, Arizona.
The Mapuche uprising of 1881 begins in Chile.

In New Zealand, 1600 armed volunteers and constabulary field forces led by Minister of Native Affairs John Bryce march on the pacifist Māori settlement at Parihaka, evicting upwards of 2000 residents, and destroying the settlement in the context of the New Zealand land confiscations.
source_pages: New_Zealand; John_Bryce; Māori_people; Parihaka; New_Zealand_land_confiscations; November_5

event_text: Mapuche uprising of 1881: Mapuche rebels destroy the Chilean settlement of Nueva Imperial after defenders fled to the hills.
Mapuche rebels attack the fortified Chilean settlement of Temuco.
A meteorite lands near the village of Grossliebenthal, southwest of Odesa, Ukraine.
The first issue of Tamperean daily newspaper Aamulehti ("Morning Paper") is published.
The first edition of the Los Angeles Times is published.
Queen Victoria narrowly escapes an assassination attempt by Roderick Maclean in Windsor.
Britain's first electric trams run in east London.
The Serbian kingdom is re-founded.
Robert Koch announces the discovery of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis.
The Knights of Columbus is established.
American Old West: Robert Ford kills Jesse James.
French and Vietnamese troops clashed in Tonkin, when Commandant Henri Rivière seized the citadel of Hanoi with a small force of marine infantry.
source_pages: French_Third_Republic; Nguyễn_dynasty; Tonkin; Henri_Rivière_(naval_officer); Battle_of_Hanoi_(1882); Imperial_Citadel_of_Thăng_Long

event_text: Thomas Henry Burke and Lord Frederick Cavendish are stabbed to death by Fenian assassins in Phoenix Park, Dublin.
The United States Congress passes the Chinese Exclusion Act.
The Triple Alliance between the German Empire, Austria-Hungary and the Kingdom of Italy is formed.

The Shewan forces of Menelik II of Ethiopia defeat the Gojjame army in the Battle of Embabo. The Shewans capture Negus Tekle Haymanot of Gojjam, and their victory leads to a Shewan hegemony over the territories south of the Abay River.
source_pages: Shewa; Menelik_II; Gojjam; Battle_of_Embabo; Blue_Nile; June_6

event_text: The Anglo-French Convention of 1882 marks the territorial boundaries between Guinea and Sierra Leone.
Charles J. Guiteau is hanged in Washington, D.C. for the assassination of U.S. President James Garfield.
War of the Pacific: Chile suffers its last military defeat in the Battle of La Concepción when a garrison of 77 men is annihilated by a 1,300-strong Peruvian force, many of them armed with spears.
The British Mediterranean Fleet begins the Bombardment of Alexandria in Egypt as part of the Anglo-Egyptian War.
Premiere of Richard Wagner's opera Parsifal at Bayreuth.
The Republic of Stellaland is founded in Southern Africa.

Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, today known as ExxonMobil, is established officially. The company would later grow to become the holder of all Standard Oil companies and the entity at the center of the breakup of Standard Oil.
Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture debuts in Moscow, Russia.
The Pearl Street Station in New York City becomes the first power plant to supply electricity to paying customers.
The first United States Labor Day parade is held in New York City.
Anglo-Egyptian War: The Battle of Tel el-Kebir is fought.
The Pacific Stock Exchange opens.
Thomas Edison's first commercial hydroelectric power plant (later known as Appleton Edison Light Company) begins operation.
The Nickel Plate Railroad opens for business.
The great fire destroys a large part of Oulu's city center in Oulu Province, Finland.
Transit of Venus, second and last of the 19th century.
Wales and England contest the first Home Nations (now Six Nations) rugby union match.
The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, establishing the United States Civil Service, is enacted by Congress.
The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires, built by Thomas Edison, begins service at Roselle, New Jersey.
Alabama becomes the first U.S. state to enact an anti-trust law.
The Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property is signed.
Buffalo Bill's first Buffalo Bill's Wild West opens in Omaha, Nebraska.
Krakatoa begins to erupt; the volcano explodes three months later, killing more than 36,000 people.
The Brooklyn Bridge in New York City is opened to traffic after 14 years of construction.
Alexander III is crowned Tsar of Russia.
In New York City, 12 people are killed in a stampede on the recently opened Brooklyn Bridge.
The first regularly scheduled Orient Express departs Paris.
The Victoria Hall theatre panic in Sunderland, England, kills 183 children.
War of the Pacific: Chileans led by Alejandro Gorostiaga defeat Andrés Avelino Cáceres's Peruvian army at the Battle of Huamachuco, hastening the end of the war.
A moderate earthquake measuring magnitude 4.3–5.2 strikes the Italian island of Ischia, killing over 2,300 people.
The last quagga dies at the Natura Artis Magistra, a zoo in Amsterdam, Netherlands.
The first public performance of the Dominican Republic's national anthem, Himno Nacional.
An F5 tornado strikes Rochester, Minnesota, leading to the creation of the Mayo Clinic.
France and Viet Nam sign the Treaty of Huế, recognizing a French protectorate over Annam and Tonkin.
The 1883 eruption of Krakatoa begins its final, paroxysmal, stage.
Eruption of Krakatoa: Four enormous explosions almost completely destroy the island of Krakatoa and cause years of climate change.

The Northern Pacific Railway (reporting mark NP) was completed in a ceremony at Gold Creek, Montana. Former president Ulysses S. Grant drove in the final "golden spike" in an event attended by rail and political luminaries.
First run of the Orient Express.
First meeting of the Boys' Brigade in Glasgow, Scotland.
Peru and Chile sign the Treaty of Ancón, by which the Tarapacá province is ceded to the latter, bringing an end to Peru's involvement in the War of the Pacific.
The Metropolitan Opera House in New York City opens with a performance of Gounod's Faust.
In the "day of two noons," American and Canadian railroad companies institute four standard continental time zones, ending the confusion of thousands of local times.
Tonkin Campaign: French forces capture the Sơn Tây citadel.
The Royal Canadian Dragoons and The Royal Canadian Regiment, the first Permanent Force cavalry and infantry regiments of the Canadian Army, are formed.
The Fabian Society is founded in London, United Kingdom.
The first volume (A to Ant) of the Oxford English Dictionary is published.
More than sixty tornadoes strike the Southern United States, one of the largest tornado outbreaks in U.S. history.
The Siege of Khartoum begins. It lasts until January 26, 1885.

A mob in Cincinnati, Ohio, United States attacks members of a jury which had returned a verdict of manslaughter in what was seen as a clear case of murder; over the next few days the mob would riot and burn down the courthouse.
Pope Leo XIII publishes the encyclical Humanum genus, condemning Freemasonry.
The arrival at Plymouth of Tāwhiao, King of Maoris, to claim the protection of Queen Victoria.
The first purpose-built roller coaster, LaMarcus Adna Thompson's "Switchback Railway", opens in New York's Coney Island amusement park.
Dow Jones & Company publishes its first stock average.
Germany takes possession of Cameroon.
The cornerstone for the Statue of Liberty is laid on Bedloe's Island (now Liberty Island) in New York Harbor.
On the night of 23–24 September, the steamship Arctique runs aground near Cape Virgenes leading to the discovery of nearby placer gold, beginning the Tierra del Fuego gold rush.
The Naval War College of the United States is founded in Rhode Island.
George Eastman receives a U.S. Government patent on his new paper-strip photographic film.
The International Meridian Conference designates the Royal Observatory, Greenwich as the world's prime meridian.

The Berlin Conference of 1884–1885 met on 15 November 1884, and after an adjournment concluded on 26 February 1885, with the signature of a General Act, regulating the European colonisation and trade in Africa during the New Imperialism period.
The Washington Monument in Washington, D.C., is completed.
Twenty-five nations adopt Sandford Fleming's proposal for standard time (and also, time zones).
Sino-French War: Beginning of the Battle of Núi Bop.
Sino-French War: French troops under General Oscar de Négrier defeat a numerically superior Qing force at Núi Bop in northern Vietnam.
A British force defeats a large Dervish army at the Battle of Abu Klea in the Sudan.
Troops loyal to The Mahdi conquer Khartoum, killing the Governor-General Charles George Gordon.
King Leopold II of Belgium establishes the Congo as a personal possession.
The first Japanese immigrants arrive in Hawaii.
Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain is published in the United States.
The newly completed Washington Monument is dedicated.
Sino-French War: French Army gains an important victory in the Battle of Đồng Đăng in the Tonkin region of Vietnam.
The Mikado, a light opera by W. S. Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan, receives its first public performance at the Savoy Theatre in London.
Louis Riel declares a provisional government in Saskatchewan, beginning the North-West Rebellion.
Sino-French War: Chinese victory in the Battle of Phu Lam Tao near Hưng Hóa, northern Vietnam.
The Métis people of the District of Saskatchewan under Louis Riel begin the North-West Rebellion against Canada.
The Battle for Kushka triggers the Panjdeh Incident which nearly gives rise to war between the Russian and British Empires.
The United Kingdom establishes the Bechuanaland Protectorate.
Canadian Cree warriors attack the village of Frog Lake, killing nine.
Gottlieb Daimler is granted a German patent for a light, high-speed, four-stroke engine, which he uses seven months later to create the world's first motorcycle, the Daimler Reitwagen.
American sharpshooter Annie Oakley is hired by Nate Salsbury to be a part of Buffalo Bill's Wild West.

Governor of New York David B. Hill signs legislation creating the Niagara Reservation, New York's first state park, ensuring that Niagara Falls will not be devoted solely to industrial and commercial use.
The original Chicago Board of Trade Building opens for business.
Cree and Assiniboine warriors win the Battle of Cut Knife, their largest victory over Canadian forces during the North-West Rebellion.
North-West Rebellion: The four-day Battle of Batoche, pitting rebel Métis against the Canadian government, comes to an end with a decisive rebel defeat.
In the last military engagement fought on Canadian soil, the Cree leader, Big Bear, escapes the North-West Mounted Police.
Treaty of Tientsin is signed to end the Sino-French War, with China eventually giving up Tonkin and Annam – most of present-day Vietnam – to France.
source_pages: Treaty_of_Tianjin_(1885); Sino-French_War; Qing_dynasty; Tonkin; Annan_(Tang_protectorate); Vietnam

event_text: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York Harbor.
The United States terminates reciprocity and fishery agreement with Canada.
The Congo Free State is established by King Leopold II of Belgium.
Louis Pasteur successfully tests his vaccine against rabies on Joseph Meister, a boy who was bitten by a rabid dog.
The Football Association legalizes professionalism in association football under pressure from the British Football Association.
Japan's first patent is issued to the inventor of a rust-proof paint.
Gottlieb Daimler patents the world's first motorcycle with an internal combustion engine, the Reitwagen.

Rock Springs massacre: In Rock Springs, Wyoming, 150 white miners, who are struggling to unionize so they could strike for better wages and work conditions, attack their Chinese fellow workers killing 28, wounding 15 and forcing several hundred more out of town.
Eastern Rumelia declares its union with Bulgaria, thus accomplishing Bulgarian unification.
Arbroath 36–0 Bon Accord, a world record scoreline in professional Association football.
Lord Randolph Churchill makes a speech in Ulster in opposition to the Irish Home Rule movement.
The first practical public electric tramway in the world is opened in Blackpool, England.
The Georgia Institute of Technology is founded in Atlanta, Georgia.
The completion of Canada's first transcontinental railway is symbolized by the Last Spike ceremony at Craigellachie, British Columbia.
Canadian rebel leader of the Métis and "Father of Manitoba" Louis Riel is executed for treason.
Serbo-Bulgarian War: The decisive Battle of Slivnitsa begins.
Serbo-Bulgarian War: Bulgarian victory in the Battle of Slivnitsa solidifies the unification between the Principality of Bulgaria and Eastern Rumelia.
Bulgarian victory in the Serbo-Bulgarian War preserves the Unification of Bulgaria.
Itō Hirobumi, a samurai, becomes the first Prime Minister of Japan.
Indian National Congress, a political party of India, is founded in Bombay Presidency, British India.
Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.
Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile.

Charles Martin Hall produced the first samples of aluminium from the electrolysis of aluminium oxide, after several years of intensive work. He was assisted in this project by his older sister, Julia Brainerd Hall.
Geronimo, Apache warrior, surrenders to the U.S. Army, ending the main phase of the Apache Wars.
William Ewart Gladstone introduces the first Irish Home Rule Bill into the British House of Commons.

Rallies are held throughout the United States demanding the eight-hour work day, culminating in the Haymarket affair in Chicago, in commemoration of which May 1 is celebrated as International Workers' Day in many countries.

Haymarket affair: In Chicago, United States, a homemade bomb is thrown at police officers trying to break up a labor rally, killing one officer. Ensuing gunfire leads to the deaths of a further seven officers and four civilians.
Workers marching for the Eight-hour day in Milwaukee, Wisconsin were shot at by Wisconsin National Guardsmen in what became known as the Bay View Massacre.
source_pages: Eight-hour_day_movement; Milwaukee; Wisconsin; Wisconsin_National_Guard; Bay_View_massacre; May_5

event_text: Pharmacist John Pemberton first sells a carbonated beverage named "Coca-Cola" as a patent medicine.
The pharmacist John Pemberton places his first advertisement for Coca-Cola, which appeared in The Atlanta Journal.

Mount Tarawera in New Zealand erupts, killing 153 people and burying the famous Pink and White Terraces. Eruptions continue for three months creating a large, 17 km (11 mi) long fissure across the mountain peak.
A fire devastates much of Vancouver, British Columbia.
Henri Moissan isolated elemental Fluorine for the first time.
The first transcontinental train trip across Canada departs from Montreal, Quebec. It arrives in Port Moody, British Columbia on July 4.
Karl Benz officially unveils the Benz Patent-Motorwagen, the first purpose-built automobile.
The New-York Tribune becomes the first newspaper to use a linotype machine, eliminating typesetting by hand.
The Canadian Pacific Railway's first scheduled train from Montreal arrives in Port Moody on the Pacific coast, after six days of travel.
The 7.0 Mw  Charleston earthquake affects southeastern South Carolina with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). Sixty people killed with damage estimated at $5–6 million.
American Indian Wars: After almost 30 years of fighting, Apache leader Geronimo, with his remaining warriors,  surrenders to General Nelson Miles in Arizona.

Normanton incident: As the British merchant vessel Normanton sinks off the coast of Japan, her European officers appear to commandeer the ship’s lifeboats for themselves, leaving her Asian crew and passengers to die and conjuring significant political outrage in Japan.
US president Grover Cleveland dedicates the Statue of Liberty.
The United States Senate allows the Navy to lease Pearl Harbor as a naval base.
The Dawes Act is enacted, authorizing the U.S. President to divide Native American tribal land into individual allotments.
The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000.
Argonia, Kansas elects Susanna M. Salter as the first female mayor in the United States.
On Easter Sunday, Pope Leo XIII authorizes the establishment of the Catholic University of America.
A week after being arrested by the Prussian Secret Police, French police inspector Guillaume Schnaebelé is released on order of William I, German Emperor, defusing a possible war.
The Peruvian Academy of Language is founded.
Herman Hollerith applies for US patent #395,781 for the 'Art of Compiling Statistics', which was his punched card calculator.
The Reinsurance Treaty between Germany and Russia is signed.
The Rocky Mountains Park Act becomes law in Canada creating the nation's first national park, Banff National Park.
The founder of Pakistan, Quaid-i-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah, joins Sindh-Madrasa-tul-Islam, Karachi.
David Kalākaua, monarch of the Kingdom of Hawaii, is forced to sign the Bayonet Constitution, which transfers much of the king's authority to the Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii.
Publication of the Unua Libro, founding the Esperanto movement.
Granny, a sea anemone, died in Edinburgh after nearly 60 years in captivity. Her death was reported in The Scotsman and The New York Times.
source_pages: Granny_(sea_anemone); Sea_anemone; Edinburgh; The_Scotsman; The_New_York_Times; August_4

event_text: A fire at the Theatre Royal, Exeter kills 186, making it the UK's deadliest ever building fire.
Balochistan is conquered by the British Empire.
The United States receives rights to Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.
Four convicted anarchists were executed as a result of the Haymarket affair.
Bloody Sunday clashes in central London.
The National Geographic Society is founded in Washington, D.C.
The Great Blizzard of 1888 begins along the eastern seaboard of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than 400 people.
The eruption of Ritter Island triggers tsunamis that kill up to 3,000 people on nearby islands.
Start of the Anglo-Tibetan War of 1888.
The premiere of the very first Romani language operetta is staged in Moscow, Russia.
In England, The Football League, the world's oldest professional association football league, meets for the first time.
Jack the Ripper: The first of 11 unsolved brutal murders of women committed in or near the impoverished Whitechapel district in the East End of London, occurs.
With the passage of the Lei Áurea ("Golden Law"), the Empire of Brazil abolishes slavery.
Nikola Tesla delivers a lecture describing the equipment which will allow efficient generation and use of alternating currents to transmit electric power over long distances.
The Rio de la Plata earthquake takes place.
The White Rajahs territories become the British protectorate of Sarawak.
George Edward Gouraud records Handel's Israel in Egypt onto a phonograph cylinder, thought for many years to be the oldest known recording of music.
The stratovolcano Mount Bandai erupts, killing approximately 500 people in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan.
Bertha Benz drives from Mannheim to Pforzheim and back in the first long distance automobile trip, commemorated as the Bertha Benz Memorial Route since 2008.
The first successful adding machine in the United States is patented by William Seward Burroughs.
Mary Ann Nichols is murdered. She is the first of Jack the Ripper's confirmed victims.
George Eastman registers the trademark Kodak and receives a patent for his camera that uses roll film.
Isaac Peral's submarine is first tested.
The Great Herding (Spanish: El Gran Arreo) begins with thousands of sheep being herded from the Argentine outpost of Fortín Conesa to Santa Cruz near the Strait of Magellan.
source_pages: Patagonian_sheep_farming_boom; Spanish_language; General_Conesa,_Río_Negro; Santa_Cruz_Province,_Argentina; Strait_of_Magellan; September_8

event_text: In London, the body of Jack the Ripper's second murder victim, Annie Chapman, is found.
In England, the first six Football League matches are played.
Jack the Ripper kills his third and fourth victims, Elizabeth Stride and Catherine Eddowes.
Louis Le Prince films the first motion picture, Roundhay Garden Scene.
The "From Hell" letter allegedly sent by Jack the Ripper is received by investigators.
The Swiss Social Democratic Party is founded.
The Convention of Constantinople is signed, guaranteeing free maritime passage through the Suez Canal during war and peace.
The Rudd Concession is granted by Matabeleland to agents of Cecil Rhodes.
Jack the Ripper murders Mary Jane Kelly, his final victim in the Whitechapel murders.
The Christmas Meeting of 1888, considered to be the official start of the Faroese independence movement.
Herman Hollerith is issued US patent #395,791 for the 'Art of Applying Statistics' — his punched card calculator.
The Coca-Cola Company, then known as the Pemberton Medicine Company, is incorporated in Atlanta.
Archduke Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria, heir to the Austro-Hungarian crown, is found dead with his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera in the Mayerling.
source_pages: Archduke; Rudolf,_Crown_Prince_of_Austria; Austria-Hungary; Baroness_Mary_Vetsera; Mayerling_incident; January_30

event_text: US president Grover Cleveland signs a bill elevating the United States Department of Agriculture to a Cabinet-level agency.
The Meiji Constitution of Japan is adopted.
Antonín Dvořák's Jakobín is premiered at National Theater in Prague
President Grover Cleveland signs a bill admitting North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington as U.S. states.
source_pages: President_of_the_United_States; Grover_Cleveland; Enabling_Act_of_1889; North_Dakota; South_Dakota; Montana; Washington_(state); U.S._state; February_22

event_text: The Ahmadiyya Muslim Community is established by Mirza Ghulam Ahmad in Qadian, British India.
The Eiffel Tower is officially opened.
At noon, thousands rush to claim land in the Land Rush of 1889. Within hours the cities of Oklahoma City and Guthrie are formed with populations of at least 10,000.
Menelik II, Emperor of Ethiopia, signs the Treaty of Wuchale, giving Italy control over Eritrea.
The Eiffel Tower is officially opened to the public at the Universal Exposition in Paris.
An attack upon a U.S. Army paymaster and escort results in the theft of over $28,000 and the award of two Medals of Honor.
Johnstown Flood: Over 2,200 people die after a dam fails and sends a 60-foot (18-meter) wall of water over the town of Johnstown, Pennsylvania.
The first long-distance electric power transmission line in the United States is completed, running 14 miles (23 km) between a generator at Willamette Falls and downtown Portland, Oregon.
The Great Seattle Fire destroys all of downtown Seattle.
Bangui is founded by Albert Dolisie and Alfred Uzac in what was then the upper reaches of the French Congo.
Hyde Park and several other Illinois townships vote to be annexed by Chicago, forming the largest United States city in area and second largest in population at the time.
The first issue of The Wall Street Journal is published.
Tijuana, Mexico, is founded.
The Great Fire of Spokane, Washington destroys some 32 blocks of the city, prompting a mass rebuilding project.
William Gray of Hartford, Connecticut is granted United States Patent Number 408,709 for "Coin-controlled apparatus for telephones."
The General Conference on Weights and Measures (CGPM) defines the length of a metre.
Henry Parkes delivers the Tenterfield Oration, effectively starting the federation process in Australia.
North Dakota and South Dakota are admitted as the 39th and 40th U.S. states.
Montana is admitted as the 41st U.S. state.
The State of Washington is admitted as the 42nd state of the United States.
Pioneering female journalist Nellie Bly (aka Elizabeth Cochrane) begins a successful attempt to travel around the world in less than 80 days. She completes the trip in 72 days.
Brazil is declared a republic by Marshal Deodoro da Fonseca as Emperor Pedro II is deposed in a military coup.
source_pages: Brazil; Marshal_(Brazil); Deodoro_da_Fonseca; List_of_monarchs_of_Brazil; Pedro_II_of_Brazil; Decline_and_fall_of_Pedro_II_of_Brazil

event_text: Elisha P. Ferry is inaugurated as first governor of Washington.
Eritrea is consolidated into a colony by the Italian government.
The United Mine Workers of America is founded in Columbus, Ohio.
Nellie Bly completes her round-the-world journey in 72 days.
The longest bridge in Great Britain, the Forth Bridge in Scotland, measuring 8,094 feet (2,467 m) long, is opened by the Duke of Rothesay, later King Edward VII.
Chancellor of the German Empire Otto von Bismarck is dismissed by Emperor Wilhelm II.
The Pan-American Union is founded by the First International Conference of American States in Washington, D.C.
The United States Census Bureau begins using Herman Hollerith's tabulating machine to count census returns.
Canada and Bermuda are linked by telegraph cable.
The U.S. Congress passes the Sherman Antitrust Act.
Idaho is admitted as the 43rd U.S. state.
Wyoming is admitted as the 44th U.S. state.
In Buenos Aires, Argentina the Revolución del Parque takes place, forcing President Miguel Ángel Juárez Celman's resignation.
Vincent van Gogh shoots himself and dies two days later.
At Auburn Prison in New York, murderer William Kemmler becomes the first person to be executed by electric chair.
Anna Månsdotter, found guilty of the 1889 Yngsjö murder, became the last woman to be executed in Sweden.[better source needed]
Salisbury, Rhodesia, is founded.
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints officially renounces polygamy.
The United States Congress establishes Sequoia National Park.
Yosemite National Park is established by the U.S. Congress.
In Washington, D.C., the Daughters of the American Revolution is founded.
Uddevalla Suffrage Association is formed.
Malleco Viaduct in Chile, at the time "the highest railroad bridge in the world", is inaugurated by President José Manuel Balmaceda.
City and South London Railway: London's first deep-level tube railway opens between King William Street and Stockwell.
King William III of the Netherlands dies without a male heir and a special law is passed to allow his daughter Princess Wilhelmina to succeed him.
The Meiji Constitution goes into effect in Japan, and the first Diet convenes.
Hunkpapa Lakota leader Sitting Bull is killed on Standing Rock Indian Reservation, leading to the Wounded Knee Massacre.
Cornwallis Valley Railway begins operation between Kentville and Kingsport, Nova Scotia.
Wounded Knee Massacre: On Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, 300 Lakota are killed by the United States 7th Cavalry Regiment.
Following the Wounded Knee Massacre, the United States Army and Lakota warriors face off in the Drexel Mission Fight.
Liliʻuokalani is proclaimed the last monarch and only queen regnant of the Kingdom of Hawaii.
History of Portugal: The first attempt at a Portuguese republican revolution breaks out in the northern city of Porto.
Shoshone National Forest is established as the first national forest in the US and world.
Almon Strowger patents the Strowger switch, a device which led to the automation of telephone circuit switching.
SS Utopia collides with HMS Anson in the Bay of Gibraltar and sinks, killing 562 of the 880 passengers on board.
Chilean Civil War: The ironclad Blanco Encalada is sunk at Caldera Bay by torpedo boats.
source_pages: Chilean_Civil_War_of_1891; Chilean_ironclad_Blanco_Encalada; Battle_of_Caldera_Bay; Caldera,_Chile; Torpedo_boat; April_23

event_text: The Music Hall in New York City (later known as Carnegie Hall) has its grand opening and first public performance, with Tchaikovsky as the guest conductor.
Pope Leo XIII defends workers' rights and property rights in the encyclical Rerum novarum, the beginning of modern Catholic social teaching.

The International Electrotechnical Exhibition opened in Frankfurt, Germany, featuring the world's first long-distance transmission of high-power, three-phase electric current (the most common form today).
History of cinema: The first public display of Thomas Edison's prototype kinetoscope.
France annexes Tahiti.
The Basilica of San Sebastian, Manila, the first all-steel church in Asia, is officially inaugurated and blessed.
A major hurricane strikes Martinique, leaving 700 dead.
The first hydropower plant of Finland is commissioned along the Tammerkoski rapids in Tampere, Pirkanmaa.
source_pages: Hydroelectricity; Finland; Tammerkoski; Tampere; Pirkanmaa; September_22

event_text: Stanford University opens its doors in California, United States.
A diplomatic incident between the United States and Chile occurred after U.S. sailors were attacked in Valparaíso, nearly leading to war.
The Mino–Owari earthquake, the largest inland earthquake in Japan's history, occurs.

James Naismith, a Canadian-American gym teacher at Springfield College, publishes the first rules for the game now known as basketball and brings it to his class, which then plays the first game of basketball.
Asteroid 323 Brucia becomes the first asteroid discovered using photography.
Ellis Island begins processing immigrants into the United States.
James Naismith publishes the rules of basketball.
The Saint-Germain bombing ushers France into the Ère des attentats (1892-1894).
The Lobau bombing is one of the first attacks of the Ère des attentats (1892-1894).
The General Electric Company is formed.
Véry bombing during the Ère des attentats (1892–1894)
In San Francisco, John Muir organizes the Sierra Club.
Liverpool F.C. is founded by John Houlding.
The Chicago "L" elevated rail system begins operation.
Homer Plessy is arrested for refusing to leave his seat in the "whites-only" car of a train; he lost the resulting court case, Plessy v. Ferguson.
The Limelight Department, one of the world's first film studios, is officially established in Melbourne, Australia.
The Homestead Strike begins near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
Western Samoa changes the International Date Line, causing Monday (July 4) to occur twice, resulting in a leap year with 367 days.
Three thousand eight hundred striking steelworkers engage in a day-long battle with Pinkerton agents during the Homestead Strike, leaving ten dead and dozens wounded.
The Katipunan is established, the discovery of which by Spanish authorities initiated the Philippine Revolution.
St. John's, Newfoundland is devastated in the Great Fire of 1892.
Dadabhai Naoroji is elected as the first Indian Member of Parliament in Britain.
The father and stepmother of Lizzie Borden are found murdered in their Fall River, Massachusetts home. She will be tried and acquitted for the crimes a year later.
Thomas Edison receives a patent for a two-way telegraph.
The Pledge of Allegiance is first recited.
Amalthea becomes the last moon to be discovered without the use of photography.
A locomotive shunting falls into a hole in the ground, leading to the burial of the locomotive.
The first night game for American football takes place in a contest between Wyoming Seminary and Mansfield State Normal.
The Pledge of Allegiance is first recited by students in many US public schools.
Edward Emerson Barnard is first to discover a comet by photographic means.
Opening ceremonies for the World's Columbian Exposition are held in Chicago, though because construction was behind schedule, the exposition did not open until May 1, 1893.
Ida B. Wells publishes Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases.
The New Orleans general strike begins, uniting black and white American trade unionists in a successful four-day general strike action for the first time.
The Carmaux-Bons Enfants bombing marks the start of Émile Henry's attacks into the Ère des attentats (1892-1894).
Pudge Heffelfinger becomes the first professional American football player on record, participating in his first paid game for the Allegheny Athletic Association.
First issue of Vogue is published.
Premiere performance of The Nutcracker by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky in Saint Petersburg, Russia.
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom holds its first meeting.
U.S. Marines land in Honolulu, Hawaii from the USS Boston to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
Lorrin A. Thurston, along with the Citizens' Committee of Public Safety, led the Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii and the government of Queen Liliʻuokalani.
The Tati Concessions Land, formerly part of Matabeleland, is formally annexed to the Bechuanaland Protectorate, now Botswana.
Thomas A. Edison finishes construction of the first motion picture studio, the Black Maria in West Orange, New Jersey.
Verdi's last opera, Falstaff premieres at La Scala, Milan.
Electrical engineer Nikola Tesla gives the first public demonstration of radio in St. Louis, Missouri.
The trial of Lizzie Borden for the murder of her father and step-mother begins in New Bedford, Massachusetts.

Grover Cleveland notices a rough spot in his mouth and on July 1 undergoes secret, successful surgery to remove a large, cancerous portion of his jaw; the operation was not revealed to the public until 1917, nine years after the president's death.
Lizzie Borden is acquitted of the murders of her father and stepmother.

The Royal Navy battleship HMS Camperdown accidentally rams the British Mediterranean Fleet flagship HMS Victoria which sinks taking 358 crew with her, including the fleet's commander, Vice-Admiral Sir George Tryon.
source_pages: Royal_Navy; Battleship; HMS_Camperdown_(1885); Mediterranean_Fleet; Flagship; HMS_Victoria_(1887); George_Tryon

event_text: Daniel Hale Williams, American heart surgeon, performs the first successful open-heart surgery in United States without anesthesia.
The first cultured pearl is obtained by Kōkichi Mikimoto.
A revolution led by the liberal general and politician José Santos Zelaya takes over state power in Nicaragua.
Katharine Lee Bates writes "America the Beautiful" after admiring the view from the top of Pikes Peak near Colorado Springs, Colorado.
Henry Perky patents shredded wheat.
France becomes the first country to introduce motor vehicle registration.
Ibadan area becomes a British Protectorate after a treaty signed by Fijabi, the Baale of Ibadan with the British acting Governor of Lagos, George C. Denton.
The Sea Islands hurricane strikes the United States near Savannah, Georgia, killing between 1,000 and 2,000 people.
Settlers make a land run for prime land in the Cherokee Strip in Oklahoma.
In New Zealand, the Electoral Act of 1893 is consented to by the governor, giving all women in New Zealand the right to vote.
Charles Duryea and his brother road-test the first American-made gasoline-powered automobile.
Pyotr Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 in B Minor, Pathétique receives its première performance only nine days before the composer's death.
The Battle of Bembezi took place and was the most decisive battle won by the British in the First Matabele War of 1893.
Women's suffrage: Women in the U.S. state of Colorado are granted the right to vote, the second state to do so.
An anarchist throws two bombs in Barcelona's Liceu opera house, killing 20.
Abdur Rahman Khan accepts the Durand Line as the border between the Emirate of Afghanistan and the British Raj.
13 November stabbing by Léon Léauthier during the Ère des attentats (1892-1894). Influential event for the birth of modern terrorism.
Women's suffrage in New Zealand concludes with the 1893 New Zealand general election.
First Matabele War: A patrol of 34 British South Africa Company soldiers is ambushed and annihilated by more than 3,000 Matabele warriors on the Shangani River in Matabeleland.
source_pages: First_Matabele_War; British_South_Africa_Company; Shangani_Patrol; Northern_Ndebele_people; Shangani_River; Matabeleland

event_text: National Assembly bombing by Auguste Vaillant during the Ère des attentats (1892–1894).

Symphony No. 9 ("From the New World" a.k.a. the "New World Symphony") by Antonín Dvořák premieres in a public afternoon rehearsal at Carnegie Hall in New York City, followed by a concert premiere on the evening of December 16.
The opera Hansel and Gretel by Engelbert Humperdinck is first performed.
Thomas Edison makes a kinetoscopic film of someone sneezing. On the same day, his employee, William Kennedy Dickson, receives a patent for motion picture film.
The Cripple Creek miner's strike, led by the Western Federation of Miners, begins in Cripple Creek, Colorado, United States.
Café Terminus bombing by Émile Henry during the Ère des attentats (1892-1894). Influential event for the birth of modern terrorism.
20 February bombings by Désiré Pauwels during the Ère des attentats (1892-1894).
Madeleine bombing by Désiré Pauwels during the Ère des attentats.
The Stanley Cup ice hockey competition is held for the first time, in Montreal, Canada.
Coxey's Army, the first significant American protest march, departs Massillon, Ohio for Washington, D.C.
Foyot bombing by the Russian or French state during the Ère des attentats (1892-1894).
The first ever commercial motion picture house opens in New York City, United States. It uses ten Kinetoscopes, devices for peep-show viewing of films.
Norway formally adopts the Krag–Jørgensen bolt-action rifle as the main arm of its armed forces, a weapon that would remain in service for almost 50 years.
Coxey's Army, the first significant American protest march, arrives in Washington, D.C.
Four thousand Pullman Palace Car Company workers go on a wildcat strike.
The Manchester Ship Canal in the United Kingdom is officially opened by Queen Victoria, who later knights its designer Sir Edward Leader Williams.
Governor Davis H. Waite orders the Colorado state militia to protect and support the miners engaged in the Cripple Creek miners' strike.
source_pages: Governor_of_Colorado; Davis_Hanson_Waite; Colorado; National_Guard_(United_States); Cripple_Creek_miners'_strike_of_1894; June_6

event_text: The International Olympic Committee is founded at the Sorbonne in Paris, at the initiative of Baron Pierre de Coubertin.
Assassination of the French President, Sadi Carnot by Sante Caserio during the Ère des attentats (1892-1894).
Labor Day becomes an official US holiday.
The short-lived Republic of Hawaii is proclaimed by Sanford B. Dole.

The first ever motor race is held in France between the cities of Paris and Rouen. The fastest finisher was the Comte Jules-Albert de Dion, but the "official" victory was awarded to Albert Lemaître driving his three-horsepower petrol engined Peugeot.
The First Sino-Japanese War begins when the Japanese fire upon a Chinese warship.
The Empire of Japan and Qing China declare war on each other after a week of fighting over Korea, formally inaugurating the First Sino-Japanese War.
Mahatma Gandhi forms the Natal Indian Congress (NIC) in order to fight discrimination against Indian traders in Natal.
Kitasato Shibasaburō discovers the infectious agent of the bubonic plague and publishes his findings in The Lancet.
Over 400 people die in the Great Hinckley Fire, a forest fire in Hinckley, Minnesota.
First Sino-Japanese War: Japan defeats the Qing dynasty in the Battle of Pyongyang, causing the Qing army to withdraw to the Chinese border with Korea.
Battle of the Yalu River, the largest naval engagement of the First Sino-Japanese War.

First Sino-Japanese War: Battle of Jiuliancheng: Under the command of General Yamagata Aritomo, the Imperial Japanese Army covertly crosses the Yalu River into Qing territory and launches an assault on the fortifications at Hushan.
source_pages: First_Sino-Japanese_War; Battle_of_Jiuliancheng; Yamagata_Aritomo; Imperial_Japanese_Army; Yalu_River; Qing_dynasty; Hushan_Great_Wall; October_24

event_text: Nicholas II becomes the new (and last) Tsar of Russia after his father, Alexander III, dies.
Buffalo Bill, 15 of his Native Americans, and Annie Oakley were filmed by Thomas Edison in his Black Maria Studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
H. H. Holmes, one of the first modern serial killers, is arrested in Boston, Massachusetts.
Port Arthur, China, falls to the Japanese, a decisive victory of the First Sino-Japanese War; Japanese troops are accused of massacring the remaining inhabitants.
The Dreyfus affair begins in France, when Alfred Dreyfus is wrongly convicted of treason.
Dreyfus affair: French army officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island.
The National Trust is founded in the United Kingdom.
First Italo-Ethiopian War: The war's opening battle, the Battle of Coatit, occurs; it is an Italian victory.
Fountains Valley, Pretoria, the oldest nature reserve in Africa, is proclaimed by President Paul Kruger.
William G. Morgan creates a game called Mintonette, which soon comes to be referred to as volleyball.
Revolution breaks out in Baire, a town near Santiago de Cuba, beginning the Cuban War of Independence; the war ends along with the Spanish–American War in 1898.
Before the Société pour L'Encouragement à l'Industrie, brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière demonstrate movie film technology publicly for the first time.
The trial in the libel case brought by Oscar Wilde begins, eventually resulting in his imprisonment on charges of homosexuality.
In Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co. the Supreme Court of the United States declares unapportioned income tax to be unconstitutional.
The 1895 Ljubljana earthquake, both the most and last destructive earthquake in the area, occurs.

The Treaty of Shimonoseki between China and Japan is signed. This marks the end of the First Sino-Japanese War, and the defeated Qing Empire is forced to renounce its claims on Korea and to concede the southern portion of the Fengtian province, Taiwan and the Penghu to Japan.
source_pages: Treaty_of_Shimonoseki; First_Sino-Japanese_War; Qing_dynasty; Liaoning; Taiwan; Penghu

event_text: Joshua Slocum, the first person to sail single-handedly around the world, sets sail from Boston, Massachusetts aboard the sloop Spray.

In Saint Petersburg, Russian scientist Alexander Stepanovich Popov demonstrates to the Russian Physical and Chemical Society his invention, the Popov lightning detector—a primitive radio receiver. In some parts of the former Soviet Union the anniversary of this day is celebrated as Radio Day.
source_pages: Saint_Petersburg; Aleksandr_Popov_(physicist); Lightning; Radio_receiver; Soviet_Union; Radio_Day

event_text: Playwright, poet and novelist Oscar Wilde is convicted of "committing acts of gross indecency with other male persons" and sentenced to serve two years in prison.
The Republic of Formosa is formed, with Tang Jingsong as its president.
Paris–Bordeaux–Paris, sometimes called the first automobile race in history or the "first motor race", takes place.

Émile Levassor wins the world's first real automobile race. Levassor completed the 732-mile course, from Paris to Bordeaux and back, in just under 49 hours, at a then-impressive speed of about fifteen miles per hour (24 km/h).
The Kiel Canal, crossing the base of the Jutland peninsula and the busiest artificial waterway in the world, is officially opened.
The inaugural run of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's Royal Blue from Washington, D.C., to New York City, the first U.S. passenger train to use electric locomotives.
The United States Court of Private Land Claims rules James Reavis's claim to Barony of Arizona is "wholly fictitious and fraudulent."

Japanese invasion of Taiwan: Battle of Baguashan: The Empire of Japan decisively defeats a smaller Formosan army at Changhua, crippling the short-lived Republic of Formosa and leading to its surrender two months later.
source_pages: Japanese_invasion_of_Taiwan_(1895); Battle_of_Baguashan; Empire_of_Japan; Republic_of_Formosa; Changhua; August_27

event_text: German Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin patents his navigable balloon.

John Brallier becomes the first openly paid professional American football player, when he was paid US$10 by David Berry, to play for the Latrobe Athletic Association in a 12–0 win over the Jeanette Athletic Association.
Horace Rawlins wins the first U.S. Open Men's Golf Championship.
Korean Empress Myeongseong is assassinated by Japanese infiltrators.
The capitulation of Tainan completes the Japanese conquest of Taiwan.
In Paris an express train derails after overrunning the buffer stop, crossing almost 30 metres (100 ft) of concourse before crashing through a wall and falling 10 metres (33 ft) to the road below.
The strongest earthquake in the Midwestern United States since 1812 strikes near Charleston, Missouri, causing damage and killing at least two.
George B. Selden is granted the first U.S. patent for an automobile.
While experimenting with electricity, Wilhelm Röntgen discovers the X-ray.
At the Swedish–Norwegian Club in Paris, Alfred Nobel signs his last will and testament, setting aside his estate to establish the Nobel Prize after he dies.
The first American automobile race takes place over the 54 miles from Chicago's Jackson Park to Evanston, Illinois. Frank Duryea wins in approximately 10 hours.
New Haven Symphony Orchestra of Connecticut performs its first concert.
The Lumière brothers perform for their first paying audience at the Grand Cafe in Boulevard des Capucines.
Wilhelm Röntgen publishes a paper detailing his discovery of a new type of radiation, which later will be known as x-rays.
Utah is admitted as the 45th U.S. state.
An X-ray generating machine is exhibited for the first time by H. L. Smith.

Walter Arnold of East Peckham, Kent, becomes the first person to be convicted of speeding. He was fined one shilling, plus costs, for speeding at 8 mph (13 km/h), thereby exceeding the contemporary speed limit of 2 mph (3.2 km/h).
La bohème premieres in Turin at the Teatro Regio (Turin), conducted by the young Arturo Toscanini.

An Englishman raised in Australia, Bob Fitzsimmons, fought an Irishman, Peter Maher, in an American promoted event which technically took place in Mexico, winning the 1896 World Heavyweight Championship in boxing.
Battle of Adwa: An Ethiopian army defeats an outnumbered Italian force, ending the First Italo-Ethiopian War.
Henri Becquerel discovers radioactive decay.
With the approval of Emperor Guangxu, the Qing dynasty post office is opened, marking the beginning of a postal service in China.
Charilaos Vasilakos wins the first modern Olympic marathon race with a time of three hours and 18 minutes.
An explosion at the Brunner Mine near Greymouth, New Zealand, kills 65 coal miners in the country's worst industrial accident.
In Athens, the opening of the first modern Olympic Games is celebrated, 1,500 years after the original games are banned by Roman emperor Theodosius I.
1896 Summer Olympics: The Olympic marathon is run ending with the victory of Greek athlete Spyridon Louis.
Closing ceremony of the Games of the I Olympiad in Athens, Greece.
Naser al-Din, Shah of Iran, is assassinated in Shah Abdol-Azim Shrine by Mirza Reza Kermani, a follower of Jamal al-Din al-Afghani.
source_pages: Naser_al-Din_Shah_Qajar; Qajar_dynasty; Shah_Abdol-Azim_Shrine; Mirza_Reza_Kermani; Jamal_al-Din_al-Afghani; May_1

event_text: The United States Supreme Court rules in Plessy v. Ferguson that the "separate but equal" doctrine is constitutional.
Khodynka Tragedy: A mass panic on Khodynka Field in Moscow during the festivities of the coronation of Russian Tsar Nicholas II results in the deaths of 1,389 people.
Nicholas II is crowned as the last Tsar of Imperial Russia.
Charles Dow publishes the first edition of the Dow Jones Industrial Average.
The F4-strength St. Louis–East St. Louis tornado hits in St. Louis, Missouri, and East St. Louis, Illinois, killing at least 255 people and causing over $10 million in damage.
Guglielmo Marconi applies for a patent for his wireless telegraph.
Henry Ford completes the Ford Quadricycle, his first gasoline-powered automobile and also gives it a successful test run.
One of the deadliest tsunamis in Japan's history kills more than 22,000 people.
An explosion in the Newton Coal Company's Twin Shaft Mine in Pittston, Pennsylvania results in a massive cave-in that kills 58 miners.
William Jennings Bryan delivers his Cross of Gold speech advocating bimetallism at the 1896 Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
The city of Miami is incorporated.
Skookum Jim Mason, George Carmack and Dawson Charlie discover gold in a tributary of the Klondike River in Canada, setting off the Klondike Gold Rush.
Bridget Driscoll became the first recorded case of a pedestrian killed in a collision with a motor car in the United Kingdom.
Anglo-Zanzibar War: The shortest war in world history (09:02 to 09:40), between the United Kingdom and Zanzibar.

Philippine Revolution: After Spanish victory in the Battle of San Juan del Monte, eight provinces in the Philippines are declared under martial law by the Spanish Governor-General Ramón Blanco y Erenas.
Anglo-Egyptian conquest of Sudan: British forces under the command of Horatio Kitchener take Dongola.
Queen Victoria surpasses her grandfather King George III as the longest reigning monarch in British history (later surpassed by her great-great-granddaughter Elizabeth II on 9 September 2015).
A picture showing the bare breasts of a woman appears in National Geographic magazine for the first time.
The Western Pennsylvania Hockey League, which later became the first ice hockey league to openly trade and hire players, began play at Pittsburgh's Schenley Park Casino.
Also sprach Zarathustra by Richard Strauss is first performed.
Alfred Jarry's Ubu Roi premieres in Paris. A riot breaks out at the end of the performance.
The Glasgow Underground Railway is opened by the Glasgow District Subway Company.
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania's Schenley Park Casino, which was the first multi-purpose arena with the technology to create an artificial ice surface in North America, is destroyed in a fire.
Filipino patriot and reform advocate José Rizal is executed by a Spanish firing squad in Manila.
Canadian ice hockey player Ernie McLea scores the first hat-trick in Stanley Cup play, and the Cup-winning goal as the Montreal Victorias defeat the Winnipeg Victorias 6–5.
source_pages: Ice_hockey; Ernie_McLea; Hat-trick; Stanley_Cup; Montreal_Victorias; Winnipeg_Victorias

event_text: Shinhan Bank, the oldest bank in South Korea, opens in Seoul.
The Greco-Turkish War is declared between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.

J. J. Thomson of the Cavendish Laboratory announces his discovery of the electron as a subatomic particle, over 1,800 times smaller than a proton (in the atomic nucleus), at a lecture at the Royal Institution in London.
source_pages: J._J._Thomson; Cavendish_Laboratory; Electron; Subatomic_particle; Proton; Royal_Institution; April_30

event_text: A treaty annexing the Republic of Hawaii to the United States is signed; the Republic would not be dissolved until a year later.

British colonial officers Charles Walter Rand and Lt. Charles Egerton Ayerst are assassinated in Pune, Maharashtra, India by the Chapekar brothers and Mahadeo Vinayak Ranade, who are later caught and hanged.
British-Italian engineer Guglielmo Marconi obtains a patent for radio in London.
Salomon August Andrée leaves Spitsbergen to attempt to reach the North Pole by balloon.
American author Jack London embarks on a sailing trip to take part in the Klondike's gold rush, from which he wrote his first successful stories.
Anglo-Afghan War: The Pashtun fakir Saidullah leads an army of more than 10,000 to begin a siege of the British garrison in the Malakand Agency of the North West Frontier Province of India.
source_pages: Anglo-Afghan_War; Pashtuns; Fakir; Sartor_Faqir; Siege_of_Malakand; Malakand_Agency; Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa

event_text: Anglo-Afghan War: The Siege of Malakand ends when a relief column is able to reach the British garrison in the Malakand states.
Italian anarchist Michele Angiolillo assassinates Spanish Prime Minister Antonio Cánovas del Castillo
The first International Congress of Mathematicians is held in Zürich, Switzerland.
The Tremont Street Subway in Boston opens, becoming the first underground rapid transit system in North America.
Lattimer massacre: A sheriff's posse kills 19 unarmed striking immigrant miners in Lattimer, Pennsylvania, United States.
After months of pursuit, generals of Menelik II of Ethiopia capture Gaki Sherocho, the last king of the Kaffa.
Tirah campaign: In the Battle of Saragarhi, ten thousand Pashtun tribesmen suffer several hundred casualties while attacking 21 Sikh soldiers in British service.
The first Library of Congress building opens its doors to the public; the library had previously been housed in the Congressional Reading Room in the U.S. Capitol.
Italian Sport-Club Juventus is founded by a group of students of Liceo Classico Massimo d'Azeglio.
London becomes the world's first city to host licensed taxicabs.
The British Colony of Natal annexes Zululand.

New York, New York annexes land from surrounding counties, creating the City of Greater New York. The four initial boroughs, Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, and The Bronx, are joined on January 25 by Staten Island to create the modern city of five boroughs.
source_pages: New_York_City; City_of_Greater_New_York; Boroughs_of_New_York_City; Manhattan; Brooklyn; Queens; The_Bronx; Staten_Island

event_text: Émile Zola's J'accuse…! exposes the Dreyfus affair.
Dreyfus affair: Émile Zola is brought to trial for libel for publishing J'Accuse...!
The battleship USS Maine explodes and sinks in Havana harbor in Cuba, killing about 274 of the ship's roughly 354 crew. The disaster pushes the United States to declare war on Spain.
source_pages: USS_Maine_(1890); Havana; Cuba; February_15; United_States; Spanish–American_War; Spain

event_text: Émile Zola is imprisoned in France after writing J'Accuse…!, a letter accusing the French government of antisemitism and wrongfully imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
King George I of Greece survives an assassination attempt.
In Melbourne, the representatives of five colonies adopt a constitution, which would become the basis of the Commonwealth of Australia.[page needed]
U.S. President William McKinley signs a joint resolution to Congress for declaration of war against Spain, beginning the Spanish–American War.

Spanish–American War: The United States Navy begins a blockade of Cuban ports. When the U.S. Congress issued a declaration of war on April 25, it declared that a state of war had existed from this date.
Spanish–American War: President William McKinley calls for 125,000 volunteers to join the National Guard and fight in Cuba, while Congress more than doubles regular Army forces to 65,000.
source_pages: Spanish–American_War; William_McKinley; National_Guard_(United_States); Cuba; United_States_Congress; United_States_Army; April_22

event_text: Spanish–American War: The United States Congress declares that a state of war between the U.S. and Spain has existed since April 21, when an American naval blockade of the Spanish colony of Cuba began.

Spanish–American War: Battle of Manila Bay: The Asiatic Squadron of the United States Navy destroys the Pacific Squadron of the Spanish Navy after a seven-hour battle. Spain loses all seven of its ships, and 381 Spanish sailors die. There are no American vessel losses or combat deaths.
source_pages: Spanish–American_War; Battle_of_Manila_Bay; Asiatic_Squadron; United_States_Navy; Pacific_Squadron; Spanish_Navy; May_1

event_text: The first games of the Italian football league system are played.
Spanish–American War: In the Battle of Guantánamo Bay, U.S. Marines begin the American invasion of Spanish-held Cuba.

The Hundred Days' Reform, a planned movement to reform social, political, and educational institutions in China, is started by the Guangxu Emperor, but is suspended by Empress Dowager Cixi after 104 days. (The failed reform led to the abolition of the Imperial examination in 1905.)
Philippine Declaration of Independence: General Emilio Aguinaldo declares the Philippines' independence from Spain.
Yukon Territory is formed, with Dawson chosen as its capital.
The United States Navy Hospital Corps is established.

The United States captures Guam from Spain. The few warning shots fired by the U.S. naval vessels are misinterpreted as salutes by the Spanish garrison, which was unaware that the two nations were at war.

Spanish–American War: In a chaotic operation, 6,000 men of the U.S. Fifth Army Corps begins landing at Daiquirí, Cuba, about 16 miles (26 km) east of Santiago de Cuba. Lt. Gen. Arsenio Linares y Pombo of the Spanish Army outnumbers them two-to-one, but does not oppose the landings.
source_pages: Spanish–American_War; Fifth_Army_Corps_(Spanish–American_War); Daiquirí; Santiago_de_Cuba; Arsenio_Linares_y_Pombo; Spanish_Army; June_22

event_text: The first solo circumnavigation of the globe is completed by Joshua Slocum from Briar Island, Nova Scotia.
Spanish–American War: The Battle of San Juan Hill is fought in Santiago de Cuba, Cuba.
A Spanish squadron, led by Pascual Cervera y Topete, is defeated by an American squadron under William T. Sampson in the Battle of Santiago de Cuba.
En route from New York to Le Havre, the SS La Bourgogne collides with another ship and sinks off the coast of Sable Island, with the loss of 549 lives.
US president William McKinley signs the Newlands Resolution, annexing Hawaii as a territory of the United States.
The death of crime boss Soapy Smith, killed in the Shootout on Juneau Wharf, releases Skagway, Alaska from his iron grip.
Spanish–American War: The American invasion of Spanish-held Puerto Rico begins, as United States Army troops under General Nelson A. Miles land and secure the port at Guánica.
source_pages: Spanish–American_War; Puerto_Rico; United_States_Army; Nelson_A._Miles; Guánica,_Puerto_Rico; July_25

event_text: Spanish–American War: American troops enter the city of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico.

The Hawaiian flag is lowered from ʻIolani Palace in an elaborate annexation ceremony and replaced with the flag of the United States to signify the transfer of sovereignty from the Republic of Hawaii to the United States where it is formally recognized as Hawaii.
Spanish–American War: Spanish and American forces engage in a mock battle for Manila, after which the Spanish commander surrendered in order to keep the city out of Filipino rebel hands.
Carl Gustav Witt discovers 433 Eros, the first near-Earth asteroid to be found.
The Southern Cross Expedition, the first British venture of the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration, departs from London.
Count Muravyov, Foreign Minister of Russia presents a rescript that convoked the First Hague Peace Conference.
Caleb Bradham's beverage "Brad's Drink" is renamed "Pepsi-Cola".
The Goodyear tire company is founded in Akron, Ohio.
Battle of Omdurman: British and Egyptian troops defeat Sudanese tribesmen and establish British dominance in Sudan.
Seven hundred Greek civilians, 17 British guards and the British Consul of Crete are killed by a Turkish mob.
Empress Elisabeth of Austria is assassinated by Luigi Lucheni.
Hannibal Goodwin patents celluloid photographic film.
The Fashoda Incident triggers the last war scare between Britain and France.
Empress Dowager Cixi seizes power and ends the Hundred Days' Reform in China.
The Vienna University of Economics and Business Administration is founded under the name k.u.k. Exportakademie.
Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia, the largest American music fraternity, is founded at the New England Conservatory of Music.
The steam ship SS Mohegan sinks near the Lizard peninsula, Cornwall, killing 106.
The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
France withdraws its troops from Fashoda (now in Sudan), ending the Fashoda Incident.
Negrese nationalists revolt against Spanish rule and establish the short-lived Republic of Negros.
White supremacists seized power and massacred black Americans during the Wilmington massacre, the only instance of a municipal government being overthrown in United States history.
The Duquesne Country and Athletic Club defeats an all-star collection of early football players 16–0, in what is considered to be the first all-star game for professional American football.

Spanish–American War: The Treaty of Paris is signed, officially ending the conflict. Spain cedes administration of Cuba to the United States, and the United States agrees to pay Spain $20 million for the Philippines.
Gaston de Chasseloup-Laubat sets the first officially recognized land speed record of 63.159 km/h (39.245 mph) in a Jeantaud electric car.
Marie and Pierre Curie announce the isolation of radium.
Spanish rule ends in Cuba.
RMS Oceanic, the largest ship afloat since SS Great Eastern, is launched.
The United States takes possession of Wake Island in the Pacific Ocean.
Anglo-Egyptian Sudan is formed.
The Malolos Constitution is inaugurated, establishing the First Philippine Republic. Emilio Aguinaldo is sworn in as its first president.
The Philippine–American War begins when four Filipino soldiers enter the "American Zone" in Manila, igniting the Battle of Manila.
Spanish–American War: The Treaty of Paris, a peace treaty between the United States and Spain, is ratified by the United States Senate.
Voting machines are approved by the U.S. Congress for use in federal elections.
Tsar Nicholas II of Russia issues a declaration known as the February Manifesto, which reduces the autonomy of the Grand Duchy of Finland, thus beginning the first period of oppression.
Iceland's first football club, Knattspyrnufélag Reykjavíkur, is founded.

Filipino forces led by General Antonio Luna launch counterattacks for the first time against the American forces during the Philippine–American War. The Filipinos fail to regain Manila from the Americans.
Cyclone Mahina sweeps in north of Cooktown, Queensland, with a 12 metres (39 ft) wave that reaches up to 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) inland, killing over 300.
Phoebe, a satellite of Saturn, becomes the first to be discovered with photographs, taken in August 1898, by William Henry Pickering.
Emilio Aguinaldo leads Filipino forces for the only time during the Philippine–American War at the Battle of Marilao River.
German Society of Chemistry issues an invitation to other national scientific organizations to appoint delegates to the International Committee on Atomic Weights.
Philippine–American War: Malolos, capital of the First Philippine Republic, is captured by American forces.
The St. Andrew's Ambulance Association is granted a royal charter by Queen Victoria.
The Irish Literary Theatre in Dublin produced its first play.
Finnish farmworker Karl Emil Malmelin kills seven people with an axe at the Simola croft in the village of Klaukkala.
Pearl Hart, a female outlaw of the Old West, robs a stage coach 30 miles southeast of Globe, Arizona.
American Temperance crusader Carrie Nation begins her campaign of vandalizing alcohol-serving establishments by destroying the inventory in a saloon in Kiowa, Kansas.
New Richmond tornado: The ninth deadliest tornado in U.S. history kills 117 people and injures around 200.
Fiat founded by Giovanni Agnelli in Turin, Italy.
NEC Corporation is organized as the first Japanese joint venture with foreign capital.
Ulises Heureaux, the 27th President of the Dominican Republic, is assassinated.
The First Hague Convention is signed.
Fratton Park football ground in Portsmouth, England is officially first opened.
Mackinder, Ollier and Brocherel make the first ascent of Batian (5,199 m – 17,058 ft), the highest peak of Mount Kenya.
The American Asiatic Squadron destroys a Filipino battery at the Battle of Olongapo.
The Second Boer War erupts in South Africa between the British-ruled Cape Colony, and the Boer-ruled Transvaal and Orange Free State.
The Boers begin their 118-day siege of British-held Ladysmith during the Second Boer War.
Second Boer War: Battle of Chieveley, a British armored train is ambushed and partially derailed. British lose the battle, with 80 soldiers captured, along with war correspondent Winston Churchill.
The Second Boer War: A British column is engaged by Boer forces at the Battle of Modder River; although the Boers withdraw, the British suffer heavy casualties.
FC Barcelona is founded by Catalan, Spanish and Englishmen.  It later develops into one of Spanish and world football's most iconic and strongest teams.
Philippine–American War: The Battle of Tirad Pass, known as the "Filipino Thermopylae", is fought.

Second Boer War: In the Battle of Magersfontein the Boers commanded by general Piet Cronjé inflict a defeat on the forces of the British Empire commanded by Lord Methuen trying to relieve the Siege of Kimberley.
source_pages: Second_Boer_War; Battle_of_Magersfontein; Boers; Piet_Cronjé; British_Empire; Paul_Methuen,_3rd_Baron_Methuen; Siege_of_Kimberley

event_text: British Army forces are defeated at the Battle of Colenso in Natal, South Africa, the third and final battle fought during the Black Week of the Second Boer War.
source_pages: British_Army; Second_Battle_of_Colenso; Natal_(province); South_Africa; Black_Week; Second_Boer_War; December_15

event_text: Nigeria becomes a British protectorate with Frederick Lugard as high commissioner.
American statesman and diplomat John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote trade with China.
Chicago Canal opens.
Irish nationalist leader John Edward Redmond calls for revolt against British rule.
Second Boer War: Having already besieged the fortress at Ladysmith, Boer forces attack it, but are driven back by British defenders.
President William McKinley  places Alaska under military rule.
To combat Czech nationalism, Emperor Franz Joseph decrees German will be language of the Austro-Hungarian Armed Forces.
Giacomo Puccini's Tosca opens in Rome.
The United States Senate accepts the Anglo-German treaty of 1899 in which the United Kingdom renounces its claims to the Samoan islands.
Second Boer War: The Battle of Spion Kop between the forces of the South African Republic and the Orange Free State and British forces ends in a British defeat.
Second Boer War: Boers stop a British attempt to break the Siege of Ladysmith in the Battle of Spion Kop.
Datu Muhammad Salleh is killed in Kampung Teboh, Tambunan, ending the Mat Salleh Rebellion.
Great Britain, defeated by Boers in key battles, names Lord Roberts commander of British forces in South Africa.
The Permanent Court of Arbitration, an international arbitration court at The Hague, is created when the Senate of the Netherlands ratifies an 1899 peace conference decree.
Second Boer War: British troops fail in their third attempt to lift the Siege of Ladysmith.
A Chinese immigrant in San Francisco falls ill to bubonic plague in the first plague epidemic in the continental United States.
The Davis Cup competition is established.
The British Army begins the Battle of the Tugela Heights in an effort to lift the Siege of Ladysmith.
The Southern Cross expedition led by Carsten Borchgrevink achieved a new Farthest South of 78° 50'S, making the first landing at the Great Ice Barrier.
Second Boer War: Imperial forces suffer their worst single-day loss of life on Bloody Sunday, the first day of the Battle of Paardeberg.
Second Boer War: During the Battle of the Tugela Heights, the first British attempt to take Hart's Hill fails.
Second Boer War: In South Africa, British military leaders receive an unconditional notice of surrender from Boer General Piet Cronjé at the Battle of Paardeberg.
The British Labour Party is founded.
Fußball-Club Bayern München is founded.
British forces occupy Bloemfontein, Orange Free State, during the Second Boer War.
The Gold Standard Act is ratified, placing the United States currency on the gold standard.
Mayor of New York City Robert Anderson Van Wyck breaks ground for a new underground "Rapid Transit Railroad" that would link Manhattan and Brooklyn.
source_pages: Mayor_of_New_York_City; Robert_Anderson_Van_Wyck; New_York_City_Subway; Manhattan; Brooklyn; March_24

event_text: Carnegie Steel Company is formed in New Jersey; its capitalization of $160 million is the largest to date.
Archaeologists in Knossos, Crete, discover the first clay tablet with hieroglyphic writing in a script later called Linear B.
source_pages: Archaeology; Knossos; Crete; Clay_tablet; Egyptian_hieroglyphs; Linear_B; March_30

event_text: Prince George becomes absolute monarch of the Cretan State.
British suffer a sharp defeat by the Boers south of Brandfort. 600 British troops are killed and wounded and 800 taken prisoner.
One day after its enactment by the Congress, President William McKinley signs the Foraker Act into law, giving Puerto Rico limited self-rule.
source_pages: United_States_Congress; William_McKinley; Foraker_Act; Puerto_Rico; Self-governance; April_12

event_text: The world's fair Exposition Universelle opens in Paris.
Philippine–American War: Filipino guerrillas launch a surprise attack on U.S. infantry and begin a four-day siege of Catubig, Philippines.
Fires destroy Canadian cities Ottawa and Hull, reducing them to ashes in 12 hours. Twelve thousand people are left without a home.
Hawaii becomes a territory of the United States, with Sanford B. Dole as governor.
The Scofield Mine disaster kills over 200 men in Scofield, Utah in what is to date the fifth-worst mining accident in United States history.
Opening of World Amateur championship at the Paris Exposition Universelle, also known as Olympic Games.
The children's novel The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, by L. Frank Baum, is first published in the United States. The first copy is given to the author's sister.
The United Kingdom proclaims a protectorate over Tonga.
Great Britain annexes Tonga Island.
Second Boer War: British troops relieve Mafeking.
American Civil War: Sergeant William Harvey Carney is awarded the Medal of Honor for his heroism in the Assault on the Battery Wagner in 1863.
Second Boer War: The United Kingdom annexes the Orange Free State.
Thousand Days' War: The Colombian Conservative Party turns the tide of war in their favor with victory against the Colombian Liberal Party in the Battle of Palonegro.
N'Djamena is founded as Fort-Lamy by the French commander Émile Gentil.
Second Boer War: British soldiers take Pretoria.
Indian nationalist Birsa Munda dies of cholera in a British prison.

The Reichstag approves new legislation continuing Germany's naval expansion program, providing for construction of 38 battleships over a 20-year period. Germany's fleet would be the largest in the world.
Hawaii becomes a United States territory.
The second German Naval Law calls for the Imperial German Navy to be doubled in size, resulting in an Anglo-German naval arms race.
Boxer Rebellion: Western Allied and Japanese forces capture the Taku Forts in Tianjin, China.
source_pages: Boxer_Rebellion; Eight-Nation_Alliance; Battle_of_the_Taku_Forts_(1900); Taku_Forts; Tianjin; June_17

event_text: Empress Dowager Cixi of China orders all foreigners killed, including foreign diplomats and their families.
Boxer Rebellion: The Imperial Chinese Army begins a 55-day siege of the Legation Quarter in Beijing, China.
Baron Eduard Toll, leader of the Russian Polar Expedition of 1900, departs Saint Petersburg in Russia on the explorer ship Zarya, never to return.
Boxer Rebellion: China formally declares war on the United States, Britain, Germany, France and Japan, as an edict issued from the Empress Dowager Cixi.
The Taoist monk Wang Yuanlu discovers the Dunhuang manuscripts, a cache of ancient texts that are of great historical and religious significance, in the Mogao Caves of Dunhuang, China.
A savage fire wrecked three steamships docked at a pier in Hoboken, New Jersey. Over 200 crew members and passengers are killed, and hundreds injured.
An airship designed and constructed by Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin of Germany made its first flight on Lake Constance near Friedrichshafen.
Jean Sibelius' Finlandia receives its première performance in Helsinki with the Helsinki Philharmonic Society conducted by Robert Kajanus.
The Federation of Australia is given royal assent.
The Governor of Shanxi province in North China orders the execution of 45 foreign Christian missionaries and local church members, including children.
Armies of the Eight-Nation Alliance capture Tientsin during the Boxer Rebellion.
The first line of the Paris Métro opens for operation.
Pressed by expanding immigration, Canada closes its doors to paupers and criminals.
Kaiser Wilhelm II makes a speech comparing Germans to Huns; for years afterwards, "Hun" would be a disparaging name for Germans.
In Italy, King Umberto I of Italy is assassinated by the anarchist Gaetano Bresci. His son, Victor Emmanuel III, 31 years old, succeeds to the throne.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company is founded.

The steamer Deutschland of Hamburg America Lines set a new record for the eastward passage when it docked on Plymouth, England, five days, 11 hours and 45 minutes after sailing from New York, breaking by three hours, six minutes its previous mark in its maiden voyage in July.
Battle of Peking: The Eight-Nation Alliance occupies Beijing, China, in a campaign to end the bloody Boxer Rebellion in China.

The Battle of Elands River during the Second Boer War ends after a 13-day siege is lifted by the British. The battle had begun when a force of between 2,000 and 3,000 Boers had surrounded a force of 500 Australians, Rhodesians, Canadians and British soldiers at a supply dump at Brakfontein Drift.
Galveston hurricane: A powerful hurricane hits Galveston, Texas killing about 8,000 people.
Filipino insurgents defeat a small American column in the Battle of Pulang Lupa, during the Philippine–American War.
Philippine–American War: Filipinos under Juan Cailles defeat Americans under Colonel Benjamin F. Cheatham Jr. at Mabitac.
Peace congress in Paris condemns British policy in South Africa and asserts Boer Republic's right to self-determination.
The Cook Islands become a territory of the United Kingdom.
Count Bernhard von Bülow becomes chancellor of Germany.
Max Planck discovers Planck's law of black-body radiation.
U.S. Government announces plans to buy Danish West Indies for $7 million.

President William McKinley is re-elected, along with his vice-presidential running mate, Governor Theodore Roosevelt of New York. Republicans also swept the congressional elections, winning increased majorities in both the Senate and the House of Representatives.
Second Boer War: The Battle of Leliefontein takes place, during which the Royal Canadian Dragoons win three Victoria Crosses.
Russian invasion of Manchuria: Russia completes its occupation of Manchuria with 100,000 troops.

The French actress Sarah Bernhardt receives the press at the Savoy Hotel in New York at the outset of her first visit since 1896. She talked about her impending tour with a troupe of more than 50 performers and her plans to play the title role in Hamlet.
Claude Monet's paintings shown at Gallery Durand-Ruel in Paris.
Nicaragua sells canal rights to U.S. for $5 million. The canal agreement fails in March 1901. Great Britain rejects amended treaty
Quantum mechanics: Max Planck presents a theoretical derivation of his black-body radiation law (quantum theory) at the Physic Society in Berlin.

Hopetoun Blunder: The first Governor-General of Australia John Hope, 7th Earl of Hopetoun, appoints Sir William Lyne premier of the new state of New South Wales, but he is unable to persuade other colonial politicians to join his government and is forced to resign.
source_pages: Hopetoun_Blunder; Governor-General_of_Australia; John_Hope,_7th_Earl_of_Hopetoun; William_Lyne; New_South_Wales; December_19

event_text: French parliament votes amnesty for all involved in scandalous army treason trial known as Dreyfus affair.
The Southern Nigeria Protectorate is established within the British Empire.

The British colonies of New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton is appointed the first Prime Minister.
source_pages: New_South_Wales; Queensland; Victoria_(state); South_Australia; Tasmania; Western_Australia; Federation_of_Australia; Australia; Edmund_Barton; Prime_Minister_of_Australia; January_1

event_text: The first great Texas oil gusher is discovered at Spindletop in Beaumont, Texas.
New York: Automobile Club of America installs signs on major highways.
Queen Victoria, Queen of the United Kingdom, stricken with paralysis. She dies three days later at the age of 81.
Edward VII is proclaimed King of the United Kingdom after the death of his mother, Queen Victoria.
Anton Chekhov's Three Sisters premieres at Moscow Art Theatre in Russia.

J. P. Morgan incorporates U.S. Steel in the state of New Jersey, although the company would not start doing business until February 25 and the assets of Andrew Carnegie's Carnegie Steel Company, Elbert H. Gary's Federal Steel Company, and William Henry Moore's National Steel Company were not acquired until April 1.
source_pages: J._P._Morgan; U.S._Steel; New_Jersey; February_5; Andrew_Carnegie; Carnegie_Steel_Company; Elbert_Henry_Gary; Illinois_Steel_Company; William_Henry_Moore_(financier)

event_text: The legislature of Hawaii Territory convenes for the first time.
The Australian Army is formed.

United States Steel Corporation is founded as a result of a merger between Carnegie Steel Company and Federal Steel Company which became the first corporation in the world with a market capital over $1 billion.
The U.S. Congress passes the Platt Amendment limiting the autonomy of Cuba, as a condition of the withdrawal of American troops.
