William McKinley inaugurated president for second time; Theodore Roosevelt is vice president.
Anarchist assassin tries to kill German Emperor Wilhelm II.
Utah governor Heber Manning Wells vetoes a bill that would have eased restriction on polygamy.
The Kumasi Mutiny of 1901 begins.
Emilio Aguinaldo, only President of the First Philippine Republic, is captured at Palanan, Isabela by the forces of American General Frederick Funston.
Philippine–American War: Emilio Aguinaldo, leader of the First Philippine Republic, is captured by the Americans.
Rusalka by Antonín Dvořák premieres at the National Opera House in Prague.
New York becomes the first U.S. state to require automobile license plates.
The Great Fire of 1901 begins in Jacksonville, Florida.
The first issue of Gorkhapatra, the oldest still running state-owned Nepali newspaper was published.
Australia opens its first national parliament in Melbourne.
The boundaries of the Colony of New Zealand are extended by the UK to include the Cook Islands.
The College Board introduces its first standardized test, the forerunner to the SAT.
French government enacts its anti-clerical legislation Law of Association prohibiting the formation of new monastic orders without governmental approval.
William Howard Taft becomes American governor of the Philippines.
O. Henry is released from prison in Columbus, Ohio, after serving three years for embezzlement from a bank.
Land lottery begins in Oklahoma.
Peter O'Connor sets the first World Athletics recognised long jump world record of 24 ft 11.75 in (7.6137 m), a record that would stand for 20 years.
Kiowa land in Oklahoma is opened for white settlement, effectively dissolving the contiguous reservation.
The U.S. Steel recognition strike by the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers begins.
The first claimed powered flight, by Gustave Whitehead in his Number 21.
Six hundred American school teachers, Thomasites, arrived in Manila on the USAT Thomas.
Silliman University is founded in the Philippines. It is the first American private school in the country.
Vice President of the United States Theodore Roosevelt utters the famous phrase, "Speak softly and carry a big stick" at the Minnesota State Fair.
Leon Czolgosz, an unemployed anarchist, shoots and fatally wounds US president William McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York.
source_pages: Leon_Czolgosz; Anarchism; Assassination_of_William_McKinley; President_of_the_United_States; William_McKinley; Pan-American_Exposition; Buffalo,_New_York

event_text: The Boxer Rebellion in Qing dynasty (modern-day China) officially ends with the signing of the Boxer Protocol.
U.S. President William McKinley dies after being mortally wounded on September 6 by anarchist Leon Czolgosz and is succeeded by Vice President Theodore Roosevelt.
Second Boer War: A Boer column defeats a British force at the Battle of Blood River Poort.
Second Boer War: Boers capture a squadron of the 17th Lancers at the Battle of Elands River.
Philippine–American War: Filipino guerrillas kill more than forty American soldiers while losing 28 of their own.
President Theodore Roosevelt officially renames the "Executive Mansion" to the White House.
Annie Edson Taylor becomes the first person to go over Niagara Falls in a barrel.
Gospel riots: Bloody clashes take place in Athens following the translation of the Gospels into demotic Greek.
Prince George, Duke of Cornwall (later George V of the United Kingdom), becomes Prince of Wales and Earl of Chester.
The 1901 Caister lifeboat disaster.
Britain and the United States sign the Hay–Pauncefote Treaty, which nullifies the Clayton–Bulwer Treaty and withdraws British objections to an American-controlled canal in Panama.
The U.S. Army War College is established.

In a State of the Union message, U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt delivers a 20,000-word report to the House of Representatives asking Congress to curb the power of trusts "within reasonable limits".  The speech was not delivered in person.
The first Nobel Prize ceremony is held in Stockholm on the fifth anniversary of Alfred Nobel's death.
Guglielmo Marconi transmits the first transatlantic radio signal from Poldhu, Cornwall, England to Saint John's, Newfoundland.
Guglielmo Marconi receives the first transatlantic radio signal (the letter "S" [•••] in Morse Code), at Signal Hill in St John's, Newfoundland.
The first American college football bowl game, the Rose Bowl between Michigan and Stanford, is held in Pasadena, California.
source_pages: College_football; Bowl_game; Rose_Bowl_Game; University_of_Michigan; Stanford_University; Pasadena,_California; January_1

event_text: The Carnegie Institution of Washington is founded in Washington, D.C., with a $10 million gift from Andrew Carnegie.
The first Anglo-Japanese Alliance is signed in London.
Second Boer War: Australian soldiers Harry "Breaker" Morant and Peter Handcock are executed in Pretoria after being convicted of war crimes.
Second Boer War: Boers, led by Koos de la Rey, defeat the British at the Battle of Tweebosch.
Macario Sakay issues Presidential Order No. 1 of his Tagalog Republic.
Dmitry Sipyagin, Minister of Interior of the Russian Empire, is assassinated in the Mariinsky Palace, Saint Petersburg.
"Electric Theatre", the first full-time movie theater in the United States, opens in Los Angeles.

A stand box collapses at Ibrox Park (now Ibrox Stadium) in Glasgow, Scotland, which led to the deaths of 25 and injuries to more than 500 supporters during an international association football match between Scotland and England.
source_pages: 1902_Ibrox_disaster; Ibrox_Stadium; Glasgow; Association_football; Scotland_national_football_team; England_national_football_team; April_5

event_text: The 7.5 Mw  Guatemala earthquake shakes Guatemala with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), killing between 800 and 2,000.
Pierre and Marie Curie refine radium chloride.
In Martinique, Mount Pelée erupts, destroying the town of Saint-Pierre and killing over 30,000 people. Only a handful of residents survive the blast.
Greek archaeologist Valerios Stais discovers the Antikythera mechanism, an ancient mechanical analog computer.
Cuba gains independence from the United States. Tomás Estrada Palma becomes the country's first President.
Second Boer War: The Treaty of Vereeniging ends the war and ensures British control of South Africa.
The U.S. Congress passes the Spooner Act, authorizing President Theodore Roosevelt to acquire rights from Colombia for the Panama Canal.
Peruvian explorer and farmer Agustín Lizárraga discovers Machu Picchu, the "Lost City of the Incas".
The Campanile in St Mark's Square, Venice collapses, also demolishing the loggetta.
Edward VII and Alexandra of Denmark are crowned King and Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
The Cadillac Motor Company is founded.
Theodore Roosevelt becomes the first President of the United States to make a public appearance in an automobile.
At least 6,000 people are killed by the magnitude 7.7 Kashgar earthquake in the Tien Shan mountains.
A stampede at Shiloh Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama, leads to the death of 115 attendees.
Guatemala's Santa María volcano begins to erupt, becoming the third-largest eruption of the 20th century.
The Philadelphia Football Athletics defeat the Kanaweola Athletic Club of Elmira, New York, 39–0, in the first-ever professional American football night game.
The opening of the reservoir of the Aswan Dam in Egypt.
The Commercial Pacific Cable Company lays the first Pacific telegraph cable, from San Francisco to Honolulu.
The Syracuse Athletic Club defeat the New York Philadelphians, 5–0, in the first indoor professional football game, which was held at Madison Square Garden.
The Discovery Expedition under Robert Falcon Scott attained a Farthest South at 82°17′S in Antarctica.
Topsy, an elephant, is electrocuted by the owners of Luna Park, Coney Island. The Edison film company records the film Electrocuting an Elephant of Topsy's death.
source_pages: Topsy_(elephant); Elephant; Luna_Park_(Coney_Island,_1903); Edison_Studios; Electrocuting_an_Elephant; January_4

event_text: Hallam Tennyson, 2nd Baron Tennyson, son of the poet Alfred Tennyson, becomes the second Governor-General of Australia.
El Yunque National Forest in Puerto Rico becomes part of the United States National Forest System as the Luquillo Forest Reserve.
Anton Bruckner's 9th Symphony receives its first performance in Vienna, Austria.
The United States Department of Commerce and Labor is established (later split into the Department of Commerce and the Department of Labor).
Cuba leases Guantánamo Bay to the United States "in perpetuity".
In New York City the Martha Washington Hotel opens, becoming the first hotel exclusively for women.
Pelican Island National Wildlife Refuge, the first national wildlife refuge in the US, is established by President Theodore Roosevelt.
The first of a series of auctions of sheep farming land in southern Patagonia takes place impacting established settlers.
The Kishinev pogrom in Kishinev (Bessarabia) begins, forcing tens of thousands of Jews to later seek refuge in Palestine and the Western world.
Atlético Madrid Association football club is founded.
A landslide kills 70 people in Frank, in the District of Alberta, Canada.
Românul de la Pind, the longest-running newspaper by and about Aromanians until World War II, is founded.
In the May Coup, Alexander I, King of Serbia, and Queen Draga, are assassinated in Belgrade by the Black Hand (Crna Ruka) organization.
A group of Serbian officers storms the royal palace and assassinates King Alexander I of Serbia and his wife, Queen Draga.
The Ford Motor Company is incorporated.
Roald Amundsen leaves Oslo, Norway, to commence the first east–west navigation of the Northwest Passage.
Benito Mussolini, at the time a radical Socialist, is arrested by Bern police for advocating a violent general strike.
Start of first Tour de France bicycle race.
The Philippine–American War is officially concluded.
Maurice Garin wins the first Tour de France.
The Ford Motor Company ships its first automobile.
The Ford Motor Company sells its first car.
The Ilinden–Preobrazhenie Uprising against the Ottoman Empire begins.
Macedonian rebels in Kruševo proclaim the Kruševo Republic, which exists for only ten days before Ottoman Turks lay waste to the town.
Black Saturday occurs, killing 12 in a stadium collapse in Philadelphia.
German engineer Karl Jatho allegedly flies his self-made, motored gliding airplane four months before the first flight of the Wright brothers.
The Transfiguration Uprising breaks out in East Thrace, resulting in the establishment of the Strandzha Commune.
The Slava, the last of the five Borodino-class battleships, is launched.
The Ottoman Empire launches a counter-offensive against the Strandzha Commune, which dissolves.
The first race at the Milwaukee Mile in West Allis, Wisconsin is held. It is the oldest major speedway in the world.
"Wreck of the Old 97": an American rail disaster, in which 11 people are killed; it later becomes the subject of a popular ballad.
Baseball: The Boston Americans play the Pittsburgh Pirates in the first game of the modern World Series.
The High Court of Australia sits for the first time.
The Women's Social and Political Union is founded in support of the enfranchisement of British women.
The Boston Red Sox win the first modern World Series, defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates in the eighth game.
The Purdue Wreck, a railroad train collision in Indianapolis, kills 17 people, including 14 players of the Purdue University football team.
With the encouragement of the United States, Panama separates from Colombia.
The Russian Social Democratic Labour Party splits into two groups: The Bolsheviks (Russian for "majority") and Mensheviks (Russian for "minority").
The Hay–Bunau-Varilla Treaty is signed by the United States and Panama, giving the United States exclusive rights over the Panama Canal Zone.
The Wright brothers make their first attempt to fly with the Wright Flyer at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
Italian American food cart vendor Italo Marchiony receives a U.S. patent for inventing a machine that makes ice cream cones.
The Wright brothers make the first controlled powered, heavier-than-air flight in the Wright Flyer at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
A fire at the Iroquois Theater in Chicago, Illinois kills at least 605.
The distress signal "CQD" is established only to be replaced two years later by "SOS".
Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard receives its premiere performance at the Moscow Art Theatre.
Ålesund Fire: The Norwegian coastal town Ålesund is devastated by fire, leaving 10,000 people homeless and one person dead. Kaiser Wilhelm II funds the rebuilding of the town in Jugendstil style.
The Great Baltimore Fire begins in Baltimore, Maryland; it destroys over 1,500 buildings in 30 hours.
Japanese forces launch a surprise attack against Russian-controlled Port Arthur, marking the start of the Russo-Japanese war.
source_pages: Empire_of_Japan; Battle_of_Port_Arthur; Russian_Empire; Lüshunkou,_Dalian; Russo-Japanese_War; February_8

event_text: The Dutch Colonial Army's Marechaussee regiment led by General G.C.E. van Daalen launch a military campaign in the Dutch East Indies' Northern Sumatra region, leading to the deaths of thousands of civilians.
source_pages: Royal_Netherlands_East_Indies_Army; Korps_Marechaussee_te_voet; General_officer; Gotfried_Coenraad_Ernst_van_Daalen; Aceh_War; Dutch_East_Indies; North_Sumatra; February_8

event_text: Russo-Japanese War: Battle of Port Arthur concludes.
The United Kingdom sells a meteorological station on the South Orkney Islands to Argentina; the islands are subsequently claimed by the United Kingdom in 1908.
Scottish National Antarctic Expedition: Led by William Speirs Bruce, the Antarctic region of Coats Land was discovered from the Scotia.
source_pages: Scottish_National_Antarctic_Expedition; William_Speirs_Bruce; Antarctica; Coats_Land; Scotia_(barque); March_6

event_text: Two Ms  ~7.1 earthquakes, among the largest in Europe, strike Bulgaria, killing over 200 people and causing destruction.
The French Third Republic and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland sign the Entente cordiale.
The United States begins construction of the Panama Canal.
Pitching against the Philadelphia Athletics at the Huntington Avenue Grounds, Cy Young of the Boston Americans throws the first perfect game in the modern era of baseball.
source_pages: Pitcher; Philadelphia_Athletics; Huntington_Avenue_Grounds; Cy_Young; Boston_Red_Sox; Perfect_game_(baseball); Baseball

event_text: The Horch & Cir. Motorwagenwerke AG is founded. It would eventually become the Audi company.
The Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA) is founded in Paris.
A fire aboard the steamboat SS General Slocum in New York City's East River kills 1,000.
Eugen Schauman assassinates Nikolay Bobrikov, Governor-General of Finland.
Irish author James Joyce begins a relationship with Nora Barnacle and subsequently uses the date to set the actions for his novel Ulysses; this date is now traditionally called "Bloomsday".
The SS Norge runs aground on Hasselwood Rock in the North Atlantic 430 kilometres (270 mi) northwest of Ireland. More than 635 people die during the sinking.
Louis Rigolly, a Frenchman, becomes the first man to break the 100 mph (161 km/h) barrier on land. He drove a 15-liter Gobron-Brillié in Ostend, Belgium.
Russo-Japanese War: Battle of Hsimucheng: Units of the Imperial Japanese Army defeat units of the Imperial Russian Army in a strategic confrontation.
Russo-Japanese War: The Battle of the Yellow Sea between the Russian and Japanese battleship fleets takes place.
The automobile tire chain is patented.
Russo-Japanese War: The Battle of Liaoyang begins.
Chile and Bolivia sign the Treaty of Peace and Friendship, delimiting the border between the two countries.
English engineer John Ambrose Fleming receives a patent for the thermionic valve (vacuum tube).
The Jovian moon Himalia is discovered by Charles Dillon Perrine at California's Lick Observatory.
Theodore Roosevelt articulated his "Corollary" to the Monroe Doctrine, stating that the U.S. would intervene in the Western Hemisphere should Latin American governments prove incapable or unstable.

Comparative fuel trials begin between warships HMS Spiteful and HMS Peterel: Spiteful was the first warship powered solely by fuel oil, and the trials led to the obsolescence of coal in ships of the Royal Navy.
Bloody Sunday in Saint Petersburg, beginning of the 1905 revolution.
The world's largest diamond ever, the Cullinan, which weighs 3,106.75 carats (0.621350 kg), is found at the Premier Mine near Pretoria in South Africa.
In Mexico, the General Hospital of Mexico is inaugurated, started with four basic specialties.
Russian Revolution of 1905: Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia is assassinated in the Moscow Kremlin by Socialist Revolutionary Ivan Kalyayev.
The U.S. Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of Massachusetts's mandatory smallpox vaccination program in Jacobson v. Massachusetts.
Chicago attorney Paul Harris and three other businessmen meet for lunch to form the Rotary Club, the world's first service club.
Eleftherios Venizelos calls for Crete's union with Greece, and begins what is to be known as the Theriso revolt.
The Greek football club P.A.E. G.S. Diagoras is founded in the city of Rhodes.
Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany declares his support for Moroccan independence in Tangier, beginning the First Moroccan Crisis.
Association football club Boca Juniors is founded in Buenos Aires, Argentina
In India, an earthquake hits the Kangra Valley, killing 20,000, and destroying most buildings in Kangra, McLeod Ganj and Dharamshala.

The Supreme Court of the United States decides Lochner v. New York, which holds that the "right to free contract" is implicit in the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
Albert Einstein completes his doctoral thesis at the University of Zurich.
The trial in the Stratton Brothers case begins in London, England; it marks the first time that fingerprint evidence is used to gain a conviction for murder.
The city of Las Vegas is founded in Nevada, United States.

The Sultan of the Ottoman Empire Abdul Hamid II establishes the Ullah millet for the Aromanians of the empire. For this reason, the Aromanian National Day is sometimes celebrated on this day, although most do so on May 23 instead, which is when this event was publicly announced.
source_pages: List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire; Abdul_Hamid_II; Ullah_millet; Aromanians; Aromanian_National_Day; May_22; May_23

event_text: Abdul Hamid II, Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, publicly announces the creation of the Ullah millet for the Aromanians of the empire, which had been established one day earlier. For this reason, the Aromanian National Day is usually celebrated on May 23, although some do so on May 22 instead.
source_pages: Abdul_Hamid_II; List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire; Ullah_millet; Aromanians; Aromanian_National_Day; May_23; May_22

event_text: Russo-Japanese War: The Battle of Tsushima begins.
Russo-Japanese War: The Battle of Tsushima ends with the destruction of the Russian Baltic Fleet by Admiral Tōgō Heihachirō and the Imperial Japanese Navy.
source_pages: Russo-Japanese_War; Battle_of_Tsushima; Baltic_Fleet; Admiral; Tōgō_Heihachirō; Imperial_Japanese_Navy; May_28

event_text: Norway's parliament dissolves its union with Sweden. The vote was confirmed by a national plebiscite on August 13 of that year.
During the Russo-Japanese War, sailors start a mutiny aboard the Russian battleship Potemkin.
Albert Einstein sends the article On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies, in which he introduces special relativity, for publication in Annalen der Physik.
Russo-Japanese War: Peace negotiations begin in Portsmouth, New Hampshire.
Norwegians vote to end the union with Sweden.
Sun Yat-sen, Song Jiaoren, and others establish the Tongmenghui, a Republican, anti-Qing revolutionary organisation, in Tokyo, Japan.
source_pages: Sun_Yat-sen; Song_Jiaoren; Tongmenghui; Republicanism; Anti-Qing_sentiment; Tokyo; August_20

event_text: Russo-Japanese War: In New Hampshire, United States, the Treaty of Portsmouth, mediated by U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt, ends the war.
The 7.2 Mw  Calabria earthquake shakes southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing between 557 and 2,500 people.
The Ninth Avenue derailment occurs in New York City, killing 13.
Norway and Sweden sign the Karlstad Treaty, peacefully dissolving the Union between the two countries.
Albert Einstein publishes the third of his Annus Mirabilis papers, introducing the special theory of relativity.
The Wright brothers pilot the Wright Flyer III in a new world record flight of 24 miles in 39 minutes.
The Partition of Bengal in India takes place.
King Oscar II recognizes the dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden.
Tsar Nicholas II issues the October Manifesto, nominally granting the Russian peoples basic civil liberties and the right to form a duma. (October 17 in the Julian calendar)
Lahti, a city in Finland, is granted city rights by Tsar Nicholas II of Russia, the last Grand Duke of Finland.
The Province of Alberta, Canada, holds its first general election.
Norway holds a referendum resulting in popular approval of the Storting's decision to authorise the government to make the offer of the throne of the newly independent country.
Prince Carl of Denmark becomes King Haakon VII of Norway.
Albert Einstein's paper that leads to the mass–energy equivalence formula, E = mc², is published in the journal Annalen der Physik.
Prince Carl of Denmark arrives in Norway to become King Haakon VII of Norway.
Irish nationalist Arthur Griffith founds Sinn Féin as a political party with the main aim of establishing a dual monarchy in Ireland.
In France, a law separating church and state is passed.
A workers' uprising occurs in Kyiv, Ukraine (then part of the Russian Empire), and establishes the Shuliavka Republic.
The Pushkin House is established in Saint Petersburg, Russia, to preserve the cultural heritage of Alexander Pushkin.
In Rugby Union, The "Match of the Century" is played between Wales and New Zealand at Cardiff Arms Park.
source_pages: Rugby_union; Match_of_the_Century_(rugby_union); Wales_national_rugby_union_team; New_Zealand_national_rugby_union_team; Cardiff_Arms_Park; December_16

event_text: The Tampere conference, where Vladimir Lenin and Joseph Stalin meet for the first time, is held in Tampere, Finland.
Former Idaho Governor Frank Steunenberg is assassinated at the front gate of his home in Caldwell.
SS Valencia runs aground on rocks on Vancouver Island, British Columbia, killing more than 130.
HMS Dreadnought, the first of a revolutionary new breed of battleships, is christened.
Pope Pius X publishes the encyclical Vehementer Nos.
Édouard de Laveleye forms the Belgian Olympic Committee in Brussels.
Moro Rebellion: United States Army troops bring overwhelming force against the native Moros in the First Battle of Bud Dajo, leaving only six survivors.
The Courrières mine disaster, Europe's worst ever, kills 1099 miners in northern France.
The first England vs France rugby union match is played at Parc des Princes in Paris.
The Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States (later the National Collegiate Athletic Association) is established to set rules for college sports in the United States.
Mount Vesuvius erupts and devastates Naples.
The Algeciras Conference gives France and Spain control over Morocco.
The first meeting of the Azusa Street Revival, which will launch Pentecostalism as a worldwide movement, is held in Los Angeles.
The 7.9 Mw earthquake and fire destroy much of San Francisco, California, killing more than 3,000 people, making one of the worst natural disasters in American history.
The 1906 Intercalated Games open in Athens.
The State Duma of the Russian Empire meets for the first time.
Closing ceremony of the Intercalated Games in Athens, Greece.
The Russian Constitution of 1906 is adopted (on April 23 by the Julian calendar).
The Wright brothers are granted U.S. patent number 821,393 for their "Flying-Machine".
The attempted regicide of Spanish King Alfonso XIII and Queen Victoria Eugenie on their wedding day instead kills 24
Cunard Line's RMS Lusitania is launched from the John Brown Shipyard, Glasgow (Clydebank), Scotland.
Theodore Roosevelt signs the Antiquities Act into law, authorizing the President to restrict the use of certain parcels of public land with historical or conservation value.
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania millionaire Harry Thaw shoots and kills prominent architect Stanford White.
The first Grand Prix motor race is held at Le Mans.
The United States Congress passes the Meat Inspection Act and Pure Food and Drug Act.
Murder of Grace Brown by Chester Gillette in the United States, inspiration for Theodore Dreiser's An American Tragedy.
In Finland, a new electoral law is ratified, guaranteeing the country the first and equal right to vote in the world. Finnish women are the first in Europe to receive the right to vote.
Persian Constitutional Revolution: Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar, King of Iran, agrees to convert the government to a constitutional monarchy.

The all black infantrymen of the U.S. Army's 25th Infantry Regiment are accused of killing a white bartender and wounding a white police officer in Brownsville, Texas, despite exculpatory evidence; all are later dishonorably discharged. (Their records were later restored to reflect honorable discharges but there were no financial settlements.)
The 8.2 Mw Valparaíso earthquake hits central Chile, killing 3,882 people.
Alberto Santos-Dumont flies his 14-bis aircraft at Bagatelle, France successfully for the first time.
The Newport Transporter Bridge is opened in Newport, South Wales by Viscount Tredegar.
The Santos-Dumont 14-bis makes a short hop, the first flight of a fixed-wing aircraft in Europe.
The 1906 Hong Kong typhoon kills an estimated 10,000 people.
U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt proclaims Devils Tower in Wyoming as the nation's first National Monument.
Racial tensions exacerbated by rumors lead to the Atlanta Race Riot, further increasing racial segregation.

Leonardo Torres Quevedo demonstrates the Telekino in the Bilbao Abra (Spain), guiding an electric boat from the shore with people on board, which was controlled at a distance over 2 km (1.2 mi), in what is considered to be the origin of modern wireless remote-control operation principles.
The Royal Galician Academy, the Galician language's biggest linguistic authority, starts working in La Coruña, Spain.
San Francisco sparks a diplomatic crisis between the United States and Japan by ordering segregated schools for Japanese students.
Alberto Santos-Dumont flies an airplane in the first heavier-than-air flight in Europe.
Theodore Roosevelt is the first sitting President of the United States to make an official trip outside the country, doing so to inspect progress on the Panama Canal.

A 13–6 victory by the Massillon Tigers over their rivals, the Canton Bulldogs, for the "Ohio League" Championship, leads to accusations that the championship series was fixed and results in the first major scandal in professional American football.
Alpha Phi Alpha the first intercollegiate Greek lettered fraternity for African-Americans was founded at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York.
U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in the mediation of the Russo-Japanese War, becoming the first American to win a Nobel Prize in any field.
The London Underground's Great Northern, Piccadilly and Brompton Railway opens.
An Mw  7.9 earthquake strikes Xinjiang, China, killing at least 280.
Reginald Fessenden transmits the first radio broadcast; consisting of a poetry reading, a violin solo, and a speech.
The All-India Muslim League is founded in Dacca, East Bengal, British India (later Dhaka, Bangladesh).
Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar signs the Persian Constitution of 1906.
Maria Montessori opens her first school and daycare center for working class children in Rome, Italy.
An earthquake in Kingston, Jamaica kills more than 1,000 people.
Charles Curtis of Kansas becomes the first Native American U.S. Senator.
Belgian chemist Leo Baekeland announces the creation of Bakelite, the world's first synthetic plastic.
The Mud March is the first large procession organised by the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies (NUWSS).
The first parliamentary elections of Finland (at the time the Grand Duchy of Finland) are held.
The Ellis Island immigration center processes 11,747 people, more than on any other day.
The unicameral Parliament of Finland gathers for its first plenary session.
The first Isle of Man TT race is held.
The National Association for Women's Suffrage succeeds in getting Norwegian women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.
The London Underground's Charing Cross, Euston and Hampstead Railway opens.
Florenz Ziegfeld Jr. staged his first Follies on the roof of the New York Theater in New York City.
The passenger steamer SS Columbia sinks after colliding with the steam schooner San Pedro off Shelter Cove, California, killing 88 people.

Sir Robert Baden-Powell sets up the Brownsea Island Scout camp in Poole Harbour on the south coast of England. The camp runs from August 1 to August 9 and is regarded as the foundation of the Scouting movement.
The start of the first Scout camp on Brownsea Island, the origin of the worldwide Scouting movement.
Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis fines Standard Oil of Indiana a record $29.4 million for illegal rebating to freight carriers; the conviction and fine are later reversed on appeal.
The first Boy Scout encampment concludes at Brownsea Island in southern England.
Ordination in Constantinople of Fr. Raphael Morgan, the first African-American Orthodox priest, "Priest-Apostolic" to America and the West Indies.
The Quebec Bridge collapses during construction, killing 75 workers.

Russia and the United Kingdom sign the Anglo-Russian Convention, by which the UK recognizes Russian preeminence in northern Persia, while Russia recognizes British preeminence in southeastern Persia and Afghanistan. Both powers pledge not to interfere in Tibet.
Cunard Line's RMS Lusitania sets sail on her maiden voyage from Liverpool, England, to New York City.
Four months after the 1907 Imperial Conference, New Zealand and Newfoundland are promoted from colonies to dominions within the British Empire.
The cornerstone is laid at the Cathedral Church of Saint Peter and Saint Paul (better known as Washington National Cathedral) in Washington, D.C.
The McKinley National Memorial, the final resting place of assassinated U.S. President William McKinley and his family, is dedicated in Canton, Ohio.
Marconi begins the first commercial transatlantic wireless service.
The 1907 Qaratog earthquake hits the borders of Uzbekistan and Tajikistan, killing between 12,000 and 15,000 people.
A run on the stock of the Knickerbocker Trust Company sets events in motion that will spark the Panic of 1907.
Fifteen people are killed in Hungary when gendarmes opened fire on a crowd gathered at a church consecration.
The Parliament of Finland approved the Prohibition Act, but the law was not implemented because it was not ratified by Tsar Nicholas II of Russia.
Jesús García saves the entire town of Nacozari de García by driving a burning train full of dynamite six kilometres (3.7 miles) away before it can explode.
The Cullinan Diamond is presented to King Edward VII on his birthday.
Indian Territory and Oklahoma Territory join to form Oklahoma, which is admitted as the 46th U.S. state.
A coal mine explosion at Monongah, West Virginia, kills 362 workers.
King Gustaf V of Sweden accedes to the Swedish throne.
The worst night of the Brown Dog riots in London, when 1,000 medical students, protesting against the existence of a memorial for animals that have been vivisected, clash with 400 police officers.
The New Zealand Parliament Buildings are almost completely destroyed by fire.
The Thomas W. Lawson, the largest ever ship without a heat engine, runs aground and founders near the Hellweather's Reef within the Isles of Scilly in a gale. The pilot and 15 seamen die.
Ugyen Wangchuck is crowned first King of Bhutan.
Two hundred thirty-nine coal miners die in the Darr Mine Disaster in Jacobs Creek, Pennsylvania.
The Chilean Army commits a massacre of at least 2,000 striking saltpeter miners in Iquique, Chile.
source_pages: Chilean_Army; Santa_María_School_massacre; Sodium_nitrate; Iquique; Chile; December_21

event_text: The first ever ball drop in Times Square.
Grand Canyon National Monument is created.
The Rhoads Opera House fire in Boyertown, Pennsylvania kills 171 people.
The Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority becomes the first Greek-letter organization founded and established by African American college women.
New York City passes the Sullivan Ordinance, making it illegal for women to smoke in public, only to have the measure vetoed by the mayor.
The first Boy Scout troop is organized in England by Robert Baden-Powell.
Members of the Portuguese Republican Party fail in their attempted coup d'état against the administrative dictatorship of Prime Minister João Franco.
Indian pacifist and leader Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi is released from prison by Jan C. Smuts after being tried and sentenced to two months in jail earlier in the month.
Lisbon Regicide: King Carlos I of Portugal and Infante Luis Filipe are shot dead in Lisbon.
The Collinwood school fire, Collinwood near Cleveland, Ohio, kills 174 people.
Inter Milan was founded on Football Club Internazionale, following a schism from A.C. Milan.
The Territorial Force (renamed Territorial Army in 1920) is formed as a volunteer reserve component of the British Army.
SMS Blücher, the last armored cruiser to be built by the Imperial German Navy, is launched.
Hauser Dam, a steel dam on the Missouri River in Montana, fails, sending a surge of water 25 to 30 feet (7.6 to 9.1 m) high downstream.
Natural Bridges National Monument is established in Utah.
Opening day of competition in the New South Wales Rugby League.
Mother's Day is observed for the first time in the United States, in Grafton, West Virginia.
The first major commercial oil strike in the Middle East is made at Masjed Soleyman in southwest Persia. The rights to the resource were quickly acquired by the Anglo-Persian Oil Company.
Japanese immigration to Brazil begins when 781 people arrive in Santos aboard the ship Kasato-Maru.
The University of the Philippines is established.
The Tunguska Event, the largest impact event on Earth in human recorded history, resulting in a massive explosion over Eastern Siberia.
SOS is adopted as the international distress signal.
The Second Constitution accepted by the Ottomans.
Ajinomoto is founded. Kikunae Ikeda of the Tokyo Imperial University discovers that a key ingredient in kombu soup stock is monosodium glutamate (MSG), and patents a process for manufacturing it.
United States Attorney General Charles Joseph Bonaparte issues an order to immediately staff the Office of the Chief Examiner (later renamed the Federal Bureau of Investigation).
Wilbur Wright makes his first flight at a racecourse at Le Mans, France. It is the Wright Brothers' first public flight.
The Qing dynasty promulgates the Qinding Xianfa Dagang, the first constitutional document in the history of China, transforming the Qing empire into a constitutional monarchy.
The General Motors Corporation is founded.
The Wright Flyer flown by Orville Wright, with Lieutenant Thomas Selfridge as passenger, crashes, killing Selfridge, who becomes the first airplane fatality.
Production of the Model T automobile begins at the Ford Piquette Avenue Plant in Detroit.
Ford Model T automobiles are offered for sale at a price of US$825.
The Bosnian crisis erupts when Austria-Hungary formally annexes Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Margaret Travers Symons bursts into the UK parliament and becomes the first woman to speak there.
The Chicago Cubs defeat the Detroit Tigers, 2–0, clinching the 1908 World Series; this would be their last until winning the 2016 World Series.
William Howard Taft is elected the 27th President of the United States.
The Congress of Manastir establishes the Albanian alphabet.
A fire breaks out on SS Sardinia as it leaves Malta's Grand Harbour, resulting in the ship's grounding and the deaths of at least 118 people.
A mine explosion in Marianna, Pennsylvania, kills 154 men, leaving only one survivor.
Puyi becomes Emperor of China at the age of two.
The 7.1 Mw  Messina earthquake shakes Southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing between about 80,000.
Explorer Aeneas Mackintosh of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition escaped death by fleeing across ice floes.
Ernest Shackleton, leading the Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole, plants the British flag 97 nautical miles (180 km; 112 mi) from the South Pole, the farthest anyone had ever reached at that time.
Ernest Shackleton's expedition finds the magnetic South Pole.
Newly formed automaker General Motors (GM) buys into the Oakland Motor Car Company, which later becomes GM's long-running Pontiac division.

RMS Republic, a passenger ship of the White Star Line, becomes the first ship to use the CQD distress signal after colliding with another ship, the SS Florida, off the Massachusetts coastline, an event that kills six people. The Republic sinks the next day.
Richard Strauss's opera Elektra receives its debut performance at the Dresden State Opera.
United States troops leave Cuba, with the exception of Guantanamo Bay Naval Base, after being there since the Spanish–American War.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) is founded.
New Zealand's worst maritime disaster of the 20th century happens when the SS Penguin, an inter-island ferry, sinks and explodes at the entrance to Wellington Harbour.
The Flores Theater fire in Acapulco, Mexico kills 250.
Publication of the Futurist Manifesto in the French journal Le Figaro.
The sixteen battleships of the Great White Fleet, led by USS Connecticut, return to the United States after a voyage around the world.
The AEA Silver Dart makes the first powered flight in Canada and the British Empire.
Kinemacolor, the first successful color motion picture process, is first shown to the general public at the Palace Theatre in London.

U.S. President William Taft used what became known as a Saxbe fix, a mechanism to avoid the restriction of the U.S. Constitution's Ineligibility Clause, to appoint Philander C. Knox as U.S. Secretary of State.
source_pages: William_Howard_Taft; Saxbe_fix; Constitution_of_the_United_States; Ineligibility_Clause; Philander_C._Knox; United_States_Secretary_of_State

event_text: By signing the Anglo-Siamese Treaty of 1909, Thailand relinquishes its sovereignty over the Malay states of Kedah, Kelantan, Perlis and Terengganu, which become British protectorates.
source_pages: Anglo-Siamese_Treaty_of_1909; Thailand; Sovereignty; Monarchies_of_Malaysia; Kedah; Kelantan; Perlis; Terengganu; British_protectorate; March_10

event_text: Theodore Roosevelt leaves New York for a post-presidency safari in Africa. The trip is sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution and National Geographic Society.
Serbia formally withdraws its opposition to Austro-Hungarian actions in the Bosnian Crisis.
Robert Peary and Matthew Henson become the first people to reach the North Pole; Peary's claim has been disputed because of failings in his navigational ability.
The U.S. Congress passes the Payne–Aldrich Tariff Act.
The city of Tel Aviv is founded.
The 31 March Incident leads to the overthrow of Sultan Abdul Hamid II.
Muslims in the Ottoman Empire begin a massacre of Armenians in Adana.
Joan of Arc is beatified in Rome.
In Portugal, a magnitude 6.0 earthquake strikes near Lisbon, killing at least 60 people and injuring 75.
Sultan of Ottoman Empire Abdul Hamid II is overthrown, and is succeeded by his brother, Mehmed V.
The first edition of the Giro d'Italia, a long-distance multiple-stage bicycle race, began in Milan; the Italian cyclist Luigi Ganna was the eventual winner.
The National Negro Committee, forerunner to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), convenes for the first time.
Alfred Deakin becomes Prime Minister of Australia for the third time.
The Science Museum in London comes into existence as an independent entity.
Persian Constitutional Revolution: Mohammad Ali Shah Qajar is forced out as Shah of Persia and is replaced by his son Ahmad Shah Qajar.
Louis Blériot makes the first flight across the English Channel in a heavier-than-air machine from Calais to Dover, England, United Kingdom in 37 minutes.
Alice Huyler Ramsey and three friends become the first women to complete a transcontinental auto trip, taking 59 days to travel from New York, New York to San Francisco, California.
The Indianapolis Motor Speedway opens for automobile racing. William Bourque and his mechanic are killed during the first day's events.
Workers start pouring concrete for the Panama Canal.
A group of mid-level Greek Army officers launches the Goudi coup, seeking wide-ranging reforms.
Burgess Shale fossils are discovered by Charles Doolittle Walcott.

Eugène Lefebvre crashes a new French-built Wright biplane during a test flight at Port-Aviation (often called "Juvisy Airfield") at Viry-Châtillon, south of Paris, becoming the first aviator in the world to lose his life piloting a powered heavier-than-air craft.
The Cunard Line's RMS Mauretania makes a record-breaking westbound crossing of the Atlantic, that will not be bettered for 20 years.
Foundation of Coritiba Foot Ball Club.
William Howard Taft and Porfirio Díaz hold the first summit between a U.S. and a Mexican president. They narrowly escape assassination.
Japanese occupation of Korea: An Jung-geun assassinates Japan's Resident-General of Korea.
Two United States warships are sent to Nicaragua after 500 revolutionaries (including two Americans) are executed by order of José Santos Zelaya.
In Canadian football, the First Grey Cup game is played. The University of Toronto Varsity Blues defeat the Toronto Parkdale Canoe Club, 26–6.
The Montreal Canadiens ice hockey club, the oldest surviving professional hockey franchise in the world, is founded as a charter member of the National Hockey Association.
Selma Lagerlöf becomes the first female writer to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature.
New South Wales Premier Charles Wade signs the Seat of Government Surrender Act 1909, formally completing the transfer of State land to the Commonwealth to create the Australian Capital Territory.
Captain David Beatty is promoted to rear admiral, and becomes the youngest admiral in the Royal Navy (except for royal family members) since Horatio Nelson.
Construction ends on the Buffalo Bill Dam in Wyoming, United States, which was the highest dam in the world at the time, at 99 m (325 ft).
The Boy Scouts of America is incorporated by William D. Boyce.
The deadliest avalanche in United States history buries a Great Northern Railway train in northeastern King County, Washington, killing 96 people.
French aviator Raymonde de Laroche becomes the first woman to receive a pilot's license.
Henri Fabre becomes the first person to fly a seaplane, the Fabre Hydravion, after taking off from water runway Étang le Barre, near Marseille.
The Transandine Railway connecting Chile and Argentina is inaugurated.
SMS Zrínyi, one of the last pre-dreadnought battleships built by the Austro-Hungarian Navy, is launched.[citation needed]
The oldest existing indoor ice hockey arena still used for the sport in the 21st century, Boston Arena, opens for the first time.
Frenchman Louis Paulhan wins the 1910 London to Manchester air race, the first long-distance aeroplane race in the United Kingdom.
The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the People's Budget, the first budget in British history with the expressed intent of redistributing wealth among the British public.
The Royal Canadian Navy is created.
George V becomes King of Great Britain, Ireland, and many overseas territories, on the death of his father, Edward VII.
The South Africa Act comes into force, establishing the Union of South Africa.
Charles Rolls, a co-founder of Rolls-Royce Limited, becomes the first man to make a non-stop double crossing of the English Channel by plane.
Aurel Vlaicu pilots an A. Vlaicu nr. 1 on its first flight.
The first Father's Day is celebrated in Spokane, Washington.

The United States Congress passes the Mann Act, which prohibits interstate transport of women or girls for "immoral purposes"; the ambiguous language would be used to selectively prosecute people for years to come.
Igor Stravinsky's ballet The Firebird is premiered in Paris, bringing him to prominence as a composer.
The Johnson–Jeffries riots occur after African-American boxer Jack Johnson knocks out white boxer Jim Jeffries in the 15th round. Between 11 and 26 people are killed and hundreds more injured.
In his book Clinical Psychiatry, Emil Kraepelin gives a name to Alzheimer's disease, naming it after his colleague Alois Alzheimer.
John Robertson Duigan makes the first flight of the Duigan pusher biplane, the first aircraft built in Australia.
The Ottoman Empire captures the city of Shkodër, putting down the Albanian Revolt of 1910.
The two-day Slocum massacre commences in Texas, a race riot in which more than 100 African Americans are murdered.

Extreme fire weather in the Inland Northwest of the United States causes many small wildfires to coalesce into the Great Fire of 1910, burning approximately 3 million acres (12,000 km2) and killing 87 people.
The Japan–Korea Treaty of 1910, also known as the Japan–Korea Annexation Treaty, becomes effective, officially starting the period of Japanese rule in Korea.
Premiere performance of Gustav Mahler's Symphony No. 8 in Munich (with a chorus of 852 singers and an orchestra of 171 players. Mahler's rehearsal assistant conductor was Bruno Walter).
The Duke of York's Picture House opens in Brighton, now the oldest continually operating cinema in Britain.
A large bomb destroys the Los Angeles Times building, killing 21.
In a revolution in Portugal the monarchy is overthrown and a republic is declared.
Eleftherios Venizelos is elected Prime Minister of Greece for the first of seven times.
Piloted by Arch Hoxsey, Theodore Roosevelt becomes the first U.S. president to fly in an airplane.
English aviator Claude Grahame-White lands his aircraft on Executive Avenue near the White House in Washington, D.C.
Airship America is launched from New Jersey in the first attempt to cross the Atlantic by a powered aircraft.
British ocean liner RMS Olympic is launched.
HMS Niobe arrives in Halifax Harbour to become the first ship of the Royal Canadian Navy.
Hawley Harvey Crippen (the first felon to be arrested with the help of radio) is convicted of poisoning his wife.
The first air freight shipment (from Dayton, Ohio, to Columbus, Ohio) is undertaken by the Wright brothers and department store owner Max Morehouse.
The date of Thomas A. Davis' opening of the San Diego Army and Navy Academy, although the official founding date is November 23, 1910.
Aviator Eugene Burton Ely performs the first takeoff from a ship in Hampton Roads, Virginia, taking off from a makeshift deck on the USS Birmingham in a Curtiss pusher.
source_pages: Aircraft_pilot; Eugene_Burton_Ely; Takeoff; Hampton_Roads; Virginia; USS_Birmingham_(CL-2); Curtiss_Model_D

event_text: In their campaign for women's voting rights, hundreds of suffragettes march to the British Parliament in London. Several are beaten by police, newspaper attention embarrasses the authorities, and the march is dubbed Black Friday.

Mexican Revolution: Francisco I. Madero issues the Plan de San Luis Potosí, denouncing Mexican President Porfirio Díaz, calling for a revolution to overthrow the government of Mexico, effectively starting the Mexican Revolution.
source_pages: Mexican_Revolution; Francisco_I._Madero; Plan_of_San_Luis_Potosí; Porfirio_Díaz; Revolution; Federal_government_of_Mexico

event_text: Sailors on board Brazil's warships including the Minas Gerais, São Paulo, and Bahia, violently rebel in what is now known as the Revolta da Chibata (Revolt of the Lash).
Johan Alfred Ander becomes the last person to be executed in Sweden.
Modern neon lighting is first demonstrated by Georges Claude at the Paris Motor Show.
An underground explosion at the Hulton Bank Colliery No. 3 Pit in Over Hulton, Westhoughton, England, kills 344 miners.
A magnitude 7.7 earthquake destroys the city of Almaty in Russian Turkestan.
A gun battle in the East End of London leaves two dead. It sparked a political row over the involvement of then-Home Secretary Winston Churchill.
Kappa Alpha Psi, the world's third-oldest and largest black fraternity, is founded at Indiana University.
The University of the Philippines College of Law is established.
Roald Amundsen's South Pole expedition makes landfall on the eastern edge of the Ross Ice Shelf.
Palestinian Arabic-language Falastin newspaper founded.
Eugene B. Ely lands on the deck of the USS Pennsylvania anchored in San Francisco Bay, the first time an aircraft landed on a ship.
The first Monte Carlo Rally takes place.
Mexican Revolution: Mexicali is captured by the Mexican Liberal Party, igniting the Magonista rebellion of 1911.
source_pages: Mexican_Revolution; Mexicali; Capture_of_Mexicali; Mexican_Liberal_Party; Magonista_rebellion_of_1911; January_29

event_text: The destroyer USS Terry makes the first airplane rescue at sea saving the life of Douglas McCurdy 16 kilometres (10 miles) from Havana, Cuba.

The first official flight with airmail takes place from Allahabad, United Provinces, British India (now India), when Henri Pequet, a 23-year-old pilot, delivers 6,500 letters to Naini, about 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) away.
In New York City, the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire kills 146 garment workers.
Andrey Yushchinsky is murdered in Kiev, leading to the Beilis affair.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics conducts the country's first national census.

During the Battle of Deçiq, Dedë Gjon Luli Dedvukaj, leader of the Malësori Albanians, raises the Albanian flag in the town of Tuzi, Montenegro, for the first time after George Kastrioti (Skanderbeg).
source_pages: Battle_of_Deçiq; Ded_Gjo_Luli; Malësia; Albania; Tuzi; Skanderbeg

event_text: The Second Canton Uprising took place in Guangzhou, Qing China but was suppressed.
Tsinghua University, one of mainland China's leading universities, is founded.

In Standard Oil Co. of New Jersey v. United States, the United States Supreme Court declares Standard Oil to be an "unreasonable" monopoly under the Sherman Antitrust Act and orders the company to be broken up.
More than 300 Chinese immigrants are killed in the Torreón massacre when the forces of the Mexican Revolution led by Emilio Madero take the city of Torreón from the Federales.
Parks Canada, the world's first national park service, is established as the Dominion Parks Branch under the Department of the Interior.

President of Mexico Porfirio Díaz and the revolutionary Francisco Madero sign the Treaty of Ciudad Juárez to put an end to the fighting between the forces of both men, concluding the initial phase of the Mexican Revolution.
The New York Public Library is dedicated.
At the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, the first Indianapolis 500 ends with Ray Harroun in his Marmon Wasp becoming the first winner of the 500-mile auto race.
The RMS Titanic is launched in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
The President of Mexico Porfirio Díaz flees the country during the Mexican Revolution.
IBM founded as the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company in Endicott, New York.
George V and Mary of Teck are crowned King and Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
Mexican Revolution: Government forces bring an end to the Magonista rebellion of 1911 in the Second Battle of Tijuana.
The Nakhla meteorite,  the first one to suggest signs of aqueous processes on Mars, falls to Earth, landing in Egypt.
Germany dispatches the gunboat SMS Panther to Morocco, sparking the Agadir Crisis.
A massive heat wave strikes the northeastern United States, killing 380 people in eleven days and breaking temperature records in several cities.
The United States, UK, Japan, and Russia sign the North Pacific Fur Seal Convention of 1911 banning open-water seal hunting, the first international treaty to address wildlife preservation issues.
Harry Atwood, an exhibition pilot for the Wright brothers, is greeted by President Taft after he lands his aeroplane on the South Lawn of the White House, having flown from Boston.
source_pages: Harry_Atwood; Wright_brothers; William_Howard_Taft; South_Lawn; Boston; July_14

event_text: Hiram Bingham III re-discovers Machu Picchu, "the Lost City of the Incas".
The Australasian Antarctic Expedition began as the SY Aurora departed London.
Harriet Quimby takes her pilot's test and becomes the first U.S. woman to earn an Aero Club of America aviator's certificate.
The Mona Lisa is stolen by Vincenzo Peruggia, a Louvre employee.
Manuel de Arriaga is elected and sworn in as the first President of Portugal.
Ishi, considered the last Native American to make contact with European Americans, emerges from the wilderness of northeastern California.
The Canadian Naval Service becomes the Royal Canadian Navy.
A fire that started on Fraser's Million Dollar Pier destroys six to eight square blocks of Ocean Park, California.
French poet Guillaume Apollinaire is arrested and put in jail on suspicion of stealing the Mona Lisa from the Louvre museum.
Russian Premier Pyotr Stolypin is shot by Dmitry Bogrov while attending a performance of Rimsky-Korsakov's The Tale of Tsar Saltan at the Kiev Opera House, in the presence of Tsar Nicholas II.
source_pages: Pyotr_Stolypin; Dmitrii_Bogrov; Nikolai_Rimsky-Korsakov; The_Tale_of_Tsar_Saltan_(opera); Nicholas_II; September_14

event_text: The White Star Line's RMS Olympic collides with the British warship HMS Hawke.
His Majesty's Airship No. 1, Britain's first rigid airship, is wrecked by strong winds before her maiden flight at Barrow-in-Furness.
An explosion of badly degraded propellant charges on board the French battleship Liberté detonates the forward ammunition magazines and destroys the ship.
Italy declares war on the Ottoman Empire.
The Kowloon–Canton Railway commences service.
An accidental bomb explosion triggers the Wuchang Uprising against the Qing dynasty, beginning the Xinhai Revolution.
The day after a bomb explodes prematurely, the Wuchang Uprising begins against the Chinese monarchy.
Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn, becomes the first Governor General of Canada of royal descent.
The Italo-Turkish War sees the first use of an airplane in combat when an Italian pilot makes a reconnaissance flight.
Orville Wright remains in the air nine minutes and 45 seconds in a glider at Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina.
The Xinhai Revolution spreads to Guangzhou, where the Qing general Fengshan is assassinated by the Chinese Assassination Corps.
World's first combat aerial bombing mission takes place in Libya during the Italo-Turkish War. Second Lieutenant Giulio Gavotti of Italy drops several small bombs.
Chevrolet officially enters the automobile market in competition with the Ford Model T.
After declaring war on the Ottoman Empire on September 29, 1911, Italy annexes Tripoli and Cyrenaica.
Many cities in the Midwestern United States break their record highs and lows on the same day as a strong cold front rolls through.
The Doom Bar in Cornwall claims two ships, Island Maid and Angele, the latter killing the entire crew except the captain.
A mine explosion near Briceville, Tennessee, kills 84 miners despite rescue efforts led by the United States Bureau of Mines.
Roald Amundsen's team, comprising himself, Olav Bjaaland, Helmer Hanssen, Sverre Hassel, and Oscar Wisting, becomes the first to reach the South Pole.
source_pages: Roald_Amundsen; Olav_Bjaaland; Helmer_Hanssen; Sverre_Hassel; Oscar_Wisting; South_Pole

event_text: "Jana Gana Mana", the national anthem of India, is first sung in the Calcutta Session of the Indian National Congress.
Mongolia gains independence from the Qing dynasty, enthroning 8th Jebtsundamba Khutughtu as Khagan of Mongolia.
The Republic of China is established.
The Scout Association is incorporated throughout the British Empire by royal charter.

The sixth All-Russian Conference of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Prague Party Conference) opens. In the course of the conference, Vladimir Lenin and his supporters break from the rest of the party to form the Bolshevik movement.
New Mexico is admitted to the Union as the 47th U.S. state.
German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presents his theory of continental drift.
The African National Congress is founded, under the name South African Native National Congress (SANNC).
Immigrant textile workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts, go on strike when wages are reduced in response to a mandated shortening of the work week.
British polar explorer Captain Robert Falcon Scott reaches the South Pole, one month after Roald Amundsen.
The International Opium Convention is signed at The Hague.
The Xuantong Emperor, the last Emperor of China, abdicates.
Arizona is admitted as the 48th and the last contiguous U.S. state.
The U.S. Navy commissions its first class of diesel-powered submarines.
Marie-Adélaïde, the eldest of six daughters of Guillaume IV, becomes the first reigning Grand Duchess of Luxembourg.
Italo-Turkish War: Italian forces are the first to use airships for military purposes, employing them for reconnaissance behind Turkish lines.
Italo-Turkish War: Italian forces become the first to use airships in war, as two dirigibles drop bombs on Turkish troops encamped at Janzur, from an altitude of 1,800 m.
The Girl Guides (later renamed the Girl Scouts of the USA) are founded in the United States.

First Lady Helen Taft and the Viscountess Chinda, wife of the Japanese ambassador, plant two Yoshino cherry trees on the northern bank of the Potomac River in Washington, D.C., the origin of the National Cherry Blossom Festival.
source_pages: Helen_Herron_Taft; Cherry; Potomac_River; Washington,_D.C.; National_Cherry_Blossom_Festival; March_27

event_text: Sultan Abd al-Hafid signs the Treaty of Fez, making Morocco a French protectorate.
The ill-fated RMS Titanic begins sea trials.
RMS Titanic sets sail from Southampton, England on her maiden and only voyage.
The British passenger liner RMS Titanic hits an iceberg in the North Atlantic and begins to sink.
The British passenger liner RMS Titanic sinks in the North Atlantic at 2:20 a.m., two hours and forty minutes after hitting an iceberg. Only 710 of 2,224 passengers and crew on board survive.
Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly an airplane across the English Channel.
Russian troops open fire on striking goldfield workers in northeast Siberia, killing at least 150.
The Cunard liner RMS Carpathia brings 705 survivors from the RMS Titanic to New York City.
Italy occupies the Ottoman island of Rhodes.
The first issue of the Bolshevik newspaper Pravda was published.
The Royal Flying Corps, the forerunner of the Royal Air Force, is established in the United Kingdom.
The first Indian film, Shree Pundalik by Dadasaheb Torne, is released in Mumbai.
Massachusetts becomes the first state of the United States to set a minimum wage.
The eruption of Novarupta in Alaska begins. It is the largest volcanic eruption of the 20th century.
The Regina Cyclone, Canada's deadliest tornado event, kills 28 people in Regina, Saskatchewan.
Henrique Mitchell de Paiva Couceiro leads an unsuccessful royalist attack against the First Portuguese Republic in Chaves.
Japan's Emperor Meiji dies and is succeeded by his son Yoshihito, who is now known as the Emperor Taishō.
The Kuomintang is founded for the first time in Peking.
A typhoon strikes China, killing at least 50,000 people.
Arthur Rose Eldred is awarded the first Eagle Scout award of the Boy Scouts of America.
Albanian rebels succeed in their revolt when the Ottoman Empire agrees to fulfill their demands
Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism is founded in New York City.
The Ulster Covenant is signed by some 500,000 Ulster Unionists in opposition to the Third Irish Home Rule Bill.
Corporal Frank S. Scott of the United States Army becomes the first enlisted man to die in an airplane crash.
U.S. forces defeat Nicaraguan rebels at the Battle of Coyotepe Hill.
The Helsinki Stock Exchange sees its first transaction.
The First Balkan War begins when Montenegro declares war against the Ottoman Empire.
First Balkan War: The day after the Battle of Sarantaporo, Greek troops liberate the city of Kozani.
Former president Theodore Roosevelt is shot and mildly wounded by John Flammang Schrank. With the fresh wound in his chest, and the bullet still within it, Roosevelt delivers his scheduled speech.
Bulgaria, Greece and Serbia declare war on the Ottoman Empire, joining Montenegro in the First Balkan War.
First Balkan War: King Peter I of Serbia issues a declaration "To the Serbian People", as his country joins the war.
Italo-Turkish War: Italy takes possession of what is now Libya from the Ottoman Empire.
First Balkan War: The Greek navy completes the capture of the island of Lemnos for use as a forward base against the Dardanelles.
First Balkan War: The Battle of Kumanovo between the Serbian and Ottoman armies begins.
First Balkan War: The Battle of Kirk Kilisse concludes with a Bulgarian victory against the Ottoman Empire.
First Balkan War: The Battle of Kumanovo concludes with the Serbian victory against the Ottoman Empire.
First Balkan War: The Ottomans lose the cities of Thessaloniki and Skopje.
Bulgaria defeats the Ottoman Empire in the Battle of Lule Burgas, the bloodiest battle of the First Balkan War, which opens her way to Constantinople.
source_pages: Kingdom_of_Bulgaria; Ottoman_Empire; Battle_of_Lule_Burgas; First_Balkan_War; Constantinople; November_2

event_text: Woodrow Wilson is elected the 28th President of the United States, defeating incumbent William Howard Taft.
The Deutsche Opernhaus (now Deutsche Oper Berlin) opens in the Berlin neighborhood of Charlottenburg, with a production of Beethoven's Fidelio.
First Balkan War: King George I of Greece makes a triumphal entry into Thessaloniki after its liberation from 482 years of Ottoman rule.
The frozen bodies of Robert Scott and his men are found on the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica.
First Balkan War: The Serbian Army captures Bitola, ending the five-century-long Ottoman rule of Macedonia.
Românul de la Pind, the longest-running newspaper by and about Aromanians until World War II, ceases its publications.
Spain declares a protectorate over the north shore of Morocco.
Albania declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire.

Bulgaria, Greece, Montenegro, and Serbia (the Balkan League) sign an armistice with the Ottoman Empire, temporarily halting the First Balkan War. (The armistice will expire on February 3, 1913, and hostilities will resume.)
source_pages: Kingdom_of_Bulgaria; Kingdom_of_Greece; Kingdom_of_Montenegro; Kingdom_of_Serbia; Balkan_League; Ottoman_Empire; First_Balkan_War

event_text: The Nefertiti Bust is discovered.
Leaders of the German Empire hold an Imperial War Council to discuss the possibility that war might break out.
First Balkan War: The Royal Hellenic Navy defeats the Ottoman Navy at the Battle of Elli.

William Van Schaick, captain of the steamship General Slocum which caught fire and killed over one thousand people, is pardoned by U.S. President William Howard Taft after 3+1⁄2 years in Sing Sing prison.
The first municipally owned streetcars take to the streets in San Francisco.
An Atlantic coast storm sets the lowest confirmed barometric pressure reading (955.0 mb (28.20 inHg)) for a non-tropical system in the continental United States.
First Balkan War: Greece completes its capture of the eastern Aegean island of Chios, as the last Ottoman forces on the island surrender.

First Balkan War: The Battle of Lemnos begins; Greek admiral Pavlos Kountouriotis forces the Turkish fleet to retreat to its base within the Dardanelles, from which it did not venture for the rest of the war.

Indian mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan writes his first letter to G. H. Hardy at Cambridge, stating without proof various formulae involving integrals, infinite series, and continued fractions, beginning a long correspondence between the two as well as widespread recognition of Ramanujan's results.
source_pages: Srinivasa_Ramanujan; G._H._Hardy; University_of_Cambridge; Integral; Series_(mathematics); Continued_fraction; January_16

event_text: First Balkan War: A Greek flotilla defeats the Ottoman Navy in the Naval Battle of Lemnos, securing the islands of the Northern Aegean Sea for Greece.
The Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, authorizing the Federal government to impose and collect an income tax.
Greek military aviators Michael Moutoussis and Aristeidis Moraitinis perform the first naval air mission in history, with a Farman MF.7 hydroplane.
Claudio Monteverdi's last opera L'incoronazione di Poppea was performed theatrically for the first time in more than 250 years.
A group of meteors is visible across much of the eastern seaboard of the Americas, leading astronomers to conclude the source had been a small, short-lived natural satellite of the Earth.
The 13th Dalai Lama proclaims Tibetan independence following a period of domination by Manchu Qing dynasty and initiated a period of almost four decades of independence.
The Armory Show opens in New York City, displaying works of artists who are to become some of the most influential painters of the early 20th century.
Pedro Lascuráin becomes President of Mexico for 45 minutes; this is the shortest term to date of any person as president of any country.
King O'Malley drives in the first survey peg to mark commencement of work on the construction of Canberra.
Ioannina is incorporated into the Greek state after the Balkan Wars.
Thousands of women march in the Woman Suffrage Procession in Washington, D.C.
First Balkan War: The Greek army engages the Turks at Bizani, resulting in victory two days later.
The United States Department of Labor is formed.
The future capital of Australia is officially named Canberra.
King George I of Greece is assassinated in the recently liberated city of Thessaloniki.
Sung Chiao-jen, a founder of the Chinese Nationalist Party, is wounded in an assassination attempt and dies 2 days later.

Mystic Phan Xích Long, the self-proclaimed Emperor of Vietnam, is arrested for organising a revolt against the colonial rule of French Indochina, which was nevertheless carried out by his supporters the following day.
A tornado outbreak kills more than 240 people in the central United States, while an ongoing flood in the Ohio River watershed was killing 650 people.
First Balkan War: Bulgarian forces capture Adrianople.

The Vienna Concert Society rioted during a performance of modernist music by Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, Alexander von Zemlinsky, and Anton von Webern, causing a premature end to the concert due to violence; this concert became known as the Skandalkonzert.
source_pages: Modernism_(music); Arnold_Schoenberg; Alban_Berg; Alexander_von_Zemlinsky; Anton_Webern; Skandalkonzert

event_text: First Balkan War: Greek aviator Emmanouil Argyropoulos becomes the first pilot to die in the Hellenic Air Force when his plane crashes.
The Woolworth Building, a skyscraper in New York City, is opened.
Raja Harishchandra, the first full-length Indian feature film, is released, marking the beginning of the Indian film industry.
Governor of New York William Sulzer approves the charter for the Rockefeller Foundation, which begins operations with a $100 million donation from John D. Rockefeller.
Igor Stravinsky's ballet score The Rite of Spring receives its premiere performance in Paris, France, provoking a riot.
The Treaty of London is signed, ending the First Balkan War; Albania becomes an independent nation.
The Greek–Serbian Treaty of Alliance is signed, paving the way for the Second Balkan War.
Emily Davison, a suffragette, runs out in front of King George V's horse at The Derby. She is trampled, never regains consciousness, and dies four days later.
Natives Land Act, 1913 in South Africa implemented.
Second Balkan War: The Greeks defeat the Bulgarians in the Battle of Doiran.
Greece and Serbia annul their alliance with Bulgaria.
American Civil War veterans begin arriving at the Great Reunion of 1913.

Confederate veterans at the Great Reunion of 1913 reenact Pickett's Charge; upon reaching the high-water mark of the Confederacy they are met by the outstretched hands of friendship from Union survivors.
President Woodrow Wilson addresses American Civil War veterans at the Great Reunion of 1913.
Serbian forces begin their siege of the Bulgarian city of Vidin; the siege is later called off when the war ends.
The Second Revolution breaks out against the Beiyang government, as Li Liejun proclaims Jiangxi independent from the Republic of China.
source_pages: Second_Revolution_(Republic_of_China); Beiyang_government; Li_Liejun; Jiangxi; Republic_of_China_(1912–1949); July_12

event_text: The 1913 Romanian Army cholera outbreak during the Second Balkan War starts.
Second Balkan War: Delegates from Bulgaria, Romania, Serbia, Montenegro, and Greece sign the Treaty of Bucharest, ending the war.
source_pages: Second_Balkan_War; Bulgaria; Romania; Serbia; Montenegro; Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1913)

event_text: First production in the UK of stainless steel by Harry Brearley.
Tōhoku Imperial University of Japan (modern day Tohoku University) becomes the first university in Japan to admit female students.
Completion of the Royal Navy battlecruiser HMS Queen Mary.
Queen Wilhelmina opens the Peace Palace in The Hague.
The United Mine Workers of America launch a strike which eventually escalated into the Colorado Coalfield War.
Ford Motor Company introduces the first moving vehicle assembly line.
The steamship SS Volturno catches fire in the mid-Atlantic.
U.S. President Woodrow Wilson triggers the explosion of the Gamboa Dike, completing major construction on the Panama Canal.
Senghenydd colliery disaster, the United Kingdom's worst coal mining accident, claims the lives of 439 miners.
Dedication of the Lincoln Highway, the first automobile highway across United States.
The Indianapolis Streetcar Strike and subsequent riot begins.
King Otto of Bavaria is deposed by his cousin, Prince Regent Ludwig, who assumes the title Ludwig III.

The first day of the Great Lakes Storm of 1913, a massive blizzard that ultimately killed 250 and caused over $5 million (about $159,243,000 in 2024 dollars) damage. Winds reach hurricane force on this date.

The Great Lakes Storm of 1913, the most destructive natural disaster ever to hit the lakes, reaches its greatest intensity after beginning two days earlier. The storm destroys 19 ships and kills more than 250 people.
The Buenos Aires Metro, the first underground railway system in the Southern Hemisphere and in Latin America, begins operation.
Crete, having obtained self rule from Turkey after the First Balkan War, is annexed by Greece.
More than two years after it was stolen from the Louvre, Leonardo da Vinci's painting Mona Lisa is recovered in Florence, Italy. The thief, Vincenzo Peruggia, is immediately arrested.
source_pages: Louvre; Leonardo_da_Vinci; Mona_Lisa; Florence; Vincenzo_Peruggia; December_11

event_text: Haruna, the fourth and last Kongō-class ship, launches, eventually becoming one of the Japanese workhorses during World War I and World War II.
Arthur Wynne's "word-cross", the first crossword puzzle, is published in the New York World.
The Federal Reserve Act is signed into law by President Woodrow Wilson, creating the Federal Reserve System.
The Italian Hall disaster in Calumet, Michigan results in the deaths of 73 striking workers families at a Christmas party participants (including 59 children) when someone falsely yells "fire".
Cecil B. DeMille starts filming Hollywood's first feature film, The Squaw Man.
The SPT Airboat Line becomes the world's first scheduled airline to use a winged aircraft.
The Ford Motor Company announces an eight-hour workday and minimum daily wage of $5 in salary plus bonuses.
The Phi Beta Sigma fraternity is founded by African-American students at Howard University in Washington D.C., United States.
The Karluk, flagship of the Canadian Arctic Expedition, sinks after being crushed by ice.
Copyright: In New York City the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers is established to protect the copyrighted musical compositions of its members.
HMHS Britannic, sister to the RMS Titanic, is launched at Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast.
China joins the Universal Postal Union.
In the Curragh incident over 100 British Army officers threatened to resign if ordered to march against the Ulster Volunteers.
The Greek multi-sport club Aris Thessaloniki is founded in Thessaloniki.
Nineteen men, women, and children participating in a strike are killed in the Ludlow Massacre during the Colorado Coalfield War.
Ypiranga incident: A German arms shipment to Mexico is intercepted by the U.S. Navy near Veracruz.
The Franck–Hertz experiment, a pillar of quantum mechanics, is presented to the German Physical Society.
The Protocol of Corfu is signed, recognising full autonomy to Northern Epirus under nominal Albanian sovereignty.
The House of Commons of the United Kingdom passes the Home Rule Bill for devolution in Ireland.
The Ocean liner RMS Empress of Ireland sinks in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence with the loss of 1,012 lives.
The new, and then the largest, Cunard ocean liner RMS Aquitania, 45,647 tons, sets sails on her maiden voyage from Liverpool, England, to New York City.
Massacre of Phocaea: Turkish irregulars slaughter 50 to 100 Greeks and expel thousands of others in an ethnic cleansing operation in the Ottoman Empire.
Mexican Revolution: Pancho Villa takes Zacatecas from Victoriano Huerta.
The Illinois Monument is dedicated at Cheatham Hill in what is now the Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park.
Causes of World War I: Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife Sophie are assassinated in Sarajevo, beginning the July Crisis and providing the casus belli of World War I.
source_pages: Causes_of_World_War_I; Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria; Sophie,_Duchess_of_Hohenberg; Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand; July_Crisis; Casus_belli; World_War_I

event_text: The funeral of Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sophie takes place in Vienna, six days after their assassinations in Sarajevo.
Babe Ruth makes his debut in Major League Baseball.
The US Navy launches the USS Nevada (BB-36) as its first standard-type battleship.
The U.S. Congress forms the Aviation Section, U.S. Signal Corps, giving official status to aircraft within the U.S. Army for the first time.

July Crisis: Austria-Hungary issues a series of demands in an ultimatum to the Kingdom of Serbia demanding Serbia to allow the Austrians to determine who assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand. Serbia accepts all but one of those demands and Austria declares war on July 28.
source_pages: July_Crisis; Austria-Hungary; Ultimatum_of_July_23,_1914; Kingdom_of_Serbia; Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand; Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria; July_28

event_text: In the culmination of the July Crisis, Austria-Hungary declares war on Serbia, igniting World War I.
The Cape Cod Canal opened.
World War I: The German Empire declares war on the Russian Empire.
World War I: The Swiss Army mobilizes because of World War I.
The German occupation of Luxembourg during World War I begins.
World War I: Germany declares war against France, while Romania declares its neutrality.
World War I: In response to the German invasion of Belgium, Belgium and the British Empire declare war on Germany. The United States declares its neutrality.
World War I: The German minelayer SS Königin Luise lays a minefield about 40 miles (64 km) off the Thames Estuary (Lowestoft). She is intercepted and sunk by the British light-cruiser HMS Amphion.
source_pages: World_War_I; Minelayer; SS_Königin_Luise_(1913); Thames_Estuary; Lowestoft; HMS_Amphion_(1911)

event_text: World War I: The guns of Point Nepean fort at Port Phillip Heads in Victoria (Australia) fire across the bows of the Norddeutscher Lloyd steamer SS Pfalz which is attempting to leave the Port of Melbourne in ignorance of the declaration of war and she is detained; this is said to be the first Allied shot of the War.
In Cleveland, Ohio, the first electric traffic light is installed.

World War I: U-boat campaign: Two days after the United Kingdom had declared war on Germany over the German invasion of Belgium, ten German U-boats leave their base in Heligoland to attack Royal Navy warships in the North Sea.
source_pages: World_War_I; U-boat_campaign; U-boat; Heligoland; Royal_Navy; North_Sea

event_text: World War I: Serbia declares war on Germany; Austria declares war on Russia.
World War I: The United Kingdom and the British Empire declare war on Austria-Hungary.
World War I: The Battle of Halen a.k.a. Battle of the Silver Helmets a clash between large Belgian and German cavalry formations at Halen, Belgium.
World War I: Start of the Battle of Lorraine, an unsuccessful French offensive.
A servant of American architect, Frank Lloyd Wright, sets fire to the living quarters of Wright's Wisconsin home, Taliesin, and murders seven people there.
The Panama Canal opens to traffic with the transit of the cargo ship SS Ancon.
World War I: The First Russian Army, led by Paul von Rennenkampf, enters East Prussia.
World War I: Beginning of the Battle of Cer, the first Allied victory of World War I.
World War I: Battle of Stallupönen: The German army of General Hermann von François defeats the Russian force commanded by Paul von Rennenkampf near modern-day Nesterov, Russia.
source_pages: World_War_I; Battle_of_Stallupönen; General_officer; Hermann_von_François; Paul_von_Rennenkampf; Nesterov

event_text: World War I: Brussels is captured during the German invasion of Belgium.
World War I: The Battle of Charleroi, a successful German attack across the River Sambre that pre-empted a French offensive in the same area.
World War I: The British Expeditionary Force and the French Fifth Army begin their Great Retreat before the German Army.
World War I: Japan declares war on Germany.
World War I: German troops capture Namur.
World War I: The Battle of Cer ends as the first Allied victory in the war.
World War I: Japan declares war on Austria-Hungary.

World War I: The library of the Catholic University of Leuven is deliberately destroyed by the German Army. Hundreds of thousands of irreplaceable volumes and Gothic and Renaissance manuscripts are lost.
World War I: The German colony of Togoland surrenders to French and British forces after a 20-day campaign. Togoland is the first German colony to fall to Allied hands in World War I.
