World War I: During the retreat from Mons, the British II Corps commanded by General Sir Horace Smith-Dorrien fights a vigorous and successful defensive action at Le Cateau.
World War I: Battle of Étreux: A British rearguard action by the Royal Munster Fusiliers during the Great Retreat.
World War I: Siege of Tsingtao: A Japanese fleet commanded by Vice Admiral Sadakichi Kato imposes a blockade along the whole coastline of German Tsingtao, initiating the Siege of Tsingtao.
World War I: The Royal Navy defeats the German fleet in the Battle of Heligoland Bight.
World War I: Start of the Battle of St. Quentin in which the French Fifth Army counter-attacked the invading Germans at Saint-Quentin, Aisne.
World War I: Germans defeat the Russians in the Battle of Tannenberg.
William, Prince of Albania leaves the country after just six months due to opposition to his rule.
French composer Albéric Magnard is killed defending his estate against invading German soldiers.
World War I: Start of the Battle of Grand Couronné, a German assault against French positions on high ground near the city of Nancy.
World War I: First Battle of the Marne begins. Northeast of Paris, the French attack and defeat German forces who are advancing on the capital.
World War I: The First Battle of the Marne, which would halt the Imperial German Army's advance into France, begins.
World War I: Private Thomas Highgate becomes the first British soldier to be executed for desertion during the war.
World War I: The creation of the Canadian Automobile Machine Gun Brigade, the first fully mechanized unit in the British Army.
World War I: Australia invades German New Guinea, defeating a German contingent at the Battle of Bita Paka.

The Second Period of Russification: The teaching of the Russian language and Russian history in Finnish schools is ordered to be considerably increased as part of the forced Russification program in Finland run by Tsar Nicholas II.
source_pages: Russification_of_Finland; Russian_language; History_of_Russia; Grand_Duchy_of_Finland; Nicholas_II; September_11

event_text: HMAS AE1, the Royal Australian Navy's first submarine, is lost at sea with all hands near East New Britain, Papua New Guinea.
World War I: The Siege of Przemyśl (present-day Poland) begins.
Andrew Fisher becomes Prime Minister of Australia for the third time.
World War I: The Race to the Sea begins.
The Irish Home Rule Act becomes law, but is delayed until after World War I.
A German submarine sinks three British cruisers over a seventy-minute period, killing almost 1,500 sailors.
The United States Federal Trade Commission is established by the Federal Trade Commission Act.
World War I: An aircraft successfully destroys another aircraft with gunfire for the first time.
World War I: The Siege of Antwerp comes to an end.
The Schoenstatt Apostolic Movement is founded in Germany.
World War I: The First Battle of Ypres begins.
World War I: The new British battleship HMS Audacious is sunk by a minefield laid by the armed German merchant-cruiser Berlin.
Ottoman entry into World War I.

World War I: The first British Royal Navy defeat of the war with Germany, the Battle of Coronel, is fought off of the western coast of Chile, in the Pacific, with the loss of HMS Good Hope and HMS Monmouth.
source_pages: World_War_I; Royal_Navy; Battle_of_Coronel; Chile; HMS_Good_Hope_(1901); HMS_Monmouth_(1901)

event_text: World War I: The Australian Imperial Force (AIF) departed by ship in a single convoy from Albany, Western Australia bound for Egypt.
World War I: The Russian Empire declares war on the Ottoman Empire and the Dardanelles is subsequently closed.
World War I: France and the British Empire declare war on the Ottoman Empire.
The German colony of Kiaochow Bay and its centre at Tsingtao are captured by Japanese forces.
SMS Emden is sunk by HMAS Sydney in the Battle of Cocos.
Zaian War: Berber tribesmen inflict the heaviest defeat of French forces in Morocco at the Battle of El Herri.
The Joensuu City Hall, designed by Eliel Saarinen, was inaugurated in Joensuu, Finland.
The Federal Reserve Bank of the United States officially opens.
Mexican Revolution: The last of U.S. forces withdraw from Veracruz, occupied seven months earlier in response to the Tampico Affair.
HMS Bulwark is destroyed by a large internal explosion with the loss of 741 men while at anchor near Sheerness.
World War I: Following a war-induced closure in July, the New York Stock Exchange re-opens for bond trading.
The Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition began in an attempt to make the first land crossing of Antarctica.
World War I: A squadron of Britain's Royal Navy defeats the Imperial German East Asia Squadron in the Battle of the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic.
Lisandro de la Torre and others found the Democratic Progressive Party (Partido Demócrata Progresista, PDP) at the Hotel Savoy, Buenos Aires, Argentina.
World War I: The Serbian Army recaptures Belgrade from the invading Austro-Hungarian Army.
A gas explosion at Mitsubishi Hōjō coal mine, in Kyushu, Japan, kills 687.
World War I: Admiral Franz von Hipper commands a raid on Scarborough, Hartlepool and Whitby.
World War I: Australian and New Zealand troops arrive in Cairo, Egypt.
World War I: During the Battle of Sarikamish, Ottoman forces mistook one another for Russian troops. The following friendly fire incident leaves 2,000 Ottomans dead and many more wounded.
World War I: The "Christmas truce" begins.
World War I: A series of unofficial truces occur across the Western Front to celebrate Christmas.
The United States House of Representatives rejects a proposed constitutional amendment to require states to give women the right to vote.
The 6.7 Mw  Avezzano earthquake shakes the Province of L'Aquila in Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing between 29,978 and 32,610.
Russia defeats Ottoman Turkey in the Battle of Sarikamish during the Caucasus Campaign of World War I.
Japan issues the "Twenty-One Demands" to the Republic of China in a bid to increase its power in East Asia.
Georges Claude patents the neon discharge tube for use in advertising.

German strategic bombing during World War I: German zeppelins bomb the towns of Great Yarmouth and King's Lynn in the United Kingdom killing at least 20 people, in the first major aerial bombardment of a civilian target.
Kiwanis International is founded in Detroit.
Over 600 people are killed in Guadalajara, Mexico, when a train plunges off the tracks into a deep canyon.
World War I: British Grand Fleet battle cruisers under Vice-Admiral Sir David Beatty engage Rear-Admiral Franz von Hipper's battle cruisers in the Battle of Dogger Bank.
Alexander Graham Bell inaugurates U.S. transcontinental telephone service, speaking from New York to Thomas Watson in San Francisco.
The Rocky Mountain National Park is established by an act of the U.S. Congress.
An act of the U.S. Congress creates the United States Coast Guard as a branch of the United States Armed Forces.
World War I: Germany is the first to make large-scale use of poison gas in warfare in the Battle of Bolimów against Russia.
source_pages: World_War_I; German_Empire; Chemical_weapons_in_World_War_I; Battle_of_Humin-Bolimów; Russian_Empire; January_31

event_text: D. W. Griffith's controversial landmark film The Birth of a Nation premieres in Los Angeles.
U-boat Campaign: The Imperial German Navy institutes unrestricted submarine warfare in the waters around Great Britain and Ireland.
World War I: The first naval attack on the Dardanelles begins when a strong Anglo-French task force bombards Ottoman artillery along the coast of Gallipoli.
World War I: During the Battle of Gallipoli, three battleships are sunk during a failed British and French naval attack on the Dardanelles.
The Vancouver Millionaires win the 1915 Stanley Cup Finals, the first championship played between the Pacific Coast Hockey Association and the National Hockey Association.
Typhoid Mary, the first healthy carrier of disease ever identified in the United States, is put in quarantine for the second time, where she would remain for the rest of her life.
World War I: French pilot Roland Garros is shot down and glides to a landing on the German side of the lines.
World War I: The use of poison gas in World War I escalates when chlorine gas is released as a chemical weapon in the Second Battle of Ypres.
The arrest of 250 Armenian intellectuals and community leaders in Istanbul marks the beginning of the Armenian genocide.

World War I: The Battle of Gallipoli begins: The invasion of the Turkish Gallipoli Peninsula by British, French, Indian, Newfoundland, Australian and New Zealand troops, begins with landings at Anzac Cove and Cape Helles.
World War I: Italy secretly signs the Treaty of London pledging to join the Allied Powers.
RMS Lusitania departs from New York City on her 202nd, and final, crossing of the North Atlantic. Six days later, the ship is torpedoed off the coast of Ireland with the loss of 1,198 lives.
Babe Ruth, then a pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, hits his first major league home run.
Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition: The SY Aurora broke loose from its anchorage during a gale, beginning a 312-day ordeal.

World War I: German submarine U-20 sinks RMS Lusitania, killing 1,199 people, including 128 Americans. Public reaction to the sinking turns many former pro-Germans in the United States against the German Empire.
source_pages: World_War_I; Submarine; SM_U-20_(Germany); Sinking_of_the_RMS_Lusitania; RMS_Lusitania; German_Empire

event_text: The Republic of China accedes to 13 of the 21 Demands, extending the Empire of Japan's control over Manchuria and the Chinese economy.
World War I: Second Battle of Artois between German and French forces.
The May 14 Revolt takes place in Lisbon, Portugal.
The last British Liberal Party government (led by H. H. Asquith) falls.
Lassen Peak erupts with a powerful force, the only volcano besides Mount St. Helens to erupt in the contiguous U.S. during the 20th century.
Three trains collide in the Quintinshill rail disaster near Gretna Green, Scotland, killing 227 people and injuring 246.
World War I: Italy joins the Allies, fulfilling its part of the Treaty of London.
World War I: Italy declares war on Austria-Hungary, joining the conflict on the side of the Allies.
HMS Princess Irene explodes and sinks off Sheerness, Kent, with the loss of 352 lives.
Denmark amends its constitution to allow women's suffrage.
William Jennings Bryan resigns as Woodrow Wilson's Secretary of State over a disagreement regarding the United States' handling of the sinking of the RMS Lusitania.

The U.S. Supreme Court hands down its decision in Guinn v. United States 238 US 347 1915, striking down Oklahoma grandfather clause legislation which had the effect of denying the right to vote to blacks.
The North Saskatchewan River flood of 1915 is the worst flood in Edmonton history.

Leutnant Kurt Wintgens of the then-named German Deutsches Heer's Fliegertruppe army air service achieves the first known aerial victory with a synchronized machine-gun armed fighter plane, the Fokker M.5K/MG Eindecker.
source_pages: Leutnant; Kurt_Wintgens; Imperial_German_Army; Luftstreitkräfte; Synchronization_gear; Fokker_E.I

event_text: The Liberty Bell leaves Philadelphia by special train on its way to the Panama–Pacific International Exposition.  This is the last trip outside Philadelphia that the custodians of the bell intend to permit.
The First Battle of the Isonzo comes to an end.
Colombo Town Guard officer Henry Pedris is executed in British Ceylon for allegedly inciting persecution of Muslims.
Beginning of the McMahon–Hussein Correspondence between Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca and the British official Henry McMahon concerning the Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire.
source_pages: McMahon–Hussein_correspondence; Hussein_bin_Ali,_King_of_Hejaz; Henry_McMahon; Arab_Revolt; Ottoman_Empire; July_14

event_text: Henry James becomes a British citizen to highlight his commitment to Britain during the first World War.

At Treasure Island on the Delaware River in the United States, the First Order of the Arrow ceremony takes place and the Order of the Arrow is founded to honor American Boy Scouts who best exemplify the Scout Oath and Law.

The passenger ship SS Eastland capsizes while tied to a dock in the Chicago River. A total of 844 passengers and crew are killed in the largest loss of life disaster from a single shipwreck on the Great Lakes.
RFC Captain Lanoe Hawker becomes the first British pursuit aviator to earn the Victoria Cross.
The United States begins a 19-year occupation of Haiti.
Patrick Pearse gives his famous speech "Ireland unfree shall never be at peace" at O'Donovan Rossa's funeral in Dublin.
World War I: The German 12th Army occupies Warsaw during the Gorlice–Tarnów Offensive and the Great Retreat of 1915.
World War I: Battle of Sari Bair: The Allies mount a diversionary attack timed to coincide with a major Allied landing of reinforcements at Suvla Bay.

A story in New York World newspaper reveals that the Imperial German government had purchased excess phenol from Thomas Edison that could be used to make explosives for the war effort and diverted it to Bayer for aspirin production.
Jewish American Leo Frank is lynched in Marietta, Georgia, USA after his death sentence is commuted by Governor John Slaton.
A Category 4 hurricane hits Galveston, Texas with winds at 135 miles per hour (217 km/h).
Attempted assassination of Bishop Patrick Heffron, bishop of the Diocese of Winona, by Rev. Louis M. Lesches.
US Navy salvage divers raise F-4, the first U.S. submarine sunk in an accident.
The pacifist Zimmerwald Conference begins.
World War I: The first tank prototype, developed by William Foster & Co. for the British army, was completed and given its first test drive.
French soldiers rescue over 4,000 Armenian genocide survivors stranded on Musa Dagh.
New Culture Movement: Chen Duxiu establishes the New Youth magazine in Shanghai.
World War I: The Second Battle of Champagne begins.
World War I: Radoje Ljutovac becomes the first soldier in history to shoot down an enemy aircraft with ground-to-air fire.
The Metamorphosis written by Franz Kafka is published in the German journal Die Weißen Blätter
World War I: Combined Austro-Hungarian and German Central Powers, reinforced by the recently joined Bulgaria launched a new offensive against Serbia under command of August von Mackensen .
source_pages: World_War_I; Central_Powers; Kingdom_of_Bulgaria; Kingdom_of_Serbia; August_von_Mackensen; October_6

event_text: World War I: Entente forces land in Thessaloniki, to open the Macedonian front against the Central Powers.
World War I: British nurse Edith Cavell is executed by a German firing squad for helping Allied soldiers escape from occupied Belgium.
First World War: The Battle of the Hohenzollern Redoubt marks the end of the Battle of Loos.
World War I: Bulgaria joins the Central Powers.
Albert Einstein presents the field equations of general relativity to the Prussian Academy of Sciences.
Yuan Shikai declares the establishment of the Empire of China and proclaims himself Emperor.
World War I: The last Australian troops are evacuated from Gallipoli.
The National Protection War breaks out against the Empire of China, as military leaders Cai E and Tang Jiyao proclaim the independence of Yunnan and begin a campaign to restore the Republic.
source_pages: National_Protection_War; Empire_of_China_(1915–1916); Cai_E; Tang_Jiyao; Yunnan; Republic_of_China_(1912–1949); December_25

event_text: World War I: The Battle of Gallipoli concludes with an Ottoman Empire victory when the last Allied forces are evacuated from the peninsula.
World War I: Imperial Russia begins the Erzurum Offensive, leading to the defeat of the Ottoman Empire's Third Army.

Oswald Boelcke and Max Immelmann become the first German aviators to earn the Pour le Mérite, receive the German Empire's highest military award, for achieving eight aerial victories each over Allied aircraft.
source_pages: Oswald_Boelcke; Max_Immelmann; Pour_le_Mérite; German_Empire; Allies_of_World_War_I; January_12

event_text: In Brushaber v. Union Pacific Railroad Co., the Supreme Court of the United States declares the federal income tax constitutional.
World War I: The British government passes the Military Service Act that introduces conscription in the United Kingdom.

The Canadian province of Manitoba grants women the right to vote and run for office in provincial elections (although still excluding women of Indigenous or Asian heritage), marking the first time women in Canada are granted voting rights.
The Centre Block of the Parliament buildings in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada burns down with the loss of seven lives.
World War I: In France, the Battle of Verdun begins.
The Governor-General of Korea establishes a clinic called Jahyewon in Sorokdo to segregate Hansen's disease patients.
World War I: In the Battle of Verdun, a German unit captures Fort Douaumont, keystone of the French defences, without a fight.
Ocean liner SS Maloja strikes a mine near Dover and sinks with the loss of 155 lives.
World War I: A British force unsuccessfully attempts to relieve the siege of Kut (present-day Iraq) in the Battle of Dujaila.
Mexican Revolution: Pancho Villa leads nearly 500 Mexican raiders in an attack against the border town of Columbus, New Mexico.
The 7th and 10th US cavalry regiments under John J. Pershing cross the US–Mexico border to join the hunt for Pancho Villa.
Albert Einstein submits his paper, "The Foundation of the General Theory of Relativity", which establishes his general theory of relativity, to the journal Annalen der Physik.
Yuan Shikai abdicates as Emperor of China, restoring the Republic and returning to the Presidency.
The Professional Golfers' Association of America (PGA) is created in New York City.
World War I: During a mine warfare in high altitude on the Dolomites, the Italian troops conquer the Col di Lana held by the Austrian army.
Easter Rising: Irish rebels, led by Patrick Pearse and James Connolly, launch an uprising in Dublin against British rule and proclaim an Irish Republic.

Ernest Shackleton and five men of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition launch a lifeboat from uninhabited Elephant Island in the Southern Ocean to organise a rescue for the crew of the sunken Endurance.
Anzac Day is commemorated for the first time on the first anniversary of the landing at ANZAC Cove.
Easter Rising: Battle of Mount Street Bridge.
World War I: The UK's 6th Indian Division surrenders to Ottoman Forces at the Siege of Kut in one of the largest surrenders of British forces up to that point.
Easter Rising: After six days of fighting, Irish rebel leaders surrender to British forces in Dublin, bringing the Easter Rising to an end.
Twenty-one Lebanese nationalists are executed in Martyrs' Square, Beirut by Djemal Pasha.
Vietnamese Emperor Duy Tân is captured while calling upon the people to rise up against the French, and is later deposed and exiled to Réunion island.
Sailing in the lifeboat James Caird, Ernest Shackleton arrives at South Georgia after a journey of 800 nautical miles from Elephant Island.
A seventeen-year-old farmworker, Jesse Washington, is infamously lynched in Waco, Texas, USA, after being convicted of rape and murder.
source_pages: Farmworker; Lynching_of_Jesse_Washington; Waco,_Texas; Conviction; Rape; Murder; May_15

event_text: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and the French Third Republic sign the secret wartime Sykes-Picot Agreement partitioning former Ottoman territories such as Iraq and Syria.
World War I: Battle of Jutland: The British Grand Fleet engages the High Seas Fleet in the largest naval battle of the war, which proves indecisive.
The United States Senate confirms the appointment of Louis Brandeis to the United States Supreme Court, making him the first Jew to be an Associate Justice.
The National Defense Act is signed into law, increasing the size of the United States National Guard by 450,000 men.
World War I: Russia opens the Brusilov Offensive with an artillery barrage of Austro-Hungarian lines in Galicia.
source_pages: World_War_I; Russian_Empire; Brusilov_offensive; Artillery; Austria-Hungary; Galicia_(Eastern_Europe)

event_text: Louis Brandeis is sworn in as a Justice of the United States Supreme Court; he is the first American Jew to hold such a position.
World War I: The Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire breaks out.
The Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire was declared by Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca.
Mary Pickford becomes the first female film star to sign a million-dollar contract.
British diplomat turned Irish nationalist Roger Casement is sentenced to death for his part in the Easter Rising.
World War I: In "the day Sussex died", elements of the Royal Sussex Regiment take heavy casualties in the Battle of the Boar's Head at Richebourg-l'Avoué in France.
source_pages: World_War_I; Royal_Sussex_Regiment; Attack_on_the_Boar's_Head; Richebourg-l'Avoué; France; June_30

event_text: World War I: First day on the Somme: On the first day of the Battle of the Somme 19,000 soldiers of the British Army are killed and 40,000 wounded.
The New Zealand Labour Party was founded in Wellington.
Battle of Delville Wood begins as an action within the Battle of the Somme, lasting until 3 September 1916.
In Seattle, Washington, William Boeing and George Conrad Westervelt incorporate Pacific Aero Products (later renamed Boeing).
World War I: Battle of Fromelles: British and Australian troops attack German trenches as part of the Battle of the Somme.
Preparedness Day Bombing: In San Francisco, a bomb explodes on Market Street during a parade, killing ten and injuring 40.
The Black Tom explosion in New York Harbor kills four and destroys some $20,000,000 worth of military goods.
World War I: Austrian sabotage causes the sinking of the Italian battleship Leonardo da Vinci in Taranto.

World War I: Battle of Romani: Allied forces, under the command of Archibald Murray, defeat an attacking Ottoman army under the command of Friedrich Freiherr Kress von Kressenstein, securing the Suez Canal and beginning the Ottoman retreat from the Sinai Peninsula.
The Migratory Bird Treaty between Canada and the United States is signed.
World War I: Romania signs a secret treaty with the Entente Powers. According to the treaty, Romania agreed to join the war on the Allied side.
The United States National Park Service is created.
World War I: The Kingdom of Romania declares war on Austria-Hungary, entering the war as one of the Allied nations.
World War I: Germany declares war on Romania.
World War I: Italy declares war on Germany.
The United States passes the Philippine Autonomy Act.
Ernest Shackleton completes the rescue of all of his men stranded on Elephant Island in Antarctica.
World War I: Leefe Robinson destroys the German airship Schütte-Lanz SL 11 over Cuffley, north of London; the first German airship to be shot down on British soil.
US federal employees win the right to Workers' compensation by Federal Employers Liability Act (39 Stat. 742; 5 U.S.C. 751)

In a bid to prove that women were capable of serving as military dispatch riders, Augusta and Adeline Van Buren arrive in Los Angeles, completing a 60-day, 5,500 mile cross-country trip on motorcycles.
The Quebec Bridge's central span collapses, killing 11 men. The bridge previously collapsed completely on August 29, 1907.
World War I: Tanks are used for the first time in battle, at the Battle of the Somme.
World War I: Manfred von Richthofen ("The Red Baron"), a flying ace of the German Luftstreitkräfte, wins his first aerial combat near Cambrai, France.
World War I: During the East African Campaign, colonial forces of the Belgian Congo (Force Publique) under the command of Charles Tombeur capture the town of Tabora after heavy fighting.
Iyasu V is proclaimed deposed as ruler of Ethiopia in a palace coup in favor of his aunt Zewditu.
Georgia Tech defeats Cumberland University 222–0 in the most lopsided college football game in American history.
Margaret Sanger opens the first family planning clinic in the United States.
Negus Mikael, marching on the Ethiopian capital in support of his son Emperor Iyasu V, is defeated by Fitawrari Habte Giyorgis, securing the throne for Empress Zewditu I.
In Russia, Pavel Milyukov delivers in the State Duma the famous "stupidity or treason" speech, precipitating the downfall of the government of Boris Stürmer.
The Kingdom of Poland is proclaimed by the Act of 5th November of the emperors of Germany and Austria-Hungary.
The Everett massacre takes place in Everett, Washington as political differences lead to a shoot-out between the Industrial Workers of the World organizers and local police.
Jeannette Rankin is the first woman elected to the United States Congress.
Woodrow Wilson is reelected as President of the United States.

Boston Elevated Railway Company's streetcar No. 393 smashes through the warning gates of the open Summer Street drawbridge in Boston, Massachusetts, plunging into the frigid waters of Fort Point Channel, killing 46 people.
source_pages: Boston_Elevated_Railway; Summer_Street_Bridge_disaster; Summer_Street_Bridge; Boston; Fort_Point_Channel; November_7

event_text: World War I: Prime Minister of Australia Billy Hughes is expelled from the Labor Party over his support for conscription.
World War I: First Battle of the Somme: In France, British Expeditionary Force commander Douglas Haig calls off the battle which started on July 1, 1916.
Samuel Goldwyn and Edgar Selwyn establish Goldwyn Pictures.
Mines from SM U-73 sink HMHS Britannic, the largest ship lost in the First World War.
Costa Rica signs the Buenos Aires Convention, a copyright treaty.
World War I: The Central Powers capture Bucharest.
World War I: The Battle of Verdun ends when the second French offensive pushes the Germans back two or three kilometres, causing them to cease their attacks.
World War I: Battle of Magdhaba: Allied forces defeat Turkish forces in the Sinai Peninsula.

Russian mystic and advisor to the Tsar Grigori Yefimovich Rasputin is murdered by a loyalist group led by Prince Felix Yusupov. His frozen, partially-trussed body was discovered in a Petrograd river three days later.
The last coronation in Hungary is performed for King Charles IV and Queen Zita.
World War I: The Battle of Rafa is fought near the Egyptian border with Palestine.
Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition: Seven survivors of the Ross Sea party were rescued after being stranded for several months.
The Kingsland munitions factory explosion occurs as a result of sabotage.
The United States pays Denmark $25 million for the Virgin Islands.
Silvertown explosion: A blast at a munitions factory in London kills 73 and injures over 400. The resulting fire causes over £2,000,000 worth of damage.
American entry into World War I: President Woodrow Wilson of the still-neutral United States calls for "peace without victory" in Europe.
Sinking of the SS Laurentic after hitting two German mines off the coast of northwest Ireland.
World War I: Kaiser Wilhelm II orders the resumption of unrestricted submarine warfare.
World War I: The American entry into World War I begins when diplomatic relations with Germany are severed due to its unrestricted submarine warfare.
The current constitution of Mexico is adopted, establishing a federal republic with powers separated into independent executive, legislative, and judicial branches.
The Congress of the United States passes the Immigration Act of 1917 over President Woodrow Wilson's veto.
First demonstrations in Saint Petersburg, Russia. The beginning of the February Revolution (March 8 in the Gregorian calendar).

World War I: The U.S. ambassador Walter Hines Page to the United Kingdom is given the Zimmermann Telegram, in which Germany pledges to ensure the return of New Mexico, Texas, and Arizona to Mexico if Mexico declares war on the United States.
source_pages: World_War_I; Walter_Hines_Page; Zimmermann_telegram; New_Mexico; Texas; Arizona

event_text: The Zimmermann Telegram is reprinted in newspapers across the United States after the U.S. government releases its unencrypted text.
The enactment of the Jones–Shafroth Act grants Puerto Ricans United States citizenship.
Jeannette Rankin of Montana becomes the first female member of the United States House of Representatives.
International Women's Day protests in Petrograd mark the beginning of the February Revolution (February 23 in the Julian calendar).
The United States Senate votes to limit filibusters by adopting the cloture rule.
World War I: Mesopotamian campaign: Baghdad falls to Anglo-Indian forces commanded by General Frederick Stanley Maude.
source_pages: World_War_I; Mesopotamian_campaign; Fall_of_Baghdad_(1917); Anglo-Indian_people; Stanley_Maude; March_11

event_text: Tsar Nicholas II of Russia abdicates the Russian throne, ending the 304-year Romanov dynasty.
The Georgian Orthodox Church restores its autocephaly abolished by Imperial Russia in 1811.
World War I: First Battle of Gaza: British troops are halted after 17,000 Turks block their advance.
According to the terms of the Treaty of the Danish West Indies, the islands become American possessions.
American entry into World War I: President Wilson asks the U.S. Congress for a declaration of war on Germany.
World War I: The United States declares war on Germany.
World War I: The Battle of Arras: The battle begins with Canadian Corps executing a massive assault on Vimy Ridge.
World War I: Canadian forces successfully complete the taking of Vimy Ridge from the Germans.
Russian Revolution: Vladimir Lenin returns to Petrograd, Russia, from exile in Switzerland.
Three children report the first apparition of Our Lady of Fátima in Fátima, Portugal.
World War I: The Selective Service Act of 1917 is passed, giving the President of the United States the power of conscription.
The Norwegian football club Rosenborg BK is founded.
The Imperial War Graves Commission is established through royal charter to mark, record, and maintain the graves and places of commemoration of the British Empire's military forces.

The Great Atlanta fire of 1917 causes $5.5 million in damages, destroying some 300 acres including 2,000 homes, businesses and churches, displacing about 10,000 people but leading to only one fatality (due to heart attack).
Pope Benedict XV promulgates the 1917 Code of Canon Law, the first comprehensive codification of Catholic canon law in the legal history of the Catholic Church.

The first Pulitzer Prizes are awarded: Laura E. Richards, Maude H. Elliott, and Florence Hall receive the first Pulitzer for biography (for Julia Ward Howe). Jean Jules Jusserand receives the first Pulitzer for history for his work With Americans of Past and Present Days. Herbert B. Swope receives the first Pulitzer for journalism for his work for the New York World.
source_pages: Pulitzer_Prize; Laura_E._Richards; Maud_Howe_Elliott; Florence_Howe_Hall; Julia_Ward_Howe; Jean_Jules_Jusserand; Herbert_Bayard_Swope; Journalism; New_York_World

event_text: World War I: Conscription begins in the United States as "Army registration day".
World War I: Battle of Messines: Allied soldiers detonate a series of mines underneath German trenches at Messines Ridge, killing 10,000 German troops.
King Alexander assumes the throne of Greece after his father, Constantine I, is deemed to have abdicated under pressure from allied armies occupying Athens.
source_pages: Alexander_of_Greece; Kingdom_of_Greece; Constantine_I_of_Greece; Triple_Entente; Athens; June_11

event_text: World War I: The deadliest German air raid on London of the war is carried out by Gotha G.IV bombers and results in 162 deaths, including 46 children, and 432 injuries.
In a game against the Washington Senators, Boston Red Sox pitcher Ernie Shore retires 26 batters in a row after replacing Babe Ruth, who had been ejected for punching the umpire.
World War I: The American Expeditionary Forces begin to arrive in France. They will first enter combat in the Battle of Hamel on July 4.
World War I: Greece joins the Allied powers.
World War I: Russia launches an offensive against Austria-Hungary to capture Galicia, its final offensive of the war.

Chinese General Zhang Xun seizes control of Beijing and restores the monarchy, installing Puyi, last emperor of the Qing dynasty, to the throne. The restoration is reversed just shy of two weeks later, when Republican troops regain control of the capital.
source_pages: Zhang_Xun; Beijing; Manchu_Restoration; Puyi; Qing_dynasty; Republic_of_China_(1912–1949); July_1

event_text: World War I: Arabian troops led by T. E. Lawrence ("Lawrence of Arabia") and Auda ibu Tayi capture Aqaba from the Ottoman Empire during the Arab Revolt.
source_pages: World_War_I; Arabs; T._E._Lawrence; Auda_Abu_Tayi; Battle_of_Aqaba; Ottoman_Empire; Arab_Revolt

event_text: The Bisbee Deportation occurs as vigilantes kidnap and deport nearly 1,300 striking miners and others from Bisbee, Arizona.
source_pages: Bisbee_Deportation; Vigilantism; Kidnapping; Deportation; Strike_action; Bisbee,_Arizona

event_text: World War I: The Corfu Declaration, which leads to the creation of the post-war Kingdom of Yugoslavia, is signed by the Yugoslav Committee and Kingdom of Serbia.
Sir Robert Borden introduces the first income tax in Canada as a "temporary" measure (lowest bracket is 4% and highest is 25%).
World War I: The Allies reach the Yser Canal at the Battle of Passchendaele.
The Silent Parade takes place in New York City, in protest against murders, lynchings, and other violence directed towards African Americans.
World War I: The Battle of Passchendaele begins near Ypres in West Flanders, Belgium.
World War I: Battle of Mărășești between the Romanian and German armies begins.

World War I: The Republic of China, which had heretofore been shipping labourers to Europe to assist in the war effort, officially declares war on the Central Powers, although it will continue to send to Europe labourers instead of combatants for the remaining duration of the war.
A Great Fire in Thessaloniki, Greece, destroys 32% of the city leaving 70,000 individuals homeless.
Ten suffragists, members of the Silent Sentinels, are arrested while picketing the White House in favor of women's suffrage in the United States.
Vietnamese prison guards led by Trịnh Văn Cấn mutiny at the Thái Nguyên penitentiary against local French authority.
The Russian Empire is formally replaced by the Russian Republic.
World War I: The Battle of Polygon Wood begins.
World War I: The Battle of Broodseinde is fought between the British and German armies in Flanders.
World War I: The First Battle of Passchendaele takes place resulting in the largest single-day loss of life in New Zealand history.
The "Miracle of the Sun" is witnessed by an estimated 70,000 people in the Cova da Iria in Portugal.
World War I: Italy suffers a disastrous defeat at the Battle of Caporetto on the Austro-Italian front.
Old Style date of the October Revolution in Russia.
World War I: Brazil declares war on the Central Powers.
World War I: Battle of Beersheba: The "last successful cavalry charge in history".

The Balfour Declaration proclaims British support for the "establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people" with the clear understanding "that nothing shall be done which may prejudice the civil and religious rights of existing non-Jewish communities".
The Military Revolutionary Committee of the Petrograd Soviet, in charge of preparation and carrying out the Russian Revolution, holds its first meeting.
Lenin calls for the October Revolution.
Tikhon is elected the Patriarch of Moscow and of the Russian Orthodox Church.
The October Revolution, which gets its name from the Julian calendar date of 25 October, occurs, according to the Gregorian calendar; on this date, the Bolsheviks storm the Winter Palace.
World War I: The Third Battle of Gaza ends, with British forces capturing Gaza from the Ottoman Empire.
The first Council of People's Commissars is formed, including Vladimir Lenin, Leon Trotsky and Joseph Stalin.
The Balfour Declaration is published in The Times newspaper.

World War I: beginning of the First Battle of Monte Grappa (in Italy known as the "First Battle of the Piave"). The Austro-Hungarian Armed Forces, despite help from the German Alpenkorps and numerical superiority, will fail their offensive against the Italian Army now led by its new chief of staff Armando Diaz.
source_pages: Battle_of_Monte_Grappa; Austro-Hungarian_Armed_Forces; Alpenkorps_(German_Empire); Italian_Army; Armando_Diaz; November_13

event_text: Eduskunta declares itself the supreme state power of Finland, prompting its declaration of independence and secession from Russia.
World War I: Battle of Cambrai begins: British forces make early progress in an attack on German positions but are later pushed back.
In Milwaukee, nine members of the Milwaukee Police Department are killed by a bomb, the most deaths in a single event in U.S. police history until the September 11 attacks in 2001.
World War I: German forces defeat Portuguese army of about 1,200 at Negomano on the border of modern-day Mozambique and Tanzania.
The Manchester Guardian publishes the 1916 secret Sykes-Picot Agreement between the United Kingdom and France.
The National Hockey League is formed, with the Montreal Canadiens, Montreal Wanderers, Ottawa Senators, Quebec Bulldogs, and Toronto Arenas as its first teams.
source_pages: National_Hockey_League; Montreal_Canadiens; Montreal_Wanderers; Ottawa_Senators_(original); Quebec_Bulldogs; Toronto_Arenas

event_text: P. E. Svinhufvud becomes the chairman of his first senate, technically the first Prime Minister of Finland.
The Estonian Provincial Assembly declares itself the sovereign power of Estonia.
World War I: Russia and the Central Powers sign an armistice at Brest-Litovsk, and peace talks leading to the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk begin.

The Finnish Senate submits to the Parliament of Finland a proposal for the form of government of the Republic of Finland and issued a communication to Parliament declaring the independence of Finland.
Finland declares independence from the Russian Empire.
Halifax Explosion: A munitions explosion near Halifax, Nova Scotia kills more than 1,900 people in the largest artificial explosion up to that time.
World War I: USS Jacob Jones is the first American destroyer to be sunk by enemy action when it is torpedoed by German submarine SM U-53.
World War I: The United States declares war on Austria-Hungary.
World War I: Field Marshal Allenby captures Jerusalem from the Ottoman Empire.
World War I: The Kingdom of Romania signs the Armistice of Focșani with the Central Powers.
World War I: British General Edmund Allenby enters Jerusalem on foot and declares martial law.
Father Edward J. Flanagan founds Boys Town as a farm village for wayward boys.
World War I: An armistice between Russia and the Central Powers is signed.
The resolution containing the language of the Eighteenth Amendment to enact Prohibition is passed by the United States Congress.
Cheka, the first Soviet secret police force, is founded.
The Finnish Declaration of Independence is recognized by Russia, Sweden, Germany and France.
U.S. President Woodrow Wilson announces his "Fourteen Points" as conditions for ending World War I.
Battle of Bear Valley: The last battle of the American Indian Wars.
The Minnie Pit Disaster coal mining accident occurs in Halmer End, Staffordshire, in which 155 men and boys die.
Finnish Civil War: The first serious battles take place between the Red Guards and the White Guard.
The Gregorian calendar is introduced in Russia by decree of the Council of People's Commissars effective February 14 (New Style).
The Ukrainian People's Republic declares independence from Soviet Russia.
The Finnish Defence Forces (The White Guards) are established as the official army of independent Finland, and Baron C. G. E. Mannerheim is appointed its Commander-in-Chief.
Finnish Civil War: A group of Red Guards hangs a red lantern atop the tower of Helsinki Workers' Hall to symbolically mark the start of the war.
Beginning of the Finnish Civil War.
Finnish Civil War: The Red Guard rebels seize control of the capital, Helsinki; members of the Senate of Finland go underground.
Ukrainian–Soviet War: The Bolshevik Red Army, on its way to besiege Kyiv, is met by a small group of military students at the Battle of Kruty.
source_pages: Ukrainian–Soviet_War; Bolsheviks; Red_Army; Kyiv; Battle_of_Kruty; January_29

event_text: Ukrainian–Soviet War: An armed uprising organized by the Bolsheviks in anticipation of the encroaching Red Army begins at the Kiev Arsenal, which will be put down six days later.
A series of accidental collisions on a misty Scottish night leads to the loss of two Royal Navy submarines with over a hundred lives, and damage to another five British warships.
Finnish Civil War: The Suinula massacre, which changes the nature of the war in a more hostile direction, takes place in Kangasala.
The Twin Peaks Tunnel in San Francisco, California begins service as the longest streetcar tunnel in the world at 11,920 feet (3,630 meters) long.
Stephen W. Thompson shoots down a German airplane; this is the first aerial victory by the U.S. military.
SS Tuscania is torpedoed off the coast of Ireland; it is the first ship carrying American troops to Europe to be torpedoed and sunk.
British women over the age of 30 who meet minimum property qualifications, get the right to vote when  Representation of the People Act 1918 is passed by Parliament.
Russia adopts the Gregorian calendar.
The Council of Lithuania unanimously adopts the Act of Independence, declaring Lithuania an independent state.
The last Carolina parakeet dies in captivity at the Cincinnati Zoo.
Estonian Declaration of Independence.
World War I: German forces capture Tallinn to virtually complete the occupation of Estonia.

Russia signs the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, agreeing to withdraw from World War I, and conceding German control of the Baltic States, Belarus and Ukraine. It also conceded Turkish control of Ardahan, Kars and Batumi.
source_pages: Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic; Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk; World_War_I; Baltic_states; Belarus; Ukraine; Ardahan; Kars; Batumi

event_text: A case of influenza was recorded at Camp Funston, Kansas, conventionally marking the beginning of the worldwide Spanish flu pandemic.
Moscow becomes the capital of Russia again after Saint Petersburg held this status for most of the period since 1713.
Finnish Civil War: The battle of Tampere begins.
Finnish Civil War: Battle of Länkipohja is infamous for its bloody aftermath as the Whites execute 70–100 capitulated Reds.
The US Congress establishes time zones and approves daylight saving time.
World War I: The first phase of the German spring offensive, Operation Michael, begins.
First World War: On the third day of the German Spring Offensive, the 10th Battalion of the Royal West Kent Regiment is annihilated with many of the men becoming prisoners of war
The Belarusian People's Republic is established.
The National Council of Bessarabia proclaims union with the Kingdom of Romania.

General John J. Pershing, during World War I, cancels 42nd 'Rainbow' Division's orders to Rolampont for further training and diverted it to the occupy the Baccarat sector. Rainbow Division becomes "the first American division to take over an entire sector on its own, which it held longer than any other American division-occupied sector alone for a period of three months".
source_pages: General_(United_States); John_J._Pershing; World_War_I; 42nd_Infantry_Division_(United_States); Rolampont; Military_education_and_training; Baccarat,_Meurthe-et-Moselle; March_28; United_States; Division_(military)

event_text: Finnish Civil War: On the so-called "Bloody Maundy Thursday of Tampere", the Whites force the Reds to attack the city center, where the city's fiercest battles being fought in Kalevankangas with large casualties on both sides. During the same day, an explosion at the Red headquarters of Tampere kills several commanders.
source_pages: Finnish_Civil_War; Tampere; White_Guard_(Finland); Red_Guards_(Finland); Battle_of_Tampere; March_28

event_text: Beginning of the bloody March Events in Baku and other locations of Baku Governorate.
Massacre of ethnic Azerbaijanis is committed by allied armed groups of Armenian Revolutionary Federation and Bolsheviks. Nearly 12,000 Azerbaijani Muslims are killed.
Daylight saving time goes into effect in the United States for the first time.
The Royal Air Force is created by the merger of the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service.
Finnish Civil War: The battle of Tampere ends.
World War I: The Battle of the Lys: The Portuguese Expeditionary Corps is crushed by the German forces during what is called the Spring Offensive on the Belgian region of Flanders.
Manfred von Richthofen, a.k.a. The Red Baron, shoots down his 79th and 80th victims, his final victories before his death the following day.
World War I: German fighter ace Manfred von Richthofen, better known as "The Red Baron", is shot down and killed over Vaux-sur-Somme in France.
World War I: The British Royal Navy makes a raid in an attempt to neutralise the Belgian port of Bruges-Zeebrugge.
World War I: First tank-to-tank combat, during the second Battle of Villers-Bretonneux. Three British Mark IVs meet three German A7Vs.
World War I: Germany repels Britain's second attempt to blockade the port of Ostend, Belgium.
Cape Town Mayor, Sir Harry Hands, inaugurates the Two-minute silence.
The Finnish Civil War ends when the Whites took over Fort Ino, a Russian coastal artillery base on the Karelian Isthmus, from Russian troops.
source_pages: Finnish_Civil_War; White_Guard_(Finland); Fort_Ino; Coastal_artillery; Karelian_Isthmus; May_15

event_text: The Sedition Act of 1918 is passed by the U.S. Congress, making criticism of the government during wartime an imprisonable offense. It will be repealed less than two years later.
The Democratic Republic of Georgia is established.
The Azerbaijan Democratic Republic and the First Republic of Armenia declare their independence.
Armenia defeats the Ottoman Army in the Battle of Sardarabad.
World War I: Western Front: Battle of Belleau Wood: Allied Forces under John J. Pershing and James Harbord engage Imperial German Forces under Wilhelm, German Crown Prince.
source_pages: World_War_I; Western_Front_(World_War_I); Battle_of_Belleau_Wood; John_J._Pershing; James_Harbord; Wilhelm,_German_Crown_Prince

event_text: World War I: U.S. Marine Corps suffers its worst single day's casualties during the Battle of Belleau Wood while attempting to recapture the wood at Château-Thierry (the losses are exceeded at the Battle of Tarawa in November 1943).
source_pages: World_War_I; United_States_Marine_Corps; Battle_of_Belleau_Wood; Château-Thierry; Battle_of_Tarawa; June_6

event_text: The Austro-Hungarian battleship SMS Szent István sinks off the Croatian coast after being torpedoed by an Italian MAS motorboat; the event is recorded by camera from a nearby vessel.
The Hammond Circus Train Wreck kills 86 and injures 127 near Hammond, Indiana.
First airmail service in Canada from Montreal to Toronto.
World War I: Allied forces under John J. Pershing and James Harbord defeat Imperial German forces under Wilhelm, German Crown Prince in the Battle of Belleau Wood.
source_pages: Allies_of_World_War_I; John_J._Pershing; James_Harbord; German_Empire; Wilhelm,_German_Crown_Prince; Battle_of_Belleau_Wood

event_text: Mehmed V died at the age of 73 and Ottoman sultan Mehmed VI ascends to the throne.
World War I: The Battle of Hamel, a successful attack by the Australian Corps against German positions near the town of Le Hamel on the Western Front.
The Left SR uprising in Russia starts with the assassination of German ambassador Wilhelm von Mirbach by Cheka members.
In Nashville, Tennessee, an inbound local train collides with an outbound express, killing 101 and injuring 171 people, making it the deadliest rail accident in United States history.
The Imperial Japanese Navy battleship Kawachi blows up at Shunan, western Honshu, Japan, killing at least 621.
World War I: The Second Battle of the Marne begins near the River Marne with a German attack.
Tsar Nicholas II of Russia and his immediate family and retainers are executed by Bolshevik Chekists at the Ipatiev House in Yekaterinburg, Russia.
source_pages: Nicholas_II; Russian_Empire; Murder_of_the_Romanov_family; Bolsheviks; Cheka; Ipatiev_House; Yekaterinburg; Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic; July_17

event_text: The RMS Carpathia is sunk off Ireland by the German SM U-55; five lives are lost.

Emmy Noether's paper, which became known as Noether's theorem was presented at Göttingen, Germany, from which  conservation laws are deduced for symmetries of angular momentum, linear momentum, and energy.
source_pages: Emmy_Noether; Noether's_theorem; Göttingen; Conservation_law; Angular_momentum; Momentum; Energy

event_text: The first general strike in Canadian history takes place in Vancouver.
World War I: The Battle of Amiens begins a string of almost continuous Allied victories with a push through the German front lines (Hundred Days Offensive).
World War I: The Battle of Amiens ends.
Women enlist in the United States Marine Corps for the first time. Opha May Johnson is the first woman to enlist.
Bayerische Motoren Werke AG (BMW) established as a public company in Germany.
The Battle of Lake Baikal was fought between the Czechoslovak Legion and the Red Army.
Bolshevik revolutionary leader Moisei Uritsky is assassinated.
World War I: The Second Battle of the Somme begins.
Mexican Revolution: Battle of Ambos Nogales: U.S. Army forces skirmish against Mexican Carrancistas in the only battle of World War I fought on American soil.
World War I: Bapaume taken by the New Zealand Division in the Hundred Days Offensive.

Fanni Kaplan shoots and seriously injures Bolshevik leader Vladimir Lenin, which along with the assassination of Bolshevik senior official Moisei Uritsky days earlier, prompts the decree for Red Terror.
World War I: Start of the Battle of Mont Saint-Quentin, a successful assault by the Australian Corps during the Hundred Days Offensive.
Russian Civil War: The Red Army captures Kazan.
World War I: Allied troops break through the Bulgarian defenses on the Macedonian front.
World War I: The Battle of Haifa takes place in present-day Israel, part of the Ottoman Empire at that time.
World War I: The end of the Battle of Megiddo, the climax of the British Army's Sinai and Palestine campaign under General Edmund Allenby.
World War I: The Meuse-Argonne Offensive began which would last until the total surrender of German forces.
World War I: The Fifth Battle of Ypres begins.
Bulgaria signs the Armistice of Salonica ending its participation in World War I.
The Hindenburg Line is broken by an Allied attack in World War I.
Germany's Supreme Army Command tells Kaiser Wilhelm II and Imperial Chancellor Georg Michaelis to open negotiations for an armistice to end World War I.
Ukrainian War of Independence: Insurgent forces led by Nestor Makhno defeat the Central Powers at the battle of Dibrivka.
source_pages: Ukrainian_War_of_Independence; Revolutionary_Insurgent_Army_of_Ukraine; Nestor_Makhno; Central_Powers; Battle_of_Dibrivka; September_30

event_text: World War I: The Egyptian Expeditionary Force captures Damascus.
Sayid Abdullah becomes the last Khan of Khiva.
Tsar Boris III of Bulgaria accedes to the throne.
World War I: An explosion kills more than 100 people and destroys a Shell Loading Plant in New Jersey.
World War I: Corporal Alvin C. York kills 28 German soldiers and captures 132 for which he was awarded the Medal of Honor.
The Finnish Parliament offers to Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse the throne of a short-lived Kingdom of Finland.
RMS Leinster is torpedoed and sunk by UB-123, killing 564, the largest loss of life on the Irish Sea.
The 7.1 Mw San Fermín earthquake shakes Puerto Rico. The quake and resulting tsunami kill up to 116 people.
A massive forest fire kills 453 people in Minnesota.
World War I: Italian victory in the Battle of Vittorio Veneto.
World War I: Erich Ludendorff, quartermaster-general of the Imperial German Army, is dismissed by Kaiser Wilhelm II for refusing to cooperate in peace negotiations.
World War I: A new Polish government in western Galicia is established, triggering the Polish–Ukrainian War.
World War I: Czech politicians peacefully take over the city of Prague, thus establishing the First Czechoslovak Republic.
The German High Seas Fleet is incapacitated when sailors mutiny, an action which would trigger the German Revolution of 1918–19.
World War I: The Ottoman Empire signs the Armistice of Mudros with the Allies.

World War I: Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen, a state union of Kingdom of Hungary and Triune Kingdom of Croatia, Slavonia and Dalmatia is abolished with decisions of Croatian and Hungarian parliaments
World War I: The Aster Revolution terminates the Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867, and Hungary achieves full sovereignty.

World War I: With a brave action carried out into the waters of the Austro-Hungarian port of Pula, two officers of the Italian Regia Marina sink with a manned torpedo the enemy battleship SMS Viribus Unitis.
Malbone Street wreck: The worst rapid transit accident in US history occurs under the intersection of Malbone Street and Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York City, with at least 102 deaths.
Western Ukraine separates from Austria-Hungary.
The German Revolution of 1918–19 begins when 40,000 sailors take over the port in Kiel.
World War I: The Armistice of Villa Giusti between Italy and Austria-Hungary is implemented.
The 1918 influenza epidemic spreads to Western Samoa, killing 7,542 (about 20% of the population) by the end of the year.
Kurt Eisner overthrows the Wittelsbach dynasty in the Kingdom of Bavaria.
Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany abdicates after the German Revolution, and Germany is proclaimed a Republic.

The Western Union Cable Office in North Sydney, Nova Scotia, receives a top-secret coded message from Europe (that would be sent to Ottawa and Washington, D.C.) that said on November 11, 1918, all fighting would cease on land, sea and in the air.
World War I: Germany signs an armistice agreement with the Allies in a railroad car in the forest of Compiègne.
Józef Piłsudski assumes supreme military power in Poland – symbolic first day of Polish independence.
Emperor Charles I of Austria relinquishes power.
Dissolution of Austria-Hungary: Austria becomes a republic. After the proclamation, a coup attempt by the communist Red Guard is defeated by the social-democratic Volkswehr.
World War I: Allied troops occupy Constantinople, the capital of the Ottoman Empire.
The Provisional National Assembly of the new republic of Czechoslovakia meets to devise a constitution.
Latvia declares its independence from Russia.
The Flag of Estonia, previously used by pro-independence activists, is formally adopted as the national flag of the Republic of Estonia.
The Parliament (Qualification of Women) Act 1918 is passed, allowing women to stand for Parliament in the UK.
A pogrom takes place in Lwów (now Lviv); over three days, at least 50 Jews and 270 Ukrainian Christians are killed by Poles.
Vojvodina, formerly Austro-Hungarian crown land, proclaims its secession from Austria-Hungary to join the Kingdom of Serbia.
The Montenegrin Podgorica Assembly votes for a "union of the people", declaring assimilation into the Kingdom of Serbia.
The Makhnovshchina is established.
The Soviet Forces move against Estonia when the 6th Red Rifle Division strikes the border town of Narva, marking the beginning of the Estonian War of Independence.
Transylvania unites with Romania, following the incorporation of Bessarabia (March 27) and Bukovina (November 28) and thus concluding the Great Union.
source_pages: Transylvania; Union_of_Transylvania_with_Romania; Kingdom_of_Romania; Bessarabia; March_27; Bukovina; November_28; Great_Union

event_text: Iceland becomes a sovereign state, yet remains a part of the Danish kingdom.
The Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes (later known as the Kingdom of Yugoslavia) is proclaimed.
U.S. President Woodrow Wilson sails for the World War I peace talks in Versailles, becoming the first US president to travel to Europe while in office.
Friedrich Karl von Hessen, a German prince elected by the Parliament of Finland to become King Väinö I, renounces the Finnish throne.
Portuguese President Sidónio Pais is assassinated.

The 1918 United Kingdom general election occurs, the first where women were permitted to vote. In Ireland the Irish republican political party Sinn Féin wins a landslide victory with nearly 47% of the popular vote.
Giacomo Puccini's comic opera Gianni Schicchi premieres at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City.
Darwin Rebellion: Up to 1,000 demonstrators march on Government House in Darwin, Northern Territory, Australia.
Region of Međimurje is captured by the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes from Hungary.
The Great Poland Uprising against the Germans begins.
Ukrainian War of Independence: The Revolutionary Insurgent Army of Ukraine occupies Yekaterinoslav and seizes seven airplanes from the UPRAF, establishing an Insurgent Air Fleet.
Constance Markievicz, while detained in Holloway prison, becomes the first woman to be elected Member of Parliament (MP) to the British House of Commons.
The German Workers' Party, which would become the Nazi Party, is founded in Munich.
Montenegrin guerrilla fighters rebel against the planned annexation of Montenegro by Serbia, but fail.
Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht, two of the most prominent communists in Germany, are clubbed and then shot to death by members of the Freikorps at the end of the Spartacist uprising.
source_pages: Rosa_Luxemburg; Karl_Liebknecht; Communism; Freikorps; Spartacist_uprising; January_15

event_text: Great Molasses Flood: A wave of molasses released from an exploding storage tank sweeps through Boston, Massachusetts, killing 21 and injuring 150.

Nebraska becomes the 36th state to approve the Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. With the necessary three-quarters of the states approving the amendment, Prohibition is constitutionally mandated in the United States one year later.
World War I: The Paris Peace Conference opens in Versailles, France.
Ignacy Jan Paderewski becomes Prime Minister of the newly independent Poland.
A revolutionary Irish parliament is founded and declares the independence of the Irish Republic. One of the first engagements of the Irish War of Independence takes place.
Act Zluky is signed, unifying the Ukrainian People's Republic and the West Ukrainian National Republic.
The First Regional Congress of Peasants, Workers and Insurgents is held by the Makhnovshchina at Velykomykhailivka.
The Order of the White Rose of Finland is established by Baron Gustaf Mannerheim, the regent of the Kingdom of Finland.
The Battle of George Square takes place in Glasgow, Scotland, during a campaign for shorter working hours.
Charlie Chaplin, Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks, and D. W. Griffith launch United Artists.
The five-day Seattle General Strike begins, as more than 65,000 workers in the city of Seattle, Washington, walk off the job.
Friedrich Ebert (SPD), is elected President of Germany.
The Second Regional Congress of Peasants, Workers and Insurgents is held by the Makhnovshchina at Huliaipole.
The Polish–Soviet War begins.
The Ukrainian People's Republic asks the Entente and the United States for help fighting the Bolsheviks.
German socialist Kurt Eisner is assassinated. His death results in the establishment of the Bavarian Soviet Republic and parliament and government fleeing Munich, Germany.
President Woodrow Wilson signs an act of Congress establishing the Grand Canyon National Park.
March 1st Movement begins in Korea under Japanese rule.
The first Communist International meets in Moscow.
Ukrainian War of Independence: The Kontrrazvedka is established as the counterintelligence division of the Revolutionary Insurgent Army of Ukraine.
The American Legion is founded.
The Hungarian Soviet Republic is established becoming the first Communist government to be formed in Europe after the October Revolution in Russia.
In Milan, Italy, Benito Mussolini founds his Fascist political movement.
The Tetiev pogrom occurs in Ukraine, becoming the prototype of mass murder during the Holocaust.
Mexican Revolution leader Emiliano Zapata is ambushed and shot dead by government forces in Morelos.
The Third Regional Congress of Peasants, Workers and Insurgents is held by the Makhnovshchina at Huliaipole.

Jallianwala Bagh massacre: British Indian Army troops led by Brigadier-General Reginald Dyer kill approximately 379–1,000 unarmed demonstrators including men and women in Amritsar, India; and approximately 1,500 injured.
Mohandas Gandhi organizes a day of "prayer and fasting" in response to the killing of Indian protesters in the Jallianwala Bagh massacre by the British colonial troops three days earlier.
Polish–Lithuanian War: The Polish Army launches the Vilna offensive to capture Vilnius in modern Lithuania.
The Estonian Constituent Assembly is held in Estonia, which marks the birth of the Estonian Parliament, the Riigikogu.
German troops enter Munich to suppress the Bavarian Soviet Republic.
May Fourth Movement: Student demonstrations take place in Tiananmen Square in Beijing, China, protesting the Treaty of Versailles, which transferred Chinese territory to Japan.
Edward George Honey proposes the idea of a moment of silence to commemorate the Armistice of 11 November 1918 which ended World War I.
Uruguay becomes a signatory to the Buenos Aires copyright treaty.
The Winnipeg general strike begins. By 11:00, almost the whole working population of Winnipeg had walked off the job.
Greek occupation of Smyrna. During the occupation, the Greek army kills or wounds 350 Turks; those responsible are punished by Greek commander Aristides Stergiades.
A naval Curtiss NC-4 aircraft commanded by Albert Cushing Read leaves Trepassey, Newfoundland, for Lisbon via the Azores on the first transatlantic flight.
source_pages: Curtiss_NC-4; Albert_Cushing_Read; Trepassey; Newfoundland_and_Labrador; Lisbon; Azores; Transatlantic_flight

event_text: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk lands at Samsun on the Anatolian Black Sea coast, initiating what is later termed the Turkish War of Independence.
Sheikh Mahmud Barzanji, a Kurdish sheikh and at-the-time governor of the Slêmanî Province of British Iraq, initiates the first Mahmud Barzanji revolt.
The NC-4 aircraft arrives in Lisbon after completing the first transatlantic flight.
Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity is tested (later confirmed) by Arthur Eddington and Andrew Claude de la Cherois Crommelin.
Prohibition comes into force in Finland.
Anarchists simultaneously set off bombs in eight separate U.S. cities.
Women's rights: The U.S. Congress approves the Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which guarantees suffrage to women, and sends it to the U.S. states for ratification.
Leon Trotsky bans the Planned Fourth Regional Congress of Peasants, Workers and Insurgents.
Sette Giugno: Nationalist riots break out in Valletta, the capital of Malta. British soldiers fire into the crowd, killing four people.
Sir Barton wins the Belmont Stakes, becoming the first horse to win the U.S. Triple Crown.
John Alcock and Arthur Whitten Brown depart from St. John's, Newfoundland on the first nonstop transatlantic flight.
John Alcock and Arthur Brown complete the first nonstop transatlantic flight when they reach Clifden, County Galway, Ireland.
The Royal Canadian Mounted Police fire a volley into a crowd of unemployed war veterans, killing two, during the Winnipeg general strike.
Admiral Ludwig von Reuter scuttles the German fleet at Scapa Flow, Orkney. The nine sailors killed are the last casualties of World War I.
Estonian War of Independence: The decisive defeat of the Baltische Landeswehr in the Battle of Cēsis; this date is celebrated as Victory Day in Estonia.
The Treaty of Versailles is signed, ending the state of war between Germany and the Allies of World War I.
The British dirigible R34 lands in New York, completing the first crossing of the Atlantic Ocean by an airship.
The eight-hour day and free Sunday become law for workers in the Netherlands.
The British airship R34 lands in Norfolk, England, completing the first airship return journey across the Atlantic in 182 hours of flight.
The form of government in the Republic of Finland is officially confirmed. For this reason, July 17 is known as the Day of Democracy (Kansanvallan päivä) in Finland.
The dirigible Wingfoot Air Express crashes into the Illinois Trust and Savings Building in Chicago, killing 12 people.
Prince Regent Aleksander Karađorđević signs the decree establishing the University of Ljubljana
The Chicago Race Riot erupts after a racial incident occurred on a South Side beach, leading to 38 fatalities and 537 injuries over a five-day period.

The Anglo-Afghan Treaty of 1919 is signed. It establishes peaceful relations between Afghanistan and the UK, and confirms the Durand line as the mutual border. In return, the UK is no longer obligated to subsidize the Afghan government.
Germany's Weimar Constitution is signed into law.
Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, who founded the Republic of Turkey, gathers a congress in Sivas to make decisions as to the future of Anatolia and Thrace.
The Republic of German-Austria signs the Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye, ceding significant territories to Italy, Yugoslavia, and Czechoslovakia.
United States Marine Corps invades Honduras.
Fritz Pollard becomes the first African American to play professional football for a major team, the Akron Pros.
The steel strike of 1919, led by the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers, begins in Pennsylvania before spreading across the United States.
Race riots begin in Omaha, Nebraska, United States.

Seven days after suffering a "physical collapse" following a speech in Pueblo, Colorado, U.S. president Woodrow Wilson has a catastrophic stroke at the White House, leaving him physically and mentally incapacitated for the remainder of his presidency.
Cincinnati Reds pitcher Adolfo Luque becomes the first Latin American player to appear in a World Series.
KLM, the flag carrier of the Netherlands, is founded. It is the oldest airline still operating under its original name.
The Cincinnati Reds win the World Series, resulting in the Black Sox Scandal.
Adolf Hitler delivers his first public address at a meeting of the German Workers' Party.
Leeds United F.C. founded at Salem Chapel, Holbeck after the winding up of Leeds City F.C. for making illegal payments to players during World War I
The Fourth Regional Congress of Peasants, Workers and Insurgents is held by the Makhnovshchina at Oleksandrivsk.
The U.S. Congress passes the Volstead Act over President Woodrow Wilson's veto, paving the way for Prohibition to begin the following January.
The first Palmer Raid is conducted on the second anniversary of the Russian Revolution. Over 10,000 suspected communists and anarchists are arrested in 23 U.S. cities.

Eichenfeld massacre: Members of the Revolutionary Insurgent Army of Ukraine murder 136 Mennonite colonists at Jaskyowo, initiating a series of massacres that resulted in the deaths of 827 Ukrainian Mennonites.
The Industrial Workers of the World attack an Armistice Day parade in Centralia, Washington, ultimately resulting in the deaths of five people.
Latvian forces defeat the West Russian Volunteer Army at Riga in the Latvian War of Independence.
Lady Astor is elected as a Member of the Parliament of the United Kingdom. She is the first woman to sit in the House of Commons. (Countess Markievicz, the first to be elected, refused to sit.)
Lady Astor becomes the first female Member of Parliament (MP) to take her seat in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom. (She had been elected to that position on November 28.)
After nearly 20 years of planning and construction, including two collapses causing 89 deaths, the Quebec Bridge opens to traffic.
Ukrainian War of Independence: The Polonsky conspiracy is initiated, with an attempt to assassinate the high command of the Revolutionary Insurgent Army of Ukraine.
Ukrainian War of Independence: The Polonsky conspiracy is suppressed and its participants are executed by the Kontrrazvedka.
American anarchist Emma Goldman is deported to Russia.
Sex Disqualification (Removal) Act 1919 becomes law in the United Kingdom.
Babe Ruth of the Boston Red Sox is sold to the New York Yankees by owner Harry Frazee, allegedly establishing the Curse of the Bambino superstition.
The second Palmer Raid, ordered by the US Department of Justice, results in 6,000 suspected communists and anarchists being arrested and held without trial.
Over 640 are killed after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake strikes the Mexican states Puebla and Veracruz.
The New York State Assembly refuses to seat five duly elected Socialist assemblymen.
The steel strike of 1919 ends in failure for the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers labor union.
Ukrainian War of Independence: The All-Ukrainian Central Executive Committee outlaws the Makhnovshchina by decree, igniting the Bolshevik–Makhnovist conflict.
The Treaty of Versailles takes effect, officially ending World War I for all combatant nations except the United States.
League of Nations Covenant automatically enters into force after the Treaty of Versailles is ratified by Germany.
The Reichstag Bloodbath of January 13, 1920, the bloodiest demonstration in German history.
The League of Nations holds its first council meeting in Paris, France.
Alcohol Prohibition begins in the United States as the Volstead Act goes into effect.
The United States Senate votes against joining the League of Nations.
The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) is founded.
The Netherlands refuses to surrender the exiled Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany to the Allies.
Foundation of the Spanish Legion.
Japanese carmaker Mazda is founded, initially as a cork-producing company.
Under the terms of the Svalbard Treaty, international diplomacy recognizes Norwegian sovereignty over Arctic archipelago Svalbard, and designates it as demilitarized.
Józef Haller de Hallenburg performs the symbolic wedding of Poland to the sea, celebrating restitution of Polish access to open sea.
About 75% of the population in Zone I votes to join Denmark in the 1920 Schleswig plebiscites.
The Negro National League is formed.
The League of Women Voters is founded in Chicago.
An earthquake kills between 114 and 130 in Georgia and heavily damages the town of Gori.
Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom following her election as a Member of Parliament (MP) three months earlier.
The Nazi Party (NSDAP) was founded by Adolf Hitler in the Hofbräuhaus beer hall in Munich, Germany.
The Kapp Putsch begins when the Marinebrigade Ehrhardt is ordered to march on Berlin.
The Kapp Putsch briefly ousts the Weimar Republic government from Berlin.
In the second of the 1920 Schleswig plebiscites, about 80% of the population in Zone II votes to remain part of Weimar Germany.
The United States Senate rejects the Treaty of Versailles for the second time (the first time was on November 19, 1919).
Azeri and Turkish army soldiers with participation of Kurdish gangs attack the Armenian inhabitants of Shushi (Nagorno Karabakh).
source_pages: Azerbaijan_Democratic_Republic; Turkey; Kurds; Shusha_massacre; Armenians; Shusha; Nagorno-Karabakh

event_text: Palm Sunday tornado outbreak of 1920 affects the Great Lakes region and Deep South states.
Attempts are made to carry out the failed assassination attempt on General Mannerheim, led by Aleksander Weckman by order of Eino Rahja, during the White Guard parade in Tampere, Finland.
The four-day Nebi Musa riots commence.
Two security guards are murdered during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts. Anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti would be convicted of and executed for the crime, amid much controversy.
The Grand National Assembly of Turkey (TBMM) is founded in Ankara. The assembly denounces the government of Sultan Mehmed VI and announces the preparation of a temporary constitution.

At the San Remo conference, the principal Allied Powers of World War I adopt a resolution to determine the allocation of Class "A" League of Nations mandates for administration of the former Ottoman-ruled lands of the Middle East.
Ice hockey makes its Olympic debut at the Antwerp Games with center Frank Fredrickson scoring seven goals in Canada's 12–1 drubbing of Sweden in the gold medal match.
The Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic is founded.
The first game of the Negro National League baseball is played in Indianapolis.
A Bolshevik coup fails in the Democratic Republic of Georgia.
Authorities arrest Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti for alleged robbery and murder.

Polish–Soviet War: Kyiv offensive: Polish troops led by Józef Piłsudski and Edward Rydz-Śmigły and assisted by a symbolic Ukrainian force capture Kyiv only to be driven out by the Red Army counter-offensive a month later.
source_pages: Polish–Soviet_War; Kiev_offensive_(1920); Second_Polish_Republic; Józef_Piłsudski; Edward_Rydz-Śmigły; Ukrainian_People's_Republic; Kyiv; Red_Army

event_text: Treaty of Moscow: Soviet Russia recognizes the independence of the Democratic Republic of Georgia only to invade the country six months later.
Polish–Soviet War: The Polish army under General Edward Rydz-Śmigły celebrates its capture of Kiev with a victory parade on Khreshchatyk.
In Rome, Pope Benedict XV canonizes Joan of Arc.

The Louth flood of 1920 was a severe flash flooding in the Lincolnshire market town of Louth, resulting in 23 fatalities in 20 minutes. It has been described as one of the most significant flood disasters in the United Kingdom during the 20th century.
Hungary loses 71% of its territory and 63% of its population when the Treaty of Trianon is signed in Paris.

During the U.S. Republican National Convention in Chicago, U.S. Republican Party leaders gathered in a room at the Blackstone Hotel to come to a consensus on their candidate for the U.S. presidential election, leading the Associated Press to coin the political phrase "smoke-filled room".
Following the 1920 Schleswig plebiscites, Northern Schleswig is transferred from Germany to Denmark.
The Troubles in Ulster (1920–1922) begin with a week of sectarian violence in Derry.
Arthur Meighen becomes Prime Minister of Canada.
In the East Prussian plebiscite the local populace decides to remain with Weimar Germany.
The Soviet–Lithuanian Peace Treaty is signed, by which Soviet Russia recognizes the independence of Lithuania.
Aftermath of World War I: The Parliament of Poland establishes Silesian Voivodeship before the Polish-German plebiscite.
The Greek Army takes control of Silivri after Greece is awarded the city by the Paris Peace Conference; by 1923 Greece effectively lost control to the Turks.
The "Belfast Pogrom" begins two years of violence with the expulsion of thousands of Catholic shipyard, factory and linen mill workers from their jobs.
Construction of the Link River Dam begins as part of the Klamath Reclamation Project.
World War I: Ottoman sultan Mehmed VI's representatives sign the Treaty of Sèvres that divides up the Ottoman Empire between the Allies.
source_pages: World_War_I; List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire; Mehmed_VI; Treaty_of_Sèvres; Ottoman_Empire; Allies_of_World_War_I

event_text: The 1920 Cork hunger strike begins which eventually results in the deaths of three Irish Republicans including the Lord Mayor of Cork Terence MacSwiney.
The Latvian–Soviet Peace Treaty, which relinquished Russia's authority and pretenses to Latvia, is signed, ending the Latvian War of Independence.
Polish–Soviet War: The Battle of Warsaw begins and will last till August 25. The Red Army is defeated.

The 1920 Summer Olympics, having started four months earlier, officially open in Antwerp, Belgium, with the newly adopted Olympic flag and the Olympic oath being raised and taken at the Opening Ceremony for the first time in Olympic history.
Polish–Soviet War: Battle of Warsaw, so-called Miracle at the Vistula.

Ray Chapman of the Cleveland Indians is hit on the head by a fastball thrown by Carl Mays of the New York Yankees. Next day, Chapman will become the second player to die from injuries sustained in a Major League Baseball game.
source_pages: Ray_Chapman; Cleveland_Guardians; Fastball; Carl_Mays; New_York_Yankees; Major_League_Baseball

event_text: The congress of the Communist Party of Bukhara opens. The congress would call for armed revolution.
Polish–Soviet War: The Battle of Radzymin concludes; the Soviet Red Army is forced to turn away from Warsaw.
The Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, guaranteeing women's suffrage.
The Tambov Rebellion breaks out, in response to the Bolshevik policy of Prodrazvyorstka.
The first commercial radio station, 8MK (now WWJ), begins operations in Detroit.
The National Football League is organized as the American Professional Football Conference in Canton, Ohio
Polish–Soviet War: Battle of Warsaw, which began on August 13, ends with the Red Army's defeat.
The 19th amendment to United States Constitution, giving women the right to vote, is certified.
Polish–Soviet War: A decisive Polish victory in the Battle of Komarów.
Two newly purchased Savoia flying boats crash in the Swiss Alps en route to Finland where they were to serve with the Finnish Air Force, killing both crews.
The Wall Street bombing: A bomb in a horse wagon explodes in front of the J. P. Morgan building in New York City killing 38 and injuring 400.
The National Football League is organized as the American Professional Football Association in Canton, Ohio.
Irish War of Independence: British police known as "Black and Tans" burn the town of Balbriggan and kill two local men in revenge for an IRA assassination.
The Louisiana hurricane dissipated over Kansas after forcing around 4,500 people to evacuate and causing $1.45 million in damages.
Ukrainian War of Independence: The Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic agree to a truce with the Makhnovshchina.
Ukrainian War of Independence: Mikhail Frunze orders the Red Army to immediately cease hostilities with the Revolutionary Insurgent Army of Ukraine.
The Mannerheim League for Child Welfare, a Finnish non-governmental organization, is founded on the initiative of Sophie Mannerheim.
Ukrainian War of Independence: The Starobilsk agreement is signed by representatives of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and the Makhnovshchina.
The Carinthian plebiscite determines that the larger part of the Duchy of Carinthia should remain part of Austria.
Finland and Soviet Russia sign the Treaty of Tartu, exchanging some territories.
After 74 days on hunger strike in Brixton Prison, England, the Sinn Féin Lord Mayor of Cork, Terence MacSwiney dies.
The Communist Party of Australia is founded in Sydney.
In the United States, KDKA of Pittsburgh starts broadcasting as the first commercial radio station. The first broadcast is the result of the 1920 United States presidential election.
