Russian Civil War: The Russian Army retreats to Crimea, after a successful offensive by the Red Army and Revolutionary Insurgent Army of Ukraine.
source_pages: Russian_Civil_War; Army_of_Wrangel; Crimea; Northern_Taurida_Operation; Red_Army; Revolutionary_Insurgent_Army_of_Ukraine; November_3

event_text: Patriarch Tikhon of Moscow issues a decree that leads to the formation of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia.
Rupert Bear, illustrated by Mary Tourtel makes his first appearance in print.
The 1920 Cork hunger strike by Irish republicans ends after three deaths.
Italy and the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes sign the Treaty of Rapallo.
Pesäpallo, the Finnish version of baseball developed by Lauri Pihkala, is played for the first time at Kaisaniemi Park in Helsinki.
source_pages: Pesäpallo; Baseball; Lauri_Pihkala; Kaisaniemi_Park; Helsinki; November_14

event_text: The first assembly of the League of Nations is held in Geneva, Switzerland.
The Free City of Danzig is established.
Qantas, Australia's national airline, is founded as Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services Limited.

Irish War of Independence: On "Bloody Sunday" in Dublin, the Irish Republican Army (IRA) assassinated a group of British Intelligence agents, and British forces killed 14 civilians at a Gaelic football match at Croke Park.
source_pages: Irish_War_of_Independence; Bloody_Sunday_(1920); Irish_Republican_Army_(1919–1922); Cairo_Gang; Gaelic_football; Croke_Park

event_text: Ukrainian War of Independence: The Red Army launches a surprise attack against the Makhnovshchina.
FIDAC (The Interallied Federation of War Veterans Organisations), the first international organization of war veterans is established in Paris, France.
Irish War of Independence: Kilmichael Ambush: The Irish Republican Army ambush a convoy of British Auxiliaries and kill seventeen.
Following more than a month of Turkish–Armenian War, the Turkish-dictated Treaty of Alexandropol is concluded.

Irish War of Independence: In retaliation for a recent IRA ambush, British forces burn and loot numerous buildings in Cork city. Many civilians report being beaten, shot at, robbed and verbally abused by British forces.
The Haiyuan earthquake of 8.5Mw , rocks the Gansu province in China, killing an estimated 200,000.
King Constantine I is restored as King of the Hellenes after the death of his son Alexander of Greece and a plebiscite.
The GOELRO economic development plan is adopted by the 8th Congress of Soviets of the Russian SFSR.
Gabriele D'Annunzio surrendered the Italian Regency of Carnaro in the city of Fiume to Italian Armed Forces.
World premiere of the science fiction play R.U.R. by the Czech writer Karel Čapek in a theater in Hradec Králové.
Greco-Turkish War: The First Battle of İnönü, the first battle of the war, begins near Eskişehir in Anatolia.
The Marxist Left in Slovakia and the Transcarpathian Ukraine holds its founding congress in Ľubochňa.
The British K-class submarine HMS K5 sinks in the English Channel; all 56 on board die.
The first Constitution of Turkey is adopted, making fundamental changes in the source and exercise of sovereignty by consecrating the principle of national sovereignty.
Bolsheviks launch a revolt in Georgia as a preliminary to the Red Army invasion of Georgia.
Constituent Assembly of the Democratic Republic of Georgia adopts the country's first constitution.
Rezā Shāh takes control of Tehran during a successful coup.
After Russian forces under Baron Roman von Ungern-Sternberg drive the Chinese out, the Bogd Khan is reinstalled as the emperor of Mongolia.[citation needed]
Georgian capital Tbilisi falls to the invading Russian forces after heavy fighting and the Russians declare the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic.
The International Working Union of Socialist Parties is founded in Vienna.
The Australian cricket team captained by Warwick Armstrong becomes the first team to complete a whitewash of The Ashes, something that would not be repeated for 86 years.
Following mass protests in Petrograd demanding greater freedom in the RSFSR, the Kronstadt rebellion begins, with sailors and citizens taking up arms against the Bolsheviks.
The short-lived socialist Labin Republic is proclaimed.
Spanish Prime Minister Eduardo Dato Iradier is assassinated while on his way home from the parliament building in Madrid.
Six members of a group of Irish Republican Army activists known as the Forgotten Ten, are hanged in Dublin's Mountjoy Prison.
Talaat Pasha, former Grand Vizir of the Ottoman Empire and chief architect of the Armenian genocide is assassinated in Berlin by a 23-year-old Armenian, Soghomon Tehlirian.
source_pages: Talaat_Pasha; Ottoman_Empire; Armenian_genocide; Assassination_of_Talaat_Pasha; Soghomon_Tehlirian; March_15

event_text: The Second Polish Republic adopts the March Constitution.
The second Peace of Riga is signed between Poland and the Soviet Union.
The Kronstadt rebellion is suppressed by the Red Army.

Mongolian Revolution of 1921: The Mongolian People's Army defeated local Chinese forces at Altanbulag, Selenge (then known as Maimachen). This battle was seen as the birthday of the People's Army and completed the expulsion of Chinese militants in Mongolia.

Irish War of Independence: One of the biggest engagements of the war takes place at Crossbarry, County Cork. About 100 Irish Republican Army (IRA) volunteers escape an attempt by over 1,300 British forces to encircle them.
The Upper Silesia plebiscite, mandated by the Versailles Treaty to determine a section of the border between Weimar Germany and Poland, is held.
The New Economic Policy is implemented by the Bolshevik Party in response to the economic failure as a result of war communism.
The 1921 Women's Olympiad began in Monte Carlo, becoming the first international women's sports event.
The Royal Australian Air Force is formed.
The Autonomous Government of Khorasan, a military government encompassing the modern state of Iran, is established.
Emir Abdullah establishes the first centralised government in the newly created British protectorate of Transjordan.
The Jaffa riots commence.
Ireland is partitioned under British law by the Government of Ireland Act 1920, creating Northern Ireland and Southern Ireland.
West Virginia becomes the first state to legislate a broad sales tax, but does not implement it until a number of years later due to enforcement issues.
The creation of the Communist Party of Romania.
The United States Congress passes the Emergency Quota Act establishing national quotas on immigration.
The Tulsa race massacre kills at least 39, but other estimates of black fatalities vary from 55 to about 300.
Mikhail Tukhachevsky orders the use of chemical weapons against the Tambov Rebellion, bringing an end to the peasant uprising.
The village of Knockcroghery, Ireland, is burned by British forces.
Workers of Buckingham and Carnatic Mills in the city of Chennai, India, begin a four-month strike.
The Irish village of Knockcroghery was burned by British forces.
Serbian King Alexander I proclaims the new constitution of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, known thereafter as the Vidovdan Constitution.
U.S. President Warren G. Harding appoints former President William Howard Taft as Chief Justice of the United States.

The Chinese Communist Party is founded by Chen Duxiu and Li Dazhao, with the help of the Far Eastern Bureau of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks), who seized power in Russia after the 1917 October Revolution, and the Far Eastern Secretariat of the Communist International.
World War I: U.S. President Warren G. Harding signs the Knox–Porter Resolution formally ending the war between the United States and Germany.
Belfast's Bloody Sunday occurs with 20 killings, at least 100 wounded and 200 homes destroyed during rioting and gun battles in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
A truce in the Irish War of Independence comes into effect.
The Red Army captures Mongolia from the White Army and establishes the Mongolian People's Republic.
Former president of the United States William Howard Taft is sworn in as 10th chief justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, becoming the only person ever to hold both offices.
Rif War: The Spanish Army suffers its worst military defeat in modern times to the Berbers of the Rif region of Spanish Morocco.
source_pages: Rif_War; Spanish_Army; Battle_of_Annual; Berbers; Rif; Spanish_protectorate_in_Morocco; July_22

event_text: The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) is established at the founding National Congress.
Researchers at the University of Toronto, led by biochemist Frederick Banting, prove that the hormone insulin regulates blood sugar.
source_pages: University_of_Toronto; Biochemist; Frederick_Banting; Hormone; Insulin; Blood_sugar_level

event_text: Adolf Hitler becomes leader of the National Socialist German Workers' Party.
Major League Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis confirms the ban of the eight Chicago Black Sox, the day after they were acquitted by a Chicago court.
Bolshevik–Makhnovist conflict: Mikhail Frunze declares victory over the Makhnovshchina.
Tannu Uriankhai, later Tuvan People's Republic is established as a completely independent country (which is supported by Soviet Russia).
British airship R-38 experiences structural failure over Hull in England and crashes in the Humber Estuary; of her 49 British and American training crew, only four survive.
Russian Civil War: The Red Army dissolves the Makhnovshchina after driving the Revolutionary Insurgent Army out of Ukraine.
In Atlantic City, New Jersey, the first Miss America Pageant, a two-day event, is held.
The Legion of Mary, the largest apostolic organization of lay people in the Catholic Church, is founded in Dublin, Ireland.
Margaret Gorman, a 16-year-old, wins the Atlantic City Pageant's Golden Mermaid trophy; pageant officials later dubbed her the first Miss America.
Nahalal, a Jewish moshav in Palestine, is settled.
A storage silo in Oppau, Germany, explodes, killing 500–600 people.
The World Series is the first to be broadcast on radio.
KDKA in Pittsburgh's Forbes Field conducts the first live broadcast of a football game.
Soviet republics sign the Treaty of Kars to formalize the borders between Turkey and the South Caucasus states.
The Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic is formed as part of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic.
The Portuguese Prime Minister and several officials are murdered in the Bloody Night coup.
President Warren G. Harding delivers the first speech by a sitting U.S. president against lynching in the Deep South.
United States: Second trial of Sacco and Vanzetti in Boston, Massachusetts.
The Saalschutz Abteilung (hall defense detachment) of the Nazi Party is renamed the Sturmabteilung (storm detachment) after a large riot in Munich.
Japanese Prime Minister Hara Takashi is assassinated in Tokyo.
The National Fascist Party (Partito Nazionale Fascista or PNF) is founded in Italy.
The Tomb of the Unknowns is dedicated by U.S. President Warren G. Harding at Arlington National Cemetery.
The Communist Party of Spain is founded, and issues the first edition of Mundo obrero.
During The Troubles in Northern Ireland (1920–1922), 22 Irish Nationalists are killed in Belfast in one day.
Warren G. Harding, 29th President of the United States, signs the Willis–Campbell Act into law, prohibiting doctors from prescribing beer or liquor for medicinal purposes.
The Football Association bans women's football in England from league grounds, a ban that stays in place for 50 years.
The Anglo-Irish Treaty is signed in London by British and Irish representatives.
Opening of Visva-Bharati College, also known as Santiniketan College, now Visva Bharati University, India.
Dáil Éireann ratifies the Anglo-Irish Treaty by a 64–57 vote.[citation needed]
Leonard Thompson becomes the first person to be injected with insulin.
Knickerbocker Storm: Washington, D.C.'s biggest snowfall, causes a disaster when the roof of the Knickerbocker Theatre collapses, killing over 100 people.
The Washington Naval Treaty is signed in Washington, D.C., limiting the naval armaments of United States, Britain, Japan, France, and Italy.
Brazil becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
A challenge to the Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, allowing women the right to vote, is rebuffed by the Supreme Court of the United States in Leser v. Garnett.
The United Kingdom ends its protectorate over Egypt through a Unilateral Declaration of Independence.
Mahatma Gandhi is arrested in India, tried for sedition, and sentenced to six years in prison, only to be released after nearly two years for an appendicitis operation.
After Egypt gains nominal independence from the United Kingdom, Fuad I becomes King of Egypt.
In India, Mohandas Gandhi is sentenced to six years in prison for civil disobedience, of which he serves only two.
The USS Langley is commissioned as the first United States Navy aircraft carrier.

The McMahon killings take place in Belfast. Six Catholic civilians are shot dead, two others wounded and a female family member assaulted. Police were suspected as being responsible, but no one was prosecuted.
The German Social Democratic Party is founded in Poland.
In newly formed Northern Ireland, six Catholics are murdered in the Arnon Street killings, one week after six others were killed in the  McMahon killings.
Joseph Stalin becomes the first General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
The American Birth Control League, forerunner of Planned Parenthood, is incorporated.
Teapot Dome scandal: United States Secretary of the Interior Albert B. Fall leases federal petroleum reserves to private oil companies on excessively generous terms.
U.S. Senator John B. Kendrick of Wyoming introduces a resolution calling for an investigation of a secret land deal, which leads to the discovery of the Teapot Dome scandal.
The Treaty of Rapallo, pursuant to which Germany and the Soviet Union re-establish diplomatic relations, is signed.
The Soviet government creates South Ossetian Autonomous Oblast within Georgian SSR.
The first segment of the Imperial Wireless Chain providing wireless telegraphy between Leafield in Oxfordshire, England, and Cairo, Egypt, comes into operation.
The United States annexes the Kingman Reef.
Seamus Woods leads an Irish Republican Army attack on the headquarters of the Royal Irish Constabulary in Belfast.
The Young Pioneer Organization of the Soviet Union is established.
The Lincoln Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C.
The Royal Ulster Constabulary is founded.
Åland's Regional Assembly convened for its first plenary session in Mariehamn, Åland; today, the day is celebrated as Self-Government Day of Åland.
General election in the Irish Free State: The pro-Treaty Sinn Féin party wins a large majority.
Portuguese naval aviators Gago Coutinho and Sacadura Cabral complete the first aerial crossing of the South Atlantic.
British Army Field Marshal Sir Henry Wilson is killed by the Irish Republican Army helping to spark the Irish Civil War.
The American Professional Football Association is renamed the National Football League.
The Irish Civil War begins with the shelling of the Four Courts in Dublin by Free State forces.
France grants "one square kilometer" at Vimy Ridge "freely, and for all time, to the Government of Canada, the free use of the land exempt from all taxes".

In Washington D.C., U.S. Secretary of State Charles Evans Hughes and Dominican Ambassador Francisco J. Peynado sign the Hughes–Peynado agreement, which ends the United States occupation of the Dominican Republic.
The Great Railroad Strike of 1922 begins in the United States.
Johnny Weissmuller swims the 100 meters freestyle in 58.6 seconds breaking the world swimming record and the 'minute barrier'.
The Hollywood Bowl opens.
The Japanese Communist Party is established in Japan.
The League of Nations awards mandates of Togoland to France and Tanganyika to the United Kingdom.
The draft of the British Mandate of Palestine was formally confirmed by the Council of the League of Nations; it came into effect on 26 September 1923.
A typhoon hits Shantou, Republic of China, killing more than 50,000 people.
Michael Collins, Commander-in-chief of the Irish Free State Army, is shot dead in an ambush during the Irish Civil War.
Greco-Turkish War (1919–22): Turkish army launched what has come to be known to the Turks as the Great Offensive (Büyük Taarruz). The major Greek defense positions were overrun.
Greco-Turkish War: The Turkish army takes the Aegean city of Afyonkarahisar from the Kingdom of Greece.
Battle of Dumlupınar: The final battle in the Greco-Turkish War (Turkish War of Independence).
The Greco-Turkish War effectively ends with Turkish victory over the Greeks in Smyrna.
The Treaty of Kars is ratified in Yerevan, Armenia.
The final act of the Greco-Turkish War, the Great Fire of Smyrna, commences.
The Kingdom of Hungary is admitted to the League of Nations.
King Constantine I of Greece abdicates his throne in favor of his eldest son, George II.
The British Broadcasting Company (later Corporation)  is founded by a consortium, to establish a nationwide network of radio transmitters to provide a national broadcasting service.
British Conservative MPs vote to terminate the coalition government with the Liberal Party.
A referendum in Rhodesia rejects the country's annexation to the South African Union.
Italian fascists led by Benito Mussolini march on Rome and take over the Italian government.
Benito Mussolini is made Prime Minister of Italy.
Abolition of the Ottoman sultanate: The last sultan of the Ottoman Empire, Mehmed VI, abdicates.
In Egypt, British archaeologist Howard Carter and his men find the entrance to Tutankhamun's tomb in the Valley of the Kings.
The United States Supreme Court upholds mandatory vaccinations for public school students in Zucht v. King.
The British Broadcasting Company begins radio service in the United Kingdom.
At least 300 are massacred during a general strike in Guayaquil, Ecuador.
Rebecca Latimer Felton of Georgia takes the oath of office, becoming the first female United States Senator.
Nine Irish Republican Army members are executed by an Irish Free State firing squad. Among them is author Erskine Childers, who had been arrested for illegally carrying a revolver.
Howard Carter and Lord Carnarvon become the first people to enter the tomb of Pharaoh Tutankhamun in over 3,000 years.
The Toll of the Sea debuts as the first general release film to use two-tone Technicolor. (The Gulf Between was the first film to do so, but it was not widely distributed.)
The Armenian Revolutionary Committee declares Armenia to be a Soviet Socialist Republic, starting 71 years of Soviet rule in Armenia
One year to the day after the signing of the Anglo-Irish Treaty Ireland is partitioned. Northern Ireland and the Irish Free State come into existence.
The Parliament of Northern Ireland votes to remain a part of the United Kingdom and not unify with Southern Ireland.
Two days after coming into existence, the Irish Free State executes four leaders of the Irish Republican Army: Liam Mellows, Rory O'Connor, Joe McKelvey and Dick Barrett.
source_pages: Irish_Free_State; Irish_Republican_Army_(1922–1969); Liam_Mellows; Rory_O'Connor_(Irish_republican); Joe_McKelvey; Richard_Barrett_(Irish_republican); December_8

event_text: Gabriel Narutowicz is elected the first president of Poland.
Japanese aircraft carrier Hōshō becomes the first purpose-built aircraft carrier to be commissioned in the world.
The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) is formed.
Britain's Railways are grouped into the Big Four: LNER, GWR, SR, and LMS.
Juan de la Cierva makes the first autogyro flight.
Lithuanian residents of the Memel Territory rebel against the League of Nations' decision to leave the area as a mandated region under French control.
Occupation of the Ruhr: Troops from France and Belgium occupy the Ruhr area to force Germany to make its World War I reparation payments.
source_pages: Occupation_of_the_Ruhr; France; Belgium; Ruhr; Germany; World_War_I

event_text: Texas Tech University is founded as Texas Technological College in Lubbock, Texas.
Greece becomes the last European country to adopt the Gregorian calendar.
Howard Carter unseals the burial chamber of Pharaoh Tutankhamun.
US magazine Time publishes its first issue.
Charlie Daly and three other members of the Irish Republican Army are executed by Irish Free State forces.
The Arts Club of Chicago hosts the opening of Pablo Picasso's first United States showing, entitled Original Drawings by Pablo Picasso, becoming an early proponent of modern art in the United States.
Insulin becomes generally available for use by people with diabetes.
Racially motivated Nihon Shōgakkō fire lit by a serial arsonist kills 10 children in Sacramento, California.
The Duke of York weds Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon at Westminster Abbey.
Wembley Stadium is opened, named initially as the Empire Stadium.
The first 24 Hours of Le Mans is held in France. Run annually in June thereafter, it became the oldest endurance racing event in the world.
Bulgaria's military takes over the government in a coup.
The Parliament of Canada suspends all Chinese immigration.
The Treaty of Lausanne, settling the boundaries of modern Turkey, is signed in Switzerland by Greece, Bulgaria and other countries that fought in World War I.
Vice President Calvin Coolidge becomes U.S. President upon the death of President Warren G. Harding.
The United Kingdom gives the name "Ross Dependency" to part of its claimed Antarctic territory and makes the Governor-General of the Dominion of New Zealand its administrator.
The first British Track and Field championships for women are held in London, Great Britain.
Captain Lowell Smith and Lieutenant John P. Richter perform the first mid-air refueling on De Havilland DH-4B, setting an endurance flight record of 37 hours.
The Great Kantō earthquake devastates Tokyo and Yokohama, killing about 105,000 people.

Kantō Massacre: Amid rumors that Koreans had been conducting acts of sabotage in the aftermath of the 1923 Great Kantō earthquake, lynch mobs of Japanese begin massacring thousands of civilians over the course of several weeks, mainly ethnic minorities such as Koreans and Chinese.
Maiden flight of the first U.S. airship, the USS Shenandoah.
The International Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL) is formed.
Honda Point disaster: Nine US Navy destroyers run aground off the California coast. Seven are lost, and twenty-three sailors killed.
Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, the founder of the Republic of Turkey, founds the Republican People's Party.
Southern Rhodesia, today called Zimbabwe, is annexed by the United Kingdom.
Following a military coup in Spain, Miguel Primo de Rivera takes over, setting up a dictatorship.
The German government calls off the passive resistance to the French and Belgian occupation of the Ruhr.
The Mandate for Palestine takes effect, creating Mandatory Palestine.
The Mandate for Syria and Lebanon takes effect.
The First American Track and Field championships for women are held.
The 1923 Imperial Conference opened in London.
Georges Carpentier knocked out former British heavyweight champion Joe Beckett a mere twenty seconds into the first round of their boxing match at Olympia in London.
The Turkish National Movement enters Constantinople.
Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
After the Irish Civil War the 1923 Irish hunger strikes were undertaken by thousands of Irish republican prisoners protesting the continuation of their internment without trial.
The German Rentenmark is introduced in Germany to counter hyperinflation in the Weimar Republic.
Walt Disney and his brother, Roy, found the Disney Brothers Cartoon Studio, today known as The Walt Disney Company.
The royalist Leonardopoulos–Gargalidis coup d'état attempt fails in Greece, discrediting the monarchy and paving the way for the establishment of the Second Hellenic Republic.
German October: Due to a miscommunication with the party leadership, a militant section of the Communist Party of Germany launches an insurrection in Hamburg.
Turkey becomes a republic following the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire.
The first of 160 consecutive days of 100° Fahrenheit at Marble Bar, Western Australia.
The Finnish airline Aero O/Y (now Finnair) is founded.
Beer Hall Putsch: In Munich, Adolf Hitler leads the Nazis in an unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the German government.
In Munich, police and government troops crush the Nazi Beer Hall Putsch.
Adolf Hitler is arrested in Munich for high treason for his role in the Beer Hall Putsch.
The 1923 Irish hunger strikes ends, four Irish Republicans die from starvation.
United Kingdom and Nepal formally sign an agreement of friendship, called the Nepal–Britain Treaty of 1923, which superseded the Treaty of Sugauli signed in 1816.
Ramsay MacDonald becomes the first Labour Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The 1924 Winter Olympics opens in Chamonix, in the French Alps, inaugurating the Winter Olympic Games.
Six days after his death Lenin's body is carried into a specially erected mausoleum.
Russia–United Kingdom relations are restored, over six years after the Communist revolution.
The Royal Greenwich Observatory begins broadcasting the hourly time signals known as the Greenwich Time Signal.
The first state execution in the United States by gas chamber takes place in Nevada.
The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
The Ottoman Caliphate is abolished, when the Caliph Abdülmecid II of the Ottoman dynasty is deposed. The last remnant of the old monarchy gives way to the reformed Turkey of Kemal Atatürk.
source_pages: Ottoman_Caliphate; List_of_caliphs; Abdülmecid_II; Ottoman_dynasty; Turkey; Mustafa_Kemal_Atatürk

event_text: The Free State of Fiume is annexed by the Kingdom of Italy.
A mine disaster kills 172 coal miners near Castle Gate, Utah.
In accordance with the Treaty of Rome, Fiume becomes annexed as part of Italy.
On the anniversary of Greek Independence, Alexandros Papanastasiou proclaims the Second Hellenic Republic.
Adolf Hitler is sentenced to five years fortress confinement for his participation in the "Beer Hall Putsch" but spends only nine months in jail.
The Royal Canadian Air Force is formed.
A.E.K., a major Greek multi-sport club, is established in Athens by Greek refugees from Constantinople.
source_pages: A.E.K._(sports_club); Greece; Sports_club; Athens; Greek_refugees; Constantinople; April_13

event_text: Thorvald Stauning becomes premier of Denmark (first term).
The Klaipėda Convention is signed formally incorporating Klaipėda Region (Memel Territory) into Lithuania.
J. Edgar Hoover is appointed first Director of the United States' Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and remains so until his death in 1972.
University of Chicago students Richard Loeb and Nathan Leopold, Jr. murder 14-year-old Bobby Franks in a "thrill killing".
Hope Development School fire kills 24 people, mostly disabled children.
U.S. President Calvin Coolidge signs the Indian Citizenship Act into law, granting citizenship to all Native Americans born within the territorial limits of the United States.
British Mount Everest expedition: British mountaineers Andrew Irvine and George Mallory go missing.
Fascists kidnap and kill Italian Socialist leader Giacomo Matteotti in Rome.
The American occupation of the Dominican Republic ends after eight years.
The Johor–Singapore Causeway opens after five years of construction, providing a land connection for road and rail vehicles travelling between Johor and Singapore.

The National War Memorial for the Dominion of Newfoundland was inaugurated by Field Marshall Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig in St. John's, Newfoundland. The date commemorates the first day of the Battle of the Somme, where at Beaumont-Hamel, 86 percent of the Royal Newfoundland Regiment was wiped out.
source_pages: National_War_Memorial_(Newfoundland); Dominion_of_Newfoundland; Field_Marshall; Douglas_Haig,_1st_Earl_Haig; St._John's,_Newfoundland_and_Labrador; Battle_of_the_Somme; Beaumont-Hamel_Newfoundland_Memorial; Royal_Newfoundland_Regiment; July_1

event_text: Paavo Nurmi wins the 1,500 m and 5,000 m events at the Paris Olympics, with just an hour between the two races.
Eric Liddell won the gold medal in 400m at the 1924 Paris Olympics, after refusing to run in the heats for 100m, his favoured distance, on a Sunday.
Themistoklis Sofoulis becomes Prime Minister of Greece.
Diplomatic relations between Mexico and the Soviet Union are established.
The Georgian opposition stages the August Uprising against the Soviet Union.
Hanapepe massacre occurs on Kauai, Hawaii.
The Border Protection Corps is established in the Second Polish Republic for the defence of the eastern border against armed Soviet raids and local bandits.
The first aerial circumnavigation is completed by a team from the US Army.
Andreas Michalakopoulos becomes prime minister of Greece for a short period of time.

Second Zhili–Fengtian War: Warlord Feng Yuxiang, with the covert support of the Empire of Japan, stages a coup in Beijing against his erstwhile superiors in the Zhili clique, crippling their nearly victorious war effort against the Fengtian clique and forcing them to withdraw from northern China.
source_pages: Second_Zhili–Fengtian_War; Feng_Yuxiang; Empire_of_Japan; 1924_Beijing_Coup; Zhili_clique; Fengtian_clique; October_23

event_text: The Zinoviev letter, which Zinoviev himself denied writing, is published in the Daily Mail; the Labour party would later blame this letter for the Conservatives' landslide election win four days later.
The Uzbek SSR is founded in the Soviet Union.
World Savings Day is announced in Milan, Italy by the Members of the Association at the 1st International Savings Bank Congress (World Society of Savings Banks).
Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming becomes the first female elected as governor in the United States.
Edwin Hubble's discovery, that the Andromeda "nebula" is actually another island galaxy far outside our own Milky Way, is first published in The New York Times.
source_pages: Edwin_Hubble; Andromeda_Galaxy; Galaxy; Milky_Way; The_New_York_Times; November_23

event_text: The Mongolian People's Republic is officially established after a new constitution, passed by the first State Great Khural, abolishes the monarchy.
In New York City, the first Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade is held.
The National Hockey League's first United States–based franchise, the Boston Bruins, plays their first game in league play at home, at the still-extant Boston Arena indoor hockey facility.
A Soviet-backed communist 1924 Estonian coup d'état attempt fails in Estonia.
The last Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost is sold in London, England.
German serial killer Fritz Haarmann is sentenced to death for a series of murders.
Adolf Hitler is released from Landsberg Prison.
Albania becomes a republic.
Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming becomes the first female governor in the United States.
Albania declares itself a republic.
The Government of Turkey expels Patriarch Constantine VI from Istanbul.
The 1925 serum run to Nome: The second delivery of serum arrives in Nome, Alaska.
The New Yorker publishes its first issue.
The Charlevoix-Kamouraska earthquake strikes northeastern North America.
An earthquake (measuring around 7.0 magnitude) occurs in Dali, China, killing an estimated 5,000 people.
The 1925 Tri-State tornado hits the Midwestern states of Missouri, Illinois, and Indiana, killing 695 people.
The Butler Act prohibits the teaching of human evolution in Tennessee.
Syngman Rhee is removed from office after being impeached as the President of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea.
Ravel's opera L'enfant et les sortilèges, to a libretto by Colette, is premiered at the Opéra de Monte-Carlo.
The Schutzstaffel (SS) is founded under Adolf Hitler's Nazi Party in Germany.
The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald is first published in New York City, by Charles Scribner's Sons.

The Russian city of Tsaritsyn was renamed Stalingrad to honor the Soviet leader Joseph Stalin, Soviet Communist Party General Secretary, who had guided the defense of Tsaritsyn during the Russian Civil War in 1920.
During the Communist St Nedelya Church assault in Sofia, Bulgaria, 150 are killed and 500 are wounded.
The Communist Party of Korea (CPK) was founded in Japanese-ruled Korea (Chōsen) in Keijō (now Seoul) by Kim Yong-bom and Pak Hon-yong.
source_pages: Communist_Party_of_Korea; Korea_under_Japanese_rule; Keijō; Seoul; Kim_Yong-bom; Pak_Hon-yong; April_17

event_text: Colo-Colo, the most successful and popular soccer football team in the South American nation of Chile, was founded at the El Llano Stadium in San Miguel, Santiago, by footballer David Arellano and some of his teammates who had also left the Deportes Magallanes club.
source_pages: Colo-Colo; Chile; Estadio_Monumental_David_Arellano; San_Miguel,_Chile; David_Arellano; Deportes_Magallanes; April_19

event_text: Paul von Hindenburg defeats Wilhelm Marx in the second round of the German presidential election to become the first directly elected head of state of the Weimar Republic.
Automaker Dodge Brothers, Inc is sold to Dillon, Read & Co. for US$146 million plus $50 million for charity.
The All-China Federation of Trade Unions is officially founded. Today it is the largest trade union in the world, with 134 million members.
Mrs Dalloway, one of Virginia Woolf's earliest and best-known novels, was published.
The first modern performance of Claudio Monteverdi's opera Il ritorno d'Ulisse in patria occurred in Paris.
The opera Doktor Faust, unfinished when composer Ferruccio Busoni died, is premiered in Dresden.
Scopes Trial: John T. Scopes is indicted for teaching human evolution in Tennessee.
May Thirtieth Movement: Shanghai Municipal Police Force shoot and kill 13 protesting workers.
The original Chrysler Corporation was founded by Walter Chrysler from the remains of the Maxwell Motor Company.
Artek, the most famous Young Pioneer camp of the Soviet Union, is established.
Shameen Incident: British Army and French Army soldiers stationed in the concession of Shameen open fire on Chinese protesters, resulting in at least 52 deaths.
Scopes trial: In Dayton, Tennessee, the so-called "Monkey Trial" begins of John T. Scopes, a young high school science teacher accused of teaching evolution in violation of the Butler Act.
Adolf Hitler publishes Mein Kampf.
Scopes Trial: In Dayton, Tennessee, high school biology teacher John T. Scopes is found guilty of teaching human evolution in class and fined $100.
Malcolm Campbell becomes the first man to exceed 150 mph (241 km/h) on land. At Pendine Sands in Wales, he drives Sunbeam 350HP built by Sunbeam at a two-way average speed of 150.33 mph (242 km/h).
Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union (TASS) is established.
Plaid Cymru is formed with the aim of disseminating knowledge of the Welsh language that is at the time in danger of dying out.
A train robbery takes place in Kakori, near Lucknow, India, by the Indian independence revolutionaries, against the British government.

USS Shenandoah, the United States' first American-built rigid airship, was destroyed in a squall line over Noble County, Ohio. Fourteen of her 42-man crew perished, including her commander, Zachary Lansdowne.
Rif War: Spanish forces including troops from the Foreign Legion under Colonel Francisco Franco landing at Al Hoceima, Morocco.
Great Syrian Revolt: Rebels led by Fawzi al-Qawuqji captured Hama from the French Mandate of Syria.
S2, a Finnish Sokol class torpedo boat, sinks during a fierce storm near the coast of Pori in the Gulf of Bothnia, taking with it the whole crew of 53.
source_pages: Finnish_torpedo_boat_S2; S-class_torpedo_boat; Torpedo_boat; Pori; Gulf_of_Bothnia; October_4

event_text: Secret agent Sidney Reilly, the first "super-spy" of the 20th century, is executed by the OGPU, the secret police of the Soviet Union.
The Grand Ole Opry begins broadcasting in Nashville, Tennessee, as the WSM Barn Dance.
Final agreement is signed between the Irish Free State, Northern Ireland and the United Kingdom formalizing the Partition of Ireland.
Roman Catholic papal encyclical Quas primas introduces the Feast of Christ the King.
Crown Prince Nguyễn Phúc Vĩnh Thuỵ is crowned emperor of Vietnam, the country's last monarch.
Abdul-Aziz ibn Saud is crowned King of Hejaz.
The first demonstration of the television by John Logie Baird.
The El Virilla train accident, Costa Rica, kills 248 people and wounds another 93 when a train falls off a bridge over the Río Virilla between Heredia and Tibás.
History of Rocketry: Robert Goddard launches the first liquid-fueled rocket, at Auburn, Massachusetts.
Chiang Kai-shek initiates a purge of communist elements within the National Revolutionary Army in Guangzhou.
Varney Airlines makes its first commercial flight (Varney is the root company of United Airlines).
Violet Gibson attempts to assassinate Italian Prime Minister Benito Mussolini.
Al-Baqi cemetery, former site of the mausoleum of four Shi'a Imams, is leveled to the ground by Wahhabis.
The Treaty of Berlin is signed. Germany and the Soviet Union each pledge neutrality in the event of an attack on the other by a third party for the next five years.
The United Kingdom general strike begins.
Admiral Richard E. Byrd and Floyd Bennett claim to have flown over the North Pole (later discovery of Byrd's diary appears to cast some doubt on the claim.)
The Italian-built airship Norge becomes the first vessel to fly over the North Pole.
The 1926 United Kingdom general strike ends.
Evangelist Aimee Semple McPherson disappears in Venice, California.
Chiang Kai-shek replaces the communists in Kuomintang China.[vague]
Sholom Schwartzbard assassinates Symon Petliura, the head of the government of the Ukrainian People's Republic, which is in government-in-exile in Paris.
The 28 May 1926 coup d'état: Ditadura Nacional is established in Portugal to suppress the unrest of the First Republic.
Brazil leaves the League of Nations.
The 28th International Eucharistic Congress begins in Chicago, with over 250,000 spectators attending the opening procession.
The College Board administers the first SAT exam.
Mercedes-Benz is formed by Gottlieb Daimler and Karl Benz merging their two companies.

Chiang Kai-shek accepts the post of commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Army, marking the beginning of the Northern Expedition to unite China under the rule of the Nationalist government.
source_pages: Chiang_Kai-shek; National_Revolutionary_Army; Northern_Expedition; Republic_of_China_(1912–1949); Nationalist_government; July_9

event_text: Fox Film buys the patents of the Movietone sound system for recording sound onto film.
Harry Houdini performs his greatest feat, spending 91 minutes underwater in a sealed tank before escaping.
Gertrude Ederle becomes the first woman to swim across the English Channel.
First public screening using the Vitaphone process
Japan's public broadcasting company, Nippon Hōsō Kyōkai (NHK) is established.
Germany is admitted to the League of Nations.
The international Convention to Suppress the Slave Trade and Slavery is first signed.
Harry Houdini's last performance takes place at the Garrick Theatre in Detroit.
The United States Numbered Highway System is established.
The deadliest November tornado outbreak in U.S. history kills 76 people and injures more than 400.
Antanas Smetona assumes power in Lithuania as the 1926 coup d'état is successful.
World premiere of Sibelius's tone poem Tapiola.
New Mexican oil legislation goes into effect, leading to the formal outbreak of the Cristero War.
The first transatlantic commercial telephone service is established from New York City to London.
A fire at the Laurier Palace movie theatre in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, kills 78 children.
Fritz Lang's futuristic film Metropolis is released in Germany.
Louis B. Mayer, head of film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM), announces the creation of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, at a banquet in Los Angeles, California.
Teddy Wakelam gives the first live radio commentary of a football match, between Arsenal F.C. and Sheffield United at Highbury.
Ibn Saud takes the title of King of Nejd.
A revolt against the military dictatorship of Portugal breaks out at Porto.

U.S. President Calvin Coolidge signs a bill by Congress establishing the Federal Radio Commission (later replaced by the Federal Communications Commission) which was to regulate the use of radio frequencies in the United States.
German theoretical physicist Werner Heisenberg writes a letter to fellow physicist Wolfgang Pauli, in which he describes his uncertainty principle for the first time.
In New York City, Samuel Roxy Rothafel opens the Roxy Theatre.
The first Women's Boat Race between the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge takes place on The Isis in Oxford.
source_pages: Women's_Boat_Race; University_of_Oxford; University_of_Cambridge; The_Isis; Oxford; March_15

event_text: Nanking Incident: Foreign warships bombard Nanjing, China, in defence of the foreign citizens within the city.
Sunbeam 1000hp breaks the land speed record at Daytona Beach, Florida.
AT&T engineer Herbert Ives transmits the first long-distance public television broadcast (from Washington, D.C., to New York City, displaying the image of Commerce Secretary Herbert Hoover).
source_pages: AT&T_Corporation; Herbert_E._Ives; Television_broadcaster; Washington,_D.C.; New_York_City; United_States_Secretary_of_Commerce; Herbert_Hoover; April_7

event_text: Shanghai massacre of 1927: Chiang Kai-shek orders the Chinese Communist Party members executed in Shanghai, ending the First United Front.[citation needed]
Rocksprings, Texas is hit by an F5 tornado that destroys 235 of the 247 buildings in the town, kills 72 townspeople, and injures 205; third deadliest tornado in Texas history.
Mae West is sentenced to ten days in jail for obscenity for her play Sex.
Cardiff City defeat Arsenal in the FA Cup Final, the only time it has been won by a team not based in England.
Carabineros de Chile (Chilean national police force and gendarmerie) are created.
The Federal Industrial Institute for Women opens in Alderson, West Virginia, as the first women's federal prison in the United States.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is incorporated.
Attempting to make the first non-stop transatlantic flight from Paris to New York, French war heroes Charles Nungesser and François Coli disappear after taking off aboard The White Bird biplane.
The Old Parliament House, Canberra, Australia, officially opens.
The Bath School disaster: Forty-five people, including many children, are killed by bombs planted by a disgruntled school-board member in Bath Township, Michigan.
After being founded for 20 years, the Nationalist government approves Tongji University to be among the first national universities of the Republic of China.
Treaty of Jeddah: The United Kingdom recognizes the sovereignty of King Ibn Saud in the Kingdoms of Hejaz and Nejd, which later merge to become the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
source_pages: Treaty_of_Jeddah_(1927); Sovereignty; Ibn_Saud; Hejaz; Najd; Saudi_Arabia

event_text: Charles Lindbergh takes off for Paris from Roosevelt Field in Long Island, N.Y., aboard the Spirit of St. Louis on the first nonstop solo flight across the Atlantic Ocean, landing 33+1⁄2 hours later.
Charles Lindbergh touches down at Le Bourget Field in Paris, completing the world's first solo nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean.
Near Xining, China, an 8.3 magnitude earthquake causes 200,000 deaths in one of the world's most destructive earthquakes.
The last Ford Model T rolls off the assembly line after a production run of 15,007,003 vehicles.
The Ford Motor Company ceases manufacture of the Ford Model T and begins to retool plants to make the Ford Model A.
Aviator Charles Lindbergh receives a ticker tape parade up 5th Avenue in New York City.
The Cyclone roller coaster opens on Coney Island.

Prime Minister of Japan Tanaka Giichi convenes an eleven-day conference to discuss Japan's strategy in China. The Tanaka Memorial, a forged plan for world domination, is later claimed to be a secret report leaked from this conference.
The Bird of Paradise, a U.S. Army Air Corps Fokker tri-motor, completes the first transpacific flight, from the mainland United States to Hawaii.
First flight of the Lockheed Vega.
Kevin O'Higgins TD, Vice-President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State, is assassinated by the IRA.
Massacre of July 15, 1927: Eighty-nine protesters are killed by Austrian police in Vienna.

Augusto César Sandino leads a raid on U.S. Marines and Nicaraguan Guardia Nacional that had been sent to apprehend him in the village of Ocotal, but is repulsed by one of the first dive-bombing attacks in history.
The first station of the Indian Broadcasting Company goes on the air in Bombay.
The Menin Gate war memorial is unveiled at Ypres.

The Nanchang Uprising marks the first significant battle in the Chinese Civil War between the Kuomintang and Chinese Communist Party. This day is commemorated as the anniversary of the founding of the People's Liberation Army.
The Peace Bridge opens between Fort Erie, Ontario and Buffalo, New York.
The Dole Air Race begins from Oakland, California, to Honolulu, Hawaii, during which six out of the eight participating planes crash or disappear.
Patriarch Sergius of Moscow proclaims the declaration of loyalty of the Russian Orthodox Church to the Soviet Union.
Italian anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti are executed after a lengthy, controversial trial.
Five Canadian women file a petition to the Supreme Court of Canada, asking: "Does the word 'Persons' in Section 24 of the British North America Act, 1867, include female persons?"
The first fully electronic television system is achieved by Philo Farnsworth.
The Columbia Broadcasting System goes on the air.
Gutzon Borglum begins sculpting Mount Rushmore.
Opening of The Jazz Singer, the first prominent "talkie" movie.
The Imatra Cinema is destroyed in a fire in Tampere, Finland, during showing the 1924 film Wages of Virtue; 21 people die in the fire and almost 30 are injured.
The Italian luxury liner SS Principessa Mafalda sinks off the coast of Brazil, killing 314.
Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party, leaving Joseph Stalin in undisputed control of the Soviet Union.
The Holland Tunnel opens to traffic as the first Hudson River vehicle tunnel linking New Jersey to New York City.
Columbine Mine massacre: Striking coal miners are allegedly attacked with machine guns by a detachment of state police dressed in civilian clothes.
Following 19 years of Ford Model T production, the Ford Motor Company unveils the Ford Model A as its new automobile.
Guangzhou Uprising: Communist Red Guards launch an uprising in Guangzhou, China, taking over most of the city and announcing the formation of a Guangzhou Soviet.
Indian revolutionary Rajendra Lahiri is hanged in Gonda jail, Uttar Pradesh, India, two days before the scheduled date.
Three Indian revolutionaries, Ram Prasad Bismil, Roshan Singh and Ashfaqulla Khan, are executed by the British Raj for participation in the Kakori conspiracy.
B. R. Ambedkar and his followers burn copies of the Manusmriti in Mahad, Maharashtra, to protest its treatment of Dalit people.
source_pages: B._R._Ambedkar; Manusmriti; Mahad; Maharashtra; Dalit; December_25

event_text: Kern and Hammerstein's musical play Show Boat, considered to be the first true American musical play, opens at the Ziegfeld Theatre on Broadway.
The Ginza Line, the first subway line in Asia, opens in Tokyo, Japan.
Boris Bazhanov defects through Iran to seek asylum in France. He is the only member of Joseph Stalin's secretariat to have defected from the Soviet Union.
source_pages: Boris_Bazhanov; Iran; France; Joseph_Stalin; Soviet_Union; January_1

event_text: A disastrous flood of the River Thames kills 14 people and causes extensive damage to much of riverside London.
Bundaberg tragedy: a diphtheria vaccine is contaminated with Staph. aureus bacterium, resulting in the deaths of twelve children in the Australian town of Bundaberg.
Leon Trotsky is exiled to Alma-Ata.
In California, the St. Francis Dam fails; the resulting floods kill 431 people.
Charles Lindbergh is presented with the Medal of Honor for the first solo trans-Atlantic flight.
The Bremen, a German Junkers W 33 type aircraft, takes off for the first successful transatlantic aeroplane flight from east to west.

The Jinan incident begins with the deaths of twelve Japanese civilians by Chinese forces in Jinan, China, which leads to Japanese retaliation and the deaths of over 2,000 Chinese civilians in the following days.
The President of the Republic of China, Zhang Zuolin, is assassinated by Japanese agents.
Second Northern Expedition: The National Revolutionary Army captures Beijing, whose name is changed to Beiping ("Northern Peace").
Charles Kingsford Smith completes the first trans-Pacific flight in a Fokker Trimotor monoplane, the Southern Cross.
Aviator Amelia Earhart becomes the first woman to fly in an aircraft across the Atlantic Ocean (she is a passenger; Wilmer Stultz is the pilot and Lou Gordon the mechanic).
The Rovaniemi township decree is promulgated, as a result of which Rovaniemi secedes from the old rural municipality as its own market town on January 1, 1929.
Sliced bread is sold for the first time (on the inventor's 48th birthday) by the Chillicothe Baking Company of Chillicothe, Missouri.
The Kellogg–Briand Pact outlawing war is signed by fifteen nations. Ultimately sixty-one nations will sign it.
The Okeechobee hurricane strikes southeastern Florida, killing more than 2,500 people.
Juan de la Cierva makes the first Autogyro crossing of the English Channel.
The Republic of China is recognized by the United States.
Alexander Fleming notices a bacteria-killing mold growing in his laboratory, discovering what later became known as penicillin.
The Soviet Union introduces its first five-year plan.
Newark Liberty International Airport opens, becoming the first airport in the New York City metro area.
The "Prelature of the Holy Cross and the Work of God", commonly known as Opus Dei, is founded.
Chiang Kai-shek becomes Chairman of the Republic of China.
An iron lung respirator is used for the first time at Boston Children's Hospital.
The airship Graf Zeppelin completes its first trans-Atlantic flight, landing at Lakehurst, New Jersey, United States.
Indonesia Raya, now the national anthem of Indonesia, is first played during the Second Indonesian Youth Congress.
The Law on the Adoption and Implementation of the Turkish Alphabet, replaces the Arabic alphabet with the Latin alphabet.
SS Vestris sinks approximately 200 miles (320 km) off Hampton Roads, Virginia, killing at least 110 passengers, mostly women and children who die after the vessel is abandoned.
The RNLI lifeboat Mary Stanford capsizes in Rye Harbour with the loss of the entire 17-man crew.
Release of the animated short Steamboat Willie, the first fully synchronized sound cartoon.
Cosmo Gordon Lang was enthroned as the Archbishop of Canterbury, the first bachelor to be appointed in 150 years.
The government of Colombia sends military forces to suppress a month-long strike by United Fruit Company workers, resulting in an unknown number of deaths.

Indian revolutionaries Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev Thapar and Shivaram Rajguru assassinate British police officer James Saunders in Lahore, Punjab, to avenge the death of Lala Lajpat Rai at the hands of the police. The three were executed in 1931.
source_pages: Bhagat_Singh; Sukhdev_Thapar; Shivaram_Rajguru; Lahore; Punjab; Lala_Lajpat_Rai

event_text: The former municipalities of Point Grey, British Columbia and South Vancouver, British Columbia are amalgamated into Vancouver.
King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution, starting the January 6th Dictatorship.
Mother Teresa arrives by sea in Calcutta, India, to begin her work among India's poorest and sick people.
Members of the Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng assassinate the labor recruiter Bazin, prompting a crackdown by French colonial authorities.
The Kingdom of Italy and the Vatican sign the Lateran Treaty.
Saint Valentine's Day Massacre: Seven people, six of them gangster rivals of Al Capone's gang, are murdered in Chicago.

In the first battle of the Warlord Rebellion in northeastern Shandong against the Nationalist government of China, a 24,000-strong rebel force led by Zhang Zongchang was defeated at Zhifu by 7,000 NRA troops.
President Calvin Coolidge signs legislation establishing the 96,000 acres (390 km2) Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming.
Huey P. Long, Governor of Louisiana, is impeached by the Louisiana House of Representatives.
The inaugural Monaco Grand Prix takes place in the Principality of Monaco. William Grover-Williams wins driving a Bugatti Type 35.
The 7.2 Mw  Kopet Dag earthquake shakes the Iran–Turkmenistan border region with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), killing up to 3,800 and injuring 1,121.
A fire at the Cleveland Clinic in Cleveland, Ohio kills 123.
In Hollywood, the first Academy Awards ceremony takes place.
The 1st Conference of the Communist Parties of Latin America is held in Buenos Aires.
The Lateran Treaty is ratified, bringing Vatican City into existence.
Margaret Bondfield is appointed Minister of Labour. She is the first woman appointed to the Cabinet of the United Kingdom.
The town of Murchison, New Zealand is rocked by a 7.8 magnitude earthquake killing 17. At the time it was New Zealand's worst natural disaster.
An agreement brokered by U.S. Ambassador Dwight Whitney Morrow ends the Cristero War in Mexico.
The Kellogg–Briand Pact, renouncing war as an instrument of foreign policy, goes into effect (it is first signed in Paris on August 27, 1928, by most leading world powers).
The Geneva Convention of 1929, dealing with treatment of prisoners-of-war, is signed by 53 nations.
The German airship Graf Zeppelin begins a round-the-world flight.
Babe Ruth becomes the first baseball player to hit 500 home runs in his career with a home run at League Park in Cleveland, Ohio.
The 1929 Palestine riots break out in Mandatory Palestine between Palestinian Arabs and Jews and continue until the end of the month. In total, 133 Jews and 116 Arabs are killed.

Hebron Massacre during the 1929 Palestine riots: Arab attacks on the Jewish community in Hebron in the British Mandate of Palestine occur, continuing until the next day, resulting in the death of 65–68 Jews and the remaining Jews being forced to leave the city.

Second day of two-day Hebron massacre during the 1929 Palestine riots: Arab attacks on the Jewish community in Hebron in the British Mandate of Palestine, result in the death of 65–68 Jews; the remaining Jews are forced to flee the city.
Steamer Kuru capsizes and sinks on Lake Näsijärvi near Tampere in Finland. One hundred thirty-six lives are lost.
Jimmy Doolittle performs the first flight without a window, proving that full instrument flying from take off to landing is possible.
The Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes is renamed to Yugoslavia by King Alexander I.
Photius II becomes Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople.
The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council overrules the Supreme Court of Canada in Edwards v. Canada when it declares that women are considered "Persons" under Canadian law.
"Black Thursday" on the New York Stock Exchange.
Black Tuesday: The New York Stock Exchange crashes, ending the Great Bull Market of the 1920s and beginning the Great Depression.
The Gwangju Student Independence Movement occurred.
In New York City, the Museum of Modern Art opens to the public.

Grand Banks earthquake: Off the south coast of Newfoundland in the Atlantic Ocean, a Richter magnitude 7.2 submarine earthquake, centered on the  Grand Banks, breaks 12 submarine transatlantic telegraph cables and triggers a tsunami that destroys many south coast communities in the Burin Peninsula.
source_pages: 1929_Grand_Banks_earthquake; Newfoundland_(island); Richter_scale; Grand_Banks_of_Newfoundland; Transatlantic_telegraph_cable; Tsunami; Burin_Peninsula

event_text: The Finnish far-right Lapua Movement officially begins when a group of mainly the former White Guard members, led by Vihtori Kosola, interrupted communism occasion at the Workers' House in Lapua, Finland.
source_pages: Lapua_Movement; White_Guard_(Finland); Vihtori_Kosola; Communism; Lapua; November_24

event_text: U.S. Admiral Richard E. Byrd leads the first expedition to fly over the South Pole.
President Herbert Hoover delivers his first State of the Union message to Congress. It is presented in the form of a written message rather than a speech.
The Indian National Congress promulgates the Purna Swaraj (the Declaration of the Independence of India).
Assassination attempt on Argentine President Hipólito Yrigoyen.
A four alarm fire breaks out in the West Wing of the White House in Washington, D.C.
Soviet General Secretary Joseph Stalin orders the "liquidation of the kulaks as a class".
Clessie Cummins arrives at the National Automobile Show in New York City, having driven a car powered by one of his diesel engines from Indianapolis.
The Indian National Congress declares 26 January as Independence Day or as the day for Poorna Swaraj ("Complete Independence") which occurred 17 years later.

The Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union orders the confiscation of lands belonging to the Kulaks in a campaign of Dekulakization, resulting in the executions and forced deportations of millions.
The Communist Party of Vietnam is founded at a "Unification Conference" held in Kowloon, British Hong Kong.
The Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng launches the failed Yên Bái mutiny in hope of overthrowing French protectorate over Vietnam.
The Romanian Football Federation joins FIFA.
While studying photographs taken in January, Clyde Tombaugh discovers Pluto.
Elm Farm Ollie becomes the first cow to fly in a fixed-wing aircraft and also the first cow to be milked in an aircraft.
International Unemployment Day demonstrations globally initiated by the Comintern.
Mahatma Gandhi begins the Salt March, a 200-mile (320 km) march to the sea to protest the British monopoly on salt in India.
The news of the discovery of Pluto is announced by Lowell Observatory.
The Motion Picture Production Code is instituted, imposing strict guidelines on the treatment of sex, crime, religion and violence in film, in the U.S., for the next thirty-eight years.
After the mysterious death of Empress Zewditu, Haile Selassie is proclaimed emperor of Ethiopia.
At the end of the Salt March, Gandhi raises a lump of mud and salt and declares, "With this, I am shaking the foundations of the British Empire."
A fire kills 118 people at a wooden church in the small Romanian town of Costești, most of them schoolchildren, after starting during Good Friday services.
The United Kingdom, Japan and the United States sign the London Naval Treaty regulating submarine warfare and limiting shipbuilding.
The Independence Producers host the first night game in the history of Organized Baseball in Independence, Kansas.
"Pluto" is officially proposed for the name of the newly discovered dwarf planet by Vesto Slipher in the Lowell Observatory Observation Circular. The name quickly catches on.
The 1930 Bago earthquake, the former of two major earthquakes in southern Burma kills as many as 7,000 in Yangon and Bago.
The 7.1 Mw  Salmas earthquake shakes northwestern Iran and southeastern Turkey with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). Up to three-thousand people were killed.
Amy Johnson lands in Darwin, Northern Territory, becoming the first woman to fly solo from England to Australia (she left on May 5 for the 11,000 mile flight).
The 1,046 feet (319 m) Chrysler Building in New York City, the tallest man-made structure at the time, opens to the public.
The Deccan Queen is introduced as first intercity train between Bombay VT (Now Mumbai CST) and Poona (Pune) to run on electric locomotives.
A Chicago Tribune reporter, Jake Lingle, is killed during rush hour at the Illinois Central train station by Leo Vincent Brothers, allegedly over a $100,000 gambling debt owed to Al Capone.
Sovnarkom establishes decree time in the USSR.
U.S. President Herbert Hoover signs the Smoot–Hawley Tariff Act into law.
One-year conscription comes into force in France.
Industrialist Henry J. Kaiser begins construction of Boulder Dam (now known as Hoover Dam).
The Finnish far-right Lapua Movement organises the Peasant March demonstration in Helsinki to put pressure on the government to prohibit communist activities.
The inaugural FIFA World Cup begins in Uruguay.
In Montevideo, Uruguay wins the first FIFA World Cup by beating Argentina.
The last confirmed lynching of black people in the Northern United States occurs in Marion, Indiana; two men, Thomas Shipp and Abram Smith, are killed.
The first color sound cartoon, Fiddlesticks, is released by Ub Iwerks.
The first British Empire Games are opened in Hamilton, Ontario, by the Governor General of Canada, the Viscount Willingdon.
The last 36 remaining inhabitants of St Kilda are voluntarily evacuated to other parts of Scotland.
Democratically elected Argentine president Hipólito Yrigoyen is deposed in a military coup.
The Kurdish Ararat rebellion is suppressed by the Turks.
Bobby Jones wins the (pre-Masters) Grand Slam of golf.
British airship R101 crashes in France en route to India on its maiden voyage killing 48 people.
The former and first President of Finland, K. J. Ståhlberg, and his wife, Ester Ståhlberg, are kidnapped from their home by members of the far-right Lapua Movement.
source_pages: President_of_Finland; Kaarlo_Juho_Ståhlberg; Ester_Ståhlberg; Ståhlberg_kidnapping; Lapua_Movement; October_14

event_text: A bloodless coup d'état in Brazil ends the First Republic, replacing it with the Vargas Era.
Ratifications exchanged in London for the first London Naval Treaty go into effect immediately, further limiting the expensive naval arms race among its five signatories.
Getúlio Vargas becomes Head of the Provisional Government in Brazil after a bloodless coup on October 24.
Patent number US1781541 is awarded to Albert Einstein and Leó Szilárd for their invention, the Einstein refrigerator.
Great Depression: In a State of the Union message, U.S. President Herbert Hoover proposes a $150 million public works program to help generate jobs and stimulate the economy.

W1XAV in Boston, Massachusetts telecasts video from the CBS radio orchestra program, The Fox Trappers. The telecast also includes the first television advertisement in the United States, for I.J. Fox Furriers, which also sponsored the radio show.
Sir Muhammad Iqbal's presidential address in Allahabad introduces the two-nation theory and outlines a vision for the creation of Pakistan.
Guy Menzies flies the first solo non-stop trans-Tasman flight (from Australia to New Zealand) in 11 hours and 45 minutes, crash-landing on New Zealand's west coast.
Sir Isaac Isaacs is sworn in as the first Australian-born Governor-General of Australia.
The Hawke's Bay earthquake, New Zealand's worst natural disaster, kills 258.
The British Raj completes its transfer from Calcutta to New Delhi.
The U.S. Congress approves the construction of the San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge by the state of California.
An anarchist uprising in Encarnación, Paraguay briefly transforms the city into a revolutionary commune.
The British Raj: Gandhi–Irwin Pact is signed.
The Parliament House of Finland is officially inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland.
Alam Ara, India's first talking film, is released.
Governor Fred B. Balzar signs a bill legalizing gambling in Nevada.
Bhagat Singh, Shivaram Rajguru and Sukhdev Thapar are hanged for the killing of a deputy superintendent of police during the Indian independence movement.
The Scottsboro Boys are arrested in Alabama and charged with rape.
Swissair is founded as the national airline of Switzerland.
Ho Chi Minh Communist Youth Union is founded in Vietnam.
An earthquake in Nicaragua destroys Managua; killing 2,000.
A Transcontinental & Western Air airliner crashes near Bazaar, Kansas, killing eight, including University of Notre Dame head football coach Knute Rockne.
The Second Spanish Republic is proclaimed and King Alfonso XIII goes to exile. Meanwhile, in Barcelona, Francesc Macià proclaims the Catalan Republic.
source_pages: Second_Spanish_Republic; King; Alfonso_XIII; Barcelona; Francesc_Macià; Catalan_Republic_(1931); April_14

event_text: After negotiations between Catalan and Spanish provisional governments, the Catalan Republic proclaimed in April 14 becomes the Generalitat de Catalunya, the autonomous government of Catalonia within the Spanish Republic.
The Empire State Building is dedicated in New York City.
The stand-off between criminal Francis Crowley and 300 members of the New York Police Department takes place in his fifth-floor apartment on West 91st Street, New York City.
Five unarmed civilians are killed in the Ådalen shootings, as the Swedish military is called in to deal with protesting workers.
Michele Schirru, a citizen of the United States, is executed by a Royal Italian Army firing squad for intent to kill Benito Mussolini.
Wiley Post and Harold Gatty take off from Roosevelt Field, Long Island in an attempt to circumnavigate the world in a single-engine plane.
United Airlines begins service (as Boeing Air Transport).
Wiley Post and Harold Gatty become the first people to circumnavigate the globe in a single-engined monoplane aircraft.
Emperor Haile Selassie signs the first constitution of Ethiopia.
Resignation of the United Kingdom's Second Labour Government. Formation of the UK National Government.
Imperial Japan instigates the Mukden incident as a pretext to invade and occupy Manchuria.
The George Washington Bridge in the United States is opened, linking New Jersey and New York.
Clara Campoamor persuades the Constituent Cortes to enfranchise women in Spain's new constitution.
Clyde Edward Pangborn and Hugh Herndon,Jr. make the first nonstop flight across the Pacific Ocean in the plane Miss Veedol.
Al Capone is convicted of income tax evasion.
A secret society in the Imperial Japanese Army launches an abortive coup d'état attempt.
The George Washington Bridge opens to public traffic over the Hudson River.
The Chinese Soviet Republic is proclaimed on the anniversary of the October Revolution.
The Constituent Cortes approves a constitution which establishes the Second Spanish Republic.

Statute of Westminster 1931: The British Parliament establishes legislative equality between the UK and the Dominions of the Commonwealth—Australia, Canada, Newfoundland, New Zealand, South Africa, and Ireland.
source_pages: Statute_of_Westminster_1931; Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom; Dominion; Commonwealth_of_Nations; Dominion_of_Newfoundland; Dominion_of_New_Zealand; Union_of_South_Africa; Irish_Free_State

event_text: The United States Post Office Department issues a set of 12 stamps commemorating the 200th anniversary of George Washington's birth.
Hattie Caraway becomes the first woman elected to the United States Senate.
Alt Llobregat insurrection breaks out in Central Catalonia, Spain.
Finland and the Soviet Union sign a non-aggression treaty.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Chinese National Revolutionary Army begins the defense of Harbin.
Alt Llobregat insurrection suppressed in Central Catalonia, Spain.
Japanese forces attack Shanghai.
Second Sino-Japanese War: Harbin, Manchuria, falls to Japan.
Prohibition law is abolished in Finland after a national referendum, where 70% voted for a repeal of the law.

The Empire of Japan creates the independent state of Manzhouguo (the obsolete Chinese name for Manchuria) free from the Republic of China and installed former Chinese Emperor Aisin Gioro Puyi as Chief Executive of the State.
source_pages: Empire_of_Japan; Manchukuo; Manchuria; Republic_of_China_(1912–1949); Emperor_of_China; Puyi

event_text: Adolf Hitler, having been stateless for seven years, obtains German citizenship when he is appointed a Brunswick state official by Dietrich Klagges, a fellow Nazi. As a result, Hitler is able to run for Reichspräsident in the 1932 election.
source_pages: Adolf_Hitler; Statelessness; Free_State_of_Brunswick; Dietrich_Klagges; President_of_Germany_(1919–1945); February_25

event_text: The Mäntsälä rebellion begins when members of the far-right Lapua Movement start shooting at the social democrats' event in Mäntsälä, Finland.
Aviator Charles Lindbergh's 20-month-old son Charles Jr is kidnapped from his home in East Amwell, New Jersey. His body would not be found until May 12.
Finnish president P. E. Svinhufvud gives a radio speech, which four days later finally ends the Mäntsälä Rebellion and the far-right Lapua Movement that started it.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is opened.
The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier is unveiled in Athens.
Dominion of Newfoundland: Ten thousand rioters seize the Colonial Building leading to the end of self-government.
Benny Rothman leads the mass trespass of Kinder Scout, leading to substantial legal reforms in the United Kingdom.

Having been incarcerated at the Cook County Jail since his sentencing on October 24, 1931, mobster Al Capone is transferred to the federal penitentiary in Atlanta after the U.S. Supreme Court denies his appeal for conviction of tax evasion.
source_pages: Cook_County_Jail; Gangster; Al_Capone; Federal_Correctional_Institution,_Atlanta; Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States; Tax_evasion; May_4

event_text: Ten weeks after his abduction, Charles Jr., the infant son of Charles Lindbergh, is found dead near Hopewell, New Jersey, just a few miles from the Lindberghs' home.
In an attempted coup d'état, the Prime Minister of Japan Inukai Tsuyoshi is assassinated.
Amelia Earhart takes off from Newfoundland to begin the world's first solo nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean by a female pilot, landing in Ireland the next day.
Bad weather forces Amelia Earhart to land in a pasture in Derry, Northern Ireland, and she thereby becomes the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean.

In Brazil, four students are shot and killed during a manifestation against the Brazilian dictator Getúlio Vargas, which resulted in the outbreak of the Constitutionalist Revolution several weeks later.
In the Netherlands, construction of the Afsluitdijk is completed and the Zuiderzee bay is converted to the freshwater IJsselmeer.
World War I veterans begin to assemble in Washington, D.C., in the Bonus Army to request cash bonuses promised to them to be paid in 1945.
Marmaduke Grove and other Chilean military officers lead a coup d'état establishing the short-lived Socialist Republic of Chile.
Bonus Army: Around a thousand World War I veterans amass at the United States Capitol as the U.S. Senate considers a bill that would give them certain benefits.
A bloodless revolution instigated by the People's Party ends the absolute power of King Prajadhipok of Siam (now Thailand).
Australia's national broadcaster, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, was formed.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average reaches its lowest level of the Great Depression, closing at 41.22.
The state of São Paulo revolts against the Brazilian Federal Government, starting the Constitutionalist Revolution.
Altona Bloody Sunday: A riot between the Nazi Party paramilitary forces, the SS and SA, and the German Communist Party ensues.
In the Preußenschlag, German President Hindenburg places Prussia directly under the rule of the national government.
U.S. president Herbert Hoover orders the United States Army to forcibly evict the "Bonus Army" of World War I veterans gathered in Washington, D.C.
Great Depression: In Washington, D.C., troops disperse the last of the "Bonus Army" of World War I veterans using arson, bayonets, sabers, tanks, tear gas, and vomit gas.
source_pages: Great_Depression; Bonus_Army; Bayonet; Sabre; Tear_gas; Adamsite; July_29

event_text: Premiere of Walt Disney's Flowers and Trees, the first cartoon short to use Technicolor and the first Academy Award winning cartoon short.
The NSDAP (Nazi Party) wins more than 38% of the vote in German elections.
The positron (antiparticle of the electron) is discovered by Carl D. Anderson.
Amelia Earhart becomes the first woman to fly across the United States non-stop (from Los Angeles to Newark, New Jersey).
The French Upper Volta is broken apart between Ivory Coast, French Sudan, and Niger.
The Battle of Boquerón, the first major battle of the Chaco War, commences.
The New York City Subway's third competing subway system, the municipally-owned IND, is opened.
A speech by Laureano Gómez leads to the escalation of the Leticia Incident.
Saudi National Day: Crown Prince (later king) Faisal of Saudi Arabia, on behalf of Ibn Saud, proclaims the unification of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, the current iteration of the Third Saudi State.
source_pages: Saudi_National_Day; Faisal_of_Saudi_Arabia; Ibn_Saud; Saudi_Arabia; Third_Saudi_State; September_23

event_text: Gandhi and Dr. Ambedkar agree to the Poona Pact, which reserved seats in the Indian provincial legislatures for the "Depressed Classes" (Untouchables).
Last day of the Battle of Boquerón between Paraguay and Bolivia during the Chaco War.
The Kingdom of Iraq gains independence from the United Kingdom.
Tata Airlines (later to become Air India) makes its first flight.
George Lansbury became the leader of the opposition British Labour Party.
Panagis Tsaldaris becomes the 142nd Prime Minister of Greece.
Franklin D. Roosevelt is elected as the 32nd President of the United States, defeating incumbent president Herbert Hoover.
In Washington, D.C., the FBI Scientific Crime Detection Laboratory (better known as the FBI Crime Lab) officially opens.
German-born Swiss physicist Albert Einstein is granted an American visa.
Thailand becomes a constitutional monarchy.
The Chicago Bears defeat the Portsmouth Spartans in the first NFL playoff game to win the NFL Championship.
BBC World Service begins broadcasting as the BBC Empire Service.
A magnitude 7.6 earthquake in Gansu, China kills 275 people.
Radio City Music Hall, "Showplace of the Nation", opens in New York City.
Minnie D. Craig becomes the first woman elected as Speaker of the North Dakota House of Representatives, the first woman to hold a Speaker position anywhere in the United States.
Construction of the Golden Gate Bridge begins in San Francisco Bay.
Anarchist insurrection of January 1933 breaks out in Barcelona, Spain.
Casas Viejas incident: 22 peasants killed by the Security and Assault Corps in Casas Viejas, Spain.
The 20th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, changing the beginning and end of terms for all elected federal offices.
The name Pakistan is coined by Choudhry Rahmat Ali Khan and is accepted by Indian Muslims who then thereby adopted it further for the Pakistan Movement seeking independence.
Adolf Hitler's rise to power: Hitler takes office as the Chancellor of Germany.
Adolf Hitler announces that the expansion of Lebensraum into Eastern Europe, and its ruthless Germanisation, are the ultimate geopolitical objectives of Nazi foreign policy.
Mutiny on Royal Netherlands Navy warship HNLMS De Zeven Provinciën off the coast of Sumatra, Dutch East Indies.
In round 13 of a boxing match at New York City's Madison Square Garden, Primo Carnera knocks out Ernie Schaaf. Schaaf dies four days later.
LAPD Red Squad raid on John Reed Club art show in the U.S. results in the destruction of a dozen political artworks.
In Miami, Giuseppe Zangara attempts to assassinate US President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt, but instead shoots Chicago mayor Anton J. Cermak, who dies of his wounds on March 6.

The U.S. Congress approves the Blaine Act to repeal federal Prohibition in the United States, sending the Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution to state ratifying conventions for approval.
Adolf Hitler secretly meets with German industrialists to arrange for financing of the Nazi Party's upcoming election campaign.
Launch of the USS Ranger at Newport News, Virginia. It is the first purpose-built aircraft carrier to be commissioned by the US Navy.
Reichstag fire: Germany's parliament building in Berlin, the Reichstag, is set on fire; Marinus van der Lubbe, a young Dutch Communist claims responsibility.
The film King Kong premieres in Radio City Music Hall and RKO Roxy in New York City
Franklin D. Roosevelt is inaugurated as the 32nd President of the United States.
The United States Senate confirms Frances Perkins as United States Secretary of Labor and she is sworn in the same day, making her the first female member of the United States Cabinet.
The Parliament of Austria is suspended because of a quibble over procedure – Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss initiates an authoritarian rule by decree.
Adolf Hitler's Nazi Party receives 43.9% at the Reichstag elections, which allows the Nazis to later pass the Enabling Act and establish a dictatorship.
Great Depression: President Franklin D. Roosevelt submits the Emergency Banking Act to Congress, the first of his New Deal policies.
The Long Beach earthquake affects the Greater Los Angeles Area, leaving around 108 people dead.
Great Depression: Franklin D. Roosevelt addresses the nation for the first time as President of the United States. This is also the first of his "fireside chats".
Reichsführer-SS Heinrich Himmler ordered the creation of Dachau concentration camp as Chief of Police of Munich and appointed Theodor Eicke as the camp commandant.

Cullen–Harrison Act: President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs an amendment to the Volstead Act, legalizing the manufacture and sale of "3.2 beer" (3.2% alcohol by weight, approximately 4% alcohol by volume) and light wines.
Nazi Germany opens its first concentration camp, Dachau.
The Reichstag passes the Enabling Act of 1933, making Adolf Hitler dictator of Germany.
Japanese invasion of Manchuria: Japan leaves the League of Nations after it approves the Lytton Report that ruled in favour of China.
The Imperial Airways biplane City of Liverpool is believed to be the first airliner lost to sabotage when a passenger sets a fire on board.
The Civilian Conservation Corps is established with the mission of relieving rampant unemployment in the United States.
The recently elected Nazis under Julius Streicher organize a one-day boycott of all Jewish-owned businesses in Germany, ushering in a series of anti-Semitic acts.
First flight over Mount Everest, the British Houston-Mount Everest Flight Expedition, led by the Marquis of Clydesdale and funded by Lucy, Lady Houston.
U.S. Navy airship USS Akron is wrecked off the New Jersey coast due to severe weather.

U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs two executive orders: 6101 to establish the Civilian Conservation Corps, and 6102 "forbidding the Hoarding of Gold Coin, Gold Bullion, and Gold Certificates" by U.S. citizens.
Andorran Revolution: The Young Andorrans occupy the Casa de la Vall and force the government to hold democratic elections with universal male suffrage.
