Prohibition in the United States is repealed for beer of no more than 3.2% alcohol by weight, eight months before the ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution. (Now  celebrated as National Beer Day in the United States.)
Nazi Germany issues the Law for the Restoration of the Professional Civil Service banning Jews and political dissidents from civil service posts.
Nazi Germany begins its persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses by shutting down the Watch Tower Society office in Magdeburg.
Nazi Germany issues the Law Against Overcrowding in Schools and Universities limiting the number of Jewish students able to attend public schools and universities.
The Gestapo, the official secret police force of Nazi Germany, is established by Hermann Göring.
Germany's independent labor unions are replaced by the German Labour Front.
The Deutsche Studentenschaft attacked Magnus Hirschfeld's Institut für Sexualwissenschaft, later burning many of its books.
Mohandas Gandhi begins a 21-day fast of self-purification and launched a one-year campaign to help the Harijan movement.
Censorship: In Germany, the Nazis stage massive public book burnings.

The Agricultural Adjustment Act, which restricts agricultural production through government purchase of livestock for slaughter and paying subsidies to farmers when they remove land from planting, is signed into law by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
President Roosevelt signs legislation creating the Federal Emergency Relief Administration, the predecessor of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
All military aviation organizations within or under the control of the RLM of Germany were officially merged in a covert manner to form its Wehrmacht military's air arm, the Luftwaffe.
Vidkun Quisling and Johan Bernhard Hjort form Nasjonal Samling — the national-socialist party of Norway.
New Deal: President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs an act creating the Tennessee Valley Authority.
Finnish cavalry general C. G. E. Mannerheim is appointed the field marshal.
The Walt Disney Company cartoon Three Little Pigs premieres at Radio City Music Hall, featuring the hit song "Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf?"
New Deal: The U.S. Federal Securities Act is signed into law requiring the registration of securities with the Federal Trade Commission.
The first drive-in theater opens in Camden, New Jersey.

The National Industrial Recovery Act is passed in the United States, allowing businesses to avoid antitrust prosecution if they establish voluntary wage, price, and working condition regulations on an industry-wide basis.
Union Station massacre: In Kansas City, Missouri, four FBI agents and captured fugitive Frank Nash are gunned down by gangsters attempting to free Nash.
The first Major League Baseball All-Star Game is played in Chicago's Comiskey Park. The American League defeated the National League 4–2.
The first rugby union test match between the Wallabies of Australia and the Springboks of South Africa is played at Newlands Stadium in Cape Town.
source_pages: Rugby_union; Test_match_(rugby_union); Australia_national_rugby_union_team; South_Africa_national_rugby_union_team; Newlands_Stadium; Cape_Town

event_text: In a decree called the Gleichschaltung, Adolf Hitler abolishes all German political parties except the Nazis.

Nazi eugenics programme begins with the proclamation of the Law for the Prevention of Hereditarily Diseased Offspring requiring the compulsory sterilization of any citizen who suffers from alleged genetic disorders.
Aviator Wiley Post returns to Floyd Bennett Field in New York City, completing the first solo flight around the world in seven days, 18 hours and 49 minutes.
Anti-Fascist activists Bruno Tesch, Walter Möller, Karl Wolff and August Lütgens are executed by the Nazi regime in Altona.

The Kingdom of Iraq slaughters over 3,000 Assyrians in the village of Simele. This date is recognized as Martyrs Day or National Day of Mourning by the Assyrian community in memory of the Simele massacre.
Loggers cause a forest fire in the Coast Range of Oregon, later known as the first forest fire of the Tillamook Burn;  destroying 240,000 acres (970 km2) of land.
Christie Pits riot takes place in Toronto, Ontario.

The Volksempfänger is first presented to the German public at a radio exhibition; the presiding Nazi Minister of Propaganda, Joseph Goebbels, delivers an accompanying speech heralding the radio as the 'eighth great power'.
The Crescent Limited train derails in Washington, D.C., after the bridge it is crossing is washed out by the 1933 Chesapeake–Potomac hurricane.
The Diexi earthquake strikes Mao County, Sichuan, China and kills 9,000 people.

Nazi Germany and the Zionist Federation of Germany signed the Haavara Agreement. The agreement was a major factor in breaking the anti-Nazi boycott of 1933 and facilitated Jewish emigration from Germany and into Palestine.
The first Afrikaans Bible is introduced during a Bible Festival in Bloemfontein.
The Integral Nationalist Group wins the 1933 Andorran parliamentary election, the first election in Andorra held with universal male suffrage.
Yevgeniy Abalakov is the first man to reach the highest point in the Soviet Union, Communism Peak (now called Ismoil Somoni Peak and situated in Tajikistan) (7495 m).
Ghazi bin Faisal became King of Iraq.
Leó Szilárd, waiting for a red light on Southampton Row in Bloomsbury, conceives the idea of the nuclear chain reaction.
Elizabeth McCombs becomes the first woman elected to the New Zealand Parliament.
Salvador Lutteroth establishes Mexican professional wrestling.
As gangster Machine Gun Kelly surrenders to the FBI, he shouts out, "Don't shoot, G-Men!", which becomes a nickname for FBI agents.
A United Airlines Boeing 247 is destroyed by sabotage, the first such proven case in the history of commercial aviation.
The military Alcatraz Citadel becomes the civilian Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary.
Germany withdraws from the League of Nations and World Disarmament Conference.
Albert Einstein flees Nazi Germany and moves to the United States.
Fiorello H. La Guardia is elected the 99th mayor of New York City.
Great Depression: New Deal: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt unveils the Civil Works Administration, an organization designed to create jobs for more than four million unemployed.
Nazi Germany uses a referendum to ratify its withdrawal from the League of Nations.
Thailand holds its first election.
The United States and the Soviet Union establish formal diplomatic relations.
The Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, repealing Prohibition in the United States.

In United States v. One Book Called Ulysses Judge John M. Woolsey rules that James Joyce's novel Ulysses is not obscene despite coarse language and sexual content, a leading decision affirming free expression.
Anarchist insurrection breaks out in Zaragoza, Spain.
Anarchist insurrection suppressed in Zaragoza, Spain.
The first NFL Championship Game is played at Wrigley Field in Chicago between the New York Giants and Chicago Bears. The Bears won 23–21.
Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay becomes a United States federal prison.
A "Law for the Prevention of Genetically Diseased Offspring" comes into effect in Nazi Germany.
The 8.0 Mw  Nepal–Bihar earthquake strikes Nepal and Bihar with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing an estimated 6,000–10,700 people.
The Apollo Theater reopens in Harlem, New York City.
German–Polish declaration of non-aggression is signed.
Far-right leagues rally in front of the Palais Bourbon in an attempted coup against the French Third Republic, creating a political crisis in France.
The Balkan Entente is formed between Greece, Romania, Yugoslavia, and Turkey.
The Austrian Civil War ends with the defeat of the Social Democrats and the Republikanischer Schutzbund.
The Commission of Government is officially sworn in; ending 79 years of responsible government in Newfoundland.
Leopold III becomes King of Belgium.
The landmark Australian Eastern Mission led by John Latham departs on its three-month tour of East and South-East Asia.
The first Masters Tournament is held at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia.
The Tydings–McDuffie Act is passed by the United States Congress, allowing the Philippines to become a self-governing commonwealth.
The United Kingdom driving test is introduced.
The strongest surface wind gust in the world at the time of 231 mph, is measured on the summit of Mount Washington, New Hampshire. It has since been surpassed.
The U.S. Auto-Lite strike begins, culminating in a five-day melee between Ohio National Guard troops and 6,000 strikers and picketers.[citation needed]
The "Surgeon's Photograph", the most famous photo allegedly showing the Loch Ness Monster, is published in the Daily Mail (in 1994, it is revealed to be a hoax).
A self coup by prime minister Kārlis Ulmanis succeeded in Latvia, suspending its constitution and dissolving its Saeima.
Zveno and the Bulgarian Army engineer a coup d'état and install Kimon Georgiev as the new Prime Minister of Bulgaria.
Oskaloosa, Iowa, becomes the first municipality in the United States to fingerprint all of its citizens.
American bank robbers Bonnie and Clyde are ambushed by police and killed in Bienville Parish, Louisiana.
The Auto-Lite strike culminates in the "Battle of Toledo", a five-day melée between 1,300 troops of the Ohio National Guard and 6,000 picketers.
Near Callander, Ontario, Canada, the Dionne quintuplets are born to Oliva and Elzire Dionne; they will be the first quintuplets to survive infancy.
New Deal: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 into law, establishing the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
The landmark Australian Eastern Mission returns from its three-month tour of East and South-East Asia.
The Communications Act of 1934 establishes the United States' Federal Communications Commission (FCC).
United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Federal Credit Union Act, which establishes credit unions.
The Night of the Long Knives, Adolf Hitler's violent purge of his political rivals in Germany, takes place.
The Night of the Long Knives ends after three days of killings.
"Bloody Thursday": The police open fire on striking longshoremen in San Francisco.
Engelbert Zaschka of Germany flies his large human-powered aircraft, the Zaschka Human-Power Aircraft, about 20 meters at Berlin Tempelhof Airport without assisted take-off.
The rigid airship USS Macon surprised the USS Houston near Clipperton Island with a mail delivery for President Franklin D. Roosevelt, demonstrating its potential for tracking ships at sea.
Labor unrest in the U.S.: Police in Minneapolis fire upon striking truck drivers, during the Minneapolis Teamsters Strike of 1934, killing two and wounding sixty-seven.
West Coast waterfront strike: In Seattle, police fire tear gas on and club 2,000 striking longshoremen. The governor of Oregon calls out the National Guard to break a strike on the Portland docks.
The Nazis assassinate Austrian Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss in a failed coup attempt.
Reichskanzler Adolf Hitler becomes Führer of Germany following the death of President Paul von Hindenburg.
The first civilian prisoners arrive at the Federal prison on Alcatraz Island.
The first All-American Soap Box Derby is held in Dayton, Ohio.
The German referendum of 1934 approves Adolf Hitler's appointment as head of state with the title of Führer.
Bill Woodfull of Australia becomes the only test cricket captain to twice regain The Ashes.
Off the New Jersey coast, a fire aboard the passenger liner SS Morro Castle kills 137 people.
The Soviet Union is admitted to the League of Nations.
A large typhoon hits western Honshū, Japan, killing more than 3,000 people.
The Gresford disaster in Wales kills 266 miners and rescuers.
Revolution of 1934: The President of the autonomous government of Catalonia, Lluís Companys, proclaims the Catalan State with the support of the Worker's Alliance.
source_pages: Events_of_6_October; President_of_the_Government_of_Catalonia; Catalonia; Lluís_Companys; Catalan_State_(1934); October_6

event_text: An Ustashe assassin kills King Alexander I of Yugoslavia and Louis Barthou, Foreign Minister of France, in Marseille.
Chinese Communists begin the Long March to escape Nationalist encirclement.
In East Liverpool, Ohio, FBI agents shoot and kill notorious bank robber Pretty Boy Floyd.
The Shrine of Remembrance is opened in Melbourne, Australia.
An Anglo-Ethiopian boundary commission in the Ogaden discovers an Italian garrison at Walwal, well within Ethiopian territory. This leads to the Abyssinia Crisis.
Sergei Kirov is assassinated, paving way for the repressive Great Purge, and Vinnytsia massacre by General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Joseph Stalin.
Abyssinia Crisis: Italian troops attack Wal Wal in Abyssinia, taking four days to capture the city.
Bill Wilson, co-founder of Alcoholics Anonymous, takes his last drink and enters treatment for the final time.
Lieutenant Kijé, one of Sergei Prokofiev's best-known works, premiered.
Japan renounces the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922 and the London Naval Treaty of 1930.
Benito Mussolini and French Foreign Minister Pierre Laval sign the Franco-Italian Agreement.
Amelia Earhart becomes the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California.
A plebiscite in Saarland shows that 90.3% of those voting wish to no more being a "region occupied and governed by the United Kingdom and France".
Gottfried Krueger Brewing Company starts selling the first canned beer.
Iceland becomes the first Western country to legalize therapeutic abortion.
USS Macon, one of the two largest helium-filled airships ever created, crashes into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California and sinks.
A jury in Flemington, New Jersey finds Bruno Hauptmann guilty of the 1932 kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby, the son of Charles Lindbergh.
Caroline Mikkelsen becomes the first woman to set foot in Antarctica.
Adolf Hitler orders the Luftwaffe to be re-formed, violating the provisions of the Treaty of Versailles.
Robert Watson-Watt carries out a demonstration near Daventry which leads directly to the development of radar in the United Kingdom.
Adolf Hitler orders Germany to rearm itself in violation of the Treaty of Versailles. Conscription is reintroduced to form the Wehrmacht.
Shah of Iran Reza Shah Pahlavi formally asks the international community to call Persia by its native name, Iran.
Signing of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of the Philippines.
India's central banking institution, the Reserve Bank of India, is formed.

Stresa Front: opening of the conference between the British Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald, the Italian Prime Minister Benito Mussolini and the French Minister for Foreign Affairs Pierre Laval to condemn the German violations of the Treaty of Versailles.
source_pages: Stresa_Front; Ramsay_MacDonald; Benito_Mussolini; Pierre_Laval; Treaty_of_Versailles; April_11

event_text: The Black Sunday dust storm, considered one of the worst storms of the Dust Bowl, sweeps across the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles and neighboring areas.
The Polish Constitution of 1935 is adopted.
New Deal: Under the authority of the newly-enacted Federal Emergency Relief Administration, President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues Executive Order 7034 to create the Works Progress Administration.
The Constitution of the Philippines is ratified by a popular vote.
The first night game in Major League Baseball history is played in Cincinnati, Ohio, with the Cincinnati Reds beating the Philadelphia Phillies 2–1 at Crosley Field.
source_pages: Night_game; Major_League_Baseball; Cincinnati; Cincinnati_Reds; Philadelphia_Phillies; Crosley_Field

event_text: Jesse Owens of Ohio State University breaks three world records and ties a fourth at the Big Ten Conference Track and Field Championships in Ann Arbor, Michigan.
New Deal: The Supreme Court of the United States declares the National Industrial Recovery Act to be unconstitutional in A.L.A. Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States, (295 U.S. 495).
First flight of the Messerschmitt Bf 109 fighter aeroplane.
A 7.7 Mw  earthquake destroys Quetta in modern-day Pakistan killing 40,000.
One thousand unemployed Canadian workers board freight cars in Vancouver, beginning a protest trek to Ottawa.
Dr. Robert Smith takes his last drink, and Alcoholics Anonymous is founded in Akron, Ohio, United States, by him and Bill Wilson.
Chaco War ends: A truce is called between Bolivia and Paraguay who had been fighting since 1932.
A ceasefire is negotiated between Bolivia and Paraguay, ending the Chaco War.
Police in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, clash with striking longshoremen, resulting in a total of 60 injuries and 24 arrests.
Colombia–Soviet Union relations are established.
Regina, Saskatchewan, police and Royal Canadian Mounted Police ambush strikers participating in the On-to-Ottawa Trek.
The National Labor Relations Act, which governs labor relations in the United States, is signed into law by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The world's first parking meter is installed in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.
Switzerland: A Royal Dutch Airlines plane en route from Milan to Frankfurt crashes into a Swiss mountain, killing thirteen.
The Dust Bowl heat wave reaches its peak, sending temperatures to 109 °F (43 °C) in Chicago and 104 °F (40 °C) in Milwaukee.
First flight of the Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress.
Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Social Security Act, creating a government pension system for the retired.
Will Rogers and Wiley Post are killed after their aircraft develops engine problems during takeoff in Barrow, Alaska.
In an attempt to stay out of the growing tensions concerning Germany and Japan, the United States passes the first of its Neutrality Acts.
The Labor Day Hurricane, the most intense hurricane to strike the United States, makes landfall at Long Key, Florida, killing at least 400.
Sir Malcolm Campbell reaches a speed of 304.331 miles per hour on the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah, becoming the first person to drive an automobile over 300 mph.
US Senator from Louisiana Huey Long is fatally shot in the Louisiana State Capitol building.
Nazi Germany adopts a new national flag bearing the swastika.
The Niagara Gorge Railroad ceases operations after a rockslide.
Earl and Weldon Bascom produce the first rodeo ever held outdoors under electric lights.
The Hoover Dam, astride the border between the U.S. states of Arizona and Nevada, is dedicated.
Second Italo-Abyssinian War: Italy invades Ethiopia.
In Greece, a coup d'état ends the Second Hellenic Republic.
The League of Nations places economic sanctions on Italy for its invasion of Ethiopia.
The Long March, a mammoth retreat undertaken by the armed forces of the Chinese Communist Party a year prior, ends.
George II of Greece regains his throne through a popular, though possibly fixed, plebiscite.

The Committee for Industrial Organization, the precursor to the Congress of Industrial Organizations, is founded in Atlantic City, New Jersey, by eight trade unions belonging to the American Federation of Labor.
The China Clipper inaugurates the first commercial transpacific air service, connecting Alameda, California with Manila.
The Senegalese Socialist Party holds its second congress.
Mary McLeod Bethune founds the National Council of Negro Women in New York City.
Student protests occur in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, and are subsequently dispersed by government authorities.
Walter Liggett, an American newspaper editor and muckraker, is killed in a gangland murder.
The Lebensborn Project, a Nazi reproduction program, is founded by Heinrich Himmler.
First flight of the Douglas DC-3.
The Lanka Sama Samaja Party is founded in Ceylon.
Regina Jonas is ordained as the first female rabbi in the history of Judaism.
The Italian Air Force bombs a Swedish Red Cross hospital during the Second Italo-Abyssinian War.
Kashf-e hijab decree is made and immediately enforced by Reza Shah, Iran's head of state, banning the wearing of Islamic veils in public.
The first building to be completely covered in glass, built for the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, is completed in Toledo, Ohio.
The first inductees into the Baseball Hall of Fame are announced.
Second Italo-Abyssinian War: Italian troops launch the Battle of Amba Aradam against Ethiopian defenders.
The Popular Front wins the 1936 Spanish general election.
In the February 26 Incident, young nationalist Japanese military officers assassinate multiple cabinet statesmen and start a rebellion in downtown Tokyo, which is ended 3 days later.
Daytona Beach and Road Course holds its first oval stock car race.
Warmer-than-normal temperatures rapidly melt snow and ice on the upper Allegheny and Monongahela rivers, leading to a major flood in Pittsburgh.
The 1936 German parliamentary election and referendum seeks approval for the recent remilitarization of the Rhineland.
Bruno Richard Hauptmann is executed for the kidnapping and death of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr., the infant son of pilot Charles Lindbergh.
Tupelo–Gainesville tornado outbreak: An F5 tornado kills 233 in Tupelo, Mississippi.
Tupelo–Gainesville tornado outbreak: Another tornado from the same storm system as the Tupelo tornado hits Gainesville, Georgia, killing 203.
First day of the Arab revolt in Mandatory Palestine.
The Jaffa riots commence, initiating the 1936–1939 Arab revolt in Palestine.
The United Auto Workers (UAW) gains autonomy from the American Federation of Labor.
Italian troops occupy Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.
Italy formally annexes Ethiopia after taking the capital Addis Ababa on May 5.
Sada Abe is arrested after wandering the streets of Tokyo for days with her dead lover's severed genitals in her handbag. Her story soon becomes one of Japan's most notorious scandals.

In the House of Commons of Northern Ireland, Tommy Henderson begins speaking on the Appropriation bill. By the time he sits down in the early hours of the following morning, he had spoken for ten hours.
Alan Turing submits On Computable Numbers for publication.
Inventor Edwin Armstrong demonstrates FM broadcasting to an audience of engineers at the FCC in Washington, DC.
The London International Surrealist Exhibition opens.
Initial flight of the Focke-Wulf Fw 61, the first practical helicopter.
The Japanese puppet state of Mengjiang is formed in northern China.
Emperor Haile Selassie of Abyssinia appeals for aid to the League of Nations against Italy's invasion of his country.
A major breach of the Manchester Bolton & Bury Canal in England sends millions of gallons of water cascading 200 feet (61 m) into the River Irwell.
The Triborough Bridge in New York City is opened to traffic.
Spanish Civil War: An Armed Forces rebellion against the recently elected leftist Popular Front government of Spain starts the civil war.
Spanish Civil War: The CNT and UGT call a general strike in Spain – mobilizing workers' militias against the Nationalist forces. People's Olympiad of Barcelona cancelled.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Confederación_Nacional_del_Trabajo; Unión_General_de_Trabajadores; General_strike; Second_Spanish_Republic; Nationalist_faction_(Spanish_Civil_War); People's_Olympiad; July_19

event_text: The Montreux Convention is signed in Switzerland, authorizing Turkey to fortify the Dardanelles and Bosphorus but guaranteeing free passage to ships of all nations in peacetime.
Spanish Civil War: The Central Committee of Antifascist Militias of Catalonia is constituted, establishing an anarcho-syndicalist economy in Catalonia.
Spanish Civil War: The Popular Executive Committee of Valencia takes power in the Valencian Community.
In Catalonia, Spain, the Unified Socialist Party of Catalonia is founded through the merger of Socialist and Communist parties.
Spanish Civil War: Germany and Italy decide to intervene in the war in support for Francisco Franco and the Nationalist faction.
King Edward VIII, in one of his few official duties before he abdicates the throne, officially unveils the Canadian National Vimy Memorial.
The Olympics opened in Berlin with a ceremony presided over by Adolf Hitler.
Jesse Owens wins the 100 metre dash, defeating Ralph Metcalfe, at the Berlin Olympics.
A fire wipes out Kursha-2 in the Meshchera Lowlands, Ryazan Oblast, Russia, killing 1,200 and leaving only 20 survivors.
Prime Minister of Greece Ioannis Metaxas suspends parliament and the Constitution and establishes the 4th of August Regime.
Summer Olympics: Jesse Owens wins his fourth gold medal at the games.
Rainey Bethea is hanged in Owensboro, Kentucky in the last known public execution in the United States.
The Great Purge of the Soviet Union begins when the first of the Moscow Trials is convened.
The Australian Antarctic Territory is created.
Spanish Civil War: Santander falls to the nationalists and the republican interprovincial council is dissolved.
Nazi Germany begins its mass arrests of Jehovah's Witnesses, who are interned in concentration camps.
The RMS Queen Mary wins the Blue Riband by setting the fastest transatlantic crossing.
Radio Prague, now the official international broadcasting station of the Czech Republic, goes on the air.
Spanish Civil War: Largo Caballero forms a war cabinet to direct the republican war effort.
Spanish Civil War: The Interprovincial Council of Asturias and León is established.
The last thylacine, a carnivorous marsupial, dies alone in its cage at the Hobart Zoo in Tasmania.

The crews of Portuguese Navy frigate NRP Afonso de Albuquerque and destroyer Dão mutinied against the Salazar dictatorship's support of General Franco's coup and declared their solidarity with the Spanish Republic.
source_pages: Portuguese_Navy; NRP_Afonso_de_Albuquerque_(1934); NRP_Dão; 1936_Naval_Revolt; António_de_Oliveira_Salazar; Francisco_Franco; Second_Spanish_Republic

event_text: First World Individual Motorcycle Speedway Championship, Held at London's (England) Wembley Stadium
Raoul Villain, who assassinated the French Socialist Jean Jaurès, is himself killed by Spanish Republicans in Ibiza.
Spanish Civil War: Lluis Companys reshuffles the Generalitat de Catalunya, with the marxist POUM and anarcho-syndicalist CNT joining the government.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Lluís_Companys; Cabinet_reshuffle; Generalitat_de_Catalunya; Libertarian_socialism; POUM; Anarcho-syndicalism; Confederación_Nacional_del_Trabajo; September_26

event_text: Spanish Civil War: Francisco Franco is named head of the Nationalist government of Spain.
Spanish Civil War: The Central Committee of Antifascist Militias of Catalonia dissolves itself, handing control of Catalan defence militias over to the Generalitat.
The Metropolitan Police and various anti-fascist organizations violently clash in the Battle of Cable Street.
The Jarrow March sets off for London.
Boulder Dam (later Hoover Dam) begins to generate electricity and transmit it to Los Angeles.
Dod Orsborne, captain of the Girl Pat is convicted of its theft and imprisoned, having caused a media sensation when it went missing.
The first electric generator at Hoover Dam goes into full operation.
Mrs. Wallis Simpson obtains her divorce, which would eventually allow her to marry King Edward VIII of the United Kingdom, thus forcing his abdication from the throne.
The BBC Television Service, the world's first regular, "high-definition" (then defined as at least 200 lines) service begins. Renamed BBC1 in 1964, the channel still runs to this day.
Franklin D. Roosevelt is elected the 32nd President of the United States.
Spanish Civil War: Largo Caballero reshuffles his war cabinet, persuading the anarcho-syndicalist CNT to join the government.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Francisco_Largo_Caballero; Cabinet_reshuffle; War_cabinet; Anarcho-syndicalism; Confederación_Nacional_del_Trabajo; November_4

event_text: Spanish Civil War: The republican government flees from Madrid to Valencia, leading to the formation of the Madrid Defense Council in its stead.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Republican_faction_(Spanish_Civil_War); Siege_of_Madrid; Valencia; Madrid_Defense_Council; November_6

event_text: Spanish Civil War: The Madrid Defense Council is formed to coordinate the Defense of Madrid against nationalist forces.
Spanish Civil War: Francoist troops fail in their effort to capture Madrid, but begin the three-year Siege of Madrid afterwards.
American fashion designer Ruth Harkness encounters and captures a nine-week-old panda cub in Sichuan; it becomes the first live giant panda to enter the United States.
In California, the San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge opens to traffic.
José Antonio Primo de Rivera, founder of the Falange, is killed by a republican execution squad.

In Berlin, Germany and Japan sign the Anti-Comintern Pact, agreeing to consult on measures "to safeguard their common interests" in the case of an unprovoked attack by the Soviet Union against either nation.
In London, the Crystal Palace is destroyed by fire.
The Soviet Union adopts a new constitution and the Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic is established as a full Union Republic of the USSR.
Australian cricketer Jack Fingleton becomes the first player to score centuries in four consecutive Test innings.
Abdication Crisis: Edward VIII signs the Instrument of Abdication.
Abdication Crisis: Edward VIII's abdication as King of the United Kingdom and the British Dominions beyond the Seas, and Emperor of India, becomes effective.
The beginning of Xi'an incident. As a result, Chiang Kai Shek is captured.
First flight of the Junkers Ju 88 multi-role combat aircraft.
Colombia becomes a signatory to the Buenos Aires copyright treaty.
Spanish Civil War: The Spanish Republic legalizes the Regional Defence Council of Aragon.
The Flint sit-down strike hits General Motors.
Spanish Civil War: Nationalists and Republicans both withdraw after suffering heavy losses, ending the Second Battle of the Corunna Road.
Howard Hughes sets a new air record by flying from Los Angeles to New York City in seven hours, 28 minutes, 25 seconds.

Franklin D. Roosevelt and John Nance Garner are sworn in for their second terms as U.S. President and U.S. Vice President; it is the first time a Presidential Inauguration takes place on January 20 since the 20th Amendment changed the dates of presidential terms.
The trial of the anti-Soviet Trotskyist center sees seventeen mid-level Communists accused of sympathizing with Leon Trotsky and plotting to overthrow Joseph Stalin's regime.
The Guiding Light debuts on NBC radio from Chicago. In 1952 it moves to CBS television, where it remains until September 18, 2009.
Spanish Civil War: Republican forces establish the Interprovincial Council of Santander, Palencia and Burgos in Cantabria.
The Flint sit-down strike ends when General Motors recognizes the United Auto Workers trade union.
Wallace H. Carothers receives a United States patent for nylon.

Yekatit 12: During a public ceremony at the Viceregal Palace (the former Imperial residence) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, two Ethiopian nationalists of Eritrean origin attempt to kill viceroy Rodolfo Graziani with a number of grenades.
The League of Nations bans foreign national "volunteers" in the Spanish Civil War.
The Steel Workers Organizing Committee signs a collective bargaining agreement with U.S. Steel, leading to unionization of the United States steel industry.
Spanish Civil War: The Battle of Guadalajara begins.
The New London School explosion in New London, Texas, kills 300 people, mostly children.
Spanish Civil War: Spanish Republican forces defeat the Italians at the Battle of Guadalajara.
Ponce massacre: Nineteen unarmed civilians in Ponce, Puerto Rico are gunned down by police in a terrorist attack ordered by the US-appointed Governor, Blanton Winship.
Aden becomes a British crown colony.
The Royal New Zealand Air Force is formed as an independent service.
The Kamikaze arrives at Croydon Airport in London. It is the first Japanese-built aircraft to fly to Europe.
Sir Frank Whittle ground-tests the first jet engine designed to power an aircraft, at Rugby, England.
Spanish Civil War: Guernica, Spain, is bombed by the German Condor Legion and the Italian Aviazione Legionaria.
South African medical researcher Max Theiler develops the yellow fever vaccine at the Rockefeller Foundation in New York City.
source_pages: South_Africa; Max_Theiler; Yellow_fever; Vaccine; Rockefeller_Foundation; New_York_City; April_28

event_text: The Commonwealth of the Philippines holds a plebiscite for Filipino women on whether they should be extended the right to suffrage; over 90% would vote in the affirmative.
Hindenburg disaster: The German zeppelin Hindenburg catches fire and is destroyed within a minute while attempting to dock at Lakehurst, New Jersey. Thirty-six people are killed.
Spanish Civil War: The German Condor Legion, equipped with Heinkel He 51 biplanes, arrives in Spain to assist Francisco Franco's forces.
The Duke and Duchess of York are crowned as King George VI and Queen Elizabeth of the United Kingdom in Westminster Abbey.
Spanish Civil War: The Largo Caballero government resigns in the wake of the Barcelona May Days, leading Juan Negrín to form a government, without the anarcho-syndicalist CNT, in its stead.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Francisco_Largo_Caballero; May_Days; Juan_Negrín; Anarcho-syndicalism; Confederación_Nacional_del_Trabajo; May_17

event_text: A Soviet station, North Pole-1, becomes the first scientific research settlement to operate on the drift ice of the Arctic Ocean.
Walter Reuther and members of the United Auto Workers (UAW) clash with Ford Motor Company security guards at the River Rouge Complex complex in Dearborn, Michigan, during the Battle of the Overpass.
source_pages: Walter_Reuther; United_Auto_Workers; Ford_Motor_Company; Ford_River_Rouge_complex; Dearborn,_Michigan; Battle_of_the_Overpass; May_26

event_text: In California, the Golden Gate Bridge opens to pedestrian traffic, creating a vital link between San Francisco and Marin County, California.
Volkswagen, the German automobile manufacturer, is founded.
Memorial Day massacre: Chicago police shoot and kill ten labor demonstrators.
The Duke of Windsor marries Wallis Simpson.
Great Purge: The Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin executes eight army leaders.
Pennsylvania becomes the first (and only) state of the United States to celebrate Flag Day officially as a state holiday.
U.S. House of Representatives passes the Marihuana Tax Act.
The world's first emergency telephone number, 999, is introduced in London.
Amelia Earhart and navigator Fred Noonan are last heard from over the Pacific Ocean while attempting to make the first equatorial round-the-world flight.
Spam, the luncheon meat, is introduced into the market by the Hormel Foods Corporation.
Spanish Civil War: Battle of Brunete: The battle begins with Spanish Republican troops going on the offensive against the Nationalists to relieve pressure on Madrid.
The Marco Polo Bridge Incident (Lugou Bridge) provides the Imperial Japanese Army with a pretext for starting the Second Sino-Japanese War (China-Japan War).
The Peel Commission Report recommends the partition of Palestine, which was the first formal recommendation for partition in the history of Palestine.
Turkey, Iran, Iraq, and Afghanistan sign the Treaty of Saadabad.
The silent film archives of Fox Film Corporation are destroyed by the 1937 Fox vault fire.
New Deal: The United States Senate votes down President Franklin D. Roosevelt's proposal to add more justices to the Supreme Court of the United States.
Spanish Civil War: End of the Battle of Brunete with the Nationalist victory.
Tongzhou mutiny: In Tongzhou, China, the East Hebei Army attacks Japanese troops and civilians.
Josip Broz Tito reads the resolution "Manifesto of constitutional congress of KPH" to the constitutive congress of KPH (Croatian Communist Party) in woods near Samobor.
The Marihuana Tax Act of 1937 is passed in America, the effect of which is to render marijuana and all its by-products illegal.
Spanish Civil War: The Regional Defence Council of Aragon is dissolved by the Second Spanish Republic.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Battle of Shanghai begins.

A lightning strike starts the Blackwater Fire of 1937 in Shoshone National Forest, killing 15 firefighters within three days and prompting the United States Forest Service to develop their smokejumper program.
Spanish Civil War: the Basque Army surrenders to the Italian Corpo Truppe Volontarie following the Santoña Agreement.
Spanish Civil War: Sovereign Council of Asturias and León is proclaimed in Gijón.
Toyota Motors becomes an independent company.
Spanish Civil War: Llanes falls to the Nationalists following a one-day siege.
Nine nations attend the Nyon Conference to address international piracy in the Mediterranean Sea.
J.R.R. Tolkien's The Hobbit is published for the first time. (September 22 is celebrated by some fans as Hobbit Day, however.)
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Chinese Eighth Route Army gains a minor, but morale-boosting victory in the Battle of Pingxingguan.
Rafael Trujillo orders the execution of Haitians living in the border region of the Dominican Republic.
Murder of 9 Catholic priests in Zhengding, China, who protected the local population from the advancing Japanese army.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor tour Nazi Germany for 12 days and meet Adolf Hitler on 22 October.
Nazi Germany begins expulsions of 18,000 Polish Jews.
Stalinists execute Pastor Paul Hamberg and seven members of Azerbaijan's Lutheran community.
The Nazi exhibition Der ewige Jude ("The Eternal Jew") opens in Munich.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Chinese Army withdraws from the Battle of Shanghai.
Second Sino-Japanese War: Battle of Nanking: Japanese troops under the command of Lt. Gen. Yasuhiko Asaka launch an assault on the Chinese city of Nanking.
source_pages: Second_Sino-Japanese_War; Battle_of_Nanking; Empire_of_Japan; Prince_Yasuhiko_Asaka; Republic_of_China_(1912–1949); Nanjing

event_text: Second Italo-Ethiopian War: Italy leaves the League of Nations.
Second Sino-Japanese War: USS Panay incident: Japanese aircraft bomb and sink U.S. gunboat USS Panay on the Yangtze river in China.
source_pages: Second_Sino-Japanese_War; USS_Panay_incident; Empire_of_Japan; USS_Panay_(PR-5); Yangtze; December_12

event_text: Second Sino-Japanese War: Battle of Nanking: The city of Nanjing, defended by the National Revolutionary Army under the command of General Tang Shengzhi, falls to the Japanese. This is followed by the Nanking Massacre, in which Japanese troops rape and slaughter hundreds of thousands of civilians.
source_pages: Second_Sino-Japanese_War; Battle_of_Nanking; Nanjing; National_Revolutionary_Army; Tang_Shengzhi; Empire_of_Japan; Nanjing_Massacre

event_text: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, the world's first full-length animated feature, premieres at the Carthay Circle Theatre.
The Lincoln Tunnel opens to traffic in New York City.
The Irish Free State is replaced by a new state called Ireland with the adoption of a new constitution.
The World Land Speed Record on a public road is broken by Rudolf Caracciola in the Mercedes-Benz W125 Rekordwagen at a speed of 432.7 kilometres per hour (268.9 mph).
Adolf Hitler appoints himself as head of the Armed Forces High Command.
BBC Television produces the world's first ever science fiction television programme, an adaptation of a section of the Karel Čapek play R.U.R., that coined the term "robot".
source_pages: BBC_One; Science_fiction_on_television; Karel_Čapek; R.U.R.; Robot; February_11

event_text: Second Sino-Japanese War: During the Nanking Massacre, the Nanking Safety Zone International Committee is renamed "Nanking International Rescue Committee", and the safety zone in place for refugees falls apart.
Oil is discovered in Saudi Arabia.
Anschluss: German troops occupy and annex Austria.
Mexico creates Pemex by expropriating all foreign-owned oil reserves and facilities.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Battle of Taierzhuang begins, resulting several weeks later in the war's first major Chinese victory over Japan.

Spanish Civil War: Two days after the Nationalist army occupied the Catalan city of Lleida, dictator Francisco Franco decrees the abolition of the Generalitat (the autonomous government of Catalonia), the self-government granted by the Republic, and the official status of the Catalan language.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Nationalist_faction_(Spanish_Civil_War); Lleida; Francisco_Franco; Generalitat_de_Catalunya; Catalonia; Autonomous_Region_of_Catalonia_(1931–1939); Catalan_language; April_5

event_text: The 1938 German parliamentary election and referendum seeks approval for a single list of Nazi candidates and the recent annexation of Austria.
Superman debuts in Action Comics #1 (cover dated June 1938).
U.S. Supreme Court delivers its opinion in Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins and overturns a century of federal common law.
Spanish Civil War: The bombing of Alicante kills 313 people.
In the United States, the House Un-American Activities Committee begins its first session.
The Douglas DC-4E makes its first test flight.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Chinese Nationalist government creates the 1938 Yellow River flood to halt Japanese forces. Five hundred thousand to nine hundred thousand civilians are killed.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Battle of Wuhan starts.
The Civil Aeronautics Act is signed into law, forming the Civil Aeronautics Authority in the United States.
Pieces of a meteorite land near Chicora, Pennsylvania. The meteorite is estimated to have weighed 450 metric tons when it hit the Earth's atmosphere and exploded.
Dr. Douglas Hyde is inaugurated as the first President of Ireland.
World speed record for a steam locomotive is set in England, by the Mallard, which reaches a speed of 125.88 miles per hour (202.58 km/h).
United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt dedicates the Eternal Light Peace Memorial and lights the eternal flame at Gettysburg Battlefield.
Howard Hughes begins a 91-hour airplane flight around the world that will set a new record.
Douglas Corrigan takes off from Brooklyn to fly the "wrong way" to Ireland and becomes known as "Wrong Way" Corrigan.

The United States Department of Justice files suit in New York City against the motion picture industry charging violations of the Sherman Antitrust Act in regards to the studio system.  The case would eventually result in a break-up of the industry in 1948.
Hawaii Clipper disappears between Guam and Manila as the first loss of an airliner in trans-Pacific China Clipper service.
Bulgaria signs a non-aggression pact with Greece and other states of Balkan Antanti (Turkey, Romania, Yugoslavia).
Archaeologists discover engraved gold and silver plates from King Darius the Great in Persepolis.
The Thousand Islands Bridge, connecting New York, United States, with Ontario, Canada, over the Saint Lawrence River, is dedicated by U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Lou Gehrig hits his 23rd career grand slam, a record that stood for 75 years until it was broken by Alex Rodriguez.
Kweilin incident: A Japanese warplane shoots down the Kweilin, a Chinese civilian airliner, killing 14. It is the first recorded instance of a civilian airliner being shot down.
Chile: A group of youths affiliated with the fascist National Socialist Movement of Chile are executed after surrendering during a failed coup.
Adolf Hitler demands autonomy and self-determination for the Germans of the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia.
The Great Hurricane of 1938 makes landfall on Long Island in New York. The death toll is estimated at 500–700 people.
The ocean liner Queen Elizabeth is launched in Glasgow.
Britain, France, Germany and Italy sign the Munich Agreement, whereby Germany annexes the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia.
The League of Nations unanimously outlaws "intentional bombings of civilian populations".
Pursuant to the Munich Agreement signed the day before, Nazi Germany begins the military occupation and annexation of Czechoslovakia's Sudetenland.
Holocaust: In Nazi Germany, Jews' passports are invalidated.
Abiding by the Munich Agreement, Czechoslovakia completes its withdrawal from the Sudetenland.
Orson Welles broadcasts a radio adaptation of H. G. Wells's The War of the Worlds, causing a massive panic in some of the audience in the United States.
Great Depression: In an effort to restore investor confidence, the New York Stock Exchange unveils a fifteen-point program aimed to upgrade protection for the investing public.
Seabiscuit defeats War Admiral in an upset victory during a match race deemed "the match of the century" in horse racing.
Kristallnacht occurs, instigated by the Nazis using the killing of German diplomat Ernst vom Rath by Herschel Grynszpan as justification.
Nazi Germany issues the Decree on the Elimination of Jews from Economic Life prohibiting Jews from selling goods and services or working in a trade, totally segregating Jews from the German economy.
The Lions Gate Bridge, connecting Vancouver to the North Shore region, opens to traffic.
Nazi Germany bans Jewish children from public schools in the aftermath of Kristallnacht.
LSD is first synthesized by Albert Hofmann from ergotamine at the Sandoz Laboratories in Basel.
Nazi Germany issues the Decree on the Utilization of Jewish Property forcing Jews to sell real property, businesses, and stocks at below market value as part of Aryanization.
source_pages: Nazi_Germany; Real_property; Business; Stocks; Aryanization; December_3

event_text: The Holocaust: The Neuengamme concentration camp opens in the Bergedorf district of Hamburg, Germany.
Otto Hahn discovers the nuclear fission of the heavy element uranium, the scientific and technological basis of nuclear energy.
The Black Friday bushfires burn 20,000 square kilometres (7,700 sq mi) of land in Australia, claiming the lives of 71 people.
Norway claims Queen Maud Land in Antarctica.
The deadliest earthquake in Chilean history strikes Chillán, killing approximately 28,000 people.
Spanish Civil War: Catalonia Offensive: Troops loyal to nationalist General Francisco Franco and aided by Italy take Barcelona.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Catalonia_Offensive; Francisco_Franco; Kingdom_of_Italy; Barcelona; January_26

event_text: First flight of the Lockheed P-38 Lightning.
During a speech in the Reichstag, Adolf Hitler makes a prediction about the end of the Jewish race in Europe if another world war were to occur.
source_pages: 30_January_1939_Reichstag_speech; Reichstag_(Nazi_Germany); Adolf_Hitler; Hitler's_prophecy; Jews; World_war; January_30

event_text: Generalísimo Francisco Franco becomes the 68th "Caudillo de España", or Leader of Spain.
Spanish Civil War: The Nationalists conclude their conquest of Catalonia and seal the border with France.
World War II: German battleship Bismarck is launched.

Madison Square Garden Nazi rally: The largest ever pro-Nazi rally in United States history is convened in Madison Square Garden, New York City, with 20,000 members and sympathizers of the German American Bund present.
As part of British air raid precautions, the first of 2.5 million Anderson shelters is constructed in a garden in Islington, north London.

United States labor law: The U.S. Supreme Court rules in NLRB v. Fansteel Metallurgical Corp. that the National Labor Relations Board has no authority to force an employer to rehire workers who engage in sit-down strikes.
source_pages: United_States_labor_law; Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States; NLRB_v._Fansteel_Metallurgical_Corp.; National_Labor_Relations_Board; Sitdown_strike; February_27

event_text: An Imperial Japanese Army ammunition dump explodes at Hirakata, Osaka, Japan, killing 94.
Cardinal Eugenio Pacelli is elected Pope and takes the name Pius XII.
In Bombay, Mohandas Gandhi begins a hunger strike in protest at the autocratic rule in British India.
Spanish Civil War: The National Defence Council seizes control of the republican government in a coup d'etat, with the intention of negotiating an end to the war.
Slovakia declares independence under German pressure.
Germany occupies Czechoslovakia.
Carpatho-Ukraine declares itself an independent republic, but is annexed by Hungary the next day.
From Prague Castle, Hitler proclaims Bohemia and Moravia a German protectorate.
Germany takes Memel from Lithuania.
The Hungarian air force attacks the headquarters of the Slovak air force in Spišská Nová Ves, killing 13 people and beginning the Slovak–Hungarian War.

The 1939 Liechtenstein putsch takes place; approximately 40 members of the VBDL starting from Nendeln march towards Vaduz with the intention of overthrowing the government and provoking Liechtenstein's annexation into Germany.
Spanish Civil War: Nationalists begin their final offensive of the war.
Spanish Civil War: Generalissimo Francisco Franco conquers Madrid after a three-year siege.
source_pages: Spanish_Civil_War; Generalissimo; Francisco_Franco; Madrid; Siege_of_Madrid; March_28

event_text: The Heinkel He 100 fighter sets a world airspeed record of 463 mph (745 km/h).
Events preceding World War II in Europe: Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain pledges British military support to the Second Polish Republic in the event of an invasion by Nazi Germany.
Spanish Civil War: Generalísimo Francisco Franco of the Spanish State announces the end of the Spanish Civil War, when the last of the Republican forces surrender.
source_pages: Generalissimo; Francisco_Franco; Francoist_Spain; Spanish_Civil_War; Republican_faction_(Spanish_Civil_War); April_1

event_text: Benito Mussolini declares an Italian protectorate over Albania and forces King Zog I into exile.
Benito Mussolini invades Albania.
African-American singer Marian Anderson gives a concert at the Lincoln Memorial after being denied the use of Constitution Hall by the Daughters of the American Revolution.
Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) publish the first edition of their "Big Book", which introduced the twelve-step program.
Robert Menzies, who became Australia's longest-serving prime minister, is elected as leader of the United Australia Party after the death of Prime Minister Joseph Lyons.
The 1939–40 New York World's Fair opens.
NBC inaugurates its regularly scheduled television service in New York City, broadcasting President Franklin D. Roosevelt's N.Y. World's Fair opening day ceremonial address.
The All India Forward Bloc is formed by Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose.
Lina Medina becomes the youngest confirmed mother in medical history at the age of five.
The Columbia Lions and the Princeton Tigers play in the United States' first televised sporting event, a collegiate baseball game in New York City.
The Canadian National War Memorial is unveiled by King George VI and Queen Elizabeth in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
World War II: Germany and Italy sign the Pact of Steel.

The U.S. Navy submarine USS Squalus sinks off the coast of New Hampshire during a test dive, causing the death of 24 sailors and two civilian technicians. The remaining 32 sailors and one civilian naval architect are rescued the following day.
First flight of the German Focke-Wulf Fw 190 fighter aircraft.

The Holocaust: The MS St. Louis, a ship carrying 973 German Jewish refugees, is denied permission to land in Florida, in the United States, after already being turned away from Cuba. Forced to return to Europe, more than 200 of its passengers later die in Nazi concentration camps.
source_pages: The_Holocaust; MS_St._Louis; Emigration_of_Jews_from_Nazi_Germany_and_German-occupied_Europe; Florida; Cuba; Nazism; Concentration_camp

event_text: Shooting begins on Paramount Pictures' Dr. Cyclops, the first horror film photographed in three-strip Technicolor.
The Baseball Hall of Fame opens in Cooperstown, New York.
Last public guillotining in France: Eugen Weidmann, a convicted murderer, is executed in Versailles outside the Saint-Pierre prison.
Siam is renamed Thailand by Plaek Phibunsongkhram, the country's third prime minister.

Lou Gehrig, recently diagnosed with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, informs a crowd at Yankee Stadium that he considers himself "The luckiest man on the face of the earth", then announces his retirement from major league baseball.
Anti-Jewish legislation in prewar Nazi Germany closes the last remaining Jewish enterprises.
The Sutton Hoo helmet is discovered.
Albert Einstein and Leo Szilard write a letter to Franklin D. Roosevelt, urging him to begin the Manhattan Project to develop a nuclear weapon.
The Thirteen Roses: Thirteen female members of the Unified Socialist Youth are executed by Francoist forces in Madrid, Spain.
Twenty-six Junkers Ju 87 bombers commanded by Walter Sigel meet unexpected ground fog during a dive-bombing demonstration for Luftwaffe generals at Neuhammer. Thirteen of them crash and burn.
The Wizard of Oz premieres at Grauman's Chinese Theater in Los Angeles, California.

World War II: Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union sign the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact. In a secret protocol to the pact, Poland, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Romania are divided into German and Soviet "spheres of influence".
source_pages: World_War_II; Nazi_Germany; Soviet_Union; Molotov–Ribbentrop_Pact; Second_Polish_Republic; Finland; Estonia; Latvia; Lithuania; Kingdom_of_Romania; August_23

event_text: The Irish Republican Army carries out the 1939 Coventry bombing in which five civilians were killed.
The United Kingdom and Poland form a military alliance in which the UK promises to defend Poland in case of invasion by a foreign power.
First flight of the turbojet-powered Heinkel He 178, the world's first jet aircraft.
Nazi Germany mounts a false flag attack on the Gleiwitz radio station, creating an excuse to attack Poland the following day, thus starting World War II in Europe.
World War II: Germany and Slovakia invade Poland, beginning the European phase of World War II.
J. Robert Oppenheimer and his student Hartland Snyder publish the Oppenheimer–Snyder model, proving for the first time in contemporary physics how black holes could develop.
World War II: Following the start of the invasion of Poland the previous day, the Free City of Danzig (now Gdańsk, Poland) is annexed by Nazi Germany.

World War II: France, the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Australia declare war on Germany after the invasion of Poland, forming the Allied nations. The Viceroy of India also declares war, but without consulting the provincial legislatures.
World War II: The United Kingdom and France begin a naval blockade of Germany that lasts until the end of the war. This also marks the beginning of the Battle of the Atlantic.
World War II: William J. Murphy commands the first Royal Air Force attack on Germany.
World War II: The British Royal Air Force suffers its first fighter pilot casualty of the Second World War at the Battle of Barking Creek as a result of friendly fire.
World War II: Union of South Africa declares war on Germany.
World War II: The Battle of Hel begins, the longest-defended pocket of Polish Army resistance during the German invasion of Poland.
Burmese national hero U Ottama dies in prison after a hunger strike to protest Britain's colonial government.
World War II: The submarine HMS Oxley is mistakenly sunk by the submarine HMS Triton near Norway and becomes the Royal Navy's first loss of a submarine in the war.
World War II: The Canadian declaration of war on Germany receives royal assent.
World War II: The Estonian military boards the Polish submarine ORP Orzeł in Tallinn, sparking a diplomatic incident that the Soviet Union will later use to justify the annexation of Estonia.
World War II: The Soviet invasion of Poland begins.
World War II: German submarine U-29 sinks the British aircraft carrier HMS Courageous.
World War II: The Polish government of Ignacy Mościcki flees to Romania.
World War II: The radio show Germany Calling begins transmitting Nazi propaganda.
World War II: The Battle of Kępa Oksywska concludes, with Polish losses reaching roughly 14% of all the forces engaged.
Romanian Prime Minister Armand Călinescu is assassinated by the Iron Guard.
World War II: A joint German–Soviet military parade in Brest-Litovsk is held to celebrate the successful invasion of Poland.
World War II: Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union agree on a division of Poland.
World War II: The siege of Warsaw comes to an end.
World War II: General Władysław Sikorski becomes prime minister of the Polish government-in-exile.
NBC broadcasts the first televised American football game.
World War II: After a one-month siege, German troops occupy Warsaw.
World War II: The Battle of Kock is the final combat of the September Campaign in Poland.
World War II: Germany annexes western Poland.
World War II: The German submarine U-47 sinks the British battleship HMS Royal Oak within her harbour at Scapa Flow, Scotland.
The New York Municipal Airport (later renamed LaGuardia Airport) is dedicated.
World War II: No. 603 Squadron RAF intercepts the first Luftwaffe raid on Britain.
World War II: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the United States Customs Service to implement the Neutrality Act of 1939, allowing cash-and-carry purchases of weapons by belligerents.
Venlo Incident: Two British agents of SIS are captured by the Germans.
In Munich, Adolf Hitler narrowly escapes the assassination attempt of Georg Elser while celebrating the 16th anniversary of the Beer Hall Putsch.
Finnish author F. E. Sillanpää is awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.

Nine Czech students are executed as a response to anti-Nazi demonstrations prompted by the death of Jan Opletal. All Czech universities are shut down and more than 1,200 students sent to concentration camps. Since this event, International Students' Day is celebrated in many countries, especially in the Czech Republic.
World War II: HMS Rawalpindi is sunk by the German battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau.
Shelling of Mainila: The Soviet Army orchestrates an incident which is used to justify the start of the Winter War with Finland four days later.
World War II: The Soviet Red Army crosses the Finnish border in several places, bombing Helsinki and several other Finnish cities, starting the Winter War.

World War II: A day after the beginning of the Winter War in Finland, the Cajander III Cabinet resigns and is replaced by the Ryti I Cabinet, while the Finnish Parliament move from Helsinki to Kauhajoki to escape the Soviet airstrikes.
source_pages: World_War_II; Winter_War; Finland; Cajander_III_cabinet; Ryti_I_cabinet; Parliament_of_Finland; Helsinki; Kauhajoki; Bombing_of_Helsinki_in_World_War_II; December_1

event_text: The Soviet Union establishes the Finnish Democratic Republic puppet state in Terijoki.
New York City's LaGuardia Airport opens.
World War II: HMS Nelson is struck by a mine (laid by U-31) off the Scottish coast and is laid up for repairs until August 1940.
Winter War: The Red Army's advance on the Karelian Isthmus is stopped by Finns at the Mannerheim Line during the Battle of Taipale.
source_pages: Winter_War; Red_Army; Karelian_Isthmus; Mannerheim_Line; Battle_of_Taipale; December_6

event_text: HMS Duchess sinks after a collision with HMS Barham off the coast of Scotland with the loss of 124 men.
Winter War: The Battle of Tolvajärvi, also known as the first major Finnish victory in the Winter War, begins.

The Battle of the River Plate is fought off the coast of Uruguay; the first naval battle of World War II. The Kriegsmarine's Deutschland-class cruiser (pocket battleship) Admiral Graf Spee engages with three Royal Navy cruisers: HMS Ajax, HMNZS Achilles and HMS Exeter.
source_pages: Battle_of_the_River_Plate; World_War_II; Kriegsmarine; Deutschland-class_cruiser; German_cruiser_Admiral_Graf_Spee; Royal_Navy; HMS_Ajax_(22); HMNZS_Achilles; HMS_Exeter_(68); December_13

event_text: Winter War: The Soviet Union is expelled from the League of Nations for invading Finland.
Gone with the Wind (highest inflation adjusted grossing film) receives its premiere at Loew's Grand Theatre in Atlanta, Georgia, United States.
World War II: Battle of the River Plate: The Admiral Graf Spee is scuttled by Captain Hans Langsdorff outside Montevideo.
World War II: The Battle of the Heligoland Bight, the first major air battle of the war, takes place.

Indian Muslims observe a "Day of Deliverance" to celebrate the resignations of members of the Indian National Congress over their not having been consulted over the decision to enter World War II with the United Kingdom.
World War II: Pope Pius XII makes a Christmas Eve appeal for peace.
The 7.8 Mw  Erzincan earthquake shakes eastern Turkey with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme). At least 32,700 people were killed.
Winter War: Finland holds off a Soviet attack in the Battle of Kelja.
Winter War: Battle of Raate Road: The Finnish 9th Division finally defeat the numerically superior Soviet forces on the Raate-Suomussalmi road.
World War II: Britain introduces food rationing.
Three trains on the Nishinari Line; present Sakurajima Line, in Osaka, Japan, collide and explode while approaching Ajikawaguchi Station. One hundred and eighty-one people are killed.
The second full-length animated Walt Disney film, Pinocchio, premieres.
The Soviet Union begins mass deportations of Polish citizens from occupied eastern Poland to Siberia.
Paul Creston's Saxophone Sonata was officially premiered at the Carnegie Chamber Hall by saxophonist Cecil Leeson, who had commissioned it, and the composer.
World War II: Altmark incident: The German tanker Altmark is boarded by sailors from the British destroyer HMS Cossack. A total of 299 British prisoners are freed.
Martin Kamen and Sam Ruben discover carbon-14.
Five people are killed in an arson attack on the offices of the communist newspaper Flamman in Luleå, Sweden.

Six high-ranking members of the Soviet politburo, including Joseph Stalin, sign an order for the execution of 25,700 Polish intelligentsia, including 14,700 Polish POWs, in what will become known as the Katyn massacre.
Winter War: Finland signs the Moscow Peace Treaty with the Soviet Union, ceding almost all of Finnish Karelia.
source_pages: Winter_War; Finland; Moscow_Peace_Treaty; Soviet_Union; Karelia_(historical_province); March_12

event_text: The most destructive train accident in Finnish history kills 39 and injures 69 people in Turenki, Janakkala.
The Winter War between Finland and the Soviet Union officially ends after the signing of the Moscow Peace Treaty.
World War II: Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini meet at the Brenner Pass in the Alps and agree to form an alliance against France and the United Kingdom.
The Lahore Resolution (Qarardad-e-Pakistan or Qarardad-e-Lahore) is put forward at the Annual General Convention of the All-India Muslim League.
Second Sino-Japanese War: Japan declares Nanking capital of a new Chinese puppet government, nominally controlled by Wang Jingwei.
Booker T. Washington becomes the first African American to be depicted on a United States postage stamp.
The Central Committee of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party elects Yumjaagiin Tsedenbal as General Secretary, marking the beginning of his 44-year-long tenure as de facto leader of Mongolia.
World War II: Operation Weserübung: Germany invades Denmark and Norway.
Vidkun Quisling seizes power in Norway.
World War II: Royal Marines land in Namsos, Norway, preceding a larger force which will arrive two days later.
The Rhythm Club fire at a dance hall in Natchez, Mississippi, kills 198 people.
World War II: Norwegian Campaign: Norwegian squads in Hegra Fortress and Vinjesvingen capitulate to German forces after all other Norwegian forces in southern Norway had laid down their arms.
John Steinbeck is awarded the Pulitzer Prize for his novel The Grapes of Wrath.
World War II: The Norway Debate in the British House of Commons begins, and leads to the replacement of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain with Winston Churchill three days later.
World War II: German fighters accidentally bomb the German city of Freiburg.

World War II: Winston Churchill is appointed Prime Minister of the United Kingdom following the resignation of Neville Chamberlain. On the same day, Germany invades France, The Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg. Meanwhile, the United Kingdom occupies Iceland.
World War II: Germany's conquest of France begins, as the German army crosses the Meuse. Winston Churchill makes his "blood, toil, tears, and sweat" speech to the House of Commons.
source_pages: World_War_II; Battle_of_France; Meuse; Winston_Churchill; Blood,_toil,_tears_and_sweat; House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom

event_text: World War II: Rotterdam, Netherlands is bombed by the Luftwaffe of Nazi Germany despite a ceasefire, killing about 900 people and destroying the historic city center.
source_pages: World_War_II; Rotterdam; German_bombing_of_Rotterdam; Luftwaffe; Nazi_Germany; May_14

event_text: USS Sailfish is recommissioned. It was originally the USS Squalus.
World War II: The Battle of the Netherlands: After fierce fighting, the poorly trained and equipped Dutch troops surrender to Germany, marking the beginning of five years of occupation.
Richard and Maurice McDonald open the first McDonald's restaurant.
World War II: Germany occupies Brussels, Belgium.
The Holocaust: The first prisoners arrive at a new concentration camp at Auschwitz.
Igor Sikorsky performs the first successful single-rotor helicopter flight.
Acting on the orders of Soviet leader Joseph Stalin, NKVD agent Iosif Grigulevich orchestrates an unsuccessful assassination attempt on exiled Russian revolutionary Leon Trotsky in Coyoacán, Mexico.
source_pages: Soviet_Union; Joseph_Stalin; NKVD; Iosif_Grigulevich; Leon_Trotsky; Coyoacán

event_text: World War II: The German 2nd Panzer Division captures the port of Boulogne-sur-Mer; the surrender of the last French and British troops marks the end of the Battle of Boulogne.

World War II: Operation Dynamo: In northern France, Allied forces begin a massive evacuation from Dunkirk, France. The Battle of Dunkirk begins simultaneously as Allied defenders fight to slow down the German offensive.
source_pages: World_War_II; Dunkirk_evacuation; Allies_of_World_War_II; Dunkirk; Battle_of_Dunkirk; Nazi_Germany; May_26

event_text: World War II: The Siege of Calais ends with the surrender of the British and French garrison.
World War II: In the Le Paradis massacre, 99 soldiers from a Royal Norfolk Regiment unit are shot after surrendering to German troops; two survive.
World War II: Belgium surrenders to Nazi Germany to end the Battle of Belgium.
World War II: Norwegian, French, Polish and British forces recapture Narvik in Norway. This is the first Allied infantry victory of the War.
World War II: During the Battle of France, the Luftwaffe bombs Paris.
Franz Rademacher proposes plans to make Madagascar the "Jewish homeland", an idea that had first been considered by 19th century journalist Theodor Herzl.

World War II: The Dunkirk evacuation ends: the British Armed Forces completes evacuation of 338,000 troops from Dunkirk in France. To rally the morale of the country, Winston Churchill delivers, only to the House of Commons, his famous "We shall fight on the beaches" speech.
source_pages: World_War_II; Dunkirk_evacuation; British_Armed_Forces; Dunkirk; Winston_Churchill; House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom; We_shall_fight_on_the_beaches

event_text: World War II: After a brief lull in the Battle of France, the Germans renew the offensive against the remaining French divisions south of the River Somme in Operation Fall Rot ("Case Red").
King Haakon VII, Crown Prince Olav and the Norwegian government leave Tromsø and go into exile in London. They return exactly five years later.
World War II: The completion of Operation Alphabet, the evacuation of Allied forces from Narvik at the end of the Norwegian Campaign.
World War II: Fascist Italy declares war on France and the United Kingdom, beginning an invasion of southern France.
World War II: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt denounces Italy's actions in his "Stab in the Back" speech at the graduation ceremonies of the University of Virginia.
World War II: Military resistance to the German occupation of Norway ends.
World War II: The Siege of Malta begins with a series of Italian air raids.
World War II: Thirteen thousand British and French troops surrender to General Erwin Rommel at Saint-Valery-en-Caux.
World War II: The German occupation of Paris begins.
The Soviet Union presents an ultimatum to Lithuania, resulting in Lithuanian loss of independence.
Seven hundred and twenty-eight Polish political prisoners from Tarnów become the first inmates of the Auschwitz concentration camp.
World War II: Operation Aerial begins: Allied troops start to evacuate France, following Germany's takeover of Paris and most of the nation.
World War II: Marshal Henri Philippe Pétain becomes Chief of State of Vichy France (Chef de l'État Français).
The Soviet Union occupies Lithuania, which will eventually become the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (SSR).
World War II: RMS Lancastria is attacked and sunk by the Luftwaffe near Saint-Nazaire, France. At least 3,000 are killed in Britain's worst maritime disaster.
World War II: The British Army's 11th Hussars assault and take Fort Capuzzo in Libya from Italian forces.
The three Baltic states of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania fall under the occupation of the Soviet Union.
Appeal of 18 June by Charles de Gaulle.
The "Finest Hour" speech is delivered by Winston Churchill.
World War II: Italy begins an unsuccessful invasion of France.
World War II: France is forced to sign the Second Compiègne armistice with Germany, in the same railroad car in which the Germans signed the Armistice in 1918.
Adolf Hitler goes on a three-hour tour of the architecture of Paris with architect Albert Speer and sculptor Arno Breker in his only visit to the city.
Henry Larsen begins the first successful west-to-east navigation of Northwest Passage from Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.
World War II: Operation Collar, the first British Commando raid on occupied France, by No 11 Independent Company.
World War II: The French armistice with Nazi Germany comes into effect.
World War II: Under the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact, the Soviet Union presents an ultimatum to Romania requiring it to cede Bessarabia and the northern part of Bukovina.
source_pages: World_War_II; Molotov–Ribbentrop_Pact; Soviet_Union; Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_Northern_Bukovina; Kingdom_of_Romania; Bessarabia; Bukovina

event_text: Romania cedes Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina to the Soviet Union after facing an ultimatum.
Indian independence leader Subhas Chandra Bose is arrested and detained in Calcutta.
World War II: The SS Arandora Star is sunk by U-47 in the North Atlantic with the loss of over 800 lives, mostly civilians.

World War II: The Royal Navy attacks the French naval squadron in Algeria, to ensure that it will not fall under German control. Of the four French battleships present, one is sunk, two are damaged, and one escapes back to France.
World War II: Foreign relations of Vichy France are severed with the United Kingdom.
Story Bridge, a major landmark in Brisbane, as well as Australia's longest cantilever bridge is formally opened.
World War II: The Vichy government is established in France.

World War II: Six days before Adolf Hitler issues his Directive 16 to the combined Wehrmacht armed forces for Operation Sea Lion, the Kanalkampf shipping attacks begin against British maritime convoys in the leadup to initiating the Battle of Britain.
source_pages: Adolf_Hitler; List_of_Adolf_Hitler's_directives; Wehrmacht; Operation_Sea_Lion; Kanalkampf; Battle_of_Britain

event_text: World War II: Vichy France regime is formally established. Philippe Pétain becomes Chief of the French State.
World War II: Battle of Cape Spada: The Royal Navy and the Regia Marina clash; the Italian light cruiser Bartolomeo Colleoni sinks, with 121 casualties.
Field Marshal Ceremony: First occasion in World War II that Adolf Hitler appoints field marshals due to military achievements.
World War II: Army order 112 forms the Intelligence Corps of the British Army.
Denmark leaves the League of Nations.
California opens its first freeway, the Arroyo Seco Parkway.

The United States' Under Secretary of State Sumner Welles issues a declaration on the U.S. non-recognition policy of the Soviet annexation and incorporation of three Baltic states: Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
source_pages: United_States_Under_Secretary_of_State; Sumner_Welles; Welles_Declaration; Soviet_Union; Baltic_states; Estonia; Latvia; Lithuania

event_text: General Henri Guisan orders the Swiss Army to resist German invasion and makes surrender illegal.
The animated short A Wild Hare is released, introducing the character of Bugs Bunny.
World War II: Italian forces begin the invasion of British Somaliland.
World War II: The Soviet Union formally annexes Latvia.
Estonia is annexed by the Soviet Union.
The "Aufbau Ost" directive is signed by Wilhelm Keitel.

An Italian submarine torpedoes and sinks the Greek cruiser Elli at Tinos harbor during peacetime, marking the most serious Italian provocation prior to the outbreak of the Greco-Italian War in October.
World War II: The Hardest Day air battle, part of the Battle of Britain, takes place. At that point, it is the largest aerial engagement in history with heavy losses sustained on both sides.
First flight of the B-25 Mitchell medium bomber.
In Mexico City, exiled Russian revolutionary Leon Trotsky is fatally wounded with an ice axe by Ramón Mercader. He dies the next day.
World War II: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill makes the fourth of his famous wartime speeches, containing the line "Never was so much owed by so many to so few".
World War II: The Eighth Route Army launches the Hundred Regiments Offensive, a successful campaign to disrupt Japanese war infrastructure and logistics in occupied northern China.
World War II: The first Bombing of Berlin by the British Royal Air Force.
World War II: Chad becomes the first French colony to join the Allies under the administration of Félix Éboué, France's first black colonial governor.
The Second Vienna Award reassigns the territory of Northern Transylvania from Romania to Hungary.

Pennsylvania Central Airlines Trip 19 crashes near Lovettsville, Virginia. The CAB investigation of the accident is the first investigation to be conducted under the Bureau of Air Commerce act of 1938.
King Carol II of Romania abdicates and is succeeded by his son Michael. General Ion Antonescu becomes the Conducător of Romania.
Romania returns Southern Dobruja to Bulgaria under the Treaty of Craiova.
World War II: The German Luftwaffe begins the Blitz, bombing London and other British cities for over 50 consecutive nights.
George Stibitz pioneers the first remote operation of a computer.
Treznea Massacre in Transylvania.
Cave paintings are discovered in Lascaux, France.
The Hercules Powder plant disaster in the United States kills 51 people and injures over 200.
Ip massacre: The Hungarian Army, supported by local Hungarians, kill 158 Romanian civilians in Ip, Sălaj, a village in Northern Transylvania, an act of ethnic cleansing.
source_pages: Ip_massacre; Hungarian_Ground_Forces; Hungarians_in_Romania; Romania; Ip,_Sălaj; Northern_Transylvania; Ethnic_cleansing

event_text: World War II: The climax of the Battle of Britain, when the Luftwaffe launches its largest and most concentrated attack of the entire campaign.
World War II: Italian troops conquer Sidi Barrani.
World War II: Due to setbacks in the Battle of Britain and approaching autumn weather, Hitler postpones Operation Sea Lion.
World War II: Witold Pilecki is voluntarily captured and sent to Auschwitz concentration camp to gather and smuggle out information for the resistance movement.
World War II: The Tripartite Pact is signed in Berlin by Germany, Japan and Italy.
Two Avro Ansons collide in mid-air over New South Wales, Australia, remain locked together, then land safely.
The Pennsylvania Turnpike, often considered the first superhighway in the United States, opens to traffic.
World War II: The McCollum memo proposes bringing the United States into the war in Europe by provoking the Japanese to attack the United States.
World War II: The Balham underground station disaster kills sixty-six people during the London Blitz.
President Lluís Companys of Catalonia is executed by the Francoist government.
Holocaust in Poland: The Warsaw Ghetto is established.
The body of Communist propagandist Willi Münzenberg is found in South France, starting a never-resolved mystery.
The first edition of the Ernest Hemingway novel For Whom the Bell Tolls is published.
Adolf Hitler and Francisco Franco meet at Hendaye to discuss the possibility of Spain entering the Second World War.
Benjamin O. Davis Sr. is named the first African American general in the United States Army.
World War II: Greece rejects Italy's ultimatum. Italy invades Greece through Albania a few hours later.
World War II: The Battle of Britain ends, causing Germany to abandon Operation Sea Lion.
World War II: First day of Battle of Elaia–Kalamas between the Greeks and the Italians.
World War II: The British armed merchant cruiser HMS Jervis Bay is sunk by the German pocket battleship Admiral Scheer.
Franklin D. Roosevelt is the first and only President of the United States to be elected to a third term.
In Tacoma, Washington, the original Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapses in a windstorm, a mere four months after the bridge's completion.
Greco-Italian War: The Italian invasion of Greece fails as outnumbered Greek units repulse the Italians in the Battle of Elaia–Kalamas.
Warsaw is awarded the Virtuti Militari by the Polish government-in-exile.
The 1940 Vrancea earthquake strikes Romania killing an estimated 1,000 and injuring approximately 4,000 more.
World War II: In the Battle of Taranto, the Royal Navy launches the first all-aircraft ship-to-ship naval attack in history.
World War II: The German auxiliary cruiser Atlantis captures top secret British mail from the Automedon, and sends it to Japan.
World War II: The Battle of Gabon ends as Free French Forces take Libreville, Gabon, and all of French Equatorial Africa from Vichy French forces.
source_pages: World_War_II; Battle_of_Gabon; French_Liberation_Army; Libreville; Gabon; French_Equatorial_Africa; Vichy_France

event_text: World War II: Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav Molotov arrives in Berlin to discuss the possibility of the Soviet Union joining the Axis Powers.
Walt Disney's animated musical film Fantasia is first released at New York's Broadway Theatre, on the first night of a roadshow.
World War II: In England, Coventry is heavily bombed by German Luftwaffe bombers. Coventry Cathedral is almost completely destroyed.
World War II: In response to the leveling of Coventry by the German Luftwaffe two days before, the Royal Air Force bombs Hamburg.
The Holocaust: In occupied Poland, the Nazis close off the Warsaw Ghetto from the outside world.
New York City's "Mad Bomber" George Metesky places his first bomb at a Manhattan office building used by Consolidated Edison.
The Tartu Art Museum is established in Tartu, Estonia.
World War II: German leader Adolf Hitler and Italian Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano meet to discuss Benito Mussolini's disastrous Italian invasion of Greece.
