Bernard Baruch first applies the term "Cold War" to describe the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union.
The Operation Big Bang, the largest non-nuclear man-made explosion to that time, destroys bunkers and military installations on the North Sea island of Heligoland, Germany.
Thor Heyerdahl and five crew mates set out from Peru on the Kon-Tiki to demonstrate that Peruvian natives could have settled Polynesia.
In Nevada, Boulder Dam is renamed Hoover Dam.
Portella della Ginestra massacre against May Day celebrations in Sicily by the bandit and separatist leader Salvatore Giuliano where 11 persons are killed and 33 wounded.
New post-war Japanese constitution goes into effect.
Cold War: The Truman Doctrine goes into effect, aiding Turkey and Greece.
United Airlines Flight 521 crashes at LaGuardia Airport, killing 43.

Ferenc Nagy, the democratically elected Prime Minister of Hungary, resigns from office after blackmail from the Hungarian Communist Party accusing him of being part of a plot against the state. This grants the Communists effective control of the Hungarian government.
Cold War: Marshall Plan: In a speech at Harvard University, the United States Secretary of State George Marshall calls for economic aid to war-torn Europe.
Saab produces its first automobile.
Pan Am Flight 121 crashes in the Syrian Desert near Mayadin, Syria, killing 15 and injuring 21.
The United States Senate follows the United States House of Representatives in overriding U.S. President Harry S. Truman's veto of the Taft–Hartley Act.
Kenneth Arnold makes the first widely reported UFO sighting near Mount Rainier, Washington.
The Diary of a Young Girl (better known as The Diary of Anne Frank) is published.
The Philippine Air Force is established.
The "Indian Independence Bill" is presented before the British House of Commons, proposing the independence of the Provinces of British India into two sovereign countries: India and Pakistan.
Referendum held in Sylhet to decide its fate in the Partition of India.
The AK-47 goes into production in the Soviet Union.
Reports are broadcast that a UFO crash-landed in Roswell, New Mexico in what became known as the Roswell UFO incident.
Muhammad Ali Jinnah is recommended as the first Governor-General of Pakistan by the British Prime Minister, Clement Attlee.
The Exodus 1947 heads to Palestine from France.
Prime Minister of the shadow Burmese government, Bogyoke Aung San and eight others are assassinated.
Korean politician Lyuh Woon-hyung is assassinated.

Cold War: U.S. president Harry S. Truman signs the National Security Act of 1947 into United States law creating the Central Intelligence Agency, United States Department of Defense, United States Air Force, Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the United States National Security Council.
source_pages: Cold_War; Harry_S._Truman; National_Security_Act_of_1947; Law_of_the_United_States; Central_Intelligence_Agency; United_States_Department_of_Defense; United_States_Air_Force; Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff; United_States_National_Security_Council

event_text: In Vatican City, Rome, canonization of Catherine Labouré, the saint whose apparitions of the Virgin Mary originated the worldwide diffusion of the Miraculous Medal.
A British South American Airways Avro Lancastrian airliner crashes into a mountain during a flight from Buenos Aires, Argentina to Santiago, Chile. The wreckage would not be found until 1998.
The Supreme Court of Japan is established.

Thor Heyerdahl's balsa wood raft, the Kon-Tiki, smashes into the reef at Raroia in the Tuamotu Islands after a 101-day, 7,000 kilometres (4,300 mi) journey across the Pacific Ocean in an attempt to prove that pre-historic peoples could have traveled from South America.
source_pages: Thor_Heyerdahl; Ochroma; Kon-Tiki_expedition; Reef; Raroia; Tuamotus; August_7

event_text: The Bombay Municipal Corporation formally takes over the Bombay Electric Supply and Transport (BEST).
Pakistan gains independence from the British Empire as the Dominion of Pakistan, due to the partition of India.
source_pages: Pakistan; Pakistan_Movement; British_Empire; Dominion_of_Pakistan; Partition_of_India; August_14

event_text: India gains independence from British rule after near 190 years of British company and crown rule and joins the Commonwealth of Nations.
Founder of Pakistan, Muhammad Ali Jinnah is sworn in as first Governor-General of Pakistan in Karachi.
The Radcliffe Line, the border between the Dominions of India and Pakistan, is revealed.
First case of a computer bug being found: A moth lodges in a relay of a Harvard Mark II computer at Harvard University.
Typhoon Kathleen hits the Kantō region, in Japan killing around 1,000-2,000 people.
The National Security Act reorganizes the United States government's military and intelligence services.
A magnitude 6.9 earthquake strikes South Khorasan in Iran, killing over 500 people.

The 1947 World Series begins. It is the first to be televised, to include an African-American player, to exceed $2 million in receipts, to see a pinch-hit home run, and to have six umpires on the field.
Pakistan joins the United Nations.
The North American F-86 Sabre flies for the first time.
President Truman makes the first televised Oval Office address.
Flying the Bell XS-1 over Muroc Army Air Field in California, Captain Chuck Yeager breaks the sound barrier in level flight, reaching Mach 1.05.
source_pages: Bell_X-1; Edwards_Air_Force_Base; Chuck_Yeager; Sound_barrier; Mach_number; October_14

event_text: The Philippines takes over the administration of the Turtle Islands and the Mangsee Islands from the United Kingdom.

Cold War: The House Un-American Activities Committee begins its investigation into Communist infiltration of the Hollywood film industry, resulting in a blacklist that prevents some from working in the industry for years.
Famed animator Walt Disney testifies before the House Un-American Activities Committee, naming Disney employees he believes to be communists.
United Air Lines Flight 608 crashes in the Bryce Canyon National Park in Garfield County, Utah, while attempting an emergency landing at Bryce Canyon Airport, killing 52 people.
source_pages: United_Air_Lines_Flight_608; Bryce_Canyon_National_Park; Garfield_County,_Utah; Emergency_landing; Bryce_Canyon_Airport; October_24

event_text: Partition of India: The Maharaja of Kashmir and Jammu signs the Instrument of Accession with India, beginning the Indo-Pakistani War of 1947–1948 and the Kashmir conflict.
The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the foundation of the World Trade Organization (WTO), is founded.

In California, designer Howard Hughes performs the maiden (and only) flight of the Hughes H-4 Hercules (also known as the "Spruce Goose"), the largest fixed-wing aircraft ever built until Scaled Composites rolled out their Stratolaunch in May 2017.
Meet the Press, the longest running television program in history, makes its debut on NBC Television.
The Soviet Union completes development of the AK-47, one of the first proper assault rifles.
The Screen Actors Guild implements an anti-Communist loyalty oath.
American scientists John Bardeen and Walter Houser Brattain observe the basic principles of the transistor, a key element for the electronics revolution of the 20th century.
The Ballantyne's Department Store fire in Christchurch, New Zealand, kills 41; it is the worst fire disaster in the history of New Zealand.
The Princess Elizabeth marries Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten, who becomes the Duke of Edinburgh, at Westminster Abbey in London.
Red Scare: The "Hollywood Ten" are blacklisted by Hollywood movie studios.
New Zealand ratifies the Statute of Westminster and thus becomes independent of legislative control by the United Kingdom.
The United Nations General Assembly approve the United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine.
French forces carry out a massacre at Mỹ Trạch, Vietnam during the First Indochina War.
Civil War in Mandatory Palestine begins, leading up to the creation of the State of Israel and the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
Jerusalem Riots of 1947: Arabs riot in Jerusalem in response to the United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine.
First flight of the Boeing B-47 Stratojet strategic bomber.
The transistor is first demonstrated at Bell Laboratories.
Cold War: King Michael I of Romania is forced to abdicate by the Soviet Union-backed Communist government of Romania.
The British railway network is nationalized to form British Railways.
Burma gains its independence from the United Kingdom, becoming an independent republic.
Kentucky Air National Guard pilot Thomas Mantell crashes while in pursuit of a supposed UFO.
The Renville Agreement between the Netherlands and Indonesia is ratified.
The Flag of Quebec is adopted and flown for the first time over the National Assembly of Quebec. The day is marked annually as Québec Flag Day.
British South American Airways' Tudor IV Star Tiger disappears over the Bermuda Triangle.

Following the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi in his home compound, India's prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, broadcasts to the nation, saying "The light has gone out of our lives". The date of the assassination becomes observed as "Martyrs' Day" in India.
source_pages: Assassination_of_Mahatma_Gandhi; India; Jawaharlal_Nehru; The_light_has_gone_out_of_our_lives; January_30; Martyrs'_Day_(India)

event_text: Ceylon (later renamed Sri Lanka) becomes independent within the British Commonwealth.
The Al-Waziri coup briefly ousts the ruling Hamidaddin dynasty of Yemen; Imam Yahya Muhammad Hamid ed-Din is killed.
The Conference of Youth and Students of Southeast Asia Fighting for Freedom and Independence convenes in Calcutta.
NASCAR is incorporated.
In a coup d'état led by Klement Gottwald, the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia takes control of government in Prague to end the Third Czechoslovak Republic.

The 1948 Accra riots erupted following a march by ex-servicemen of the Gold Coast Regiment towards the seat of the colonial government at Christiansborg Castle where they were fired upon by Superintendant Colin Imray leading to the killing of Sergeant Adjetey, Corporal Attipoe and Private Odartey Lamptey and the arrest of the Big Six in the Gold Coast.
source_pages: 1948_Accra_riots; Ghana_Regiment; Osu_Castle; Cornelius_Francis_Adjetey; Patrick_Attipoe; Odartey_Lamptey; The_Big_Six_(Ghana); Gold_Coast_(British_colony); February_28

event_text: Belgium, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom sign the Treaty of Brussels, a precursor to the North Atlantic Treaty establishing NATO.
source_pages: Belgium; France; Luxembourg; Netherlands; United_Kingdom; Treaty_of_Brussels; North_Atlantic_Treaty; NATO; March_17

event_text: Soviet consultants leave Yugoslavia in the first sign of the Tito–Stalin split.
With a Musicians Union ban lifted, the first telecasts of classical music in the United States, under Eugene Ormandy and Arturo Toscanini, are given on CBS and NBC.
The first successful tornado forecast predicts that a tornado will strike Tinker Air Force Base, Oklahoma.
Cold War: Communist forces respond to the introduction of the Deutsche Mark by attempting to force the western powers to withdraw from Berlin.
Faroe Islands gain autonomy from Denmark.
Cold War: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs the Marshall Plan, authorizing $5 billion in aid for 16 countries.
In Jeju Province, South Korea, a civil-war-like period of violence and human rights abuses known as the Jeju uprising begins.
The Finno-Soviet Treaty is signed in Moscow.
The World Health Organization is established by the United Nations.
Jorge Eliécer Gaitán's assassination provokes a violent riot in Bogotá (the Bogotazo), and a further ten years of violence in Colombia.
Fighters from the Irgun and Lehi Zionist terror groups attacked Deir Yassin near Jerusalem, killing over 100 Palestinians.
source_pages: Irgun; Lehi_(militant_group); Zionism; Deir_Yassin; Jerusalem; Deir_Yassin_massacre

event_text: In an ambush, 78 Jewish doctors, nurses and medical students from Hadassah Hospital, and a British soldier, are massacred by Arabs in Sheikh Jarrah. This event came to be known as the Hadassah medical convoy massacre.
The Organization of European Economic Co-operation is formed.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 47 relating to Kashmir conflict is adopted.
Arab–Israeli War: The port city of Haifa is captured by Jewish forces.
Igor Stravinsky conducts the premiere of his American ballet, Orpheus at the New York City Center.
In Bogotá, Colombia, the Organization of American States is established.
The U.S. Supreme Court rules in Shelley v. Kraemer that covenants prohibiting the sale of real estate to blacks and other minorities are legally unenforceable.
The Council of Europe is founded during the Hague Congress.
Czechoslovakia's Ninth-of-May Constitution comes into effect.
Arab–Israeli War: The Kfar Etzion massacre occurs, a day prior to the Israeli Declaration of Independence.

Israel is declared to be an independent state and a provisional government is established. Immediately after the declaration, Israel is attacked by the neighboring Arab states, triggering the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
Following the expiration of The British Mandate for Palestine, the Kingdom of Egypt, Transjordan, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and Saudi Arabia invade Israel thus starting the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
source_pages: Mandatory_Palestine; Kingdom_of_Egypt; Jordan; Lebanon; Syria; Iraq; Saudi_Arabia; Israel; 1948_Arab–Israeli_War

event_text: The First Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China officially convenes in Nanking.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek wins the 1948 Republic of China presidential election and is sworn in as the first President of the Republic of China at Nanjing.

Finnish President J. K. Paasikivi releases Yrjö Leino from his duties as interior minister after the Finnish parliament adopted a motion of censure of Leino with connection to his illegal handing over of nineteen people to the Soviet Union in 1945.
source_pages: Juho_Kusti_Paasikivi; Yrjö_Leino; Minister_of_the_Interior_(Finland); Parliament_of_Finland; Soviet_Union; May_22

event_text: Thomas C. Wasson, the US Consul-General, is assassinated in Jerusalem, Israel.
Arab–Israeli War: Egypt captures the Israeli kibbutz of Yad Mordechai, but the five-day effort gives Israeli forces time to prepare enough to stop the Egyptian advance a week later.
The U.S. Congress passes Public Law 80-557, which permanently establishes the Civil Air Patrol as an auxiliary of the United States Air Force.
Daniel François Malan is elected as Prime Minister of South Africa. He later goes on to implement Apartheid.
United Nations Truce Supervision Organization is founded.
A dike along the flooding Columbia River breaks, obliterating Vanport, Oregon within minutes. Fifteen people die and tens of thousands are left homeless.
Anti-Jewish riots in Oujda and Jerada take place.
Edvard Beneš resigns as President of Czechoslovakia rather than signing the Ninth-of-May Constitution, making his nation a Communist state.
Foundation of the International Council on Archives under the auspices of the UNESCO.
Members of the Malayan Communist Party kill three British plantation managers in Sungai Siput; in response, British Malaya declares a state of emergency.
United Airlines Flight 624, a Douglas DC-6, crashes near Mount Carmel, Pennsylvania, killing all 43 people on board.
Columbia Records introduces the long-playing record album in a public demonstration at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York City.

Britain, France and the United States announce that on June 21, the Deutsche Mark will be introduced in western Germany and West Berlin. Over the next six days, Communists increasingly restrict access to Berlin.
The Deutsche Mark is introduced in Western Allied-occupied Germany. The Soviet Military Administration in Germany responded by imposing the Berlin Blockade four days later.
The ship HMT Empire Windrush brought the first group of 802 West Indian immigrants to Tilbury, marking the start of modern immigration to the United Kingdom.
King George VI formally gives up the title "Emperor of India", half a year after Britain actually gave up its rule of India.
Cold War: Start of the Berlin Blockade: The Soviet Union makes overland travel between West Germany and West Berlin impossible.
The United States Congress passes the Displaced Persons Act to allow World War II refugees to immigrate to the United States above quota restrictions.
Cold War: The first supply flights are made in response to the Berlin Blockade.
William Shockley files the original patent for the grown-junction transistor, the first bipolar junction transistor.
Shirley Jackson's short story "The Lottery" is published in The New Yorker magazine.
Cold War: The Tito–Stalin Split results in the expulsion of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia from the Cominform.
Boxer Dick Turpin beats Vince Hawkins at Villa Park in Birmingham to become the first black British boxing champion in the modern era.
Muhammad Ali Jinnah (Quaid-i-Azam) inaugurates Pakistan's central bank, the State Bank of Pakistan.
National Health Service Acts create the national public health system in the United Kingdom.
The United States Air Force accepts its first female recruits into a program called the Women's Air Force (WAF).
Israeli Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion orders the expulsion of Palestinians from the towns of Lod and Ramla.
Palmiro Togliatti, leader of the Italian Communist Party, is shot and wounded near the Italian Parliament.
Following token resistance, the city of Nazareth, revered by Christians as the hometown of Jesus, capitulates to Israeli troops during Operation Dekel in the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
The storming of the cockpit of the Miss Macao passenger seaplane, operated by a subsidiary of the Cathay Pacific Airways, marks the first aircraft hijacking of a commercial plane.
U.S. president Harry S. Truman signs Executive Order 9981, desegregating the military of the United States.
Olympic Games: The Games of the XIV Olympiad: After a hiatus of 12 years caused by World War II, the first Summer Olympics to be held since the 1936 Summer Olympics in Berlin, open in London.
At Idlewild Field in New York, New York International Airport (later renamed John F. Kennedy International Airport) is dedicated.
USS Nevada is sunk by an aerial torpedo after surviving hits from two atomic bombs (as part of post-war tests) and being used for target practice by three other ships.
Whittaker Chambers accuses Alger Hiss of being a communist and a spy for the Soviet Union.
Candid Camera makes its television debut after being on radio for a year as The Candid Microphone.
Between 15 and 150 unarmed members of the Khudai Khidmatgar movement are killed by Pakistani police.

An Idaho Department of Fish and Game program to relocate beavers known as Beaver drop occurred. This program relocated beavers from Northwestern Idaho to Central Idaho by airplane and then parachuting the beavers into the Chamberlain Basin .
The First Republic of Korea (South Korea) is established in the southern half of the peninsula.
Soviet Consul General in New York, Jacob M. Lomakin is expelled by the United States, due to the Kasenkina Case.
The World Council of Churches is formed by 147 churches from 44 countries.
The House Un-American Activities Committee holds first-ever televised congressional hearing: "Confrontation Day" between Whittaker Chambers and Alger Hiss.
Northwest Airlines Flight 421 crashes in Fountain City, Wisconsin, killing all 37 aboard.
Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands abdicates for health reasons.
In France, Robert Schuman becomes President of the Council while being Foreign minister; as such, he is the negotiator of the major treaties of the end of World War II.
Kim Il Sung declares the establishment of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea).
Deputy Prime Minister of India Vallabhbhai Patel orders the Army to move into Hyderabad to integrate it with the Indian Union.
Margaret Chase Smith is elected United States senator, and becomes the first woman to serve in both the U.S. House of Representatives and the United States Senate.
The Indian Army captures the city of Aurangabad as part of Operation Polo.
The Indian Army captures the towns of Jalna, Latur, Mominabad, Surriapet and Narkatpalli as part of Operation Polo.
source_pages: Indian_Army; Jalna,_Maharashtra; Latur; Mominabad_Town; Suryapet; Narketpally; Annexation_of_Hyderabad

event_text: The F-86 Sabre sets the world aircraft speed record at 671 miles per hour (1,080 km/h).
The Lehi (also known as the Stern gang) assassinates Count Folke Bernadotte, who was appointed by the United Nations to mediate between the Arab nations and Israel.
The Nizam of Hyderabad surrenders his sovereignty over the Hyderabad State and joins the Indian Union.
Operation Polo is terminated after the Indian Army accepts the surrender of the army of Hyderabad.
Margaret Chase Smith of Maine becomes the first woman elected to the United States Senate without completing another senator's term.
Gail Halvorsen officially starts parachuting candy to children as part of the Berlin Airlift.
Israeli-Palestine conflict: The All-Palestine Government is established by the Arab League.
The Honda Motor Company is founded.
A KLM Lockheed L-049 Constellation crashes on approach to Glasgow Prestwick Airport, killing 40.
Ecological disaster in Donora, Pennsylvania.
Paul Hermann Müller is awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discovery of the insecticidal properties of DDT.
Ecological disaster in Donora, Pennsylvania.
Israeli-Palestinian conflict: Safsaf massacre: Israeli soldiers capture the Palestinian village of Safsaf in the Galilee; afterwards, between 52 and 64 villagers are massacred by the IDF.
A luzzu fishing boat overloaded with passengers capsizes and sinks in the Gozo Channel off Qala, Gozo, Malta, killing 23 of the 27 people on board.
source_pages: Luzzu; 1948_Gozo_luzzu_disaster; Gozo_Channel; Qala,_Malta; Gozo; Crown_Colony_of_Malta; October_30

event_text: Athenagoras I, Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, is enthroned.

Aftermath of World War II: In Tokyo, the International Military Tribunal for the Far East sentences seven Japanese military and government officials, including General Hideki Tojo, to death for their roles in World War II.
Chinese Civil War: The SS Kiangya, carrying Nationalist refugees from Shanghai, explodes in the Huangpu River.
source_pages: Chinese_Civil_War; SS_Kiangya; Nationalist_government; Shanghai; Huangpu_River; December_4

event_text: The Genocide Convention is adopted.
The Human Rights Convention is signed by the United Nations.
Arab–Israeli War: The United Nations passes General Assembly Resolution 194, creating a Conciliation Commission to mediate the conflict.
Thomas T. Goldsmith Jr. and Estle Ray Mann are granted a patent for their cathode-ray tube amusement device, the earliest known interactive electronic game.
The Finnish Security Police is established to remove communist leadership from its predecessor, the State Police.
Indonesian National Revolution: The Dutch military captures Yogyakarta, the temporary capital of the newly formed Republic of Indonesia.
Sjafruddin Prawiranegara established the Emergency Government of the Republic of Indonesia (Pemerintah Darurat Republik Indonesia, PDRI) in West Sumatra.

Seven Japanese military and political leaders convicted of war crimes by the International Military Tribunal for the Far East are executed by Allied occupation authorities at Sugamo Prison in Tokyo, Japan.
Cardinal József Mindszenty is arrested in Hungary and accused of treason and conspiracy.
The last Soviet troops withdraw from North Korea.
The DC-3 airliner NC16002 disappears 80 kilometres (50 mi) south of Miami.
United Nations cease-fire takes effect in Kashmir from one minute before midnight. War between India and Pakistan stops accordingly.
Luis Muñoz Marín is inaugurated as the first democratically elected Governor of Puerto Rico.
The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the central bank of the Philippines, is established.
In his State of the Union address, United States President Harry S. Truman unveils his Fair Deal program.
The first "networked" television broadcasts took place as KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania goes on the air connecting the east coast and mid-west programming.
Chinese Civil War: The Communist forces take over Tianjin from the Nationalist government.
The first Emmy Awards are presented in the United States; the venue is the Hollywood Athletic Club.
The Hale Telescope at Palomar Observatory sees first light under the direction of Edwin Hubble, becoming the largest aperture optical telescope (until BTA-6 is built in 1976).
source_pages: Hale_Telescope; Palomar_Observatory; First_light_(astronomy); Edwin_Hubble; BTA-6; January_26

event_text: These Are My Children, the first television daytime soap opera, is broadcast by the NBC station in Chicago, United States.
The Knesset (parliament of Israel) convenes for the first time.
The Asbestos Strike begins in Canada. The strike marks the beginning of the Quiet Revolution in Quebec.
Gerald Lankester Harding and Roland de Vaux begin excavations at Cave 1 of the Qumran Caves, where they will eventually discover the first seven Dead Sea Scrolls.
Chaim Weizmann begins his term as the first President of Israel.
Ezra Pound is awarded the first Bollingen Prize in poetry by the Bollingen Foundation and Yale University.
The Armistice Agreements are signed, to formally end the hostilities of the 1948 Arab-Israeli War.
Captain James Gallagher lands his B-50 Superfortress Lucky Lady II in Fort Worth, Texas, after completing the first non-stop around-the-world airplane flight in 94 hours and one minute.
Mildred Gillars ("Axis Sally") is convicted of treason.
Hanns Albin Rauter, a chief SS and Police Leader, in the Netherlands, is convicted and executed for crimes against humanity.
More than 92,000 kulaks are suddenly deported from the Baltic states to Siberia.
Cold War: A riot breaks out in Austurvöllur square in Reykjavík, when Iceland joins NATO.
The Dominion of Newfoundland joins the Canadian Confederation and becomes the 10th Province of Canada.
Chinese Civil War: The Chinese Communist Party holds unsuccessful peace talks with the Nationalist Party in Beijing, after three years of fighting.
The Government of Canada repeals Japanese-Canadian internment after seven years.
Cold War: Twelve nations sign the North Atlantic Treaty creating the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
A fire in a hospital in Effingham, Illinois, kills 77 people and leads to nationwide fire code improvements in the United States.
The Republic of Ireland Act comes into force, declaring Éire to be a republic and severing Ireland's "association" with the Commonwealth of Nations.
source_pages: The_Republic_of_Ireland_Act_1948; Éire; Republic; Ireland; Commonwealth_of_Nations; April_18

event_text: Amethyst incident: The People's Liberation Army attacks HMS Amethyst (F116) travelling to the British embassy in Nanjing during the Chinese Civil War.
source_pages: Amethyst_incident; People's_Liberation_Army; HMS_Amethyst_(F116); Nanjing; Chinese_Civil_War; April_20

event_text: Chinese Civil War: Establishment of the People's Liberation Army Navy.

The Hukbalahap are accused of assassinating former First Lady of the Philippines Aurora Quezon, while she is en route to dedicate a hospital in memory of her late husband; her daughter and ten others are also killed.
The entire Torino football team (except for two players who did not take the trip: Sauro Tomà, due to an injury and Renato Gandolfi, because of coach request) is killed in a plane crash.
EDSAC, the first practical electronic digital stored-program computer, runs its first operation.
Cold War: The Soviet Union lifts its blockade of Berlin.
Aeroflot Flight 17 crashes on approach to Severny Airport in Novosibirsk, killing 25.
In the United States, the Armed Forces Security Agency, the predecessor to the National Security Agency, is established.
Cold War: The Western occupying powers approve the Basic Law and establish a new German state, the Federal Republic of Germany.
Thailand elects Orapin Chaiyakan, the first female member of Thailand's Parliament.
George Orwell's dystopian novel Nineteen Eighty-Four is published in the United States
Albert II, a rhesus monkey, rides a V-2 rocket to an altitude of 134 km (83 mi), thereby becoming the first mammal and first monkey in space.
The first television western, Hopalong Cassidy, starring William Boyd, is aired on NBC.

The merger of two princely states of India, Cochin and Travancore, into the state of Thiru-Kochi (later re-organized as Kerala) in the Indian Union ends more than 1,000 years of princely rule by the Cochin royal family.
The Israel–Syria Mixed Armistice Commission brokers the last of four ceasefire agreements to end the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
The United States Senate ratifies the North Atlantic Treaty.
Initial flight of the de Havilland Comet, the first jet-powered airliner.
The Basketball Association of America and the National Basketball League finalize the merger that would create the National Basketball Association.
In Ecuador, an earthquake destroys 50 towns and kills more than 6,000.
In Montana, 12 smokejumper firefighters and 1 US Forest Service fire guard are killed in the Mann Gulch Fire.

An amendment to the National Security Act of 1947 enhances the authority of the United States Secretary of Defense over the Army, Navy and Air Force, and replaces the National Military Establishment with the Department of Defense.
The 6.7 Ms  Karlıova earthquake shakes eastern Turkey with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme), leaving 320–450 dead.

Matsukawa derailment: Unknown saboteurs cause a passenger train to derail and overturn in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan, killing three crew members and igniting a political firestorm between the Japanese Communist Party and the government of Occupied Japan that will eventually lead to the Japanese Red Purge.
source_pages: Matsukawa_derailment; Tōhoku_Main_Line; Fukushima_Prefecture; Japanese_Communist_Party; Occupation_of_Japan; Red_Purge; August_17

event_text: 1949 Kemi strike: Two protesters die in the scuffle between the police and the strikers' protest procession in Kemi, Finland.
Hungary adopts the Hungarian Constitution of 1949 and becomes a People's Republic.
The Queen Charlotte earthquake is Canada's strongest since the 1700 Cascadia earthquake.
The treaty creating the North Atlantic Treaty Organization goes into effect.
Soviet atomic bomb project: The Soviet Union tests its first atomic bomb, known as First Lightning or Joe 1, at Semipalatinsk, Kazakhstan.
The retreat of the Democratic Army of Greece into Albania after its defeat on Gramos mountain marks the end of the Greek Civil War.
Paul Robeson performs a second concert in Peekskill, New York eight days after the Peekskill riots.
The Canadian steamship SS Noronic burns in Toronto Harbour with the loss of over 118 lives.
Zeng Liansong's design is chosen as the flag of the People's Republic of China.
The Berlin Airlift ends.
The People's Republic of China is established.
WERD, the first black-owned radio station in the United States, opens in Atlanta.
The communist German Democratic Republic (East Germany) is formed.
The Smith Act trials of Communist Party leaders in the United States convicts eleven defendants of conspiring to advocate the violent overthrow of the federal government.
The Greek Communist Party announces a "temporary cease-fire", thus ending the Greek Civil War.
The cornerstone of the United Nations Headquarters is laid.
The Battle of Guningtou in the Taiwan Strait begins.
An Air France Lockheed Constellation crashes in the Azores, killing all 48 people on board.

All 55 people on board Eastern Air Lines Flight 537 are killed when the Douglas DC-4 operating the flight collides in mid-air with a Bolivian Air Force Lockheed P-38 Lightning aircraft over Alexandria, Virginia.
source_pages: Eastern_Air_Lines_Flight_537; Douglas_DC-4; Mid-air_collision; Bolivian_Air_Force; Lockheed_P-38_Lightning; Alexandria,_Virginia; November_1

event_text: The Dutch–Indonesian Round Table Conference ends with the Netherlands agreeing to transfer sovereignty of the Dutch East Indies to the United States of Indonesia.
Chinese Civil War: The Battle of Dengbu Island occurs.
The first oil was taken in Oil Rocks (Neft Daşları), the world's oldest offshore oil platform.
The People's Liberation Army Air Force is founded.

The Iva Valley Shooting occurs after the coal miners of Enugu in Nigeria go on strike over withheld wages; 21 miners are shot dead and 51 are wounded by police under the supervision of the British colonial administration of Nigeria.
The Constituent Assembly of India adopts the constitution presented by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar.
Convention for the Suppression of the Traffic in Persons and of the Exploitation of the Prostitution of Others is adopted.
Sir Duncan George Stewart, governor of the Crown Colony of Sarawak, was fatally stabbed by a member of the Rukun 13.
Chinese Civil War: The Government of the Republic of China moves from Nanjing to Taipei, Taiwan.

Chinese Civil War: The People's Liberation Army begins its siege of Chengdu, the last Kuomintang-held city in mainland China, forcing President of the Republic of China Chiang Kai-shek and his government to retreat to Taiwan.
source_pages: Chinese_Civil_War; People's_Liberation_Army; Chengdu; Kuomintang; Mainland_China; President_of_the_Republic_of_China; Chiang_Kai-shek; Taiwan

event_text: The Knesset votes to move the capital of Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
Indonesian National Revolution: The Netherlands officially recognizes Indonesian independence. End of the Dutch East Indies.
The United Kingdom recognizes the People's Republic of China. The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the UK in response.

In the Sverdlovsk air disaster, all 19 of those on board are killed, including almost the entire national ice hockey team (VVS Moscow) of the Soviet Air Force – 11 players, as well as a team doctor and a masseur.
British submarine HMS Truculent collides with an oil tanker in the Thames Estuary, killing 64 men.
Finland forms diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.
The Great Brink's Robbery: Eleven thieves steal more than $2 million from an armored car company's offices in Boston.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 79 relating to arms control is adopted.
American lawyer and government official Alger Hiss is convicted of perjury.
The Knesset resolves that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel.
The Constitution of India comes into force, forming a republic. Rajendra Prasad is sworn in as the first President of India. Observed as Republic Day in India.
source_pages: Constitution_of_India; Entry_into_force; Rajendra_Prasad; President_of_India; Republic_Day_(India); January_26

event_text: The first prototype of the MiG-17 makes its maiden flight.
The Stasi, the secret police of East Germany, is established.
Second Red Scare: US Senator Joseph McCarthy accuses the United States Department of State of being filled with Communists.
source_pages: McCarthyism; United_States_Senate; Joseph_McCarthy; United_States_Department_of_State; Communism; February_9

event_text: Cold War: Klaus Fuchs is convicted of spying for the Soviet Union by disclosing top secret atomic bomb data.
The iconic Volkswagen Type 2 "Bus" begins production.
The Llandow air disaster kills 80 people when the aircraft they are travelling in crashes near Sigingstone, Wales. At the time this was the world's deadliest air disaster.
Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley announce the creation of element 98, which they name "californium".
The Nainital wedding massacre occurs, killing 22 members of the Harijan caste.
The Tollund Man was discovered in a peat bog near Silkeborg, Denmark.
Robert Schuman presents the "Schuman Declaration", considered by some to be the beginning of the creation of what is now the European Union.
The inaugural Formula One World Championship race takes place at Silverstone Circuit. The race was won by Giuseppe Farina, who would go on to become the inaugural champion that year.
A barge containing munitions destined for Pakistan explodes in the harbor at South Amboy, New Jersey, devastating the city.
Egypt announces that the Suez Canal is closed to Israeli ships and commerce.
The Linnanmäki amusement park is opened for the first time in Helsinki.
The St. Roch, the first ship to circumnavigate North America, arrives in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada.
The Declaration of Conscience speech, by U.S. Senator from Maine, Margaret Chase Smith, is delivered in response to Joseph R. McCarthy's speech at Wheeling, West Virginia.
source_pages: Declaration_of_Conscience; Maine; Margaret_Chase_Smith; Joseph_McCarthy; Wheeling,_West_Virginia; June_1

event_text: The Chinchaga fire ignites. By September, it would become the largest single fire on record in North America.
Herzog and Lachenal of the French Annapurna expedition become the first climbers to reach the summit of an 8,000-metre peak.
An Air France Douglas DC-4 crashes near Bahrain International Airport, killing 46 people.
An Air France Douglas DC-4 crashes near Bahrain International Airport, killing 40 people. This came two days after another Air France DC-4 crashed in the same location.
Apartheid: In South Africa, the Group Areas Act is passed, formally segregating races.
The Korean War begins with the invasion of South Korea by North Korea.
The United States decides to send troops to fight in the Korean War.
Korean War: Suspected communist sympathizers (between 60,000 and 200,000) are executed in the Bodo League massacre.

Korean War: Packed with its own refugees fleeing Seoul and leaving their 5th Division stranded, South Korean forces blow up the Hangang Bridge in an attempt to slow North Korea's offensive. The city falls later that day.
Korean War: The Korean People's Army kills almost a thousand doctors, nurses, inpatient civilians and wounded soldiers in the Seoul National University Hospital massacre.
Korean War: U.S. President Harry S. Truman authorizes a sea blockade of Korea.
Cold War: Radio Free Europe first broadcasts.
Korean War: Task Force Smith: American and North Korean forces first clash, in the Battle of Osan.
The Knesset of Israel passes the Law of Return which grants all Jews the right to immigrate to the Land of Israel.
Pakistan joins the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank.
Korean War: beginning of the Battle of Taejon.
Chaplain–Medic massacre: American POWs are massacred by North Korean Army.
Uruguay beats hosts Brazil 2–1 to win the World Cup in a match dubbed as the Maracanazo.
Cold War: In Philadelphia, Harry Gold pleads guilty to spying for the Soviet Union by passing secrets from atomic scientist Klaus Fuchs.
After a month-long campaign, the majority of North Korea's Air Force was destroyed by anti-communist forces.
Cape Canaveral Air Force Station begins operations with the launch of a Bumper rocket.
Korean War: After four days, the No Gun Ri Massacre ends when the US Army 7th Cavalry Regiment is withdrawn.
Guam is organized as an unincorporated territory of the United States as the President Harry S. Truman signs the Guam Organic Act.
Korean War: Bloody Gulch massacre: Seventy-five American POWs are massacred by the North Korean Army.
Measuring Mw 8.6, the largest earthquake on land occurs in the Assam-Tibet-Myanmar border, killing 4,800.
Julien Lahaut, the chairman of the Communist Party of Belgium, is assassinated. The Party newspaper blames royalists and Rexists.
Edith Sampson becomes the first black U.S. delegate to the United Nations.
To avert a threatened strike during the Korean War, President Truman orders Secretary of the Army Frank Pace to seize control of the nation's railroads.
Korean War: British Commonwealth Forces Korea arrives to bolster the US presence.
TWA Flight 903 crashes near Itay El Barud, Egypt, killing all 55 aboard.
"Nino" Farina becomes the first Formula One Drivers' champion after winning the 1950 Italian Grand Prix.
Darlington Raceway is the site of the inaugural Southern 500, the first 500-mile NASCAR race.
Korean War: The U.S. X Corps lands at Inchon.
The People's Liberation Army Air Force Airborne Corps (Then known as the PLAAF 1st Ground Forces Brigade) is founded.
Korean War: An attack by North Korean forces was repelled at the Battle of Nam River.
Korean War: The Battle of Hill 282 is the first US friendly-fire incident on British military personnel since World War II.
The eastern United States is covered by a thick haze from the Chinchaga fire in western Canada.
Korean War: United Nations troops recapture Seoul from North Korean forces.
Mother Teresa establishes the Missionaries of Charity.
The Goyang Geumjeong Cave massacre in Korea begins.
CBS's field-sequential color system for television is the first to be licensed for broadcast by the U.S. Federal Communications Commission.
China defeats the Tibetan Army at Chambo.
Korean War: The Battle of Pyongyang ends in a United Nations victory. Hours later, the Chinese Army begins crossing the border into Korea.
Iran becomes the first country to accept technical assistance from the United States under the Point Four Program.
Korean War: Heavy fighting begins between British and Australian forces and North Koreans during the Battle of Yongju.
Annexation of Tibet by the People's Republic of China: The People’s Liberation Army ceases all military operations in Tibet, ending the Battle of Chamdo.
Puerto Rican nationalists Griselio Torresola and Oscar Collazo attempt to assassinate US President Harry S. Truman at Blair House.
Air India Flight 245 crashes into Mont Blanc while on approach to Geneva Airport, killing all 48 people on board.
Korean War: British and Australian forces from the 27th British Commonwealth Brigade successfully halted the advancing Chinese 117th Division during the Battle of Pakchon.
Korean War: United States Air Force Lt. Russell J. Brown, while piloting an F-80 Shooting Star, shoots down two North Korean MiG-15s in the first jet aircraft-to-jet aircraft dogfight in history.
source_pages: Korean_War; United_States_Air_Force; Lockheed_P-80_Shooting_Star; North_Korea; Mikoyan-Gurevich_MiG-15; Jet_aircraft; Dogfight

event_text: General Carlos Delgado Chalbaud, President of Venezuela, is assassinated in Caracas.
Lhamo Dondrub is officially named the 14th Dalai Lama.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 89 relating to the Palestine Question is adopted.
US General Dwight D. Eisenhower becomes Supreme Commander of NATO-Europe.
Two Canadian National Railway trains collide in northeastern British Columbia in the Canoe River train crash; the death toll is 21, with 17 of them Canadian troops bound for Korea.
The Great Appalachian Storm of 1950 impacts 22 American states, killing 353 people, injuring over 160, and causing US$66.7 million in damages (1950 dollars).
Korean War: Communist Chinese troops launch a massive counterattack (Battle of the Ch'ongch'on River and Battle of Chosin Reservoir) against United Nations and South Korean forces.
Korean War: The Battle of the Ch'ongch'on River ends with a decisive Chinese victory and UN forces are completely expelled from North Korea.
Korean War: Jesse L. Brown (the 1st African-American Naval aviator) is killed in action during the Battle of Chosin Reservoir.

Korean War: Associated Press photographer Max Desfor photographs hundreds of Korean refugees crossing a downed bridge in the Taedong River: 1951 Pulitzer Prize winner Flight of Refugees Across Wrecked Bridge in Korea.

Cold War: Harry Gold is sentenced to 30 years in jail for helping Klaus Fuchs pass information about the Manhattan Project to the Soviet Union. His testimony is later instrumental in the prosecution of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg.
source_pages: Cold_War; Harry_Gold; Klaus_Fuchs; Manhattan_Project; Soviet_Union; Julius_and_Ethel_Rosenberg

event_text: The F-86 Sabre's first mission over Korea.
General Walton Walker dies in a jeep accident and is replaced by General Matthew Ridgway in the Eighth United States Army.
The Stone of Scone, traditional coronation stone of British monarchs, is taken from Westminster Abbey by Scottish nationalist students. It later turns up in Scotland on April 11, 1951.
Korean War: Chinese and North Korean forces capture Seoul for the second time.
Korean War: Beginning of the Ganghwa massacre, in the course of which an estimated 200–1,300 South Korean communist sympathizers are slaughtered.
First Indochina War: The Battle of Vĩnh Yên begins.
National Airlines Flight 83 crashes during landing at Philadelphia International Airport, killing seven passengers and crew.
The catastrophic eruption of Mount Lamington in Papua New Guinea claims 2,942 lives.
Nuclear testing at the Nevada Test Site begins with Operation Ranger.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 90 relating to the Korean War is adopted.
The Canadian Army enters combat in the Korean War.

The Broker, a Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train derails near Woodbridge Township, New Jersey. The accident kills 85 people and injures over 500 more. The wreck is one of the worst rail disasters in American history.
Korean War: More than 700 suspected communist sympathizers are massacred by South Korean forces.
Korean War: The two-day Geochang massacre begins as a battalion of the 11th Division of the South Korean Army kills 719 unarmed citizens in Geochang, in the South Gyeongsang district of South Korea.
source_pages: Korean_War; Geochang_massacre; Republic_of_Korea_Army; Geochang_County; South_Gyeongsang_Province; South_Korea

event_text: Korean War: Battle of Chipyong-ni, which represented the "high-water mark" of the Chinese incursion into South Korea, commences.
The first Pan American Games are officially opened in Buenos Aires by Argentine President Juan Perón.
The Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution, limiting Presidents to two terms, is ratified.
Cold War: The trial of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg begins.
Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 307 crashes in Lynnhurst, Minneapolis, killing 15 people.
Korean War: Operation Ripper: United Nations troops led by General Matthew Ridgway begin an assault against Chinese forces.
source_pages: Korean_War; Operation_Ripper; United_Nations; General_officer; Matthew_Ridgway; March_7

event_text: Iranian prime minister Ali Razmara is assassinated by Khalil Tahmasebi, a member of the Islamic fundamentalist Fada'iyan-e Islam, outside a mosque in Tehran.
Korean War: United Nations troops recapture Seoul for the second time.
Iranian oil industry is nationalized.
Fujiyoshida, a city located in Yamanashi Prefecture, Japan, in the center of the Japanese main island of Honshū is founded.
Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage.
Hypnosis murders in Copenhagen.
Remington Rand delivers the first UNIVAC I computer to the United States Census Bureau.
Cold War: Ethel and Julius Rosenberg are sentenced to death for spying for the Soviet Union.
Korean War: President Truman relieves Douglas MacArthur of the command of American forces in Korea and Japan.

The Stone of Scone, the stone upon which Scottish monarchs were traditionally crowned, is found on the site of the altar of Arbroath Abbey. It had been taken by Scottish nationalist students from its place in Westminster Abbey.
The Peak District becomes the United Kingdom's first National Park.
Korean War: The Chinese People's Volunteer Army begin assaulting positions defended by the Royal Australian Regiment and the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry at the Battle of Kapyong.
Cold War: American journalist William N. Oatis is arrested for espionage by the Communist government of Czechoslovakia.
Korean War: Assaulting Chinese forces are forced to withdraw after heavy fighting with UN forces, primarily made up of Australian and Canadian troops, at the Battle of Kapyong.
London's Royal Festival Hall opens with the Festival of Britain.

The United States Senate Committee on Armed Services and United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations begin their closed door hearings into the relief of Douglas MacArthur by U.S. President Harry Truman.
The 400th anniversary of the founding of the National University of San Marcos is commemorated by the opening of the first large-capacity stadium in Peru.
Trains run on the Talyllyn Railway in Wales for the first time since preservation, making it the first railway in the world to be operated by volunteers.

The first regularly scheduled transatlantic flights begin between Idlewild Airport (now John F Kennedy International Airport) in New York City and Heathrow Airport in London, operated by El Al Israel Airlines.

The opening of the Ninth Street Show, otherwise known as the 9th Street Art Exhibition: A gathering of a number of notable artists, and the stepping-out of the post war New York avant-garde, collectively known as the New York School.
Tibetans sign the Seventeen Point Agreement with China.
The Uniform Code of Military Justice takes effect as the legal system of the United States Armed Forces.
UNIVAC I is dedicated by the U.S. Census Bureau.
The ocean liner SS United States is christened and launched.
Cold War: A court in Czechoslovakia sentences American journalist William N. Oatis to ten years in prison on charges of espionage.
William Shockley announces the invention of the junction transistor.
Korean War: Armistice negotiations begin at Kaesong.
Vuoristorata, one of the oldest still-operating wooden roller coasters in Europe, is opened at the Linnanmäki amusement park in Helsinki, Finland.
Ferrari take their first Formula One grand prix victory at the British Grand Prix at Silverstone.
King Leopold III of Belgium abdicates in favor of his son, Baudouin of Belgium.
J. D. Salinger publishes his popular yet controversial novel, The Catcher in the Rye.
King Abdullah I of Jordan is assassinated by a Palestinian while attending Friday prayers in Jerusalem.
Canadian Pacific Air Lines Flight 3505 disappears while flying from Vancouver to Tokyo. The aircraft and its 37 occupants are never found.
Soviet space dogs: Dezik and Tsygan were launched into a sub-orbital spaceflight from Kapustin Yar and became the first dogs to fly in space and the first to safely return.
Walt Disney's 13th animated film, Alice in Wonderland, premieres in London, England, United Kingdom.
United Air Lines Flight 615 crashes near Decoto, California, killing 50 people.
The first live transcontinental television broadcast takes place in San Francisco, United States, from the Japanese Peace Treaty Conference.
George VI, king of the United Kingdom, has his left lung removed in an operation after a malignant tumour was found.
CBS makes the first color televisions available for sale to the general public, but the product is discontinued less than a month later.
Korean War: The First Battle of Maryang San pits Commonwealth troops against communist Chinese troops.
Mexican chemist Luis E. Miramontes completes the synthesis of norethisterone, the basis of an early oral contraceptive.
The first Prime Minister of Pakistan, Liaquat Ali Khan, is assassinated in Rawalpindi.
The "Johnny Bright incident" occurs during a football game between the Drake Bulldogs and Oklahoma A&M Aggies.
Operation Buster–Jangle: Six thousand five hundred United States Army soldiers are exposed to 'Desert Rock' atomic explosions for training purposes in Nevada. Participation is not voluntary.

Canada in the Korean War: A platoon of The Royal Canadian Regiment defends a vital area against a full battalion of Chinese troops in the Battle of the Song-gok Spur. The engagement lasts into the early hours the next day.
With the rollout of the North American Numbering Plan, direct-dial coast-to-coast telephone service begins in the United States.
Nikos Beloyannis, along with 11 comrades, is sentenced to death for attempting to reestablish the Communist Party of Greece.
A Miami Airlines Curtiss C-46 Commando crashes in Elizabeth, New Jersey, killing all 58 aboard including dancer Doris Ruby.
The American Civil Rights Congress delivers "We Charge Genocide" to the United Nations.
The EBR-1 in Arco, Idaho becomes the first nuclear power plant to generate electricity. The electricity powered four light bulbs.
Libya becomes independent. Idris I is proclaimed King of Libya.
A bomb explodes at the home of Harry T. Moore and Harriette V. S. Moore, early leaders of the Civil Rights Movement, killing Harry instantly and fatally wounding Harriette.
Cold War: The Marshall Plan expires after distributing more than US$13.3 billion in foreign aid to rebuild Western Europe.
NBC's long-running morning news program Today debuts, with host Dave Garroway.
Black Saturday in Egypt: rioters burn Cairo's central business district, targeting British and upper-class Egyptian businesses.

Elizabeth II becomes Queen of the United Kingdom and her other Realms and Territories and Head of the Commonwealth upon the death of her father, George VI. At the exact moment of succession, she was in a tree house at the Treetops Hotel in Kenya.
source_pages: Elizabeth_II; Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom; Head_of_the_Commonwealth; George_VI; Order_of_succession; Tree_house; Treetops_Hotel; Kenya; February_6

event_text: King George VI of the United Kingdom is buried in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.
Emmett Ashford becomes the first African-American umpire in organized baseball by being authorized to be a substitute umpire in the Southwestern International League.
The British government, under Winston Churchill, abolishes identity cards in the UK to "set the people free".
The Bengali Language Movement protests occur at the University of Dhaka in East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).
Vincent Massey is sworn in as the first Canadian-born Governor General of Canada.
Fulgencio Batista leads a successful coup in Cuba.
The US Senate ratifies the Security Treaty Between the United States and Japan.
Alan Freed presents the Moondog Coronation Ball, the first rock and roll concert, in Cleveland, Ohio.
Hugo Ballivián's government is overthrown by the Bolivian National Revolution, starting a period of agrarian reform, universal suffrage and the nationalization of tin mines
Japan Air Lines Flight 301 crashes into Mount Mihara, Izu Ōshima, Japan, killing 37.
Bolivian National Revolution: Rebels take over Palacio Quemado.
Pan Am Flight 526A ditches near San Juan-Isla Grande Airport in San Juan, Puerto Rico, after experiencing an engine failure, killing 52 people.
First flight of the Boeing B-52 Stratofortress.
Secretary's Day (now Administrative Professionals' Day) is first celebrated.
Dwight D. Eisenhower resigns as Supreme Allied Commander of NATO in order to campaign in the 1952 United States presidential election.
The Treaty of San Francisco comes into effect, restoring Japanese sovereignty and ending its state of war with most of the Allies of World War II.
The Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty (Treaty of Taipei) is signed in Taipei, Taiwan between Japan and the Republic of China to officially end the Second Sino-Japanese War.
Pan Am Flight 202 crashes into the Amazon basin near Carolina, Maranhão, Brazil, killing 50 people.
A De Havilland Comet makes the first jetliner flight with fare-paying passengers, from London to Johannesburg.
Lieutenant Colonels Joseph O. Fletcher and William P. Benedict of the United States land a plane at the North Pole.
The Kentucky Derby is televised nationally for the first time, on the CBS network.
The concept of the integrated circuit, the basis for all modern computers, is first published by Geoffrey Dummer.
The Rajya Sabha, the upper house of the Parliament of India, holds its first sitting.
Catalina affair: A Swedish Douglas DC-3 is shot down by a Soviet MiG-15 fighter.
Guatemala passes Decree 900, ordering the redistribution of uncultivated land.
The Philippine School of Commerce, through a republic act, is converted to Philippine College of Commerce, later to be the Polytechnic University of the Philippines.
The Pan-Malayan Labour Party is founded in Malaya, as a union of statewide labour parties.
The first Miss Universe pageant is held. Armi Kuusela from Finland wins the title of Miss Universe 1952.
The Constitution of Puerto Rico is approved by the United States Congress.
The SS United States sets sail on her maiden voyage to Southampton. During the voyage, the ship takes the Blue Riband away from the RMS Queen Mary.
The ocean liner SS United States passes Bishop Rock on her maiden voyage, breaking the transatlantic speed record to become the fastest passenger ship in the world.
Opening of the Summer Olympics in Helsinki, Finland.
The 7.3 Mw  Kern County earthquake strikes Southern California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing 12 and injuring hundreds.
General Muhammad Naguib leads the Free Officers Movement (formed by Gamal Abdel Nasser, the real power behind the coup) in overthrowing King Farouk of Egypt.
King Farouk of Egypt abdicates in favor of his son Fuad.
Hussein bin Talal is proclaimed King of Jordan.
The Night of the Murdered Poets: Thirteen prominent Jewish intellectuals are murdered in Moscow, Russia, Soviet Union.
A flash flood drenches the town of Lynmouth, England, killing 34 people.
American experimental composer John Cage's 4’33” premieres at Maverick Concert Hall, played by American pianist David Tudor.
source_pages: Experimental_music; John_Cage; 4′33″; Maverick_Concert_Hall; Americans; David_Tudor; August_29

event_text: A prototype aircraft crashes at the Farnborough Airshow in Hampshire, England, killing 29 spectators and the two on board.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation makes its first televised broadcast on the second escape of the Boyd Gang.
The United Nations cedes Eritrea to Ethiopia.

After being accused of financial improprieties, Senator Richard Nixon delivers his "Checkers speech" nationwide on television and radio, defending his actions and successfully salvaging his nomination as the Republican candidate for Vice President.
The United Kingdom successfully tests a nuclear weapon in the Montebello Islands, Western Australia, to become the world's third nuclear power.
The Harrow and Wealdstone rail crash kills 112 people.
Korean War: The Battle of Triangle Hill is the biggest and bloodiest battle of 1952.
Indonesian Army elements surrounded the Merdeka Palace demanding President Sukarno disband the Provisional People's Representative Council.
The Governor of Kenya Evelyn Baring declares a state of emergency and begins arresting hundreds of suspected leaders of the Mau Mau Uprising.
Nuclear weapons testing: The United States successfully detonates Ivy Mike, the first thermonuclear device, at the Eniwetok atoll. The explosion had a yield of ten megatons TNT equivalent.
source_pages: Nuclear_weapons_testing; Ivy_Mike; Thermonuclear_weapon; Enewetak_Atoll; TNT_equivalent; November_1

event_text: The United States government establishes the National Security Agency, or NSA.
The New Musical Express publishes the first regular UK Singles Chart.
Greek Field Marshal Alexander Papagos becomes the 152nd Prime Minister of Greece.
A Douglas C-124 Globemaster II crashes into Mount Gannet, Alaska, killing all 52 aboard.

Agatha Christie's murder-mystery play The Mousetrap opens at the Ambassadors Theatre in London's West End after a premiere in Nottingham, UK.  It will become the longest continuously running play in history.
Korean War: After 42 days of fighting, the Battle of Triangle Hill ends in a Chinese victory. American and South Korean units abandon their attempt to capture the "Iron Triangle".
U.S. President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower fulfills a campaign promise by traveling to Korea to find out what can be done to end the conflict.
The New York Daily News reports the news of Christine Jorgensen, the first notable case of sex reassignment surgery.

Beginning of the Great Smog in London. A cold fog combines with air pollution and brings the city to a standstill for four days. Later, a Ministry of Health report estimates 4,000 fatalities as a result of it.
A United States Air Force C-124 crashes and burns in Moses Lake, Washington, killing 87 of the 115 people on board.
First flight of Britain's Handley Page Victor strategic bomber.
An RAF Avro Lancaster bomber crashes in Luqa, Malta after an engine failure, killing three crew members and a civilian on the ground.
Frances P. Bolton and her son, Oliver from Ohio, become the first mother and son to serve simultaneously in the U.S. Congress.
The play Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett receives its première in Paris.

An article appears in Pravda accusing some of the most prestigious and prominent doctors, mostly Jews, in the Soviet Union of taking part in a vast plot to poison members of the top Soviet political and military leadership.
Josip Broz Tito is elected the first President of Yugoslavia.
Almost 72 percent of all television sets in the United States are tuned into I Love Lucy to watch Lucy give birth.

Dwight D. Eisenhower is inaugurated as the 34th President of the United States of America, becoming the first president to begin his presidency on January 20 since the 20th Amendment changed the dates of presidential terms.
A North Sea flood causes over 1,800 deaths in the Netherlands and over 300 in the United Kingdom.
The Batepá massacre occurred in São Tomé when the colonial administration and Portuguese landowners unleashed a wave of violence against the native creoles known as forros.
Cold War: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower denies all appeals for clemency for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg.
Israeli-Soviet relations are severed.
Book censorship in the United States: The Georgia Literature Commission is established.
Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin suffers a stroke and collapses; he dies four days later.
A De Havilland Comet (Canadian Pacific Air Lines) crashes in Karachi, Pakistan, killing 11 people.
Joseph Stalin, the longest serving leader of the Soviet Union, dies at his Volynskoe dacha in Moscow after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage four days earlier.
Georgy Malenkov succeeds Joseph Stalin as Premier of the Soviet Union and First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
An earthquake hits western Turkey, killing at least 1,070 people.
CIA director Allen Dulles launches the mind-control program Project MKUltra.
Winston Churchill is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
Francis Crick and James Watson publish "Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid" describing the double helix structure of DNA.
Operation Moolah offers $50,000 to any pilot who defects with a fully mission-capable Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15 to South Korea. The first pilot was to receive $100,000.
The first U.S. experimental 3D television broadcast shows an episode of Space Patrol on Los Angeles ABC affiliate KECA-TV.

Two men are rescued from a semitrailer that crashed over the side of the Pit River Bridge before it fell into the Sacramento River. Amateur photographer Virginia Schau photographs "Rescue on Pit River Bridge", the first and only winning submission for the Pulitzer Prize for Photography to have been taken by a woman.
source_pages: Semi-trailer; Pit_River_Bridge; Sacramento_River; Virginia_Schau; Pulitzer_Prize_for_Photography; May_3

event_text: Ernest Hemingway wins the Pulitzer Prize for The Old Man and the Sea.
Approximately 7,100 brewery workers in Milwaukee perform a walkout, marking the start of the 1953 Milwaukee brewery strike.
Delta Air Lines Flight 318 crashes near Marshall, Texas, killing 19.
Jacqueline Cochran becomes the first woman to break the sound barrier.
Nuclear weapons testing: At the Nevada Test Site, the United States conducts its first and only nuclear artillery test.
The first public television station in the United States officially begins broadcasting as KUHT from the campus of the University of Houston.
Edmund Hillary and Sherpa Tenzing Norgay become the first people to reach the summit of Mount Everest, on Tenzing Norgay's (adopted) 39th birthday.
The coronation of Queen Elizabeth II at Westminster Abbey becomes the first British coronation and one of the first major international events to be televised.
An F5 tornado hits Beecher, Michigan, United States, killing 116, injuring 844, and destroying 340 homes.
The United States Supreme Court rules in District of Columbia v. John R. Thompson Co. that restaurants in Washington, D.C., cannot refuse to serve black patrons.
The Flint–Worcester tornado outbreak sequence kills 94 people in Massachusetts.
Cold War: East Germany Workers Uprising: In East Germany, the Soviet Union orders a division of troops into East Berlin to quell a rebellion.
The Egyptian revolution of 1952 ends with the overthrow of the Muhammad Ali dynasty and the declaration of the Republic of Egypt.
A United States Air Force C-124 crashes and burns near Tachikawa, Japan, killing 129.
Cold War: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are executed at Sing Sing, in New York.
Lavrentiy Beria, head of MVD, is arrested by Nikita Khrushchev and other members of the Politburo.
The first Chevrolet Corvette rolls off the assembly line in Flint, Michigan.
Ernesto "Che" Guevara sets out on a trip through Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Honduras, and El Salvador.
source_pages: Che_Guevara; Bolivia; Peru; Ecuador; Panama; Costa_Rica; Nicaragua; Honduras; El_Salvador

event_text: The largest number of United States midshipman casualties in a single event results from an aircraft crash in Florida, killing 44.
Cold War: Fidel Castro leads an unsuccessful attack on the Moncada Barracks, thus beginning the Cuban Revolution. The movement took the name of the date: 26th of July Movement
Arizona Governor John Howard Pyle orders an anti-polygamy law enforcement crackdown on residents of Short Creek, Arizona, which becomes known as the Short Creek raid.

Soldiers from the 2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment repel a number of Chinese assaults against a key position known as The Hook during the Battle of the Samichon River, just hours before the Armistice Agreement is signed, ending the Korean War.

Cessation of hostilities is achieved in the Korean War when the United States, China, and North Korea sign an armistice agreement. Syngman Rhee, President of South Korea, refuses to sign but pledges to observe the armistice.
First Indochina War: The French Union withdraws its forces from Operation Camargue against the Viet Minh in central Vietnam.
First thermonuclear bomb test: The Soviet atomic bomb project continues with the detonation of "RDS-6s" (Joe 4) using a "layered" scheme.
The 7.2 Ms  Ionian earthquake shakes the southern Ionian Islands with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). Between 445 and 800 people are killed.
First meeting of Narcotics Anonymous takes place, in Southern California.
Cold War: The CIA and MI6 help to overthrow the government of Mohammad Mosaddegh in Iran and reinstate the Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi.
source_pages: Cold_War; Central_Intelligence_Agency; MI6; 1953_Iranian_coup_d'état; Mohammad_Mosaddegh; Shah; Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi

event_text: The penal colony on Devil's Island is permanently closed.
Nikita Khrushchev is elected first secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
U.S. Senator and future President John Fitzgerald Kennedy marries Jacqueline Lee Bouvier at St. Mary's Church in Newport, Rhode Island.
Nikita Khrushchev is appointed General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
American Airlines Flight 723 crashes in Colonie, New York, killing 28 people.
Lieutenant No Kum-sok, a North Korean pilot, defects to South Korea with his jet fighter.
The Four Level Interchange, first stack interchange in the world opened in Los Angeles.
Rationing of sugar in the United Kingdom ends.
Andhra State is formed, consisting of a Telugu-speaking area carved out of India's Madras State.
A United States-South Korea mutual defense treaty is concluded in Washington, D.C.

Cuban revolutionary Fidel Castro delivers his "History Will Absolve Me" speech, and is sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment by the Fulgencio Batista government for leading an attack on the Moncada Barracks.
source_pages: Cuba; Fidel_Castro; History_Will_Absolve_Me; Fulgencio_Batista; Attack_on_the_Moncada_Barracks; October_16

event_text: Ray Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451 is published.
BCPA Flight 304 DC-6 crashes near San Francisco.
President Eisenhower approves the top-secret document NSC 162/2 concerning the maintenance of a strong nuclear deterrent force against the Soviet Union.
Cambodia gains independence from France.
The remaining human inhabitants of the Blasket Islands, County Kerry, Ireland, are evacuated to the mainland.
The Natural History Museum, London announces that the "Piltdown Man" skull, initially believed to be one of the most important fossilized hominid skulls ever found, is a hoax.
Edward Mutesa II, the kabaka (king) of Buganda is deposed and exiled to London by Sir Andrew Cohen, Governor of Uganda.

U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower delivers his "Atoms for Peace" speech, which leads to an American program to supply equipment and information on nuclear power to schools, hospitals, and research institutions around the world.
Red Scare: General Electric announces that all communist employees will be discharged from the company.
British Prime Minister Winston Churchill receives the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Tangiwai disaster: In New Zealand's North Island, at Tangiwai, a railway bridge is damaged by a lahar and collapses beneath a passenger train, killing 151 people.
source_pages: Tangiwai_disaster; New_Zealand; North_Island; Tangiwai; Lahar; December_24

event_text: India establishes its highest civilian awards, the Bharat Ratna and the Padma Vibhushan.
Georgetown–IBM experiment: The first public demonstration of a machine translation system is held in New York at the head office of IBM.
BOAC Flight 781, a de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1, explodes and falls into the Tyrrhenian Sea, killing 35 people.
The Hudson Motor Car Company merges with Nash-Kelvinator Corporation forming the American Motors Corporation.
In the United States, the National Negro Network is established with 40 charter member radio stations.
The first nuclear-powered submarine, the USS Nautilus, is launched in Groton, Connecticut by Mamie Eisenhower, the First Lady of the United States.
source_pages: Nuclear_marine_propulsion; USS_Nautilus_(SSN-571); Ceremonial_ship_launching; Groton,_Connecticut; Mamie_Eisenhower; First_Lady_of_the_United_States

event_text: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower warns against United States intervention in Vietnam.
Frank Selvy becomes the only NCAA Division I basketball player ever to score 100 points in a single game.
First Indochina war - small French garrison at Đắk Đoa is overrun by the Viet Minh after a week's siege.
Canada and the United States agree to construct the Distant Early Warning Line, a system of radar stations in the far northern Arctic regions of Canada and Alaska.
The first Church of Scientology is established in Los Angeles.
Transfer of Crimea: The Soviet Politburo of the Soviet Union orders the transfer of the Crimean Oblast from the Russian SFSR to the Ukrainian SSR.
The first mass inoculation of children against polio with the Salk vaccine begins in Pittsburgh.

Nuclear weapons testing: The Castle Bravo, a 15-megaton hydrogen bomb, is detonated on Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean, resulting in the worst radioactive contamination ever caused by the United States.
source_pages: Nuclear_weapons_testing; Castle_Bravo; TNT_equivalent; Thermonuclear_weapon; Bikini_Atoll; Radioactive_contamination

event_text: Armed Puerto Rican nationalists attack the United States Capitol building, injuring five Representatives.
McCarthyism: CBS television broadcasts the See It Now episode, "A Report on Senator Joseph McCarthy", produced by Fred Friendly.
source_pages: McCarthyism; CBS; See_It_Now; Joseph_McCarthy; Fred_W._Friendly; March_9

event_text: The Battle of Điện Biên Phủ begins with an artillery barrage by Viet Minh forces under Võ Nguyên Giáp; Viet Minh victory led to the end of the First Indochina War and French withdrawal from Vietnam.
Nuclear weapons testing: The Romeo shot of Operation Castle is detonated at Bikini Atoll. Yield: 11 megatons.
United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower authorizes the creation of the United States Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
A 19-month-old infant is swept up in the ocean tides at Hermosa Beach, California. Local photographer John L. Gaunt photographs the incident; 1955 Pulitzer winner "Tragedy by the Sea".
United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower gives his "domino theory" speech during a news conference.
A Royal Canadian Air Force Canadair Harvard collides with a Trans-Canada Airlines Canadair North Star over Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, killing 37 people.
source_pages: North_American_T-6_Texan; Trans-Canada_Air_Lines_Flight_9; Trans-Canada_Air_Lines; Canadair_North_Star; Moose_Jaw; April_8

event_text: South African Airways Flight 201: A de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1 crashes into the sea during night killing 21 people.
Gamal Abdel Nasser seizes power in Egypt.
Red Scare: Witnesses begin testifying and live television coverage of the Army–McCarthy hearings begins.
The first practical solar cell is publicly demonstrated by Bell Telephone Laboratories.
The Geneva Conference, an effort to restore peace in Indochina and Korea, begins.
The first clinical trials of Jonas Salk's polio vaccine begin in Fairfax County, Virginia.
Roger Bannister becomes the first person to run the mile in under four minutes.
Indochina War: The Battle of Dien Bien Phu ends in a French defeat and a Viet Minh victory (the battle began on March 13).
The anti-National Service Riots, by Chinese middle school students in Singapore, take place.
Beginning of the Kengir uprising in the Gulag.
The United States Supreme Court hands down a unanimous decision in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas, outlawing racial segregation in public schools.

Joseph N. Welch, special counsel for the United States Army, lashes out at Senator Joseph McCarthy during the Army–McCarthy hearings, giving McCarthy the famous rebuke, "You've done enough. Have you no sense of decency, sir, at long last? Have you left no sense of decency?"

Pope Pius XII canonises Dominic Savio, who was 14 years old at the time of his death, as a saint, making him at the time the youngest unmartyred saint in the Roman Catholic Church. In 2017, Francisco and Jacinta Marto, aged ten and nine at the time of their deaths, are declared as saints.
source_pages: Pope_Pius_XII; Canonization; Dominic_Savio; Martyr; Catholic_Church; Francisco_and_Jacinta_Marto

event_text: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs a bill into law that places the words "under God" into the United States Pledge of Allegiance.
Carlos Castillo Armas leads an invasion force across the Guatemalan border, setting in motion the 1954 Guatemalan coup d'état.
First Indochina War: Battle of Mang Yang Pass: Viet Minh troops belonging to the 803rd Regiment ambush G.M. 100 of France in An Khê.
The Obninsk Nuclear Power Plant, the Soviet Union's first nuclear power station, opens in Obninsk, near Moscow.
The FIFA World Cup quarterfinal match between Hungary and Brazil, highly anticipated to be exciting, instead turns violent, with three players ejected and further fighting continuing after the game.
Food rationing in Great Britain ends, with the lifting of restrictions on sale and purchase of meat, 14 years after it began early in World War II, and nearly a decade after the war's end.
The BBC broadcasts its first daily television news bulletin.
Elvis Presley records his first single, "That's All Right", at Sun Records in Memphis, Tennessee.
The Boeing 367-80, the prototype for both the Boeing 707 and C-135 series, takes its first flight.
First Indochina War: Viet Minh troops successfully ambush the armoured French column 'G.M. 42' in the Battle of Chu Dreh Pass in the Central Highlands. It is the last battle of the war.
Germany: Otto John, head of West Germany's secret service, defects to East Germany.
First Indochina War: The Geneva Conference partitions Vietnam into North Vietnam and South Vietnam.
At Massena, New York, the groundbreaking ceremony for the Saint Lawrence Seaway is held.
Radio Pakistan broadcasts the "Qaumī Tarāna", the national anthem of Pakistan for the first time.
Alfredo Stroessner begins his dictatorship in Paraguay.
The first issue of Sports Illustrated is published.
The first flight of the Lockheed C-130 multi-role aircraft takes place.
The Cruise of the Kings, a royal cruise organised by the Queen Consort of Greece, Frederica of Hanover, departs from Marseille, France.
The Communist Control Act goes into effect, outlawing the Communist Party in the United States.
Vice president João Café Filho takes office as president of Brazil, following the suicide of Getúlio Vargas.
The People's Liberation Army begins shelling the Republic of China-controlled islands of Quemoy, starting the First Taiwan Strait Crisis.
KLM Flight 633 crashes into the River Shannon in Shannon, County Clare, Ireland, killing 28.
The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established.
The 6.7 Mw  Chlef earthquake shakes northern Algeria with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme). At least 1,243 people were killed and 5,000 were injured.
Hurricane Edna hits New England (United States) as a Category 2 hurricane, causing significant damage and 29 deaths.
In a top secret nuclear test, a Soviet Tu-4 bomber drops a 40 kiloton atomic weapon just north of Totskoye village.
Marilyn Monroe's iconic skirt scene is shot during filming for The Seven Year Itch.
Finnish president J. K. Paasikivi becomes the first Western head of state to be awarded the highest honor of the Soviet Union, the Order of Lenin.
The Moomin comics, created by Tove Jansson and Lars Jansson, is published internationally in the London newspaper The Evening News.
AEC Routemaster, the iconic London bus was introduced.
The Japanese rail ferry Tōya Maru sinks during a typhoon in the Tsugaru Strait, Japan, killing 1,172.
The convention establishing CERN (the European Organization for Nuclear Research) is signed.
The U.S. Navy submarine USS Nautilus is commissioned as the world's first nuclear-powered vessel.

The Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Sultanate of Muscat, Neil Innes, sends a signal to the Sultanate's forces, accompanied with oil explorers, to penetrate Fahud, marking the beginning of Jebel Akhdar War.
In accord with the 1954 Geneva Conference, French troops complete their withdrawal from North Vietnam.
Hurricane Hazel devastates the eastern seaboard of North America, killing 95 and causing massive floods as far north as Toronto.
Texas Instruments announces the Regency TR-1, the first mass-produced transistor radio.
US President Dwight D. Eisenhower pledges United States support to South Vietnam.
Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. becomes the first African-American general in the United States Air Force.
Aeroflot Flight 136 crashes near Krasnoyarsk, killing 19.
The Front de Libération Nationale fires the first shots of the Algerian War of Independence.
U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower dedicates the USMC War Memorial (Iwo Jima memorial) in Arlington Ridge Park in Arlington County, Virginia.
Ellis Island ceases operations.
