Great Britain defeats France to capture the first ever Rugby League World Cup in Paris in front of around 30,000 spectators.
Télé Monte Carlo, Europe's oldest private television channel, is launched by Prince Rainier III.
People's Action Party, an eventual dominative political party in Singapore, was established.
Alger Hiss is released from prison after serving 44 months for perjury.

In Sylacauga, Alabama, United States, the Hodges meteorite crashes through a roof and hits a woman taking an afternoon nap; this is the only documented case in the Western Hemisphere of a human being hit by a rock from space.
Cold War: The United States Senate votes 65 to 22 to censure Joseph McCarthy for "conduct that tends to bring the Senate into dishonor and disrepute".
The Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty, between the United States and Taiwan, is signed in Washington, D.C.
Väinö Linna's war novel The Unknown Soldier (Tuntematon sotilas) is published.
First successful kidney transplant is performed by J. Hartwell Harrison and Joseph Murray.
The Finnish National Bureau of Investigation is established to consolidate criminal investigation and intelligence into a single agency.

Following the assassination of the Panamanian president José Antonio Remón Cantera, his deputy, José Ramón Guizado, takes power, but is quickly deposed after his involvement in Cantera's death is discovered.
Contralto Marian Anderson becomes the first person of color to perform at the Metropolitan Opera in Giuseppe Verdi's Un ballo in maschera.
A Martin 2-0-2 and Douglas DC-3 collide over Boone County, Kentucky, killing 15 people.
Israel obtains four of the seven Dead Sea Scrolls.
Twenty-nine people are killed when Sabena Flight 503 crashes into Monte Terminillo near Rieti, Italy.
Operation Teapot: Teapot test shot "Wasp" is successfully detonated at the Nevada Test Site with a yield of 1.2 kilotons.  Wasp is the first of fourteen shots in the Teapot series.
Norodom Sihanouk, king of Cambodia, abdicates the throne in favor of his father, Norodom Suramarit.
An order to protect the endangered Saimaa ringed seal (Pusa hispida saimensis) is legalized.
A United States Navy Douglas R6D-1 Liftmaster crashes into Hawaii's Waiʻanae Range, killing 66.
Pan Am Flight 845/26 ditches in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Oregon, killing four.
The EOKA rebellion against the British Empire begins in Cyprus, with the goal of unifying with Greece.
The American Civil Liberties Union announces it will defend Allen Ginsberg's book Howl against obscenity charges.
Winston Churchill resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom amid indications of failing health.
The Air India Kashmir Princess is bombed and crashes in a failed assassination attempt on Zhou Enlai by the Kuomintang.
The polio vaccine, developed by Dr. Jonas Salk, is declared safe and effective.
McDonald's restaurant dates its founding to the opening of a franchised restaurant by Ray Kroc, in Des Plaines, Illinois.
Twenty-nine nations meet at Bandung, Indonesia, for the first Asian-African Conference.
The Bandung Conference ends: Twenty-nine non-aligned nations of Asia and Africa finish a meeting that condemns colonialism, racism, and the Cold War.
The General Treaty, by which France, Britain and the United States recognize the sovereignty of West Germany, comes into effect.
Cold War: West Germany joins NATO.
Cold War: Eight Communist bloc countries, including the Soviet Union, sign a mutual defense treaty called the Warsaw Pact.

Operation Passage to Freedom, the evacuation of 310,000 Vietnamese civilians, soldiers and non-Vietnamese members of the French Army from communist North Vietnam to South Vietnam following the end of the First Indochina War, ends.
source_pages: Operation_Passage_to_Freedom; Vietnamese_people; French_Union; North_Vietnam; South_Vietnam; First_Indochina_War

event_text: In the United States, a night-time F5 tornado strikes the small city of Udall, Kansas as part of a larger outbreak across the Great Plains, killing 80 and injuring 273. It is the deadliest tornado to ever occur in the state and the 23rd deadliest in the U.S.

First ascent of Mount Kangchenjunga: On the British Kangchenjunga expedition led by Charles Evans, Joe Brown and George Band reach the summit of the third-highest mountain in the world (8,586 meters); Norman Hardie and Tony Streather join them the following day.
The U.S. Supreme Court expands on its Brown v. Board of Education decision by ordering district courts and school districts to enforce educational desegregation "at all deliberate speed."
source_pages: Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States; Brown_v._Board_of_Education; United_States_district_court; School_district; School_integration_in_the_United_States; May_31

event_text: The USSR and Yugoslavia sign the Belgrade declaration and thus normalize relations between the two countries, discontinued since 1948.
Lux Radio Theatre signs off the air permanently. The show launched in New York in 1934, and featured radio adaptations of Broadway shows and popular films.
Eighty-three spectators are killed and at least one hundred are injured after an Austin-Healey and a Mercedes-Benz collide at the 24 Hours of Le Mans, the deadliest ever accident in motorsports.
Chile becomes a signatory to the Buenos Aires copyright treaty.

In a futile effort to topple Argentine President Juan Perón, rogue aircraft pilots of the Argentine Navy drop several bombs upon an unarmed crowd demonstrating in favor of Perón in Buenos Aires, killing 364 and injuring at least 800. At the same time on the ground, some soldiers attempt to stage a coup but are suppressed by loyal forces.
The South African Congress Alliance adopts the Freedom Charter at the Congress of the People in Kliptown.
The Russell–Einstein Manifesto calls for a reduction of the risk of nuclear warfare.
Eighteen Nobel laureates sign the Mainau Declaration against nuclear weapons, later co-signed by thirty-four others.
The Austrian State Treaty restores Austrian sovereignty.
El Al Flight 402 is shot down by two fighter jets after straying into Bulgarian air space. All 58 people on board are killed.
Hurricane Diane made landfall near Wilmington, North Carolina, and it went on to cause major floods and kill more than 184 people.
In the Northeast United States, severe flooding caused by Hurricane Diane, claims 200 lives.
Battle of Philippeville: In Morocco, a force of Berbers from the Atlas Mountains region of Algeria raid two rural settlements and kill 77 French nationals.
The first edition of the Guinness Book of Records is published in Great Britain.
Black teenager Emmett Till is lynched in Mississippi for whistling at a white woman, galvanizing the nascent civil rights movement.
Istanbul's Greek, Jewish, and Armenian minorities are the target of a government-sponsored pogrom; dozens are killed in ensuing riots.
The military coup to unseat President Juan Perón of Argentina is launched at midnight.
A Soviet Zulu-class submarine becomes the first to launch a ballistic missile.
The Treaty on Relations between the USSR and the GDR is signed.
An all-white jury in Mississippi finds Roy Bryant and J. W. Milam not guilty in the torture-murder of 14-year-old African American boy Emmett Till.
The Royal Jordanian Air Force is founded.
The Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region is established.
The General Assembly of the European Broadcasting Union approves the staging of the first Eurovision Song Contest.
Prime Minister Ngô Đình Diệm defeats former emperor Bảo Đại in a referendum and founds the Republic of Vietnam.
The people of the Saar region vote in a referendum to unite with West Germany instead of France.
After the last Allied troops have left the country, and following the provisions of the Austrian Independence Treaty, Austria declares that it will never join a military alliance.
Ngô Đình Diệm proclaims himself as President of the newly created Republic of Vietnam.
The Soviet battleship Novorossiysk strikes a World War II mine in the harbor at Sevastopol.
The establishment of a Military Assistance Advisory Group in South Vietnam marks the beginning of American involvement in the conflict.
The bombing of United Air Lines Flight 629 occurs near Longmont, Colorado, killing all 39 passengers and five crew members aboard the Douglas DC-6B airliner.
After being destroyed in World War II, the rebuilt Vienna State Opera reopens with a performance of Beethoven's Fidelio.
The first part of the Saint Petersburg Metro is opened.
National Review publishes its first issue.
The Soviet Union launches RDS-37, a 1.6 megaton two stage hydrogen bomb designed by Andrei Sakharov. The bomb was dropped over Semipalatinsk.
source_pages: Soviet_Union; RDS-37; Thermonuclear_weapon; Andrei_Sakharov; Semipalatinsk_Test_Site; November_22

event_text: The Cocos Islands are transferred from the control of the United Kingdom to that of Australia.

American Civil Rights Movement: In Montgomery, Alabama, seamstress Rosa Parks refuses to give up her bus seat to a white man and is arrested for violating the city's racial segregation laws, an incident which leads to that city's bus boycott.
The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations merge and form the AFL–CIO.
E. D. Nixon and Rosa Parks lead the Montgomery bus boycott.
The Flag of Europe is adopted by Council of Europe.

Albania, Austria, Bulgaria, Cambodia, Ceylon, Finland, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Jordan, Laos, Libya, Nepal, Portugal, Romania and Spain join the United Nations through United Nations Security Council Resolution 109.
source_pages: Albania; Austria; Bulgaria; Kingdom_of_Cambodia_(1953–1970); Dominion_of_Ceylon; Finland; Hungary; Republic_of_Ireland; Italy; Jordan; Laos; Libya; Nepal; Portugal; Romania; Spain; United_Nations; United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_109

event_text: Cardiff is proclaimed the capital city of Wales, United Kingdom.
The first film adaptation of Väinö Linna's novel The Unknown Soldier, directed by Edvin Laine, premieres.
A flood devastates California, killing 74 people across portions of the state.
General Motors becomes the first U.S. corporation to make over US$1 billion in a year.
Sudan achieves independence from Egypt and the United Kingdom.
A fire damages the top part of the Eiffel Tower.
The Greek National Radical Union is formed by Konstantinos Karamanlis.
Operation Auca: Five U.S. missionaries are killed by the Waorani of Ecuador shortly after making first contact.
Soviet Union cedes Porkkala back to Finland.
Elvis Presley makes his first national television appearance.
In the United States, Civil Rights Movement leader Martin Luther King Jr.'s home is bombed in retaliation for the Montgomery bus boycott.
The United States Merchant Marine Academy becomes a permanent Service Academy.
In his speech On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences, Nikita Khrushchev, leader of the Soviet Union, denounces Stalin.
The International Air Transport Association finalizes a draft of the Radiotelephony spelling alphabet for the International Civil Aviation Organization.
Formation of the East German Nationale Volksarmee.
Soviet forces suppress mass demonstrations in the Georgian SSR, reacting to Nikita Khrushchev's de-Stalinization policy.
Tunisia gains independence from France.
Pakistan becomes the first Islamic republic in the world. This date is now celebrated as Republic Day in Pakistan.
As the World Turns and The Edge of Night premiere on CBS. The two soaps become the first daytime dramas to debut in the 30-minute format.
Hudsonville–Standale tornado: The western half of the Lower Peninsula of Michigan is struck by a deadly F5 tornado.
Cuban Revolution: Fidel Castro declares himself at war with Cuban President Fulgencio Batista.
Francoist Spain agrees to surrender its protectorate in Morocco.
Actress Grace Kelly marries Prince Rainier of Monaco.
SS Ideal X, the world's first successful container ship, leaves Port Newark, New Jersey, for Houston, Texas.
Former Vice President and Democratic Senator Alben Barkley dies during a speech in Virginia.
The polio vaccine developed by Jonas Salk is made available to the public.
In Operation Redwing, the first United States airborne hydrogen bomb is dropped over Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.
The first Eurovision Song Contest is held in Lugano, Switzerland.
Elvis Presley introduces his new single, "Hound Dog", on The Milton Berle Show, scandalizing the audience with his suggestive hip movements.
Start of Gal Oya riots, the first reported ethnic riots that target minority Sri Lankan Tamils in the Eastern Province. The total number of deaths is reportedly 150.
A Venezuelan Super-Constellation crashes in the Atlantic Ocean off Asbury Park, New Jersey, killing 74 people.

The French National Assembly takes the first step in creating the French Community by passing the Loi Cadre, transferring a number of powers from Paris to elected territorial governments in French West Africa.
In Poznań, workers from HCP factory go to the streets, sparking one of the first major protests against communist government both in Poland and Europe.
The Federal Aid Highway Act of 1956 is signed by U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower, officially creating the United States Interstate Highway System.
A TWA Super Constellation and a United Airlines DC-7 collide above the Grand Canyon in Arizona and crash, killing all 128 on board both airliners.
source_pages: Trans_World_Airlines; Lockheed_Constellation; United_Airlines; Douglas_DC-7; 1956_Grand_Canyon_mid-air_collision; Grand_Canyon; Arizona

event_text: The 7.7 Mw  Amorgos earthquake shakes the Cyclades island group in the Aegean Sea with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). The shaking and the destructive tsunami that followed left fifty-three people dead. A damaging M7.2 aftershock occurred minutes after the mainshock.
The Dartmouth workshop is the first conference on artificial intelligence.
Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus closes its last "Big Tent" show in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; due to changing economics, all subsequent circus shows will be held in arenas.
Forty-five miles south of Nantucket Island, the Italian ocean liner SS Andrea Doria collides with the MS Stockholm in heavy fog and sinks the next day, killing 51.
Following the World Bank's refusal to fund building the Aswan Dam, Egyptian leader Gamal Abdel Nasser nationalizes the Suez Canal, sparking international condemnation.
source_pages: World_Bank_Group; Aswan_Dam; Egypt; Gamal_Abdel_Nasser; Suez_Canal; Suez_Crisis

event_text: A joint resolution of the U.S. Congress is signed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower, authorizing In God We Trust as the U.S. national motto.
source_pages: Joint_resolution; United_States_Congress; President_of_the_United_States; Dwight_D._Eisenhower; In_God_We_Trust; Motto

event_text: After going bankrupt in 1955, the American broadcaster DuMont Television Network makes its final broadcast, a boxing match from St. Nicholas Arena in New York in the Boxing from St. Nicholas Arena series.
Marcinelle mining disaster in Belgium. 262 coal miners, including a substantial number of Italian migrant workers, were killed in one of the largest mining accidents in Belgian history.

The nuclear power station at Calder Hall in the United Kingdom was connected to the national power grid becoming the world's first commercial nuclear power station to generate electricity on an industrial scale.
Elvis Presley appears on The Ed Sullivan Show for the first time.
The IBM 305 RAMAC is introduced, the first commercial computer to use disk storage.
The dike around the Dutch polder East Flevoland is closed.
TCN-9 Sydney is the first Australian television station to commence regular broadcasts.

A tropical storm originating in the eastern Pacific Ocean passes into the Gulf of Mexico and is upgraded and named Hurricane Flossy just hours before striking the Gulf Coast and causing 15 deaths and an estimated USD$24.8 million in damages.
source_pages: Tropical_cyclone; Pacific_Ocean; Gulf_of_Mexico; Hurricane_Flossy_(1956); Gulf_Coast_of_the_United_States; United_States_dollar; September_23

event_text: TAT-1, the first submarine transatlantic telephone cable system, is inaugurated.
USAF Captain Milburn G. Apt becomes the first person to exceed Mach 3. Shortly thereafter, the Bell X-2 goes out of control and Captain Apt is killed.
The New York Yankees's Don Larsen pitches the only perfect game in a World Series.
Dr. B. R. Ambedkar, leader of India's Untouchable caste, converts to Buddhism along with 385,000 of his followers (see Neo-Buddhism).
FORTRAN, the first modern computer language, is first shared with the coding community.
The first commercial nuclear power station is officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II in Sellafield, England.
The Soviet Union and Japan sign a Joint Declaration, officially ending the state of war between the two countries that had existed since August 1945.
The Mau Mau Uprising in Kenya is defeated.
Secret police shoot several anti-communist protesters, igniting the Hungarian Revolution.
Hungarian Revolution: In the towns of Mosonmagyaróvár and Esztergom, Hungarian secret police forces massacre civilians. As rebel strongholds in Budapest hold, fighting spreads throughout the country.

Hungarian Revolution: A de facto ceasefire comes into effect between armed revolutionaries and Soviet troops, who begin to withdraw from Budapest. Communist officials and facilities come under attack by revolutionaries.
Suez Crisis begins: Israeli forces invade the Sinai Peninsula and push Egyptian forces back toward the Suez Canal.
source_pages: Suez_Crisis; Israel; Sinai_Peninsula; Egypt; Suez_Canal; October_29

event_text: Hungarian Revolution: The government of Imre Nagy recognizes newly established revolutionary workers' councils. Army officer Béla Király leads anti-Soviet militias in an attack on the headquarters of the Hungarian Working People's Party.
Suez Crisis: The United Kingdom and France begin bombing Egypt to force the reopening of the Suez Canal.

Hungarian Revolution of 1956: A Revolutionary Headquarters is established in Hungary. Following Imre Nagy's announcement of October 30, banned non-Communist political parties are reformed, and the MDP is replaced by the MSZMP.  József Mindszenty is released from prison. The Soviet Politburo makes the decision to crush the Revolution.

The Indian states Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, and Mysore are formally created under the States Reorganisation Act; Kanyakumari district is joined to Tamil Nadu from Kerala. Delhi was established as a union territory.
source_pages: Kerala; Andhra_Pradesh; Mysore_State; States_Reorganisation_Act,_1956; Kanyakumari; Tamil_Nadu; Delhi; Union_territory

event_text: Hungarian Revolution: Imre Nagy announces Hungary's neutrality and withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact. Soviet troops begin to re-enter Hungary, contrary to assurances by the Soviet government. János Kádár and Ferenc Münnich secretly defect to the Soviets.
source_pages: Hungarian_Revolution_of_1956; Imre_Nagy; Warsaw_Pact; Soviet_Army; János_Kádár; Ferenc_Münnich

event_text: The Springhill mining disaster in Springhill, Nova Scotia kills 39 miners; 88 are rescued.

Hungarian Revolution: Nikita Khrushchev meets with leaders of other Communist countries to seek their advice on the situation in Hungary, selecting János Kádár as the country's next leader on the advice of Josip Broz Tito.
Suez Crisis: Israel occupies the Gaza Strip.
Suez Crisis: The Khan Yunis killings by the Israel Defense Forces in Egyptian-controlled Gaza result in the deaths of 275 Palestinians.

Hungarian Revolution: A new Hungarian government is formed, in which many members of banned non-Communist parties participate.  János Kádár and Ferenc Münnich form a counter-government in Moscow as Soviet troops prepare for the final assault.

Soviet troops enter Hungary to end the Hungarian revolution against the Soviet Union that started on October 23. Thousands are killed, more are wounded, and nearly a quarter million leave the country.
Suez Crisis: British and French paratroopers land in Egypt after a week-long bombing campaign.
Suez Crisis: The United Nations General Assembly adopts a resolution calling for the United Kingdom, France and Israel to immediately withdraw their troops from Egypt.
Hungarian Revolution: János Kádár returns to Budapest in a Soviet armored convoy, officially taking office as the next Hungarian leader. By this point, most armed resistance has been defeated.
Morocco, Sudan and Tunisia join the United Nations.
In the midst of the Suez Crisis, Palestinian refugees are shot dead in Rafah by Israel Defense Force soldiers following the invasion of the Gaza Strip.
The Supreme Court of the United States affirmed a lower court ruling that invalidated Alabama laws requiring segregated buses, thus ending the Montgomery bus boycott.
The Granma reaches the shores of Cuba's Oriente Province. Fidel Castro, Che Guevara and 80 other members of the 26th of July Movement disembark to initiate the Cuban Revolution.
source_pages: Landing_of_the_Granma; Cuba; Oriente_Province; Fidel_Castro; Che_Guevara; 26th_of_July_Movement; Cuban_Revolution

event_text: The Million Dollar Quartet (Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, and Johnny Cash) get together at Sun Studio for the first and last time.
source_pages: Million_Dollar_Quartet; Elvis_Presley; Jerry_Lee_Lewis; Carl_Perkins; Johnny_Cash; Sun_Studio

event_text: A violent water polo match between Hungary and the USSR takes place during the 1956 Summer Olympics in Melbourne, against the backdrop of the Hungarian Revolution of 1956.
Trans-Canada Air Lines Flight 810-9, a Canadair North Star, crashes near Hope, British Columbia, Canada, killing all 62 people on board.
An Aeroflot Lisunov Li-2 crashes near Anadyr, killing all 12 people on board.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 121 relating to acceptance of Japan to the United Nations is adopted.
Irish-born physician John Bodkin Adams is arrested in connection with the suspicious deaths of more than 160 patients. Eventually he is convicted only of minor charges.
Chin Peng, David Marshall and Tunku Abdul Rahman meet in Baling, Malaya to try and resolve the Malayan Emergency situation.
source_pages: Chin_Peng; David_Marshall_(Singaporean_politician); Tunku_Abdul_Rahman; Baling_District; Federation_of_Malaya; Baling_Talks; Malayan_Emergency

event_text: The Romanian Television network begins its first broadcast in Bucharest.
George Town, Penang, is made a city by a royal charter of Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom.
Lèse majesté in Thailand is strengthened to include "insult" and changed to a crime against national security, after the Thai criminal code of 1956 went into effect.: 6, 18
The Hamilton Watch Company introduces the first electric watch.
In a speech given to the United States Congress, United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower announces the establishment of what will later be called the Eisenhower Doctrine.
British Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden resigns from office following his failure to retake the Suez Canal from Egyptian sovereignty.
The African Convention is founded in Dakar, Senegal.
Kripalu Maharaj is named fifth Jagadguru (world teacher) after giving seven days of speeches before 500 Hindu scholars.
Israel withdraws from the Sinai Peninsula.
The New York City "Mad Bomber", George P. Metesky, is arrested in Waterbury, Connecticut and charged with planting more than 30 bombs.
American inventor Walter Frederick Morrison sells the rights to his flying disc to the Wham-O toy company, which later renames it the "Frisbee".

Eight people (five total crew from two aircraft and three on the ground) in Pacoima, California are killed following the mid-air collision between a Douglas DC-7 airliner and a Northrop F-89 Scorpion fighter jet.
Northeast Airlines Flight 823 crashes on Rikers Island in New York City, killing 20 people and injuring 78 others.
Kenyan rebel leader Dedan Kimathi is executed by the British colonial government.
Walter James Bolton becomes the last person legally executed in New Zealand.
Ngô Đình Diệm of South Vietnam survives a communist shooting assassination attempt in Buôn Ma Thuột.
The S&P 500 stock market index is introduced, replacing the S&P 90.

Sutton Wick air crash a Blackburn Beverley of 53 Squadron, Royal Air Forces, crashes into the village of Sutton Wick, Berkshire (now Oxfordshire) killing most of the crew and passengers and two local residents.
Ghana becomes the first Sub-Saharan country to gain independence from the British.
The 8.6 Mw  Andreanof Islands earthquake shakes the Aleutian Islands, causing over $5 million in damage from ground movement and a destructive tsunami.
Cuban student revolutionaries storm the presidential palace in Havana in a failed attempt on the life of President Fulgencio Batista.
A plane crash in Cebu, Philippines kills Philippine President Ramon Magsaysay and 24 others.
United States Customs seizes copies of Allen Ginsberg's poem "Howl" on obscenity grounds.
The European Economic Community is established with West Germany, France, Italy, Belgium, Netherlands and Luxembourg as the first members.
The New York, Ontario and Western Railway makes its final run, the first major U.S. railroad to be abandoned in its entirety.
Elections to the Territorial Assembly of the French colony Upper Volta are held. After the elections PDU and MDV form a government.
The flag carrier airline of Greece for decades, Olympic Airways, is founded by Aristotle Onassis following the acquisition of "TAE - Greek National Airlines".
The Suez Canal in Egypt is cleared and opens to shipping following the Suez Crisis.
United Kingdom agrees to Singaporean self-rule.
Suez Crisis: The Suez Canal is reopened following the introduction of UNEF peacekeepers to the region.
Supplementary Convention on the Abolition of Slavery entered into force.
A Vickers VC.1 Viking crashes while attempting to return to Blackbushe Airport in Yateley, killing 34.
Walter O'Malley, the owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, agrees to move the team from Brooklyn to Los Angeles.
South Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem began a state visit to the United States, his regime's main sponsor.
At Malden Island in the Pacific Ocean, Britain tests its first hydrogen bomb in Operation Grapple.
South Africa's government approves of racial separation in universities.
First ascent of Broad Peak by Fritz Wintersteller, Marcus Schmuck, Kurt Diemberger, and Hermann Buhl.
John Diefenbaker leads the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada to a stunning upset in the 1957 Canadian federal election, ending 22 years of Liberal Party government.
Ellen Fairclough is sworn in as Canada's first female Cabinet Minister.
In Roth v. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court rules that obscenity is not protected by the First Amendment.
Hurricane Audrey makes landfall near the Texas–Louisiana border, killing over 400 people, mainly in and around Cameron, Louisiana.
The International Geophysical Year begins.
Althea Gibson wins at the Wimbledon Championships, becoming the first black athlete to do so.
John Lennon and Paul McCartney meet for the first time, as teenagers at Woolton Fete, three years before forming the Beatles.
Prince Karim Husseini Aga Khan IV inherits the office of Imamat as the 49th Imam of Shia Imami Ismai'li worldwide, after the death of Sir Sultan Mahommed Shah Aga Khan III.
Rawya Ateya takes her seat in the National Assembly of Egypt, thereby becoming the first female parliamentarian in the Arab world.
KLM Flight 844 crashes off the Schouten Islands in present day Indonesia (then Netherlands New Guinea), killing 58 people.
The largely autobiographical novel The Ordeal of Gilbert Pinfold by Evelyn Waugh was published.
The Tunisian King Muhammad VIII al-Amin is replaced by President Habib Bourguiba.
Carlos Castillo Armas, dictator of Guatemala, is assassinated.
Heavy rain and a mudslide in Isahaya, western Kyushu, Japan, kills 992.
The International Atomic Energy Agency is established.
Tonight Starring Jack Paar premieres on NBC with Jack Paar beginning the modern day talk show.
The United States and Canada form the North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD).
American Bandstand, a show dedicated to the teenage "baby-boomers" by playing the songs and showing popular dances of the time, debuts on the ABC television network.
The Soviet Union successfully conducts a long-range test flight of the R-7 Semyorka, the first intercontinental ballistic missile.

U.S. Senator Strom Thurmond begins a filibuster to prevent the United States Senate from voting on the Civil Rights Act of 1957; he stopped speaking 24 hours and 18 minutes later, the longest filibuster ever conducted by a single Senator.
The Federation of Malaya (now Malaysia) gains its independence from the United Kingdom.
President Ngô Đình Diệm of South Vietnam becomes the first foreign head of state to make a state visit to Australia.

American Civil Rights Movement: Little Rock Crisis: The governor of Arkansas calls out the National Guard to prevent African American students from enrolling in Little Rock Central High School, resulting in the lawsuit Cooper v. Aaron the following year.
Cuban Revolution: Fulgencio Batista bombs the revolt in Cienfuegos.
Pamir, a four-masted barque, was shipwrecked and sank off the Azores during Hurricane Carrie.
In Haiti, François Duvalier is elected president.

Little Rock schools integration crisis: President Dwight D. Eisenhower sends the 101st Airborne Division to Little Rock, Arkansas, and federalizes the Arkansas National Guard, ordering both to support the integration of Little Rock Central High School.
source_pages: Little_Rock_Nine; Dwight_D._Eisenhower; 101st_Airborne_Division; Little_Rock,_Arkansas; National_Guard_(United_States); Arkansas_National_Guard; School_integration_in_the_United_States; Little_Rock_Central_High_School; September_23

event_text: President Eisenhower sends the 101st Airborne Division to Little Rock, Arkansas, to enforce desegregation.
Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, is integrated by the use of United States Army troops.
The Kyshtym disaster is the third-worst nuclear accident ever recorded.
The motto In God We Trust first appears on U.S. paper currency.
The California State Superior Court rules that the book Howl and Other Poems is not obscene.
Sputnik 1 becomes the first artificial satellite to orbit the Earth.
U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower apologizes to Ghanaian finance minister Komla Agbeli Gbedemah after he is refused service in a Delaware restaurant.
The Windscale fire results in Britain's worst nuclear accident.
The 23rd Canadian Parliament becomes the only one to be personally opened by the Queen of Canada.
At least 81 people are killed in the most devastating flood in the history of the Spanish city of Valencia.
The United States Air Force starts the X-20 Dyna-Soar crewed space program.
Israel's prime minister David Ben-Gurion and five of his ministers are injured when Moshe Dwek throws a grenade into the Knesset.
The Mackinac Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge between anchorages at the time, opens to traffic connecting Michigan's upper and lower peninsulas.
Sputnik program: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 2. On board is the first animal to enter orbit, a dog named Laika.
source_pages: List_of_spacecraft_called_Sputnik; Soviet_Union; Sputnik_2; November_3; Orbit; Soviet_space_dogs; Laika

event_text: Cold War: The Gaither Report calls for more American missiles and fallout shelters.
Pan Am Flight 7 disappears between San Francisco and Honolulu. Wreckage and bodies are discovered a week later.
Operation Grapple X, Round C1: The United Kingdom conducts its first successful hydrogen bomb test over Kiritimati in the Pacific.
The "Apalachin meeting" in rural Tioga County in upstate New York is raided by law enforcement; many high-level Mafia figures are arrested while trying to flee.
Short Solent 3 crashes near Chessell.

Vickers Viscount G-AOHP of British European Airways crashes at Ballerup after the failure of three engines on approach to Copenhagen Airport. The cause is a malfunction of the anti-icing system on the aircraft. There are no fatalities.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 126 relating to the Kashmir conflict is adopted.
Project Vanguard: A launchpad explosion of Vanguard TV3 thwarts the first United States attempt to launch a satellite into Earth orbit.
The Mw  6.5 Farsinaj earthquake strikes Iran with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VII, causing at least 1,119 deaths and damaging over 5,000 homes.
The United States successfully launches the first Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile at Cape Canaveral, Florida.
A violent F5 tornado wipes out the entire community of Sunfield, Illinois.
The initial production version of the Boeing 707 makes its first flight.
The European Economic Community is established.
The West Indies Federation is formed.
Sputnik 1, the first artificial Earth satellite, launched by the Soviet Union in 1957, falls to Earth from orbit.
The Moroccan Army of Liberation ambushes a Spanish patrol in the Battle of Edchera.
Willie O'Ree, the first Black Canadian National Hockey League player, makes his NHL debut with the Boston Bruins.
After a general uprising and rioting in the streets, President Marcos Pérez Jiménez leaves Venezuela.
The Lego company patents the design of its Lego bricks, still compatible with bricks produced today.
Cold War: Space Race: The Explorer 1, the first successful American satellite, detects the Van Allen radiation belt.
Founding of the Benelux Economic Union, creating a testing ground for a later European Economic Community.
Gamal Abdel Nasser is nominated to be the first president of the United Arab Republic.
A hydrogen bomb known as the Tybee Bomb is lost by the US Air Force off the coast of Savannah, Georgia, never to be recovered.
Eight Manchester United F.C. players and 15 other passengers are killed in the Munich air disaster.
The CND symbol, aka peace symbol, commissioned by the Direct Action Committee in protest against the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment, is designed and completed by Gerald Holtom.
Following a plebiscite in both countries the previous day, Egypt and Syria join to form the United Arab Republic.

Five-time Argentine Formula One champion Juan Manuel Fangio is kidnapped by rebels involved in the Cuban Revolution, on the eve of the Cuban Grand Prix. He was released the following day after the race.

A school bus in Floyd County, Kentucky hits a wrecker truck and plunges down an embankment into the rain-swollen Levisa Fork river. The driver and 26 children die in one of the worst school bus accidents in U.S. history.
Samuel Alphonsus Stritch is appointed Pro-Prefect of the Propagation of Faith and thus becomes the first U.S. member of the Roman Curia.
Nuri al-Said becomes Prime Minister of Iraq for the eighth time.
The United States launches the first solar-powered satellite, which is also the first satellite to achieve a long-term orbit.
The Monarch Underwear Company fire leaves 24 dead and 15 injured.
The United States Army launches Explorer 3.
The African Regroupment Party is launched at a meeting in Paris.
Nikita Khrushchev becomes Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union.
In the Canadian federal election, the Progressive Conservatives, led by John Diefenbaker, win the largest percentage of seats in Canadian history, with 208 seats of 265.
The CND peace symbol is displayed in public for the first time in London.
Ripple Rock, an underwater threat to navigation in the Seymour Narrows in Canada is destroyed in one of the largest non-nuclear controlled explosions of the time.
Capital Airlines Flight 67 crashes in Tittabawassee Township, Michigan, near Freeland Tri-City Airport, killing 47.

The Soviet satellite Sputnik 2 falls from orbit after a mission duration of 162 days. This was the first spacecraft to carry a living animal, a female dog named Laika, who likely lived only a few hours.
United Air Lines Flight 736 collides with a United States Air Force fighter jet near Arden, Nevada in what is now Enterprise, Nevada.
Final run of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's Royal Blue from Washington, D.C., to New York City after 68 years, the first U.S. passenger train to use electric locomotives.
During a visit to Caracas, Venezuela, the US Vice President Richard Nixon's car is attacked by anti-American demonstrators.

May 1958 crisis: A group of French military officers lead a coup in Algiers demanding that a government of national unity be formed with Charles de Gaulle at its head in order to defend French control of Algeria.

Ben Carlin becomes the first (and only) person to circumnavigate the world by amphibious vehicle, having travelled over 17,000 kilometres (11,000 mi) by sea and 62,000 kilometres (39,000 mi) by land during a ten-year journey.
Capital Airlines Flight 300 collides in mid-air with a United States Air Force Lockheed T-33 over Brunswick, Maryland, killing 12.
The 1958 riots in Ceylon become a watershed in the race relations of various ethnic communities of Sri Lanka. The total deaths are estimated at 300, mostly Tamils.
United Press International is formed through a merger of the United Press and the International News Service.
First flight of the McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II.
Cuban Revolution: Fidel Castro's 26th of July Movement, heavily reinforced by Frank Pais Militia, overwhelm an army post in El Uvero.

Memorial Day: The remains of two unidentified American servicemen, killed in action during World War II and the Korean War respectively, are buried at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery.
Charles de Gaulle comes out of retirement to lead France by decree for six months.
Aeroflot Flight 105 crashes on approach to Magdan-13 Airport, killing 24.
Imre Nagy, Pál Maléter and other leaders of the 1956 Hungarian Uprising are executed.

The Ironworkers Memorial Second Narrows Crossing, in the process of being built to connect Vancouver and North Vancouver (Canada), collapses into the Burrard Inlet killing 18 ironworkers and injuring others.
Benjamin Britten's one-act opera Noye's Fludde premiered at the Aldeburgh Festival.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation links television broadcasting across Canada via microwave.
Flooding of Canada's Saint Lawrence Seaway begins.
US President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs the Alaska Statehood Act into law.
A 7.8 Mw  strike-slip earthquake in Alaska causes a landslide that produces a megatsunami. The runup from the waves reached 525 m (1,722 ft) on the rim of Lituya Bay; five people were killed.
In the 14 July Revolution in Iraq, the monarchy is overthrown by popular forces led by Abd al-Karim Qasim, who becomes the nation's new leader.
The African Regroupment Party holds its first congress in Cotonou.
Explorer program: Explorer 4 is launched.
U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the National Aeronautics and Space Act, which creates the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).
The world's first nuclear submarine, the USS Nautilus, becomes the first vessel to complete a submerged transit of the geographical North Pole.
Law of Permanent Defense of Democracy, outlawing the Communist Party of Chile and banning 26,650 persons from the electoral lists, is repealed in Chile.
Pioneer 0, America's first attempt at lunar orbit, is launched using the first Thor-Able rocket and fails. Notable as one of the first attempted launches beyond Earth orbit by any country.
Vladimir Nabokov's controversial novel Lolita is published in the United States.
Brojen Das from Bangladesh swims across the English Channel in a competition as the first Bengali and the first Asian to do so, placing first among the 39 competitors.
Chinese Civil War: The Second Taiwan Strait Crisis begins with the People's Liberation Army's bombardment of Quemoy.
The world's first publicly marketed instant noodles, Chikin Ramen, are introduced by Taiwanese-Japanese businessman Momofuku Ando.
source_pages: Instant_noodles; Nissin_Chikin_Ramen; Taiwanese_people; Japan; Momofuku_Ando; August_25

event_text: United States Air Force Academy opens in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
A USAF RC-130 is shot down by fighters over Armenia when it strays into Soviet airspace while conducting a sigint mission. All crew members are killed.
Jack Kilby demonstrates the first working integrated circuit while working at Texas Instruments.
The first two German post-war rockets, designed by the German engineer Ernst Mohr, reach the upper atmosphere.
A Central Railroad of New Jersey commuter train runs through an open drawbridge at the Newark Bay, killing 48.
Fernando Rios, a Mexican tour guide in New Orleans, dies of injuries sustained in an incident of gay bashing.
The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics is replaced by NASA.
Guinea declares its independence from France.
The current constitution of France is adopted.
The 1958 Pakistani coup d'état inaugurates a prolonged period of military rule.
The U.S. crewed space-flight project is renamed to Project Mercury.
NASA launches Pioneer 1, its first space probe, although it fails to achieve a stable orbit.
Canada's Springhill mining disaster kills seventy-five miners, while ninety-nine others are rescued.
Belgian artist Peyo's comic characters, the Smurfs, make their debut in Spirou magazine.
Pan American Airways makes the first commercial flight of the Boeing 707 from New York City to Paris.
Iskander Mirza, the first President of Pakistan, is deposed by General Ayub Khan, who had been appointed the enforcer of martial law by Mirza 20 days earlier.
John XXIII is elected Pope.
The Hope Diamond is donated to the Smithsonian Institution by New York diamond merchant Harry Winston.
A team of rock climbers led by Warren Harding completes the first ascent of The Nose on El Capitan in Yosemite Valley.
National Airlines Flight 967 explodes in mid-air over the Gulf of Mexico, killing all 42 aboard.
French Sudan gains autonomy as a self-governing member of the French Community.
Chad, the Republic of the Congo, and Gabon become autonomous republics within the French Community.
First successful flight of SM-65 Atlas; the first operational intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), developed by the United States and the first member of the Atlas rocket family.
The Central African Republic attains self-rule within the French Union.
The Our Lady of the Angels School fire in Chicago kills 92 children and three nuns.
Subscriber Trunk Dialling (STD) is inaugurated in the United Kingdom by Queen Elizabeth II when she speaks to the Lord Provost in a call from Bristol to Edinburgh.
The Preston By-pass, the UK's first stretch of motorway, opens to traffic for the first time. (It is now part of the M6 and M55 motorways.)

French Upper Volta and French Dahomey gain self-government from France, becoming the Republic of Upper Volta (now Burkina Faso) and the Republic of Dahomey (now Benin), respectively, and joining the French Community.
source_pages: French_Upper_Volta; French_Dahomey; French_Fourth_Republic; Republic_of_Upper_Volta; Burkina_Faso; Republic_of_Dahomey; Benin; French_Community

event_text: The 3rd Soviet Antarctic Expedition becomes the first to reach the southern pole of inaccessibility.
Project SCORE, the world's first communications satellite, is launched.

"Greatest Game Ever Played": The Baltimore Colts defeat the New York Giants in the first ever National Football League sudden death overtime game at New York's Yankee Stadium to win the NFL Championship.
source_pages: 1958_NFL_Championship_Game; History_of_the_Indianapolis_Colts; New_York_Giants; National_Football_League; Sudden_death_(sport); Overtime_(sports); Yankee_Stadium_(1923)

event_text: The Guatemalan Air Force sinks several Mexican fishing boats alleged to have breached maritime borders, killing three and sparking international tension.
Cuban Revolution: Fulgencio Batista, dictator of Cuba, is overthrown by Fidel Castro's forces.
Luna 1, the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon and to orbit the Sun, is launched by the Soviet Union.
Alaska is admitted as the 49th U.S. state.
Luna 1 becomes the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon.
The United States recognizes the new Cuban government of Fidel Castro.
Charles de Gaulle is proclaimed as the first President of the French Fifth Republic.
The Vega de Tera dam fails, triggering a disastrous flood that nearly destroys the town of Ribadelago and kills 144 residents.
36 people are killed when Lufthansa Flight 502 crashes on approach to Rio de Janeiro/Galeão International Airport in Brazil.
Austral Líneas Aéreas Flight 205 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean near Astor Piazzolla International Airport in Mar del Plata, Argentina, killing 51.
The 41-acre (17 ha) Chain Island is listed for sale by the California State Lands Commission, with a minimum bid of $5,226.
The first Melodifestivalen is held at Cirkus in Stockholm, Sweden.
The forces of the Sultanate of Muscat occupy the last strongholds of the Imamate of Oman, Saiq and Shuraijah, marking the end of Jebel Akhdar War in Oman.
MS Hans Hedtoft, specifically designed to operate in icebound seas, strikes an iceberg on her maiden voyage and sinks, killing all 95 aboard.

Rock and roll musicians Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, and J. P. "The Big Bopper" Richardson are killed in a plane crash along with the pilot near Clear Lake, Iowa, an event later known as The Day the Music Died.
Sixty-five people are killed when American Airlines Flight 320 crashes into the East River on approach to LaGuardia Airport in New York City.
Jack Kilby of Texas Instruments files the first patent for an integrated circuit.
At Cape Canaveral, Florida, the first successful test firing of a Titan intercontinental ballistic missile is accomplished.
The R-7 Semyorka, the first intercontinental ballistic missile, becomes operational at Plesetsk, USSR.
The Federation of Arab Emirates of the South is created as a protectorate of the United Kingdom.
Fidel Castro becomes Premier of Cuba after dictator Fulgencio Batista was overthrown on January 1.
Project Vanguard: Vanguard 2: The first weather satellite is launched to measure cloud-cover distribution.
A Turkish Airlines Vickers Viscount crashes near Gatwick Airport, killing 14; Turkish prime minister Adnan Menderes survives the crash.
source_pages: Turkish_Airlines; Vickers_Viscount; 1959_Gatwick_Turkish_Airlines_Viscount_crash; Gatwick_Airport; Prime_Minister_of_Turkey; Adnan_Menderes; February_17

event_text: The United Kingdom grants Cyprus independence, which is formally proclaimed on August 16, 1960.
The Avro Arrow program to design and manufacture supersonic jet fighters in Canada is cancelled by the Diefenbaker government amid much political debate.
Lee Petty wins the first Daytona 500.
Discoverer 1, an American spy satellite that is the first object intended to achieve a polar orbit, is launched but fails to achieve orbit.
The Barbie doll makes its debut at the American International Toy Fair in New York.
Tibetan uprising: Fearing an abduction attempt by China, thousands of Tibetans surround the Dalai Lama's palace to prevent his removal.
The Hawaii Admission Act is signed into law.
Chain Island is sold by the State of California to Russell Gallaway III, a Sacramento businessman who plans to use it as a "hunting and fishing retreat", for $5,258.20 ($56,716 in 2024).
The State Council of the People's Republic of China dissolves the government of Tibet.
Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama, flees Tibet for India.
The 14th Dalai Lama crosses the border into India and is granted political asylum.
A team of computer manufacturers, users, and university people led by Grace Hopper meets to discuss the creation of a new programming language that would be called COBOL.
The Organization of American States drafts an agreement to create the Inter-American Development Bank.
Project Mercury: NASA announces the selection of the United States' first seven astronauts, whom the news media quickly dub the "Mercury Seven".
The Saint Lawrence Seaway, linking the North American Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean, officially opens to shipping.
The 1st Annual Grammy Awards are held.
The Tritons' Fountain in Valletta, Malta is turned on for the first time.
The North Vietnamese Army establishes Group 559, whose responsibility is to determine how to maintain supply lines to South Vietnam; the resulting route is the Ho Chi Minh trail.
The Auckland Harbour Bridge, crossing the Waitemata Harbour in Auckland, New Zealand, is officially opened by Governor-General Charles Lyttelton, 10th Viscount Cobham.
The first government of Singapore is sworn in.
USS Barbero and the United States Postal Service attempt the delivery of mail via Missile Mail.
The USS George Washington is launched. It is the first nuclear-powered ballistic missile submarine.
Disneyland Monorail System, the first daily operating monorail system in the Western Hemisphere, opens to the public in Anaheim, California.
A rare June hurricane strikes Canada's Gulf of St. Lawrence killing 35.
Convicted Manhattan Project spy Klaus Fuchs is released after only nine years in prison and allowed to emigrate to Dresden, East Germany where he resumes a scientific career.

Swedish boxer Ingemar Johansson becomes world champion of heavy weight boxing, by defeating American Floyd Patterson on technical knockout after two minutes and three seconds in the third round at Yankee Stadium.
A United States Air Force F-100 Super Sabre from Kadena Air Base, Okinawa, crashes into a nearby elementary school, killing 11 students plus six residents from the local neighborhood.

Specific values for the international yard, avoirdupois pound and derived units (e.g. inch, mile and ounce) are adopted after agreement between the US, the United Kingdom and other Commonwealth countries.
Venus occults the star Regulus. This rare event is used to determine the diameter of Venus and the structure of the Venusian atmosphere.
NS Savannah, the first nuclear-powered cargo-passenger ship, is launched as a showcase for Dwight D. Eisenhower's "Atoms for Peace" initiative.

Elijah Jerry "Pumpsie" Green becomes the first African-American to play for the Boston Red Sox, the last team to integrate. He came in as a pinch runner for Vic Wertz and stayed in as shortstop in a 2–1 loss to the Chicago White Sox.
source_pages: Pumpsie_Green; Timeline_of_African-American_firsts; Boston_Red_Sox; Pinch_runner; Vic_Wertz; Chicago_White_Sox

event_text: At the opening of the American National Exhibition in Moscow, U.S. vice president Richard Nixon and Soviet premier Nikita Khrushchev have a "Kitchen Debate".
source_pages: American_National_Exhibition; Vice_President_of_the_United_States; Richard_Nixon; Premier_of_the_Soviet_Union; Nikita_Khrushchev; Kitchen_Debate

event_text: The Continental League is announced as baseball's "third major league" in the United States.
First United States Congress elections in Hawaii as a state of the Union.
Portugal's state police force PIDE fires upon striking workers in Bissau, Portuguese Guinea, killing over 50 people.
Explorer program: Explorer 6 launches from the Atlantic Missile Range in Cape Canaveral, Florida.
Sheremetyevo International Airport, the second-largest airport in Russia, opens.
Founding and first official meeting of the American Football League.
American Airlines Flight 514, a Boeing 707, crashes near the Calverton Executive Airpark in Calverton, New York, killing all five people on board.
Quake Lake is formed by the magnitude 7.2 1959 Hebgen Lake earthquake near Hebgen Lake in Montana.
United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs an executive order proclaiming Hawaii the 50th state of the union. Hawaii's admission is currently commemorated by Hawaii Admission Day.
South Vietnamese opposition figure Phan Quang Dan was elected to the National Assembly despite soldiers being bussed in to vote for President Ngo Dinh Diem's candidate.
A parcel bomb sent by Ngô Đình Nhu, younger brother and chief adviser of South Vietnamese President Ngô Đình Diệm, fails to kill King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia.
source_pages: Letter_bomb; Ngô_Đình_Nhu; South_Vietnam; Ngo_Dinh_Diem; Norodom_Sihanouk; Cambodia

event_text: The Soviet Union launches a large rocket, Lunik II, at the Moon.
Bonanza, the first regularly scheduled TV program presented in color, is launched in the United States.
Nikita Khrushchev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the United States.
The first successful photocopier, the Xerox 914, is introduced in a demonstration on live television from New York City.
TAI Flight 307 crashes during takeoff from Bordeaux–Mérignac Airport in Bordeaux, Nouvelle-Aquitaine, France, killing 55 people.
source_pages: TAI_Flight_307; Bordeaux–Mérignac_Airport; Bordeaux; Nouvelle-Aquitaine; France; September_24

event_text: Solomon Bandaranaike, Prime Minister of Sri Lanka, is mortally wounded by a Buddhist monk, Talduwe Somarama, and dies the next day.
Typhoon Vera, the strongest typhoon to hit Japan in recorded history, makes landfall, killing 4,580 people and leaving nearly 1.6 million others homeless.
Typhoon Vera kills nearly 5,000 people in Japan.
A Lockheed L-188 Electra crashes in Buffalo, Texas, killing 34 people.
The Soviet probe Luna 3 transmits the first-ever photographs of the far side of the Moon.
At the national congress of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance in Peru, a group of leftist radicals are expelled from the party who later form APRA Rebelde.
In New York City, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum opens to the public.
President Dwight D. Eisenhower approves the transfer of all US Army space-related activities to NASA, including most of the Army Ballistic Missile Agency.
Aeroflot Flight 200 crashes while attempting to land at Vnukovo International Airport, killing 28.
Piedmont Airlines Flight 349 crashes on approach to Charlottesville–Albemarle Airport in Albemarle County, Virginia, killing 26 of the 27 on board.
Quiz show scandals: Twenty-One game show contestant Charles Van Doren admits to a Congressional committee that he had been given questions and answers in advance.
The first section of the M1 motorway, the first inter-urban motorway in the United Kingdom, is opened between the present junctions 5 and 18, along with the M10 motorway and M45 motorway.
Four members of the Clutter family are murdered near Holcomb, Kansas, by Perry Smith and Richard Hickock, a crime later detailed by Truman Capote in his 1966 non-fiction novel In Cold Blood.
source_pages: Clutter_family_murders; Holcomb,_Kansas; Perry_Edward_Smith; Richard_Hickock; November_15; Truman_Capote; Non-fiction_novel; In_Cold_Blood

event_text: Aeroflot Flight 315 crashes on approach to Lviv Airport, killing all 40 people on board.
The Declaration of the Rights of the Child is adopted by the United Nations.
American disc jockey Alan Freed, who had popularized the term "rock and roll" and music of that style, is fired from WABC radio over allegations he had participated in the payola scandal.
French President Charles de Gaulle declares in a speech in Strasbourg his vision for "Europe, from the Atlantic to the Urals".
Cold War: Opening date for signature of the Antarctic Treaty, which sets aside Antarctica as a scientific preserve and bans military activity on the continent.
The current flag of Singapore is adopted, six months after Singapore became self-governing within the British Empire.
Archbishop Makarios III becomes the first President of Cyprus.
Cameroon achieves independence from France and the United Kingdom.
National Airlines Flight 2511 is destroyed in mid-air by a bomb, while en route from New York City to Miami.
The Associations Law comes into force in Iraq, allowing registration of political parties.
President of Egypt Gamal Abdel Nasser opens construction on the Aswan Dam by detonating ten tons of dynamite to demolish twenty tons of granite on the east bank of the Nile.
source_pages: President_of_Egypt; Gamal_Abdel_Nasser; Aswan_Dam; Dynamite; Nile; January_9

event_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia, the country's central bank and banknote issuing authority authorized by the 1959 Reserve Bank Act, is established.
Capital Airlines Flight 20 crashes into a farm in Charles City County, Virginia, killing all 50 aboard, the third fatal Capital Airlines crash in as many years.
Japan and the United States sign the US–Japan Mutual Security Treaty
Scandinavian Airlines System Flight 871 crashes near Ankara Esenboğa Airport in Turkey, killing all 42 aboard.
Little Joe 1B, a Mercury spacecraft, lifts off from Wallops Island, Virginia with Miss Sam, a female rhesus monkey on board.
Avianca Flight 671 crashes at Montego Bay, Jamaica airport, killing 37 people.
A coal mine collapses at Holly Country, South Africa, killing 435 miners.
The bathyscaphe USS Trieste breaks a depth record by descending to 10,911 metres (35,797 ft) in the Pacific Ocean.
Algerian War: Some units of European volunteers in Algiers stage an insurrection known as the "barricades week", during which they seize government buildings and clash with local police.
The National Association of Broadcasters in the United States reacts to the "payola" scandal by threatening fines for any disc jockeys who accept money for playing particular records.
The National Football League announces expansion teams for Dallas to start in the 1960 NFL season and Minneapolis-St. Paul for the 1961 NFL season.
The African National Party is founded in Chad, through the merger of traditionalist parties.
Four black students stage the first of the Greensboro sit-ins at a lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina.
British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan speaks of "a wind of change", signalling that his Government was likely to support decolonisation.
Queen Elizabeth II issues an Order-in-Council, proclaiming the House of Windsor and declaring that her descendants will take the name Mountbatten-Windsor.
The Hollywood Walk of Fame is founded.
With the success of a nuclear test codenamed "Gerboise Bleue", France becomes the fourth country to possess nuclear weapons.
Black college students stage the first of the Nashville sit-ins at three lunch counters in Nashville, Tennessee.
The U.S. Navy submarine USS Triton begins Operation Sandblast, setting sail from New London, Connecticut, to begin the first submerged circumnavigation of the globe.
China successfully launches the T-7, its first sounding rocket.
A New York-bound Alitalia airliner crashes into a cemetery in Shannon, Ireland, shortly after takeoff, killing 34 of the 52 persons on board.
A Kyiv-bound Aeroflot airliner crashes on approach to Snilow Airport in Lviv, killing 32 of the 33 people on board.
The French freighter La Coubre explodes in Havana, Cuba, killing 100.
Indonesian President Sukarno dismissed the Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat (DPR), 1955 democratically elected parliament, and replaced with DPR-GR, the parliament of his own selected members.
Dr. Belding Hibbard Scribner implants for the first time a shunt he invented into a patient, which allows the patient to receive hemodialysis on a regular basis.
U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs the National Security Council directive on the anti-Cuban covert action program that will ultimately lead to the Bay of Pigs Invasion.
Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 710 crashes in Tobin Township, Perry County, Indiana, killing 63.
Apartheid: Sharpeville massacre, South Africa: Police open fire on a group of black South African demonstrators, killing 69 and wounding 180.
Arthur Leonard Schawlow and Charles Hard Townes receive the first patent for a laser.
The TIROS-1 satellite transmits the first television picture from space.
France agrees to grant independence to the Mali Federation, a union of Senegal and French Sudan.
The Netherlands and West Germany sign an agreement to negotiate the return of German land annexed by the Dutch in return for 280 million German marks as Wiedergutmachung.
Dr. Hendrik Verwoerd, Prime Minister of South Africa and architect of apartheid, narrowly survives an assassination attempt by a white farmer, David Pratt in Johannesburg.
The United States launches Transit 1-B, the world's first satellite navigation system.

At Shaw University in Raleigh, North Carolina, Ella Baker leads a conference that results in the creation of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, one of the principal organizations of the civil rights movement in the 1960s.
Students in South Korea hold a nationwide pro-democracy protest against president Syngman Rhee, eventually forcing him to resign.
Brasília, Brazil's capital, is officially inaugurated. At 09:30, the Three Powers of the Republic are simultaneously transferred from the old capital, Rio de Janeiro.
The United States Navy submarine USS Triton completes the first submerged circumnavigation of the globe.
Forced out by the April Revolution, President of South Korea Syngman Rhee resigns after 12 years of dictatorial rule.
Cold War: U-2 incident: Francis Gary Powers, in a Lockheed U-2 spyplane, is shot down over the Sverdlovsk Oblast, Soviet Union, sparking a diplomatic crisis.
source_pages: Cold_War; 1960_U-2_incident; Francis_Gary_Powers; Lockheed_U-2; Reconnaissance_aircraft; Sverdlovsk_Oblast; Soviet_Union

event_text: More than 20 million viewers watch the first televised royal wedding when Princess Margaret marries Antony Armstrong-Jones at Westminster Abbey.
Cold War: U-2 Crisis of 1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev announces that his nation is holding American U-2 pilot Gary Powers.
The Food and Drug Administration announces it will approve birth control as an additional indication for Searle's Enovid, making Enovid the world's first approved oral contraceptive pill.
source_pages: Food_and_Drug_Administration; Birth_control; Indication_(medicine); G.D._Searle,_LLC; Mestranol/noretynodrel; Combined_oral_contraceptive_pill

event_text: Hundreds of University of California, Berkeley students congregate for the first day of protest against a visit by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
Theodore Maiman operates the first optical laser (a ruby laser), at Hughes Research Laboratories in Malibu, California.
The Great Chilean earthquake, measuring 9.5 on the moment magnitude scale, hits southern Chile, becoming the most powerful earthquake ever recorded.
A tsunami caused by an earthquake in Chile the previous day kills 61 people in Hilo, Hawaii.
Following the 1960 Valdivia earthquake, the largest ever recorded earthquake, Cordón Caulle begins to erupt.
In Turkey, a military coup removes President Celâl Bayar and the rest of the democratic government from office.
The Lake Bodom murders occur in Finland.
Trans Australia Airlines Flight 538 crashes near Mackay Airport in Mackay, Queensland, Australia, killing 29.
The Nez Perce tribe is awarded $4 million for 7 million acres (28,000 km2) of land undervalued at four cents/acre in the 1863 treaty.
Charlotte Motor Speedway holds its first NASCAR race, the inaugural World 600.
The Mali Federation gains independence from France (it later splits into Mali and Senegal).
The United States Food and Drug Administration declares Enovid to be the first officially approved combined oral contraceptive pill in the world.
Venezuelan President Rómulo Betancourt is injured in an assassination attempt.
Cold War: Two cryptographers working for the United States National Security Agency left for vacation to Mexico, and from there defected to the Soviet Union.
The former British Protectorate of British Somaliland gains its independence as Somaliland.
Madagascar gains its independence from France.
Belgian Congo gains independence as Republic of the Congo (Léopoldville).

The Trust Territory of Somaliland (the former Italian Somaliland) gains its independence from Italy. Concurrently, it unites as scheduled with the five-day-old State of Somaliland (the former British Somaliland) to form the Somali Republic.
Ghana becomes a republic and Kwame Nkrumah becomes its first President as Queen Elizabeth II ceases to be its head of state.
source_pages: Ghana; Republic; Kwame_Nkrumah; President_of_Ghana; Elizabeth_II; Head_of_state

event_text: Due to the post-Independence Day admission of Hawaii as the 50th U.S. state on August 21, 1959, the 50-star flag of the United States debuts in Philadelphia, almost ten and a half months later (see Flag Acts (United States)).
Francis Gary Powers is charged with espionage resulting from his flight over the Soviet Union.
France legislates for the independence of Dahomey (later Benin), Upper Volta (later Burkina Faso) and Niger.
Congo Crisis: The State of Katanga breaks away from the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee is first published, in the United States.
Orlyonok, the main Young Pioneer camp of the Russian SFSR, is founded.
Jane Goodall arrives at the Gombe Stream Reserve in present-day Tanzania to begin her study of chimpanzees in the wild.
Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 1-11 ditches off Polillo Island in the Philippines, killing one person and injuring 44.
The Polaris missile is successfully launched from a submarine, the USS George Washington, for the first time.
Sirimavo Bandaranaike is sworn in as prime minister of Ceylon, becoming the world's first democratically elected female head of government.
The German Volkswagen Act comes into force.
Dahomey (later renamed Benin) declares independence from France.
Islamabad is declared the federal capital of the Government of Pakistan.
Niger gains independence from France.
Burkina Faso, then known as Upper Volta, becomes independent from France.
Cuban Revolution: Cuba nationalizes American and foreign-owned property in the nation.
Ivory Coast becomes independent from France.
South Kasai secedes from the Congo.
Chad declares independence from France.
Echo 1A, NASA's first successful communications satellite, is launched.
The Central African Republic declares independence from France.
Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville) becomes independent from France.
Cyprus gains its independence from the United Kingdom.

Joseph Kittinger parachutes from a balloon over New Mexico, United States, at 102,800 feet (31,300 m), setting three records that held until 2012: High-altitude jump, free fall, and highest speed by a human without an aircraft.
Aeroflot Flight 036 crashes in Soviet Ukraine, killing 34.
Cold War: In Moscow, Russia, Soviet Union, downed American U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers is sentenced to ten years imprisonment by the Soviet Union for espionage.
Sputnik program: Korabl-Sputnik 2: The Soviet Union launches the satellite with the dogs Belka and Strelka, 40 mice, two rats and a variety of plants.
Senegal breaks from the Mali Federation, declaring its independence.
The Games of the XVII Olympiad commence in Rome, Italy.
Air France Flight 343 crashes on approach to Yoff Airport in Senegal, killing all 63 aboard.
The first election of the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile. The Tibetan community observes this date as Democracy Day.
Poet Léopold Sédar Senghor is the first elected President of Senegal.
Muhammad Ali (then known as Cassius Clay) wins the gold medal in the light heavyweight boxing competition at the Olympic Games in Rome.
In Huntsville, Alabama, US President Dwight D. Eisenhower formally dedicates the Marshall Space Flight Center (NASA had already activated the facility on July 1).
At the Summer Olympics in Rome, Abebe Bikila becomes the first sub-Saharan African to win a gold medal, winning the marathon in bare feet.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is founded.
Congo Crisis: Mobutu Sese Seko seizes power in a military coup, suspending parliament and the constitution.
Fidel Castro arrives in New York City as the head of the Cuban delegation to the United Nations.
Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Pakistani President Ayub Khan sign the Indus Waters Treaty for the control and management of the Indus, Chenab, Jhelum, Ravi, Sutlej and Beas rivers.
source_pages: Jawaharlal_Nehru; Ayub_Khan; Indus_Waters_Treaty; Indus_River; Chenab_River; Jhelum_River; Ravi_River; Sutlej; Beas_River; September_19

event_text: The Sudanese Republic is renamed Mali after the withdrawal of Senegal from the Mali Federation.
USS Enterprise, the world's first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, is launched.
In Chicago, the first televised debate takes place between presidential candidates Richard M. Nixon and John F. Kennedy.
Nigeria gains independence from the United Kingdom.
An airliner crashes on takeoff from Boston's Logan International Airport, killing 62 people.
Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev pounds his shoe on a desk at the United Nations to protest a Philippine assertion.
The United States imposes a near-total trade embargo against Cuba.
Nedelin catastrophe: An R-16 ballistic missile explodes on the launch pad at the Soviet Union's Baikonur Cosmodrome space facility, killing over 100 people, including Field Marshal Mitrofan Nedelin.
source_pages: Nedelin_catastrophe; R-16_(missile); Ballistic_missile; Soviet_Union; Baikonur_Cosmodrome; Mitrofan_Nedelin

event_text: An airplane carrying the Cal Poly football team crashes on takeoff in Toledo, Ohio.
Penguin Books is found not guilty of obscenity in the trial R v Penguin Books Ltd, the Lady Chatterley's Lover case.

The land that would become the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge is established by an Act of Congress after a year-long legal battle that pitted local residents against Port Authority of New York and New Jersey officials wishing to turn the Great Swamp into a major regional airport for jet aircraft.
At the Kasakela Chimpanzee Community in Tanzania, Dr. Jane Goodall observes chimpanzees creating tools, the first-ever observation in non-human animals.
John F. Kennedy is elected as the 35th President of the United States, defeating incumbent Vice President Richard Nixon, who would later be elected president in 1968  and 1972.

Robert McNamara is named president of the Ford Motor Company, becoming the first non-Ford family member to serve in that post. He resigns a month later to join the newly elected John F. Kennedy administration.
A military coup against President Ngô Đình Diệm of South Vietnam is crushed.
Ruby Bridges becomes the first black child to attend an all-white elementary school in Louisiana.
The Mirabal sisters of the Dominican Republic are assassinated.
Mauritania becomes independent of France.
Patrice Lumumba is arrested by Mobutu Sese Seko's men on the banks of the Sankuru River, for inciting the army to rebellion.
The musical Camelot debuts at the Majestic Theatre on Broadway. It will become associated with the Kennedy administration.
The first episode of Coronation Street, the world's longest-running television soap opera, is broadcast in the United Kingdom.
French forces crack down in a violent clash with protesters in French Algeria during a visit by French President Charles de Gaulle.
While Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia visits Brazil, his Imperial Bodyguard seizes the capital and proclaims him deposed and his son, Crown Prince Asfa Wossen, Emperor.
Convention against Discrimination in Education of UNESCO is adopted.
Richard Pavlick is arrested for plotting to assassinate U.S. President-Elect John F. Kennedy.
King Mahendra of Nepal suspends the country's constitution, dissolves parliament, dismisses the cabinet, and imposes direct rule.
A United Air Lines Douglas DC-8 and a TWA Lockheed Super Constellation collide over Staten Island, New York and crash, killing all 128 people aboard both aircraft and six more on the ground.
Troops loyal to Emperor Haile Selassie in Ethiopia crush the coup that began December 13, returning power to their leader upon his return from Brazil. Haile Selassie absolves his son of any guilt.
Munich C-131 crash: Twenty passengers and crew on board as well as 32 people on the ground are killed.
Vietnam War: The National Liberation Front of South Vietnam, popularly known as the Viet Cong, is formally established in Tân Lập village, present day Tây Ninh province.
Hilkka Saarinen née Pylkkänen is murdered in the so-called "oven homicide" case in Krootila, Kokemäki, Finland.
Cold War: After a series of economic retaliations against one another, the United States severs diplomatic relations with Cuba.
The SL-1 nuclear reactor, near Idaho Falls, Idaho, is destroyed by a steam explosion in the only reactor incident in the United States to cause immediate fatalities.
A protest by agricultural workers in Baixa de Cassanje, Portuguese Angola, turns into a revolt, opening the Angolan War of Independence, the first of the Portuguese Colonial Wars.
source_pages: Baixa_de_Cassanje; Portuguese_Angola; Strike_in_Baixa_do_Cassange; Angolan_War_of_Independence; Portuguese_Colonial_War; January_3

event_text: Aero Flight 311 crashes into the forest in Kvevlax, Finland, killing 25 people.
In France a referendum supports Charles de Gaulle's policies in Algeria.
British authorities announce they have uncovered the Soviet Portland spy ring in London.
Throgs Neck Bridge over the East River, linking New York City's boroughs of The Bronx and Queens, opens to road traffic.

U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower delivers a televised farewell address to the nation three days before leaving office, in which he warns against the accumulation of power by the "military–industrial complex" as well as the dangers of massive spending, especially deficit spending.

Former Congolese Prime Minister Patrice Lumumba is murdered together with former Minister of Youth and Sports of the Republic of the Congo Maurice Mpolo and former Senator from Kasai Province Joseph Okito in circumstances suggesting the support and complicity of the governments of Belgium and the United States.
John F. Kennedy is inaugurated as the 35th President of the United States of America, becoming the youngest man to be elected into that office, and the first Roman Catholic.
Goldsboro B-52 crash: A bomber carrying two H-bombs breaks up in mid-air over North Carolina. The uranium core of one weapon remains lost.
In Washington, D.C., US President John F. Kennedy delivers the first live presidential television news conference.
The Soviet submarine S-80 sinks when its snorkel malfunctions, flooding the boat.
Project Mercury: Mercury-Redstone 2: The chimpanzee Ham travels into outer space.

The United States Air Force begins Operation Looking Glass, and over the next 30 years, a "Doomsday Plane" is always in the air, with the capability of taking direct control of the United States' bombers and missiles in the event of the destruction of the SAC's command post.
The Angolan War of Independence and the greater Portuguese Colonial War begin.
The Beatles at the Cavern Club: Lunchtime – The Beatles perform under this name at The Cavern Club for the first time following their return to Liverpool from Hamburg.
source_pages: The_Beatles_at_the_Cavern_Club; The_Beatles; The_Cavern_Club; Liverpool; Hamburg; February_9

event_text: The Soviet Union launches Venera 1 towards Venus.
An allegedly 500,000-year-old rock is discovered near Olancha, California, US, that appears to anachronistically encase a spark plug.
Discovery of the chemical elements: Element 103, Lawrencium, is first synthesized at the University of California.
Sabena Flight 548 crashes in Belgium, killing 73, including the entire United States figure skating team along with several of their coaches and family members.
Explorer program: Explorer 9 (S-56a) is launched.
The first congress of the Spanish Trade Union Organisation is inaugurated.
Uganda becomes self-governing and holds its first elections.
Sputnik 9 successfully launches, carrying a dog and a human dummy, and demonstrating that the Soviet Union was ready to begin human spaceflight.
A USAF B-52 bomber carrying nuclear weapons crashes near Yuba City, California.
At the 1961 Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference, South Africa announces that it will withdraw from the Commonwealth when the South African Constitution of 1961 comes into effect.
The Quebec Board of the French Language is established.
ČSA Flight 511 crashes in Igensdorf, Germany, killing 52.
The Twenty-third Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, allowing residents of Washington, D.C., to vote in presidential elections.
The Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs is signed in New York City.
LAN-Chile Flight 621 crashes in the Andes mountains, killing 21 people, including Argentinian football player Eliseo Mouriño.
The trial of Adolf Eichmann begins in Jerusalem.
Space Race: The Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin becomes the first human to travel into outer space and perform the first crewed orbital flight, Vostok 1.
source_pages: Space_Race; Soviet_Union; Astronaut; Yuri_Gagarin; Outer_space; Orbit; Vostok_1; April_12

event_text: In a nationally broadcast speech, Cuban leader Fidel Castro declares that he is a Marxist–Leninist and that Cuba is going to adopt Communism.
Bay of Pigs Invasion: A group of Cuban exiles financed and trained by the CIA lands at the Bay of Pigs in Cuba with the aim of ousting Fidel Castro.
Cold War: Failure of the Bay of Pigs Invasion of US-backed Cuban exiles against Cuba.
Algiers putsch by French generals.
Robert Noyce is granted a patent for an integrated circuit.
K-19, the first Soviet nuclear submarine equipped with nuclear missiles, is commissioned.
The Prime Minister of Cuba, Fidel Castro, proclaims Cuba a socialist nation and abolishes elections.
American civil rights movement: The "Freedom Riders" begin a bus trip through the South.
Malcolm Ross and Victor Prather attain a new altitude record for manned balloon flight ascending in the Strato-Lab V open gondola to 113,740 feet (34.67 km).
Project Mercury: Alan Shepard becomes the first American to travel into outer space, on a sub-orbital flight.
Air France Flight 406 is destroyed by a bomb over the Sahara, killing 78.
Civil rights movement: A white mob twice attacks a Freedom Riders bus near Anniston, Alabama, before fire-bombing the bus and attacking the civil rights protesters who flee the burning vehicle.
Park Chung Hee leads a coup d'état to overthrow the Second Republic of South Korea.
Venera program: Venera 1 becomes the first man-made object to fly by another planet by passing Venus (the probe had lost contact with Earth a month earlier and did not send back any data).
At Silchar Railway Station, Assam, 11 Bengalis die when police open fire on protesters demanding state recognition of Bengali language in the Bengali Language Movement.
American civil rights movement: Alabama Governor John Malcolm Patterson declares martial law in an attempt to restore order after race riots break out.
American civil rights movement: Freedom Riders are arrested in Jackson, Mississippi, for "disturbing the peace" after disembarking from their bus.
Apollo program: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces, before a special joint session of the U.S. Congress, his goal to initiate a project to put a "man on the Moon" before the end of the decade.

Peter Benenson's article The Forgotten Prisoners is published in several internationally read newspapers. This will later be thought of as the founding of the human rights organization Amnesty International.
The long-time Dominican dictator Rafael Trujillo is assassinated in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic.
Viasa Flight 897 crashes after takeoff from Lisbon Airport, killing 61.

The South African Constitution of 1961 becomes effective, thus creating the Republic of South Africa, which remains outside the Commonwealth of Nations until 1 June 1994, when South Africa is returned to Commonwealth membership.
