The Black Panther Party is created by Huey P. Newton and Bobby Seale.
The 23rd Street Fire in New York City kills 12 firefighters.
A colliery spoil tip slips onto houses and a school in the village of Aberfan in Wales, killing 144 people, 116 of whom were schoolchildren.
The Cuban Adjustment Act comes into force, allowing 123,000 Cubans the opportunity to apply for permanent residence in the United States.

The Arno River floods Florence, Italy, to a maximum depth of 6.7 m (22 ft), leaving thousands homeless and destroying millions of masterpieces of art and rare books. Venice is also submerged on the same day at its record all-time acqua alta of 194 cm (76 in).
Former Massachusetts Attorney General Edward Brooke becomes the first African American elected to the United States Senate since Reconstruction.
U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs into law an antitrust exemption allowing the National Football League to merge with the upstart American Football League.
NASA launches Gemini 12.
In response to Fatah raids against Israelis near the West Bank border, Israel launches an attack on the village of As-Samu.
All Nippon Airways Flight 533 crashes into the Seto Inland Sea near Matsuyama Airport in Japan, killing 50 people.
Project Gemini: Gemini 12 completes the program's final mission, when it splashes down safely in the Atlantic Ocean.
Bulgarian TABSO Flight 101 crashes near Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, killing all 82 people on board.
Michel Micombero overthrows the monarchy of Burundi and makes himself the first president.
Decolonization: Barbados becomes independent from the United Kingdom.
The Greek ship SS Heraklion sinks in a storm in the Aegean Sea, killing over 200.
Saturn's moon Epimetheus is discovered by astronomer Richard Walker.
A Canadair CL-44 chartered by the United States military crashes into a small village in South Vietnam, killing 111.
The first Kwanzaa is celebrated by Maulana Karenga, the chair of Black Studies at California State University, Long Beach.
The Cave of Swallows, the largest known cave shaft in the world, is discovered in Aquismón, San Luis Potosí, Mexico.
Ronald Reagan, past movie actor and future President of the United States, is sworn in as Governor of California.
Cultural Revolution: The Shanghai People's Commune is established following the seizure of power from local city officials by revolutionaries.
Vietnam War: United States Marine Corps and ARVN troops launch "Operation Deckhouse Five" in the Mekong River delta.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; United_States_Marine_Corps; Army_of_the_Republic_of_Vietnam; Operation_Deckhouse_Five; Mekong; January_6

event_text: Dr. James Bedford becomes the first person to be cryonically preserved with intent of future resuscitation.
Counterculture of the 1960s: The Human Be-In takes place in San Francisco, California's Golden Gate Park, launching the Summer of Love.
source_pages: Counterculture_of_the_1960s; Human_Be-In; San_Francisco; Golden_Gate_Park; Summer_of_Love; January_14

event_text: The first Super Bowl is played in Los Angeles. The Green Bay Packers defeat the Kansas City Chiefs 35–10.
Albert DeSalvo, the "Boston Strangler", is convicted of numerous crimes and is sentenced to life imprisonment.
Between dozens and hundreds of anti-Somocista demonstrators are killed by the Nicaraguan National Guard in Managua.
Diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Ivory Coast are established.

Milton Keynes (England) is founded as a new town by Order in Council, with a planning brief to become a city of 250,000 people. Its initial designated area enclosed three existing towns and twenty-one villages. The area to be developed was largely farmland, with evidence of continuous settlement dating back to the Bronze Age.
South Vietnamese junta leader and Prime Minister Nguyen Cao Ky fires rival, Deputy Prime Minister and Defence Minister Nguyen Huu Co, while the latter is overseas on a diplomatic visit.
Apollo program: Astronauts Gus Grissom, Ed White and Roger Chaffee are killed in a fire during a test of their Apollo 1 spacecraft at the Kennedy Space Center, Florida.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Astronaut; Gus_Grissom; Ed_White_(astronaut); Roger_B._Chaffee; Apollo_1; Kennedy_Space_Center; Florida

event_text: Cold War: The Soviet Union, the United States, and the United Kingdom sign the Outer Space Treaty in Washington, D.C., banning deployment of nuclear weapons in space, and limiting the usage of the Moon and other celestial bodies to peaceful purposes.
source_pages: Cold_War; Soviet_Union; Outer_Space_Treaty; Washington,_D.C.; Nuclear_weapon; Moon; Astronomical_object

event_text: Lunar Orbiter program: Lunar Orbiter 3 lifts off from Cape Canaveral's Launch Complex 13 on its mission to identify possible landing sites for the Surveyor and Apollo spacecraft.
Cultural Revolution: The Shanghai People's Commune is formally proclaimed, with Yao Wenyuan and Zhang Chunqiao being appointed as its leaders.
The 25th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified.
American researchers discover the Madrid Codices by Leonardo da Vinci in the National Library of Spain.
Cultural Revolution: Zhang Chunqiao announces the dissolution of the Shanghai People's Commune, replacing its local government with a revolutionary committee.
Lake Central Airlines Flight 527 crashes near Marseilles, Ohio, killing 38.
Cold War: Joseph Stalin's daughter Svetlana Alliluyeva defects to the United States.
Trans World Airlines Flight 553 crashes in a field in Concord Township, Ohio, following a mid-air collision with a Beechcraft Baron, killing 26 people.
source_pages: Trans_World_Airlines; TWA_Flight_553; Concord_Township,_Champaign_County,_Ohio; Mid-air_collision; Beechcraft_Baron; March_9

event_text: Suharto takes power from Sukarno when the People's Consultative Assembly inaugurate him as Acting President of Indonesia.
The body of U.S. President John F. Kennedy is moved to a permanent burial place at Arlington National Cemetery.
The supertanker Torrey Canyon runs aground off the Cornish coast.
Ten thousand people gather for one of many Central Park be-ins in New York City.
Delta Air Lines Flight 9877 crashes at Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport, killing 19.
Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "Beyond Vietnam: A Time to Break Silence" speech in New York City's Riverside Church.
The first Boeing 737 (a 100 series) makes its maiden flight.
Gnassingbé Eyadéma overthrows Nicolas Grunitzky and installs himself as the new President of Togo, a title he will hold for the next 38 years.
A few days before the general election in Greece, Colonel George Papadopoulos leads a coup d'état, establishing a military regime that lasts for seven years.
Soviet space program: Soyuz 1 (Russian: Союз 1, Union 1) a crewed spaceflight carrying cosmonaut Colonel Vladimir Komarov is launched into orbit.
Cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov dies in Soyuz 1 when its parachute fails to open. He is the first human to die during a space mission.

Vietnam War: American General William Westmoreland says in a news conference that the enemy had "gained support in the United States that gives him hope that he can win politically that which he cannot win militarily".
Expo 67 officially opens in Montreal, Quebec, Canada with a large opening ceremony broadcast around the world. It opens to the public the next day.
Vietnam War: Boxer Muhammad Ali refuses his induction into the United States Army and is subsequently stripped of his championship and license.
After refusing induction into the United States Army the previous day, Muhammad Ali is stripped of his boxing title.
The Philippine province of Davao is split into three: Davao del Norte, Davao del Sur, and Davao Oriental.
The Northrop M2-F2 crashes on landing, becoming the inspiration for the novel Cyborg and TV series The Six Million Dollar Man.
Dr. Zakir Husain becomes the third President of India. He is the first Muslim President of the Indian Union. He holds this position until August 24, 1969.
Six-Day War: President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt demands dismantling of the peace-keeping UN Emergency Force in Egypt.
The Popular Movement of the Revolution political party is established in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Egypt closes the Straits of Tiran to Israeli shipping.
L'Innovation department store in Brussels, Belgium, burns down, resulting in 323 dead or missing and 150 injured, the most devastating fire in Belgian history.
Egypt imposes a blockade and siege of the Red Sea coast of Israel.
Belle de Jour, directed by Luis Buñuel, is released.
The Beatles' album Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band is released.
Australians vote in favor of a constitutional referendum granting the Australian government the power to make laws to benefit Indigenous Australians and to count them in the national census.
The U.S. Navy aircraft carrier USS John F. Kennedy is launched by Jacqueline Kennedy and her daughter Caroline.
The Nigerian Eastern Region declares independence as the Republic of Biafra, sparking a civil war.
Luis Monge is executed in Colorado's gas chamber, in the last pre-Furman execution in the United States.

Protests in West Berlin against the arrival of the Shah of Iran are brutally suppressed, during which Benno Ohnesorg is killed by a police officer. His death results in the founding of the terrorist group Movement 2 June.
Seventy-two people are killed when a Canadair C-4 Argonaut crashes at Stockport in England.
The Six-Day War begins: Israel launches surprise strikes against Egyptian air-fields in response to the mobilisation of Egyptian forces on the Israeli border.
Six-Day War: Israeli soldiers enter Jerusalem.
Six-Day War: The USS Liberty incident: A United States Navy spy ship is attacked by the Israeli Air Force and Navy, resulting in 34 deaths and 171 wounded.
source_pages: Six-Day_War; USS_Liberty_incident; United_States_Navy; Spy_ship; Israeli_Air_Force; June_8

event_text: Six-Day War: Israel captures the Golan Heights from Syria.
The Six-Day War ends: Israel and Syria agree to a cease-fire.
The United States Supreme Court in Loving v. Virginia declares all U.S. state laws that prohibit interracial marriage to be unconstitutional.
U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson nominates Solicitor-General Thurgood Marshall to become the first black justice on the U.S. Supreme Court.
Mariner program: Mariner 5 is launched towards Venus.
Nuclear weapons testing: China announces a successful test of its first thermonuclear weapon.
Cold War: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with Soviet Premier Alexei Kosygin in Glassboro, New Jersey for the three-day Glassboro Summit Conference.
Karol Wojtyła (later John Paul II) is made a cardinal by Pope Paul VI.
Merger Treaty: The European Community is formally created out of a merger between the Common Market, the European Coal and Steel Community, and the European Atomic Energy Commission.
The Aden Emergency: The Battle of the Crater in which the British Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders retake the Crater district following the Arab Police mutiny.
Nigerian Civil War: Nigerian forces invade Biafra, beginning the war.
Riots begin in Newark, New Jersey.

Piedmont Airlines Flight 22, a Piedmont Airlines Boeing 727-22 and a twin-engine Cessna 310 collided over Hendersonville, North Carolina, USA. Both aircraft were destroyed and all passengers and crew were killed, including John T. McNaughton, an advisor to Robert McNamara.
source_pages: Piedmont_Airlines_Flight_22; Piedmont_Airlines_(1948–1989); Boeing_727; Cessna_310; Hendersonville,_North_Carolina; United_States; John_McNaughton_(government_official); Robert_McNamara; July_19

event_text: Detroit Riots: In Detroit, one of the worst riots in United States history begins on 12th Street in the predominantly African American inner city. It ultimately kills 43 people, injures 342 and burns about 1,400 buildings.

During an official state visit to Canada, French President Charles de Gaulle declares to a crowd of over 100,000 in Montreal: Vive le Québec libre! ("Long live free Quebec!"); the statement angered the Canadian government and many Anglophone Canadians.
Vietnam War: Off the coast of North Vietnam the USS Forrestal catches on fire in the worst U.S. naval disaster since World War II, killing 134.
During the fourth day of celebrating its 400th anniversary, the city of Caracas, Venezuela is shaken by an earthquake, leaving approximately 500 dead.
The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is founded by Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.
source_pages: ASEAN; Indonesia; Malaysia; Philippines; Singapore; Thailand

event_text: Two young women became the first fatal victims of grizzly bear attacks in the 57-year history of Montana's Glacier National Park in separate incidents.
UK Marine Broadcasting Offences Act 1967 declares participation in offshore pirate radio illegal.

Led by Abbie Hoffman, the Youth International Party temporarily disrupts trading at the New York Stock Exchange by throwing dollar bills from the viewing gallery, causing trading to cease as brokers scramble to grab them.
George Lincoln Rockwell, founder of the American Nazi Party, is assassinated by a former member of his group.
Thurgood Marshall is confirmed as the first African American Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
Six-Day War: The Khartoum Resolution is issued at the Arab Summit, and eight countries adopt the "three 'no's against Israel".
Dagen H in Sweden: Traffic changes from driving on the left to driving on the right overnight.
Vietnam War: Operation Swift begins when U.S. Marines engage the North Vietnamese in battle in the Que Son Valley.
The people of Gibraltar vote to remain a British dependency rather than becoming part of Spain.
China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) launched an attack on Indian posts at Nathu La, Sikkim, India, which resulted in military clashes.
The Cunard Liner Queen Elizabeth 2 is launched in Clydebank, Scotland.
Seven people die, 46 people are injured, and more than 150 boats capsize when a squall hit Lake Michigan during Michigan's first coho salmon sport fishing season.
Thurgood Marshall is sworn in as the first African-American justice of the United States Supreme Court.
Omar Ali Saifuddien III of Brunei abdicates in favour of his son.
Guerrilla leader Che Guevara and his men are captured in Bolivia.
A day after his capture, Ernesto "Che" Guevara is executed for attempting to incite a revolution in Bolivia.
The Outer Space Treaty comes into force.
A bomb explodes on board Cyprus Airways Flight 284 while flying over the Mediterranean Sea, killing 66.
The Soviet probe Venera 4 reaches Venus and becomes the first spacecraft to measure the atmosphere of another planet.
The National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam organizes a march of fifty thousand people from the Lincoln Memorial to the Pentagon.
Mohammad Reza Pahlavi crowns himself Emperor of Iran.
Montreal's World Fair, Expo 67, closes with over 50 million visitors.
Vietnam War: US President Lyndon B. Johnson and "The Wise Men" conclude that the American people should be given more optimistic reports on the progress of the war.
Vietnam War: The Battle of Dak To begins.
Iberia Flight 062 crashes in Blackdown, West Sussex, killing all 37 people on board including British actress June Thorburn.
Carl B. Stokes is elected as Mayor of Cleveland, Ohio, becoming the first African American mayor of a major American city.
US President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, establishing the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
Apollo program: NASA launches the unmanned Apollo 4 test spacecraft, atop the first Saturn V rocket, from Florida's Cape Kennedy.
The Nauru Independence Act 1967 passed the Parliament of Australia, giving independence to the UN Trust Territory of Nauru with effect from 31 January 1968.
Vietnam War: In a propaganda ceremony in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, three American prisoners of war are released by the Viet Cong and turned over to "new left" antiwar activist Tom Hayden.
The Congress of Colombia, in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the death of Policarpa Salavarrieta, declares this day as "Day of the Colombian Woman".
American physicist Theodore Maiman is given a patent for his ruby laser systems, the world's first laser.

The only fatality of the North American X-15 program occurs during the 191st flight when Air Force test pilot Michael J. Adams loses control of his aircraft which is destroyed mid-air over the Mojave Desert.
Aeroflot Flight 2230 crashes near Koltsovo Airport, killing 107.

Vietnam War: Acting on optimistic reports that he had been given on November 13, U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson tells the nation that, while much remained to be done, "We are inflicting greater losses than we're taking...We are making progress."
The establishment of TVB, the first wireless commercial television station in Hong Kong.
Vietnam War: American General William Westmoreland tells news reporters: "I am absolutely certain that whereas in 1965 the enemy was winning, today he is certainly losing."
UN Security Council Resolution 242 is adopted, establishing a set of the principles aimed at guiding negotiations for an Arab–Israeli peace settlement.
The first pulsar (PSR B1919+21, in the constellation of Vulpecula) is discovered by two astronomers Jocelyn Bell Burnell and Antony Hewish.
U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara announces his resignation.
The People's Republic of Southern Yemen gains its independence from the United Kingdom
The Pakistan Peoples Party is founded by Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who becomes its first chairman.
Pro-Soviet communists in the Philippines establish Malayang Pagkakaisa ng Kabataan Pilipino as its new youth wing.
At Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town, South Africa, a transplant team headed by Christiaan Barnard carries out the first heart transplant on a human (53-year-old Louis Washkansky).
Adrian Kantrowitz performs the first human heart transplant in the United States.
Constantine II of Greece attempts an unsuccessful counter-coup against the Regime of the Colonels.
Harold Holt, Prime Minister of Australia, disappears while swimming near Portsea, Victoria, and is presumed drowned.
Harold Holt, the Prime Minister of Australia, is officially presumed dead.
A Pennsylvania Railroad Budd Metroliner exceeds 249 kilometres per hour (155 mph) on their New York Division, also present-day Amtrak's Northeast Corridor.
Louis Washkansky, the first man to undergo a human-to-human heart transplant, dies in Cape Town, South Africa, having lived for 18 days after the transplant.
American businesswoman Muriel Siebert becomes the first woman to own a seat on the New York Stock Exchange.
Aeroflot Flight L-51 crashes near Liepāja International Airport in Liepāja, Latvia, killing 43.
Alexander Dubček comes to power in Czechoslovakia, effectively beginning the "Prague Spring".
Aeroflot Flight 1668 crashes near Olyokminsk, killing 45.
Surveyor program: Surveyor 7, the last spacecraft in the Surveyor series, lifts off from Cape Canaveral Launch Complex 36A.
Johnny Cash performs live at Folsom State Prison.
Vietnam War, Battle of Khe Sanh: One of the most publicized and controversial battles of the war begins.
A B-52 bomber crashes near Thule Air Base, contaminating the area after its nuclear payload ruptures. One of the four bombs remains unaccounted for after the cleanup operation is complete.
Apollo Program: Apollo 5 lifts off carrying the first Lunar module into space.
Operation Igloo White, a US electronic surveillance system to stop communist infiltration into South Vietnam begins installation.
USS Pueblo (AGER-2) is attacked and seized by the Korean People's Navy.
Vietnam War: The 1st Australian Task Force launches Operation Coburg against the North Vietnamese Army and Viet Cong during wider fighting around Long Bình and Biên Hòa.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; 1st_Australian_Task_Force; Operation_Coburg; People's_Army_of_Vietnam; Viet_Cong; Long_Bình,_Biên_Hòa; Biên_Hòa

event_text: Vietnam War: Tet Offensive launch by forces of the Viet Cong and North Vietnamese Army against South Vietnam, the United States, and their allies.
Vietnam War: Viet Cong guerrillas attack the United States embassy in Saigon, and other attacks, in the early morning hours, later grouped together as the Tet Offensive.

Vietnam War: The execution of Viet Cong officer Nguyễn Văn Lém by South Vietnamese National Police Chief Nguyễn Ngọc Loan is recorded on motion picture film, as well as in an iconic still photograph taken by Eddie Adams.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; Viet_Cong; Saigon_Execution; South_Vietnam; Nguyễn_Ngọc_Loan; Eddie_Adams_(photographer); February_1

event_text: Canada's three military services, the Royal Canadian Navy, the Canadian Army and the Royal Canadian Air Force, are unified into the Canadian Forces.
The New York Central Railroad and the Pennsylvania Railroad are merged to form Penn Central Transportation.
American civil rights movement: An attack on Black students from South Carolina State University who are protesting racial segregation leaves three dead and 28 injured in Orangeburg, South Carolina.
source_pages: Civil_rights_movement; Orangeburg_Massacre; South_Carolina_State_University; Racial_segregation; Orangeburg,_South_Carolina; February_8

event_text: Phong Nhị and Phong Nhất massacre.
In Haleyville, Alabama, the first 9-1-1 emergency telephone system goes into service.
Civil Air Transport Flight 010 crashes near Shongshan Airport in Taiwan, killing 21 of the 63 people on board and one more on the ground.
The China Academy of Space Technology, China's main arm for the research, development, and creation of space satellites, is established in Beijing.
Vietnam War: The Tet Offensive is halted; South Vietnamese forces led by Ngo Quang Truong recapture the citadel of Hué.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; Tet_Offensive; South_Vietnam; Ngô_Quang_Trưởng; Battle_of_Huế; Imperial_City_of_Huế; February_24

event_text: Baggeridge Colliery closes marking the end of over 300 years of coal mining in the Black Country.
Air France Flight 212 crashes into La Grande Soufrière, killing all 63 aboard.
Three rebels are executed by Rhodesia, the first executions since UDI, prompting international condemnation.
Mauritius gains independence from the United Kingdom.
Vietnam War: My Lai massacre occurs; between 347 and 500 Vietnamese villagers are killed by American troops.
As a result of nerve gas testing by the U.S. Army Chemical Corps in Skull Valley, Utah, over 6,000 sheep are found dead.
Gold standard: The U.S. Congress repeals the requirement for a gold reserve to back US currency.
Battle of Karameh in Jordan between the Israel Defense Forces and the combined forces of the Jordanian Armed Forces and PLO.
Brazilian high school student Edson Luís de Lima Souto is killed by military police at a student protest.
The funeral of Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space, started in Moscow, with thousands of people in attendance.

American President Lyndon B. Johnson speaks to the nation of "Steps to Limit the War in Vietnam" in a television address. At the conclusion of his speech, he announces: "I shall not seek, and I will not accept, the nomination of my party for another term as your President."
Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I've Been to the Mountaintop" speech; he was assassinated the next day.
Martin Luther King Jr. is assassinated by James Earl Ray at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee.
Apollo program: NASA launches Apollo 6.
In the downtown district of Richmond, Indiana, a double explosion kills 41 and injures 150.
Pierre Elliott Trudeau wins the Liberal Party leadership election, and becomes Prime Minister of Canada soon afterward.
Two-time Formula One British World Champion Jim Clark dies in an accident during a Formula Two race in Hockenheim.

BOAC Flight 712 catches fire shortly after takeoff. As a result of her actions in the accident, Barbara Jane Harrison is awarded a posthumous George Cross, the only GC awarded to a woman in peacetime.
The TEV Wahine, a New Zealand ferry sinks in Wellington harbour due to a fierce storm – the strongest winds ever in Wellington. Out of the 734 people on board, fifty-three died.
US President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Civil Rights Act of 1968, prohibiting discrimination in the sale, rental, and financing of housing.
A failed assassination attempt on Rudi Dutschke, leader of the German student movement, leaves Dutschke suffering from brain damage.
English politician Enoch Powell makes his controversial "Rivers of Blood" speech.
South African Airways Flight 228 crashes near J.G. Strijdom Airport in South West Africa (now Hosea Kutako International Airport in Namibia), killing 123 people.
Vietnam War: Student protesters at Columbia University in New York City take over administration buildings and shut down the university.
Eighty-five people are killed when Braniff International Airways Flight 352 crashes near Dawson, Texas.
Vietnam War: North Vietnamese and Viet Cong forces attack Australian troops defending Fire Support Base Coral.
The nuclear-powered submarine USS Scorpion sinks with 99 men aboard, 400 nautical miles (740 km) southwest of the Azores.
The Gateway Arch in St. Louis, Missouri, is dedicated.
H-dagurinn in Iceland: Traffic changes from driving on the left to driving on the right overnight.
Garuda Indonesian Airways Flight 892 crashes near Nala Sopara in India, killing 30.

Charles de Gaulle reappears publicly after his flight to Baden-Baden, West Germany, and dissolves the French National Assembly by a radio appeal. Immediately after, less than one million of his supporters march on the Champs-Élysées in Paris. This is the turning point of May 1968 events in France.
Presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy is assassinated by Sirhan Sirhan.
James Earl Ray, the man who assassinated Martin Luther King Jr. is arrested at London Heathrow Airport.
U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson declares a national day of mourning following the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
Lloyd J. Old identified the first cell surface antigens that could differentiate among different cell types.
Seventy-four people were killed and 150 other injured in a stampede at a football match between Boca Juniors and Club Atlético River Plate in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
Pope Paul VI issues the Credo of the People of God.
The United States Central Intelligence Agency's Phoenix Program is officially established.
The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons is signed in Washington, D.C., London and Moscow by sixty-two countries.
Formal separation of the United Auto Workers from the AFL–CIO in the United States.
The Chrysler wildcat strike begins in Detroit, Michigan.
Abdul Rahman Arif is overthrown and the Ba'ath Party is installed as the governing power in Iraq with Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr as the new Iraqi President.
Intel is founded in Mountain View, California.
The first International Special Olympics Summer Games are held at Soldier Field in Chicago, with about 1,000 athletes with intellectual disabilities.

Glenville shootout: In Cleveland, Ohio, a violent shootout between a Black Militant organization and the Cleveland Police Department occurs. During the shootout, a riot begins and lasts for five days.

The only successful hijacking of an El Al aircraft takes place when a Boeing 707 carrying ten crew and 38 passengers is taken over by three members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. The aircraft was en route from Rome, to Lod, Israel.
Vietnam War: South Vietnamese opposition leader Trương Đình Dzu is sentenced to five years hard labor for advocating the formation of a coalition government as a way to move toward an end to the war.
The coronation of Hassanal Bolkiah, the 29th Sultan of Brunei, is held.
An earthquake hits Casiguran, Aurora, Philippines killing more than 270 people and wounding 261.
Alexandros Panagoulis attempts to assassinate the Greek dictator Colonel Georgios Papadopoulos in Varkiza, Athens.

Cold War: Warsaw Pact troops invade Czechoslovakia, crushing the Prague Spring. East German participation is limited to a few specialists due to memories of the recent war. Only Albania and Romania refuse to participate.

Cold War: Nicolae Ceaușescu, leader of the Socialist Republic of Romania, publicly condemns the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia, encouraging the Romanian population to arm itself against possible Soviet reprisals.
James Anderson Jr. posthumously receives the first Medal of Honor to be awarded to an African American U.S. Marine.
Pope Paul VI arrives in Bogotá, Colombia. It is the first visit of a pope to Latin America.
Police and protesters clash during 1968 Democratic National Convention protests as protesters chant "The whole world is watching".
Operation OAU begins during the Nigerian Civil War.
Swaziland becomes independent.
Air France Flight 1611 crashes off Nice, France, killing 89 passengers and six crew.
John Eliot Gardiner conducts Monteverdi's Vespro della Beata Vergine with the Monteverdi Choir at the Proms.
Cold War: Albania leaves the Warsaw Pact.
The Soviet Zond 5 spaceship is launched, becoming the first spacecraft to fly around the Moon and re-enter the Earth's atmosphere.
The Boeing 747 is rolled out and shown to the public for the first time.
Guyana nationalizes the British Guiana Broadcasting Service, which would eventually become part of the National Communications Network, Guyana.
Mexican President Gustavo Díaz Ordaz orders soldiers to suppress a demonstration of unarmed students, ten days before the start of the 1968 Summer Olympics.
A Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association march in Derry is violently suppressed by police.
NASA launches Apollo 7, the first successful crewed Apollo mission.
Equatorial Guinea becomes independent from Spain.
Apollo program: The first live television broadcast by American astronauts in orbit is performed by the Apollo 7 crew.
The 6.5 Mw  Meckering earthquake shakes the southwest portion of Western Australia with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), causing $2.2 million in damage and leaving 20–28 people injured.
Jim Hines becomes the first man ever to break the so-called "ten-second barrier" in the 100-meter sprint with a time of 9.95 seconds.
Tommie Smith and John Carlos are ejected from the US Olympic team for participating in the Olympics Black Power salute.
Kingston, Jamaica is rocked by the Rodney riots, inspired by the barring of Walter Rodney from the country.
Yasunari Kawabata becomes the first Japanese person to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
A Fairchild F-27 crashes into Moose Mountain while on approach to Lebanon Municipal Airport in Lebanon, New Hampshire, killing 32 people.
Space Race: The Soyuz 3 mission achieves the first Soviet space rendezvous.

A squad of 120 North Korean Army commandos land in boats along a 25-mile long section of the eastern coast of South Korea in a failed attempt to overthrow the dictatorship of Park Chung Hee and bring about the reunification of Korea.

Vietnam War October surprise: Citing progress with the Paris peace talks, US President Lyndon B. Johnson announces to the nation that he has ordered a complete cessation of "all air, naval, and artillery bombardment of North Vietnam" effective November 1.
The Motion Picture Association of America's film rating system is officially introduced, originating with the ratings G, M, R, and X.
Richard Nixon is elected as 37th President of the United States.
The Vienna Convention on Road Traffic is signed to facilitate international road traffic and to increase road safety by standardising the uniform traffic rules among the signatories.
Vietnam War: Operation Commando Hunt initiated. The goal is to interdict men and supplies on the Ho Chi Minh trail, through Laos into South Vietnam.
The Cleveland Transit System becomes the first transit system in the western hemisphere to provide direct rapid transit service from a city's downtown to its major airport.
British European Airways introduces the BAC One-Eleven into commercial service.

Viewers of the Raiders–Jets football game in the eastern United States are denied the opportunity to watch its exciting finish when NBC broadcasts Heidi instead, prompting changes to sports broadcasting in the U.S.
A total of 78 miners are killed in an explosion at the Consolidated Coal Company's No. 9 mine in Farmington, West Virginia in the Farmington Mine disaster.
Japan Air Lines Flight 2 accidentally ditches in San Francisco Bay while on approach to San Francisco International Airport. No one is injured.
The Old Student House in Helsinki, Finland is occupied by a large group of University of Helsinki students.
Vietnam War: United States Air Force helicopter pilot James P. Fleming rescues an Army Special Forces unit pinned down by Viet Cong fire. He is later awarded the Medal of Honor.
Penny Ann Early becomes the first woman to play in a major professional men's basketball league, for the Kentucky Colonels in an ABA game against the Los Angeles Stars.
Wien Consolidated Airlines Flight 55 crashes into Pedro Bay, Alaska, killing all 39 people on board.
Douglas Engelbart gave what became known as "The Mother of All Demos", publicly debuting the computer mouse, hypertext, and the bit-mapped graphical user interface using the oN-Line System (NLS).
source_pages: Douglas_Engelbart; The_Mother_of_All_Demos; Computer_mouse; Hypertext; Graphical_user_interface; NLS_(computer_system)

event_text: Japan's biggest heist, the still-unsolved "300 million yen robbery", is carried out in Tokyo.
Brazilian President Artur da Costa e Silva issues AI-5 (Institutional Act No. 5), enabling government by decree and suspending habeas corpus.
Second Vatican Council: Official revocation of the Edict of Expulsion of Jews from Spain.
The Zodiac Killer murders his first two officially confirmed victims, David Arthur Faraday and Betty Lou Jensen, on Lake Herman Road in Benicia, California, United States.
Apollo program: Apollo 8 is launched from the Kennedy Space Center, placing its crew on a lunar trajectory for the first visit to another celestial body by humans.
Cultural Revolution: People's Daily posted the instructions of Mao Zedong that "The intellectual youth must go to the country, and will be educated from living in rural poverty."
The 82 sailors from the USS Pueblo are released after eleven months of internment in North Korea.

Apollo program: The crew of Apollo 8 enters into orbit around the Moon, becoming the first humans to do so. They performed ten lunar orbits, took the Earthrise photograph, broadcast live TV pictures, and read the first ten verses of Genesis.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Apollo_8; Moon; Lunar_orbit; Earthrise; Apollo_8_Genesis_reading; December_24

event_text: Apollo program: Apollo 8 performs the first successful Trans-Earth injection (TEI) maneuver, sending the crew and spacecraft on a trajectory back to Earth from Lunar orbit.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Apollo_8; Trans-Earth_injection; Earth; Lunar_orbit; December_25

event_text: Kilvenmani massacre: Forty-four Dalits (untouchables) are burnt to death in Kizhavenmani village, Tamil Nadu, a retaliation for a campaign for higher wages by Dalit laborers.
The Communist Party of the Philippines is established by Jose Maria Sison, breaking away from the Partido Komunista ng Pilipinas-1930.
Apollo program: Apollo 8 splashes down in the Pacific Ocean, ending the first orbital crewed mission to the Moon.
North Central Airlines Flight 458 crashes at O'Hare International Airport, killing 28.
The first flight of the Tupolev Tu-144, the first civilian supersonic transport in the world.
MacRobertson Miller Airlines Flight 1750 crashes near Port Hedland, Western Australia, killing all 26 people on board.
The Venera 5 space probe is launched at 06:28:08 UTC from Baikonur.
Ariana Afghan Airlines Flight 701 crashes in Fernhill, West Sussex, UK, while on approach to Gatwick Airport, killing 50 people.
Allegheny Airlines Flight 737 crashes in Lafayette Township, McKean County, Pennsylvania, United States, killing 11.

The New York Jets of the American Football League defeat the Baltimore Colts of the National Football League to win Super Bowl III in what is considered to be one of the greatest upsets in sports history.
USS Enterprise fire: An accidental explosion aboard the USS Enterprise near Hawaii kills 28 people.
The Soviet Union launches Soyuz 5.
Czech student Jan Palach commits suicide by self-immolation in Prague, Czechoslovakia, in protest against the Soviets' crushing of the Prague Spring the year before.
source_pages: Czechs; Jan_Palach; Self-immolation; Prague; Soviet_Union; Prague_Spring; January_16

event_text: Space Race: Soviet spacecraft Soyuz 4 and Soyuz 5 perform the first-ever docking of crewed spacecraft in orbit, the first-ever transfer of crew from one space vehicle to another, and the only time such a transfer was accomplished with a space walk.
Black Panther Party members Bunchy Carter and John Huggins are killed during a meeting in Campbell Hall on the campus of UCLA.
United Airlines Flight 266 crashes into Santa Monica Bay killing all 32 passengers and six crew members.

Student Jan Palach dies after setting himself on fire three days earlier in Prague's Wenceslas Square to protest about the invasion of Czechoslovakia by the Soviet Union in 1968. His funeral turns into another major protest.
source_pages: Jan_Palach; Prague; Wenceslas_Square; Warsaw_Pact_invasion_of_Czechoslovakia; Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic; Soviet_Union

event_text: Brazilian Army captain Carlos Lamarca deserts in order to fight against the military dictatorship, taking with him ten machine guns and 63 rifles.
The Beatles' last public performance, on the roof of Apple Records in London. The impromptu concert is broken up by the police.
American aquanaut Berry L. Cannon dies of carbon dioxide poisoning while attempting to repair a leak in the SEALAB III underwater habitat. The SEALAB project was subsequently abandoned.
The 1969 Portugal earthquake hits Portugal, Spain and Morocco.
In Toulouse, France, the first test flight of the Anglo-French Concorde is conducted.
Apollo program: NASA launches Apollo 9 to test the lunar module.
In Memphis, Tennessee, James Earl Ray pleads guilty to assassinating Martin Luther King Jr. He later unsuccessfully attempts to recant.
Apollo 9 returns safely to Earth after testing the Lunar Module.
A Viasa McDonnell Douglas DC-9 crashes in Maracaibo, Venezuela, killing 155.
Golda Meir becomes the first female Prime Minister of Israel.
The United States begins secretly bombing the Sihanouk Trail in Cambodia, used by communist forces to infiltrate South Vietnam.
The 385-metre-tall (1,263 ft) TV-mast at Emley Moor transmitting station, United Kingdom, collapses due to ice build-up.
A United Arab airlines (now Egyptair) Ilyushin Il-18 crashes at Aswan international Airport, killing 100 people.
Greek poet and Nobel Prize laureate Giorgos Seferis makes a famous statement on the BBC World Service opposing the junta in Greece.
The Hawker Siddeley Harrier, the first operational fighter aircraft with Vertical/Short Takeoff and Landing capabilities, enters service with the Royal Air Force.
LOT Polish Airlines Flight 165 crashes into the Polica mountain near Zawoja, Poland, killing 53.
Vietnam War: United States Secretary of Defense Melvin Laird announces that the United States will start to "Vietnamize" the war effort.
Dr. Denton Cooley implants the first temporary artificial heart.
The Internet's symbolic birth date: Publication of RFC 1.
The first British-built Concorde 002 makes its maiden flight from Filton to RAF Fairford with Brian Trubshaw as the test pilot.
The EC-121 shootdown incident: North Korea shoots down a United States Navy aircraft over the Sea of Japan, killing all 31 on board.
Sirhan Sirhan is convicted of assassinating Robert F. Kennedy.
Communist Party of Czechoslovakia chairman Alexander Dubček is deposed.
British yachtsman Sir Robin Knox-Johnston wins the Sunday Times Golden Globe Race and completes the first solo non-stop circumnavigation of the world.
The formation of the Communist Party of India (Marxist–Leninist) is announced at a mass rally in Calcutta.
Charles de Gaulle resigns as President of France.
The British ocean liner Queen Elizabeth 2 departs on her maiden voyage to New York City.
Carlos Lamarca leads the first urban guerrilla action against the military dictatorship of Brazil in São Paulo, by robbing two banks.
Vietnam War: The Battle of Dong Ap Bia begins with an assault on Hill 937. It will ultimately become known as Hamburger Hill.
In the aftermath of the 1969 Malaysian general election, Sino-Malay sectarian violence erupted in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
Venera program: Venera 5, a Soviet space probe, lands on Venus.
Venera program: Soviet Venera 6 begins its descent into the atmosphere of Venus, sending back atmospheric data before being crushed by pressure.
Apollo program: Apollo 10 is launched.
The Battle of Hamburger Hill in Vietnam ends.
Civil unrest in Rosario, Argentina, known as Rosariazo, following the death of a 15-year-old student.
Apollo 10's Lunar Module flies within 8.4 nautical miles (16 km) of the Moon's surface.
Apollo program: Apollo 10 returns to Earth after a successful eight-day test of all the components needed for the forthcoming first crewed Moon landing.
Melbourne–Evans collision: off the coast of South Vietnam, the Australian aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne cuts the U.S. Navy destroyer USS Frank E. Evans in half; resulting in 74 deaths.

The Cuyahoga River catches fire in Cleveland, Ohio, drawing national attention to water pollution, and spurring the passing of the Clean Water Act and the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Warren E. Burger is sworn in as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court by retiring Chief Justice Earl Warren.
IBM announces that effective January 1970 it will price its software and services separately from hardware thus creating the modern software industry.
Stonewall riots begin in New York City, marking the start of the Gay Rights Movement.
The Apollo 11 lunar landing mission is launched from Cape Kennedy in Florida, USA.
Chappaquiddick incident: U.S. Senator Ted Kennedy crashes his car into a tidal pond at Chappaquiddick Island, Massachusetts, killing his passenger Mary Jo Kopechne.

Apollo program: Apollo 11's crew successfully makes the first human landing on the Moon in the Sea of Tranquility. Americans Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin become the first humans to walk on the Moon six and a half hours later.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Apollo_11; Moon; Mare_Tranquillitatis; Neil_Armstrong; Buzz_Aldrin

event_text: A cease fire is announced between Honduras and El Salvador, six days after the beginning of the "Football War".
Apollo program: At 02:56 UTC, astronaut Neil Armstrong becomes the first person to walk on the Moon, followed 19 minutes later by Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin.
Apollo program: Apollo 11 splashes down safely in the Pacific Ocean.

Vietnam War: U.S. President Richard Nixon declares the Nixon Doctrine, stating that the United States now expects its Asian allies to take care of their own military defense. This is the start of the "Vietnamization" of the war.
Vietnam War: U.S. president Richard Nixon makes an unscheduled visit to South Vietnam and meets with President Nguyễn Văn Thiệu and U.S. military commanders.

Vietnam War: At the apartment of French intermediary Jean Sainteny in Paris, American representative Henry Kissinger and North Vietnamese representative Xuân Thuỷ begin secret peace negotiations. The negotiations will eventually fail.
The Lonesome Cowboys police raid occurs in Atlanta, Georgia, leading to the creation of the Georgia Gay Liberation Front.
Richard Nixon appoints Luis R. Bruce, a Mohawk-Oglala Sioux and co-founder of the National Congress of American Indians, as the new commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
source_pages: Richard_Nixon; Mohawk_people; Oglala; National_Congress_of_American_Indians; Bureau_of_Indian_Affairs; August_7

event_text: At a zebra crossing in London, photographer Iain Macmillan takes the iconic photo that becomes the cover image of the Beatles' album Abbey Road.

Tate–LaBianca murders: Followers of Charles Manson murder pregnant actress Sharon Tate (wife of Roman Polanski), coffee heiress Abigail Folger, Polish actor Wojciech Frykowski, men's hairstylist Jay Sebring and recent high-school graduate Steven Parent.
source_pages: Tate–LaBianca_murders; Charles_Manson; Sharon_Tate; Roman_Polanski; Coffee; Jay_Sebring

event_text: A day after murdering Sharon Tate and four others, members of Charles Manson's cult kill Leno and Rosemary LaBianca.
The Apollo 11 astronauts are released from a three-week quarantine following their liftoff from the Moon.
Violence erupts after the Apprentice Boys of Derry march in Derry, Northern Ireland, resulting in a three-day communal riot known as the Battle of the Bogside.

The Apollo 11 astronauts enjoy a ticker-tape parade in New York City. That evening, at a state dinner in Los Angeles, they are awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by U.S. President Richard Nixon.
source_pages: Apollo_11; Ticker-tape_parade; August_13; State_banquet; Los_Angeles; Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom; Richard_Nixon

event_text: The Troubles: British troops are deployed in Northern Ireland as political and sectarian violence breaks out, marking the start of the 37-year Operation Banner.
The Woodstock Music & Art Fair opens in Bethel, New York, featuring some of the top rock musicians of the era.
Category 5 Hurricane Camille hits the U.S. Gulf Coast, killing 256 and causing $1.42 billion in damage.
Aeroflot Flight 1770 crashes while landing at Vnukovo International Airport, killing 16.
A coup in Libya brings Muammar Gaddafi to power.
Mỹ Lai Massacre: U.S. Army Lieutenant William Calley is charged with six specifications of premeditated murder for the death of 109 Vietnamese civilians in My Lai.
In Canada, the Official Languages Act comes into force, making French equal to English throughout the Federal government.
Allegheny Airlines Flight 863 collides in mid-air with a Piper PA-28 Cherokee over Moral Township, Shelby County, Indiana, killing all 83 people on board both aircraft.
Philippine Air Lines Flight 158 crashes in Antipolo, near Manila International Airport in the Philippines, killing 45 people.
Mexicana de Aviación Flight 801, a Boeing 727-100 passenger plane, crashes during a landing attempt in Mexico City, killing 27 of the 118 occupants.
The charter establishing the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation is signed.
Concorde breaks the sound barrier for the first time.
The opening rally of the Days of Rage occurs, organized by the Weather Underground in Chicago.
In Chicago, the National Guard is called in as demonstrations continue over the trial of the "Chicago Eight".
King Crimson releases their debut album, In the Court of the Crimson King.
The Caravaggio painting Nativity with St. Francis and St. Lawrence is stolen from the Oratory of Saint Lawrence in Palermo.
The 1969 Somali coup d'état establishes a Marxist–Leninist administration.
The first-ever computer-to-computer link is established on ARPANET, the precursor to the Internet.

Vietnam War: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon addresses the nation on television and radio, asking the "silent majority" to join him in solidarity on the Vietnam War effort and to support his policies.
National Educational Television (the predecessor to the Public Broadcasting Service) in the United States debuts Sesame Street.
Vietnam War: Independent investigative journalist Seymour Hersh breaks the story of the My Lai Massacre.
Vietnam War: Anti-war protesters in Washington, D.C. stage a symbolic March Against Death.
Apollo program: NASA launches Apollo 12, the second crewed mission to the surface of the Moon.
Cold War: The Soviet submarine K-19 collides with the American submarine USS Gato in the Barents Sea.
Vietnam War: In Washington, D.C., 250,000–500,000 protesters staged a peaceful demonstration against the war, including a symbolic "March Against Death".
Cold War: Negotiators from the Soviet Union and the United States meet in Helsinki, Finland to begin SALT I negotiations aimed at limiting the number of strategic weapons on both sides.
Apollo program: Apollo 12 astronauts Pete Conrad and Alan Bean land at Oceanus Procellarum (the "Ocean of Storms") and become the third and fourth humans to walk on the Moon.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Apollo_12; Pete_Conrad; Alan_Bean; Oceanus_Procellarum; Human; Moon

event_text: Association football player Pelé scores his 1,000th goal.
Vietnam War: The Plain Dealer (Cleveland, Ohio) publishes explicit photographs of dead villagers from the My Lai Massacre in Vietnam.
Occupation of Alcatraz: Native American activists seize control of Alcatraz Island until being ousted by the U.S. Government on June 11, 1971.

U.S. President Richard Nixon and Japanese Premier Eisaku Satō agree on the return of Okinawa to Japanese control in 1972. The U.S. retains rights to bases on the island, but these are to be nuclear-free.
The first permanent ARPANET link is established between UCLA and SRI.
Apollo program: The Apollo 12 command module splashes down safely in the Pacific Ocean, ending the second crewed mission to land on the Moon.
Vietnam War: The first draft lottery in the United States is held since World War II.
Black Panther Party members Fred Hampton and Mark Clark are shot and killed during a raid by 14 Chicago police officers.
Altamont Free Concert: At a free concert performed by the Rolling Stones, eighteen-year old Meredith Hunter is stabbed to death by Hells Angels security guards.
Olympic Airways Flight 954 strikes a mountain outside of Keratea, Greece, killing 90 people in the worst crash of a Douglas DC-6 in history.

U.S. Secretary of State William P. Rogers proposes his plan for a ceasefire in the War of Attrition; Egypt and Jordan accept it over the objections of the PLO, which leads to civil war in Jordan in September 1970.

The Piazza Fontana bombing; a bomb explodes at the headquarters of Banca Nazionale dell'Agricoltura (the National Agricultural Bank) in Piazza Fontana in Milan, Italy, killing 17 people and wounding 88. The same afternoon, three more bombs are detonated in Rome and Milan, and another is found unexploded.
Project Blue Book: The United States Air Force closes its study of UFOs.
Nigerian troops capture Umuahia, the Biafran capital.
The defined beginning of Unix time, at 00:00:00.

The 7.1 Mw  Tonghai earthquake shakes Tonghai County, Yunnan province, China, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). Between 10,000 and 15,000 people are known to have been killed and about another 26,000 are injured.
Biafra capitulates, ending the Nigerian Civil War.
Nigerian Civil War: Biafran rebels surrender following an unsuccessful 32-month fight for independence from Nigeria.
Muammar Gaddafi is proclaimed premier of Libya.

The Boeing 747, the world's first "jumbo jet", enters commercial service for launch customer Pan American Airways with its maiden voyage from New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport to London Heathrow Airport.
Japan launches Ohsumi, becoming the fourth nation to put an object into orbit using its own booster.

A Dominicana de Aviación McDonnell Douglas DC-9 crashes into the Caribbean Sea after takeoff from Las Américas International Airport, killing 102, including members of the Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team and lightweight boxer Carlos Cruz.
source_pages: Dominicana_de_Aviación; McDonnell_Douglas_DC-9; 1970_Dominicana_de_Aviación_DC-9_crash; Caribbean_Sea; Las_Américas_International_Airport; Puerto_Rico_women's_national_volleyball_team; Carlos_Cruz_(boxer); February_15

event_text: the family of Jeffrey R. MacDonald, United States Army captain, is found murdered in their home in Ft. Bragg, North Carolina.  Eventually, MacDonald himself was charged with and convicted of the murder of his pregnant wife and two daughters.
The Chicago Seven are found not guilty of conspiring to incite riots at the 1968 Democratic National Convention.
Rhodesia declares itself a republic, breaking its last links with the British crown.
French submarine Eurydice explodes underwater, resulting in the loss of the entire 57-man crew.
The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons goes into effect after ratification by 43 nations.
An explosion at the Weather Underground safe house in Greenwich Village kills three.
Vietnam War: Captain Ernest Medina is charged by the U.S. military with My Lai war crimes.
Lon Nol ousts Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia.
The first Earth Day proclamation is issued by Joseph Alioto, Mayor of San Francisco.
San Diego Comic-Con, the largest pop and culture festival in the world, hosts its inaugural event.
South Vietnamese President Nguyễn Văn Thiệu implements a land reform program to solve the problem of land tenancy.
An earthquake strikes western Turkey at about 23:05 local time, killing 1,086 and injuring at least 1,200.
Explorer 1 re-enters the Earth's atmosphere after 12 years in orbit.
President Richard Nixon signs the Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act into law.
A Royal Air Maroc Sud Aviation Caravelle crashes near Berrechid, Morocco, killing 61.
Newhall massacre: Four California Highway Patrol officers are killed in a shootout.
Bahr El-Baqar primary school bombing: Israeli bombers strike an Egyptian school. Forty-six children are killed.
Paul McCartney announces that he is leaving The Beatles for personal and professional reasons.
Apollo Program: Apollo 13 is launched.
Soviet submarine K-8, carrying four nuclear torpedoes, sinks in the Bay of Biscay four days after a fire on board.

An oxygen tank aboard the Apollo 13 Service Module explodes, putting the crew in great danger and causing major damage to the Apollo command and service module (codenamed "Odyssey") while en route to the Moon.
During the Cambodian Civil War, massacre of the Vietnamese minority results in 800 bodies flowing down the Mekong river into South Vietnam.
Apollo program: The damaged Apollo 13 spacecraft returns to Earth safely.
The first Earth Day is celebrated.
Chicano residents in San Diego, California occupy a site under the Coronado Bridge, leading to the creation of Chicano Park.
China launches Dong Fang Hong I, becoming the fifth nation to put an object into orbit using its own booster.
The Gambia becomes a republic within the Commonwealth of Nations, with Dawda Jawara as its first President.
The Convention Establishing the World Intellectual Property Organization enters into force.
Vietnam War: US President Richard Nixon formally authorizes American combat troops to take part in the Cambodian campaign.
Vietnam War: United States and South Vietnamese forces invade Cambodia to interdict the Ho Chi Minh Trail in an attempt to cut off supplies to the Viet Cong and the North Vietnamese Army.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; South_Vietnam; Cambodian_campaign; Ho_Chi_Minh_trail; Viet_Cong; People's_Army_of_Vietnam; April_29

event_text: Vietnam War: Protests erupt in response to U.S. and South Vietnamese forces attacking Vietnamese communists in a Cambodian Campaign.
ALM Flight 980 ditches in the Caribbean Sea near Saint Croix, killing 23.

Vietnam War: Kent State shootings: The Ohio National Guard, sent to Kent State University after disturbances in the city of Kent the weekend before, opens fire killing four unarmed students and wounding nine others. The students were protesting the Cambodian Campaign of the United States and South Vietnam.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; Kent_State_shootings; Ohio_National_Guard; Kent_State_University; Cambodian_campaign; South_Vietnam

event_text: The Beatles release their 12th and final studio album Let It Be.
The 1970 Lubbock tornado kills 26 and causes $250 million in damage.
Andreas Baader is freed from custody by Ulrike Meinhof, Gudrun Ensslin and others, a pivotal moment in the formation of the Red Army Faction.
President Richard Nixon appoints Anna Mae Hays and Elizabeth P. Hoisington the first female United States Army generals.
The Soviet Tupolev Tu-144 becomes the first commercial transport to exceed Mach 2.

The 7.9 Mw  Ancash earthquake shakes Peru with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe) and a landslide buries the town of Yungay, Peru. Between 66,794 and 70,000 were killed and 50,000 were injured.
Tonga gains independence from the British Empire.
After being appointed on May 15, Anna Mae Hays and Elizabeth P. Hoisington officially receive their ranks as U.S. Army general officers, becoming the first women to do so.
Penn Central declares Section 77 bankruptcy in what was the largest U.S. corporate bankruptcy to date.
The Troubles: The "Falls Curfew" begins in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
Dan-Air Flight 1903 crashes into the Les Agudes mountain in the Montseny Massif near the village of Arbúcies in Catalonia, Spain, killing all 112 people aboard.
source_pages: Dan-Air_Flight_1903; Les_Agudes; Montseny_Massif; Arbúcies; Catalonia; July_3

event_text: Air Canada Flight 621 crashes in Brampton, Ontario, Canada, killing all 109 people on board.

Richard Nixon delivers a special congressional message enunciating Native American self-determination as official US Indian policy, leading to the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act of 1975.
An Antonov An-22 of the Soviet Air Forces crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 23 aboard.
After 11 years of construction, the Aswan High Dam in Egypt is completed.
Qaboos bin Said al Said becomes Sultan of Oman after overthrowing his father, Said bin Taimur initiating massive reforms, modernization programs and end to a decade long civil war.
Black Tot Day: The last day of the officially sanctioned rum ration in the Royal Navy.
California judge Harold Haley is taken hostage in his courtroom and killed during an effort to free George Jackson from police custody.
LANSA Flight 502 crashes after takeoff from Alejandro Velasco Astete International Airport in Cusco, Peru, killing 99 of the 100 people on board, as well as two people on the ground.
Patricia Palinkas becomes the first woman to play professionally in an American football game.
Soviet Union Venera program: Venera 7 launched. It will become the first spacecraft to successfully transmit data from the surface of another planet (Venus).
Organized by Mexican American labor union leader César Chávez, the Salad Bowl strike, the largest farm worker strike in U.S. history, begins.
Vietnam War protesters bomb Sterling Hall at the University of Wisconsin–Madison, leading to an international manhunt for the perpetrators.
The fiftieth anniversary of American women being able to vote is marked by a nationwide Women's Strike for Equality.
Chicano Moratorium against the Vietnam War, East Los Angeles, California. Police riot kills three people, including journalist Rubén Salazar.
NASA announces the cancellation of two Apollo missions to the Moon, Apollo 15 (the designation is re-used by a later mission), and Apollo 19.

Aeroflot Flight 3630, a Tupolev Tu-124 en route from southern Russia to Lithuania, crashes after the pilots lost control of the aircraft at cruise altitude between Rostov-on-Don Airport and Vilnius Airport, on the second leg of the flight; all 37 passengers and crew are killed.
source_pages: Aeroflot_Flight_3630; Tupolev_Tu-124; Lithuania; Rostov-on-Don_Airport; Vilnius_Airport; September_2

event_text: Salvador Allende is elected President of Chile.
Vietnam War: Operation Jefferson Glenn begins: The United States 101st Airborne Division and the South Vietnamese 1st Infantry Division initiate a new operation in Thừa Thiên–Huế Province.
Two passenger jets bound from Europe to New York are simultaneously hijacked by Palestinian terrorist members of the PFLP and taken to Dawson's Field, Jordan.
Fighting begins between Arab guerrillas and government forces in Jordan.
Vietnam Television was established.
Trans International Airlines Flight 863 crashes during takeoff from John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York City, killing all 11 aboard.
A British airliner is hijacked by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and flown to Dawson's Field in Jordan.
The Dawson's Field hijackers release 88 of their hostages. The remaining hostages, mostly Jews and Israeli citizens, are held until September 25.

Dawson's Field hijackings: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine terrorists blow up three hijacked airliners in Zarqa, Jordan, continuing to hold the passengers hostage in various undisclosed locations in Amman.
King Hussein of Jordan declares war against the Palestine Liberation Organization, the conflict came to be known as Black September.
Michael Eavis hosts the first Glastonbury Festival.
Kostas Georgakis, a Greek student of geology, sets himself ablaze in Matteotti Square in Genoa, Italy, as a protest against the dictatorial regime of Georgios Papadopoulos.
Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser dies of a heart attack in Cairo.
Jordan makes a deal with the PFLP for the release of the remaining hostages from the Dawson's Field hijackings.
An aircraft carrying the Wichita State University football team, administrators, and supporters crashes in Colorado, killing 31 people.
The Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) is founded.
The British Trade Commissioner, James Cross, is kidnapped by members of the Front de libération du Québec, triggering the October Crisis in Canada.
Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn wins the Nobel Prize in literature.
The Khmer Republic is proclaimed in Cambodia.
Fiji becomes independent.
Canada's October Crisis escalates when Quebec Vice Premier Pierre Laporte is kidnapped by members of the Front de libération du Québec.
Vietnam War: Vietnamization continues as President Richard Nixon announces that the United States will withdraw 40,000 more troops before Christmas.
During the construction of Australia's West Gate Bridge, a span of the bridge falls and kills 35 workers. The incident is the country's worst industrial accident to this day.
Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau invokes the War Measures Act during the October Crisis.
FLQ terrorists murder Quebec Vice-Premier and Minister of Labour Pierre Laporte.
Gary Gabelich sets a land speed record in a rocket-powered automobile called the Blue Flame, fueled with natural gas.
Club Cinq-Sept fire in Saint-Laurent-du-Pont, France kills 146 young people.
Vietnam War: The United States turns over control of the air base at Bình Thủy in the Mekong Delta to South Vietnam.
Salvador Allende takes office as President of Chile, the first Marxist to become president of a Latin American country through open elections.
The Military Assistance Command, Vietnam reports the lowest weekly American soldier death toll in five years (24).

Vietnam War: The Supreme Court of the United States votes 6–3 against hearing a case to allow Massachusetts to enforce its law granting residents the right to refuse military service in an undeclared war.
Vietnam War: Vietnamization: For the first time in five years, an entire week ends with no reports of American combat fatalities in Southeast Asia.
Luna 17: uncrewed space mission launched by the Soviet Union.
The Oregon Highway Division attempts to destroy a rotting beached sperm whale with explosives, leading to the now infamous "exploding whale" incident.
The 1970 Bhola cyclone makes landfall on the coast of East Pakistan, becoming the deadliest tropical cyclone in history.
Bhola cyclone: A 240 km/h (150 mph) tropical cyclone hits the densely populated Ganges Delta region of East Pakistan (now Bangladesh), killing an estimated 500,000 people in one night.
Soviet Union enters ICAO, making Russian the fourth official language of organization.
Southern Airways Flight 932 crashes in the mountains near Huntington, West Virginia, killing 75, including almost all of the Marshall University football team.
Vietnam War: Lieutenant William Calley goes on trial for the My Lai Massacre.

Luna programme: The Soviet Union lands Lunokhod 1 on Mare Imbrium (Sea of Rains) on the Moon. This is the first roving remote-controlled robot to land on another world and is released by the orbiting Luna 17 spacecraft.
U.S. President Richard Nixon asks the U.S. Congress for $155 million in supplemental aid for the Cambodian government.
Vietnam War: Operation Ivory Coast: A joint United States Air Force and Army team raids the Sơn Tây prisoner-of-war camp in an attempt to free American prisoners of war thought to be held there.
In Japan, author Yukio Mishima and one compatriot commit ritualistic seppuku after an unsuccessful coup attempt.
In Basse-Terre, Guadeloupe, 38 millimetres (1.5 in) of rain fall in a minute, the heaviest rainfall ever recorded.
The United States Environmental Protection Agency begins operations.
Soviet spacecraft Venera 7 successfully lands on Venus. It is the first successful soft landing on another planet.
Polish protests: In Gdynia, soldiers fire at workers emerging from trains, killing dozens.

Koza riot: After a series of hit-and-runs and other vehicular incidents involving American service personnel, roughly 5,000 Okinawans take to the streets, clashing with American law enforcement in protest against the U.S. occupation of Okinawa.
First flight of F-14 multi-role combat aircraft.
The North Tower of the World Trade Center in Manhattan, New York, New York is topped out at 417 metres (1,368 ft), making it the tallest building in the world.
The Democratic Republic of the Congo officially becomes a one-party state.
Cigarette advertisements are banned on American television.
The second Ibrox disaster kills 66 fans at a Rangers-Celtic association football match.

The Harrisburg Seven: Rev. Philip Berrigan and five other activists are indicted on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry Kissinger and of plotting to blow up the heating tunnels of federal buildings in Washington, D.C.
The current Emley Moor transmitting station, the tallest free-standing structure in the United Kingdom, begins transmitting UHF broadcasts.
The Singapore Declaration, one of the two most important documents to the uncodified constitution of the Commonwealth of Nations, is issued.
Charles Manson and four "Family" members (three of them female) are found guilty of the 1969 Tate–LaBianca murders.
Idi Amin leads a coup deposing Milton Obote and becomes Uganda's president.
Apollo program: Apollo 14: Astronauts Alan Shepard, Stuart Roosa, and Edgar Mitchell, aboard a Saturn V, lift off for a mission to the Fra Mauro Highlands on the Moon.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Apollo_14; Alan_Shepard; Stuart_Roosa; Edgar_Mitchell; Saturn_V; Fra_Mauro_formation; Moon

event_text: The Winter Soldier Investigation, organized by the Vietnam Veterans Against the War to publicize alleged war crimes and atrocities by Americans and allies in Vietnam, begins in Detroit.
New York Police Officer Frank Serpico is shot during a drug bust in Brooklyn and survives to later testify against police corruption.
Astronauts land on the Moon in the Apollo 14 mission.
The NASDAQ stock market index opens for the first time.
South Vietnamese ground troops launch an incursion into Laos to try to cut off the Ho Chi Minh trail and stop communist infiltration into the country.
source_pages: Army_of_the_Republic_of_Vietnam; Operation_Lam_Son_719; Laos; Ho_Chi_Minh_trail; People's_Army_of_Vietnam; February_8

event_text: The 6.5–6.7 Mw  Sylmar earthquake hits the Greater Los Angeles Area with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing 64 and injuring 2,000.
Satchel Paige becomes the first Negro league player to be voted into the USA's Baseball Hall of Fame.
Apollo program: Apollo 14 returns to Earth after the third human Moon landing.
Cold War: the Seabed Arms Control Treaty opened for signature outlawing nuclear weapons on the ocean floor in international waters.
The decimalisation of the currencies of the United Kingdom and Ireland is completed on Decimal Day.
The United States Emergency Broadcast System is accidentally activated in an erroneous national alert.
The Convention on Psychotropic Substances is signed at Vienna.
Operation Lam Son 719: South Vietnamese General Do Cao Tri was killed in a helicopter crash en route to taking control of the faltering campaign.
The All India Forward Bloc holds an emergency central committee meeting after its chairman, Hemantha Kumar Bose, is killed three days earlier. P.K. Mookiah Thevar is appointed as the new chairman.
U.N. Secretary-General U Thant signs United Nations proclamation of the vernal equinox as Earth Day.
Doctors in the first Dutch abortion clinic (the Mildredhuis in Arnhem) start performing artificially-induced abortions.
President of Pakistan Yahya Khan indefinitely postpones the pending national assembly session, precipitating massive civil disobedience in East Pakistan.
John Gorton resigns as Prime Minister of Australia and the leader of the Liberal Party of Australia after a secret ballot vote of confidence, being replaced in both positions by William McMahon.
The 1971 Turkish military memorandum is sent to the Süleyman Demirel government of Turkey and the government resigns.
Peru: A landslide crashes into Yanawayin Lake, killing 200 people at the mining camp of Chungar.
The Army of the Republic of Vietnam abandon an attempt to cut off the Ho Chi Minh trail in Laos.
East Pakistan, then province of Pakistan, declares its independence from Pakistan to form Bangladesh; the Bangladesh's War of Independence begins.
My Lai massacre: Lieutenant William Calley is convicted of premeditated murder and sentenced to life in prison.
Bangladesh Liberation War: The Pakistan Army massacre more than a thousand people in Keraniganj Upazila, Bangladesh.
In Sri Lanka, Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna launches a revolt against the United Front government of Sirimavo Bandaranaike.
Vietnam War: President Richard Nixon announces his decision to quicken the pace of Vietnamization.
Ping-pong diplomacy: In an attempt to thaw relations with the United States, China hosts the U.S. table tennis team for a week-long visit.
The Provisional Government of Bangladesh is formed.
Sierra Leone becomes a republic, and Siaka Stevens the president.
Launch of Salyut 1, the first space station.
Charles Manson is sentenced to death (later commuted to life imprisonment) for conspiracy in the Tate–LaBianca murders.
Bangladesh Liberation War: The Pakistan Army and Razakars massacre approximately 3,000 Hindu emigrants in the Jathibhanga area of East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).
Amtrak (the National Railroad Passenger Corporation) takes over operation of U.S. passenger rail service.
Erich Honecker becomes First Secretary of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany, remaining in power until 1989.
Mars probe program: Mars 2 is launched by the Soviet Union.
In the Chuknagar massacre, Pakistani forces massacre thousands, mostly Bengali Hindus.
Seventy-eight people are killed when Aviogenex Flight 130 crashes on approach to Rijeka Airport in present-day Rijeka, Croatia (then the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia).
The Intercontinental Hotel in Bucharest opens, becoming the second-tallest building in the city.
Bangladesh Liberation War: The Pakistan Army slaughters at least 71 Hindus in Burunga, Sylhet, Bangladesh.
The Dahlerau train disaster, the worst railway accident in West Germany, kills 46 people and injures 25 near Wuppertal.
Pakistani forces massacre over 200 civilians, mostly Bengali Hindus, in the Bagbati massacre.
Mariner program: Mariner 9 is launched to map 70% of the surface, and to study temporal changes in the atmosphere and surface, of Mars.

In accordance with the Uniform Monday Holiday Act passed by the U.S. Congress in 1968, observation of Memorial Day occurs on the last Monday in May for the first time, rather than on the traditional Memorial Day of May 30.

Soyuz 11 is launched. The mission ends in disaster when all three cosmonauts, Georgy Dobrovolsky, Vladislav Volkov, and Viktor Patsayev are suffocated by uncontrolled decompression of the capsule during re-entry on 29 June.
source_pages: Soyuz_11; Georgy_Dobrovolsky; Vladislav_Volkov; Viktor_Patsayev; Uncontrolled_decompression; Atmospheric_entry; June_6

event_text: Hughes Airwest Flight 706 collides with a McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II of the United States Marine Corps over the San Gabriel Mountains, killing 50.

The United States Supreme Court overturns the conviction of Paul Cohen for disturbing the peace, setting the precedent that vulgar writing is protected under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.
The Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms Division of the U.S. Internal Revenue Service raids the home of Ken Ballew for illegal possession of hand grenades.
Allegheny Airlines Flight 485 crashes on approach to Tweed New Haven Airport in New Haven, Connecticut, killing 28 of 31 aboard.
The U.S. Government forcibly removes the last holdouts to the Native American Occupation of Alcatraz, ending 19 months of control.
Vietnam War: The New York Times begins publication of the Pentagon Papers.
U.S. President Richard Nixon in a televised press conference called drug abuse "America's public enemy number one", starting the War on drugs.

Prior to re-entry (following a record-setting stay aboard the Soviet Union's Salyut 1 space station), the crew capsule of the Soyuz 11 spacecraft depressurizes, killing the three cosmonauts on board. Georgy Dobrovolsky, Vladislav Volkov and Viktor Patsayev are the first humans to die in space.
source_pages: Soviet_Union; Salyut_1; Soyuz_11; Georgy_Dobrovolsky; Vladislav_Volkov; Viktor_Patsayev; June_29

event_text: The crew of the Soviet Soyuz 11 spacecraft are killed when their air supply escapes through a faulty valve.
The Twenty-sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution, lowering the voting age from 21 to 18 years, is formally certified by President Richard Nixon.
The nationalization of all large copper mines in Chile is completed.
The Australian Aboriginal flag is flown for the first time.
The United Red Army is founded in Japan.
The Sohagpur massacre is perpetrated by the Pakistan Army.
Apollo program: Launch of Apollo 15 on the first Apollo "J-Mission", and first use of a Lunar Roving Vehicle.
Apollo program: On Apollo 15, David Scott and James Irwin in the Apollo Lunar Module Falcon land on the Moon with the first Lunar Rover.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Apollo_15; David_Scott; James_Irwin; Apollo_Lunar_Module; Moon; Lunar_Roving_Vehicle

event_text: An All Nippon Airways Boeing 727 and a Japanese Air Force F-86 collide over Morioka, Iwate, Japan killing 162.
source_pages: All_Nippon_Airways; Boeing; Japan_Air_Self-Defense_Force; North_American_F-86_Sabre; All_Nippon_Airways_Flight_58; Morioka

event_text: Apollo program: the Apollo 15 astronauts become the first to ride in a lunar rover.
The Concert for Bangladesh, organized by former Beatle George Harrison, is held at Madison Square Garden in New York City.

The first Pacific Islands Forum (then known as the "South Pacific Forum") is held in Wellington, New Zealand, with the aim of enhancing cooperation between the independent countries of the Pacific Ocean.

The Troubles: In Northern Ireland, the British authorities launch Operation Demetrius. The operation involves the mass arrest and internment without trial of individuals suspected of being affiliated with the Irish Republican Army (PIRA). Mass riots follow, and thousands of people flee or are forced out of their homes.
The Society for American Baseball Research is founded in Cooperstown, New York.
Bahrain declares independence from Britain.
President Richard Nixon completes the break from the gold standard by ending convertibility of the United States dollar into gold by foreign investors.
Bahrain gains independence from the United Kingdom.
Vietnam War: Australia and New Zealand decide to withdraw their troops from Vietnam.
A bomb exploded in the Liberal Party campaign rally in Plaza Miranda, Manila, Philippines with several anti-Marcos political candidates injured.
J. Edgar Hoover and John Mitchell announce the arrest of 20 of the Camden 28.
An attempted coup d'état fails in the African nation of Chad. The Government of Chad accuses Egypt of playing a role in the attempt and breaks off diplomatic relations.
Qatar becomes an independent state.
Alaska Airlines Flight 1866 crashes near Juneau, Alaska, killing all 111 people on board.
Paninternational Flight 112 crashes on the Bundesautobahn 7 highway near Hamburg Airport, in Hamburg, Germany, killing 22.
In Washington, D.C., the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is inaugurated, with the opening feature being the premiere of Leonard Bernstein's Mass.
The four-day Attica Prison riot begins, eventually resulting in 39 dead, most killed by state troopers retaking the prison.
The Egyptian Constitution becomes official.
State police and National Guardsmen storm New York's Attica Prison to quell a prison revolt, which claimed 43 lives.
Chairman Mao Zedong's second in command and successor Marshal Lin Biao flees China after the failure of an alleged coup. His plane crashes in Mongolia, killing all aboard.
The first Greenpeace ship departs from Vancouver to protest against the upcoming Cannikin nuclear weapon test in Alaska.

Having weakened after making landfall in Nicaragua the previous day, Hurricane Irene regains enough strength to be renamed Hurricane Olivia, making it the first known hurricane to cross from the Atlantic Ocean into the Pacific.
Bahrain, Bhutan and Qatar join the United Nations.
Oman joins the Arab League.
Walt Disney World opens near Orlando, Florida.
The first practical CT scanner is used to diagnose a patient.
South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu is re-elected in a one-man election.
British European Airways Flight 706 crashes near Aarsele, Belgium, killing 63.
Aeroflot Flight 773 is destroyed by a bomb over Moscow Oblast, killing 25.
The 2,500 year celebration of the Persian Empire begins.
A gas explosion kills 22 people at a shopping centre near Glasgow, Scotland.
The People's Republic of China replaces the Republic of China at the United Nations.
The Democratic Republic of the Congo is renamed Zaire.
Prospero becomes the only British satellite to be launched by a British rocket.
The United States Atomic Energy Commission tests the largest U.S. underground hydrogen bomb, code-named Cannikin, on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians.
source_pages: United_States_Atomic_Energy_Commission; Thermonuclear_weapon; Cannikin; Amchitka; Aleutian_Islands; November_6

event_text: American banker John List murdered his wife, mother, and three children with a pair of handguns.
In Cambodia, Khmer Rouge forces attack the city of Phnom Penh and its airport, killing 44, wounding at least 30 and damaging nine aircraft.
A Merpati Nusantara Airlines Vickers Viscount crashes into the Indian Ocean near Padang, West Sumatra, Indonesia, killing all 69 people on board.
source_pages: Merpati_Nusantara_Airlines; Vickers_Viscount; 1971_Merpati_Nusantara_Airlines_Vickers_Viscount_crash; Indian_Ocean; Padang; West_Sumatra; Indonesia; November_10

event_text: Vietnam War: As part of Vietnamization, U.S. President Richard Nixon sets February 1, 1972 as the deadline for the removal of another 45,000 American troops from Vietnam.
Aeroflot Flight N-63 crashes on approach to Vinnytsia Airport, killing 48.
Mariner 9 enters orbit around Mars.
Intel releases the world's first commercial single-chip microprocessor, the 4004.
Oman declares its independence from the United Kingdom.
