Indian troops, partly aided by Mukti Bahini (Bengali guerrillas), defeat the Pakistan army in the Battle of Garibpur.
In Britain's worst mountaineering tragedy, the Cairngorm Plateau Disaster, five children and one of their leaders are found dead from exposure in the Scottish mountains.
Representatives of the People's Republic of China attend the United Nations, including the United Nations Security Council, for the first time.

During a severe thunderstorm over Washington state, a hijacker calling himself Dan Cooper (aka D. B. Cooper) parachutes from a Northwest Orient Airlines plane with $200,000 in ransom money. He has never been found.
The Soviet space program's Mars 2 orbiter releases a descent module. It malfunctions and crashes, but it is the first man-made object to reach the surface of Mars.
Fred Quilt, a leader of the Tsilhqot'in First Nation suffers severe abdominal injuries allegedly caused by Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers; he dies two days later.
Wasfi al-Tal, Prime Minister of Jordan, is assassinated by the Black September unit of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Iran seizes the Greater and Lesser Tunbs from the Emirates of Sharjah and Ras Al Khaimah.
Cambodian Civil War: Khmer Rouge rebels intensify assaults on Cambodian government positions, forcing their retreat from Kompong Thmar and nearby Ba Ray.
Purge of Croatian Spring leaders starts in Yugoslavia at the meeting of the League of Communists at the Karađorđevo estate.
Abu Dhabi, Ajman, Fujairah, Sharjah, Dubai, and Umm al-Quwain form the United Arab Emirates.
source_pages: Emirate_of_Abu_Dhabi; Ajman; Fujairah; Emirate_of_Sharjah; Dubai; Umm_Al_Quwain; United_Arab_Emirates

event_text: Indo-Pakistani War of 1971: Pakistan launches a pre-emptive strike against India and a full-scale war begins.
The PNS Ghazi, a Pakistan Navy submarine, sinks during the course of the Indo-Pakistani Naval War of 1971.

During a concert by Frank Zappa and The Mothers of Invention at the Montreux Casino, an audience member fires a flare gun into the ceiling, causing a fire that destroys the venue. The incident served as the inspiration for Deep Purple's 1973 song Smoke on the Water.
source_pages: Frank_Zappa; The_Mothers_of_Invention; Montreux_Casino; Flare_gun; Deep_Purple; Smoke_on_the_Water

event_text: Battle of Gazipur: Pakistani forces stand defeated as India cedes Gazipur to Bangladesh.
Pakistan severs diplomatic relations with India, initiating the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971.
The Battle of Sylhet is fought between the Pakistani military and the Indian Army.
Pakistan President Yahya Khan announces the formation of a coalition government with Nurul Amin as Prime Minister and Zulfikar Ali Bhutto as Deputy Prime Minister.
Indo-Pakistani War: The Indian Navy launches an attack on West Pakistan's port city of Karachi.
Indo-Pakistani War: The Indian Air Force executes an airdrop of Indian Army units, bypassing Pakistani defences.
Bangladesh Liberation War: Over 200 of East Pakistan's intellectuals are executed by the Pakistan Army and their local allies. (The date is commemorated in Bangladesh as Martyred Intellectuals Day.)

Bangladesh Liberation War and Indo-Pakistani War of 1971: The surrender of the Pakistan Army brings an end to both conflicts. This is commemorated annually as Victory Day in Bangladesh and Vijay Diwas in India respectively.
The United Kingdom recognizes Bahrain's independence, which is commemorated annually as Bahrain's National Day.
The international aid organization Doctors Without Borders is founded by Bernard Kouchner and a group of journalists in Paris, France.
LANSA Flight 508 is struck by lightning and crashes in the Puerto Inca District in the Department of Huánuco in Peru, killing 91.
Rose Heilbron becomes the first female judge to sit at the Old Bailey in London, UK.
US President Richard Nixon announces the Space Shuttle program.
Iberia Flight 602 crashes near Ibiza Airport, killing all 104 people on board.

Bowing to international pressure, President of Pakistan Zulfikar Ali Bhutto releases Bengali leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman from prison, who had been arrested after declaring the independence of Bangladesh.
source_pages: President_of_Pakistan; Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto; Bengalis; Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman; Bangladesh; January_8

event_text: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman returns to the newly independent Bangladesh as president after spending over nine months in prison in Pakistan.
East Pakistan renames itself Bangladesh.
Prime Minister Kofi Abrefa Busia and President Edward Akufo-Addo of Ghana are ousted in a bloodless military coup by Colonel Ignatius Kutu Acheampong.
Queen Margrethe II of Denmark ascends the throne, the first Queen of Denmark since 1412 and the first Danish monarch not named Frederik or Christian since 1513.
Members of the Mukti Bahini lay down their arms to the government of the newly independent Bangladesh, a month after winning the war against the occupying Pakistan Army.
Pakistan launches its nuclear weapons program, a few weeks after its defeat in the Bangladesh Liberation War, as well as the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971.
Japanese Sgt. Shoichi Yokoi is found hiding in a Guam jungle, where he had been since the end of World War II.
JAT Flight 367 is destroyed by a terrorist bomb, killing 27 of the 28 people on board the DC-9. Flight attendant Vesna Vulović survives with critical injuries.
The Troubles: Bloody Sunday: British paratroopers open fire on anti-internment marchers in Derry, Northern Ireland, killing 13 people; another person later dies of injuries sustained.
Pakistan leaves the Commonwealth of Nations in protest of its recognition of breakaway Bangladesh.
Kuala Lumpur becomes a city by a royal charter granted by the Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia.
The first day of the seven-day 1972 Iran blizzard, which would kill at least 4,000 people, making it the deadliest snowstorm in history.
Ras Al Khaimah joins the United Arab Emirates, now making up seven emirates.
Sound recordings are granted U.S. federal copyright protection for the first time.
José María Velasco Ibarra, serving as President of Ecuador for the fifth time, is overthrown by the military for the fourth time.
Cumulative sales of the Volkswagen Beetle exceed those of the Ford Model T.
The California Supreme Court in the case of People v. Anderson, (6 Cal.3d 628) invalidates the state's death penalty and commutes the sentences of all death row inmates to life imprisonment.
United States President Richard Nixon visits China to normalize Sino-American relations.
The Soviet uncrewed spaceship Luna 20 lands on the Moon.
The Official Irish Republican Army detonates a car bomb at Aldershot barracks, killing seven and injuring nineteen others.
The Pioneer 10 space probe is launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida with a mission to explore the outer planets.
Mohawk Airlines Flight 405 crashes as a result of a control malfunction and insufficient training in emergency procedures.
Sterling Airways Flight 296 crashes near Kalba, United Arab Emirates while on approach to Dubai International Airport, killing 112 people.
The Troubles: The first car bombing by the Provisional IRA in Belfast kills seven people and injures 148 others in Northern Ireland.
The United States Congress sends the Equal Rights Amendment to the states for ratification.
In Eisenstadt v. Baird, the United States Supreme Court decides that unmarried persons have the right to possess contraceptives.
Direct rule is imposed on Northern Ireland by the Government of the United Kingdom under Edward Heath.
Vietnam War: The Easter Offensive begins after North Vietnamese forces cross into the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) of South Vietnam.
Actor Charlie Chaplin returns to the United States for the first time since being labeled a communist during the Red Scare in the early 1950s.
Vietnam War: Easter Offensive: American forces begin sustained air strikes and naval bombardments.
Vietnam War: Communist forces overrun the South Vietnamese town of Loc Ninh.
Tombs containing bamboo slips, among them Sun Tzu's Art of War and Sun Bin's lost military treatise, are discovered by construction workers in Shandong.
source_pages: Yinqueshan_Han_Tombs_Bamboo_Slips_Museum; Yinqueshan_Han_Slips; Sun_Tzu; The_Art_of_War; Sun_Bin; Sun_Bin's_Art_of_War; Shandong

event_text: Vietnam War: For the first time since November 1967, American B-52 bombers reportedly begin bombing North Vietnam.
The Universal Postal Union decides to recognize the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate Chinese representative, effectively expelling the Republic of China administering Taiwan.
Vietnam War: The Battle of An Lộc begins.
Apollo program: The launch of Apollo 16 from Cape Canaveral, Florida.
East African Airways Flight 720 crashes during a rejected takeoff from Addis Ababa Bole International Airport in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, killing 43.
Apollo program: Apollo 16 Lunar Module, commanded by John Young and piloted by Charles Duke, lands on the Moon.
Astronauts John Young and Charles Duke fly Apollo 16's Apollo Lunar Module to the Moon's surface, the fifth NASA Apollo Program crewed lunar landing.
source_pages: John_Young_(astronaut); Charles_Duke; Apollo_16; Apollo_Lunar_Module; Apollo_program; April_21

event_text: Vietnam War: Nguyen Hue Offensive: The North Vietnamese 320th Division forces 5,000 South Vietnamese troops to retreat and traps about 2,500 others northwest of Kontum.
In the early morning hours a fire breaks out at the Sunshine Mine located between Kellogg and Wallace, Idaho, killing 91 workers.
The Don't Make A Wave Committee, a fledgling environmental organization founded in Canada in 1971, officially changes its name to "Greenpeace Foundation".
Alitalia Flight 112 crashes into Mount Longa near Palermo, Sicily, killing all 115 aboard, making it the deadliest single-aircraft disaster in Italy.
Deniz Gezmiş, Yusuf Aslan and Hüseyin İnan are executed in Ankara after being convicted of attempting to overthrow the Constitutional order.
Vietnam War: U.S. President Richard Nixon announces his order to place naval mines in major North Vietnamese ports in order to stem the flow of weapons and other goods to that nation.
A fire occurs in the Sennichi Department Store in Osaka, Japan. Blocked exits and non-functional elevators result in 118 fatalities (many victims leaping to their deaths).

The Troubles: A car bombing outside a crowded pub in Belfast sparks a two-day gun battle involving the Provisional IRA, Ulster Volunteer Force and British Army. Seven people are killed and over 66 injured.
The Ryukyu Islands, under U.S. military governance since its conquest in 1945, reverts to Japanese control.
An Antonov An-24 crashes into a kindergarten building in Svetlogorsk, killing 35.
During approach to Kharkiv International Airport, Aeroflot Flight 1491 crashes near Ruska Lozova, killing all 112 aboard.
Michelangelo's Pietà in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome is damaged by a vandal, the mentally disturbed Hungarian geologist Laszlo Toth.
Ceylon adopts a new constitution, becoming a republic and changing its name to Sri Lanka.
Over 400 women in Derry, Northern Ireland attack the offices of Sinn Féin following the shooting by the Irish Republican Army of a young British soldier on leave.
The United States and the Soviet Union sign the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.
The Angry Brigade goes on trial over a series of 25 bombings throughout the United Kingdom.
In Ben Gurion Airport (at the time: Lod Airport), Israel, members of the Japanese Red Army carry out the Lod Airport massacre, killing 24 people and injuring 78 others.

Vietnam War: Nine-year-old Phan Thị Kim Phúc is burned by napalm, an event captured by Associated Press photographer Nick Ut moments later while the young girl is seen running naked down a road, in what would become an iconic, Pulitzer Prize-winning photo.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; Phan_Thi_Kim_Phuc; Napalm; Associated_Press; Nick_Ut; Pulitzer_Prize

event_text: Severe rainfall causes a dam in the Black Hills of South Dakota to burst, creating a flood that kills 238 people and causes $160 million in damage.

Japan Air Lines Flight 471 crashes on approach to Palam International Airport (now Indira Gandhi International Airport) in New Delhi, India, killing 82 of the 87 people on board and four more people on the ground.
Cathay Pacific Flight 700Z is destroyed by a bomb over Pleiku, Vietnam (then South Vietnam) and kills 81 people.
The largest single-site hydroelectric power project in Canada is inaugurated at Churchill Falls Generating Station.

Watergate scandal: Five White House operatives are arrested for burgling the offices of the Democratic National Committee during an attempt by members of the administration of President Richard M. Nixon to illegally wiretap the political opposition as part of a broader campaign to subvert the democratic process.
source_pages: Watergate_scandal; White_House; Democratic_National_Committee; Presidency_of_Richard_Nixon; Wiretapping; Operation_Sandwedge; June_17

event_text: Staines air disaster: One hundred eighteen people are killed when a BEA H.S. Trident crashes minutes after takeoff from London's Heathrow Airport.

Watergate scandal: An 18+1⁄2-minute gap appears in the tape recording of the conversations between U.S. President Richard Nixon and his advisers regarding the recent arrests of his operatives while breaking into the Watergate complex.

Watergate scandal: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and White House Chief of Staff H. R. Haldeman are taped talking about illegally using the Central Intelligence Agency to obstruct the Federal Bureau of Investigation's investigation into the Watergate break-ins.
source_pages: Watergate_scandal; Richard_Nixon; White_House; H._R._Haldeman; Central_Intelligence_Agency; Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation; June_23

event_text: Title IX of the United States Civil Rights Act of 1964 is amended to prohibit sexual discrimination to any educational program receiving federal funds.

The United States Supreme Court rules in the case Furman v. Georgia that arbitrary and inconsistent imposition of the death penalty violates the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments and constitutes cruel and unusual punishment.
A Convair CV-580 and De Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter collide above Lake Winnebago near Appleton, Wisconsin, killing 13.
The first leap second is added to the UTC time system.
The first Gay pride march in England takes place.
Israeli Mossad assassinate Palestinian writer Ghassan Kanafani.
The first game of the World Chess Championship 1972 between challenger Bobby Fischer and defending champion Boris Spassky starts.
Dhofar Rebellion: British SAS units help the Omani government against Popular Front for the Liberation of Oman rebels in the Battle of Mirbat.
The Troubles: Bloody Friday: The Provisional IRA detonate 22 bombs in central Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom in the space of 80 minutes, killing nine and injuring 130.
The United States launches Landsat 1, the first Earth-resources satellite.
Two Avianca Douglas DC-3 airliners collide over Colombia, killing 38.

The Troubles: In Operation Motorman, the British Army re-takes the urban no-go areas of Northern Ireland. It is the biggest British military operation since the Suez Crisis of 1956, and the biggest in Ireland since the Irish War of Independence. Later that day, nine civilians are killed by car bombs in the village of Claudy.
source_pages: The_Troubles; Operation_Motorman; No-go_area; Northern_Ireland; Suez_Crisis; Irish_War_of_Independence; Claudy_bombing; Claudy

event_text: The United States Senate ratifies the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.
Ugandan President Idi Amin announces that Uganda is no longer responsible for the care of British subjects of Asian origin, beginning the expulsions of Ugandan Asians.
source_pages: President_of_Uganda; Idi_Amin; Uganda; Indians_in_Uganda; Expulsion_of_Asians_from_Uganda; August_4

event_text: Vietnam War: The last United States ground combat unit leaves South Vietnam.
An Ilyushin Il-62 airliner crashes near Königs Wusterhausen, East Germany killing 156 people.
In an unsuccessful coup d'état attempt, the Royal Moroccan Air Force fires upon Hassan II of Morocco's plane while he is traveling back to Rabat.
Rhodesia is expelled by the IOC for its racist policies.
The Games of the XX Olympiad open in Munich, West Germany.
Aeroflot Flight 558 crashes in the Abzelilovsky District in Bashkortostan, Russia (then the Soviet Union), killing all 102 people aboard.
Mark Spitz becomes the first competitor to win seven medals at a single Olympic Games.
The Price Is Right premieres on CBS. It currently is the longest running game show on American television.

Munich massacre: A Palestinian terrorist group called "Black September" attacks and takes hostage 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympic Games. Two die in the attack and nine are murdered the following day.

Munich massacre: Nine Israeli athletes die (along with a German policeman) at the hands of the Palestinian "Black September" terrorist group after being taken hostage at the Munich Olympic Games. Two other Israeli athletes were slain in the initial attack the previous day.

In Kentucky's Mammoth Cave National Park, a Cave Research Foundation exploration and mapping team discovers a link between the Mammoth and Flint Ridge cave systems, making it the longest known cave passageway in the world.
The San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit system begins passenger service.
A Scandinavian Airlines System domestic flight from Gothenburg to Stockholm is hijacked and flown to Malmö Bulltofta Airport.
source_pages: Scandinavian_Airlines; Domestic_flight; Gothenburg; Stockholm; Scandinavian_Airlines_System_Flight_130; Malmö_Bulltofta_Airport

event_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos begins authoritarian rule by declaring martial law.
Japan Airlines Flight 472 lands at Juhu Aerodrome instead of Santacruz Airport in Bombay, India.
Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China after breaking official ties with the Republic of China.
Aeroflot Flight 217 crashes outside Moscow, killing 174.
Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571 crashes in the Andes mountains. Twenty-eight survive the crash. All but 16 succumb before rescue on December 23.
Vietnam War: Operation Linebacker, a US bombing campaign against North Vietnam in response to its Easter Offensive, ends after five months.
The three surviving perpetrators of the Munich massacre are released from prison in exchange for the hostages of the hijacked Lufthansa Flight 615.
United States presidential election: U.S. President Richard Nixon is re-elected in the largest landslide victory at the time.
American pay television network Home Box Office (HBO) launches.

Southern Airways Flight 49 from Birmingham, Alabama is hijacked and, at one point, is threatened with crashing into the nuclear installation at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. After two days, the plane lands in Havana, Cuba, where the hijackers are jailed by Fidel Castro.
source_pages: Southern_Airways; Southern_Airways_Flight_49; Birmingham,_Alabama; Aircraft_hijacking; Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory; Havana; Cuba; Fidel_Castro

event_text: Vietnam War: Vietnamization: The United States Army turns over the massive Long Binh military base to South Vietnam.
Voters in South Korea overwhelmingly approve a new constitution, giving legitimacy to Park Chung Hee and the Fourth Republic.
The Soviet Union makes its final attempt at launching the N1 rocket.
Last executions in Paris: Claude Buffet and Roger Bontems are guillotined at La Santé Prison.
Atari releases Pong, the first commercially successful video game.

Vietnam War: White House Press Secretary Ron Ziegler tells the press that there will be no more public announcements concerning American troop withdrawals from Vietnam because troop levels are now down to 27,000.

Gough Whitlam is elected the 21st Prime Minister of Australia in the 1972 Australian federal election, defeating William McMahon and leading the Australian Labor Party back into office after 23 years in Opposition.
Spantax Flight 275 crashes during takeoff from Tenerife North–Ciudad de La Laguna Airport, killing all 155 people on board.
Apollo 17, the last Apollo Moon mission, is launched. The crew takes the photograph known as The Blue Marble as they leave the Earth.
United Airlines Flight 553, a Boeing 737, crashes after aborting its landing attempt at Chicago Midway International Airport, killing 45. This is the first-ever loss of a Boeing 737.
Apollo 17 becomes the sixth and final Apollo mission to land on the Moon.
Apollo program: Eugene Cernan and Harrison Schmitt begin the third and final extra-vehicular activity (EVA) or "Moonwalk" of Apollo 17. To date they are the last humans to set foot on the Moon.
Apollo program: Eugene Cernan is the most recent person to walk on the Moon, after he and Harrison Schmitt complete the third and final extravehicular activity (EVA) of the Apollo 17 mission.
The Constitution of the People's Republic of Bangladesh was enacted.

Vietnam War: President Richard Nixon announces that the United States will engage North Vietnam in Operation Linebacker II, a series of Christmas bombings, after peace talks collapsed with North Vietnam on the 13th.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; President_of_the_United_States; Richard_Nixon; North_Vietnam; Operation_Linebacker_II; Christmas

event_text: Apollo program: The last crewed lunar flight, Apollo 17, carrying Eugene Cernan, Ronald Evans, and Harrison Schmitt, returns to Earth.
source_pages: Apollo_program; Apollo_17; Gene_Cernan; Ronald_Evans_(astronaut); Harrison_Schmitt; Earth

event_text: The Immaculate Reception is caught by Franco Harris to win the Pittsburgh Steelers their first ever playoff victory, after defeating the Oakland Raiders.
A 6.5 magnitude earthquake strikes the Nicaraguan capital of Managua killing more than 10,000.
The 16 survivors of the Andes flight disaster are rescued after 73 days, surviving by cannibalism.

Vietnam War: As part of Operation Linebacker II, 120 American B-52 Stratofortress bombers attacked Hanoi, including 78 launched from Andersen Air Force Base in Guam, the largest single combat launch in Strategic Air Command history.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; Operation_Linebacker_II; Boeing_B-52_Stratofortress; Hanoi; Andersen_Air_Force_Base; Guam; Strategic_Air_Command

event_text: The last scheduled day for induction into the military by the Selective Service System. Due to the fact that President Richard Nixon declared this day a national day of mourning due to former President Harry S Truman's death, approximately 300 men were not able to report due to most Federal offices being closed. Since the draft was not resumed in 1973, they were never drafted.
Eastern Air Lines Flight 401 (a Lockheed L-1011 TriStar) crashes in the Florida Everglades on approach to Miami International Airport, Florida, killing 101 of the 176 people on board.
source_pages: Eastern_Air_Lines_Flight_401; Lockheed_L-1011_TriStar; Everglades; Miami_International_Airport; Florida; December_29

event_text: Vietnam War: Operation Linebacker II ends.
Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom are admitted into the European Economic Community.
In his second shooting spree of the week, Mark Essex fatally shoots seven people and wounds five others at Howard Johnson's Hotel in New Orleans, before being shot to death by police officers.
Soviet space mission Luna 21 is launched.
Watergate scandal: The trial of seven men accused of illegal entry into Democratic Party headquarters at Watergate begins.
Major League Baseball owners vote in approval of the American League adopting the designated hitter position.
Elvis Presley's concert Aloha from Hawaii is broadcast live via satellite, and sets the record as the most watched broadcast by an individual entertainer in television history.
Vietnam War: Citing progress in peace negotiations, President Richard Nixon announces the suspension of offensive action in North Vietnam.
Amílcar Cabral, leader of the independence movement in Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde, is assassinated in Conakry, Guinea.
The Supreme Court of the United States delivers its decisions in Roe v. Wade and Doe v. Bolton, legalizing elective abortion in all fifty states.
The crew of Apollo 17 addresses a joint session of Congress after the completion of the final Apollo Moon landing mission.
A chartered Boeing 707 explodes in flames upon landing at Kano Airport, Nigeria, killing 176.

In a bout for the world heavyweight boxing championship in Kingston, Jamaica, challenger George Foreman knocks down champion Joe Frazier six times in the first two rounds before the fight is stopped by referee Arthur Mercante.
The Paris Peace Accords officially ends the Vietnam War. Colonel William Nolde is killed in action becoming the conflict's last recorded American combat casualty.
EgyptAir Flight 741 crashes into the Kyrenia Mountains in Cyprus, killing 37 people.
The Ms  7.6 Luhuo earthquake strikes Sichuan Province, causing widespread destruction and killing at least 2,199 people.
Over the Sinai Desert, Israeli fighter aircraft shoot down Libyan Arab Airlines Flight 114 jet killing 108 people.
Cold War: Following President Richard Nixon's visit to the People's Republic of China, the two countries agree to establish liaison offices.
The American Indian Movement occupies Wounded Knee in protest of the federal government.
Aeroflot Flight X-167 crashes during takeoff from Semey Airport, killing 32 people.
Black September storms the Saudi embassy in Khartoum, Sudan, resulting in the assassination of three Western hostages.
An Iberia McDonnell Douglas DC-9 collide in mid-air with a Spantax Convair 990 Coronado over Nantes, France, killing all 68 people aboard the DC-9, including music manager Michael Jeffery.
source_pages: Iberia_(airline); McDonnell_Douglas_DC-9; 1973_Nantes_mid-air_collision; Spantax; Convair_990_Coronado; Nantes; Michael_Jeffery_(music_manager); March_5

event_text: The Pulitzer Prize–winning photograph Burst of Joy is taken, depicting a former prisoner of war being reunited with his family, which came to symbolize the end of United States involvement in the Vietnam War.
Vietnam War: The last United States combat soldiers leave South Vietnam.
Operation Barrel Roll, a covert American bombing campaign in Laos to stop communist infiltration of South Vietnam, ends.
Project Tiger, a tiger conservation project, is launched in the Jim Corbett National Park, India.
Launch of the LexisNexis computerized legal research service.
Martin Cooper of Motorola makes the first handheld mobile phone call to Joel S. Engel of Bell Labs.
The Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York City are officially dedicated.
A Lockheed C-141 Starlifter, dubbed the Hanoi Taxi, makes the last flight of Operation Homecoming.
Launch of Pioneer 11 spacecraft.
The American League of Major League Baseball begins using the designated hitter.
Invicta International Airlines Flight 435 crashes in a snowstorm on approach to Basel, Switzerland, killing 108 people.
The Portuguese Socialist Party is founded in the German town of Bad Münstereifel.
The Dark Side of the Moon by Pink Floyd, recorded in Abbey Road Studios goes to number one on the US Billboard chart, beginning a record-breaking 741-week chart run.
Watergate scandal: U.S. President Richard Nixon fires White House Counsel John Dean; other top aides, most notably H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman, resign.
source_pages: Watergate_scandal; Richard_Nixon; White_House; John_Dean; H._R._Haldeman; John_Ehrlichman

event_text: The 108-story Sears Tower in Chicago is topped out at 1,451 feet (442 m) as the world's tallest building.
Secretariat wins the 1973 Kentucky Derby in 1:59.4, an as-yet-unbeaten record.
A 71-day standoff between federal authorities and the American Indian Movement members occupying the Pine Ridge Reservation at Wounded Knee, South Dakota ends with the surrender of the militants.
Citing government misconduct, Daniel Ellsberg's charges for his involvement in releasing the Pentagon Papers to The New York Times are dismissed.
Aeroflot Flight 6551 crashes in Semey, Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic (now Kazakhstan), killing all 63 aboard.
Skylab, the United States' first space station, is launched.
Watergate scandal: Televised hearings begin in the United States Senate.
Aeroflot Flight 109 is hijacked mid-flight and the aircraft is subsequently destroyed when the hijacker's bomb explodes, killing all 82 people on board.
In protest against the dictatorship in Greece, the captain and crew on Greek naval destroyer Velos mutiny and refuse to return to Greece, instead anchoring at Fiumicino, Italy.
Tom Bradley is elected the first black mayor of Los Angeles, California.
The United States Senate votes to cut off funding for the bombing of Khmer Rouge targets within Cambodia, hastening the end of the Cambodian Civil War.
Indian Airlines Flight 440 crashes near Palam Airport in Delhi, killing 48.
A Soviet supersonic Tupolev Tu-144 crashes near Goussainville, France, killing 14, the first crash of a supersonic passenger aircraft.
In horse racing, Secretariat wins the U.S. Triple Crown.

In a game versus the Philadelphia Phillies at Veterans Stadium, Los Angeles Dodgers teammates Steve Garvey, Davey Lopes, Ron Cey and Bill Russell play together as an infield for the first time, going on to set the Major League Baseball record of staying together for 8+1⁄2 years.
Snipers fire upon left-wing Peronists in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in what is known as the Ezeiza massacre. At least 13 are killed and more than 300 are injured.
Aeroméxico Flight 229 crashes on approach to Licenciado Gustavo Díaz Ordaz International Airport, killing all 27 people on board.
The Primer Congreso del Hombre Andino is inaugurated in Arica, Chile.

In its decision in Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15, the Supreme Court of the United States establishes the Miller test for determining whether something is obscene and not protected speech under the U.S. constitution.

A fire at a house in Hull, England, which kills a six-year-old boy is passed off as an accident; it later emerges as the first of 26 deaths by fire caused over the next seven years by serial arsonist Peter Dinsdale.

The UpStairs Lounge arson attack takes place at a gay bar located on the second floor of the three-story building at 141 Chartres Street in the French Quarter of New Orleans, Louisiana, US. Thirty-two people die as a result of fire or smoke inhalation.
The President of Uruguay Juan María Bordaberry dissolves Parliament and establishes a dictatorship.
Elections are held for the Northern Ireland Assembly, which will lead to power-sharing between unionists and nationalists in Northern Ireland for the first time.
Concorde 001 intercepts the path of a total solar eclipse and follows the moon's shadow, experiencing the longest total eclipse observation.
David Bowie retires his stage persona Ziggy Stardust with the surprise announcement that it is "the last show that we'll ever do" on the last day of the Ziggy Stardust Tour.

Barbados, Guyana, Jamaica, and Trinidad and Tobago sign the Treaty of Chaguaramas in Chaguaramas, Trinidad and Tobago establishing the Caribbean Community (CARICOM). It replaces the Caribbean Free Trade Association as another step towards Caribbean regional integration.
source_pages: Barbados; Guyana; Jamaica; Trinidad_and_Tobago; Treaty_of_Chaguaramas; Chaguaramas,_Trinidad_and_Tobago; Caribbean_Community; Caribbean_Free_Trade_Association; Regional_integration; July_4

event_text: A boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE) in Kingman, Arizona, following a fire that broke out as propane was being transferred from a railroad car to a storage tank, kills eleven firefighters.
Juvénal Habyarimana seizes power over Rwanda in a coup d'état.
The Bahamas gains full independence within the Commonwealth of Nations.
Varig Flight 820 crashes near Paris on approach to Orly Airport, killing 123 of the 134 on board. In response, the FAA bans smoking in airplane lavatories.
A fire destroys the entire sixth floor of the National Personnel Records Center of the United States.
Watergate scandal: Alexander Butterfield reveals the existence of a secret Oval Office taping system to investigators for the Senate Watergate Committee.
King Mohammed Zahir Shah of Afghanistan, while having surgery in Italy, is deposed by his cousin Mohammed Daoud Khan.
In Lillehammer, Norway, Mossad agents kill a waiter whom they mistakenly thought was involved in the 1972 Munich Olympics Massacre.
Pan Am Flight 816 crashes after takeoff from Faa'a International Airport in Papeete, French Polynesia, killing 78.
Soviet Mars 5 space probe is launched.
Summer Jam at Watkins Glen: Nearly 600,000 people attend a rock festival at the Watkins Glen International Raceway.
Greeks vote to abolish the monarchy, beginning the first period of the Metapolitefsi.
Driver Roger Williamson is killed during the Dutch Grand Prix, after a suspected tire failure causes his car to pitch into the barriers at high speed.
A Delta Air Lines jetliner, flight DL 723 crashes while landing in fog at Logan International Airport, Boston, Massachusetts killing 89.
A flash fire kills 50 people at the Summerland amusement centre at Douglas, Isle of Man.
Mars 6 is launched from the USSR.
Kim Dae-jung, a South Korean politician and later president of South Korea, is kidnapped.
Mars 7 is launched from the USSR.

At the 1520 Sedgwick Avenue apartment building in The Bronx, New York, DJ Kool Herc hosts a house party widely considered to mark the birthplace of hip hop culture and music. DJ Kool Herc demonstrates a new technique of beat juggling and Coke La Rock performs a new style of vocal performance called rapping.
source_pages: 1520_Sedgwick_Avenue; The_Bronx; DJ_Kool_Herc; Hip-hop; August_11; Beat_juggling; Coke_La_Rock; Rapping

event_text: Aviaco Flight 118 crashes on approach to A Coruña Airport in A Coruña, Spain, killing all 85 people on the plane and one other one the ground.
Vietnam War: The USAF bombing of Cambodia ends.
Aeroflot Flight A-13 crashes after takeoff from Baku-Bina International Airport in Azerbaijan, killing 56 people and injuring eight.
The Congress of Chile votes in favour of a resolution condemning President Salvador Allende's government and demands that he resign or else be unseated through force and new elections.
A bank robbery gone wrong in Stockholm, Sweden, turns into a hostage crisis; over the next five days the hostages begin to sympathise with their captors, leading to the term "Stockholm syndrome".

Norrmalmstorg robbery: Stockholm police secure the surrenders of hostage-takers Jan-Erik Olsson and Clark Olofsson, defusing the Norrmalmstorg hostage crisis. The behaviours of the hostages later give rise to the term Stockholm syndrome.
source_pages: Norrmalmstorg_robbery; Stockholm; Jan-Erik_Olsson; Clark_Olofsson; Stockholm_syndrome; August_28

event_text: A 76-hour multinational rescue effort in the Celtic Sea resulted in the Rescue of Roger Mallinson and Roger Chapman.
World Airways Flight 802 crashes into Mount Dutton in King Cove, Alaska, killing six people.
A coup in Chile, headed by General Augusto Pinochet, topples the democratically elected president Salvador Allende.
JAT Airways Flight 769 crashes into the Maganik mountain range while on approach to Titograd Airport, killing 35 passengers and six crew.
The Bahamas, East Germany and West Germany are admitted to the United Nations.
Billie Jean King beats Bobby Riggs in the Battle of the Sexes tennis match at the Houston Astrodome.
Singer Jim Croce, songwriter and musician Maury Muehleisen and four others die when their light aircraft crashes shortly after takeoff from Natchitoches Regional Airport in Louisiana.
Argentine general election: Juan Perón returns to power in Argentina.
Guinea-Bissau declares its independence from Portugal.
Texas International Airlines Flight 655 crashes into the Black Fork Mountain Wilderness near Mena, Arkansas, killing all 11 people on board.
The ITT Building in New York City is bombed in protest at ITT's alleged involvement in the coup d'état in Chile.
Egypt and Syria launch coordinated attacks against Israel, beginning the Yom Kippur War.
Yom Kippur War: Israel loses more than 150 tanks in a failed attack on Egyptian-occupied positions.
Spyros Markezinis begins his 48-day term as prime minister in an abortive attempt to lead Greece to parliamentary rule.
U.S. Vice President Spiro Agnew resigns after being charged with evasion of federal income tax.
President Nixon nominates House Minority Leader Gerald R. Ford as the successor to Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.
In the Thammasat student uprising, over 100,000 people protest in Thailand against the military government. Seventy-seven are killed and 857 are injured by soldiers.
Henry Kissinger and Lê Đức Thọ are awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
OPEC imposes an oil embargo against countries they deem to have helped Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
President Nixon rejects an Appeals Court decision that he turn over the Watergate tapes.

Watergate scandal: "Saturday Night Massacre": United States President Richard Nixon fires U.S. Attorney General Elliot Richardson and Deputy Attorney General William Ruckelshaus after they refuse to fire special prosecutor Archibald Cox, who is finally fired by Solicitor General Robert Bork.
source_pages: Watergate_scandal; Saturday_Night_Massacre; Richard_Nixon; Elliot_Richardson; William_Ruckelshaus; Archibald_Cox; Robert_Bork

event_text: The Sydney Opera House is opened by Elizabeth II after 14 years of construction.
Fred Dryer of the Los Angeles Rams becomes the first player in NFL history to score two safeties in the same game.
Egypt and Israel accept United Nations Security Council Resolution 339.
The Bosphorus Bridge in Turkey is completed, connecting the continents of Europe and Asia over the Bosphorus for the second time.
Mountjoy Prison helicopter escape. Three Provisional Irish Republican Army members escape from Mountjoy Prison, Dublin aboard a hijacked helicopter that landed in the exercise yard.
Watergate scandal: Leon Jaworski is appointed as the new Watergate Special Prosecutor.
The Indian state of Mysore is renamed as Karnataka to represent all the regions within Karunadu.
Aeroflot Flight 19 is hijacked and diverted to Vnukovo International Airport, where the aircraft is stormed by authorities.
Mariner program: NASA launches the Mariner 10 toward Mercury. On March 29, 1974, it becomes the first space probe to reach that planet.
source_pages: Mariner_program; NASA; Mariner_10; Mercury_(planet); November_3; Uncrewed_spacecraft

event_text: The Netherlands experiences the first car-free Sunday caused by the 1973 oil crisis. Highways are used only by cyclists and roller skaters.
The United States Congress overrides President Richard Nixon's veto of the War Powers Resolution, which limits presidential power to wage war without congressional approval.
The right ear of John Paul Getty III is delivered to a newspaper outlet along with a ransom note, convincing his father to pay US$2.9 million.
In the United Kingdom, Princess Anne marries Captain Mark Phillips, in Westminster Abbey.
The Athens Polytechnic uprising, a massive demonstration of popular rejection of the Greek military junta of 1967–74, begins.
Skylab program: NASA launches Skylab 4 with a crew of three astronauts from Cape Canaveral, Florida for an 84-day mission.
source_pages: Skylab; NASA; Skylab_4; Astronaut; Cape_Canaveral,_Florida; November_16

event_text: U.S. President Richard Nixon signs the Trans-Alaska Pipeline Authorization Act into law, authorizing the construction of the Alaska Pipeline.
Watergate scandal: In Orlando, Florida, U.S. President Richard Nixon tells 400 Associated Press managing editors "I am not a crook."
The Athens Polytechnic uprising against the military regime ends in a bloodshed in the Greek capital.
A national speed limit is imposed on the Autobahn in Germany because of the 1973 oil crisis. The speed limit lasts only four months.
Georgios Papadopoulos, head of the military Regime of the Colonels in Greece, is ousted in a hardliners' coup led by Brigadier General Dimitrios Ioannidis.
Twenty-fifth Amendment: The United States Senate votes 92–3 to confirm Gerald Ford as Vice President of the United States. (On December 6, the House will confirm him 387–35).
Papua New Guinea gains self-government from Australia.
Pioneer program: Pioneer 10 sends back the first close-up images of Jupiter.
The Twenty-fifth Amendment: The United States House of Representatives votes 387–35 to confirm Gerald Ford as Vice President of the United States. (On November 27, the Senate confirmed him 92–3.)
British and Irish authorities sign the Sunningdale Agreement in an attempt to establish a power-sharing Northern Ireland Executive and a cross-border Council of Ireland.
John Paul Getty III, grandson of American billionaire J. Paul Getty, is found alive near Naples, Italy, after being kidnapped by an Italian gang on July 10.
The American Psychiatric Association votes 13–0 to remove homosexuality from its official list of psychiatric disorders, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.
Aeroflot Flight 2022 crashes in the Soviet Union's (now Russia) Volokolamsky District, killing all 51 aboard, including four Lithuanian doctors.
Thirty passengers are killed in an attack by Palestinian terrorists on Rome's Leonardo da Vinci–Fiumicino Airport.
Soviet Soyuz Programme: Soyuz 13, crewed by cosmonauts Valentin Lebedev and Pyotr Klimuk, is launched from Baikonur in the Soviet Union.
source_pages: Soyuz_programme; Soyuz_13; List_of_cosmonauts; Valentin_Lebedev; Pyotr_Klimuk; Baikonur; Soviet_Union

event_text: Assassination of Luis Carrero Blanco: A car bomb planted by ETA in Madrid kills three people, including the Prime Minister of Spain, Admiral Luis Carrero Blanco.
source_pages: Assassination_of_Luis_Carrero_Blanco; Car_bomb; ETA_(separatist_group); Madrid; Prime_Minister_of_Spain; Luis_Carrero_Blanco; December_20

event_text: The Geneva Conference on the Arab–Israeli conflict opens.
A Royal Air Maroc Sud Aviation Caravelle crashes near Tangier-Boukhalef Airport in Tangier, Morocco, killing 106.
District of Columbia Home Rule Act is passed, allowing residents of Washington, D.C. to elect their own local government.
The United States Endangered Species Act is signed into law by President Richard Nixon.
United States President Richard Nixon signs a bill lowering the maximum U.S. speed limit to 55 mph in order to conserve gasoline during an OPEC embargo.
source_pages: Richard_Nixon; National_Maximum_Speed_Law; Speed_limit; Gasoline; OPEC; January_2

event_text: In response to the 1973 oil crisis, daylight saving time commences nearly four months early in the United States.
Aeroflot Flight H-75 crashes near Mukachevo, killing 24.
A Disengagement of Forces agreement is signed between the Israeli and Egyptian governments, ending conflict on the Egyptian front of the Yom Kippur War.
China gains control over all the Paracel Islands after a military engagement between the naval forces of China and South Vietnam.
Turkish Airlines Flight 301 crashes during takeoff from Izmir Cumaovası Airport (now İzmir Adnan Menderes Airport), killing 66 of the 73 people on board the Fokker F28 Fellowship.
Pan Am Flight 806 crashes near Pago Pago International Airport in American Samoa, killing 97.
A fire in the 25-story Joelma Building in São Paulo, Brazil kills 189 and injures 293.
The Symbionese Liberation Army kidnaps Patty Hearst in Berkeley, California.

M62 coach bombing: The Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) explodes a bomb on a bus carrying off-duty British Armed Forces personnel in Yorkshire, England. Nine soldiers and three civilians are killed.
Grenada gains independence from the United Kingdom.
The crew of Skylab 4, the last mission to visit the American space station Skylab, returns to Earth after 84 days in space.
Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1970, is exiled from the Soviet Union.
Robert K. Preston, a disgruntled U.S. Army private, buzzes the White House in a stolen helicopter.
The last Israeli soldiers leave the west bank of the Suez Canal pursuant to a truce with Egypt.
The Organisation of the Islamic Conference summit begins in Lahore, Pakistan. Thirty-seven countries attend and twenty-two heads of state and government participate. It also recognizes Bangladesh.

Samuel Byck attempts to hijack an aircraft at Baltimore/Washington International Airport with the intention of crashing it into the White House to assassinate Richard Nixon, but commits suicide after being wounded by police.
The Symbionese Liberation Army demands $4 million more to release kidnap victim Patty Hearst.
The British election ended in a hung parliament after the Jeremy Thorpe-led Liberal Party achieved their biggest vote share since 1929.
Watergate scandal: Seven are indicted for their role in the Watergate break-in and charged with conspiracy to obstruct justice.
Turkish Airlines Flight 981 crashes at Ermenonville near Paris, France killing all 346 aboard.
Yom Kippur War: Israeli forces withdraw from the west bank of the Suez Canal.
The Mars 7 Flyby bus releases the descent module too early, missing Mars.
1974 Belgian general election: Elections are held in Belgium for all 212 seats in the Chamber of Representatives, the Belgian Socialist Party taking the majority with 59.
Sierra Pacific Airlines Flight 802 crashes into the White Mountains near Bishop, California, killing 36.
Fifteen people are killed when Sterling Airways Flight 901, a Sud Aviation Caravelle, catches fire following a landing gear collapse at Mehrabad International Airport in Tehran, Iran.
source_pages: Sterling_Airways_Flight_901; Sud_Aviation_Caravelle; Landing_gear; Mehrabad_International_Airport; Tehran; March_15

event_text: Güzel İstanbul, a nude sculpture by Gürdal Duyar in Istanbul is torn down in the middle of the night.
NASA's Mariner 10 becomes the first space probe to fly by Mercury.
Terracotta Army was discovered in Shaanxi province, China.
The Local Government Act 1972 of England and Wales comes into effect.
The 1974 Super Outbreak occurs, the second largest tornado outbreak in recorded history (after the 2011 Super Outbreak). The death toll is 315, with nearly 5,500 injured.
Carrie, the first novel by American author Stephen King, is published for the first time with a print run of 30,000 copies.
In Brighton, United Kingdom, ABBA wins the 1974 edition of the Eurovision Song Contest with "Waterloo", the first of a joint-record seven Swedish wins.
source_pages: Brighton; ABBA; Eurovision_Song_Contest_1974; Eurovision_Song_Contest; Waterloo_(song); Sweden; April_6

event_text: The first California Jam festival takes place at the Ontario Motor Speedway in Ontario, California. Co-headlined by Deep Purple and Emerson, Lake & Palmer. The festival set what were then records for the loudest amplification system ever installed, the highest paid attendance, and highest gross in history.
source_pages: California_Jam; Ontario_Motor_Speedway; Ontario,_California; Deep_Purple; Emerson,_Lake_&_Palmer; April_6

event_text: Hank Aaron passes Babe Ruth as the all-time leader in career home runs by hitting his 715th home run off of Al Downing at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium.
Pan Am Flight 812 crashes on approach to Ngurah Rai International Airport in Denpasar, Bali, Indonesia, killing all 107 people on board.
Carnation Revolution: A leftist military coup in Portugal overthrows the authoritarian-conservative Estado Novo regime.
109 people are killed in a plane crash near Pulkovo Airport.
Watergate scandal: United States President Richard Nixon announces the release of edited transcripts of White House tape recordings relating to the scandal.
Watergate scandal: The  United States House Committee on the Judiciary opens formal and public impeachment hearings against President Richard Nixon.
Ma'alot massacre: Members of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine attack and take hostages at an Israeli school; a total of 31 people are killed, including 22 schoolchildren.
Josip Broz Tito is elected president for life of Yugoslavia.
The Troubles: Thirty-three civilians are killed and 300 injured when the Ulster Volunteer Force (UVF) detonates four car bombs in Dublin and Monaghan, Ireland.
source_pages: The_Troubles; Dublin_and_Monaghan_bombings; Ulster_Volunteer_Force; Dublin; Monaghan; Republic_of_Ireland

event_text: Police in Los Angeles raid the Symbionese Liberation Army's headquarters, killing six members, including Camilla Hall.
Nuclear weapons testing: Under project Smiling Buddha, India successfully detonates its first nuclear weapon becoming the sixth nation to do so.
Northern Ireland's power-sharing Sunningdale Agreement collapses following a general strike by loyalists.
SETA, a Finnish LGBT rights organisation, is founded in Helsinki.
The Airbus A300 passenger aircraft first enters service.
The Heimlich maneuver for rescuing choking victims is published in the journal Emergency Medicine.
The Universal Product Code is scanned for the first time to sell a package of Wrigley's chewing gum at the Marsh Supermarket in Troy, Ohio.
U.S. president Richard Nixon visits the Soviet Union.
Vice President Isabel Perón assumes powers and duties as Acting President of Argentina, while her husband President Juan Perón is terminally ill.
Mikhail Baryshnikov defects from the Soviet Union to Canada while on tour with the Kirov Ballet.
The Baltimore municipal strike of 1974 begins.
An EgyptAir Tupolev Tu-154 stalls and crashes at Cairo International Airport, killing all six people on board.
In Nicosia, Cyprus, Greek junta-sponsored nationalists launch a coup d'état, deposing Makarios III and installing Nikos Sampson as the president of Cyprus.
source_pages: Nicosia; Greek_junta; Coup_d'état; Makarios_III; Nikos_Sampson; President_of_Cyprus

event_text: Turkish invasion of Cyprus: Forces from Turkey invade Cyprus after a coup d'état, organised by the dictator of Greece, against president Makarios.
The Greek military junta collapses, and former Prime Minister Konstantinos Karamanlis is invited to lead the new government, beginning Greece's metapolitefsi era.

Watergate scandal: The United States Supreme Court unanimously ruled that President Richard Nixon did not have the authority to withhold subpoenaed White House tapes and they order him to surrender the tapes to the Watergate special prosecutor.
source_pages: Watergate_scandal; Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States; President_of_the_United_States; Richard_Nixon; White_House; United_States_v._Nixon

event_text: Greek Prime Minister Konstantinos Karamanlis forms the country's first civil government after seven years of military rule.
Watergate scandal: The House of Representatives Judiciary Committee votes 27 to 11 to recommend the first article of impeachment (for obstruction of justice) against President Richard Nixon.
source_pages: Watergate_scandal; United_States_House_of_Representatives; United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary; Impeachment_process_against_Richard_Nixon; Article_of_impeachment; Federal_impeachment_in_the_United_States; Obstruction_of_justice_in_the_United_States; President_of_the_United_States; Richard_Nixon

event_text: Spetsgruppa A, Russia's elite special force, was formed.
Watergate scandal: U.S. President Richard Nixon releases subpoenaed White House recordings after being ordered to do so by the Supreme Court of the United States.
Cyprus dispute: The United Nations Security Council authorizes the UNFICYP to create the "Green Line", dividing Cyprus into two zones.
A bomb explodes in the Italicus Express train at San Benedetto Val di Sambro, Italy, killing 12 people and wounding 22.

Watergate scandal: President Richard Nixon, under orders of the US Supreme Court, releases the "Smoking Gun" tape, recorded on June 23, 1972, clearly revealing his actions in covering up and interfering investigations into the break-in. His political support vanishes completely.
Philippe Petit performs a high wire act between the twin towers of the World Trade Center 1,368 feet (417 m) in the air.
President Richard Nixon, in a nationwide television address, announces his resignation from the office of the President of the United States effective noon the next day.
As a direct result of the Watergate scandal, Richard Nixon becomes the first President of the United States to resign from office. Vice President Gerald Ford becomes president.
Yuk Young-soo, First Lady of South Korea, is killed during an apparent assassination attempt upon President Park Chung Hee.
A Belgrade–Dortmund express train derails at the main train station in Zagreb killing 153 passengers.

A powerful bomb explodes at the Mitsubishi Heavy Industries headquarters in Marunouchi, Tokyo. Eight are killed, 378 are injured. Eight left-wing activists are arrested on May 19, 1975, by Japanese authorities.
The Third World Population Conference ends in Bucharest, Romania. At the end of the ceremony, the UN-Romanian Demographic Centre is inaugurated.
The SR-71 Blackbird sets (and holds) the record for flying from New York to London in the time of one hour, 54 minutes and 56.4 seconds at a speed of 1,435.587 miles per hour (2,310.353 km/h).
Watergate scandal: US President Gerald Ford signs the pardon of Richard Nixon for any crimes Nixon may have committed while in office.
Guinea-Bissau gains independence from Portugal.
Eastern Air Lines Flight 212 crashes in Charlotte, North Carolina, killing 69 passengers and two crew.
Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, 'Messiah' of the Rastafari movement, is deposed following a military coup by the Derg, ending a reign of 58 years.
source_pages: Haile_Selassie; Ethiopia; Messiah; Rastafari; Coup_d'état; Derg

event_text: Air Vietnam Flight 706 is hijacked, then crashes while attempting to land with 75 on board.
Bangladesh, Grenada and Guinea-Bissau join the United Nations.
Hurricane Fifi strikes Honduras with 110 mph winds, killing 5,000 people.
Dr. Frank Jobe performs first ulnar collateral ligament replacement surgery (better known as Tommy John surgery) on baseball player Tommy John.
Bombs planted by the PIRA in pubs in Guildford kill four British soldiers and one civilian.
Franklin National Bank collapses due to fraud and mismanagement; at the time it is the largest bank failure in the history of the United States.
Niue becomes a self-governing colony of New Zealand.
The Arecibo message is broadcast from Puerto Rico.
The United States Department of Justice files its final anti-trust suit against AT&T Corporation. This suit later leads to the breakup of AT&T and its Bell System.

The first fatal crash of a Boeing 747 occurs when Lufthansa Flight 540 crashes while attempting to takeoff from Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi, Kenya, killing 59 out of the 157 people on board.
The Birmingham pub bombings kill 21 people. The Birmingham Six are sentenced to life in prison for the crime but subsequently acquitted.
Sixty Ethiopian politicians, aristocrats, military officers, and other persons are executed by the provisional military government.

Donald Johanson and Tom Gray discover the 40% complete Australopithecus afarensis skeleton, nicknamed "Lucy" (after The Beatles song "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds"), in the Awash Valley of Ethiopia's Afar Depression.
source_pages: Donald_Johanson; Australopithecus_afarensis; Lucy_(Australopithecus); The_Beatles; Lucy_in_the_Sky_with_Diamonds; Awash_River; Ethiopia; Afar_Triangle

event_text: TWA Flight 514, a Boeing 727, crashes northwest of Dulles International Airport, killing all 92 people on board.
Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 6231, another Boeing 727, crashes northwest of John F. Kennedy International Airport.
Martinair Flight 138 crashes into the Saptha Kanya mountain range in Maskeliya, Sri Lanka, killing 191.
A plebiscite results in the abolition of monarchy in Greece.
Malta becomes a republic within the Commonwealth of Nations.
In the Vietnam War, the North Vietnamese forces launch their 1975 Spring Offensive (to 30 April 1975), which results in the final capitulation of South Vietnam.
Nelson Rockefeller is sworn in as Vice President of the United States under President Gerald Ford under the provisions of the Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
Grande Comore, Anjouan and Mohéli vote to become the independent nation of Comoros. Mayotte remains under French administration.
The house of former British Prime Minister Edward Heath is attacked by members of the Provisional IRA.
Cyclone Tracy devastates Darwin, Australia.
At the opening of a new railway line, a bomb blast at Samastipur, Bihar, India, fatally wounds Lalit Narayan Mishra, Minister of Railways.
The Federal Rules of Evidence are approved by the United States Congress.
This date overflowed the 12-bit field that had been used in TOPS-10. There were numerous problems and crashes related to this bug while an alternative format was developed.
The Tasman Bridge in Tasmania, Australia, is struck by the bulk ore carrier Lake Illawarra, killing twelve people.
Ella T. Grasso becomes Governor of Connecticut, the first woman to serve as a Governor in the United States other than by succeeding her husband.
The Alvor Agreement is signed, ending the Angolan War of Independence and giving Angola independence from Portugal.
The Monitor National Marine Sanctuary is established as the first United States National Marine Sanctuary.
Turkish Airlines Flight 345 crashes into the Sea of Marmara near Istanbul Yeşilköy Airport, killing 42.
Haicheng earthquake (magnitude 7.3 on the Richter scale) occurs in Haicheng, Liaoning, China.
Riots break out in Lima, Peru after the police forces go on strike the day before. The uprising (locally known as the Limazo) is bloodily suppressed by the military dictatorship.
The Soyuz 17 Soviet spacecraft returns to Earth.
Fire at One World Trade Center (North Tower) of the World Trade Center in New York.
Watergate scandal: Former United States Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former White House aides H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman are sentenced to prison.
source_pages: Watergate_scandal; United_States_Attorney_General; John_N._Mitchell; White_House; H._R._Haldeman; John_Ehrlichman

event_text: In London, an underground train fails to stop at Moorgate terminus station and crashes into the end of the tunnel, killing 43 people.
The Zapruder film of the assassination of John F. Kennedy is shown in motion to a national TV audience for the first time by Robert J. Groden and Dick Gregory.
Algiers Accord: Iran and Iraq announce a settlement of their border dispute.
Vietnam War: Ho Chi Minh Campaign: North Vietnamese troops attack Ban Mê Thuột in the South on their way to capturing Saigon in the final push for victory over South Vietnam.
A fire at the Browns Ferry Nuclear Power Plant in Decatur, Alabama, causes a dangerous reduction in cooling water levels.
Faisal of Saudi Arabia is shot and killed by his nephew.
The Biological Weapons Convention comes into force.
Construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System begins.
Vietnam War: Thousands of civilian refugees flee from Quảng Ngãi Province in front of advancing North Vietnamese troops.
Vietnam War: Operation Babylift, a mass evacuation of children in the closing stages of the war begins.
Bobby Fischer refuses to play in a chess match against Anatoly Karpov, giving Karpov the title of World Champion by default.
Microsoft is founded as a partnership between Bill Gates and Paul Allen in Albuquerque, New Mexico.
Vietnam War: A United States Air Force Lockheed C-5A Galaxy transporting orphans, crashes near Saigon, South Vietnam shortly after takeoff, killing 172 people.
An attack by the Phalangist resistance kills 26 militia members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, marking the start of the 15-year Lebanese Civil War.
The Cambodian Civil War ends. The Khmer Rouge captures the capital Phnom Penh and Cambodian government forces surrender.
India's first satellite Aryabhata launched in orbit from Kapustin Yar, Russia.
South Vietnamese forces withdraw from the town of Xuan Loc in the last major battle of the Vietnam War.
Vietnam War: President of South Vietnam Nguyễn Văn Thiệu flees Saigon, as Xuân Lộc, the last South Vietnamese outpost blocking a direct North Vietnamese assault on Saigon, falls.
source_pages: Vietnam_War; South_Vietnam; Nguyễn_Văn_Thiệu; Ho_Chi_Minh_City; Xuân_Lộc_district; North_Vietnam; Battle_of_Xuân_Lộc

event_text: General Cao Văn Viên, chief of the South Vietnamese military, departs for the US as the North Vietnamese Army closes in on victory.

Vietnam War: Operation Frequent Wind: The U.S. begins to evacuate U.S. citizens from Saigon before an expected North Vietnamese takeover. U.S. involvement in the war comes to an end. This happens after the Bombing of Tan Son Nhut Air Base.
Vietnam War: The North Vietnamese Army completes its capture of all parts of South Vietnam-held Trường Sa Islands.
Fall of Saigon: Communist forces gain control of Saigon. The Vietnam War formally ends with the unconditional surrender of South Vietnamese president Dương Văn Minh.
source_pages: Fall_of_Saigon; Communism; Ho_Chi_Minh_City; Vietnam_War; South_Vietnam; Dương_Văn_Minh

event_text: The Särkänniemi Amusement Park opens in Tampere, Finland.
During a lull in fighting, 100,000 Armenians gather in Beirut for the 60th anniversary commemorations of the Armenian genocide.
Sony introduces the Betamax videocassette recorder.
Indochina Wars: Democratic Kampuchea naval forces capture the SS Mayaguez.
Junko Tabei from Japan becomes the first woman to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
Dibbles Bridge coach crash near Grassington, in North Yorkshire, England, kills 33 – the highest ever death toll in a road accident in the United Kingdom.
Fifteen West African countries sign the Treaty of Lagos, creating the Economic Community of West African States.
At Brampton Centennial Secondary School, student Michael Slobodian kills two people and injures 13 others before committing suicide.
European Space Agency is established.
The Patriotic Union of Kurdistan was founded by Jalal Talabani, Nawshirwan Mustafa, Fuad Masum and others.
Governor of California Jerry Brown signs the California Agricultural Labor Relations Act into law, the first law in the United States giving farmworkers collective bargaining rights.
The Suez Canal opens for the first time since the Six-Day War.
The United Kingdom holds its first country-wide referendum on membership of the European Economic Community (EEC).
British referendum results in continued membership of the European Economic Community, with 67% of votes in favour.
Sony launches Betamax, the first videocassette recorder format.

State of Uttar Pradesh v. Raj Narain: Judge Jagmohanlal Sinha rules against Indira Gandhi in a case on her election to the Indian Parliament, and that she should be banned from holding any public office, triggering a political crisis.
The film Jaws is released in the United States, becoming the highest-grossing film of that time and starting the trend of films known as "summer blockbusters".

Eastern Air Lines Flight 66 encounters severe wind shear and crashes on final approach to New York's JFK Airport killing 113 of the 124 passengers on board, making it the deadliest U.S. plane crash at the time. This accident led to decades of research into downburst and microburst phenomena and their effects on aircraft.
Mozambique achieves independence from Portugal.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of internal emergency in India.

Two FBI agents and a member of the American Indian Movement are killed in a shootout on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota; Leonard Peltier is later convicted of the murders in a controversial trial.
Pope Paul VI ordains some 350 priests in St. Peter's Square in the largest ordination in history
Arthur Ashe becomes the first black man to win the Wimbledon singles title.
Cape Verde gains its independence from Portugal.
The Comoros declares independence from France.
São Tomé and Príncipe declare independence from Portugal.

Space Race: Apollo–Soyuz Test Project features the dual launch of an Apollo spacecraft and a Soyuz spacecraft on the first Soviet-United States human-crewed flight. It was the last launch of both an Apollo spacecraft, and the Saturn family of rockets.
Aeroflot Flight E-15 crashes on approach to Batumi International Airport, killing 40.
Apollo–Soyuz Test Project: An American Apollo and a Soviet Soyuz spacecraft dock with each other in orbit marking the first such link-up between spacecraft from the two nations.
Mayor of Jaffna and former MP Alfred Duraiappah is shot dead.
Jimmy Hoffa disappears from the parking lot of the Machus Red Fox restaurant in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, a suburb of Detroit, at about 2:30 p.m. He is never seen or heard from again.
The Troubles: Three members of a popular cabaret band and two gunmen are killed during a botched paramilitary attack in Northern Ireland.
A privately chartered Boeing 707 strikes a mountain peak and crashes near Agadir, Morocco, killing 188.

The Japanese Red Army takes more than 50 hostages at the AIA Building housing several embassies in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The hostages include the U.S. consul and the Swedish Chargé d'affaires. The gunmen win the release of five imprisoned comrades and fly with them to Libya.
East Timor: Governor Mário Lemos Pires of Portuguese Timor abandons the capital Dili, following a coup by the Timorese Democratic Union (UDT) and the outbreak of civil war between UDT and Fretilin.
source_pages: Timor-Leste; Mário_Lemos_Pires; Portuguese_Timor; Dili; Timorese_Democratic_Union; Fretilin

event_text: Bangladeshi leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman is killed along with most members of his family during a military coup.
Takeo Miki makes the first official pilgrimage to Yasukuni Shrine by an incumbent prime minister on the anniversary of the end of World War II.

Australian Prime Minister Gough Whitlam symbolically hands over land to the Gurindji people after the eight-year Wave Hill walk-off, a landmark event in the history of Indigenous land rights in Australia, commemorated in a 1991 song by Paul Kelly and an annual celebration.
source_pages: Gough_Whitlam; Gurindji_people; Wave_Hill_walk-off; Indigenous_land_rights_in_Australia; Paul_Kelly_(Australian_musician); August_16

event_text: Viking program: NASA launches the Viking 1 planetary probe toward Mars.
ČSA Flight 540 crashes on approach to Damascus International Airport in Damascus, Syria, killing 126 people.

The start of the Wave Hill walk-off by Gurindji people in Australia, lasting eight years, a landmark event in the history of Indigenous land rights in Australia, commemorated in a 1991 Paul Kelly song and an annual celebration.
The Pontiac Silverdome opens in Pontiac, Michigan, 30 miles (48 km) northwest of Detroit, Michigan
The Governor of Portuguese Timor abandons its capital, Dili, and flees to Atauro Island, leaving control to a rebel group.

El Tacnazo:  Francisco Morales Bermúdez, Peruvian Prime Minister carries out a coup d'état in the city of Tacna, forcing the sitting President of Peru, Juan Velasco Alvarado, to resign and assuming his place as the new President.
source_pages: Tacnazo; Francisco_Morales_Bermúdez; Prime_Minister_of_Peru; Tacna; President_of_Peru; Juan_Velasco_Alvarado; August_29

event_text: The Sinai Interim Agreement relating to the Arab–Israeli conflict is signed.
Sacramento, California: Lynette Fromme attempts to assassinate U.S. President Gerald Ford.

Gays in the military: US Air Force Tech Sergeant Leonard Matlovich, a decorated veteran of the Vietnam War, appears in his Air Force uniform on the cover of Time magazine with the headline "I Am A Homosexual". He is given a general discharge, later upgraded to honorable.
The first American saint, Elizabeth Ann Seton, is canonized by Pope Paul VI.
The French department of "Corse" (the entire island of Corsica) is divided into two: Haute-Corse (Upper Corsica) and Corse-du-Sud (Southern Corsica).
Papua New Guinea gains independence from Australia.
Cape Verde, Mozambique, and São Tomé and Príncipe join the United Nations.
The first prototype of the Mikoyan MiG-31 interceptor makes its maiden flight.
Sara Jane Moore tries to assassinate U.S. President Gerald Ford, but is foiled by the Secret Service.
Southwest Face expedition members become the first persons to reach the summit of Mount Everest by any of its faces, instead of using a ridge route.
The last use of capital punishment in Spain sparks worldwide protests.
The Spaghetti House siege, in which nine people are taken hostage, takes place in London.
WGPR becomes the first black-owned-and-operated television station in the US.
Malév Flight 240 crashes into the Mediterranean Sea while on approach to Beirut International Airport in Beirut, Lebanon, killing 60.
Muhammad Ali defeats Joe Frazier in a boxing match in Manila, Philippines.
Papua New Guinea joins the United Nations.
An RAF Avro Vulcan bomber explodes and crashes over Żabbar, Malta after an aborted landing, killing five crew members and one person on the ground.
Indonesian troops kill the Balibo Five, a group of Australian journalists, in Portuguese Timor.
Three-year-old Rahima Banu, from Bangladesh, is the last known case of naturally occurring smallpox.
The Australian Coalition sparks a constitutional crisis when they vote to defer funding for the government's annual budget.
The Soviet uncrewed space mission Venera 9 lands on Venus.
In Iceland, 90% of women take part in a national strike, refusing to work in protest of gender inequality.
Prince Juan Carlos I of Spain becomes acting head of state, taking over for the country's ailing dictator, Gen. Francisco Franco.

Forty-five people are killed when Inex-Adria Aviopromet Flight 450 crashes into Suchdol, Prague, while on approach to Prague Ruzyně Airport (now Václav Havel Airport Prague) in Czechoslovakia (present-day Czech Republic).
source_pages: Inex-Adria_Aviopromet_Flight_450; Suchdol_(Prague); Prague; Václav_Havel_Airport_Prague; Czechoslovakia; Czech_Republic; October_30

event_text: Four Bangladeshi politicians are killed in the Dhaka Central Jail.

In Bangladesh, a joint force of people and soldiers takes part in an uprising led by Colonel Abu Taher that ousts and kills Brigadier Khaled Mosharraf, freeing the then house-arrested army chief and future president Major General Ziaur Rahman.
source_pages: Bangladesh; Abu_Taher; Khaled_Mosharraf; House_arrest; Chief_of_Army_Staff_(Bangladesh); President_of_Bangladesh; Major_general; Ziaur_Rahman

event_text: The 729-foot-long freighter SS Edmund Fitzgerald sinks during a storm on Lake Superior, killing all 29 crew on board.
Treaty of Osimo between Yugoslavia and Italy
Israeli-Palestinian conflict: the United Nations General Assembly passes Resolution 3379, determining that Zionism is a form of racism.

Australian constitutional crisis of 1975: Australian Governor-General Sir John Kerr dismisses the government of Gough Whitlam, appoints Malcolm Fraser as caretaker Prime Minister and announces a general election to be held in early December.
Independence of Angola.
The Comoros joins the United Nations.
With the signing of the Madrid Accords, Spain abandons Western Sahara.
Juan Carlos is declared King of Spain following the death of Francisco Franco.
Coup of 25 November 1975, a failed military coup d'état by Portuguese far-left activists seeking to hijack the  Portuguese transition to democracy to establishment a communist regime.
Suriname gains independence from the Netherlands.

The Provisional IRA assassinates Ross McWhirter, after a press conference in which McWhirter had announced a reward for the capture of those responsible for multiple bombings and shootings across England.
East Timor declares its independence from Portugal.
Laotian Civil War: The Pathet Lao seizes the Laotian capital of Vientiane, forces the abdication of King Sisavang Vatthana, and proclaims the Lao People's Democratic Republic.
The Troubles: Fleeing from the police, a Provisional IRA unit takes a British couple hostage in their flat on Balcombe Street, London, beginning a six-day siege.
U.S. President Gerald Ford creates the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in response to the 1970s energy crisis.
Tu-144, the world's first commercial supersonic aircraft, surpassing Mach 2, goes into service.
A bomb explodes at LaGuardia Airport in New York City, killing 11 people and injuring more than 75.
A bomb explodes on board Middle East Airlines Flight 438 over Qaisumah, Saudi Arabia, killing all 81 people on board.

The Gale of January 1976 begins, resulting in coastal flooding around the southern North Sea coasts, affecting countries from Ireland to Yugoslavia and causing at least 82 deaths and US$1.3 billion in damage.
source_pages: Gale_of_January_1976; Coastal_flooding; North_Sea; Republic_of_Ireland; Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia; January_2

event_text: The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, adopted by the United Nations General Assembly, comes into force.

The Troubles: The Ulster Volunteer Force shoots dead six Irish Catholic civilians in County Armagh, Northern Ireland. The next day, gunmen would shoot dead ten Protestant civilians nearby in retaliation.
source_pages: The_Troubles; Ulster_Volunteer_Force; Reavey_and_O'Dowd_killings; County_Armagh; Kingsmill_massacre; January_4

event_text: The Khmer Rouge announce that the new Constitution of Democratic Kampuchea is ratified.

The Troubles: Gunmen shoot dead ten Protestant civilians after stopping their minibus at Kingsmill in County Armagh, Northern Ireland, UK, allegedly as retaliation for a string of attacks on Catholic civilians in the area by Loyalists, particularly the killing of six Catholics the night before.
source_pages: The_Troubles; Kingsmill_massacre; County_Armagh; Irish_Catholics; Ulster_loyalism; Reavey_and_O'Dowd_killings; January_5

event_text: The United Nations Security Council votes 11–1 to allow the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in a Security Council debate (without voting rights).
Gerald Ford's would-be assassin, Sara Jane Moore, is sentenced to life in prison.
Lebanese Christian militias kill at least 1,000 in Karantina, Beirut.
Commercial service of Concorde begins with the London-Bahrain and Paris-Rio routes.
In Guatemala and Honduras an earthquake kills more than 22,000.

In testimony before a United States Senate subcommittee, Lockheed Corporation president Carl Kotchian admits that the company had paid out approximately $3 million in bribes to the office of Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.
Aeroflot Flight 3739, a Tupolev Tu-104, crashes during takeoff from Irkutsk Airport, killing 24.
Executive Order 9066, which led to the relocation of Japanese Americans to internment camps, is rescinded by President Gerald Ford's Proclamation 4417.
The 1976 constitution of Cuba is formally proclaimed.
The former Spanish territory of Western Sahara, under the auspices of the Polisario Front declares independence as the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic.
The Northern Ireland Constitutional Convention is formally dissolved in Northern Ireland resulting in direct rule of Northern Ireland from London by the British parliament.
Forty-two people die in the Cavalese cable car disaster, the deadliest cable car accident in history.
In Argentina, the armed forces overthrow the constitutional government of President Isabel Perón and start a seven-year dictatorial period self-styled the National Reorganization Process.
source_pages: Argentina; Argentine_Army; 1976_Argentine_coup_d'état; President_of_Argentina; Isabel_Perón; National_Reorganization_Process; March_24

event_text: The first section of the Washington Metro opens to the public.
Israeli-Palestinian conflict: in the first organized response against Israeli policies by a Palestinian collective since 1948, Palestinians create the first Land Day.
Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak found Apple Computer, Inc.
Prince Norodom Sihanouk resigns as leader of Cambodia and is placed under house arrest.
In China, the April Fifth Movement leads to the Tiananmen Incident.
Member of Parliament and suspected spy John Stonehouse resigns from the Labour Party after being arrested for faking his own death.
The Apple I is created.
The United States Treasury Department reintroduces the two-dollar bill as a Federal Reserve Note on Thomas Jefferson's 233rd birthday as part of the United States Bicentennial celebration.
Forty workers die in the Lapua Cartridge Factory explosion, the deadliest industrial accident in modern Finnish history.
A violent F5 tornado strikes around Brownwood, Texas, injuring 11 people. Two people were thrown at least 1,000 yards (910 m) by the tornado and survived uninjured.
Thirty-seven people are killed when American Airlines Flight 625 crashes at Cyril E. King Airport in Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands.
The 6.5 Mw  Friuli earthquake affected Northern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme), leaving 900–978 dead and 1,700–2,400 injured.
The rollercoaster The New Revolution, the first steel coaster with a vertical loop, opens at Six Flags Magic Mountain.
Aeroflot Flight 1802 crashes near Viktorivka, Chernihiv Raion, Chernihiv Oblast, killing 52.
Twenty-nine people are killed in the Yuba City bus disaster in Martinez, California.
The Judgment of Paris takes place in France, launching California as a worldwide force in the production of quality wine.
Aeroflot Flight 418 crashes in Bioko, Equatorial Guinea, killing 46.
The Teton Dam in Idaho, United States, collapses. Eleven people are killed as a result of flooding.
Chief Minister of Sabah Faud Stephens, Peter Joinud Mojuntin, and several other politicians are killed in a plane crash near Kota Kinabalu International Airport in Malaysia.
Soweto uprising: A non-violent march by 15,000 students in Soweto, South Africa, turns into days of rioting when police open fire on the crowd.

Missouri Governor Kit Bond issues an executive order rescinding the Extermination Order, formally apologizing on behalf of the state of Missouri for the suffering it had caused to members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Air France Flight 139 (Tel Aviv-Athens-Paris) is hijacked en route to Paris by the PFLP and redirected to Entebbe, Uganda.
The Angolan court sentences US and UK mercenaries to death sentences and prison terms in the Luanda Trial.
The Seychelles become independent from the United Kingdom.
The Conference of Communist and Workers Parties of Europe convenes in East Berlin.
Portugal grants autonomy to Madeira.
End of South Vietnam; Communist North Vietnam annexes the former South Vietnam to form the unified Socialist Republic of Vietnam.
Israeli commandos raid Entebbe airport in Uganda, rescuing all but four of the passengers and crew of an Air France jetliner seized by Palestinian terrorists.
Four mercenaries (one American and three British) are executed in Angola following the Luanda Trial.
East Timor is annexed and becomes the 27th province of Indonesia.

The opening of the Summer Olympics in Montreal is marred by 25 African teams boycotting the games because of New Zealand's participation. Contrary to rulings by other international sports organizations, the IOC had declined to exclude New Zealand because of their participation in South African sporting events during apartheid.
