Nadia Comăneci becomes the first person in Olympic Games history to score a perfect 10 in gymnastics at the 1976 Summer Olympics.
Sagarmatha National Park in Nepal is created.
The American Viking 1 lander successfully lands on Mars.
Christopher Ewart-Biggs, the British ambassador to the Republic of Ireland, is assassinated by the Provisional IRA.
Japan completes its last reparation to the Philippines for war crimes committed during imperial Japan's conquest of the country in the Second World War.
Viking program: Viking 1 takes the famous Face on Mars photo.
The Tangshan earthquake measuring between 7.8 and 8.2 moment magnitude flattens Tangshan in the People's Republic of China, killing 242,769 and injuring 164,851.
In New York City, David Berkowitz (a.k.a. the "Son of Sam") kills one person and seriously wounds another in the first of a series of attacks.
Niki Lauda has a severe accident that almost claims his life at the German Grand Prix at Nürburgring.
Viking program: Viking 2 enters orbit around Mars.
Between 1,000 and 3,500 Palestinians are killed in the Tel al-Zaatar massacre, one of the bloodiest events of the Lebanese Civil War.
SAETA Flight 011 crashes into the Chimborazo volcano in Ecuador, killing all 59 people on board; the wreckage is not discovered until 2002.
A magnitude 7.9 earthquake hits off the coast of Mindanao, Philippines, triggering a destructive tsunami, killing between 5,000 and 8,000 people and leaving more than 90,000 homeless.
The Korean axe murder incident in Panmunjom results in the deaths of two US Army officers.
The Soviet Union's robotic probe Luna 24 successfully lands on the Moon.
Viking program: The American Viking 2 spacecraft lands at Utopia Planitia on Mars.
Cold War: Soviet Air Defence Forces pilot Viktor Belenko lands a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-25 jet fighter at Hakodate in Japan and requests political asylum in the United States; his request is granted.
source_pages: Cold_War; Soviet_Air_Defence_Forces; Viktor_Belenko; Mikoyan-Gurevich_MiG-25; Hakodate; Refugee

event_text: Two Aeroflot flights collide in mid-air over Anapa, Soviet Union, killing 70.
A British Airways Hawker Siddeley Trident and an Inex-Adria DC-9 collide near Zagreb, Yugoslavia, killing 176.
A bomb planted by a Croatian terrorist, Zvonko Bušić, is found at New York's Grand Central Terminal; one NYPD officer is killed trying to defuse it.
Armenian champion swimmer Shavarsh Karapetyan saves 20 people from a trolleybus that had fallen into a Yerevan reservoir.
The Space Shuttle Enterprise is unveiled by NASA.
Turkish Airlines Flight 452 hits the Taurus Mountains, outskirt of Karatepe, Turkey, killing all 154 passengers and crew.
Two Imperial Iranian Air Force F-4 Phantom II jets fly out to investigate an unidentified flying object.
Orlando Letelier is assassinated in Washington, D.C., at the order of Augusto Pinochet.
Seychelles joins the United Nations.
Red Dye No. 4 is banned by the US Food and Drug Administration after it is discovered that it causes tumors in the bladders of dogs.
Cubana de Aviación Flight 455 is destroyed by two bombs, placed on board by an anti-Castro militant group.
Premier Hua Guofeng arrests the Gang of Four, ending the Cultural Revolution in China.
Dozens are killed by Thai police and right-wing paramilitaries in the Thammasat University massacre; afterwards, the Seni Pramoj government is toppled in a military coup led by Sangad Chaloryu.
George Washington is posthumously promoted to the grade of General of the Armies.
Indian Airlines Flight 171 crashes at Santacruz Airport in Bombay, India, killing 95.
The first electron micrograph of an Ebola virus is taken at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention by Dr. F. A. Murphy.
A Lloyd Aéreo Boliviano Boeing 707 crashes after takeoff from El Trompillo Airport in Santa Cruz de la Sierra, Bolivia, killing 91.

The Luling–Destrehan Ferry MV George Prince is struck by the Norwegian freighter SS Frosta while crossing the Mississippi River in St. Charles Parish, Louisiana. Seventy-eight passengers and crew die, and only 18 people aboard the ferry survive.
Burundian president Michel Micombero is deposed in a bloodless military coup d'état by deputy Jean-Baptiste Bagaza.
Uttawar forced sterilisations: Mass vasectomy of nearly 800 men of Uttawar village, Palwal district, Haryana during India’s Emergency imposed by Indira Gandhi.
source_pages: Uttawar_forced_sterilisations; Compulsory_sterilization; Palwal_district; The_Emergency_(India); Indira_Gandhi; November_6

event_text: René Lévesque and the Parti Québécois take power to become the first Quebec government of the 20th century clearly in favor of independence.
Jacques Mayol is the first man to reach a depth of 100 m (330 ft) undersea without breathing equipment.
The Çaldıran–Muradiye earthquake in eastern Turkey kills between 4,000 and 5,000 people.
Fidel Castro becomes President of Cuba, replacing Osvaldo Dorticós Torrado.
EgyptAir Flight 864, a Boeing 707-366C, crashes on approach to Don Mueang International Airport, killing 71 people.
Apple Computer is incorporated.
Three bombs explode in Moscow, Russia, Soviet Union, within 37 minutes, killing seven. The bombings are attributed to an Armenian separatist group.
Japan Air Lines Cargo Flight 1045, a Douglas DC-8 jet, crashes onto the runway during takeoff from Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport, killing five.
Linjeflyg Flight 618 crashes in Kälvesta near Stockholm Bromma Airport in Stockholm, Sweden, killing 22 people.
Capital punishment in the United States resumes after a ten-year hiatus, as convicted murderer Gary Gilmore is executed by firing squad in Utah.
Scientists at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announce they have identified a previously unknown bacterium as the cause of the mysterious Legionnaires' disease.
Australia's worst rail disaster occurs at Granville, Sydney, killing 83.
SFR Yugoslavia's Prime minister, Džemal Bijedić, his wife and six others are killed in a plane crash in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
President Gerald Ford pardons Iva Toguri D'Aquino (a.k.a. "Tokyo Rose").
The Atocha massacre occurs in Madrid during the Spanish transition to democracy.
The first day of the Great Lakes Blizzard of 1977, which dumps 3 metres (10 ft) of snow in one day in Upstate New York. Buffalo, Syracuse, Watertown, and surrounding areas are most affected.
A Chicago Transit Authority elevated train rear-ends another and derails, killing 11 and injuring 180, the worst accident in the agency's history.

The Xinjiang 61st Regiment Farm fire started during Chinese New Year when a firecracker ignited memorial wreaths of the late Mao Zedong, killing 694 personnel. It remains the deadliest fireworks accident in the world.
A thousand armed soldiers raid Kalakuta Republic, the commune of Nigerian singer Fela Kuti, leading to the death of Funmilayo Anikulapo Kuti.
The Space Shuttle Enterprise test vehicle is carried on its maiden "flight" on top of a Boeing 747.
Libya becomes the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya as the General People's Congress adopted the "Declaration on the Establishment of the Authority of the People".
The 1977 Vrancea earthquake in eastern and southern Europe kills more than 1,500, mostly in Bucharest, Romania.
The Hanafi Siege: In a 39-hour standoff, armed Hanafi Muslims seize three Washington, D.C., buildings.
Astronomers discover the rings of Uranus.
The 1977 Hanafi Siege: Around 150 hostages held in Washington, D.C., by Hanafi Muslims are set free after ambassadors from three Islamic nations join negotiations.
Assassination of Kamal Jumblatt, the main leader of the anti-government forces in the Lebanese Civil War.

The first of The Nixon Interviews (12 will be recorded over four weeks) is videotaped with British journalist David Frost interviewing former United States President Richard Nixon about the Watergate scandal and the Nixon tapes.
Morarji Desai became the Prime Minister of India, the first Prime Minister not to belong to Indian National Congress.

Tenerife airport disaster: Two Boeing 747 airliners collide on a foggy runway on Tenerife in the Canary Islands, killing 583 (all 248 on KLM and 335 on Pan Am). Sixty-one survived on the Pan Am flight. This is the deadliest aviation accident in history.
source_pages: Tenerife_airport_disaster; Boeing_747; Airliner; Tenerife; Canary_Islands; KLM; Pan_Am

event_text: Southern Airways Flight 242 crashes in New Hope, Paulding County, Georgia, killing 72.

The US Supreme Court rules that congressional legislation that diminished the size of the Sioux people's reservation thereby destroyed the tribe's jurisdictional authority over the area in Rosebud Sioux Tribe v. Kneip.
German Federal prosecutor Siegfried Buback and his driver are shot by two Red Army Faction members while waiting at a red light.
London Transport's Silver Jubilee AEC Routemaster buses are launched.
Annie opens on Broadway.
Optical fiber is first used to carry live telephone traffic.
The Red Army Faction trial ends, with Andreas Baader, Gudrun Ensslin and Jan-Carl Raspe found guilty of four counts of murder and more than 30 counts of attempted murder.
A Dan-Air Boeing 707 leased to IAS Cargo Airlines crashes on approach to Lusaka International Airport in Lusaka, Zambia, killing six people.
source_pages: Dan-Air; Boeing_707; IAS_Cargo_Airlines; 1977_Dan-Air_Boeing_707_crash; Kenneth_Kaunda_International_Airport; Lusaka; May_14

event_text: Nolan Bushnell opened the first Chuck E. Cheese's Pizza Time Theatre (later renamed Chuck E. Cheese) in San Jose, California.
Likud party wins the 1977 Israeli legislative election, with Menachem Begin, its founder, as the sixth Prime Minister of Israel.
Star Wars (retroactively titled Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope) is released in US theaters.
The Chinese government removes a decade-old ban on William Shakespeare's work, effectively ending the Cultural Revolution started in 1966.
A plane crash at José Martí International Airport in Havana, Cuba, kills 67.
The Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Kentucky, is engulfed by fire, killing 165 people inside.
The Trans-Alaska Pipeline System is completed.

JVC introduces its VHS videotape at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago. It will eventually prevail against Sony's rival Betamax system in a format war to become the predominant home video medium.
source_pages: JVC; VHS; CES_(trade_show); Chicago; Sony; Betamax; Videotape_format_war; Home_video; June_4

event_text: Five hundred million people watch the high day of the Silver Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II begin on television.
James Earl Ray escapes from Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary in Petros, Tennessee. He is recaptured three days later.
Convicted Martin Luther King Jr. assassin James Earl Ray is recaptured after escaping from prison three days before.
After the death of dictator Francisco Franco in 1975, the first democratic elections take place in Spain.
Oracle Corporation is incorporated in Redwood Shores, California, as Software Development Laboratories (SDL), by Larry Ellison, Bob Miner and Ed Oates.
Elvis Presley holds what will prove to be his final concert at Market Square Arena in Indianapolis, Indiana.
France grants independence to Djibouti.
Constitution for the Federation of Earth was adopted by the second session of the World Constituent Assembly, held at Innsbruck, Austria.
The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization disbands.

The George Jackson Brigade plants a bomb at the main power substation for the Washington state capitol in Olympia, in solidarity with a prison strike at the Walla Walla State Penitentiary Intensive Security Unit.

The Pakistan Armed Forces under Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq seize power in Operation Fair Play and begin 11 years of martial law. Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the first elected Prime Minister of Pakistan, is overthrown.
The Pinochet dictatorship in Chile organises the youth event of Acto de Chacarillas, a ritualised act reminiscent of Francoist Spain.
Martin Luther King Jr., assassinated in 1968, is posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
Somalia declares war on Ethiopia, starting the Ogaden War.
Amidst a period of financial and social turmoil, New York City experiences an electrical blackout lasting nearly 24 hours that leads to widespread fires and looting.

The world's first Global Positioning System (GPS) signal was transmitted from Navigation Technology Satellite 2 (NTS-2) and received at Rockwell Collins in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, at 12:41 a.m. Eastern time (ET).
The Central Intelligence Agency releases documents under the Freedom of Information Act revealing it had engaged in mind-control experiments.
The Johnstown flood of 1977 kills 84 people and causes millions of dollars in damages.
Aeroflot Flight B-2 crashes after takeoff from Vitim Airport in the Sakha Republic, killing 39.
The start of the four-day-long Libyan–Egyptian War.
Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping is restored to power.
End of a four-day-long Libyan–Egyptian War.
The National Assembly of Quebec imposes the use of French as the official language of the provincial government.
Tandy Corporation announces the TRS-80, one of the world's first mass-produced personal computers.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation creating the United States Department of Energy.
In Yonkers, New York, 24-year-old postal employee David Berkowitz ("Son of Sam") is arrested for a series of killings in the New York City area over the period of one year.
The first free flight of the Space Shuttle Enterprise.
The Sri Lanka Riots: Targeting the minority Sri Lankan Tamils, begin, less than a month after the United National Party came to power. Over 300 Tamils are killed.
Members of the British National Front (NF) clash with anti-NF demonstrators in Lewisham, London, resulting in 214 arrests and at least 111 injuries.

The Big Ear, a radio telescope operated by Ohio State University as part of the SETI project, receives a radio signal from deep space; the event is named the "Wow! signal" from the notation made by a volunteer on the project.
The Soviet icebreaker Arktika becomes the first surface ship to reach the North Pole.

Steve Biko is arrested at a police roadblock under Terrorism Act No. 83 of 1967 in King William's Town, South Africa. He later dies from injuries sustained during this arrest, bringing attention to South Africa's apartheid policies.
Voyager program: NASA launches the Voyager 2 spacecraft.
The Charter of the French Language is adopted by the National Assembly of Quebec.
The Golden Dragon massacre takes place in San Francisco.
Voyager Program: NASA launches the Voyager 1 spacecraft.

The Torrijos–Carter Treaties between Panama and the United States on the status of the Panama Canal are signed. The United States agrees to transfer control of the canal to Panama at the end of the 20th century.
The 300-metre-tall CKVR-DT transmission tower in Barrie, Ontario, Canada, is hit by a light aircraft in a fog, causing it to collapse. All aboard the aircraft are killed.
Hamida Djandoubi, convicted of torture and murder, is the last person to be executed by guillotine in France.
South African anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko dies in police custody.
Voyager I takes the first distant photograph of the Earth and the Moon together.
Vietnam is admitted to the United Nations.
About 4,200 people take part in the first running of the Chicago Marathon.
Japan Airlines Flight 715 crashes on approach to Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah Airport in Subang, Malaysia, killing 34 of the 79 people on board.
The first prototype of the Mikoyan MiG-29, designated 9-01, makes its maiden flight.
The Fourth Soviet Constitution is adopted.
Hua Guofeng succeeds Mao Zedong as paramount leader of China.
Hijacking of Lufthansa Flight 181 by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.
The hijacked Lufthansa Flight 181 lands in Mogadishu. The remaining hostages are later rescued.

German Autumn: A set of events revolving around the kidnapping of Hanns Martin Schleyer and the hijacking of a Lufthansa flight by the Red Army Faction (RAF) comes to an end when Schleyer is murdered and various RAF members allegedly commit suicide.
A plane carrying the rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd crashes in woodland in Mississippi, United States. Six people, including three band members, are killed.

Ali Maow Maalin, the last natural case of smallpox, develops a rash in Somalia. The WHO and the CDC consider this date to be the anniversary of the eradication of smallpox, the most spectacular success of vaccination.
The Kelly Barnes Dam, located above Toccoa Falls College near Toccoa, Georgia, fails, killing 39.
Manolis Andronikos, a Greek archaeologist and professor at the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, discovers the tomb of Philip II of Macedon at Vergina.
A munitions explosion at a train station in Iri, South Korea kills at least 56 people.
France conducts the Oreste nuclear test as 14th in the group of 29, 1975–78 French nuclear tests series.
During a British House of Commons debate, Labour MP Tam Dalyell poses what would become known as the West Lothian question, referring to issues related to devolution in the United Kingdom.
TAP Air Portugal Flight 425 crashes in the Madeira Islands, killing 131.

Egyptian President Anwar Sadat becomes the first Arab leader to officially visit Israel, when he meets Israeli prime minister Menachem Begin and speaks before the Knesset in Jerusalem, seeking a permanent peace settlement.
source_pages: Egypt; Anwar_Sadat; Arabs; Israel; Menachem_Begin; Knesset; Jerusalem

event_text: Minister of Internal Affairs Allan Highet announces that the national anthems of New Zealand shall be the traditional anthem "God Save the Queen" and "God Defend New Zealand".
Former Senator Benigno Aquino Jr., is found guilty by the Philippine Military Commission No. 2 and is sentenced to death by firing squad. He is later assassinated in 1983.
An unidentified hijacker named Vrillon, claiming to be the representative of the "Ashtar Galactic Command", takes over Britain's Southern Television for six minutes, starting at 5:12 pm.
A Tupolev Tu-154 crashes near Benghazi, Libya, killing 59.
Jean-Bédel Bokassa, president of the Central African Republic, crowns himself Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Empire.
Malaysian Airline System Flight 653 is hijacked and crashes in Tanjong Kupang, Johor, killing 100.
Egypt breaks diplomatic relations with Syria, Libya, Algeria, Iraq and South Yemen in retaliation to preventing President Anwar el‐Sadat from pursuing negotiations with Israel at the Tripoli confer.
source_pages: Egypt; Egypt–Iraq_relations; Syria; Libya; Algeria; Iraq; South_Yemen; Anwar_Sadat

event_text: South Africa grants independence to Bophuthatswana, although it is not recognized by any other country.
Air Indiana Flight 216 crashes near Evansville Regional Airport, killing 29, including the University of Evansville basketball team, support staff, and boosters of the team.
United Airlines Flight 2860 crashes near Kaysville, Utah, killing all three crew members on board.
SA de Transport Aérien Flight 730 crashes near Madeira Airport in Funchal, Madeira, Portugal, killing 36.
source_pages: SA_de_Transport_Aérien_Flight_730; Madeira_Airport; Funchal; Madeira; Portugal; December_18

event_text: The Ms  5.8 Bob–Tangol earthquake strikes Kerman Province in Iran, destroying villages and killing 665 people.

With the approval of the State Council, China’s two largest newspapers, the People’s Daily and the Guangming Daily, publish in full for the first time the Second Chinese Character Simplification Scheme.
Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin meets in Egypt with its president Anwar Sadat.
Air India Flight 855, a Boeing 747, crashes into the Arabian Sea off the coast of Bombay, India, due to instrument failure, spatial disorientation, and pilot error, killing all 213 people on board.
source_pages: Air_India_Flight_855; Boeing_747; Arabian_Sea; Mumbai; Spatial_disorientation; Pilot_error; January_1

event_text: On the orders of the President of Pakistan, Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq, paramilitary forces opened fire on peaceful protesting workers in Multan, Pakistan; it is known as 1978 massacre at Multan Colony Textile Mills.
United States Food and Drug Administration requires all blood donations to be labeled "paid" or "volunteer" donors.
The European Court of Human Rights finds the United Kingdom's government guilty of mistreating prisoners in Northern Ireland, but not guilty of torture.
The last Volkswagen Beetle made in Germany leaves VW's plant in Emden. Beetle production in Latin America continues until 2003.
Soviet satellite Kosmos 954, with a nuclear reactor on board, burns up in Earth's atmosphere, scattering radioactive debris over Canada's Northwest Territories. Only 1% is recovered.
The Crown of St. Stephen (also known as the Holy Crown of Hungary) goes on public display after being returned to Hungary from the United States, where it was held after World War II.
The Blizzard of 1978, one of the worst Nor'easters in New England history, hit the region, with sustained winds of 65 mph and snowfall of four inches an hour.
The Budd Company unveils its first SPV-2000 self-propelled railcar in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
Pacific Western Airlines Flight 314 crashes at the Cranbrook/Canadian Rockies International Airport in Cranbrook, British Columbia, Canada with 42 deaths and seven survivors.
Hilton bombing: A bomb explodes in a refuse truck outside the Hilton Hotel in Sydney, Australia, killing two refuse collectors and a policeman.
The first computer bulletin board system is created (CBBS in Chicago).
The Troubles: The Provisional IRA detonates an incendiary bomb at the La Mon restaurant, near Belfast, killing 12 and seriously injuring 30 others, all Protestants.

Egyptian forces raid Larnaca International Airport in an attempt to intervene in a hijacking, without authorisation from the Republic of Cyprus authorities. The Cypriot National Guard and Police forces kill 15 Egyptian commandos and destroy the Egyptian C-130 transport plane in open combat.
The Yuba County Five disappear in California. Four of their bodies are found four months later.
Czech Vladimír Remek becomes the first non-Russian or non-American to go into space, when he is launched aboard Soyuz 28.
The late iconic actor Charlie Chaplin's coffin is stolen from his grave in Switzerland.
The Landsat 3 is launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.
President Soeharto inaugurated Jagorawi Toll Road, the first toll highway in Indonesia, connecting Jakarta, Bogor and Ciawi, West Java.
source_pages: Suharto; Jagorawi_Toll_Road; Toll_road; Indonesia; Jakarta; Bogor; West_Java; March_9

event_text: Coastal Road massacre: At least 37 are killed and more than 70 are wounded when Fatah hijack an Israeli bus, prompting Israel's Operation Litani.
The Israel Defense Forces launch Operation Litani, a seven-day campaign to invade and occupy southern Lebanon.
Somalia and Ethiopia signed a truce to end the Ethio-Somali War.
Former Italian Prime Minister Aldo Moro is kidnapped; he is later murdered by his captors.
A Balkan Bulgarian Airlines Tupolev Tu-134 crashes near Gabare, Bulgaria, killing 73.
Supertanker Amoco Cadiz splits in two after running aground on the Portsall Rocks, three miles off the coast of Brittany, resulting in the largest oil spill in history at that time.
Karl Wallenda of The Flying Wallendas dies after falling off a tight-rope suspended between two hotels in San Juan, Puerto Rico.
The first UNIFIL troops arrived in Lebanon for peacekeeping mission along the Blue Line.
The US Supreme Court hands down 5–3 decision in Stump v. Sparkman, a controversial case involving involuntary sterilization and judicial immunity.
Development of the neutron bomb is canceled by President Jimmy Carter.
Tbilisi demonstrations: Thousands of Georgians demonstrate against Soviet attempts to change the constitutional status of the Georgian language.
Mir Akbar Khyber is assassinated, provoking the Saur Revolution in Afghanistan.
John Ehrlichman, a former aide to U.S. President Richard Nixon, is released from the Federal Correctional Institution, Safford, Arizona, after serving 18 months for Watergate-related crimes.
The Saur Revolution begins in Afghanistan, ending the following morning with the murder of Afghan President Mohammed Daoud Khan and the establishment of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.

Willow Island disaster: In the deadliest construction accident in United States history, 51 construction workers are killed when a cooling tower under construction collapses at the Pleasants Power Station in Willow Island, West Virginia.
The President of Afghanistan, Mohammad Daoud Khan, is overthrown and assassinated in a coup led by pro-communist rebels.
Japan's Naomi Uemura, travelling by dog sled, becomes the first person to reach the North Pole alone.

The first unsolicited bulk commercial email (which would later become known as "spam") is sent by a Digital Equipment Corporation marketing representative to every ARPANET address on the west coast of the United States.
The South African Defence Force attacks a SWAPO base at Cassinga in southern Angola, killing about 600 people.
The first ascent of Mount Everest without supplemental oxygen, by Reinhold Messner and Peter Habeler.
In Zaire, rebels occupy the city of Kolwezi, the mining center of the province of Shaba (now known as Katanga); the local government asks the US, France and Belgium to restore order.
A Tupolev Tu-144 crashes near the Russian town of Yegoryevsk, killing two.
The first of a series of bombings orchestrated by the Unabomber detonates at Northwestern University resulting in minor injuries.
The first international applications under the Patent Cooperation Treaty are filed.
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints opens its priesthood to "all worthy men", ending a 148-year-old policy of excluding black men.
Altaf Hussain founds the student political movement All Pakistan Muhajir Students Organisation (APMSO) in Karachi University.
Garfield's first comic strip, originally published locally as Jon in 1976, goes into nationwide syndication.
The original production of Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical, Evita, based on the life of Eva Perón, opens at the Prince Edward Theatre, London.
source_pages: Tim_Rice; Andrew_Lloyd_Webber; Musical_theatre; Evita_(musical); Eva_Perón; Prince_Edward_Theatre; London

event_text: Charon, the first of Pluto's satellites to be discovered, was first seen at the United States Naval Observatory by James W. Christy.
The rainbow flag representing gay pride is flown for the first time during the San Francisco Gay Freedom Day Parade.
Air Canada Flight 189, flying to Toronto, overruns the runway and crashes into the Etobicoke Creek ravine. Two of the 107 passengers on board perish.
The United States Supreme Court, in Regents of the University of California v. Bakke bars quota systems in college admissions.
The Northern Territory in Australia is granted self-government.
The Solomon Islands becomes independent from the United Kingdom.
President Moktar Ould Daddah of Mauritania is ousted in a bloodless coup d'état.
Los Alfaques disaster: A truck carrying liquid gas crashes and explodes at a coastal campsite in Tarragona, Spain killing 216 tourists.
Puerto Rican police shoot two nationalists in the Cerro Maravilla murders.
Birth of Louise Joy Brown, the first human to have been born after conception by in vitro fertilisation, or IVF.
The 730: Okinawa Prefecture changes its traffic on the right-hand side of the road to the left-hand side.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter declares a federal emergency at Love Canal due to toxic waste that had been disposed of negligently.
Three members of the Ulrich family are killed in an accident. This leads to the Ford Pinto litigation.
One hundred fifty Palestinians in Beirut are killed in a terrorist attack during the second phase of the Lebanese Civil War.
Double Eagle II becomes first balloon to cross the Atlantic Ocean when it lands in Miserey, France near Paris, 137 hours after leaving Presque Isle, Maine.
In Iran, the Cinema Rex fire causes more than 400 deaths.
Nicaraguan Revolution: The FSLN seizes the National Congress of Nicaragua, along with over a thousand hostages.
The District of Columbia Voting Rights Amendment is passed by the U.S. Congress, although it is never ratified by a sufficient number of states.
Papal conclave: Albino Luciani is elected as Pope John Paul I.

During the Rhodesian Bush War a group of ZIPRA guerrillas shot down civilian Vickers Viscount aircraft (Air Rhodesia Flight 825) with a Soviet-made SAM Strela-2; of 56 passengers and crew 38 people died in crash, 10 were massacred by the guerrillas at the site.
Camp David Accords: Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat begin peace discussions at Camp David, Maryland.

While walking across Waterloo Bridge in London, Bulgarian dissident Georgi Markov is assassinated by Bulgarian secret police agent Francesco Gullino by means of a ricin pellet fired from a specially designed umbrella.
Black Friday, a massacre by soldiers against protesters in Tehran, results in 88 deaths, it marks the beginning of the end of the monarchy in Iran.
At the Superdome in New Orleans, Muhammad Ali outpoints Leon Spinks in a rematch to become the first boxer to win the world heavyweight title three times.
The 7.4 Mw  Tabas earthquake affects the city of Tabas, Iran with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). At least 15,000 people are killed.
The Camp David Accords are signed by Israel and Egypt.
The Solomon Islands join the United Nations.
PSA Flight 182, a Boeing 727, collides in mid-air with a Cessna 172 and crashes in San Diego, killing all 135 aboard Flight 182, both occupants of the Cessna, as well as seven people on the ground.
Air Caribbean Flight 309 crashes in Residencial Las Casas in San Juan, Puerto Rico, killing six.
Finnair Flight 405 is hijacked by Aarno Lamminparras in Oulu, Finland.
Tuvalu gains independence from the United Kingdom.
Aeroflot Flight 1080 crashes after takeoff from Koltsovo International Airport, killing 38.
Australia's Ken Warby sets the current world water speed record of 275.97 knots at Blowering Dam, Australia.
Cardinal Karol Wojtyła is elected to the papacy as Pope John Paul II, he becomes the first non-Italian pontiff since 1523.
Based on the world's first children's art museum, the Henrik Igityan National Centre for Aesthetics opened in Yerevan.
Australian civilian pilot Frederick Valentich vanishes over the Bass Strait south of Melbourne, after reporting contact with an unidentified aircraft.
Aeroflot Flight 6515 crashes off Syvash, killing all 26 people aboard.
Dominica gains its independence from the United Kingdom.
France conducts the Aphrodite nuclear test as 25th in the group of 29 1975–78 French nuclear tests.
A chartered Douglas DC-8 crashes near Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing 183.
The McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet makes its first flight, at the Naval Air Test Center in Maryland, United States.
In Jonestown, Guyana, Jim Jones leads his Peoples Temple to a mass murder–suicide that claimed 918 lives in all, 909 of them in Jonestown itself, including over 270 children.
Cyclone kills about 1,000 people in eastern Sri Lanka.
The Geneva Frequency Plan of 1975 goes into effect, realigning many of Europe's longwave and mediumwave broadcasting frequencies.
In San Francisco, city mayor George Moscone and openly gay city supervisor Harvey Milk are assassinated by former supervisor Dan White.
source_pages: San_Francisco; George_Moscone; Gay; Board_of_supervisors; Harvey_Milk; Assassinations_of_George_Moscone_and_Harvey_Milk; Dan_White

event_text: The Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) is founded in the Turkish village of Fis.
Following the murder of Mayor George Moscone, Dianne Feinstein becomes San Francisco's first female mayor.
Spain ratifies the Spanish Constitution of 1978 in a referendum.
Arab–Israeli conflict: Prime Minister of Israel Menachem Begin and President of Egypt Anwar Sadat are jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
source_pages: Arab–Israeli_conflict; Prime_Minister_of_Israel; Menachem_Begin; President_of_Egypt; Anwar_Sadat; Nobel_Peace_Prize

event_text: The Lufthansa heist is committed by a group led by Lucchese family associate Jimmy Burke. It was the largest cash robbery ever committed on American soil, at that time.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces that the United States will recognize the People's Republic of China and sever diplomatic relations with the Republic of China (Taiwan).

The pivotal Third Plenum of the 11th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party is held in Beijing, with Deng Xiaoping reversing Mao-era policies to pursue a program for Chinese economic reform.
Alitalia Flight 4128 crashes into the Tyrrhenian Sea while on approach to Falcone Borsellino Airport in Palermo, Italy, killing 108.
source_pages: Alitalia_Flight_4128; Tyrrhenian_Sea; Palermo_Airport; Palermo; Italy; December_23

event_text: The inaugural Paris-Dakar Rally begins.
Spain becomes a democracy after 40 years of fascist dictatorship.
United Airlines Flight 173 crashes in a residential neighborhood near Portland International Airport, killing 10 people.

the Joint Communiqué on the Establishment of Diplomatic Relations and Taiwan Relations Act enter into force. Through the Communiqué, the United States establishes normal diplomatic relations with China. Through the Act, the United States guarantees military support for Taiwan.
Third Indochina War: Cambodian–Vietnamese War: Phnom Penh falls to the advancing Vietnamese troops, driving out Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge.
source_pages: Sino-Vietnamese_War; Cambodian–Vietnamese_War; Phnom_Penh; Vietnam; Pol_Pot; Khmer_Rouge; January_7

event_text: Iranian Revolution: The last Iranian Shah flees Iran with his family for good and relocates to Egypt.
Pope John Paul II starts his first official papal visits outside Italy to The Bahamas, Dominican Republic, and Mexico.
A Varig Boeing 707-323C freighter, flown by the same commander as Flight 820, disappears over the Pacific Ocean 30 minutes after taking off from Tokyo.
Iranian Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns to Tehran after nearly 15 years of exile.
Pluto moves inside Neptune's orbit for the first time since either was discovered.
The Iranian Revolution establishes an Islamic theocracy under the leadership of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
An intense windstorm strikes western Washington and sinks a 0.5-mile (0.80 km) long section of the Hood Canal Bridge.
In Kabul, Setami Milli militants kidnap the American ambassador to Afghanistan, Adolph Dubs who is later killed during a gunfight between his kidnappers and police.
The Sino-Vietnamese War begins.
Richard Petty wins a then-record sixth Daytona 500 after leaders Donnie Allison and Cale Yarborough crash on the final lap of the first NASCAR race televised live flag-to-flag.
An earthquake cracks open the Sinila volcanic crater on the Dieng Plateau, releasing poisonous H2S gas and killing 149 villagers in the Indonesian province of Central Java.
Saint Lucia gains independence from the United Kingdom.
The Superliner railcar enters revenue service with Amtrak.
Soviet probes Venera 11, Venera 12 and the German-American solar satellite Helios II all are hit by "off the scale" gamma rays leading to the discovery of soft gamma repeaters.
Philips demonstrates the compact disc publicly for the first time.
Images taken by Voyager 1 prove the existence of volcanoes on Io, a moon of Jupiter.
1979 International Women's Day protests in Tehran: Protestor involvement peaks with 15,000 Iranian women and girls performing a three‐hour-long sit‐in at the Courthouse of Tehran.
The New Jewel Movement, headed by Maurice Bishop, ousts the Prime Minister of Grenada, Eric Gairy, in a coup d'état.
source_pages: New_Jewel_Movement; Maurice_Bishop; List_of_heads_of_government_of_Grenada; Eric_Gairy; Coup_d'état; March_13

event_text: Alia Royal Jordanian Flight 600 crashes at Doha International Airport, killing 45 people.
Sino-Vietnamese War: The People's Liberation Army crosses the border back into China, ending the war.
The Penmanshiel Tunnel collapses during engineering works, killing two workers.
The United States House of Representatives begins broadcasting its day-to-day business via the cable television network C-SPAN.
The first fully functional Space Shuttle orbiter, Columbia, is delivered to the John F. Kennedy Space Center to be prepared for its first launch.
Anwar al-Sadat, Menachem Begin and Jimmy Carter sign the Egypt–Israel peace treaty in Washington, D.C.
An Interflug Ilyushin Il-18 crashes at Quatro de Fevereiro Airport during a rejected takeoff, killing 10.
A coolant leak at the Three Mile Island's Unit 2 nuclear reactor outside Harrisburg, Pennsylvania leads to the core overheating and a partial meltdown.
The British House of Commons passes a vote of no confidence against James Callaghan's government by one vote, precipitating a general election.
Quebecair Flight 255 crashes after takeoff from Québec City Jean Lesage International Airport in Quebec City, killing 17.
Airey Neave, a British Member of Parliament (MP), is killed by a car bomb as he exits the Palace of Westminster. The Irish National Liberation Army claims responsibility.
Iran becomes an Islamic republic by a 99% vote, officially overthrowing the Shah.
A Soviet bio-warfare laboratory at Sverdlovsk accidentally releases airborne anthrax spores, killing 66 plus an unknown amount of livestock.
Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan is executed.
Red River Valley tornado outbreak: A tornado lands in Wichita Falls, Texas killing 42 people.
Ugandan dictator Idi Amin is deposed.

The Progressive Alliance of Liberia stages a protest, without a permit, against an increase in rice prices proposed by the government, with clashes between protestors and the police resulting in over 70 deaths and over 500 injuries.
SAETA Flight 011 crashes in Pastaza Province, Ecuador, killing all 57 people on board. The wreckage was not discovered until 1984.
Blair Peach, a British activist, was fatally injured after being knocked unconscious during an Anti-Nazi League demonstration against a National Front election meeting in Southall, London.
Blair Peach, a New Zealand teacher, dies after being knocked unconscious during an Anti-Nazi League demonstration against a National Front election meeting in Southall, London.
Eruption of Mount Marapi: Mount Marapi, a complex volcano on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, erupted. Between 80 and 100 people were killed.
Margaret Thatcher wins the United Kingdom general election. The following day, she becomes the first female British Prime Minister.
Margaret Thatcher becomes the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Iranian Jewish businessman Habib Elghanian is executed by firing squad in Tehran, prompting the mass exodus of the once 100,000-strong Jewish community of Iran.
White Night riots in San Francisco following the manslaughter conviction of Dan White for the assassinations of George Moscone and Harvey Milk.
source_pages: White_Night_riots; San_Francisco; Manslaughter; Dan_White; George_Moscone; Harvey_Milk

event_text: John Spenkelink, a convicted murderer, is executed in Florida; he is the first person to be executed in the state after the reintroduction of capital punishment in 1976.
American Airlines Flight 191: A McDonnell Douglas DC-10 crashes during takeoff at O'Hare International Airport, Chicago, killing all 271 on board and two people on the ground.
Konstantinos Karamanlis signs the full treaty of the accession of Greece with the European Economic Community.
Downeast Flight 46 crashes on approach to Knox County Regional Airport in Rockland, Maine, killing 17.
The first black-led government of Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) in 90 years takes power.
Pope John Paul II starts his first official visit to his native Poland, becoming the first Pope to visit a Communist country.

A blowout at the Ixtoc I oil well in the southern Gulf of Mexico causes at least 3,000,000 barrels (480,000 m3) of oil to be spilled into the waters, the second-worst accidental oil spill ever recorded.
Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings takes power in Ghana after a military coup in which General Fred Akuffo is overthrown.
The Ghost Train fire at Luna Park Sydney, Australia, kills seven.
Bryan Allen wins the second Kremer prize for a man-powered flight across the English Channel in the Gossamer Albatross.
SALT II is signed by the United States and the Soviet Union.

ABC News correspondent Bill Stewart is shot dead by a Nicaraguan National Guard soldier under the regime of Anastasio Somoza Debayle during the Nicaraguan Revolution. The murder is caught on tape and sparks an international outcry against the regime.
Former Liberal Party leader Jeremy Thorpe was acquitted of conspiracy to murder Norman Scott, who had accused Thorpe of having a relationship with him.
Sony introduces the Walkman.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs the first directive for secret aid to the opponents of the pro-Soviet regime in Kabul.
A car bomb destroys a Renault motor car owned by "Nazi hunters" Serge and Beate Klarsfeld outside their home in France in an unsuccessful assassination attempt.
America's first space station, Skylab, is destroyed as it re-enters the Earth's atmosphere over the Indian Ocean.
The island nation of Kiribati becomes independent from the United Kingdom.
U.S. president Jimmy Carter gives his "malaise speech".
Iraqi President Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr resigns and is replaced by Saddam Hussein.
A landslide occurs on the Iliwerung volcano in Indonesia, triggering a tsunami that kills over 530 and leaves 700 missing.
The Sandinista rebels overthrow the government of the Somoza family in Nicaragua.
The oil tanker SS Atlantic Empress collides with another oil tanker, causing the largest ever ship-borne oil spill.
Jay Silverheels, a Mohawk actor, becomes the first Native American to have a star commemorated in the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
In accord with the Egypt–Israel peace treaty, Israel begins its withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula.
In Afghanistan, Maoists undertake the Bala Hissar uprising against the Leninist government.
Two Aeroflot Tupolev Tu-134s collide over the Ukrainian city of Dniprodzerzhynsk and crash, killing all 178 aboard both airliners.

The Troubles: Eighteen British soldiers are killed in an ambush by the Provisional Irish Republican Army near Warrenpoint, Northern Ireland, in the deadliest attack on British forces during Operation Banner. An IRA bomb also kills British royal family member Lord Mountbatten and three others on his boat at Mullaghmore, Republic of Ireland.
source_pages: The_Troubles; Warrenpoint_ambush; Provisional_Irish_Republican_Army; Warrenpoint; Operation_Banner; British_royal_family; Lord_Mountbatten; Mullaghmore,_County_Sligo

event_text: The Chrysler Corporation asks the United States government for US$1.5 billion to avoid bankruptcy.
South Africa grants independence to the "homeland" of Venda (not recognised outside South Africa).
Afghan leader Nur Muhammad Taraki is assassinated upon the order of Hafizullah Amin, who becomes the new General Secretary of the People's Democratic Party.
Eight people escape from East Germany to the west in a homemade hot air balloon.
A French-supported coup d'état in the Central African Empire overthrows Emperor Bokassa I.
A bright flash, resembling the detonation of a nuclear weapon, is observed near the Prince Edward Islands. Its cause is never determined.
The dictator Francisco Macias of Equatorial Guinea is executed by soldiers from Western Sahara.
Pope John Paul II begins his first pastoral visit to the United States.
The MTR, Hong Kong's rapid transit railway system, opens.
Pope John Paul II becomes the first pontiff to visit the White House.
Swissair Flight 316 crashes at Ellinikon International Airport in Athens, Greece, killing 14.
The Olkiluoto Nuclear Power Plant began operations in Eurajoki, Satakunta, Finland.
Typhoon Tip becomes the largest and most intense tropical cyclone ever recorded.
The first National March on Washington for Lesbian and Gay Rights draws approximately 100,000 people.
Supporters of the Malta Labour Party ransack and destroy the Times of Malta building and other locations associated with the Nationalist Party.
A coup d'état in El Salvador overthrows President Carlos Humberto Romero and begins the 12 year-long Salvadoran Civil War.
Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
The Department of Education Organization Act creates the U.S. Department of Education.
The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) begins allowing people to have home satellite earth stations without a federal government license.
Moshe Dayan resigns from the Israeli government because of strong disagreements with Prime Minister Menachem Begin over policy towards the Arabs.
Park Chung Hee, President of South Korea, is assassinated by Korean CIA head Kim Jae-gyu.
Saint Vincent and the Grenadines gains its independence from the United Kingdom.
Western Airlines Flight 2605 crashes on landing in Mexico City, killing 73 people.
In Bolivia, Colonel Alberto Natusch executes a bloody coup d'état against the constitutional government of Wálter Guevara.
Griselda Álvarez becomes the first female governor of a state of Mexico.

Greensboro massacre: Five members of the Communist Workers Party are shot dead and seven are wounded by a group of Klansmen and neo-Nazis during a "Death to the Klan" rally in Greensboro, North Carolina, United States.
Iran hostage crisis: A group of Iranian college students overruns the U.S. embassy in Tehran and takes 90 hostages.

Cold War: Nuclear false alarm: The NORAD computers and the Alternate National Military Command Center in Fort Ritchie, Maryland, detect a purported massive Soviet nuclear strike. After reviewing the raw data from satellites and checking the early-warning radars, the alert is cancelled.
A 106-car Canadian Pacific freight train carrying explosive and poisonous chemicals from Windsor, Ontario, Canada derails in Mississauga, Ontario.
Iran hostage crisis: In response to the hostage situation in Tehran, U.S. President Jimmy Carter orders a halt to all petroleum imports into the United States from Iran.
US President Jimmy Carter issues Executive Order 12170, freezing all Iranian assets in the United States in response to the hostage crisis.
A package from Unabomber Ted Kaczynski begins smoking in the cargo hold of a flight from Chicago to Washington, D.C., forcing the plane to make an emergency landing.
The first line of Bucharest Metro (Line M1) is opened from Timpuri Noi to Semănătoarea in Bucharest, Romania.
Iran hostage crisis: Iranian leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini orders the release of 13 female and black American hostages being held at the US Embassy in Tehran.

Grand Mosque seizure: About 200 Sunni Muslims revolt in Saudi Arabia at the site of the Kaaba in Mecca during the pilgrimage and take about 6,000 hostages. The Saudi government receives help from French special forces to put down the uprising.
The United States Embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan, is attacked by a mob and set on fire, killing four.
Pakistan International Airlines Flight 740 crashes near Taif in Mecca Province, Saudi Arabia, killing all 156 people on board.
Air New Zealand Flight 901, a DC-10 sightseeing flight over Antarctica, crashes into Mount Erebus, killing all 257 people on board.
In Cincinnati, 11 fans are suffocated in a crush for seats on the concourse outside Riverfront Coliseum before a Who concert.
Iranian Revolution: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini becomes the first Supreme Leader of Iran.
The Hastie fire in Hull kills three schoolboys and eventually leads police to arrest Bruce George Peter Lee.
The eradication of the smallpox virus is certified, making smallpox the first of only two diseases that have been driven to extinction (with rinderpest in 2011 being the other).
Kaohsiung Incident: Taiwanese pro-democracy demonstrations are suppressed by the KMT dictatorship, and organizers are arrested.
The 8.2 Mw  Tumaco earthquake shakes Colombia and Ecuador with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), killing 300–600, and generating a large tsunami.
Coup d'état of December Twelfth occurs in South Korea.
Lancaster House Agreement: An independence agreement for Rhodesia is signed in London by Lord Carrington, Sir Ian Gilmour, Robert Mugabe, Joshua Nkomo, Bishop Abel Muzorewa and S.C. Mundawarara.
source_pages: Lancaster_House_Agreement; Rhodesia; Peter_Carington,_6th_Baron_Carrington; Ian_Gilmour,_Baron_Gilmour_of_Craigmillar; Robert_Mugabe; Joshua_Nkomo; Abel_Muzorewa

event_text: Soviet–Afghan War: Soviet Union forces occupy Kabul, the Afghan capital.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter authorizes legislation giving $1.5 billion in loans to bail out the Chrysler Corporation.
The New England Journal of Medicine publishes the letter Addiction Rare in Patients Treated with Narcotics, which is later misused to downplay the general risk of addiction to opioids.
Iran Air Flight 291 crashes in the Alborz Mountains while on approach to Mehrabad International Airport in Tehran, Iran, killing 128 people.
Mother Teresa is honored with India's highest civilian award, the Bharat Ratna.
Through cooperation between the U.S. and Canadian governments, six American diplomats secretly escape hostilities in Iran in the culmination of the Canadian Caper.
USCGC Blackthorn collides with the tanker Capricorn while leaving Tampa, Florida and capsizes, killing 23 Coast Guard crewmembers.
First winter ascent of Mount Everest by Krzysztof Wielicki and Leszek Cichy.
Miracle on Ice: In Lake Placid, New York, the United States hockey team defeats the Soviet Union hockey team 4–3.
Iran hostage crisis: Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini states that Iran's parliament will decide the fate of the American embassy hostages.
The government of Suriname is overthrown by a military coup led by Dési Bouterse.
Egypt and Israel establish full diplomatic relations.
The USS Nautilus is decommissioned and stricken from the Naval Vessel Register.
Nationalist leader Robert Mugabe wins a sweeping election victory to become Zimbabwe's first black prime minister.
LOT Polish Airlines Flight 007 crashes during final approach near Warsaw, Poland, killing 87 people, including a 14-man American boxing team.
A Vostok-2M rocket at Plesetsk Cosmodrome Site 43 explodes during a fueling operation, killing 48 people.
Cold War: American President Jimmy Carter announces a United States boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow to protest the Soviet–Afghan War.
Archbishop Óscar Romero of El Salvador gives his famous speech appealing to men of the El Salvadoran armed forces to stop killing the Salvadorans.
El Salvadorian Archbishop Óscar Romero is assassinated while celebrating Mass in San Salvador.
source_pages: El_Salvador; Archbishop; Óscar_Romero; Mass_in_the_Catholic_Church; San_Salvador; March_24

event_text: The Norwegian oil platform Alexander L. Kielland collapses in the North Sea, killing 123 of its crew of 212.
The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad operates its final train after being ordered to liquidate its assets because of bankruptcy and debts owed to creditors.
United States President Jimmy Carter signs the Crude Oil Windfall Profits Tax Act.
US Congress restores a federal trust relationship with the 501 members of the Shivwits, Kanosh, Koosharem, and the Indian Peaks and Cedar City bands of the Paiute people of Utah.
During the Iran hostage crisis, the United States severs relations with Iran.
The Iraqi regime of Saddam Hussein kills philosopher Muhammad Baqir al-Sadr and his sister Bint al-Huda after three days of torture.
The Americo-Liberian government of Liberia is violently deposed.
Transbrasil Flight 303, a Boeing 727, crashes on approach to Hercílio Luz International Airport in Florianópolis, Brazil. Fifty-five out of the 58 people on board are killed.
Canadian runner and athlete, Terry Fox begins his Marathon of Hope Run in St. John's, NF
The Republic of Zimbabwe (formerly Rhodesia) comes into being, with Canaan Banana as the country's first President. The Zimbabwean dollar replaces the Rhodesian dollar as the official currency.
The town of Elmore City, Oklahoma holds its first dance in the town's history.
Eight U.S. servicemen die in Operation Eagle Claw as they attempt to end the Iran hostage crisis.
One hundred forty-six people are killed when Dan-Air Flight 1008 crashes near Los Rodeos Airport in Tenerife, Canary Islands.
Beatrix is inaugurated as Queen of the Netherlands following the abdication of Juliana.
The Iranian Embassy siege begins in London.
Operation Nimrod: The British Special Air Service storms the Iranian embassy in London after a six-day siege.
The World Health Organization confirms the eradication of smallpox.

In Florida, United States, Liberian freighter MV Summit Venture collides with the Sunshine Skyway Bridge over Tampa Bay, making a 430-meter (1,400 ft) section of the southbound span collapse. Thirty-five people in six cars and a Greyhound bus fall 46 metres (150 ft) into the water and die.
source_pages: Florida; Liberia; MV_Summit_Venture; Sunshine_Skyway_Bridge; Tampa_Bay; Greyhound_Lines

event_text: In Norco, California, United States, five masked gunmen hold up a Security Pacific bank, leading to a violent shoot-out and one of the largest pursuits in California history. Two of the gunmen and one police officer are killed and thirty-three police and civilian vehicles are destroyed in the chase.
An F3 tornado hits Kalamazoo County, Michigan. President Jimmy Carter declares it a federal disaster area.
Salvadoran Civil War: the Sumpul River massacre occurs in Chalatenango, El Salvador.
General Chun Doo-hwan of South Korea seizes control of the government and declares martial law in order to suppress student demonstrations.
On the eve of presidential elections, Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path attacks a polling location in Chuschi (a town in Ayacucho), starting the Internal conflict in Peru.
source_pages: Maoism; Guerrilla_warfare; Shining_Path; Chuschi; Ayacucho; Internal_conflict_in_Peru

event_text: Mount St. Helens erupts in Washington, United States, killing 57 people and causing $3 billion in damage.
Students in Gwangju, South Korea begin demonstrations calling for democratic reforms.
In a referendum in Quebec, the population rejects, with 60% of the vote, a government proposal to move towards independence from Canada.
The Gwangju Massacre: Airborne and army troops of South Korea retake the city of Gwangju from civil militias, killing at least 207 and possibly many more.
Cable News Network (CNN) begins broadcasting.
The 1980 Grand Island tornado outbreak hits Nebraska, United States, causing five deaths and $300 million (equivalent to $1145 million in 2024) worth of damage.
The African National Congress in South Africa publishes a call to fight from their imprisoned leader Nelson Mandela.
The 'Ustica massacre': Itavia Flight 870 crashes in the sea while en route from Bologna to Palermo, Italy, killing all 81 on board.
"O Canada" officially becomes the national anthem of Canada.
Swedish tennis player Björn Borg wins his fifth Wimbledon final and becomes the first male tennis player to win the championships five times in a row (1976–1980).
Institution of sharia law in Iran.
During the Lebanese Civil War, 83 Tiger militants are killed during what will be known as the Safra massacre.
The inaugural 1980 State of Origin game is won by Queensland who defeat New South Wales 20–10 at Lang Park.
Aeroflot Flight 4225 crashes near Almaty International Airport in the then Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic (present day Kazakhstan) killing all 166 people on board.
Opening of the Summer Olympics in Moscow.
Phạm Tuân becomes the first Vietnamese citizen and the first Asian in space when he flies aboard the Soyuz 37 mission as an Intercosmos Research Cosmonaut.
The Quietly Confident Quartet of Australia wins the men's 4 x 100 metre medley relay at the Moscow Olympics, the only time the United States has not won the swimming event at Olympic level.
Iran adopts a new "holy" flag after the Islamic Revolution.
Vanuatu gains independence.
Israel's Knesset passes the Jerusalem Law.
Vigdís Finnbogadóttir is elected President of Iceland and becomes the world's first democratically elected female head of state.
A train crash kills 18 people and injures over 170 more in County Cork, Ireland.
A bomb explodes at the railway station in Bologna, Italy, killing 85 people and wounding more than 200.
Lech Wałęsa leads strikes at the Gdańsk, Poland shipyards.
Saudia Flight 163, a Lockheed L-1011 TriStar burns after making an emergency landing at Riyadh International Airport in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, killing 301 people.
Otłoczyn railway accident: In Poland's worst post-war railway accident, 67 people lose their lives and a further 62 are injured.
Zimbabwe joins the United Nations.
After John Birges plants a bomb at Harvey's Resort Hotel in Stateline, Nevada, in the United States, the FBI inadvertently detonates the bomb during its disarming.

South Korean presidential election: After successfully staging the Coup d'état of May Seventeenth, General Chun Doo-hwan, running unopposed, has the National Conference for Unification elect him President of the Fourth Republic of Korea.
The Gotthard Road Tunnel opens in Switzerland as the world's longest highway tunnel at 10.14 miles (16.32 km) stretching from Göschenen to Airolo.
A new constitution of Chile is established under the influence of then Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet, which is subject to controversy in Chile today.
The 43rd government of Turkey is overthrown in a coup d'état led by General Kenan Evren.
After weeks of strikes at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdańsk, Poland, the nationwide independent trade union Solidarity is established.
Former Nicaraguan President Anastasio Somoza Debayle is killed in Asunción, Paraguay.
Soyuz 38 carries two cosmonauts (including one Cuban) to the Salyut 6 space station.
Iraq invades Iran, sparking the nearly eight year Iran–Iraq War.
A terrorist bombing at the Oktoberfest in Munich, Germany, kills 13 people and injures 213 others.
Ethernet specifications are published by Xerox working with Intel and Digital Equipment Corporation.
Michael Myers becomes the first member of either chamber of Congress to be expelled since the Civil War.
Pope John Paul II greets the Dalai Lama during a private audience in Vatican City.
The 7.1 Mw  El Asnam earthquake shakes northern Algeria, killing 2,633 and injuring 8,369.
The Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front is founded in El Salvador.
The 6th Congress of the Workers' Party ended, having anointed North Korean President Kim Il Sung's son Kim Jong Il as his successor.
As part of the Holy See–United Kingdom relations a British monarch makes the first state visit to the Vatican.
The government of Poland legalizes the Solidarity trade union.
Proceedings on the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction conclude.

Demonstration flight of a secretly modified C-130 for an Iran hostage crisis rescue attempt ends in a crash landing at Eglin Air Force Base's Duke Field, Florida, leading to the cancellation of Operation Credible Sport.
El Salvador and Honduras agree to put the border dispute fought over in 1969's Football War before the International Court of Justice.
A Latin Carga Convair CV-880 crashes at Simón Bolívar International Airport in Venezuela, killing four.
Ronald Reagan is elected as the 40th President of the United States, defeating incumbent Jimmy Carter.
The NASA space probe Voyager I makes its closest approach to Saturn and takes the first images of its rings.

Lake Peigneur in Louisiana drains into an underlying salt deposit. A misplaced Texaco oil probe had been drilled into the Diamond Crystal Salt Mine, causing water to flow down into the mine, eroding the edges of the hole.
A deadly fire breaks out at the MGM Grand Hotel in Paradise, Nevada (now Bally's Las Vegas). Eighty-five people are killed and more than 650 are injured in the worst disaster in Nevada history.
The 6.9 Mw  Irpinia earthquake shakes southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme), killing 2,483–4,900, and injuring 7,700–8,934.
Sangoulé Lamizana, president of Upper Volta, is ousted from power in a coup d'état led by Colonel Saye Zerbo.
Iran–Iraq War: Operation Morvarid: The bulk of the Iraqi Navy is destroyed by the Iranian Navy in the Persian Gulf. (Commemorated in Iran as Navy Day.)
source_pages: Iran–Iraq_War; Operation_Morvarid; Iraqi_Navy; Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Navy; Persian_Gulf; Navy_Day

event_text: Salvadoran Civil War: Four American missionaries are raped and murdered by a death squad.
John Lennon is murdered by Mark David Chapman in front of The Dakota in New York City.
source_pages: John_Lennon; Murder_of_John_Lennon; Mark_David_Chapman; The_Dakota; New_York_City; December_8

event_text: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (Superfund) is enacted by the U.S. Congress.
Witnesses report the first of several sightings of unexplained lights near RAF Woodbridge, in Rendlesham Forest, Suffolk, England, United Kingdom, an incident called "Britain's Roswell".
source_pages: Rendlesham_Forest_incident; RAF_Woodbridge; Rendlesham_Forest; Suffolk; Roswell_incident; December_26

event_text: Greece is admitted into the European Community.
One of the largest investigations by a British police force ends when serial killer Peter Sutcliffe, the "Yorkshire Ripper", is arrested in Sheffield, South Yorkshire.
A local farmer reports a UFO sighting in Trans-en-Provence, France, claimed to be "perhaps the most completely and carefully documented sighting of all time".
Salvadoran Civil War: The FMLN launches its first major offensive, gaining control of most of Morazán and Chalatenango departments
Pope John Paul II receives a delegation from the Polish trade union Solidarity at the Vatican led by Lech Wałęsa.
President of the Philippines Ferdinand Marcos lifts martial law eight years and five months after declaring it.

Phil Smith and Phil Mayfield parachute off a Houston skyscraper, becoming the first two people to BASE jump from objects in all four categories: buildings, antennae, spans (bridges), and earth (cliffs).
Iran hostage crisis: United States and Iranian officials sign an agreement to release 52 American hostages after 14 months of captivity.
Twenty minutes after Ronald Reagan is inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States of America, Iran releases 52 American hostages.
Production of the DeLorean sports car begins in Dunmurry, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom.
Ronald Reagan lifts remaining domestic petroleum price and allocation controls in the United States, helping to end the 1979 energy crisis and begin the 1980s oil glut.
The Underarm bowling incident of 1981 occurred when Trevor Chappell bowls underarm on the final delivery of a game between Australia and New Zealand at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG).
source_pages: Underarm_bowling_incident_of_1981; Trevor_Chappell; Australia_national_cricket_team; New_Zealand_national_cricket_team; Melbourne_Cricket_Ground; February_1

event_text: Operation Soap: The Metropolitan Toronto Police Force raids four gay bathhouses in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, arresting just under 300, triggering mass protest and rallies.
The National Resistance Army of Uganda launches an attack on a Ugandan Army installation in the central Mubende District to begin the Ugandan Bush War.
A plane crash at Pushkin Airport kills 50 people, including 16 members of the Pacific Fleet.
A series of sewer explosions destroys more than two miles of streets in Louisville, Kentucky.
In Spain, Antonio Tejero attempts a coup d'état by capturing the Spanish Congress of Deputies.
The 6.7 Ms Gulf of Corinth earthquake affected Central Greece with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). Twenty-two people were killed, 400 were injured, and damage totaled $812 million.
Provisional Irish Republican Army member Bobby Sands begins his hunger strike in HM Prison Maze.
The ZX81, a pioneering British home computer, is launched by Sinclair Research and would go on to sell over 11⁄2 million units around the world.
Hundreds of students protest in the University of Pristina in Kosovo, then part of Yugoslavia, to give their province more political rights. The protests then became a nationwide movement.
Social Democratic Party (UK) is founded as a party.
The Solidarity movement in Poland stages a warning strike, in which at least 12 million Poles walk off their jobs for four hours.
U.S. President Ronald Reagan is shot in the chest outside a Washington, D.C., hotel by John Hinckley Jr.; three others are wounded in the same incident.
The Osborne 1, the first successful portable computer, is unveiled at the West Coast Computer Faire in San Francisco.
Iran–Iraq War: The Islamic Republic of Iran Air Force mounts an attack on H-3 Airbase and destroys about 50 Iraqi aircraft.
The U.S. Navy nuclear submarine USS George Washington accidentally collides with the Nissho Maru, a Japanese cargo ship, sinking it and killing two Japanese sailors.
Imprisoned IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands was elected to Westminster as the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, Northern Ireland. He died twenty-six days later.
A massive riot in Brixton, south London results in almost 300 police injuries and 65 serious civilian injuries.
The first launch of a Space Shuttle (Columbia) takes place: The STS-1 mission.
STS-1: The first operational Space Shuttle, Columbia completes its first test flight.
More than 100 workers are exposed to radiation during repairs of at the Tsuruga Nuclear Power Plant in Japan.
Dr. Michael R. Harrison of the University of California, San Francisco Medical Center performs the world's first human open fetal surgery.
Bobby Sands dies in the Long Kesh prison hospital after 66 days of hunger-striking, aged 27.
Mehmet Ali Ağca attempts to assassinate Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square in Rome. The Pope is rushed to the Agostino Gemelli University Polyclinic to undergo emergency surgery and survives.
The Italian government releases the membership list of Propaganda Due, an illegal pseudo-Masonic lodge that was implicated in numerous Italian crimes and mysteries.
Transamerica Corporation agrees to sell United Artists to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for $380 million after the box office failure of the 1980 film Heaven's Gate.

Ecuadorian president Jaime Roldós Aguilera, his wife, and his presidential committee die in an aircraft accident while travelling from Quito to Zapotillo minutes after the president gave a famous speech regarding the 24 de mayo anniversary of the Battle of Pichincha.
In Riyadh, the Gulf Cooperation Council is created between Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
source_pages: Riyadh; Gulf_Cooperation_Council; Bahrain; Kuwait; Oman; Qatar; Saudi_Arabia; United_Arab_Emirates

event_text: Italian Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani and his coalition cabinet resign following a scandal over membership of the pseudo-masonic lodge P2 (Propaganda Due).
An EA-6B Prowler crashes on the flight deck of the aircraft carrier USS Nimitz, killing 14 crewmen and injuring 45 others.

The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that five people in Los Angeles, California, have a rare form of pneumonia seen only in patients with weakened immune systems, in what turns out to be the first recognized cases of AIDS.
The Israeli Air Force destroys Iraq's Osiraq nuclear reactor during Operation Opera.
A magnitude 6.9 earthquake at Golbaf, Iran, kills at least 2,000.
The first of the Indiana Jones film franchise, Raiders of the Lost Ark, is released in theaters.
At the Trooping the Colour ceremony in London, a teenager, Marcus Sarjeant, fires six blank shots at Queen Elizabeth II.

US President Ronald Reagan awards the Congressional Gold Medal to Ken Taylor, Canada's former ambassador to Iran, for helping six Americans escape from Iran during the hostage crisis of 1979–81; he is the first foreign citizen bestowed the honor.
The Lockheed F-117 Nighthawk, the first operational aircraft initially designed around stealth technology, makes its first flight.
The Humber Bridge opens to traffic, connecting Yorkshire and Lincolnshire. It remained the world's longest bridge span for 17 years.
Microsoft is restructured to become an incorporated business in its home state of Washington.
Dan-Air Flight 240, flying to East Midlands Airport, crashes in Nailstone, Leicestershire. All three crew members perish.

The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party issues its "Resolution on Certain Questions in the History of Our Party Since the Founding of the People's Republic of China", laying the blame for the Cultural Revolution on Mao Zedong.
A powerful bomb explodes in Tehran, killing 73 officials of the Islamic Republican Party.
US President Ronald Reagan nominates Sandra Day O'Connor to become the first female member of the Supreme Court of the United States.
A structural failure leads to the collapse of a walkway at the Hyatt Regency in Kansas City, Missouri, killing 114 people and injuring more than 200.
A Canadair CL-44 and Sukhoi Su-15 collide in mid-air near Yerevan, Armenia, killing four.

In a private meeting with U.S. President Ronald Reagan, French President François Mitterrand reveals the existence of the Farewell Dossier, a collection of documents showing the Soviet Union had been stealing American technological research and development.
Somali Airlines Flight 40 crashes in Balad, Somalia, killing 50 people.
The first game of the 1981 South Africa rugby union tour of New Zealand and the United States is held in Gisborne, New Zealand.
While landing at Chihuahua International Airport, Aeromexico Flight 230 overshoots the runway. Thirty-two of the 66 passengers and crew on board the DC-9 are killed.
A worldwide television audience of around 750 million people watch the wedding of Charles, Prince of Wales, and Lady Diana Spencer at St Paul's Cathedral in London.

After impeachment on June 21, Abolhassan Banisadr flees with Massoud Rajavi to Paris, in an Iranian Air Force Boeing 707, piloted by Colonel Behzad Moezzi, to form the National Council of Resistance of Iran.
source_pages: Abolhassan_Banisadr; Massoud_Rajavi; Paris; Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Air_Force; Boeing_707; National_Council_of_Resistance_of_Iran; July_29

event_text: As many as 50,000 demonstrators, mostly women and children, took to the streets in Łódź to protest food ration shortages in Communist Poland.
MTV begins broadcasting in the United States and airs its first video, "Video Killed the Radio Star" by The Buggles.
Senegalese opposition parties, under the leadership of Mamadou Dia, launch the Antiimperialist Action Front – Suxxali Reew Mi.
President Ronald Reagan fires 11,359 striking air-traffic controllers who ignored his order for them to return to work.
The Washington Star ceases all operations after 128 years of publication.
Murder of Adam Walsh: The head of John Walsh's son is found. This inspires the creation of the television series America's Most Wanted and the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children.
The IBM Personal Computer is released.
Gulf of Sidra Incident: United States F-14A Tomcat fighters intercept and shoot down two Libyan Sukhoi Su-22 fighter jets over the Gulf of Sidra.
Far Eastern Air Transport Flight 103 disintegrates in mid-air and crashes in Sanyi Township, Miaoli County, Taiwan. All 110 people on board are killed.
Mark David Chapman is sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for murdering John Lennon.
Voyager 2 spacecraft makes its closest approach to Saturn.
President Mohammad-Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammad-Javad Bahonar of Iran are assassinated in a bombing. The office of Iran's Prosecutor General blames the People's Mujahedin of Iran.
Central African President David Dacko is ousted from power in a bloodless military coup led by General André Kolingba.
The Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, an international bill of rights for women, is instituted by the United Nations.
The first women arrive at what becomes Greenham Common Women's Peace Camp in the UK.
The Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously approves Sandra Day O'Connor to become the first female justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
The John Bull becomes the oldest operable steam locomotive in the world when the Smithsonian Institution operates it under its own power outside Washington, D.C.
The Assemblée Nationale votes to abolish capital punishment in France.
Belize is granted full independence from the United Kingdom.
Sandra Day O'Connor is unanimously approved by the U.S. Senate as the first female Supreme Court justice.
During a military exercise, a Turkish Air Force Northrop F-5 crashes in Babaeski as a result of pilot error, killing one crew member and also 65 soldiers on the ground.
source_pages: Military_exercise; Turkish_Air_Force; Northrop_F-5; Pancarköy_air_disaster; Babaeski; Pilot_error; September_22

event_text: Belize joins the United Nations.
An Iranian Air Force Lockheed C-130 Hercules military transport aircraft crashes into a firing range near Kahrizak, Iran, killing 80 people.
The hunger strike at the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland ends after seven months and ten deaths.
Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is murdered by Islamic extremists.
NLM CityHopper Flight 431 crashes in Moerdijk after taking off from Rotterdam The Hague Airport in the Netherlands, killing all 17 people on board.
President François Mitterrand abolishes capital punishment in France.
Vice President Hosni Mubarak is elected as the President of Egypt, one week after the assassination of Anwar Sadat.
Two police officers and a Brink's armored car guard are killed during an armed robbery carried out by members of the Black Liberation Army and Weather Underground in Nanuet, New York.
Andreas Papandreou becomes Prime Minister of Greece, ending an almost 50-year-long system of power dominated by conservative forces.
The US Federal Labor Relations Authority votes to decertify the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization (PATCO) for its strike the previous August.
Cold War: The Soviet submarine S-363 runs aground on the east coast of Sweden.
Antigua and Barbuda gains independence from the United Kingdom.
Aeroméxico Flight 110 crashes near Zihuatanejo, Mexico, killing all 18 people on board.
Antigua and Barbuda joins the United Nations.
Space Shuttle program: Mission STS-2, utilizing the Space Shuttle Columbia, marks the first time a crewed spacecraft is launched into space twice.
Aeroflot Flight 3603 crashes during landing at Norilsk Airport, killing 99.

Iran–Contra affair: Ronald Reagan signs the top secret National Security Decision Directive 17 (NSDD-17), giving the Central Intelligence Agency the authority to recruit and support Contra rebels in Nicaragua.
Pope John Paul II appoints Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger (the future Pope Benedict XVI) Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith.

Cold War: In Geneva, representatives from the United States and the Soviet Union begin to negotiate intermediate-range nuclear weapon reductions in Europe. (The meetings end inconclusively on December 17.)
Inex-Adria Aviopromet Flight 1308, a McDonnell Douglas MD-80, crashes in Corsica, killing all 180 people on board.
South Africa grants independence to the Ciskei "homeland" (not recognized by any government outside South Africa).
El Mozote massacre: Armed forces in El Salvador kill an estimated 900 civilians in an anti-guerrilla campaign during the Salvadoran Civil War.
General Wojciech Jaruzelski declares martial law in Poland, largely due to the actions by Solidarity.
Arab–Israeli conflict: Israel's Knesset ratifies the Golan Heights Law, extending Israeli law to the Golan Heights.

A suicide car bombing targeting the Iraqi embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, levels the embassy and kills 61 people, including Iraq's ambassador to Lebanon. The attack is considered the first modern suicide bombing.
American Brigadier General James L. Dozier is abducted by the Red Brigades in Verona, Italy.
First flight of the Russian heavy strategic bomber Tu-160, the world's largest combat aircraft, largest supersonic aircraft and largest variable-sweep wing aircraft built.
source_pages: Heavy_bomber; Strategic_bomber; Tupolev_Tu-160; Military_aircraft; Supersonic_aircraft; Variable-sweep_wing

event_text: Sixteen lives are lost when the Penlee lifeboat goes to the aid of the stricken coaster Union Star in heavy seas.
A coup d'état in Ghana removes President Hilla Limann's PNP government and replaces it with the Provisional National Defence Council led by Flight lieutenant Jerry Rawlings.
source_pages: Coup_d'état; Ghana; List_of_heads_of_state_of_Ghana; Hilla_Limann; People's_National_Party_(Ghana); Limann_government; Provisional_National_Defence_Council; Flight_lieutenant; Jerry_Rawlings

event_text: Peruvian Javier Pérez de Cuéllar becomes the first Latin American to hold the title of Secretary-General of the United Nations.
Breakup of the Bell System: In the United States, AT&T agrees to divest itself of twenty-two subdivisions.
Shortly after takeoff, Air Florida Flight 90, a Boeing 737 jet, crashes into Washington, D.C.'s 14th Street Bridge and falls into the Potomac River, killing 78 including four motorists.
World Airways Flight 30 overshoots the runway at Logan International Airport in Boston, Massachusetts, and crashes into Boston Harbor. Two people are missing and presumed dead.
source_pages: World_Airways_Flight_30; Logan_International_Airport; Boston; Massachusetts; Boston_Harbor; January_23

event_text: US Army General James L. Dozier is rescued by Italian anti-terrorism forces from captivity by the Red Brigades.
Richard Skrenta writes the first PC virus code, which is 400 lines long and disguised as an Apple boot program called "Elk Cloner".
Japan Air Lines Flight 350 crashes near Haneda Airport in an attempted pilot mass murder-suicide, killing 24 of the 174 people on board.
The drilling rig Ocean Ranger sinks during a storm off the coast of Newfoundland, killing 84 workers.
Soviet probe Venera 14 lands on Venus.
Syzygy: All nine planets recognized at this time — Mercury to Pluto — align on the same side of the Sun.
Fifteen people are killed when Widerøe Flight 933 crashes into the Barents Sea near Gamvik, Norway.
The South African government bombs the headquarters of the African National Congress in London.
Falklands War: Argentinian forces land on South Georgia Island, precipitating war with the United Kingdom.
NASA's Space Shuttle Columbia is launched from the Kennedy Space Center on its third mission, STS-3.
Guatemala's government, headed by Fernando Romeo Lucas García is overthrown in a military coup by right-wing General Efraín Ríos Montt.
Bangladeshi President Abdus Sattar is deposed in a bloodless coup led by Army Chief Lieutenant general Hussain Muhammad Ershad, who suspends the Constitution and imposes martial law.
source_pages: Abdus_Sattar_(president); 1982_Bangladeshi_coup_d'état; Chief_of_Army_Staff_(Bangladesh); Hussain_Muhammad_Ershad; Constitution_of_Bangladesh; Martial_law; March_24

event_text: A groundbreaking ceremony for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial is held in Washington, D.C.
The Canada Act 1982 receives the Royal Assent from Queen Elizabeth II, setting the stage for the Queen of Canada to proclaim the Constitution Act, 1982.
