Second Chechen War: Chechen separatist terrorists seize the House of Culture theater in Moscow and take approximately 700 theater-goers hostage.

Approximately 50 Chechen terrorists and 150 hostages die when Russian special forces troops storm a theater building in Moscow, which had been occupied by the terrorists during a musical performance three days before.

A fire destroys a luxurious department store in Ho Chi Minh City, where 1,500 people are shopping. More than 60 people die and over 100 are unaccounted for in the deadliest peacetime disaster in Vietnam.

A federal grand jury in Houston, Texas indicts former Enron chief financial officer Andrew Fastow on 78 counts of wire fraud, money laundering, conspiracy and obstruction of justice related to the collapse of his ex-employer.
source_pages: Houston; Enron; Andrew_Fastow; Mail_and_wire_fraud; Money_laundering; Criminal_conspiracy; Obstruction_of_justice_in_the_United_States

event_text: Chinese authorities arrest cyber-dissident He Depu for signing a pro-democracy letter to the 16th Communist Party Congress.
Jiang Lijun is detained by Chinese police for signing the Open Letter to the 16th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.
A Fokker 50 crashes near Luxembourg Airport, killing 20 and injuring three.

Iraq disarmament crisis: UN Security Council Resolution 1441: The United Nations Security Council unanimously approves a resolution on Iraq, forcing Saddam Hussein to disarm or face "serious consequences".
Veteran's Day Weekend Tornado Outbreak: A tornado outbreak stretching from Northern Ohio to the Gulf Coast, one of the largest outbreaks recorded in November.
A Fokker F27 Friendship operating as Laoag International Airlines Flight 585 crashes into Manila Bay shortly after takeoff from Ninoy Aquino International Airport, killing 19 people.

Russian mathematician Grigori Perelman posts the first of three preprint texts with his proof of the Poincaré conjecture. It remains the only of the Millennium Prize Problems in mathematics to be solved. He later refused both the prize money from Clay Mathematics Institute as well as the Fields Medal for his work.
source_pages: Grigori_Perelman; Poincaré_conjecture; Millennium_Prize_Problems; Clay_Mathematics_Institute; Fields_Medal; November_11

event_text: Iraq disarmament crisis: Iraq agrees to the terms of the UN Security Council Resolution 1441.

During the Prestige oil spill, a storm bursts a tank of the oil tanker MV Prestige, which was not allowed to dock and sank on November 19, 2002, off the coast of Galicia, spilling 63,000 metric tons of heavy fuel oil, more than the Exxon Valdez oil spill.
Hu Jintao becomes General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party and a new nine-member Politburo Standing Committee is inaugurated.
The first cases of the 2002–2004 SARS outbreak are traced to Foshan, Guangdong Province, China.
Iraq disarmament crisis: United Nations weapons inspectors led by Hans Blix arrive in Iraq.

The Greek oil tanker Prestige splits in half and sinks off the coast of Galicia, releasing over 76,000 m3 (20 million US gal) of oil in the largest environmental disaster in Spanish and Portuguese history.
NATO invites Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia to become members.
source_pages: NATO; Bulgaria; Estonia; Latvia; Lithuania; Romania; Slovakia; Slovenia

event_text: Arturo Guzmán Decena, founder of Los Zetas and high-member of the Gulf Cartel, is killed in a shoot-out with the Mexican Army and the police.
Space Shuttle Endeavour launches on STS-113 to the International Space Station carrying the Expedition 6 crew and the P1 truss.
source_pages: Space_Shuttle_Endeavour; STS-113; International_Space_Station; Expedition_6; Integrated_Truss_Structure; November_23

event_text: Suicide bombers blow up an Israeli-owned hotel in Mombasa, Kenya; their colleagues fail in their attempt to bring down Arkia Israel Airlines Flight 582 with surface-to-air missiles.
European Union enlargement: The EU announces that Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia will become members on May 1, 2004.
source_pages: 2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union; Cyprus; Czech_Republic; Estonia; Hungary; Latvia; Lithuania; Malta; Poland; Slovakia; Slovenia

event_text: Second Congo War: The Congolese parties of the Inter Congolese Dialogue sign a peace accord which makes provision for transitional governance and legislative and presidential elections within two years.

California gubernatorial recall: Then Governor of California Gray Davis announces that the state would face a record budget deficit of $35 billion, roughly double the figure reported during his reelection campaign one month earlier.
A U.S. MQ-1 Predator is shot down by an Iraqi MiG-25 in the first combat engagement between a drone and conventional aircraft.
Two truck bombs kill 72 and wound 200 at the pro-Moscow headquarters of the Chechen government in Grozny, Chechnya, Russia.
Turkish Airlines Flight 634 crashes near Diyarbakır Airport, Turkey, killing the entire crew and 70 of the 75 passengers.
Air Midwest Flight 5481 crashes at Charlotte-Douglas Airport, in Charlotte, North Carolina, killing all 21 people on board.
TANS Perú Flight 222 crashes on approach to Chachapoyas Airport in Chachapoyas, Peru, killing 46 people.
North Korea withdraws from the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, making it the first state to withdraw from the treaty.
Illinois Governor George Ryan commutes the death sentences of 167 prisoners on Illinois's death row based on the Jon Burge scandal.
The Space Shuttle Columbia takes off for mission STS-107 which would be its final one. Columbia disintegrated 16 days later on re-entry.
A bushfire kills four people and destroys more than 500 homes in Canberra, Australia.
A 7.6 magnitude earthquake strikes the Mexican state of Colima, killing 29 and leaving approximately 10,000 people homeless.
A very weak signal from Pioneer 10 is detected for the last time, but no usable data can be extracted.
The United States Department of Homeland Security officially begins operation.
Invasion of Iraq: A group of people leave London, England, for Baghdad, Iraq, to serve as human shields, intending to prevent the U.S.-led coalition troops from bombing certain locations.
The first selections for the National Recording Registry are announced by the Library of Congress.
The Waterfall rail accident occurs near Waterfall, New South Wales, Australia.
Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrated during the reentry of mission STS-107 into the Earth's atmosphere, killing all seven astronauts aboard.
The Federal Republic of Yugoslavia adopts a new constitution, becoming a loose confederacy between Montenegro and Serbia.
France and Belgium break the NATO procedure of silent approval concerning the timing of protective measures for Turkey in case of a possible war with Iraq.
Iraq disarmament crisis: UNMOVIC Executive Chairman Hans Blix reports to the United Nations Security Council that disarmament inspectors have found no weapons of mass destruction in Ba'athist Iraq.
source_pages: Iraq_disarmament_crisis; United_Nations_Monitoring,_Verification_and_Inspection_Commission; Hans_Blix; United_Nations_Security_Council; Iraq_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction; Ba'athist_Iraq; February_14

event_text: Protests against the Iraq war take place in over 600 cities worldwide. It is estimated that between eight million and 30 million people participate, making this the largest peace demonstration in history.
192 people die when an arsonist sets fire to a subway train in Daegu, South Korea.
An Ilyushin Il-76 military aircraft crashes near Kerman, Iran, killing 275.
During a Great White concert in West Warwick, Rhode Island, a pyrotechnics display sets the Station nightclub ablaze, killing 100 and injuring over 200 others.
Management of the United States Customs Service and the United States Secret Service move to the United States Department of Homeland Security.
In Haifa, 17 Israeli civilians are killed in the Haifa bus 37 suicide bombing.
Air Algérie Flight 6289 crashes at the Aguenar – Hadj Bey Akhamok Airport in Tamanrasset, Algeria, killing 102 out of the 103 people on board.
The International Criminal Court holds its inaugural session in The Hague.
Zoran Đinđić, Prime Minister of Serbia, is assassinated in Belgrade.
source_pages: Zoran_Đinđić; Prime_minister; Serbia; Assassination_of_Zoran_Đinđić; Belgrade; March_12

event_text: The World Health Organization officially release a global warning of outbreaks of Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
An article in Nature identifies the Ciampate del Diavolo as 350,000-year-old hominid footprints.
American activist Rachel Corrie is killed in Rafah by being run over by an Israel Defense Forces bulldozer while trying to obstruct the demolition of a home.
Leader of the House of Commons and Lord President of the Council, Robin Cook, resigns from the British Cabinet in disagreement with government plans for the 2003 invasion of Iraq.
United States President George W. Bush addresses the nation, announcing the invasion of Iraq.
Iraq War: The United States, the United Kingdom, Australia, and Poland begin an invasion of Iraq.
Battle of Nasiriyah, first major conflict during the invasion of Iraq.
The Arab League votes 21–1 in favor of a resolution demanding an end to the 2003 invasion of Iraq.
In a friendly fire incident, two American A-10 Thunderbolt II aircraft attack British tanks participating in the 2003 invasion of Iraq, killing one soldier.
Iraq War: U.S. troops capture Baghdad; Saddam Hussein's Ba'athist regime falls two days later.
Haitian president Jean-Bertrand Aristide demands reparations of $21 billion from France for the Haiti Independence Debt.
Iraq War: Baghdad falls to American forces.
The Human Genome Project is completed with 99% of the human genome sequenced to an accuracy of 99.99%.
U.S. troops in Baghdad capture Abu Abbas, leader of the Palestinian group that killed an American on the hijacked cruise liner MS Achille Lauro in 1985.
The Treaty of Accession is signed in Athens admitting ten new member states to the European Union.
Anneli Jäätteenmäki takes office as the first female prime minister of Finland.

Invasion of Iraq: In what becomes known as the "Mission Accomplished" speech, on board the USS Abraham Lincoln (off the coast of California), U.S. President George W. Bush declares that "major combat operations in Iraq have ended".
The Riyadh compound bombings in Saudi Arabia, carried out by al-Qaeda, kill 39 people.
In Morocco, 33 civilians are killed and more than 100 people are injured in the Casablanca terrorist attacks.

The 6.8 Mw  Boumerdès earthquake shakes northern Algeria with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). More than 2,200 people were killed and a moderate tsunami sank boats at the Balearic Islands.
Ukrainian-Mediterranean Airlines Flight 4230 crashes in the Turkish town of Maçka, killing 75.
Peter Hollingworth resigns as Governor-General of Australia following criticism of his handling of child sexual abuse allegations during his tenure as Anglican Archbishop of Brisbane.

Depayin massacre: At least 70 people associated with the National League for Democracy are killed by government-sponsored mob in Burma. Aung San Suu Kyi flees the scene, but is arrested soon afterwards.
Air France retires its fleet of Concorde aircraft.
Europe launches its first voyage to another planet, Mars. The European Space Agency's Mars Express probe launches from the Baikonur space center in Kazakhstan.
A severe heat wave across Pakistan and India reaches its peak, as temperatures exceed 50 °C (122 °F) in the region.
The Spirit rover is launched, beginning NASA's Mars Exploration Rover mission.
The Wikimedia Foundation is founded in St. Petersburg, Florida.
The U.S. Supreme Court rules in Lawrence v. Texas that sex-based sodomy laws are unconstitutional.
Over 500,000 people protest against efforts to pass anti-sedition legislation in Hong Kong.
The World Health Organization announces that the 2002–2004 SARS outbreak has been contained.

The 70-metre Yevpatoria Planetary Radar sends a METI message (Cosmic Call 2) to five stars: Hip 4872, HD 245409, 55 Cancri (HD 75732), HD 10307 and 47 Ursae Majoris (HD 95128). The messages will arrive to these stars in 2036, 2040, 2044, and 2049, respectively.
source_pages: Yevpatoria; Active_SETI; Cosmic_Call; Cassiopeia_(constellation); Orion_(constellation); 55_Cancri; HD_10307; 47_Ursae_Majoris

event_text: NASA Opportunity rover, MER-B or Mars Exploration Rover–B, was launched into space aboard a Delta II rocket.
Sudan Airways Flight 139 crashes near Port Sudan Airport during an emergency landing attempt, killing 116 of the 117 people on board.
French DGSE personnel abort an operation to rescue Íngrid Betancourt from FARC rebels in Colombia, causing a political scandal when details are leaked to the press.
AOL Time Warner disbands Netscape. The Mozilla Foundation is established on the same day.

Iraq War: Members of 101st Airborne of the United States, aided by Special Forces, attack a compound in Iraq, killing Saddam Hussein's sons Uday and Qusay, along with Mustapha Hussein, Qusay's 14-year-old son, and a bodyguard.
source_pages: Iraq_War; 101st_Airborne_Division; Iraq; Killing_of_Qusay_and_Uday_Hussein; Saddam_Hussein; Uday_Hussein; Qusay_Hussein

event_text: In Mexico, the last 'old style' Volkswagen Beetle rolls off the assembly line.

Three years after the death the last Pyrenean ibex, Celia, a clone of her is born only to subsequently die from lung defects. Within minutes, the Pyrenean ibex becomes the first and so-far only species to have ever gone de-extinct as well as go extinct twice.
A car bomb explodes in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta outside the Marriott Hotel killing 12 and injuring 150.
The Okinawa Urban Monorail is opened in Naha, Okinawa.
NATO takes over command of the peacekeeping force in Afghanistan, marking its first major operation outside Europe in its 54-year-history.
Jemaah Islamiyah leader Riduan Isamuddin, better known as Hambali, is arrested in Bangkok, Thailand.
A widescale power blackout affects the northeast United States and Canada.

One-year-old Zachary Turner is murdered in Newfoundland by his mother, who was awarded custody despite facing trial for the murder of Zachary's father. The case was documented in the film Dear Zachary and led to reform of Canada's bail laws.
A truck-bomb attack on United Nations headquarters in Iraq kills the agency's top envoy Sérgio Vieira de Mello and 21 other employees.
Shmuel HaNavi bus bombing: A suicide attack on a bus in Jerusalem, planned by Hamas, kills 23 Israelis, seven of them children.

Alabama Chief Justice Roy Moore is suspended after refusing to comply with a federal court order to remove a rock inscribed with the Ten Commandments from the lobby of the Alabama Supreme Court building.
NASA successfully launches the Spitzer Space Telescope into space.
A Beechcraft 1900 operating as Colgan Air Flight 9446 crashes after taking off from Barnstable Municipal Airport in Yarmouth, Massachusetts, killing both pilots on board.
Mars makes its closest approach to Earth in nearly 60,000 years, passing 34,646,418 miles (55,758,005 km) distant.

The first six-party talks, involving South and North Korea, the United States, China, Japan and Russia, convene to find a peaceful resolution to the security concerns of the North Korean nuclear weapons program.

In "one of the most complicated and bizarre crimes in the annals of the FBI", Brian Wells dies after becoming involved in a complex plot involving a bank robbery, a scavenger hunt, and a homemade explosive device.
source_pages: Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation; Death_of_Brian_Wells; Bank_robbery; Scavenger_hunt; Improvised_explosive_device; August_28

event_text: Sayed Ayatollah Mohammed Baqir al-Hakim, the Shia Muslim leader in Iraq, is assassinated in a terrorist bombing, along with nearly 100 worshippers as they leave a mosque in Najaf.
source_pages: Sayyid; Ayatollah; Mohammad_Baqir_al-Hakim; Shia_Islam; Iraq; Assassination; 2003_Imam_Ali_Shrine_bombing; Mosque; Najaf

event_text: Mahmoud Abbas resigns from his position of Palestinian Prime Minister.
The United Nations lifts sanctions against Libya after that country agreed to accept responsibility and recompense the families of victims in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103.
Iraq War: In Fallujah, U.S. forces mistakenly shoot and kill eight Iraqi police officers.
Typhoon Maemi, the strongest recorded typhoon to strike South Korea, made landfall near Busan.
In a referendum, Estonia approves joining the European Union.
Bissau-Guinean President Kumba Ialá is ousted from power in a bloodless military coup led by General Veríssimo Correia Seabra.
Civil unrest in the Maldives breaks out after a prisoner is killed by guards.
The Galileo spacecraft is terminated by sending it into Jupiter's atmosphere.
The 8.3 Mw  Hokkaidō earthquake strikes just offshore Hokkaidō, Japan.
The SMART-1 satellite is launched.
The popular and controversial English-language imageboard 4chan is launched.
The Maxim restaurant suicide bombing in Israel kills twenty-one Israelis, both Jews and Arabs.
The Steve Bartman Incident takes place at Wrigley Field in Chicago, Illinois.
China launches Shenzhou 5, its first crewed space mission.
Bolivian gas conflict: Bolivian President Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada is forced to resign and leave Bolivia.
Mother Teresa is beatified by Pope John Paul II.
The Sloan Great Wall, once the largest cosmic structures known to humanity, is discovered by students at Princeton University.
Concorde makes its last commercial flight.
The Cedar Fire, the third-largest wildfire in California history, kills 15 people, consumes 250,000 acres (1,000 km2), and destroys 2,200 homes around San Diego.
Mahathir Mohamad resigns as Prime Minister of Malaysia and is replaced by Deputy Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, marking an end to Mahathir's 22 years in power.
Iraq War: In Nasiriyah, Iraq, at least 23 people, among them the first Italian casualties of the 2003 invasion of Iraq, are killed in a suicide bomb attack on an Italian police base.
Shanghai Transrapid sets a new world speed record of 501 kilometres per hour (311 mph) for commercial railway systems, which remains the fastest for unmodified commercial rail vehicles.
Astronomers discover Sedna, a distant trans-Neptunian dwarf planet.
The first day of the 2003 Istanbul bombings, in which two car bombs, targeting two synagogues, explode, kill 25 people and wound 300 more.
Actor Arnold Schwarzenegger's tenure as the governor of California began.

The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court rules 4–3 in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health that the state's ban on same-sex marriage is unconstitutional and gives the state legislature 180 days to change the law making Massachusetts the first state in the United States to grant marriage rights to same-sex couples.
After the November 15 bombings, a second day of the 2003 Istanbul bombings occurs in Istanbul, Turkey, destroying the Turkish head office of HSBC Bank AS and the British consulate.
Baghdad DHL attempted shootdown incident: Shortly after takeoff, a DHL Express cargo plane is struck on the left wing by a surface-to-air missile and forced to land.
Rose Revolution: Georgian president Eduard Shevardnadze resigns following weeks of mass protests over flawed elections.
The Concorde makes its final flight, over Bristol, England.
The Conservative Party of Canada is officially registered, following the merger of the Canadian Alliance and the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada.
A blast in the center of Moscow kills six people and wounds several more.
Iraq War: Operation Red Dawn: Former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is captured near his home town of Tikrit.
Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf narrowly escapes an assassination attempt.
The Soham murder trial ends at the Old Bailey in London, with Ian Huntley found guilty of two counts of murder.  His girlfriend, Maxine Carr, is found guilty of perverting the course of justice.
SpaceShipOne, piloted by Brian Binnie, makes its first powered and first supersonic flight.

Sex work rights activists establish December 17 (or "D17") as International Day to End Violence Against Sex Workers to memorialize victims of a serial killer who targeted prostitutes, and highlight State violence against sex workers by police and others.
An explosion at the PetroChina Chuandongbei natural gas field in Kai County, Chongqing, China, kills at least 234.
The Spanish police thwart an attempt by ETA to detonate 50 kg of explosives at 3:55 p.m. inside Madrid's busy Chamartín Station.
UTA Flight 141, a Boeing 727-223, crashes at the Cotonou Airport in Benin, killing 141 people.
The ill-fated Beagle 2 probe, released from the Mars Express spacecraft on December 19, stops transmitting shortly before its scheduled landing.
The 6.6 Mw  Bam earthquake shakes southeastern Iran with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), leaving more than 26,000 dead and 30,000 injured.
The last known speaker of Akkala Sami dies, rendering the language extinct.

In a vote of confidence, General Pervez Musharraf wins 658 out of 1,170 votes in the Electoral College of Pakistan, and according to Article 41(8) of the Constitution of Pakistan, is "deemed to be elected" to the office of President until October 2007.
source_pages: Motion_of_no_confidence; Pervez_Musharraf; Electoral_College_(Pakistan); Constitution_of_Pakistan; President_of_Pakistan; January_1

event_text: Stardust successfully flies past Comet Wild 2, collecting samples that are returned to Earth.
Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea, resulting in 148 deaths, making it one of the deadliest aviation accidents in Egyptian history.
Spirit, a NASA Mars rover, lands successfully on Mars at 04:35 UTC.
source_pages: Spirit_(rover); NASA; Mars_rover; Mars; Coordinated_Universal_Time; January_4

event_text: Mikheil Saakashvili is elected President of Georgia following the November 2003 Rose Revolution.
The RMS Queen Mary 2, then the largest ocean liner ever built, is christened by her namesake's granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.

An inflatable boat carrying illegal Albanian emigrants stalls near the Karaburun Peninsula en route to Brindisi, Italy; exposure to the elements kills 28. This is the second deadliest marine disaster in Albanian history.
source_pages: Inflatable_boat; Albania; Karaburun_tragedy; Karaburun_Peninsula,_Albania; Brindisi; January_9

event_text: The world's largest ocean liner, RMS Queen Mary 2, makes its maiden voyage.
The national flag of the Republic of Georgia, the so-called "five cross flag", is restored to official use after a hiatus of some 500 years.
NASA's MER-A (the Mars Rover Spirit) ceases communication with mission control. The problem lies in the management of its flash memory and is fixed remotely from Earth on February 6.
Hajj pilgrimage stampede: In a stampede at the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia, 251 people are trampled to death and 244 injured.
Double suicide attack in Erbil on the offices of Iraqi Kurdish political parties by members of Jama'at al-Tawhid wal-Jihad
Facebook, a mainstream online social networking site, is founded by Mark Zuckerberg and Eduardo Saverin.
Rebels from the Revolutionary Artibonite Resistance Front capture the city of Gonaïves, starting the 2004 Haiti rebellion.
Forty-three people are killed and three are injured when a Fokker 50 crashes near Sharjah International Airport.
The city of San Francisco begins issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples in response to a directive from Mayor Gavin Newsom.

The Harvard–Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics announces the discovery of the universe's largest known diamond, white dwarf star BPM 37093. Astronomers named this star "Lucy" after The Beatles' song "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds".
source_pages: Harvard–Smithsonian_Center_for_Astrophysics; Diamond; White_dwarf; Star; BPM_37093; The_Beatles; Lucy_in_the_Sky_with_Diamonds

event_text: In a suburb of Moscow, Russia, the roof of the Transvaal water park collapses, killing more than 28 people, and wounding 193 others.
Up to 295 people, 182 of which being rescue workers, die near Nishapur, Iran, when a runaway freight train carrying sulfur, petrol and fertilizer catches fire and explodes.
The 6.3 Mw Al Hoceima earthquake strikes northern Morocco with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). At least 628 people are killed, 926 are injured, and up to 15,000 are displaced.
A bombing of a SuperFerry by Abu Sayyaf in the Philippines' worst terrorist attack kills more than 100 passengers.
Shoko Asahara, the leader of the Japanese doomsday cult Aum Shinrikyo, is sentenced to death for masterminding the 1995 Tokyo subway sarin attack.
War in Iraq: Al-Qaeda carries out the Ashoura Massacre in Iraq, killing 170 and wounding over 500.
A new constitution is signed by Iraq's Governing Council.
Madrid train bombings: Simultaneous explosions on rush hour trains in Madrid, Spain kill 191 people.
The President of South Korea, Roh Moo-hyun, is impeached by its National Assembly: the first such impeachment in the nation's history.
Unrest in Kosovo: More than 22 are killed and 200 wounded. Thirty-five Serbian Orthodox shrines in Kosovo and two mosques in Serbia are destroyed.
Catalina affair: A Swedish DC-3 shot down by a Soviet MiG-15 in 1952 over the Baltic Sea is finally recovered after years of work.
March 19 Shooting Incident: The Republic of China (Taiwan) president Chen Shui-bian is shot just before the country's presidential election on March 20.
The Konginkangas bus disaster kills 23 and injures 14 people in Äänekoski, Finland.

Ahmed Yassin, co-founder and leader of the Palestinian Sunni Islamist group Hamas, two bodyguards, and nine civilian bystanders are killed in the Gaza Strip when hit by Israeli Air Force Hellfire missiles.
source_pages: Ahmed_Yassin; Palestinians; Sunni_Islam; Hamas; Gaza_Strip; Israeli_Air_Force; AGM-114_Hellfire

event_text: HMS Scylla, a decommissioned Leander-class frigate, is sunk as an artificial reef off Cornwall, the first of its kind in Europe.
Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, and Slovenia join NATO as full members.
source_pages: Bulgaria; Estonia; Latvia; Lithuania; Romania; Slovakia; Slovenia; NATO; March_29

event_text: The Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat certifies Taipei 101 as the world's tallest building, based on the building having been topped out on 1 July 2003, even though the building was not completed until 31 December 2004.
Iraq War in Anbar Province: In Fallujah, Iraq, four American private military contractors working for Blackwater USA, are killed after being ambushed.
Google launches its Email service Gmail.
Islamist terrorists involved in the 11 March 2004 Madrid attacks attempt to bomb the Spanish high-speed train AVE near Madrid; the attack is thwarted.
Islamic terrorists involved in the 2004 Madrid train bombings are trapped by the police in their apartment and kill themselves.
Rolandas Paksas becomes the first president of Lithuania to be peacefully removed from office by impeachment.
The Nicoll Highway in Singapore collapsed, killing four workers.
Five suicide car bombers target police stations in and around Basra, killing 74 people and wounding 160.
The United States lifts economic sanctions imposed on Libya 18 years previously, as a reward for its cooperation in eliminating weapons of mass destruction.
The March for Women's Lives brings over one million protesters, mostly pro-choice, to Washington D.C. to protest the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act of 2003, and other restrictions on abortion.
CBS News releases evidence of the Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse. The photographs show rape and abuse from the American troops over Iraqi detainees.
The final Oldsmobile is built in Lansing, Michigan, ending 107 years of vehicle production.
U.S. media release graphic photos of American soldiers committing war crimes against Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison.
Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia join the European Union, celebrated at the residence of the Irish President in Dublin.
source_pages: Cyprus; Czech_Republic; Estonia; Hungary; Latvia; Lithuania; Malta; Poland; Slovakia; Slovenia; European_Union; President_of_Ireland; Dublin

event_text: The Yelwa massacre concludes. It began on 4 February 2004 when armed Muslims killed 78 Christians at Yelwa, Nigeria. In response, about 630 Muslims were killed by Christians on May 2.
The final episode of the television sitcom Friends was aired.
American businessman Nick Berg is beheaded by Islamist militants. The act is recorded on videotape and released on the Internet.
The Constitutional Court of South Korea overturns the impeachment of President Roh Moo-hyun.
Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark and Mary Donaldson are married at Copenhagen Cathedral.
Rico Linhas Aéreas Flight 4815 crashes into the Amazon rainforest during approach to Eduardo Gomes International Airport in Manaus, Brazil, killing 33 people.
Arsenal F.C. go an entire league campaign unbeaten in the English Premier League, joining Preston North End F.C. with the right to claim the title "The Invincibles".
The first legal same-sex marriages in the U.S. are performed in the state of Massachusetts.
The Iraqi Governing Council chooses Ayad Allawi, a longtime anti-Saddam Hussein exile, as prime minister of Iraq's interim government.
The National World War II Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C.
Oklahoma City bombing co-conspirator Terry Nichols is sentenced to 161 consecutive life terms without the possibility of parole.
Noël Mamère, Mayor of Bègles, celebrates marriage for two men for the first time in France.
The first Venus Transit in well over a century takes place, the previous one being in 1882.
Cassini–Huygens makes its closest flyby of the Saturn moon Phoebe.
SpaceShipOne becomes the first privately funded spaceplane to achieve spaceflight.
In New York, capital punishment is declared unconstitutional.
Iraq War: Sovereign power is handed to the interim government of Iraq by the Coalition Provisional Authority, ending the U.S.-led rule of that nation.
Saturn orbit insertion of Cassini–Huygens begins at 01:12 UTC and ends at 02:48 UTC.
The cornerstone of the Freedom Tower is laid on the World Trade Center site in New York City.
Greece beats Portugal in the UEFA Euro 2004 Final and becomes European Champion for first time in its history.
The first direct Indonesian presidential election is held.
The Senate Report on Iraqi WMD Intelligence is released by the United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, casting doubt on the rationale for the Iraq War.
Millennium Park, considered Chicago's first and most ambitious early 21st-century architectural project, is opened to the public by Mayor Richard M. Daley.
A supermarket fire kills 396 people and injures 500 others in Asunción, Paraguay.
The pedestal of the Statue of Liberty reopens after being closed since the September 11 attacks.
A tour bus belonging to the Dave Matthews Band dumps approximately 800 pounds of human waste onto a boat full of passengers.
One hundred fifty-six Congolese Tutsi refugees are massacred at the Gatumba refugee camp in Burundi.
The National Assembly of Serbia unanimously adopts new state symbols for Serbia: Bože pravde becomes the new anthem and the coat of arms is adopted for the whole country.
Google Inc. has its initial public offering on Nasdaq.
Versions of The Scream and Madonna, two paintings by Edvard Munch, are stolen at gunpoint from a museum in Oslo, Norway.
Ninety passengers die after two airliners explode after flying out of Domodedovo International Airport, near Moscow. The explosions are caused by suicide bombers from Chechnya.

The Beslan school siege begins when armed terrorists take schoolchildren and school staff hostage in North Ossetia, Russia; by the end of the siege, three days later, more than 385 people are dead (including hostages, other civilians, security personnel and terrorists).
Beslan school siege results in over 330 fatalities, including 186 children.
NASA's uncrewed spacecraft Genesis crash-lands when its parachute fails to open.
National Hockey League commissioner Gary Bettman announces lockout of the players' union and cessation of operations by the NHL head office.
Hurricane Ivan makes landfall in Gulf Shores, Alabama as a Category 3 hurricane.
Over 3,000 people die in Haiti after Hurricane Jeanne produces massive flooding and mudslides.
The asteroid 4179 Toutatis passes within four lunar distances of Earth.
Burt Rutan's Ansari SpaceShipOne performs a successful spaceflight, the first of two required to win the Ansari X Prize.
The first parkrun, then known as the Bushy Park Time Trial, takes place in Bushy Park, London, UK.
SpaceShipOne wins the Ansari X Prize for private spaceflight.
Three bombs explode at Taba and Nuweiba in the Sinai Peninsula, Egypt, killing 34.
MK Airlines Flight 1602 crashes during takeoff from Halifax Stanfield International Airport, killing all seven people on board.
Pinnacle Airlines Flight 3701 crashes in Jefferson City, Missouri. The two pilots (the aircraft's only occupants) are killed.
A fire that lasted over 15 hours destroyed almost one third of the East Tower of the Parque Central Urban Complex in Caracas, Venezuela.
Thirteen people are killed when Corporate Airlines Flight 5966 crashes in Adair County, Missouri, while on approach to Kirksville Regional Airport.
A powerful earthquake and its aftershocks hit Niigata Prefecture in northern Japan, killing 35 people, injuring 2,200, and leaving 85,000 homeless or evacuated.
Arsenal Football Club loses to Manchester United, ending a row of unbeaten matches at 49 matches, which is the record in the Premier League.
Rockstar Games releases Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas for the PlayStation 2 in North America, which sold 12 million units for the PS2, becoming the console's best-selling video game.

The Arabic-language news network Al Jazeera broadcasts an excerpt from a 2004 Osama bin Laden video in which the terrorist leader first admits direct responsibility for the September 11, 2001 attacks and references the 2004 U.S. presidential election.
An express train collides with a stationary car near the village of Ufton Nervet, England, killing seven and injuring 150.
Iraq War: The interim government of Iraq calls for a 60-day state of emergency as U.S. forces storm the insurgent stronghold of Fallujah.
Iraq War: More than 10,000 U.S. troops and a small number of Iraqi army units participate in a siege on the insurgent stronghold of Fallujah.
Firefox 1.0 is released.
New Zealand Tomb of the Unknown Warrior is dedicated at the National War Memorial, Wellington.
The Palestine Liberation Organization confirms the death of Yasser Arafat from unidentified causes. Mahmoud Abbas is elected chairman of the PLO minutes later.
Half-Life 2 is released, a game winning 39 Game of the Year awards and being cited as one of the best games ever made.
The worst brawl in NBA history results in several players being suspended. Several players and fans are charged with assault and battery.
The second round of the Ukrainian presidential election is held, giving rise to massive protests and controversy over the election's integrity.

Dominica is hit by the most destructive earthquake in its history. The northern half of the island sustains the most damage, especially the town of Portsmouth. In neighboring Guadeloupe, one person is killed.
The Paris Club agrees to write off 80% (up to $100 billion) of Iraq's external debt.
China Eastern Airlines Flight 5210 crashes after takeoff from Baotou Donghe Airport, killing 55.
The Orange Revolution begins in Ukraine, resulting from the presidential elections.
The Holy Trinity Cathedral of Tbilisi, the largest religious building in Georgia, is consecrated.
Ruzhou School massacre: A man stabs and kills eight people and seriously wounds another four in a school dormitory in Ruzhou, China.
The last Poʻouli (Black-faced honeycreeper) dies of avian malaria in the Maui Bird Conservation Center in Olinda, Hawaii, before it could breed, making the species in all probability extinct.
Pope John Paul II returns the relics of Saint John Chrysostom to the Eastern Orthodox Church.
Blackwater 61 crash: A CASA C-212 Aviocar crashes into the Koh-i-Baba mountain range in Afghanistan, killing six.
A McDonnell Douglas MD-82, operating as Lion Air Flight 538, overran the runway and crashed, killing 25 people.
The Cusco Declaration is signed in Cusco, Peru, establishing the South American Community of Nations.

Columbus nightclub shooting: Nathan Gale opens fire at the Alrosa Villa nightclub in Columbus, Ohio, killing former Pantera guitarist Dimebag Darrell and three others before being shot dead by a police officer.
The Millau Viaduct, the tallest bridge in the world, is formally inaugurated near Millau, France.

A gang of thieves steal £26.5 million worth of currency from the Donegall Square West headquarters of Northern Bank in Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom, one of the largest bank robberies in British history.
source_pages: Northern_Bank_robbery; Donegall_Square; Danske_Bank_(Northern_Ireland); Belfast; Northern_Ireland; Bank_robbery

event_text: Cave Story releases to the public.
Iraq War: A suicide bomber kills 22 at the forward operating base next to the main U.S. military airfield at Mosul, Iraq, the single deadliest suicide attack on American soldiers in Iraq.
The Cassini orbiter releases Huygens probe which successfully landed on Saturn's moon Titan on January 14, 2005.

The 9.1–9.3 Mw  Indian Ocean earthquake shakes northern Sumatra with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). One of the largest observed tsunamis, it affected coastal and partially mainland areas of Thailand, India, Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Malaysia, Myanmar, Bangladesh, and Indonesia; death toll is estimated at 227,898.
source_pages: 2004_Indian_Ocean_earthquake_and_tsunami; Sumatra; Modified_Mercalli_intensity_scale; Tsunami; Thailand; India; Sri_Lanka; Maldives; Malaysia; Myanmar; Bangladesh; Indonesia

event_text: Orange Revolution: The final run-off election in Ukraine is held under heavy international scrutiny.
Radiation from an explosion on the magnetar SGR 1806-20 reaches Earth. It is the brightest extrasolar event known to have been witnessed on the planet.
A fire in the República Cromagnon nightclub in Buenos Aires, Argentina, kills 194.
The official opening of Taipei 101, the tallest skyscraper at that time in the world, standing at a height of 509 metres (1,670 ft).
The dwarf planet Eris is discovered by Palomar Observatory-based astronomers, later motivating the International Astronomical Union (IAU) to define the term planet for the first time.
Edgar Ray Killen is indicted for the 1964 murders of Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner during the American Civil Rights Movement.
A train collision in Graniteville, South Carolina, United States, releases about 60 tons of chlorine gas.
The nuclear sub USS San Francisco collides at full speed with an undersea mountain south of Guam. One man is killed, but the sub surfaces and is repaired.
Mahmoud Abbas wins the election to succeed Yasser Arafat as President of the Palestinian National Authority, replacing interim president Rawhi Fattouh.
The Sudan People's Liberation Movement and the Government of Sudan sign the Comprehensive Peace Agreement to end the Second Sudanese Civil War.
Deep Impact launches from Cape Canaveral on a Delta II rocket.
ESA's SMART-1 lunar orbiter discovers elements such as calcium, aluminum, silicon, iron, and other surface elements on the Moon.
source_pages: European_Space_Agency; SMART-1; Calcium; Aluminium; Silicon; Iron

event_text: The Airbus A380, the world's largest commercial jet, is unveiled at a ceremony in Toulouse, France
In Belmopan, Belize, the unrest over the government's new taxes erupts into riots.
A stampede at the Mandhradevi temple in Maharashtra, India kills at least 258.
The first direct commercial flights from mainland China (from Guangzhou) to Taiwan since 1949 arrived in Taipei. Shortly afterwards, a China Airlines flight lands in Beijing.
source_pages: Mainland_China; Guangzhou; Taiwan; Taipei; China_Airlines; Beijing; January_29

event_text: King Gyanendra of Nepal carries out a coup d'état to capture the democracy, becoming Chairman of the Councils of ministers.
One hundred five people are killed when Kam Air Flight 904 crashes in the Pamir Mountains in Afghanistan.
In Beirut, 23 people, including former Prime Minister Rafic Hariri, are killed when the equivalent of around 1,000 kg of TNT is detonated while Hariri's motorcade drives through the city.
source_pages: Beirut; Prime_Minister_of_Lebanon; Rafic_Hariri; TNT; Motorcade; February_14

event_text: Seven people are killed and 151 wounded in a series of bombings by suspected al-Qaeda-linked militants that hit Makati, Davao City, and General Santos, all in the Philippines.
YouTube is launched by a group of college students, eventually becoming the largest video sharing website in the world and a main source for viral videos.
The Kyoto Protocol comes into force, following its ratification by Russia.
The National Hockey League cancels the entire 2004–05 regular season and playoffs.
Spain becomes the first country to vote in a referendum on ratification of the proposed Constitution of the European Union, passing it by a substantial margin, but on a low turnout.
The 6.4 Mw  Zarand earthquake shakes the Kerman province of Iran with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), leaving 612 people dead and 1,411 injured.
In Roper v. Simmons, the U.S. Supreme Court rules that the execution of juveniles found guilty of any crime is unconstitutional.

James Roszko murders four Royal Canadian Mounted Police constables during a drug bust at his property in Rochfort Bridge, Alberta, then commits suicide. This is the deadliest peace-time incident for the RCMP since 1885 and the North-West Rebellion.
Steve Fossett becomes the first person to fly an airplane non-stop around the world solo without refueling.

Margaret Wilson is elected as Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives, beginning a period lasting until August 23, 2006, where all the highest political offices (including Elizabeth II as Head of State), were occupied by women, making New Zealand the first country for this to occur.
Israel officially hands over Jericho to Palestinian control.
Around 200,000 to 300,000 Taiwanese demonstrate in Taipei in opposition to the Anti-Secession Law of  China.
An earthquake shakes northern Sumatra with a magnitude of 8.6 and killing over 1000 people.
The dwarf planet Makemake is discovered by a team led by astronomer Michael E. Brown at the Palomar Observatory.
Kurdish leader Jalal Talabani becomes Iraqi president; Shiite Arab Ibrahim al-Jaafari is named premier the next day.
First release of Git distributed version control system.
A solar eclipse occurs, visible over areas of the Pacific Ocean and Latin American countries such as Costa Rica, Panama, Colombia and Venezuela.
source_pages: Solar_eclipse_of_April_8,_2005; Pacific_Ocean; Costa_Rica; Panama; Colombia; Venezuela; April_8

event_text: The Oregon Supreme Court nullifies marriage licenses issued to same-sex couples a year earlier by Multnomah County.
Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger is elected to the papacy and becomes Pope Benedict XVI.
Japan's Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi apologizes for Japan's war record.
The first YouTube video, titled "Me at the zoo", was published by co-founder Jawed Karim.
Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger is inaugurated as the 265th Pope of the Catholic Church taking the name Pope Benedict XVI.
The final piece of the Obelisk of Axum is returned to Ethiopia after being stolen by the invading Italian army in 1937.
A seven-car commuter train derails and crashes into an apartment building near Amagasaki Station in Japan, killing 107, including the driver.
Bulgaria and Romania sign the Treaty of Accession 2005 to join the European Union.

Cedar Revolution: Under international pressure, Syria withdraws the last of its 14,000 troop military garrison in Lebanon, ending its 29-year military domination of that country (Syrian occupation of Lebanon).
Airbus A380 aircraft has its maiden test flight.
A hand grenade thrown by Vladimir Arutyunian lands about 20 m from U.S. President George W. Bush while he is giving a speech to a crowd in Tbilisi, Georgia, but it malfunctions and does not detonate.
source_pages: Grenade; Vladimir_Arutyunian; George_W._Bush; Tbilisi; Georgia_(country); May_10

event_text: Andijan uprising, Uzbekistan; Troops open fire on crowds of protestors after a prison break; at least 187 people were killed according to official estimates.
Kuwait permits women's suffrage in a 35–23 National Assembly vote.
A second photo from the Hubble Space Telescope confirms that Pluto has two additional moons, Nix and Hydra.
The tallest roller coaster in the world, Kingda Ka opens at Six Flags Great Adventure in Jackson Township, New Jersey.
France rejects the Constitution of the European Union in a national referendum.
Vanity Fair reveals that Mark Felt was "Deep Throat".
The Civic Forum of the Romanians of Covasna, Harghita and Mureș is founded.
The jury acquits pop singer Michael Jackson of his charges for allegedly sexually molesting a child in 1993.

Following a series of Michelin tire failures during the United States Grand Prix weekend at Indianapolis, and without an agreement being reached, 14 cars from seven teams in Michelin tires withdrew after completing the formation lap, leaving only six cars from three teams on Bridgestone tires to race.

Edgar Ray Killen, who had previously been unsuccessfully tried for the murders of James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Mickey Schwerner, is convicted of manslaughter 41 years afterwards (the case had been reopened in 2004).
American social news and discussion site Reddit is founded in Medford, Massachusetts by Steve Huffman and Alexis Ohanian.
The Live 8 benefit concerts takes place in the G8 states and in South Africa. More than 1,000 musicians perform and are broadcast on 182 television networks and 2,000 radio networks.
The Deep Impact collider hits the comet Tempel 1.
A series of four explosions occurs on London's transport system, killing 56 people, including four suicide bombers, and injuring over 700 others.
An Antonov An-24 crashes near Baney in Bioko Norte, Equatorial Guinea, killing 60 people.
The Civil Marriage Act legalizes same-sex marriage in Canada.
Four attempted bomb attacks by Islamist extremists disrupt part of London's public transport system.
Jean Charles de Menezes is killed by police as the hunt begins for the London Bombers responsible for the 7 July 2005 London bombings and the 21 July 2005 London bombings.
Three bombs explode in the Naama Bay area of Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, killing 88 people.
Space Shuttle program: STS-114 Mission: Launch of Discovery, NASA's first scheduled flight mission after the Columbia Disaster in 2003.
Mumbai, India receives 99.5cm of rain (39.17 inches) within 24 hours, resulting in floods killing over 5,000 people.
After an incident during STS-114, NASA grounds the Space Shuttle, pending an investigation of the continuing problem with the shedding of foam insulation from the external fuel tank.
The Provisional Irish Republican Army calls an end to its thirty-year-long armed campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland.
Astronomers announce their discovery of the dwarf planet Eris.
Air France Flight 358 lands at Toronto Pearson International Airport and runs off the runway, causing the plane to burst into flames, leaving 12 injuries and no fatalities.
President of Mauritania Maaouya Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya is overthrown in a military coup while attending the funeral of King Fahd in Saudi Arabia.
source_pages: List_of_heads_of_state_of_Mauritania; Maaouya_Ould_Sid'Ahmed_Taya; 2005_Mauritanian_coup_d'état; Coup_d'état; Fahd_of_Saudi_Arabia; Saudi_Arabia; August_3

event_text: Helios Airways Flight 522, en route from Larnaca, Cyprus to Prague, Czech Republic via Athens, crashes in the hills near Grammatiko, Greece, killing 121 passengers and crew.
Israel's unilateral disengagement plan to evict all Israelis from the Gaza Strip and from four settlements in the northern West Bank begins.
The Helsinki Agreement between the Free Aceh Movement and the Government of Indonesia was signed, ending almost three decades of fighting.
West Caribbean Airways Flight 708, a McDonnell Douglas MD-82, crashes in Machiques, Venezuela, killing all 160 people on board.
The first forced evacuation of settlers, as part of Israeli disengagement from Gaza, starts.
Over 500 bombs are set off by terrorists at 300 locations in 63 out of the 64 districts of Bangladesh.
A massive power blackout hits the Indonesian island of Java; affecting almost 100 million people, it is one of the largest and most widespread power outages in history.
The first-ever joint military exercise between Russia and China, called Peace Mission 2005 begins.
Hurricane Katrina makes landfall in Florida.
Hurricane Katrina devastates much of the U.S. Gulf Coast from Louisiana to the Florida Panhandle, killing up to 1,836 people and causing $125 billion in damage.
The 2005 Al-Aaimmah bridge stampede in Baghdad kills 953 people.
Mandala Airlines Flight 091 crashes after takeoff from Polonia International Airport in Medan, Indonesia, killing 149.
Egypt holds its first-ever multi-party presidential election.
Two Ilyushin Il-76 aircraft from EMERCOM land at a disaster aid staging area at Little Rock Air Force Base; the first time Russia has flown such a mission to North America.
Israeli–Palestinian conflict: the Israeli disengagement from Gaza is completed, leaving some 2,530 homes demolished.
The Camorra organized crime boss Paolo Di Lauro is arrested in Naples, Italy.
Hurricane Rita makes landfall in the United States, devastating portions of southwestern Louisiana and extreme southeastern Texas.
John Roberts is confirmed as Chief Justice of the United States.
Controversial drawings of Muhammad are printed in a Danish newspaper.
The 7.6 Mw  Kashmir earthquake leaves 86,000–87,351 people dead, 69,000–75,266 injured, and 2.8 million homeless.
The second Chinese human spaceflight, Shenzhou 6, is launched, carrying two cosmonauts in orbit for five days.
Saddam Hussein goes on trial in Baghdad for crimes against humanity.
Hurricane Wilma becomes the most intense Atlantic hurricane on record with a minimum pressure of 882 mb.
The general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) passes the Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions.
Images of the dwarf planet Eris are taken and subsequently used in documenting its discovery.
Tropical Storm Alpha forms in the Atlantic Basin, making the 2005 Atlantic hurricane season the most active Atlantic hurricane season until surpassed by the 2020 season.
Bellview Airlines Flight 210 crashes in Nigeria, killing all 117 people on board.
Hurricane Wilma makes landfall in Florida, resulting in 35 direct and 26 indirect fatalities and causing $20.6B USD in damage.
Bombings in Delhi, India kill 67 and injure over 200 people.
The rebuilt Dresden Frauenkirche (destroyed in the firebombing of Dresden during World War II) is reconsecrated after a thirteen-year rebuilding project.
The Venus Express mission of the European Space Agency is launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.
Suicide bombers attack three hotels in Amman, Jordan, killing at least 60 people.
Following a 31-year wait, Australia defeats Uruguay in a penalty shootout to qualify for the 2006 FIFA World Cup.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf is elected president of Liberia and becomes the first woman to lead an African country.
John Sentamu becomes the first black archbishop in the Church of England with his enthronement as the 97th Archbishop of York.
As a result of the merger of the Perm Oblast and the Komi-Permyak Autonomous Okrug, a new subject of the Russian Federation, the Perm Krai, was created.
source_pages: Perm_Oblast; Komi-Permyak_Autonomous_Okrug; Federal_subjects_of_Russia; Russia; Perm_Krai; December_1

event_text: XCOR Aerospace makes the first crewed rocket aircraft delivery of U.S. Mail in Kern County, California.
Tens of thousands of people in Hong Kong protest for democracy and call on the government to allow universal and equal suffrage.
The Civil Partnership Act comes into effect in the United Kingdom, and the first civil partnership is registered there.
The 6.8 Mw  Lake Tanganyika earthquake shakes the eastern provinces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme), killing six people.
An Iranian Air Force C-130 military transport aircraft crashes into a ten-floor apartment building in a residential area of Tehran, killing all 94 on board and 12 more on the ground.
Rigoberto Alpizar, a passenger on American Airlines Flight 924 who allegedly claimed to have a bomb, is shot and killed by a team of U.S. federal air marshals at Miami International Airport.
Sosoliso Airlines Flight 1145 crashes at Port Harcourt International Airport in Nigeria, killing 108 people.
The Buncefield Oil Depot catches fire in Hemel Hempstead, England.

Cronulla riots: Thousands of White Australians demonstrate against ethnic violence resulting in a riot against anyone thought to be Lebanese in Cronulla, New South Wales; these are followed up by retaliatory ethnic attacks on Cronulla.
Introduction of the Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor into USAF active service.
Anti-World Trade Organization protesters riot in Wan Chai, Hong Kong.
Jigme Singye Wangchuck abdicates the throne as King of Bhutan.
The Chadian Civil War begins when rebel groups, allegedly backed by neighbouring Sudan, launch an attack in Adré.
Chalk's Ocean Airways Flight 101 crashes into the Government Cut channel immediately after takeoff from Miami Seaplane Base, killing 20.
An Antonov An-140, Azerbaijan Airlines Flight 217 from Baku, Azerbaijan, to Aktau, Kazakhstan, heading across the Caspian Sea, crashes, killing 23 people.
source_pages: Antonov_An-140; Azerbaijan_Airlines_Flight_217; Baku; Azerbaijan; Aktau; Kazakhstan; Caspian_Sea; December_23

event_text: Chad–Sudan relations: Chad declares a state of belligerence against Sudan following a December 18 attack on Adré, which left about 100 people dead.
source_pages: Chad–Sudan_relations; Chad; Declaration_of_war; Sudan; December_18; Battle_of_Adré; December_24

event_text: Tropical Storm Zeta forms in the open Atlantic Ocean, tying the record for the latest tropical cyclone ever to form in the North Atlantic basin.
Ehud Olmert becomes acting Prime Minister of Israel after the incumbent, Ariel Sharon, suffers a second, apparently more serious stroke.
A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least 362 Muslim pilgrims.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf is sworn in as Liberia's new president. She becomes Africa's first female elected head of state.
A Slovak Air Force Antonov An-24 crashes near Hejce, Hungary, killing 42.
Evo Morales is inaugurated as President of Bolivia, becoming the country's first indigenous president.
Mexican professional wrestler Juana Barraza is arrested in connection with the serial killing of at least ten elderly women.
The roof of one of the buildings at the Katowice International Fair in Poland collapses due to the weight of snow, killing 65 and injuring more than 170 others.
The Goleta postal facility shootings occur, killing seven people before the perpetrator took her own life.
Stephen Harper becomes Prime Minister of Canada.
The last Mobile army surgical hospital (MASH) is decommissioned by the United States Army.
A massive mudslide occurs in Southern Leyte, Philippines; the official death toll is set at 1,126.
A methane explosion in a coal mine near Nueva Rosita, Mexico, kills 65 miners.

At approximately 6:44 a.m.  local Iraqi time, explosions occurred at the al-Askari Shrine in Samarra, Iraq. The attack on the shrine, one of the holiest sites in Shia Islam, caused the escalation of sectarian tensions in Iraq into a full-scale civil war.
source_pages: UTC+03:00; 2006_al-Askari_mosque_bombing; Al-Askari_Shrine; Samarra; Shia_Islam; Sectarian_violence_in_Iraq; Iraqi_civil_war_(2006–2008); February_22

event_text: The Securitas depot robbery was the UK's largest heist. Almost £53m (about $92.5 million or €78 million) was stolen from a Securitas depot in Tonbridge, Kent.
Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declares Proclamation 1017 placing the country in a state of emergency in attempt to subdue a possible military coup.
English-language Wikipedia reaches its one millionth article, Jordanhill railway station.

In Monterrey, Mexico, a man identified as Diego Santoy Riveroll committed a double murder against two children, followed by an attempted murder of his ex-partner, Erika. The incident is popularly known as the Cumbres case.
The terrorist organisation Lashkar-e-Taiba coordinates a series of bombings in Varanasi, India.
The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter arrives at Mars.
Michelle Bachelet is inaugurated as the first female president of Chile.
The 2006 Chadian coup d'état attempt ends in failure.
Operation Bringing Home the Goods: Israeli troops raid an American-supervised Palestinian prison in Jericho to capture six Palestinian prisoners, including PFLP chief Ahmad Sa'adat.
Over 150 Chadian soldiers are killed in eastern Chad by members of the rebel UFDC. The rebel movement sought to overthrow Chadian president Idriss Déby.
The social media site Twitter (now officially named X) is founded.
Three Christian Peacemaker Team (CPT) hostages are freed by British forces in Baghdad after 118 days of captivity and the murder of their colleague from the U.S., Tom Fox.
Capitol Hill massacre: A gunman kills six people before taking his own life at a party in Seattle's Capitol Hill neighborhood.

Protesters demanding a new election in Belarus, following the rigged 2006 Belarusian presidential election, clash with riot police. Opposition leader Aleksander Kozulin is among several protesters arrested.
At least one million union members, students and unemployed take to the streets in France in protest at the government's proposed First Employment Contract law.
Cyclone Glenda, one of the strongest tropical cyclones in the Australian region makes landfall near Onslow, Western Australia.
Serious Organised Crime Agency (SOCA) of the Government of the United Kingdom is enforced, but later merged into National Crime Agency on 7 October 2013.
Over 60 tornadoes break out in the United States; Tennessee is hardest hit with 29 people killed.
Iranian president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad announces Iran's claim to have successfully enriched uranium.
The United Front for Democratic Change's attack on the Chadian capital of N'Djamena is repelled by the Chadian army
source_pages: United_Front_for_Democratic_Change; Battle_of_N'Djamena_(2006); Chad; N'Djamena; Chadian_National_Army; April_13

event_text: Twin blasts triggered by crude bombs during Asr prayer in the Jama Masjid mosque in Delhi injure 13 people.
A Palestinian suicide bomber detonates an explosive device in a Tel Aviv restaurant, killing 11 people and injuring 70.
Bombings in the Egyptian resort city of Dahab kill 23 people and injure about 80.
Construction begins on the Freedom Tower (later renamed One World Trade Center) in New York City.
Armavia Flight 967 crashes into the Black Sea near Sochi International Airport in Sochi, Russia, killing 113 people.
The government of Sudan signs an accord with the Sudan Liberation Army.
Mass unrest by the Primeiro Comando da Capital begins in São Paulo (Brazil), leaving at least 150 dead.
Iranian Azeris interpret a cartoon published in an Iranian magazine as insulting, resulting in massive riots throughout the country.
São Paulo violence: Rebellions occur in several prisons in Brazil.
The aircraft carrier USS Oriskany is sunk in the Gulf of Mexico as an artificial reef.
The post Loktantra Andolan government passes a landmark bill curtailing the power of the monarchy and making Nepal a secular country.
The Republic of Montenegro holds a referendum proposing independence from the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro; 55% of Montenegrins vote for independence.
Alaskan stratovolcano Mount Cleveland erupts.
The 6.4 Mw  Yogyakarta earthquake shakes central Java with an MSK intensity of VIII (Damaging), leaving more than 5,700 dead and 37,000 injured.
The union of Serbia and Montenegro comes to an end with Montenegro's formal declaration of independence.
Serbia declares independence from the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro.
The first Kazakh space satellite, KazSat-1 is launched.
Pluto's newly discovered moons are officially named Nix and Hydra.
A Yeti Airlines de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter crashes at Jumla Airport in Nepal, killing nine people.
Mari Alkatiri, the first Prime Minister of East Timor, resigns after weeks of political unrest.
Hamdan v. Rumsfeld: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that President George W. Bush's plan to try Guantanamo Bay detainees in military tribunals violates U.S. and international law.
source_pages: Hamdan_v._Rumsfeld; Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States; George_W._Bush; Guantanamo_Bay_detention_camp; International_law; June_29

event_text: The first operation of Qinghai–Tibet Railway is conducted in China.

Space Shuttle program: Discovery launches STS-121 to the International Space Station. The event gained wide media attention as it was the only shuttle launch in the program's history to occur on the United States' Independence Day.
source_pages: Space_Shuttle_program; Space_Shuttle_Discovery; STS-121; International_Space_Station; Independence_Day_(United_States); July_4

event_text: North Korea tests four short-range missiles, one medium-range missile and a long-range Taepodong-2. The long-range Taepodong-2 reportedly fails in mid-air over the Sea of Japan.
The Nathu La pass between India and China, sealed during the Sino-Indian War, re-opens for trade after 44 years.
A shootout happens in Spiritwood, Canada, killing 2 Royal Canadian Mounted Police and wounding a 3rd officer.
One hundred and twenty-five people are killed when S7 Airlines Flight 778, an Airbus A310 passenger jet, veers off the runway while landing in wet conditions at Irkutsk Airport in Siberia.
Italy win their fourth World Cup title, defeating France 5–3 on penalties following a 1–1 draw after extra time.
A Pakistan International Airlines Fokker F27 Friendship crashes near Multan International Airport, killing all 45 people on board.
Mumbai train bombings: 209 people are killed in a series of bomb attacks in Mumbai, India.
The 2006 Lebanon War begins.
Twitter, later one of the largest social media platforms in the world, is launched.
The 7.7 Mw  Pangandaran tsunami earthquake severely affects the Indonesian island of Java, killing 668 people, and leaving more than 9,000 injured.
The world's longest running music show Top of the Pops is broadcast for the last time on BBC Two. The show had aired for 42 years.
An Israeli airstrike kills 28 Lebanese civilians, including 16 children.
Fidel Castro hands over power to his brother, Raúl.
A massacre is carried out by Sri Lankan government forces, killing 17 employees of the French INGO Action Against Hunger (known internationally as Action Contre la Faim, or ACF).

At least 21 suspected terrorists are arrested in the 2006 transatlantic aircraft plot that happened in the United Kingdom. The arrests are made in London, Birmingham, and High Wycombe in an overnight operation.
The oil tanker MT Solar 1 sinks off the coast of Guimaras and Negros Islands in the Philippines, causing the country's worst oil spill.

Lebanon War: A ceasefire takes effect three days after the United Nations Security Council's approval of United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701, formally ending hostilities between Lebanon and Israel.
Sri Lankan Civil War: Sixty-one schoolgirls killed in Chencholai bombing by Sri Lankan Air Force air strike.
Sri Lankan Civil War: Sri Lankan Tamil politician and former MP S. Sivamaharajah is shot dead at his home in Tellippalai.
Pulkovo Aviation Enterprise Flight 612 crashes near the Russian border over eastern Ukraine, killing all 170 people on board.
Grigori Perelman is awarded the Fields Medal for his proof of the Poincaré conjecture in mathematics but refuses to accept the medal.
Natascha Kampusch, who had been abducted at the age of ten, escapes from her captor Wolfgang Přiklopil, after eight years of captivity.
The International Astronomical Union (IAU) redefines the term "planet" such that Pluto is now considered a dwarf planet.
Former Prime Minister of Ukraine Pavlo Lazarenko is sentenced to nine years imprisonment for money laundering, wire fraud, and extortion.

Comair Flight 5191 crashes on takeoff from Blue Grass Airport in Lexington, Kentucky, bound for Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport in Atlanta. Of the passengers and crew, 49 of 50 are confirmed dead in the hours following the crash.
Edvard Munch's famous painting, The Scream, stolen on August 22, 2004, is recovered in a raid by Norwegian police.

Space Shuttle Program: Space Shuttle Atlantis is launched on STS-115 to resume assembling the International Space Station. It is the first ISS assembly mission after the Columbia disaster back in 2003.
Fourpeaked Mountain in Alaska erupts, marking the first eruption for the volcano in at least 10,000 years.

An audio tape of a private speech by Hungarian Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsány is leaked to the public, in which he confessed that his Hungarian Socialist Party had lied to win the 2006 election, sparking widespread protests across the country.
The Thai army stages a coup. The Constitution is revoked and martial law is declared.
Twenty-three people were killed in a maglev train collision in Lathen, Germany.
A Boeing 737 and an Embraer 600 collide in mid-air, killing 154 people and triggering a Brazilian aviation crisis.
Five Amish girls are murdered in a shooting at a school in Pennsylvania, United States.
WikiLeaks is launched.
North Korea conducts its first nuclear test.
The 6.7 Mw Kiholo Bay earthquake rocks Hawaii, causing property damage, injuries, landslides, power outages, and the closure of Honolulu International Airport.
A Panama Canal expansion proposal is approved by 77.8% of voters in a national referendum.
A funeral service takes place at the Bykivnia graves for Ukrainians who were killed by the Soviet secret police.
ADC Airlines Flight 053 crashes after takeoff from Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport in Abuja, Nigeria killing 96 people and injuring nine.

Saddam Hussein, the former president of Iraq, and his co-defendants Barzan Ibrahim al-Tikriti and Awad Hamed al-Bandar, are sentenced to death in the al-Dujail trial for their roles in the 1982 massacre of 148 Shia Muslims.
source_pages: Saddam_Hussein; Iraq; Barzan_Ibrahim_al-Tikriti; Awad_Hamed_al-Bandar; Trial_of_Saddam_Hussein; Dujail_massacre

event_text: Israeli-Palestinian conflict: The Israeli Defense Force kill 19 Palestinian civilians in their homes during the shelling of Beit Hanoun.
Sri Lankan Tamil politician Nadarajah Raviraj is assassinated in Colombo.

The National Museum of the Marine Corps in Quantico, Virginia is opened and dedicated by U.S. President George W. Bush, who announces that Marine Corporal Jason Dunham will posthumously receive the Medal of Honor.
Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II unveils the New Zealand War Memorial in London, United Kingdom, commemorating the loss of soldiers from the New Zealand Army and the British Army.
Al Jazeera English launches worldwide.
Anti-Syrian Lebanese politician and government minister Pierre Gemayel is assassinated in suburban Beirut.
A series of bombings kills at least 215 people and injures 257 others in Sadr City, making it the second deadliest sectarian attack since the beginning of the Iraq War in 2003.
The House of Commons of Canada approves a motion introduced by Prime Minister Stephen Harper recognizing the Québécois as a nation within Canada.
The law on same-sex marriage comes into force in South Africa, legalizing same-sex marriage for the first time on the African continent.
Six black youths assault a white teenager in Jena, Louisiana.
Commodore Frank Bainimarama overthrows the government in Fiji.
NASA reveals photographs taken by Mars Global Surveyor suggesting the presence of liquid water on Mars.
Space Shuttle program: Space Shuttle Discovery is launched on STS-116 carrying the P5 truss segment of the International Space Station.
source_pages: Space_Shuttle_program; Space_Shuttle_Discovery; STS-116; Integrated_Truss_Structure; International_Space_Station; December_9

event_text: The International Conference to Review the Global Vision of the Holocaust is opened in Tehran, Iran, by then-president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad; nations such as Israel and the United States express concern.

Felipe Calderón, the President of Mexico, launches a military-led offensive to put down the drug cartel violence in the state of Michoacán. This effort is often regarded as the first event in the Mexican Drug War.
The first of a series of floods strikes Malaysia. The death toll of all flooding is at least 118, with over 400,000 people displaced.
United Arab Emirates holds its first-ever elections.
Two earthquakes in Hengchun, Taiwan measuring 7.0 and 6.9 on the moment magnitude scale kill two and disrupt telecommunications across Asia.
War in Somalia: The militaries of Somalia's Transitional Federal Government and Ethiopian troops capture Mogadishu unopposed.
The UK settles its Anglo-American loan, post-WWII loan debt.
Madrid–Barajas Airport is bombed.
The Indonesian passenger ferry MV Senopati Nusantara sinks in a storm, resulting in at least 400 deaths.
Former President of Iraq Saddam Hussein is executed.
Bulgaria and Romania join the EU.
Adam Air Flight 574 breaks apart in mid-air and crashes near the Makassar Strait, Indonesia, killing all 102 people on board.
The 110th United States Congress convenes, electing Nancy Pelosi as the first female Speaker of the House in U.S. history.
Apple CEO Steve Jobs introduces the original iPhone at a Macworld keynote in San Francisco.
A general strike begins in Guinea in an attempt to get President Lansana Conté to resign.
Comet C/2006 P1 (McNaught), one of the brightest comets ever observed is at its zenith visible during the day.
The Doomsday Clock is set to five minutes to midnight in response to North Korea's nuclear testing.

The strongest storm in the United Kingdom in 17 years kills 14 people and Germany sees the worst storm since 1999 with 13 deaths. Cyclone Kyrill causes at least 44 deaths across 20 countries in Western Europe.
Turkish-Armenian journalist Hrant Dink is assassinated in front of his newspaper's Istanbul office by 17-year-old Turkish ultra-nationalist Ogün Samast.

Four-man Team N2i, using only skis and kites, completes a 1,093-mile (1,759 km) trek to reach the Antarctic pole of inaccessibility for the first time since 1965 and for the first time ever without mechanical assistance.
At least 88 people are killed when two car bombs explode in the Bab Al-Sharqi market in central Baghdad, Iraq.
Microsoft Corporation releases Windows Vista, a major release of the operating system Microsoft Windows and the NT based kernel.
Emergency officials in Boston mistakenly identified battery-powered LED placards depicting characters from Aqua Teen Hunger Force as Improvised explosive devices (IEDs), causing a panic.
The National Weather Service in the United States switches from the Fujita scale to the new Enhanced Fujita scale to measure the intensity and strength of tornadoes.
A Baghdad market bombing kills at least 135 people and injures a further 339.

Taiwan opposition leader Ma Ying-jeou resigns as the chairman of the Kuomintang party after being indicted on charges of embezzlement during his tenure as the mayor of Taipei; Ma also announces his candidacy for the 2008 presidential election.

A train derails on an evening express service near Grayrigg, Cumbria, England, killing one person and injuring 88. This results in hundreds of points being checked over the UK after a few similar accidents.
Japan launches its fourth spy satellite, stepping up its ability to monitor potential threats such as North Korea.

Chinese stock bubble of 2007: The Shanghai Stock Exchange falls 9%, the largest daily fall in ten years, following speculation about a crackdown on illegal share offerings and trading, and fears about accelerating inflation.
Tornadoes break out across the southern United States, killing at least 20 people, including eight at Enterprise High School.
Reform of the House of Lords: The British House of Commons votes to make the upper chamber, the House of Lords, 100% elected.
Garuda Indonesia Flight 200 crashes at Adisutjipto International Airport in the Special Region of Yogyakarta, Indonesia, killing 21 people.
The Nandigram violence in Nandigram, West Bengal, results in the deaths of at least 14 people.
Conventional-Train World Speed Record: A French TGV train on the LGV Est high speed line sets an official new world speed record of 574.8 km/h (159.6 m/s, 357.2 mph).
The cruise ship MS Sea Diamond strikes a volcanic reef near Nea Kameni and sinks the next day.  Two passengers were never recovered and are presumed dead.
Algiers bombings: Two bombings in Algiers kill 33 people and wound a further 222 others.
A suicide bomber penetrates the Green Zone and detonates in a cafeteria within a parliament building, killing Iraqi MP Mohammed Awad and wounding more than twenty other people.
Virginia Tech shooting: Seung-Hui Cho murders 32 people and injures 17 before committing suicide.
Johnson Space Center shooting: William Phillips barricades himself with a handgun in NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas before killing a male hostage and himself.
source_pages: Johnson_Space_Center_shooting; Handgun; NASA; Johnson_Space_Center; Houston; April_20

event_text: Boris Yeltsin's funeral: The first to be sanctioned by the Russian Orthodox Church for a head of state since the funeral of Emperor Alexander III in 1894.
Estonian authorities remove the Bronze Soldier, a Soviet Red Army war memorial in Tallinn, amid political controversy with Russia.
source_pages: Estonia; Bronze_Soldier_of_Tallinn; Soviet_Union; Red_Army; War_memorial; Tallinn

event_text: Israeli archaeologists discover the tomb of Herod the Great south of Jerusalem.
The three-year-old British girl Madeleine McCann disappears in Praia da Luz, Portugal, starting "the most heavily reported missing-person case in modern history".
Greensburg, Kansas is almost completely destroyed by the 2007 Greensburg tornado, a 1.7-mile wide EF5 tornado. It was the first-ever tornado to be rated as such with the new Enhanced Fujita scale.
Kenya Airways Flight 507 crashes after takeoff from Douala International Airport in Douala, Cameroon, killing all 114 aboard, making it the deadliest aircraft disaster in Cameroon.
Trains from North and South Korea cross the 38th Parallel in a test-run agreed by both governments. This is the first time that trains have crossed the Demilitarized Zone since 1953.
President of Romania Traian Băsescu survives an impeachment referendum and returns to office from suspension.
Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia, is hit by the State's worst storms and flooding in 30 years resulting in the death of nine people and the grounding of a trade ship, the MV Pasha Bulker.
Mudslides in Chittagong, Bangladesh, kill 130 people.
The Al Askari Mosque is bombed for a second time.
The Charleston Sofa Super Store fire happened in Charleston, South Carolina, killing nine firefighters.
The al-Khilani Mosque bombing in Baghdad leaves 78 people dead and another 218 injured.
The small town of Elie, Manitoba is hit by Canada’s most intense tornado on record.
PMTair Flight 241 crashes in the Dâmrei Mountains in Kampot Province, Cambodia, killing all 22 people on board.
Pope Benedict XVI reinstates the traditional laws of papal election in which a successful candidate must receive two-thirds of the votes.
Tony Blair resigns as British Prime Minister, a position he had held since 1997. Chancellor Gordon Brown succeeds him.
The Brazilian Military Police invades the favelas of Complexo do Alemão in an episode which is remembered as the Complexo do Alemão massacre.
Apple Inc. releases its first mobile phone, the iPhone.

A Jeep Cherokee filled with propane canisters drives into the entrance of Glasgow Airport, Scotland in a failed terrorist attack. This was linked to the 2007 London car bombs that had taken place the day before.
Smoking in England is banned in all public indoor spaces.
The first Live Earth benefit concert was held in 11 locations around the world.
Erden Eruç begins the first solo human-powered circumnavigation of the world.
U.S. Army Apache helicopters engage in airstrikes against armed insurgents in Baghdad, Iraq, where civilians are killed; footage from the cockpit is later leaked to the Internet.
An earthquake of magnitude 6.8 and 6.6 aftershock occurs off the Niigata coast of Japan killing eight people, injuring at least 800 and damaging a nuclear power plant.
TAM Airlines Flight 3054, an Airbus A320, crashes into a warehouse after landing too fast and missing the end of the São Paulo–Congonhas Airport runway, killing 199 people.
Pratibha Patil is sworn in as India's first female president.
Operation Banner, the presence of the British Army in Northern Ireland, and the longest-running British Army operation ever, comes to an end.
The I-35W Mississippi River bridge spanning the Mississippi River in Minneapolis, Minnesota, collapses during the evening rush hour, killing 13 people and injuring 145.
Former deputy director of the Chilean secret police Raúl Iturriaga is captured after having been on the run following a conviction for kidnapping.
NASA's Phoenix spacecraft is launched.
At AT&T Park, Barry Bonds hits his 756th career home run to surpass Hank Aaron's 33-year-old record.
An EF2 tornado touches down in Kings County and Richmond County, New York, the most powerful tornado in New York to date and the first in Brooklyn since 1889.
Space Shuttle program: STS-118 Mission: Endeavor takes off on a mission to the International Space Station.
Air Moorea Flight 1121 crashes after takeoff from Moorea Airport in French Polynesia, killing all 20 people on board.
The Kahtaniya bombings kill at least 500 people.
An 8.0-magnitude earthquake off the Pacific coast devastates Ica and various regions of Peru killing 514 and injuring 1,090.
China Airlines Flight 120 catches fire and explodes after landing at Naha Airport in Okinawa, Japan.
The Texas Rangers defeat the Baltimore Orioles 30–3, the most runs scored by a team in modern Major League Baseball history.
The skeletal remains of Russia's last royal family members Alexei Nikolaevich, Tsarevich of Russia, and his sister Grand Duchess Anastasia are discovered near Yekaterinburg, Russia.
Three terrorists suspected to be a part of Al-Qaeda are arrested in Germany after allegedly planning attacks on both the Frankfurt International airport and US military installations.
Israel executes the air strike Operation Orchard to destroy a nuclear reactor in Syria.
